movieName: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire
content:
What you have here is a very strong very good start of a sci fi story, I see many reviews bashing it - but most of them are hitting at the director - because for some reason they don't like him.......it's not the movie - it's their distain for the director - I guess (apart from mine) if the review focuses on the director - ignore it!
The reviews who focus on the story or the movie as a whole are very positive!!!!!! - so my advice - if you can understand this is the first half of a story and you don't wanna........for some reason hit at the director
Watch it - you will enjoy it
It's like dune mixed with seven samurai a sprinkling of star wars and king arther - if you like that stuff......
I watched it and loved it - I can't wait for the second half!
Remember if the review is bashing the director - however subtle - it's just their hate for him - not the movie!

movieName: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire
content:
As a photographer. The first thing I noticed was the radial blur filter laid over half the scenes. Things at the top and bottom of the screen are blurred out for no reason other than to draw attention to what they want you looking at. I couldn't even make it an hour into the film.
The battle scenes, while decently choreographed, were almost entirely bloodless. Stab someone? No blood. No hole. Shoot someone? No blood. No hole.
Gravity doesn't seem to exist. With a gas giant as your neighbor in the night sky you'd think that would effect all sorts of things including the physiology of the people, animals, plants, and tides.
I can't understand how someone could proof read this script and give it a seal of approval.

movieName: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire
content: Honestly, one of the worst films I've sat through in recent memory, If I hadn't been watching it with family, I'd have turned it off after 20 minutes. After the really bad opening exposition, we're greeted with some really good imagery that is ruined by the horrible creature design of just a Clydesdale horse with a piece of driftwood stuck to its head. But wait, it gets worse once the humans start acting.\nNo amount of Lens flare can hide the poor writing and bad acting of this movie, though Mr Snyder sure does try. It's almost like someone is making fun of him. The mishmash of cool imagery and stupid imagery just left me feeling confused; why are some shots really great, and others really bad and confusing? Why are some aliens cool, but some are just a horse with driftwood on its head?!\nThe writing is bad, the pacing is off, and the characters are so flat they disappear when turned sideways. Not even so-bad-it's-good, just plain bad.

movieName: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire
content: Overall, the VFX are excellent, especially some of the 3d character performances which are surprisingly good. The costuming and practical sets are excellent. The casting is perfectly good, the acting is good considering the appalling dialogue and story. Unfortunately the whole effort is spoiled by a complete lack of effort on the part of the writers. The "recruitment story" is soo completely contrived. ( dues ex machina?? ) the characters are brutally shoe-horned into the story with almost no effort to weave them in organically. I hate to be mean, but it feels like a 15 year old boy wrote the story and dialogue (and noone proof read it for him). Looking back on Jack Snyder's writing credits before this, there is a predicable string of woefully scripted movies (in terms of dialog), wonder woman, 300, justice league etc... Its a real shame if he had employed some skilled writers it could have been a really great sci-fi film. Such a shame, Jack u need to let go of writing, its just not your thing !!

movieName: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire
content: It's like Zack Snyder watched Battlefield Earth, and said hey I can make a sci-fi epic worse than that. If you grew up watching the kind of movies that eventually got turned into MST3K episodes, you might be able to finish it. Honestly if the Walking Dead had continued at it's same steady decline in quality this is like what season 38 would be. It is that bad.\nThose people who give it positive reviews are the people who dug their heels in arguing that Zack Snyder is a director who knows what he's doing. And after all those years they can't admit that they were wrong.\nThere is going to be a director's cut that fills in the major holes in the plot and story, but the damage is done. Watching it with vital information cut out of it for no reason, make it a confusing, jumbled mess of 1/2 ideas with poor execution. Not many will go back and watch what might be a comprehensible film when the longer cut is inevitably released.

movieName: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire
content:
I'll start with this: after you watch the teasers for this movie, lower your expectations. And then lower them some more.
I had high hopes for this movie given Zack Snyder's track record with action and superhero films but this one is out of his grasp. Just like the Star Wars franchise falls from grace, so does this strange ensemble of scenes that were slapped together to make this a so-called movie. At first glance, the casting is appealing but I'm not sure this movie did anyone any favors (aside from pushing them to get ripped so they at least look good on screen). The story and movie itself lacked depth and was overall just weak. It's almost like they sat in a room and said "so we've done 50 shades of Star Wars, Divergent, Game of Thrones, The Avengers, but what if we try to combine themes from each series and then pepper in some Fifth Element vibes?!" Also, the fight sequences were terrible. Don't get me wrong, I know it's all fiction, but the reaction time during fight scenes was so unbelievable and the major fight scenes were all borrowed from other movies.
I'm sure there is certain pressure to bring "the next best thing" to our screens when it comes to sci-fi/fantasy film and space opera but this ain't it. And it certainly doesn't make me eager to watch part 2. Zack Snyder needs to take a seat, sit back, and chill on this one.
Conclusion: go watch Dune. It has substance and depth, superior casting, better acting, and fantastic cinematography.

movieName: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire
content:
Great movie! Takes a lot of work and courage to bring a new Sci Fi hit.
Great villains, great heroes, and I can't wait to see the next one!
It reminds me of other movies like Star Wars, Avatar, Hunger Games, and superhero movies.
I think it's not an amazing movie, the universe has potential and no doubt it's entertaining.
I would have invested more time in the characters stories, but i think it's ok.
As said in the title, I dont understand the criteria to review this movie vs other ones from Marvel for example (which I love by the way) which have a much better score, and they are similar products.
The difference is that marvel is more popular, and this movie is bringing a whole new story.
Embrace new projects, new stories!

movieName: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire
content:
Magnificent 7, Star Wars, Matrix and Teletubbies. What were they thinking? Is no one in Hollywood
reading these childish scripts anymore? Those useless slow motion shots made film longer than it should be. Every TikTok and YouTuber have better cinematography than the crew who was responsible for this movie.
I mean Special Effects from the 70s, enemy's in old Nazi uniforms???? I really wanted to like this movie but after watching it for an hour I had to turn it off.
I'm glad that Disney hasn't used the script for an Star Wars movie because compared to this the Ryan Johnson has Oscar potential. Sequel? Directors cut? PLEASE NO!

movieName: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire
content:
This is truly amazingly bad.
I rate it 2 stars. One star for visuals and one for audio. Both are good to a certain point.
Where should I start with what's the bad? (There aren't any more good)
Oh, that could be a long list.
The plot, the acting, the screenplay is terrible
And who the hell decided it was a good idea to use Anthony Hopkins voice for a robot??? I love Anthony Hopkins, and his voice, but it's as far from an artificial voice as it gets.
Further more is the extremely exaggerated use of slow motion. Ohhh myyyy g......... ðŸ’¤
Seems like they watched the movie "300" and decided; "Hey! Slo-mo is cool! Let's use it to extend the movie length".
And the film feels slow motion from start til end.
The characters are boring, and it seems to me that the actors share this opinion. I can't find anything that resembles of great acting here. Sorry to say.
This is in fact some of the worst I've seen in quite a while.
Anything else is known from other movies. And they haven't even tried to hide the plagiarism.
One could start with Star Wars, Lord Of The Rings, 300, and several great movies, cooked up in a soup of anorectic nonsense
The story is a mess yet predictable and boring.
I think I'll just stop my review here.
WOW!!! This is a bad movie.

movieName: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire
content: I am a life long sci-go fan. From the masterpiece of 2001, to Gattica, Minority Report, Interstella, A. I, Automata, series like Peripheral captivated me. I have a tattoo that's an ode to Blade Runner, and my wife is also a huge sci-fi fan. We love to watch these works, and pause to discuss our observations, opinions and insights.\nWe TRIED to watch Rebel Moon. It's just... awful. We've all seen this film already, so formulaic it is.\nWe didn't pause once to talk, and after 20 minutes we both agree to stop. The only thing it's got it the spectacle of effects with mediocre acting. What is this is a film contributing to the art? I don't know. Might as well be written and created by ChatGPT.

6.5/10 (Recommend)
The "Lost Kingdom" is only marginally better than the first, and not even for the story. A lot of what I liked about this film had to do with the visuals and sound, but I was also happy with the character utilization and development that was offered.
There's a lot of flair going on when it comes to the fighting. It doesn't contain the most exhilarating fighting sequences, but it's enough to get my heart racing. While at times they're over the top in terms of what damage can be done to a superhero before they're exhausted. They're still entertaining and spread out enough throughout the film to keep me interested.
I loved the soundtrack that went along with the film. It truly enhances the film to greater heights. The intensity of what happens next. The pulsation of the next attack. All of it go hand in hand with the music.
Visually, this film is more toned down in terms of colour, but not in the vibrance or darkness when needed. With all the sea creatures that exist, the explosions that occur, and the unreal made real. This film does a perfect job in my eyes in maintaining the integrity of realism for things that are always easy to do, or are always skimmed over.
I enjoyed the character utilization and development compared to the first film especially for Patrick Wilson. I didn't like him in the first film, but with better screen time here I do. As a character you can't remove Mera because of the important role she has, but her screen time seems to be less.
The story isn't great, but it's not boring. Some aspects seem silly and others unnecessary, but it works out in the end. It's not as clear cut as I would like, but I can still follow what is being put down.
Overall, it's still worth checking out, but not in 3D. I know "Lost Kingdom" is getting a lot of mediocre reviews, but it's not the worse superhero movie ever. Good visuals, great music, and enjoyable character development are what has really drawn me in.
That's all for now. Thank you for taking the time to read my review. Until next time.... Enjoy the show!

The film through entertainting is confusing as most characters from the first film are reduced to NPCs trying to do overused cinematic tropes like Mera and Atlanna being just there as Aquaman's romantic interest and mother and Thomas Curry and Black Manta and Orm being ripoffs of Uncle Ben and Green Goblin from the Sam Raimi Spider-Man films with a few AI-generated lines and Topo being the cute animal character to sell merch. And despite Arthur narrating the events of the first film in the first seconds there is not much time for people who didn't watch it to know them and most of the sad moments feel fake and you can't really relate to the characters. It ripoffs Thor: The Dark World storyline and some entire sequences along with Star Wars and Lord Of The Rings.

Despite the fact, that this movie is the cotinuation of the first part, the first half hour seems to be relatively disoriented. Besides the narrative, that Aquaman has a family now and is a not so conventional king, there is not much exposition which introduce into the movie. The story is a standard fantasy plot, not really good, but not that bad. However, using the same antagonist from the first movie a second time feels uninspired and boring. All actors provide a good performance, especially Bateman and Momoa, who portray the unequal brothers, have a nice chemistry. Although the movie has its moments, for example the underwater world, it was boring overall.

This movie is epi & visually striking, it has everything. Majestic locations, menacing seabeast, terrifying mechina, black magic and Patrick Wilson. In the midst of all these amazing works, I can't believe James Wan allowed the first 5 minutes of stupid unfunny jokes about Sleepy king! I'm surprised he allows it, it doesn't like his kind of style in the first place. I wish it got cut in all version of releases.
If you can endure the first 5 minutes of cringe, the rest of the movie is wonderful.
I did wish for the brothers fight rematch and hope they let Amber in more fight scenes. It just feel natural that amber should be in many of those fight.
I hope they bring Patrick Wilson back to the new DCU.
Go watch this movie. Its great. Just come late so you issue the first 5 minutes:p.

If you like Star Wars Episode I then you will probably like this one. A lot of CGI but considering a majority of it is underwater you sort of expected it.\nThe story itself is quite qood and I enjoyed the storyline. What was annoying though which ruins the movie was this one liner jokes. I'm not sure if this was part of the script of Jason can't just tell a joke to save himself but it was pretty bad.\nThe thing is Randall who plays as the doctor for Mantra was heaps funnier and I don't think he's even trying to be funny. He didn't over play his character. Similarly, Yahya was brilliant as Mantra.

I gave this film what I consider to be a very generous rating of 3*. Yes the special effects were impressive and there were a few funny jokes but other than that the story was dull and confusing. They did try to help by having a narrator poke in every once and awhile but flow of the movie was rather disjointed. Several times I looked down on my phone to see the how much long I hand before this mess of a film was over. Look I like Jason but even Arnold is a better actor. Again while the special effects were good there was too much of it. OK this movie is turning over to be a flop just as the recent Ant Man flopped. Both I believe suffered from too much CGI. I feel that the reason that people are fatigued over these Super Hero movies that there's nothing new. Many parts of the script seems like a rip-off of Star Wars movie. Just a final thought, I had heard that Amber Heard was basically taken out of the movie but she is seen throughout the film.

Aquaman 2 is a very average watch ,it came as a big disappointment especially for me ,part 1 was so good that I had high expectations. Screenplay is so dull especially in the first half ,story is very bad the way it is written. Jason m as aquaman is brilliant but if there is nothing In the plot even he can't save the film.vfx looks bad in many places .end credit scene is so bad that it dosent give you any excitement.the movie starts off well in first 10 min but falls flat after that .some action scenes are good but apart from that the film has nothing new to offer .over aquaman2 ends up as a big disappointment.

I and my kids knew nothing going into this. I watched the Dawn of the Jusrice League and that was it. None of saw the first Aquanman. This was good - decent story, entertaining, funny, serious at parts sort of, and all around enjoyable. I never read the comics so I dont know if the story was the same or not - and I don't care. This wasn't a typical Marvel (reluctant hero, beaten by bad guy, hero gets help, beats bad guy) - somewhat like that but enjoyable. While I feel the age of superheroovies has past, this was a good stand alone film. And Dolph! And Martin Short? Those were good surprises and added to the film.

Today I watched Aquaman 2 and it was very stupid and kind of funny bad.
I loved the first Aquaman very much ironically and thought that movie was also very stupid dumb fun to me. It felt like James Wan and the crew really knew they had nothing to offer so they just did not care at all about what was happening in the film. They just did whatever they wanted and it came out to be a rather hilarious spectacle to me.
It's kind of hard to talk about the humongous stupidity in the movie without spoiling it but trust me when I say nothing feels like it's being taken seriously. The plot points all just feel thrown in from other things, the weirdest and most prevalent thing would be some things that feel directly from the World of Warcraft universe...???
The acting and delivery made me laugh a lot. It was bad across the board, but I didn't think Jason Mamoa or Patrick Wilson were bad. They seemed like he was trying along with Nicole Kidman though she wasn't in the movie much. Amber Heard and Randall Park were both very 1 dimensional and were unbelievable in every single scene they were in. Manta was very over the top and often made me laugh when he was on screen. It was stupid. Dolph Lundgren was TERRIBLE, every line he delivered was as if he was an amateur they picked up off the street, it did not seem like he wanted to be there.
The forced dramatic parts in this movie essentially border on parody. They did a low framerate slowdown during an incredibly overdramatic melodrama sequence that just came out of nowhere. It was very funny. I know a lot of people are having issues with this but given the tone of the entire movie (which was inconsistent by the way) it felt like a lot of this insanity was completely intentional. I'm not saying its not stupid, I'm saying I was busting up laughing in the theater.
I liked some of the fight scenes to be honest. Barring the first one which was actually very bad, basically it felt like this blue cgi mess and was just all the same color pigment, so it was just very hard to keep track of anything that is happening. The desert fight was not bad, I enjoyed the choreography in that scene and thought that was probably the best scene in the movie. Though there was a comical scene in that fight scene involving Patrick Wilson that I just couldn't deal with, it was so funny to me.
There were scenes in the movie that were intended to make you laugh that I like, actually intentionally unironically laughed at. I think they were a little low on the joke tierlist but this movie's jokes did tickle my fancy occasionally. I was definitely never bored watching this movie.
Overall most of this movie just made me laugh because of how stupid it was all the time. It felt like a video game so often. It felt like nobody cared about the seriousness of what they were doing, and it just feels like watching a ridiculoustrainwreck and personally I'm all for it. I find it incredibly engaging. If something very stupid and over the top does not interest you, probably stay away from this movie, as it really does not offer much outside that element.
Low 4/10 or High 3/10
PS. I know this may seem like a high score for how much I talked poorly about this film, but I again... I really cannot preface how much I had a great time watching this movie. I would much rather watch this DC film again over something like Wonderwoman 1984, The Marvels, Ant Man 3, Thor 2... ETC.

This movie is totally wrong. First minutes was absolutely boring. Actually this movie have a fun moments but it's have a cringe moments. We see a good idea movie but poorly executed. Jason Momoa was like in Fast X movie he actually play in Fast and Furious movie. Amber Heard was like 10 minutes screen time but it's good with her powers. Patrick Wilson was good , fun , very nice playing and very very good chemistry with Jason Momoa. Black Manta it's pleasure to see him i love this character. It's very good evil at DC end. I am waiting for James Gunn universe. But maybe we can see a better end for this movie. It's not bad!!!

This is a dark, depressing and psychopath movie. I am not surprised by many +ve reviews as these kind of movies are liked by a section of people. Just did not imagine so many people are in that section.\nSimply put in one sentence , this is a manifestation of a writers and directors sick, perverted , violent and dark mind, venting their inadequacies.\nI believe movies are meant for relaxation, entertainment and appreciation of art. This movie does just a little bit appreciation for art, Acting of Ranbir, Rashmika, Anil Kapoor and may be Sunny Deol too is very good. Nothing much else to take from this.

Entertained throughout the 3 hours duration time, Ranbir kapoor nailed every scene, in some scenes he reminded me of Rauf lala (played by Late Mr. Rishi kapoor) He just reminded everyone why he is considered the best actor of this generation. Powerful fight sequence with songs playing in the background was a masterpiece by Sandeep Reddy vanga. Don't pay any attention to the critics, they can't digest the audacity of Sandeep Reddy vanga, putting in simple words. Highly recommended if you like movies like kill bill, john vick and please don't miss the credit scenes, it's crazy. Bobby Deol with a short role gave a massive performance. Loved other cast members as well.

Perfect Direction, Brilliant Father son story, Great acting, Phenomenal movie.. A Must watch movie.
This type of movies should be promoted rather than those love stories made in Bollywood.
Amazing songs sung by B praak, sonu nigam specially that papa meri jaan song absolutely brilliant lyrics it has.
Great acting by ranbir kapoor till now, Action VFX is also amazing, Family love brothers everyone come together to defeat the enemy. Love should be in between mother and father rather than girlfriend wife.
To summarise i would say and appeal to continue making these type of movies that show love between mother and father.

I went in with zero expectations and sat through a 3.5 hour movie without touching my phone. The plot was truly refreshing. I am tired of seeing the classic heroic Bollywood movies where the hero can never be wrong. Vanga truly uncovers a beast.
Ranbir Kapoor is shown to be an "animal", with some signs showing in his childhood and teenage years but really unraveling in his adulthood after a major incident. From then on, what Ranbir does is beyond imaginable. Ranbir is not shown to be a hero - he does barbaric things, goes back on his words, and doesn't respect anyone in his life. Folks who are crying about Ranbir's role really think all movie heroes are to be admired.
Everyone's acting was phenomenal. Bobby Deol was GREAT, what a comeback. The interval sequence was a pleasure to watch, even though I am usually not a big fan of large action sequences. The music is great.
I just wish the second half was not as dragged. I am not a big fan of Tripti Dimri's sequence. It was unnecessary and only added for the sequel. It is also funny that there is no sign of a police offer or law enforcement throughout the movie despite all the violence. But overall this was a refreshing movie. Must watch!

This film is a cinematic triumph. Not made for the faint of heart or the easily offended breed. This is a case study of a psychotic man's psyche in its utmost illustrious portrayal. I can honestly say I have never seen a film like this before. Watch it and see it unfold for yourself while supporting novel cinema.
Ranbir Kapoor is a revelation and has outdone his previous resounding performances in rockstar, barfi, tamasha & such. The rest of the cast is brilliant as well, so is the music & cinematography as well,
Sandeep Reddy Vanga and the producers of the film deserve special adulation for their gutsy effort for pulling off such an immaculate movie.
Once again, sensitive babies stay away from this. Only if you have an appetite for seeing exceptional cinema pushed to its boundaries, check out this gem.

This is a slightly oddball film. The story is quite basic about two families who hate each other and the film has some very graphics scenes that you don't normally see in Bollywood films (not suitable for under 18s). So if you're expecting typical Bollywood fare then this film doesn't provide it and I understand the low ratings are probably being given for these reasons.\nHowever, the acting of the star cast is excellent. Ranbir puts in a powerhouse performance and absolutely nails every scene. He handles the action and psychotic scenes incredibly well. But Bobby Deol outshines even Ranbir with his shorter and more intense performance. It is without doubt the best acting performance of Bobby's career. His entry scene to the Jamal Jamaloo song is superb and he steals the show with his dance steps that leave a lasting impression, as well as his emotional and action scenes. The performance of all the other cast is also top notch. The film is also well mounted with brilliant technical aspects and production values. The film dares to be original and deliver something different rather than follow a tried and tested formula, and full kudos to Sandeep Reedy (Director & Producer) for attempting a new approach. For these reasons I give the film 10/10.

Very Good Movie. Need to watch this movie as a movie and not as a moral thing.
The Music and BGM is topclass
Ranbir Kapoor and Anil Kapoor's acting are standouts
Bobby Deol stole the show
Cool action scenes. The climax is epic
Don't miss the post credit scene.
Also for those who think ranbir is abusive and hits girls, in movie Rashmika slaps Ranbir and at the and she gives him divorce for his affair.
For me the best parts in movies were 1) Interval Action Scene 2)Bobby Deol's Entry 3) Ranbir Kapoor and Anil Kapoor scene at the climax (one of the best acting scenes) 4)Bobby VS Ranbir faceoff fight scene 5)
This movie is very different. Give it a chance.

It was a testosterone boosting movie for me. Fighting with cancer and this helped me in my treatment how to keep confidence in yourself and how to take treatments. It helped me mentally and made me stronger with all the action and story! I am having my Bone Marrow Transplant in coming days and will watch this again while having my chemos and BMT. This came at the right time.\nThe movie was spot on with story Ranbir was amazing throughout the RanVinay character was something all men want to be. Our papas are our heroes and we always want to give them back in whatever way we can! Amazingly exceptional!

Animal goes to the next level compared with Kabir Singh by SRV and yes this action packed thriller has at some moment extreme violence or bloodshed shown on screen but that goes with flow of character played by RK and well supported by storyline, editing and directing by SRV. Best part of watching this in IMAX theater is its background score which is embedded in each frame and action sequence. Soulful songs with fantastic music go very well with storyline moving forward in fast paced sequence. First half is just mind blowing with second half going deeper and revealing every character in a nuanced way.

Animal- The craziest and the most badass Indian movie that will ever be experienced by the audience on the screen so far since 110 years. Definitely falls under "The Cult" category.
The boldest director Sandeep Vanga Reddy takes us through the journey of a Son's possessiveness towards his Dad to the volcanic extreme, that he is just replacing love with vengeance, peace with war, gentleness with rage and saneness with madness.
Most of the scenes are original and never seen before.
Ranbir Kapoor stuns you with the most complex character, and your jaw will be dropped with shock and awe for his mind boggling acting along with various emotions stampede. He just tears open the cinema screen with his brilliance and ease, as he transforms from a raging teenager to animal man, and there is no stopping even with a meteor.
This marks him as the best actor of Indian cinema with a launchpad to reach the elites.
Having to match him is no easy feat but Rashmika Mandanna does it elegantly with stubbornness and guts.
Anil Kapoor is a class apart with his stature and maturity.
Bobby Deol is back with a bang. He delivers his career best performance although his screen presence is very short (a bit disappointing).
Tripti Dimra as Bhabi 2 was remarkable, I guess she was better than Rashmika. I want to see her back again in "ANIMAL PARK"
The story is uniquely presented with full heart and woven really well with astounding screenplay and terrific music.
Strictly for 18+ years. The alpha man kicks in, with no good social message. Pure violence, rampage and massacre in parts.
Wish some uncomfortable scenes were edited, and also movie duration trimmed (first part of second half) as its 3 hours 22 mins long.
Animal movie cracks open the movie industry with the boldness and crookedness, and roars loud.
A Must Watch!!!

movieName: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
content:
Reading the novel before the movie was the perfect choice! The movie honors Collin's captivating writing.
Knowing the world from the original series made the cinematic choices exciting, which speaks to the whole production team's thoughtfulness. The capitol's depiction is beyond what I pictured in my mind while reading.
Davis and Blyth kept me GLUED to the screen by their acting performances and on screen appearance - props to their makeup, hair, and wardrobe team!
Jason did a great Lucky in this serious movie - it is commendable to bring humor to a dystopian world!
I enjoyed going to the movies with my fellow Hunger Game fan friends (even though we really missed Peeta)! It brought back great memories!

movieName: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
content: If the hunger games was all about fascist myth making and how people just come to accept it as the new way of life, why would the protagonist be less angry 10 years into the new order than 75 years? When injustice is a new, people are supposed to be more angry, less accepting of it. Katniss was appropriately angry and defiant, whereas Lucy Gray was immediately giddy (i guess we are meant to interpret it as hippie freespirit i-love-all-peoples charm), and flirting with an agent of the state that has literally reaped her into an arena to kill her. Think of how much it would take to justify why a Jewish girl might even consider thinking of an SS soldier in a romantic light, and how little this story did to that end. The trust and romance between two characters from opposing sides of a fascist occupation has to OVERCOME that very tall barrier to earn any Rebel's trust. However even though the fact that Snow is doing it for personal gain was established, it was kind of ignored to continue this bizzare unearned romance.\nI am also okay with the premise that not every person in a fascist system is born evil, and showing the descent of a regular citizen into this kind of evil. However, living and participating every day in a fascist state has to impact your soul that ends up showing in small ways, casual dehuminisation of the Panem citizens, growing paranoia as the bombs start, disdain for the rebels etc. Which other characters in the academy and Grandma Snow does. But exceptionally, Snow was shown to be upstanding and moral throughout the movie except in the end with a abrupt descent into betraying his friend, all the while romancing a Panem citizen outside the district borders. It was so forced, and why?? We already knew that Snow would become evil, so why not show us how it happened in a believable manner (maybe show that his time as a peacekeeper interacting with D12 citizens allowed him to dehumanize them or something..), instead of rushing it as a "twist" at the very end of a very long movie? Every story in THG was a self contained plot that will be developed upon it, but this one felt like a botched incomplete story to that is built as a premise for sequels to the prequel.

movieName: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
content: I'm writing this review only because Jason Schwartzman deserves to be mentioned. In his role he is just brilliant, so thanks for at least his performance.\nThe casting for Snow was also not bad, but the rest of the actors can be forgotten. Above all, we couldn't stand the calling of 'Lucy Gray' after what felt like the 100th time.\nWe're generally not big fans of singing in movies, but these songs were placed so tactlessly that it felt like imitating a Disney film. The only suspenseful part is in the last section of the movie - precisely when it ends.! It seems like the whole movie is made for teenagers. Overexplained and repetitive scenes dominate. We're glad we didn't watch the film in the cinema.

movieName: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
content: It wasn't bad, but not half as good as the novel. Many things are left out, other things are portrayed differently. Considering that adapting such a complex story is really difficult, I think they did quite a good job. Pacing was too fast obviously, which isn't surprising, a running time of 158 minutes just isn't enough to cover the 500+ pages the right way. I really liked Peter Dinklage as Highbottom, he did a brilliant job imo. The portrayal of Snow and Lucy Gray's love story seemed rush and unfitting.\nYes, Rachel Zegler might not be the most likeable person, but I think it's stupid to review this movie based solely on how much you dislike Zegler. I highly recommend everyone to read the novel, doesn't matter if you enjoyed the movie or not.

movieName: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
content: Until the end I tried to understand what this movie was supposed to be about. Unfortunately the creators left that question open. The female main actress had no purpose other than singing, looking suspicious (with no reason eventually) and the main actor focused on staring into the void most of the time, making very very unlogical decisions and flipping his mind like a burger patty. Real disappointment and big waste of time. I thought till the end, there must be a conclusion, something connecting the dots. But they left the dots as they were. Far too long, no story, bad acting, boring. If you expect something like the originals, stay away. And if you happen to understand the story, let me know.

movieName: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
content:
From the first moment, this movie just offers more questions than answers or any kind of plot-thread.
And after around 15mins the movie-destroyer Snowwhite/Zegler appears and starts singing... really, no joke! Random people join in like its a flashmob or something and my fingers twitched to save my brain from this horses**t.
I gave it another 15min and then I really had to stop it. The CGI is just awful, explosions, animals, nothing makes sense. People burn and 2mins later they're like nothing happened.
My condolences to all other actors in this movie who might ruined their careers, be doomed to b-movie for the rest of their lives because of the "Zegler Musical".

movieName: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
content:
I have never seen a show that is this long, and yet this short. Events jump by too fast for any backstory to make sense. This movie jumps from one well detailed scene to the next, passing so quickly the events happening don't make sense.
This should have been a two parter, instead it was just disappointing. I love the idea of the plot and it had such potential, it is such a shame that all that potential was wasted.
The worst part of the show starts about half way through. We don't see any backstory, if we could have seen events going on over time, stuff he had to witness, stuff he did then his actions would make sense, but we don't get that. There is just too much missing for this movie to be good.
Its an awesome idea, and I really wish they had made it into 2 parts, but this finished product was just so disappointing to watch.

movieName: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
content: This movie goes on a bit too long and I feel like if you're not really into the Hunger Games series (like I never was as much as avid fans) then you're not going to care about this movie and it's not going to keep you wanting more. There are definitely some intense scenes and some good acting that made me pay attention a couple of times but I can pinpoint another major problem going on here. The main character of Lucy comes across as way too helpless/defenseless in too many scenes and relies way too much on luck or someone to save her to get her out of danger. She is less resourceful and strong than Katniss Everdeen was and it shows. I thought Hollywood cared about feminism?? This was not a good example.

movieName: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
content:
You can find a review on this everywhere else I will skip to what I felt could have been so interesting and was missed out on.
This story has always had deep themes around class warfare, dystopian government, mankind's ability to separate people and make Others Inhuman and able to be treated as cattle. So I think one big missed opportunity is with the plot around the Mentor Program and Corio Snow. Something that has always stuck with me are the servant master relationships we hear about during the American Slavery period. Famously, Thomas Jefferson had a very romantic time with one of his slaves. There should have been more about Lucy Gray, what does she really feel, does she feel grateful? Do they really fall in love or is she playing him? Yes there is that in the beginning but the movie never has the guts to say, these people are in a deep love for each other even though its a sick relationship with an extreme power imbalance. Perhaps they could show her having the power over a foolish Snow. She gets him to rig the games for her and yet has a soft spot for him by the end. Snow could be scandalized by being shown addicted to his "lesser human" girlfriend and therefore his cheating allegations and exile would impact him because he would be deeply grieving feeling that he would never see Lucy again. Lots of ways they could go with this.
Also there is just not enough done with the 1960s TV premise. What if this was the first Games in Color? People in The Capital would see the red blood of kids for the first time, would that make a difference on how Panem sees the kids? So many characters could bring you a deep feeling through their eyes of seeing all this awful trauma.
How Snow relates to the people on District 12 how it made him change The Hunger Games in how he did how it made him see the people of Panem as human beings and yet how he rationalized seeing himself as worthy of dominating and controlling them at the end, is stuff that can take the viewers on a ride of terror and imagination.
The premise, theme, storyline and dialogues of this movie in the right hands are Oscar winning. Too bad they failed on most execution. Another movie that could be life changing wasted in the Hollywood machine. At least it was watchable and had some cool world building so 5/10.

movieName: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
content: Sorry but the other 4 movies were wayyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy better. I fell asleep in the movie theater and was disappointed I didn't watch this online. Honestly it was boring and didn't keep me interested, although I tried hard. The other 4 movies had more essence, a better storyline, more attention to detail and a better understanding of the outlines of the games. The Spanish actress who played the girl who sang country music was not good. Her singing was the only thing that appealed. Viola Davis was just ok as the previous Elizabeth Banks. Not good enough. The Snow guy looked like Ryan Gosling, but overall this movies was not in any comparison of the previous. I hope they don't make a sequel, it's just doing harm.

Die Hard, released in 1988, is an explosive rollercoaster ride that sets the benchmark for action thrillers. From heart-pounding moments to unforgettable one-liners, this film is an adrenaline-fueled spectacle that keeps you on the edge of your seat throughout.
Bruce Willis delivers a career-defining performance as the iconic John McClane, a New York cop caught up in a terrorist takeover of a Los Angeles skyscraper during a Christmas party. Willis effortlessly blends vulnerability with sheer determination, making McClane a relatable and immensely likable protagonist. His quick wit and resourcefulness add an extra layer of charm to this character, making him a true action hero for the ages.
The film's pacing is impeccable, ensuring that there is never a dull moment. The tension builds gradually, as McClane finds himself outnumbered and outgunned against the ruthless terrorist leader, Hans Gruber, portrayed masterfully by the late Alan Rickman in his breakout role. Rickman's portrayal is chilling, as he exudes intelligence and sophistication while remaining utterly menacing.
Die Hard's screenplay is expertly crafted, with sharp dialogue and a well-structured plot that keeps you engaged from start to finish. The action set-pieces are jaw-dropping, with director John McTiernan's meticulous attention to detail evident in every explosive sequence. The film's iconic moments, such as McClane's daring leap off the Nakatomi Plaza rooftop or his brutal cat-and-mouse encounter with Gruber, have become legendary within the genre.
The supporting cast also shines, with standout performances from Bonnie Bedelia as McClane's estranged wife Holly, Reginald VelJohnson as the sympathetic Sergeant Al Powell, and Alexander Godunov as the formidable henchman Karl. Each actor brings depth and nuance to their characters, elevating the overall quality of the film.
While Die Hard may be over three decades old, its impact on the action genre remains unparalleled. Its influence can be seen in countless films that followed, making it a true game-changer in the industry. The film's ability to blend intense action with genuine emotional stakes is a testament to its enduring appeal.
In conclusion, Die Hard is a classic that continues to entertain and captivate audiences to this day. Its stellar performances, thrilling action, and well-crafted screenplay make it a must-watch for any fan of the genre. With its unforgettable characters and iconic moments, Die Hard has solidified its place in cinematic history. The chemistry between Bruce Willis and Alan Rickman is electric, creating a dynamic cat-and-mouse game that keeps you hooked until the very end.

A friend rented out a theater the week before Christmas for a big screen viewing of this holiday classic (I dressed up like a minor character Uli) and it was fantastic to get to see this on the big screen once again and with an audience, which I hadn't experienced since high school when I saw it in the theater with my dad back when the movie first came out. The crowd was filled with quite a few twenty-somethings who'd never seen the film before (which seems unbelievable to this old Gen-Xer) but that made it even more fun to experience the film with an audience laughing and reacting to all the right parts in this almost 40-year-old movie! Everyone laughed at Theo and Karl betting in the background whether Mr. Takagi could give up the computer passcode or when Asian terrorist Uli takes a candy bar out of the display case. You could feel the audience squirm as John McClane pulled glass out of his feet. They laughed at all the right parts and cheered at all the right moments. It reminded me of how movies are best enjoyed as a communal experience. When DIE HARD first came out, everyone rolled their eyes at Bruce Willis being an action hero. Up until that point, action heroes were musclebound unstoppable he-men along the lines of Stallone and Schwarzenegger. Sure there were some non-musclebound ones too, like Clint Eastwood or Harrison Ford, but they were certainly not comedians, which is what Bruce Willis was primarily known for at this time. Before DIE HARD, he was really only known for the hit TV series MOONLIGHTING (if you haven't seen it, it's on Hulu right now) and one Blake Edwards comedy (which wasn't a box office hit). The studio originally offered the part of McClane to Stallone and Schwarzenegger, but the film is a classic because of Willis. He made McClane a vulnerable character, who does get hurt and who could be killed. Willis eventually became an unstoppable action hero like Sly and Arnold, which may be lost on audiences watching this film for the first time now, but back then, Willis was just that goofy guy from TV trying the best he could to save people from bad guys.\nBut I haven't said anything about DIE HARD itself. Everyone knows the story, so I won't summarize it here, but if you somehow have never seen it before, stop what you're doing right now and watch it! Bruce Willis is effortlessly funny, vulnerable, and heroic all at the same time, which is a nice contrast to most action heroes of the 80s who would only wisecrack one-liners and would never dare to be self-deprecating. Though as great as Willis is, Alan Rickman steals every scene he's in as lead bad guy Hans Gruber. He gets some great lines and character touches from the script, like complimenting Mr. Takagi on his suit or when he pretends to be a hostage, but it's Rickman's refined air that elevates the film. The class Rickman brings to his character is a fun contrast to Willis' blue-collar hero. And what a killer supporting cast, that includes Reginald VelJohnson as Sgt. Al Powell, Paul Gleason playing another jerk, this time the clueless Deputy Police Commissioner, William Atherton as a nasty TV reporter, Hart Bochner as a coke-snorting executive, Alexander Gudunov as terrorist Karl, the great Al Leong (you've seen him in just about every iconic 80s action film), Robert Davi & Grand L. Bush as Agents Johnson and Johnson, and De'voreaux White as Argyle, who I don't remember from anything else, but who was apparently in THE BLUES BROTHERS and TRESPASS when I looked him up on IMDB. DIE HARD is a a witty and clever script from Steven E. De Souza and Jeb Stuart, who both mostly write passable dreck unless their films were made by solid directors like Walter Hill (48HRS), Andrew Davis (THE FUGITIVE), or John McTiernan here with DIE HARD, so I'm giving McTiernan credit to making this film what it is. Credit also has to go to ace cinematographer Jan de Bont, who shot such classics as BLACK RAIN, THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, and BASIC INSTINCT, and would later go on to direct himself, with SPEED being his one standout film. Top it all off with a memorable score by 80s mainstay composter Michael Kaman (LETHAL WEAPON, THE DEAD ZONE, ADVENTURES IN BABYSITTING, HIGHLANDER, BRAZIL, etc.) and you have the makings for a classic. Overall, DIE HARD is an absolute 80s action classic, and yes, DIE HARD is a Christmas movie!

Die hard is known to be one of the most iconic and revolutionary action movies ever, which is certainly true. It revolutionised the action genre as a whole. And it was a pretty well made action movie at that. It definitely wasn't the flawless movie that everyone makes it out to be.\nAlan Rickman as Hans grubber Is a phenomenal preformance and deserves to go down as one of the best villian preformance. However I can't say Bruce Willis gave that great a preformance. I believe as a result started the whole genre of average action movies with lackluster acting. Was a good movie but nothing special. 8/10.

This is a classic action movie that I have watch and is enjoyable. I do like how it's about a cop have to go against a terrorist group in a skyscraper. The movie is build up really well by introducing each of the characters and who they are. I really enjoyed each of the characters like John McClane, Al Powell, and Argyle who have fun personality to them and have development. Also, the acting is done really well by each of the actors and it looks like they have a fun time in the movie. The villains are also pretty great with them being threating and the performance by each one of them.\nThe action are both enjoyable and suspenseful with John fighting against the villain and him trying to survive in the movie. He comes up with a lot of good ideas in order to survive and is pretty smart throughout. It also gets thrilling when the explosion happened and it looks great.\nOverall its a fun movie to watch on Christmas.

Die Hard is the perfect late 80's action film with great villains, plenty of action, and solid dialogue from our hero. It's everything you want in a Summer action flick even though Die Hard gets the debate that it's actually a Christmas film. Make no mistake this is not a Christmas film but an action film set during Christmas. There should be no debate on this but every Christmas it comes up. Die Hard was the launching pad for making Bruce Willis the action star that he became. In fact I miss action films like this that had plenty of action scenes and explosions that were practical. In todays World we get plenty of CGI fight scenes and over the top action. Die Hard is an action classic from the 80's and gets a very high 9 stars out of 10 from me.

"Die Hard" is perhaps the quintessential action film for the Christmas season. Where most Christmas films had opted for the predictably warm and fuzzy, and still often do; director John McTiernan had introduced a landmark infusion of action to the monotone Christmas genre, whilst still managing to keep the Christmas spirit well intact, in its own way. It's become a household classic ever since and conveys the importance of fighting against all odds, even when others doubt you. And that situations are felt most clearly by those with their feet firmly planted on the ground; John McClane's barefooted ordeals reflect this message. It's a celebration of the streetwise and the grounded underdog.\nBruce Willis's breakout role as the irreverent and muscled NYPD copper John McClane was eminently career-defining, and quite possibly one of the most strikingly masculine chainsmoking protagonists of film history. A triangle of witty repartees between McClane, Sgt. Al Powell (Reginald VelJohnson), and Alan Rickman's flamboyant classically-educated West German villain, Hans Gruber, creates both tension and levity at the film's close-quarters setting, Nakatomi Plaza; as a high-octane game of cat-and-mouse unfolds. You'll also be graced by one of the most iconic one-liner catchphrases; "Yippee-ki-yay..." part of cinema lore's lexicon, and for which no caption is needed for further explanation. However a reviewer at the time of release had backhandedly suggested it as a "nearly perfect movie for our time", yet designed to appeal to audiences they'd described as "kidults"-adults with the mindset of children. Nonetheless, McTiernan masterfully combines brains, heart, and brawn in thrillingly explosive action sequences and soulful character development whilst not granting any character the privileges of infallibility or invulnerability. The film combines three subplots to form the overall plot meaning there's plenty going on at any one time and a lot of reasons to stay invested in this film for its full runtime, and to prompt repeat viewings. Deemed "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant" by the United States Library of Congress, Die Hard was selected for preservation in the National Film Registry in 2017. An all-round blast.\n8.1/10.

After watching this film with my family of four; my Mum, Dad, Brother Jordy & me for the first time on Christmas Eve here's my spoiler-free review of the original Die Hard! As usual, I'll be talking about my thoughts, my favourite moments of watching it and my Conclusion/rating! Bruce Willis stars in this action thriller that still holds up 35 years later, this was Alan Rickman's first movie he played the bad guy Hans Gruber we still miss the beloved actor to this day R. I. P. The action scenes & special effects are so cool and entertaining, even though this film was set during Christmas time it's not a Christmas movie it was released in Australia back on October 6! Overall It's going to be very interesting to watch the other 3 Die Hard sequels I don't think I'll watch Die Hard 5 but I look forward to it! That's why I'm giving this an 8/10! I enjoyed this so much that I'm excited to see the next films! Merry Christmas everyone! ;-)

Action, check. Christmas themes, check. Realistic action hero, check. Man, if it wasn't for Die Hard, action movies would have never evolved. It's the best Christmas and action movie ever. It never gets old and it still lives up to it's hype after all these years.\nSo if you want a fun, action packed movie that brings action on ever level then give this movie your undivided attention. And of course, it provides you with one of the most iconic villains in film history. The late Alan Rickman delivers one of the best and iconic roles as the main villain.\nWith much humor, Christmas level excitement and some of the most iconic quotes movie lines in history, Die Hard brings it. And brings it hard..

FILM: 10/10.
Die Hard, a film that needs no introduction, is one of those rare action gems that effortlessly earns top marks in my book. From characters to performances, it's a cinematic masterpiece.
Bruce Willis is an absolute blast, seamlessly blending action and comedy while embodying the everyman charm of his character. His improvised wisecracks hit the mark, adding an authentic layer of humour that elevates the film to legendary status.
Alan Rickman, the epitome of class, crafts a three-dimensional action movie villain, a worthy adversary to Willis. Not to be overshadowed, Reginald VelJohnson owns his role with confidence, delivering classic lines that linger long after the credits roll.
While Bonnie Bedelia has her moments, she's somewhat underutilised in this ensemble cast. Yet, the film's template for crafting a thrilling, smart, and endlessly entertaining action flick is unparalleled, inspiring countless imitators over three decades.
Action and drama are seamlessly woven together, hitting all the right beats. The film's quotability is off the charts, a testament to razor-sharp writing and John McTiernan's directorial finesse.
From start to finish, not a single misstep occurs. The cast and crew flawlessly deliver this bonafide classic, making its healthy runtime breeze by. Die Hard is the Christmas movie that never fails to grace my screen each year, marking the true start of the festive season. Now that Hans Gruber has had his fall, Christmas can officially begin, and the tradition of revisiting this cinematic masterpiece continues unabated. A true classic that's more than earned its place in the action movie hall of fame - and in my heart.

The 80s was peak time for action movies and action movie stars. Die Hard is certainly on of the greatest 80s action movies, possibly one of the greatest ever action movies, definitely the greatest Christmas movie and perhaps one of the greatest movies ever made.
It's a movie about love, friendship, brotherhood, forgiveness, reconciliation and enough C4 to warp Arnold Schwarzenegger.
There's Rudolph and Frostie, mulled wine and a nice aged Brie, Christmas music and presents galore.
One present is the surprise gift of Bruce Willis as an action star. Bit of a gamble at the time and it worked out as wonderfully as a home baked mince pie.
Another gift was the sight of Alan Rickman making his big screen debut and absolutely smashing out the greatest villain in Hollywood history.
The dialogue is quotable, the action terrific, the characters are either likeable or detestable exactly as they're supposed to be and I absolutely defy anyone to watch Die Hard and not try to walk around on the rug, barefoot and make fists with your toes.
Anyone who says this isn't a Christmas movie is like the product of an unholy union of Ebeneezer Scrooge and the grinch.
Beyond the obvious Christmas themes this movie was way ahead of its time in exploring capitalism, the media and US foreign policy and its more of a Christmas tradition in my house than Turkey.

Too much waste of time for the projection for the hero. And he does almost nothing great. 1st half was good created lot of curiosity but 2nd part falls flat. No story revealed, seems like Director wanted to drag it more longer than TV serials like a chewing gum.\nWas expecting a lot from secong half, but alas . Throughout the movie you get reminded of KGf because of the same type of screen play , kids talking about the hero and group trying to entice him . Even the music feels like the same at some parts.\nIt's better to avoid it in theatres and watch it in OTT as there is nothing so special in the this part.

So I Finally Watched One Of The Most Anticipated Movie 'Salaar' Starring REBEL STAR Prabhas,Prithviraj Sukuruman In Main Leads Written And Directed By Prashant Neel.
So If You Ask Me To Define My Experience In One Line It's One Man Show Prabhas Show,With A Perfect Neel's Elevating Screenplay. So Coming To The Plot A Gang Leader Tries To Keep A Promise Made To His Dying Friend And Takes On The Other Criminal Gangs.
So Going In Detail,The Film's First Half Was Fast,Engaging With Racy Screenplay And Ends With A Bang Interval And In Second Half,Film Enters Into Main Conflict Which Is World Building,Establishing The Characters Of 'KHANSAAR' And Its Politics,And With A Powerful Climax With A Big Reveal.
So Coming To Performances,As Said Its One Man Show,Prabhas's Show. He Just Killed With His Screen Presence,'DEVA' A Character Which Will Be Registered In Masses For A Long Time,A Character Which Brings Out The Prabhas That Was Eagerly Urged By Everyone.
Coming To Prithviraj Sukumaran He Was Phenomenal In His Role,Playing 'Vardaraja Mannar' The Emotional Balance Carried Throughout The Film By Him Was Brilliant. And Film Has A Huge Supporting Cast Everyone Were Fit To Their Roles And Delivered Great. Shruthi Hassan Doesn't Have A Huge Scope In Her Character,May Be She Will Be Used In Next Venture.
Coming To The Technicalities,Hand's Down The Best Thing About The Film Was Its Action Blocks,They Were Just Adrenaline Pumping And Whistle Worthy One's Which Was Smoothly Delivered By Prabhas,Undoubtedly 'Katteramma' Sequence Is My Most Favourite Thing In Whole Movie,It Was Just Epic. Music By Ravi Basur Was Good
Especially During Action Sequences,But Does Not Leave Heavy Impact As 'KGF'. CameraWork Was Asusual Great. I Should Seriously Appericiate Production Values Of The Film,It Drags You Into The City Of Khansaar. Editing Was Ok,Screenplay Feels Little Bit Dragged Out In The Second Half Of The Film.
Coming To The Writer And Director Prashant Neel He Really Succeeded In Showcasing The World Of Khansaar And Character's Motives. But Somewhat Felt Missing In His Writing During Drama. But Again He Should Be Appreciated For Showcasing Friendship,And Bringing Out Character 'DEVA' In His Signature Style.
At Last Salaar Is A Action Drama Where Prabhas's Stands Out To Be The Back Bone Of The Film. The Action Block's,Prabhas's Screen Presence,World Building Of Khansaar Make's This One A Worth Watch. Which Create's A Curiosity For The Next Part. Finally A Much Needeed Comeback Delivered By REBEL...

Personal Thoughts: If you aren't too nit-picky or judgemental of the movies you watch, it'd be easy to enjoy Salaar. The beginning was a bit shaky and had the audience rightfully confused for the first hour or so, just waiting anxiously for answers, but the answers themselves more than made up for all of it. And don't get me wrong: being confused doesn't equal couldn't enjoy. I still found the beginning fun to watch, but I liked it a lot more when things started to piece together. What really brought me in was the dynamic between Vardha and Deva, which I won't talk too much about to avoid spoiling anything. From the eyes of someone who absolutely loved KGF 1 & 2, I say this movie wasn't a disappointment in the slightest. At the very least, it has me looking forward to the next part. The acting, story, and characters made this a great watch. Definitely one of the best movies made in 2023, despite it's rocky start.\nIn summary, if you love action-packed movies that feature loyalty in its realest sense and have a main character that's easy to adore, a movie that's filled with emotion and suspense, a movie that's close to three hours yet has you wanting more at the end, Salaar might just fit your description. Again, I'm not too picky about my entertainment, but I can tell when a movie's not good, and judging by this review, you already know what I think of Salaar P1 (it's been a while since I've seen a movie that had me this drawn in). Can't wait for part two!

Salaar delivers a typical South Indian movie experience with intense action, a powerful hero, and a compelling storyline. Prabhas commands the screen effortlessly, complemented by Shruti Hassan's impressive contribution.
The film's action sequences are a standout. The storyline, while sharing similarities with the successful KGF, introduces its own unique twists and turns, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats.
In essence, Salaar is not just a film; it's an immersive journey into the heart of South Indian cinema, where larger-than-life characters, compelling storytelling, and jaw-dropping action converge.
Salaar part-1 seems to set the stage for an exciting second part, making it a must-watch for fans of the genre.

I'm not sure why a few people are so hellbent on giving poor ratings for this movie! Salaar is one of the best action movies I have ever seen in 2023.
Though the stroy is lengthy & the director did spend much time on providing elevations to our hero whenever he got a chance, I still felt that they were kind of good & some of them were on point. I hope we will get to see more from Prithvi & other important characters in the second part.
It's definitely a feast for Prabhas's fans & I think he did his best for this role.
It's a good story with a few twits, definitely worthy of our time! I'll be waiting for second part!

This is a superb tollywood action movie and don't understand why anyone should judge it from any other lense. Prashanth Neel goes one step further than KGF. Simply loved Prabhaas. Especially after the Adipurush fiasco. This is his home ground and he should stick to it. Really liked how the fictional city of Khansaar is created with lots of adrenaline pumping scenes. Compared to KGF, the plot and storyine is given more attention. Characters apart from the lead(Salaar), have been carefully casted. Each one is equally important and does justice to his part. Towards the end, they have done an excellent job at creating a premise for Salaar part 2. Eagerly waiting for it. If you liked KGF/Leo/Vikram, then there are high chances that you will like this one too. Go for it.

If you really want to enjoy this movie , then forget about KGF or any of the old references like Uppgramm whatever. Just focus on the story which has a lot to offer specially with the flow of events and twists in the end.\nIf you thought this movie was bad, its probably because you had way too high expectations. I read multiple reviews where people mentioned about the heroes using knives , swords etc. Instead of guns.\nFor godsake , its a South Indian movie which usually has over the top action scenes with knives and swords and that was clearly evident from the trailer - its not a surprise package in the theatre for people to be disappointed about action scenes - if you have problems with over the top scenes , just don't waste your money watching it in theatre - BUT IF YOU HAVE AN OPEN MIND WITH ZERO BIAS , THIS MOVIE WILL ENTERTAIN YOU FOR SURE.

This time Prashanth's magic didn't worked out. As KGF holds up to Prashanths narration style plus Yash acting levels, Salaar has lot of dependency only on Prabhas(REBEL STAR). Story wasn't quiet interesting but elevations about second part in the movie gets the attention. Children singing song+seeking help from God+then Hero fight scenes are completely outdated. If this kind of screenplay continues its no more mass instead it makes us bore and looks like a comic. Please don't do this Mr. Neel garu.
Just Prabhas makes the run time looks OK.
Prabhas entry to KHANSAR: ðŸ”¥bgm remind me something like i am watching a MARVEL hero.
For me personally the mother character role Eshwari garu performed little over-acting.
Though the movie stood like a feast for mass fanzzz still it doesn't has much potential as expected. When i first watched kgf-1 i didn't liked it because of over hype back voice twlling about Yash but it was ok since it's all about introduction to Hero character likewise i hv satisfaction level about SðŸ”¥LðŸ”¥ðŸ”¥R part 1.

Watched a Prabhas movie for the first time in theater.
Consistently Hombale production films has a dark theme.
The movie has a good story. All actors have a well designed look. The locations are also apt for this war like movie.
There a quite a few mass scenes. Music and background score not bad, I liked the title theme music the most.
I doubted the inclusion of Shruti Haasan in the movie, but then realised since there is not much of a hard acting role, she is enough.
Many co-actors like Mime Gopi, John Vijay, Bobby Simha did perform well.
I felt that Prithviraj was very highly suppressed in this part 1 movie. He could have been given at least half a strong role Prabhas was given. Hope the parts coming further will make it a exciting watch.

Absolutely mesmerized by the cinematic marvel that was this movie! The story took me by surprise, surpassing all my expectations. A heartfelt thank you to Prashant Neil, and every actor involved-you've left me truly speechless. Prabhas, your performance was nothing short of extraordinary; your dedication shines through. I sincerely hope you continue to explore and embody such captivating roles in your future endeavours.
The film's success is undoubtedly a testament to the collective brilliance of the entire team. The direction by Prashant and the contributions of Prabhas and the entire cast were integral to its magic. Each actor brought their A-game, adding layers of emotion and authenticity to the narrative. It's rare to witness such a seamless blend of talent and storytelling.
Prabhas, your portrayal was a standout, showcasing your versatility and leaving an indelible mark. Your commitment to the character was evident, and it resonated powerfully with the audience. May you carry this dedication forward, blessing us with more memorable performances in the future.
As the credits rolled, the anticipation for Part 2 intensified. Best of luck to the entire team as they embark on the next chapter of this extraordinary journey. The bar has been set high, and fans eagerly await the continuation of this gripping saga. Here's to the success and triumph of the upcoming instalment!
In conclusion, my gratitude to everyone involved in creating this cinematic masterpiece. It's not just a movie; it's an experience that will linger in our hearts. Thank you for this unforgettable ride, and I eagerly await the cinematic brilliance that Part 2 promises to deliver. Best wishes for the continued success of this phenomenal endeavor!

3.5 out of 5 stars.
The Family Plan is a pretty fair action comedy film that has a family road trip with Mark Wahlberg having a secret life before them. As he was once a rogue agent and trained to kill. And a bunches of henchmen are after him.
The plot is okay which involves Mark Wahlberg trying to connect with his teen kids and trying to break the news to his wife the truth.
The action sequences are okay and entertaining. Mark Wahlberg did great in the role. The rest of the cast did okay as well. The villain felt underdeveloped. The humor can be cheesy with Mark Wahlberg and the baby fighting with the baby just giggling through tough situations.
Overall, it was a pretty fair film with plenty of fun action but cheesy humor.

Diving into the intricate life of a retired government hitman trying to balance family and a covert past, this film captivates with a compelling narrative, earning a solid 9/10. However, a regrettable choice in portraying antagonists solely as individuals of African, Asian, and Italian descent introduces an uncomfortable racial dynamic. The lack of diversity in this aspect mars an otherwise outstanding plot. With a touch of sarcasm, one can't help but wonder if the filmmakers forgot to include Latino adversaries, leaving the audience questioning the film's inclusivity. Despite this misstep, the gripping storyline manages to keep viewers engaged, making it a commendable cinematic experience."

This deserves better ratings. It's at least a 7/10. The script is very good. The acting is very good. The comedic elements are very good. The directing is excellent. Overall, this is a fun action comedy worth watching.
I'm very picky and this did have a few minor issues but way fewer than most of the stuff being made these days.
If you have an overinflated sense of superiority and you like to think that your criticisms matter more than the efforts of the people who put in the effort to create a decently entertaining movie, then don't watch this.
As other reviewers have said, grab some popcorn and enjoy this movie.

If you've read any short synopsis of this movie, you don't need to see it. The story begins with an inexplicable set-up (some sort of privatized witness protection program?), kicks off with an unexplained plot twist (why are the bad guys after him NOW?), and proceeds through unbelievable series of public shootouts across the country (at no point across the country were the authorities alarmed or mobilized?). I wish I had these two hours back.\nIf you get tricked into sitting through this garbage, bring a good book. The story will not require more than about three percent of your attention to keep up with the action.

The wife put this film on in the background whilst I was doing something else. 20 minutes in I surprised us both by suggesting this was a Marky Marky I'd actually like to watch.
So we saved it for a day later, and here I am giving it 8 stars.
Nothing ground breaking about the script. But refreshingly warm and charming. There's some great hits by the stunt team. Lots of great little jokes to be found. Max the baby is a stand out character.
When I see this film get slammed by the critics, but a film like Extraction 2 with an even weaker story. I start to wonder if I should believe their reviews anymore.
So I'm writing this review.
If you considering watching it, go in with no expectation and you'll have a great time.

Oh come on. Some people took this movie way too seriously with their ridiculously low ratings. It is what it is with no pretentious "deeper meaning". This was a fun ride. A goofy at times holiday treat. Yes, you could probably predict some of what was coming, but so what. The cast was great. And so many other fun characters in the entire movie. The baby was so cute and hysterical at times. This is a sit back with popcorn and laugh movie. If you just want to relax and enjoy a movie that is not stuffed with obligatory "stuff" and divisive messaging, this is it. It is entertainment. Don't take it too seriously.

"The Family Plan" is just another weak action-comedy, with very low quality on ideas, originality, and development, as well as the cheesy and non-organic love connection between the main characters. The story is simply about a family, and a father that hides his dark, bloody past. When things are getting out of control for him, he has to take the mission in his own hands and hide his true identity from his family. First, I had an impression that this was going to be a fun comedy that can live on its action, but turned out to be an unoriginal flick that really looks like it's written be Ai. First I got to mention the characters. I remembered maybe half of the names, because I never get connected that much (Besides the father, Sean, the main hero) that by the way carried the cast mostly. Sean as a character himself was interesting, but unfortunately not so interesting as I expected him to be. The villain he had to fight came out of nowhere and felt totally out of place, in my opinion. His backstory came more on the end, too, and I wished maybe a little peak before. Sean's wife (The Mother) was fun, yet she was very plastic and the actress could be more of a food commercial women. The kids are the most predictable characters, easily comparable to kids from other family comedies. It's always a computer dude, a weirdo and some little kid. A few of the action sequences were acceptable, yet not so great as I expected. Generic and predictable, it tried to make things interesting but ended with a cheesy clichÃ© that should never took have place. I got really surprised over the camera filming and overall quality, and sometimes I think that not only Apple sponsored this movie, but helped to make it with their cameras. I don't know if I liked it or not, it was a weird feeling in the filming, I don't know, something was just strange. The movie was carried by nice soundtrack, as well as nice suspense score that was good, but some of the action was so lame that the music was wasted for nothing, and that's bad, because they could use it for something much better. In the end, this is an Ai-Script, bad, plastic acting, as well as uninteresting and forgettable action. The rating was saved some more by a few good sequences and nice soundtrack overall.

"The Family Plan" is a heartwarming comedy that explores the chaos and joy that ensue when a well-intentioned family attempts to execute a foolproof plan to reconnect. The ensemble cast delivers standout performances, with each actor bringing a unique charm to their roles. Emily Thompson shines as the determined matriarch, balancing humor and vulnerability with ease."The Family Plan" is a delightful cinematic experience that will leave audiences both laughing and reflecting on the importance of family. Whether you're part of a close-knit family or simply seeking an uplifting escape, "The Family Plan" is a must-watch that celebrates the beautiful chaos of familial love. It's so good movie.

The film overall was quite enjoyable, with its major strengths lying in the comedic aspects and the remarkable performance of the young boy. The humorous elements brought a vibrant and lively feel to the narrative, making it engaging and entertaining. However, incorporating even more comedic scenes could elevate the film's appeal and enjoyment factor. The young boy's role deserves special mention; his presence on screen was a highlight, consistently bringing fun and energy to the film. This combination of humor and the boy's performance made the movie memorable, although there's potential for further enhancement in the comedic department to make a good movie even better.

This movie is to action movies what Hallmark Xmas movies are to romantic movies. A ton of ludicrous and implausible scenes stitched together in a contrived feel good way.
I'm happy with the acting skills, it's the plot that is the let down. For most of the movie, viewers are wondering where the cops are. Violence in casinos and on the roads are left unanswered by police or security. Why?
The extremely unlikely case of the family revolting against dear ol' dad just because he killed a few people is extremely unrealistic as well. There are bad people in the world, and there are assassins. And it is not wrong to take bad people out. Would you cry if someone were to take out Putin today? This manufactured outrage is tiring exhausting and unbelievable.
All in all, certainly a watchable movie. Somewhat enjoyable. But with a few tweaks, it could have been more than Hallmark vomit.

It was so great to finally see a Godzilla movie that held true to the original Godzilla theme. Godzilla is supposed to represent nuclear weapons and the impact that these weapons and the violence of the second World War had on the people of Japan. This theme was powerfully demonstrated in this film.\nAside from the obvious destruction and trauma caused by the monster, the film also touched on other aspects of war that had an impact on the people of Japan, such as dying and living honorably as well as rebuilding a nation. Additionally, you did not feel that there was glorification of the monster or the war, however, respect was shown for both.\nI would highly encourage anybody who has not seen this movie and is fond of Godzilla or monster movies in general to go see this movie (in theatres preferred!).

What can I say other than...Well Done!
On a teeny budget of $15M this Toho Studio movie lacks for nothing. The action kicks off right away with a Japanese pilot touching down on a chunky island airstrip. He's questioned as to why he has returned (was supposed to be a kamikaze mission, I think. I watched a no-subtitles version). Next scene, BOOM, Godzilla!
Note: Gojira = gorilla + kujira/whale.
There's plenty of human drama laced into the story. The toddler gives an award-worthy performance. My goodness, when her face crumples up in a sob, you'd have to be a block of wood not to shed a tear yourself.
It's refreshing to see a movie stay period-accurate; notice that all the scenes of decision-making and naval heroism are all-male. Women play a role in the plot - the main character's life is saved by a woman - just not in the attack against the monster.
My criticisms of the movie are as follows:
***MILD SPOILERS***
(1) There are too many rousing speeches rallying the spirit of the troops. Godzilla conveniently disappears for large chunks of the run time.
(2) One consequential scene that happens midway thru the film gets undone in the ending. That felt cheap.
Overall, RECOMMENDED.
Note: A second release of this movie called "Godzilla Minus 1/Minus Color" will be coming out in mid-January. Black & White, baby!

Godzilla Minus One ðŸ‘ðŸ‘ðŸ‘
It's going straight into my IMDb as a 10/10 (recency bias score, as initial watch experience...on a more critical analysis could be 9.6 to 9.8)
If a movie can make you feel for the characters and poke at the emotions of an emotionless person like myself, yeah, it's getting that big recommendation from me.
I loved the intensity of the music and the monster Godzilla scenes, done so well, yet it's actually not just those big scenes that do it for this one.
The story, the writing (subtitles), but how they dealt with some heavy sentiments, I thought they did an incredible job. Well done.
I even liked the "feel" of the movie, the texture of it, the way that Godzilla himself actually looks a bit funny ðŸ˜… it worked.
