The sense of scale also worked, this Godzilla looked MASSIVE, enough to make you tremble, that sense of hopeless impending devastation, and how that was tackled, as well as some darker, sadder emotions that the movie touches on, yep, fair play, you guys got me on this one. ðŸ‘
Highly recommend, catch in the cinema for the SOUNDS and scale of it, but I think it could still work on the small screen if you're waiting for that.
Loved this movie.

In "Godzilla Minus One," the film deeply explores the emotional side, portraying a kamikaze soldier facing the consequences of World War II and Godzilla. The dramatic depth is remarkable, delving into post-war traumas in an impactful way. Unlike North American versions of "Godzilla," it adds complexity to the characters, enriching the viewer's experience.
The film's execution highlights the strength of Asian cinema, surpassing Hollywood in many aspects. The Godzilla scenes are impressive, offering a unique sensory experience. The action sequences, especially the destruction of a major city, effectively convey the villain's relentless threat.
"Godzilla Minus One" indirectly challenges prejudices against Asian films, providing a positive experience for audiences weary of American blockbusters.
On the downside, a slight negative point is noted in the conclusion, where there's an effort to appeal to the Western audience with a more "Hollywood-esque" ending, which felt somewhat forced but didn't diminish the film's overall impact.

10/10, not only the best movie of 2023, but in my opinion probably the best Godzilla film ever put to film. For a budget that looks incredibly budgeted and small compared to Hollywood's recent $200-300 Million bloated budgets and limitations of practical and visual effects, this movie absolutely blows the competition out of the water.
Toho made the right choice to go back to basics and make Godzilla the ultimate destructive antagonistic force of nature and bringing back the monster-horror aspect that's very much needed in these movies.
Like the 1954 original, the dark and serious tone works beautifully and incredibly effectively in conveying what the scene needs to. And whether on screen, off screen or implied, Godzilla's mere presence conveys that tone of dread and terror, truly retaining back the title of King of the Monsters.
And the characters! It's been a long time since we've had characters in these films that we could actually care for, let alone give any interest or sympathy towards. Minus One's characters grow and are fleshed out throughout the story, and the context of being a kamakazi pilot in a post-WWII 1940's Japan. It asks questions of the value of life and vengeance for those who've lost theirs, and the guilt of actions, what we do and don't do. This film reflects back to a conflicted and broken time, but one inhabited by good and united people choosing to give their lives for something greater. It's truly a relieving and hopeful sight for what makes great cinema through the infinite muddled assembly line of cheap, poorly made, factory-produced content called film.
Forget the multiverse movies, give us more of this!

Movies just don't get better than this -- certainly not this kind of action/monster movie.
"Blown away" is an understatement.
Aspiring screenwriters: THIS is how you develop characters and story simultaneously. Too many good/great things to mention. Nits to be picked here and there, but they pale in comparison to the tone, characters, and STORY.
Each character (even the ancillary, non-speaking parts) add to the humaness here. If you are 40+ years old and don't shed a tear (or MANY, as I did) here, you have lost your soul. Or ... perhaps you are deficient. No judging here, just wanting to make sure that those who DO posess souls go see this gem of a film.

Godzilla Minus One is a Japanese foreign language movie. I was hesitant going in as I'm
not the biggest fan the Hollywood Godzilla movies post 2000. I recently watched Godzilla: King of Monsters and couldn't convince myself to squeeze in Godzilla v King Kong before watching Godzilla Minus One.
Fortunately, Godzilla Minus One is the best Godzilla movie I've seen and it's completely unlike any of the others. Like 2019's Joker, it feels like a movie that is much greater than its genre, using the Godzilla skin as a vessel to tell a bigger story.
Godzilla Minus One is set in Japan at the end of World War II. We meet Shikishima, a Kamikaze pilot who survived the war but for several reasons believes he has failed as a man and as a representative of the Japanese Army.
During this time, Godzilla appears and we follow the Army's attempt to stop Godzilla. These two plot lines intertwine and complement each other throughout the film as we are given a window into the Japanese war mentality.
The scenes with Godzilla are epic. It's the best and most menacing I've ever seen Godzilla look. Unlike in recent films, Godzilla feels majestic and absolutely terrifying. The Godzilla laser beam was crafted amazingly. Each laser beam felt as big a deal as the explosion scene in Oppenheimer.
I had heard good things but this generally surprised me. I was captivated throughout. Captivated with Godzilla, Japanese war mentality, post war Japan and with the story of an individual that constantly fails to live up to standards he and society has set for himself.
Let's hope the next Hollywood Godzilla Movie from Legendary captures some of this magic.

I wish I could have seen it in IMAX, but even in standard format it was an epic experience!
Godzilla minus one, is like a good ol' 90s anime story in live action. The acting is great and the story flows naturally and easy to follow.
What really sets it apart from the Hollywood versions is not savvy CGI nor explosive action sequences, but its ability to tell the human side story in a way that makes the audience care and follow. The motivation of the protagonist is clear, Godzilla's role to symbolize the sheer destruction of war, is felt front and center.
The messages the movie contains are simplistic yet profound. The movie is clearly very well crafted with heart, love and effort! My hats off to the director, cast and crew that brought this onto the big screen.

This new Godzilla film directed by Takashi Yamazaki exceeded my expectations of any kaiju films. This compelling story about human beings faced by existential crisis is so touching.
This drama is set in post-war Japan, when Japan tried to recover from the damage caused by war and re-establish a new society. One of the highlights for the film is the evocative human drama which plays a significant role in this film. Firstly, the plot delves into the sense of guilt and search for redemption of the protagonist, Koichi Shikishima, an ex-Kamikaze pilot. By using its machine's fault as pretext, he fails to complete a mission as the pilot. Throughout the film, we see him grappling with the consequences of his actions, sense of loss and shame. Shikishima won't stop his ongoing search for redemption while he can't even allow himself to embrace life itself. The dishonour shames and haunts him as he waits for an opportunity for living his life again. This failed war hero story is recounted poignantly and compellingly. The screen play by Yamazaki gives us hope for humanity as many of the citizens fight against the monster with their sense of moral purpose. This is a film about Godzilla; however, the balance between the 'human story' and the 'Godzilla spectacle' seems just right.
Ryonosuke Kamiki's acting was highly convincing and the timing of his line delivery is masterful. It could be also said Yamazaki's film craft made the screenplay more effective and alive. One of the memorable lines is 'my war hasn't finished yet' which Shikishima utters during an argument with a colleague at a local izakaya. The camaraderie and affection shown by his co-coworkers were also beautiful. Kuranoske Sasaki's acting highlights qualities of a fearless colleague who seems rather rough, but who cares about others and is ready to embrace this mission to conquer Godzilla.
Of course the entertainment value of Godzilla cannot be missed. The scale of the spectacle and absurdity of Godzilla's relentlessness is sometimes comical, yet at times also moving. Music written by Naoki Sato sets scenes skilfully. It creates an ominous and foreboding mood while it enhances tragedy and tension of the film.

I love movies, but I've been extremely disappointed by the movies that have been coming out this last decade (I know I'm not alone). This movie is STUNNING. It's a return to form while being fresh, vibrant, and powerful. I cannot say enough good things about this movie.\nThere is no lack of Godzilla throughout the film, but the characters are actually interesting and have incredible depth. The way it skillfully weaves character arcs and handles post-war attitudes while not excusing a formerly fascist government is masterful. I hope that every major Hollywood executive is ashamed to show their face in the streets after this film. I hope this is the beginning of a new revival in the art of film.\nIf you haven't seen this yet, get in line IMMEDIATELY!

movieName: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny
content:
Films may not have necessarily been better in the past, but the standout productions of the 80s and 90s often shared a common trait - a significant investment of heart. Despite varying budgets or circumstances.
The film industry back then was perhaps as calculating as today, aiming to at least double every dollar spent. However, the caution in film making and storytelling today, together with the fact that most people now consider themselves hardcore critics first, rather than an audience, contributes to a scarcity of heartfelt and those charming imperfections in movies.
The things we loved about Indiana Jones: Indy clumsily beating up Nazis and creepy Indian cult members over some archaeological artifact. Accompanied by John Williams' brilliant melodies, occasionally a little bit too loud and tiresome score and dialogue but... Nevertheless, it remains a masterpiece-ingenious, entertaining, and delightfully imperfect.
No need to compare this final chapter to its predecessors. Streamed in 4K during a time when many believe VHS was an ancient STD, I must say, the movie sent me away on delightful nostalgic trip. The story and the actors successfully brought back some of that wonderful 'heart' from the past. A more than worthy ending.
Well done James Mangold, and thank you Harrison Ford for spoiling us with great entertainment throughout the decades.

movieName: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny
content: This movie garnered a whole bunch of criticism and I can see why. If I didn't get Disney + for free I would have never seen this based on all the negative reviews and clips I saw of it. But I DO get D+ for free which this showed up on. So I gave it a try. This is NOT the Indy that we deserved for a final movie. Out of nowhere is introduced a character that is NEVER before mentioned in one of the previous movies and is the most insufferable and annoying person in the whole movie.\nThe action sequences are ok and the music scores are top notch. The acting is also OK. I have to say that any upcoming movies that have Phoebe Waller Bridge as the main draw will not be any temptation for me to go to. She's fairly underwhelming.\nOverall, the writing and premise of this show are really not that good. As far as storytelling and keeping me 'on the edge of my seat' (a gold standard for keeping your audience engaged) it was never there. I watched the first movie and this last iteration of Indy is such a pale imitation. Why have writers and directors have lost all semblance of creativity lately??

movieName: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny
content: A sad farewell to Indiana Jones. There is so much CGI going on that the chase scenes mean nothing. Time and time again things happen too conveniently (thanks to the CGI). There are masses of green screen shots which take out the mysticism of the journey. I'd rathe the film was poorly lit but practically shot than all done on a lit set.\nPlot wise, its too magical and not based in reality enough. We don't want time travel, or multiverses, just go on a good old romping journey to some interesting places. It's not that difficult to write. I think too many people got involved in the story and there were too many things shoehorned in to say farewell to Indiana. Why does this happen to every great franchise?!

movieName: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny
content: A very disappointing and charmless end to the Indiana Jones franchise. The first three movies are bona-fide classics, built on great story telling, imaginative action scenes and extremely charming performances from Ford, and all the supporting casts. But this film has none of that. Ford looks great, but he can't hold the film together. Mads is terrific, but Waller-Bridge is no film star, and is extremely poor and charmless. I've watched the original movies countless times, even the much maligned 4th movie has its highlights (Blanchlet is superb), but I'll never watch this movie again. Disappointing end to what was a great adventure.

movieName: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny
content:
I certainly didn't start "Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny" with any particular sense of anticipation. But I did think that it would be reasonably entertaining and a decent end to the poorly named trilogy. But not so much. It's far too long and it sent me to sleep.
The problems are manifold I think. For one it's trying to be an action movie when the Indy films were always just comic books projected onto the big screen. Sure they have action but it's in the service of something else rather than being the main attraction.
Then there's the fact that, keeping with the comic book style, previous scripts have been generally light-hearted and funny. An attempt is made here at humour but that's as far as it goes. In fact much of the dialogue between Indy and Helena (the other main character but not a love interest thank God!) is snarky and lacking in affection.
Finally you've got a bizarre plot involving time travel, Nazis (what, again?) and the Greek empire. It's just all over the place with long sequences given over to CGI effects that look out of place.
I hesitate to say that this could ever have been a good movie but you never know with Harrison Ford. There's a reason why he was (and is) a movie star and it comes down to his easy charisma and ability to light up a film. But even his talent is put to the test here.

movieName: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny
content:
This is just another movie lost to the Disney house of terrible movies. Terrible set ups, terrible casting and acting and over use of effects which makes it look terrible
Who ever thought it would be a good idea replacing indie with Pheobe was wrong... She is ok in other roles catered to her but this is not one of those. I couldn't stand her arrogance and undermining character. It's an insult to good characters.
The vilkian was typical over the top nazi and why they keep using madz... I will never know
This isn't a crapxon women or anything, it's a this was just a crap movie that went for entertainment and modern telling over heart.
This is what's wrong with Hollywood and Disney. They don't write heart anymore.
So I give it a 2 and say it sucked.

movieName: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny
content: I don't know why there are so many negative reviews of this movie. There's a few things like extreme use of CGI, but who cares...isn't that 99% of the MCU. I think that they did a great job with the Dial of Destiny given Harrison's age. He's still got it at 80+ years of age. The throw-back to create the story line was creative too. They did an awesome job of recreating those scenes from the Last Crusade. It really felt like an old Indy movie. I know a lot people had complained about the Helena character, and I found her unlikeable as well, but it wouldn't be an Indiana Jones movie without an annoying sidekick. This was a nice end to a classic era of Indy!

movieName: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny
content:
"Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny" marks a grand and fitting finale to one of the most beloved action-adventure series in cinematic history. Directed by James Mangold, this 2023 release stands as the fifth and final chapter in the Indiana Jones saga, a series that has captivated audiences for decades.
Set in the pivotal year of 1969, the film weaves an intricate and gripping narrative that follows the iconic Indiana Jones, portrayed once again by the legendary Harrison Ford. Alongside him are familiar faces: John Rhys-Davies as Sallah and Karen Allen as Marion Ravenwood. This ensemble is joined by a stellar cast of newcomers, including Phoebe Waller-Bridge, Antonio Banderas, and Mads Mikkelsen, each adding their unique flair to the story.
The plot centers around Indy and his estranged goddaughter, Helena, in their race against time to prevent a former Nazi scientist from using a powerful artifact to change the course of history. The storyline is a masterful blend of intrigue and action, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats.
James Mangold's direction is impeccable, capturing the essence of the Indiana Jones series while injecting his own creative flair. The film pays homage to its predecessors, balancing nostalgic elements with fresh, innovative storytelling. The absence of Steven Spielberg's direction and George Lucas's conception is not felt, as Mangold steps up to the challenge with finesse.
Phedon Papamichael's cinematography is nothing short of extraordinary, capturing the film's fast-paced action and stunning locales with precision and beauty. Every frame is a visual feast, complementing the film's dynamic narrative.
For fans of the Indiana Jones series, "Dial of Destiny" is a must-watch. It not only honors the legacy of the iconic character but also offers a thrilling adventure that stands on its own. The performances are top-notch, with each actor bringing their character to life with depth and charisma.
In summary, "Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny" is a cinematic triumph. It is a film that successfully concludes an epic saga while standing as a remarkable achievement in the action-adventure genre. Its blend of exhilarating storyline, stellar cast, masterful direction, and breathtaking cinematography makes it an unforgettable experience and a fitting tribute to the enduring legacy of Indiana Jones.

movieName: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny
content: This film is a wonderful addition to the saga. The complaints are the usual we've heard about many "older" hero films from Luke Skywalker to Indiana Jones. The stars, and their characters, aren't the young bouncy heroes they used to be. Destiny is just that, a passing of the torch and a sweet goodbye, the ending is beautiful. The story typical wild adventure wrapped around villains and action. The stars playing off each other with Voller being a brilliant foil for Indy. The story itself is no more or less wild than the Ark's wrath of God, Shiva's power over Kali, a Grail of life, and aliens on Earth. Pulp fiction and fun throughout! Watch and enjoy!

movieName: Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny
content: This film should never have been made and is a horrible end to the franchise. In the original films the violence has an almost comic edge to it and it is largely confined to the 'baddies' getting their well served punishment. This film seems to revel in the body count of dead civilians. The chief villain is a poorly fleshed out character and his henchmen have no redeeming or comic qualities. They are just nasty pieces of work. The plot is confusing and frankly boring. And there are very few nice characters including Phoebe Waller-Bridge's character. Those that do raise a smile are not in the film long. The tone of this film is bleak and miserable, it has been made by old men about an old character and you can feel it in every frame. There isn't much humour in watching an old man at the end of his life. The budget was far too big and they've, frankly, chucked everything and the kitchen sink at it. The action scenes are too lunch and predictable and everything is drenched in CGI. The sound quality is awful. Hollywood continues its march away from clear dialogue cleaned up in post production and continues to encourage mumbling. Why? I have no idea. This is a film best to forget. Remember the original three films fondly. Not because of nostalgia, but because they were better films.

I saw previews for this in the theaters before I think Ant Man Quantumania and thought it looked pretty cool.
I didn't want to buy it, or rent it, so I waited til one day I noticed on my Roku tv that it was available to stream on Hulu of all places, and I have a basic Hulu plan I never use through Verizon.
Ok cool, let's check it out then!
Right away I wasn't buying into the flawed storyline of Keith David Washington and Gemma Chan.
I like Gemma Chan, but she's picked some bad roles. She played Sersi in Marvels Immortals, and that movie was awful; one of Marvels worst!
Honestly, I didn't get or buy her role in this movie. Her character could have been played by anyone , no offense, and it's nothing against her, the storyline fell short.
There were some things I did like, and the cgi/scenery is right on point , but I feel they could have done so much more with this movie.
Overall I struggled to finish watching it, and felt disappointed because it had potential.
I guess they'll let anyone make a movie these days, but judge for yourself.

The worst thing about The Creator is just that it's a bad story that is without any depth or significant meaning.
Humans make robots. Humans turn against robots. Lots of very flashy VFX and Sci-Fi Composites that really don't look believable cos they are mixed so haphazardly with contemporary scenery that it's just obviously compositing.
So many stupid things happen in the story. The characters move from one location to another do a battle scene then go to another location to do another battle scene. Why are some of the cars super futuristic and some of the cars are just modern normal cars??? If the film is set in say 2100, then why are not all cars modern cars? It would be like arriving in 2025 and seeing a mix of modern cars and cars from the 1930s - it's so blatently a dumb decision from the director and the whole film is full of stuff like that. And why was there an evil looking spider robot in the escape pod bay?? Just so it could have a fight with the hero.... blah.
And why was Claire De Lune by Debussey playing at the end of this film?? What on earth does an action film about explosions and battle have to do with a romantic, twinkling piece of classical music???
This film is a perfect example of why the "Rule of Cool" does not work. By the end of the film I was profoundly bored and rolling my eyes. So glad I didn't waste my money going to see this in the Cinema.

There is a complexity to The Creator that is hard to fathom at first. It draws the viewer firmly into a world where AI Robots are as ubiquitous as mobile phones today and they are partly human with faces that reflect the diversity of the human species in both ethnicity and age. To some, this makes no sense as we're used to seeing Robots in sci-fi that all look the same, however if you accept the premise that these simulants are meant to blend into all aspects of human culture, it makes sense. It also adds more conviction that the simulants represent an entirely seperate species aside from humanity with their own diversity and complexity. Contrasting this are the utilitarian faceless robots that perform functions such as the police and army bots. I think it worked very well.
There's are aspects here which remind me of Blade Runner in terms of the city scapes and the infrastructure around this robotic world, but on the ground it reminds me of District 9 and Elysium to some degree, where technology is advanced but also used , scratched, dirty and worn. This conveys reality and is very likely what will happen when we eventually have robots everywhere.
The story is somewhat original and the acting is excellent, particularly John David Washington who is eminently watchable and the child robot, Alpha who is remarkable. I loved the fact that most of the cast were Asian, the languages and locations were Asian, and it was a refreshing change from always having these blockbusters set in the USA. It was also a metaphor for American interference in other parts of the world and the remote warfare which is today conducted by technology mostly and mostly happens in silence from western media. There is some deep commentary here on the morals and societal ignorance of stealth warfare, but it is delivered mostly visually, there for those who might wish to dwell on it if they like, rather than any outright political monologue that might seem preachy. This was smartly done.
Not just Sci-Fi, it has heart and is a film for everyone. One of the best of it's genre in the last decade.

Flaw #1: John David Washington has the acting ability of the lumbar section of Home Depot. I've seen him now in all three of his major movies - BlacKkKlansman, Tenet, and this movie, and in all three, I can only imagine how much BETTER all three movies would have been if his dad, Denzel, were in the movie instead of this flat, atonal, and wooden stiff occupying the screen.
Oh, and the kid playing Alphie also belonged in the lumbar section.
Flaw #2: I don't know what writer/director Gareth Edwards was trying to do with this movie, but the whole concept of where AI and android - human interaction could go in the future could have been imagined in a far more interesting and plausible world than what was put out in this movie.
Instead, what ended up on the screen was this very simplistic, implausible, and heavy handed theme of:
West - Fears AI = Bad
New Asia - Embraces AI = Good.
It's such a simple minded Hollywood trope to lump the entire Western culture and all the diverse and vastly different Asian cultures into heavily caricatured single unified entities that by the end of the movie I was flat out just offended.
The character of General Andrews - how many times have we seen this caricature of the Evil Military Mastermind in movies past? Couldn't Gareth Edwards come up with something new and original?
This is in the end, just a poorly thought out, badly acted and dumb movie. It could have been so much more.

Because this is the first time film reviews have ever actually annoyed me.
First of all, anyone who includes in their review, some version of 'I am a film expert and anyone who liked this film obviously isnt', is not someone anyone should be taking any kind of advice from. Ever. Ignore those. People like different things. You're allowed to like this film without being condescended to.
I really enjoyed it. There are definitely some holes in the story and a few lines of questionable writing. So what? It thoroughly entertained me for a few hours and unlike the vast majority of new films I see, I think I'll remember it in a few years time.
So many people have recommended it to me - I'm yet to speak to anyone IRL who didn't like it.
The two main actors are excellent. I didn't even notice the bits of bad script until we discussed it later because the delivery is perfect. John David Washington is a wonderful actor and he made the soldier, the broken man, and the father figure roles completely believable.
Madeleine Yuna Voyles was 7 at the time of filming! 7 years old and she is exceptional. Kids can be annoying and tend to over act in big roles. She just became the character. And she's so sweet - I doubt she could annoy anyone.
Gemma Chan and Ken Watanabe are both consistently good in everything they do and fit well here.
I wasn't very impressed with some of the other supporting performances but they didn't matter - this film was all about the two main stars and they absolutely smashed it!
For a relatively small budget (ridiculous thing to say about 80 mil I know, but that's a fraction of some other big Sci Fi films), it is a visual masterpiece. It's stunning.
Don't go in expecting the writing to blow you away and I think the overall experience will anyway.

Gareth Edwards' "The Creator" isn't a paint by numbers sci-fi flick; it's a trip into a mind-bending and emotional alternate future - with battle between two philosophies that cannot coexist. One side of humanity seeks harmony between AI and humans; the other side fights to win the "Humans versus AI" conflict, believing that loss = extinction. It's like trying to choose between a digital utopia and an Armageddon nightmare. Gareth Edwards pulls it off with style.
The movie juxtaposes between these two contrasting worldviews using visually stunning "uniforms." One team is represented by "Zen" like New Asian "harmony" vibe that values all life; while the other team uses a military industrial complex motif, dark corridors, heartless soldiers. At the same time, you have a group of researchers attempting to create/raise an electronic savior figure that will rescue the oppressed AI - a futuristic "Moses." It's done well.
The film's visuals are nothing short of spectacular. Gareth Edwards, despite reportedly raiding the piggy bank for his budget, manages to weave magic with the camera. (It has to be...right?!? I mean look at the price!) The scenes are a visual feast, and you find yourself forgiving any budget constraints because the cinematography is on point.
The special effects - they're downright incredible. Every frame is a testament to Edwards' visual genius. He filmed this all on location, without "Green Screens" and then had the effects' studios work within the palette he and his cinematographer created. Mr. Edwards has pioneered a way to make a low-budget blockbuster without sacrificing an ounce of the sci-fi wow factor. This movie (and Godzilla Minus One) is going to re-invent how studios spend their money.
"The Creator" was a roller-coaster of emotions and ideas, wrapped up nicely for my holiday season. Gareth Edwards manages to juggle the complexities of his AI vision while treating our eyes to a cinematic smorgasbord of awe-inspiring scenery and mind-blowing special effects. It doesn't matter if you're into the whole "Can humans and AI be friends?" debate or whether or not the U. S. MIC is bad, etc. "The Creator" is a sci-fi gem that does what "Sci-Fi" is supposed to do.
I loved it - 9/10. (Btw, I couldn't get my kids to watch this for some reason. They heard that it was "too slow" and for the "over forty crowd!?!")

For 80 Million, could have done sooo much more with this and made it a movie that people can watch again and again.
Boring. Still waiting for the good part to happen....
Has no "feels cool to be in the future" moments, also doesn't really try to explain the technology either.
It's full of plot gaps and cringe worthy moments from its highly one dimensional villains.
The plot twist are wired from miles away and there are no real surprises to be seen.
The Movie plays out precisely like you would anticipate it to.
I was very excited to see the trailer for a new Sci-fi Movie.
Great CGI, but a terrible script.

Its hard to find a decent movie these days, the quality is on the drop in recent years, this one is no exception...
The story is so uninteresting and the end don't save the movie.
Directed by Gareth Edwards (Rogue One: A Star Wars Story), the film stars John David Washington (Tenet), Madeleine Yuna Voyles, Gemma Chan (Eternals), Ken Watanabe (The Last Samurai), Allison Janney (The Help) and Marc Menchaca (Ozark).
While the storyline bore strong resemblances to Blade Runner, unfortunately, the plot of The Creator proved to be highly predictable, with only one noteworthy twist, and I didn't find myself as invested in the characters as I had hoped. On the positive side, the acting, special effects, cinematography and settings were magnificent, but throughout the entire film, there was a sense that something crucial was missing. Additionally, the film's extended runtime led to certain sections that dragged. However, it's worth noting that the ending was satisfying, and every action scene and shootout was executed exceptionally well, I asked myself at one point, is this movies re-watchable, Sure its not...

Of all the epic sci-fis we've been fed, this one is, by far, the most satisfying. It won't beat the OG Star Wars trilogy or the new Dune installement, but it will, for sure, beat movies like Netflix's Rebel Moon or others in the like. It's a classic father figure taking care of, and leading, a child but set in a beautiful world that, to a point, could almost be ours one day. It starts with the feeling of another Terminor story but leads into something quite different, something of its own. Liked it more than I first expected and woukd definately watch it again for sure. Don't go in with any expectations and enjoy!

A lot of reviewers have focussed on how derivative the movie is and how the story has too many logical leaps. Having rewatched it both criticisms are valid but do not do it justice. Taken on its own terms The Creator is visually stunning and had a sweet love story at its heart. The little girl is particularly impressive. Just sit back and enjoy it, you won't be disappointed. I also recommend checking out the director's earlier sci-fi movie Monsters which I don't believe many people heard about. Despite it being shot for apparently no money at all it is also beautifully made and surprisingly touching.

'Migration' is a really well-made family film. It's a simple premise about anthropomorphic ducks - the father duck, Mack (Nanjiani), wants to protect his children/chicks, Dax (Jennings) and Gwen (Gazal), and the mother duck, Pam (Banks), wants them to experience the world and gain some experience. They meet some other ducks migrating south for the winter - they're presumably in North-Eastern USA - so they decide to do the same, with quirky uncle Dan (DeVito) in tow.\nWhat follows is both a semi-familiar road-trip comedy, as well as a refreshing take on family, trying new things and helping others. There's a great support cast, as the duck family passes through New York City and meets Chump the pigeon (Awkwafina), Delroy the macaw (Key), as well as Erin the heron (Kane) and GooGoo (Mitchell) - either a goose or a white duck. There's a nice jail-break sequence for Delroy, which sets up the human antagonist, the Chef.\nFor some reason the Chef also has a Chinook and hunts them down, leading to Dax and Gwen having to step-up. The animation is a nice mix of cartoonish and realistic, and it looks excellent, especially at the end. There's no overly-scary moments, some teachable themes, the voice cast is all good and there's consistent laughs throughout. There's also 'Mooned', the 9-min 'Despicable Me' tie-in at the start of the film, which kids seemed to love.

Rarely do I find a movie that captivates my heart like "Migration" did. It's a safe yet heartwarmingly funny film, a refreshing gem amidst many misses in the industry. The plot was engaging, and the humor... I found myself bursting into laughter, a rarity these days.\nKumail Nanjiani and Tresi Gazal's voice acting breathed life into the characters, infusing the film with a vibrant and comedic essence. Their performances offered a fresh and delightful perspective. However, despite the talent, Awkwafina's presence felt exhausting, not due to poor performance but sheer overexposure in the cinematic landscape.\nOverall, "Migration" is a delightful journey, offering a charming storyline and standout performances, making it a memorable watch amidst the sea of recent film disappointments.

Illumination, the studio behind the Despicable Me and Sing franchises, is thriving financially, with its Super Mario Bros. Movie being the second-highest grossing film of 2023. However, true respect and acclaim still elude the Minion-spawning animation house. Migration, a film about a family of ducks, the Mallards, led by Kumail Nanjiani and Elizabeth Banks, aims to break the labels of cheap gags and stories that appeal to a broad audience. The creative control of Ernest and Celestine co-director Benjamin Renner promises a different approach to other Illumination movies. Migration's success can be attributed to its focus on relationships and warmth, which has been absent from much of Illumination's output since the first Despicable Me. The Mallard family's journey to Jamaica is a well-crafted film that builds connections between its ducklings, enhancing the plot. The family's motivations for leaving their pond and their desire for adventure are relatable, as is the family's patriarch, Mack, who prioritizes the safety of his children over everything else. When the family faces the challenge of survival in New York City, their perception of the world is challenged. Despite being set up as a stereotypical family with a stern dad, loving mom, and a brash teenage boy with a cute younger sister, the film ensures an emotional attachment to the ducklings, making it a satisfying and formulaic film. The animation quality in Migration represents an evolution of Illumination's past work. The film begins with a beautifully rendered bedtime story, blending hand-drawn and CG elements. The CG journey is characterized by realism, with cliffs tanned with autumn leaves and New York cityscapes painted with concrete coldness and bustling life. The water animation and cloud effects are particularly impressive. These changes do not change Illumination's identity, but rather create a better version of the typical film. However, this overfamiliarity overshadows much of Migration's cool new elements. Migration, a 3D animation by Mike White, is a delightful story developed with French animation director Benjamin Renner. Renner, known for his 2012 2D film Ernest and Celestine, has joined Illumination to lead his first studio and 3D animation effort, which is sure to delight fans of ducks. The Mallard family lives a dependable life in a pond, with dad Mack (Kumail Nanjiani) hesitant to leave his accustomed life. Wife Pam (Elizabeth Banks) encourages him to relax and take their children, Dax (Caspar Jennings) and Gwen (Tresi Gazal), on a trip to Jamaica. After a heart-to-heart with Uncle Dan (Danny DeVito), Mack realizes he has been missing life's essence and agrees to take the family on a life-changing adventure.

I'm honestly shocked! Migration is a really wholesome, loveable movie! What looked like a painfully average Illumination movie turned out to be one of its best! We got a well-written family story from Mike White about getting out of one's comfort zone and accepting change with likeable characters, solid humour, and beautiful visuals. It even had some good tension and suspense! Migration isn't your usual fare from Illumination, in fact, it might very well be the antithesis to the claims people (including me) make about Illumination. There are no pop culture references. The humour is character, visual, or slapstick based (I actually laughed a lot) and the characters are really lovable. It's very sweet and the animation is stunning and extremely expressive. The visuals are really stellar - a massive step up for Illumination. It's easily their best animation. The musical score was fantastic too - John Powell did not have to go that hard with his score. The music is so fun and inventive. And the voice cast turned out to be really awesome! Migration is a wholesome, charming film for the whole family that is very funny and has a lot of heart. Went in expecting a dumb, pop culture romp and got a funny, sweet, entertaining, and gorgeously animated family adventure. Illumination created an underrated gem with this one!

The typical laidback light hearted fun family film! I love it a lot! The characters get plenty of screen time, no one gets left out or not a chance to shine. The flight scenes are beautiful and the animation for the flying is pretty stunning as well you can really sense the weight when they fly If that makes any sense. The character designs are great. So many different locations they visit it's interesting to see how different they all look, the scenery is neat to look at. Also all sorts of bird species they meet along the way of many shapes and size if you're a fan of birds you'll definitely enjoy this film!

Most of the animated movies nowadays lack depth in my opinion, despite their stunning visuals. Migration fortunately breaks this curse...\nIts vivid colors and lively characters only add up to an already solid plot with fun witty dialogues, and most notably, beneficial educational values for children and parents.\nThis is a perfect family movie that is truly as good as an animated movie can get. Its unique in being very relatable, and manages to have different cultural elements embedded without trying too hard. I really appreciate the balance illumination achieved in this masterpiece, and consider this one of their classics.

Migration is just a simple adventure, but still an enjoyable film on its own. It does have a predictable story and an unneeded villain for a movie about migrating. But it still provides things to be a decent film thanks to great animation, some cute jokes that I at least chuckled, and as someone that loves to travel, it does have the heart of venturing the world. I think it would be worth watching at least once. But I do think that the kids will love it for the funny characters and a tale that they will easily get into more than adults would. Like The Super Mario Bros Movie and the other films Illumination has made, it's not the best movie of the year. I do think this movie is pretty simple, but pretty cute for a migrate adventure.

This is pretty typical of recent CGI animated movies of late. Cookie-cutter, very predictable, shallow story line with impressive animation. It will keep the little kids occupied for a couple of hours (the preceding trailers at our theater ran for about 30 minutes), but don't expect them to learn much from it.\nI feared the worst at the beginning when the dad duck who wanted to stay near home and not migrate was being portrayed as a clueless and ridiculous character, sadly a common story component in children's films, making the adults out to be stupid, but subsequent suspenseful moments during the migration tended to lend some vindication to his concerns. However, those moments were always ultimately inconsequential and, of course, the movie had a very happy ending.\nI will leave it to the other reviewers to provide more detailed spoiler information.

I recently watched the movie Migration (2023) in theaters with my daughter. The storyline follows a northeastern family of ducks ðŸ¦† who encounter a flock of migrating birds that invite them to fly south for the winter. Despite their usual winter stay, the family convinces the dad to fly to Jamaica ðŸ‡¯ðŸ‡² this year, and an adventure ensues.
This movie is co-directed by Benjamin Renner (Ernest & Celestine) and Guylo Homsy (Eddie's Life Coach) and features the voices of Kumail Nanjiani (Stuber), Danny DeVito (Twins), Awkwafina (Crazy Rich Asians), Keegan-Michael Key (Wonka), and Elizabeth Banks (The Hunger Games).
The animation in this picture is outstanding, while the rest of the film is fairly average. The storyline is straightforward, with a few worthwhile subplots. I particularly enjoyed the husband and wife working together through various circumstances for the betterment of the family. The voices are well selected, and Awkwafina and DeVito comedic content keep the film well-paced. The conclusion is as expected, though its sequel potential remains uncertain.
In conclusion, Migration is a fun family animated picture with enough worthwhile elements to make it worth a watch, but it doesn't stand out in the genre. I would score this a 5.5/10 and recommend seeing it once.

'Migration' is yet another big studio animation with some big Hollywood names attached to it. I'll be surprised if anyone was actually looking forward to it, as it seemed like one of those disposable yearly animations we never run out of. And to an extent it is.\n'Migration' is a passable movie that, while lacking depth, manages to deliver a few good laughs and boasts decent animation. The movie remains very surface level, making it an easy watch that won't leave much of an impression on adult viewers. However it's not without its entertainment value though, as the children in the theater seemed to be having a blast.\nSo if you do have kids around, 'Migration' might be just enough fun and distraction to last the weekend.

Violent Night completely surpassed our expectations, it was a really good time - highly enjoyable and lots of funny moments. David Harbour is great in the role and really brings it to life. The action looks good, it has fun and innovative fight scenes, and just enough blood to satisfy your desire for the bad guys to get their comeuppance. It's good for teens and above - I have a feeling younger kids may find the fights a bit too bloody - but could be a really good family Christmas movie.\nI'd happily watch it every Christmas and make a tradition out of it. If you like Die Hard you'll probably like this.

'Violent Night (2022)' is surprisingly earnest in its themes of Christmas magic and rekindling your Christmas spirit. What initially seems like a sardonic anti-Christmas movie soon reveals itself to be genuinely interested in spreading Yuletide cheer, although that's not to imply it doesn't also feature all the brutality, bad language and bodily fluids its concept promises. Merging 'Die Hard (1988)', 'Home Alone (1990', 'Bad Santa (2004)' and 'John Wick (2014)' (or, perhaps more accurately, some of its lesser imitators), the piece provides a stockingful of festive fun despite its undeniably derivative nature. David Harbour and John Leguizamo make up for the cast's general lack of charisma, as they're eminently watchable and sell even the silliest of dialogue. Though the piece is certainly self-aware, it's also really sincere and it establishes a strong sense of character for its central figure. In fact, Papa NoÃ«l actually has a relatively convincing character arc which prevents his inclusion from feeling as half-baked as it may initially seem. Although the flick sometimes comes closer to feeling like 'Paul Blart: Mall Cop (2009)' than 'Die Hard (1988)' (particularly when it comes to most elements not directly associated with Santa), it features plenty of well-choreographed and exciting set-pieces that revel in all the gory mayhem you could want. The action never rises to the level of something like 'John Wick (2014)', but it's better than a lot of similar American stuff and it continues the welcome post-'Wick' trend of having clean camera work that favours wider compositions. The movie is really fun when it gets going. It has a few issues here and there, and it's arguably a little too sappy for its own good, but it's an entertaining actioner with a strong central performance and several accomplished set-pieces.

"Violent Night" is a satirical, extremely violent dark comedy about the "real" Santa Claus looking to save a little girl and her family as they're being held hostage by a group of military trained criminals. David Harbour is simply perfect as the bad ass Santa gone all out wild on the criminals. Just imagine "Die Hard" meets "Home Alone" meets Jason from "Friday The 13th" movies, add tons of violent gory deaths with tongue firmly planted in cheek and you'll get an idea what this movie is all about.\nThis is not masterpiece theater so if you're expecting something profound, please look elsewhere.\n"Violent Night" is good holiday gory fun and those of us who enjoy this type of humor (pitch black humor) will certainly enjoy it very much! 9 out of 10!

Isn't it fantastic when everything you love nicely comes together? Especially around Christmas! What I like to do most during the holiday period is watching at least one - preferably more - Christmas horror movies, but the two mainstream non-horror Christmas movies that I've seen the most (that everyone has seen the most, for that matter) are "Die Hard" and "Home Alone".\n"Violent Night" may not be a genuine horror movie, but it's excessively violent for sure, and - moreover - it's a love letter to the two aforementioned cinematic Christmas landmarks! Tommy Wirkola, who brought us the refreshing "Dead Snow", goes mainstream with this thrill-ride of an actioner about Santa Clause - the real one - battling a small army of evil scoundrels and protecting a cute girl and her rotten wealthy family during a heist/home invasion. It's not very original, it's not particularly sophisticated, but it sure is a lot of fun.\nCertain ideas and gimmicks in the script are genius, like Santa having a Viking background, the casting of Beverly D'Angelo as a loathsome hag of a matriarch, or the killing of thugs with Christmas attributes like candy canes or electric lights. Other parts are clichÃ©d and/or sentimental (but mandatory), like the overlong "true meaning of Christmas" conversations, but that's just a minor default. The "John Wick" type of battle in the bar is dÃ©jÃ -vu but nonetheless exciting, especially because it's to the cheesy tones of Bryan Adams' "Christmas Time". There are other jolly great songs on the soundtrack, like from Slade and Burl Ives, and a great role for John Leguizamo as Ã¼ber-villain "Scrooge".

Is definitely NOT for under 13. Have many weird comebacks, yet enjoyable, to Die Hard and Home Alone combined. David Harbour delivers an excellent rendition of a Santa really worthy yo be a Mortal Kombat One character; John Legizamo is excellent too
After a thousand gunshots the movie somehow still hold many plot holes (pun intended), but who cares when you are enjoying Finish Him combos.
The only really bad part is trying to make an action movie and go with the trend of extra violent extra gory extra ketchup blood sprinkling all over the camera and limbs and heads rolling around.
I will enjoy it one more time some other christmas in the future.

It's always terrible when you see a concept that has potential, but then is destroyed by the script and by the directing. This film is precisely and instance of that. Home Alone has more actual violence than this. Sure, Violent Christmas has violence and gore, but it's not truly violent, because there is nothing at stake, it's empty of thrills and its so incredibly dumbed down and bland that only a very very specific public will find this good. The gore is not shocking at all, the psychological violence is null, and the characters have lines that are trying to pay tribute to Die Hard or Home Alone, but just sound like they were written by a 5 year old. There is good stupid and bad stupid and this is clearly in the bad camp. Good concept, absolutely terrible execution. Makes you wonder if the script is actually good, but then the studio came in and completely destroyed it. This film could easily be PG-13, it doesn't offend or shock anyone more than home alone does. Pathetic waste of money and a good idea.

This movie turned out suprisingly entertaining. It was much better than I expected. I ignored this movie for a few weeks but when I saw reviews in IMDB, I decided to watch it. And I'm glad I did.
Think of this as amalgamation of Die Hard, Home Alone & Santa Clause movies. It is a very different take on Santa. A Santa whose inner animal has been unleashed. And while it is gory in many areas, it never truly takes itself seriously. The movie has plenty of comedy thrown here and there. Some good, some terrible. But all-in-all, it was entertaining.
So, if you don't take this movie seriously and accept it for what it is - ie. Pure mindless entertainment - then you won't be disappointed.
SUMMARY: A different take on a Christmas movie and Santa Clause. It's entertainment not for kids.

The 2022 "Christmas" movie VIOLENT NIGHT was mis-marketed a year ago as ads made it appear that this was just another "slasher" flick, when...in fact...it is a fun action flick that settles the DIE HARD Christmas movie debate once and for all.
Compared to VIOLENT NIGHT, DIE HARD is not a Christmas movie for VIOLENT NIGHT (which is a DIE HARD knock-off) is MOST DEFINITELY a Christmas Movie, but instead of former Cop John McClane thwarting bad guys, it is SANTA CLAUS.
Yes, you read that right, Santa Claus.
Director Tommy Wirkola got the idea for VIOLENT NIGHT when watching another Christmas Classic - HOME ALONE. He thought that the traps Kevin sets up for the crooks would really do some physical damage to people and decided to make a movie that did just that...add a dash of "Die Hard with Santa Claus" and...voila...you got yourself a fun action flick.
David Harbour (STRANGER THINGS) hits just the right notes as a burned out Santa Claus who just wants to get through the night, but when he is stranded in an isolated compound (when his reindeer are scared away by gunfire) he must decide to stay and help or stay out of the way.
Jon Leguizamo (MOULIN ROUGE) is the "Hans Gruber" of this piece - a mercenary named SCROOGE and he is a "good enough" villain. While Leah Brady is "charming enough" as the little girl that Santa decides to help. All the rest of the hostages and mercenaries (including CHRISTMAS VACATION's Beverly D'Angelo) are underwritten "cannon fodder" for the action that takes place.
And...that is just fine as this is an action/comedy flick, so the enjoyment lies in the creativity that Santa (and others) use in dispatching the bad guys. Candy Canes, Christmas Stars, Ice Skates and...yes...SnowThrowers are all used to the advantage of the good guys (and the ultimate demise of the bad guys).
It's not going to win any Oscars, but Violent Night is a fun "anti-Holiday" action film that the older folks in the crowd will enjoy later at night after the kiddo-s go to bed.
Letter Grade: B
7 stars (out of 10) and you can take that to the Bank(ofMarquis)
P. S.: Violent Night is streaming for free (with your Amazon Prime subscription) or you can rent or own it in many of the usual ways.

Title says it all... yeah its gore, maybe a bit over which drag downs.
Kinda some 90s guy wake up... hey what were all the best movies in the 90s? Both from Santa claus (aka "Santa Claus, the movie"), Die Hard (of course), Home Alone (well, no brainer if you want to do a holiday parody)....
Not seen Thor, but seen Vikings.... so can grab some paralells. However I believed St. Nicolaus were Turkish... but maybe a viking that found a new way in TUrkey...
Nope not your tear wet movie... And ABSOLUTELY should maybe be rated 18+. But definetly a movie to watch before/in christmas with a cag of beer, and good friends have experienced the fine movies of the 90s.

One thing about me, I'm not big about Christmas at all, I used to be super excited for it as a kid (as most kids are) but nowadays it's just an average holiday for me, and I don't like a lot of Christmas movies or Christmas music at all, however this one was a pleasant exception and surprise, being released last year starring David Harbour of Stranger Things fame, I wasn't sure what to expect, but it was a worthwhile 2 hours.
This film takes an exceptionally interesting approach to the idea of a "Scrooge", or a character such as The Grinch, who will do anything he can to get rid of Christmas, John Leguizamo gives an incredible performance as this villain, who just wants Christmas to be abolished.
It's filled with great humor and brilliant action scenes, extremely self-aware and reminiscent of "Home Alone" which it even references itself, and Santa fighting people was not what I expected, but it delivered in the best possible ways.
Violent Night was a great, fun movie for this time of year, and it gets an A-

Really boring. Had to fast forward so many times...
The main character is hollow despite a much too long introduction. He has no consideration for his wife and is a living clichÃ©, so to speak.
It reminded me the Charles Bronson Death Wish movies. It's as bad, just visually better.
John Woo needed money but wasn't interested, obviously.
Joel Kinnaman has been better.
And the story requires more than a suspension of belief. Steven Seagal movies could feel realistic compared to this one.
It's a mockery of an action movie, without any humor or irony. Just very bad.
Such a disappointment...
Not recommended.

The question: Can John Woo sustain interest in an Christmas-set action movie conducted almost completely in silence?
The answer: Not really, no. But he certainly gives it a bloody good go, and after the tedious first half when our grieving father (who has his voicebox blown out early, hence the title) trains himself to be a superman to avenge his dead son, there is a number of impressive fight scenes during the intense climax involving cars, guns, martial arts, knives... the works.
To get there though, you'll have to wade through a whole load of soapy melodrama involving the deceased kid and the protagonist's non-existent chemistry with his wife. What makes it even more tough is the aforementioned absence of proper dialogue from the movie, so it's very hard to relate to this couple who can't even properly communicate their feelings to each other.
Oh well. I can't help thinking the film would've been better if they'd ditched the stupid 'silence' gimmick and just done a straight action flick. Plus a bit more humour would've be nice... apart from the bizarre opening sequence involving hero wearing a Rudolf jumper whilst chasing the bad guys, there's not much funny here at all.
5/10 mostly for the last half-an-hour or so... once you get there, decide for yourself if it was worth it or not.

I had intended to watch this movie in theaters, but there were too many other movies I chose to pay for in theaters and missed out. It may have been good I did. I finally saw this on a streaming service and I was blown away. First, I usually run my sound system at level 20. I thought my ears were messed up and turned it to 25 and still heard very little. I had no idea this movie has nearly no dialogue. While movies have been able to pull this off for effect and purpose, I don't see why no other character in the movie could say anything. Lots of texting and sign language. I guess John Woo was challenged to direct a movie with no actual dialogue.\nSecond, this movie, while cliche to the max, could have been way more entertaining. Everyone loves a revenge / payback movie. However, this was a complete mess. The storytelling was all over the place, and without anyone actually talking, you, the viewer are left trying to learn how to read body language and texts. Third, this is a huge drop off for both Kinnaman who I loved in Altered Carbon Season 1 - IMO, the best single season in Sci-Fi TV history, and John Woo who directed Face / Off.\nLastly, the ending of this movie was more of a comedy than anything. I really don't know if John Woo was trolling the studio for the ending or what. The action scenes were ok, but the rest of the movie was a complete mess. The only positive is it's only around 100 minutes so you can watch in one sitting.

I generally like Joel kinnermans films, good solid actor and funny too. I think I thought this was going to be a Death Wish type movie, and have no issues with revenge vigilante films. This was definitely not what I thought. Violent, tick, story, well there is story, so tick. But ultimately this is a grim, grim film of a man in pure raw grief. Could never have a happy ending. In many ways it reminded me of 3 Billboards..... A great film, but half way through you realise that Frances mcCormand would get her revenge but never get her daughter back. We made it to the end, but it's 1 hour 44 minutes of my life that I can never get back. Nothing wrong with the activity, but a grim movie that I (and husband) disliked intensely. You have been warned.

If you can't think of anything to write perhaps don't attempt a feature length movie. This is just another gimmick in the last few years that has been tried as everyone is struggling to come up with new ideas. Maybe black and white films will make a come back next year.\nI like Joel, but here he is about as hamstrung as an actor can be agreeing to be in a film without dialogue. There has to be some sort of savant film maker to be able to pull this off, and Woo is more of an action director, and it just doesn't work.\nSadly, even if you add in a script and additional veteran actors this is still a mess as the story is just simple. Hard Pass.

I should not be surprised by all of the negative reviews. Most people, and yes myself sometimes, cannot handle being silent or simply, being, without background noise. I'll be honest, this movie made me feel everything: sadness, excitement, anticipation, anxiety. I literally cried, laughed, was on the edge of my seat, and cheered. All of that without dialogue. Personally, I was impressed and indeed, I am surprised by all the negative reviews.\nI love the John Wick movies, and I think one mistake is this film being associated with that series. They're not even in the same league, but in a good way. One of the things I appreciated most was how realistic most of the training/revenge was. Yes, I know, some things were still questionable... but it felt possible overall.\nNothing can please everyone, but I had to add my own take on it. I hope it is viewed by the people who will appreciate what was done with this film. I will definitely be watching it again. Loved it.

Watched about 30 mins to realise that it's got to be the worst film ever that Sky have put their name to. Plot sounds good but if you want absolutely no communication between characters or anyone to be fair. Woo should be ashamed to put his name to this movie. Sky should also be ashamed to even put their name to it. Mind you, they haven't got a good track record as it is as many of their films are total flops and are literally "made for TV" films that just shows the calibre. I could go on but in a nutshell the film is so boring that I'd rather cut my grass than watch this film as there would prob more interesting aspects to it.

This is a generic but powerful revenge story that has a satisfying enough ending, although the movie spend too long on the build up.
The main character being unable to speak was a cool twist/concept and overall worked out very well in practice.
The action is on par with the first John Wick movie, not perfect but has some super satisfying moments.
All in all it was a better movie than I expected with such a low score here on imdb, BUT the pacing absolutely killed the arguably good content of the movie.
Act 1 takes up 2/3rds of the whole movie, act 2 is also a bit longer than act 3 making the ending of the movie feel very abrupt, I was surprised when the credits popped up because I was still expecting atleast a couple more scenes to close out the movie.

Nice movie, great story, great action but it needs a new edition where the car and moto scenes seems to be faster. Sometimes it looks like it is really to slow. For the dialog it is normal that has he can't speak there is no dialog which marks the difference between this movie and some others of this kind. Please release a new improved action version don't need to reshoot only need to do a new edition of the actions scenes I'm sure it could be done without a loot or work. I even invite students to edit this movie I'm sure it will be improved and raise the stars at least 2 in 10. I really can't understand how they released it this way.

Could silent night, be the world's first art house action movie? Directed by the action, Master John Woo who spent nearly 20 years making historical drama films in China returns to the genre that put him on the map in the first place. Nobody can dispute the peerless action drama of the likes of hard boiled, hard target and face off. But those were all long time ago.
I don't know why he decided to make another American movie after such a long hiatus, but he is back with an intriguing idea of doing a film with no dialogue at all. There are a few moments of showing newspaper cuttings or texts to add a little bit of flavour, but he wanted to come up with an idea of explaining an entire story with no dialogue, and it works. The idea of a bereaved father going for revenge and slowly coming up with his plan is really intriguing and Woo does it extremely well. Let's be honest a lot of action dialogue is really there to set up the conflict and is often criticised for being cheesy.
The problem is after an opening action scene when there is nothing except seeing the father train there isn't enough in this film. It could've really of done with a big action sequence in the middle to reassure you. With no funny dialogue no plot twist you've seen all of this done before in a more entertaining way and without the dialogue no matter how well done it is it is, I'm sorry to say, a bit dull. When the action comes, it's good, but it isn't peak Woo.
It turns out there's a reason why we have dialogue in movies after all.

So good loved it. Love the plot and everything. It was the perfect amount of action, and you really just could connect with each character. A great movie for action lovers. This movie really puts you in the edge of your seat. It was done so well. 10/10 One of the best action movies I've seen in a long time. So if you are looking for a cool movie to watch with your action loving family I would 100% recommend this movie. It is just pure action no gore and other stuff. Just a great action movie. But there is also just enough not action where you get to know the characters and get to feel like your in the movie.

Given that the original film is such an iconic piece of american cinema released in the height of the 80s and the launch platform of superstar Tom Cruise, making a sequel seemed a daunting task and at times an unnecesary one, but this film proves otherwise as the final product is a masterfully crafted movie that respects the original film and is able to surparsse it in every aspect: production,acting, dialogue,etc.\nIn order to fully appreciate this movie, a theather is neccesary as it is the only tool that conveys adrenaline Rush of an aerial dogfight.\nA passion project in Tony scott's memory.

I could not brow an emotional attachment with the characters in this film as I did with the first one. Tom Cruise carries the movie most of the way through but you could near say with a bunch of cliche scenes that were a throw back from the first movie.
I could say that the movie felt slapped together more for a cash grab rather than put together a great follow up script from part 1.
It was the usual script where they throw the manual out the window and let's do it the way that would get 99% thrown out of a training school whether it be a teacher or student but it's ok for Maverick to work right outside the laws that everyone else is given and get away with it with no action taken.
I liked two scenes in it and one was when Tom was initially in the bar and saw his ex wingman's son playing the piano and the scene where he met up with Val Kilmer. The rest was predictable and nothing new added to the story from part 1.
It was good but I really felt it was more of a let's run the 2nd movie to grab some extra cash rather than bringing anything new to make it more intriguing. Good and I sat through it but wouldn't go out of my way to watch it again.

This is a typical American overproduction. It proves that if you throw enough cash at it, you can make any film spectacular. And truly, the special effects are stunning, time and again. Other than that: this movie contains just too much nonsense. Too much coincidence, over-the-top displays of heroism and plots that keep on repeating themselves\nYet, it's difficult to get bored, watching this movie. Of course, they throw in the mandatory romance although it has nothing to do with the facts at hand.\nBeing totally honest, you'll have to admit that you wouldn't have lost anything worthwhile if you missed this movie. It's just another costly time-waster.

A terrific thrilling film which works its socks off to entertain you. Technically its spectacular the sound design conveying the awesome speed and power of aviation, the cinematography and cockpit footage is second to none and leaves you baffled how they achieved it. The new group of characters are memorable and the film does a good job at developing them and their stories while also allowing Tom Cruise to still shine in the lead role. The film has some nice call backs to the original but it's more just a just a repeat of the first movie. The film is pretty fresh these days in being very unapologetic and patriotic in it's themes and imagery. While it's a pretty great film there's a few moments where it tries a bit too hard to pay homage to the original, it also had me think it pushed things a bit too far towards the end that I didn't quite believe it. Overall though a fine entertaining movie with some amazing aviation scenes and Tom Cruise giving one of his best performances.

I really don't understand all the fuss around this sequel.
It's completely predictable, in every scene, by anyone (even by a child).
I grow up but Tom Cruise hasn't and he's ridiculous acting like this. That's Peter Pan syndrome, man!
The movie is also unnecessarily long.
I do acknowledge that I enjoyed the first Top Gun more ALSO because I was younger and less "demanding", but at least that movie was brand new and in line with those years. This one is not, it's out of time, no matter the efforts to update it
If that's the best Hollywood can offer nowadays, then it's a well deserved epitaph. Maybe directors (and actors) shouldn't go on strike against AI, but rather prove themselves still capable of something either good and new. So definitely not Too Gun Maverick!

Not much diff from original movie. Poor acting by all, same old script as in must take out an adversary. Same music at beginning as original. Cruise can't act or the other key players for that matter. Old resentments linger amongst the players. Superiors don't like Maverick. The script overall is tired and predictable. The only way to take out a uranium site is to send in the fighters. Yet they send in tomahawk missiles to take out the entire air field prior to the jets going in? Yes it's a mediocre movie and this love affair with a bar maid is old and tired. Racing his bike trying to keep up with a jet on take off is old as well.

The fact that no info was given about the "enemy" at all made it feel like it wasn't a real battle but a staged performance or videogame. Even if animosity isn't the most important point, it felt fake as if driving the other planes, fighting on the other side, aren't real people. About the mission we only got to know the trajectory of the planes and their job but there was no backstory.
The main plot, between Mav and Rooster was consistent and the two actors had interesting chemistry. On the other hand, the love story felt rushed and the female character felt like a prop. The love story, although secondary, isn't supposed to feel like a box checked from the Hollywood movie guidelines but the lack of depth, kind of made it look like that.
Finally, all the actors used too much makeup it really through me off. Between that and the fake tan, they definitely didn't look like they were on the job as pilots in the navy. Felt staged and amateur, a classic Hollywood mistake though.
The effect are now much better than in the first one, but that's just a consequence of the evolution of technology, yet it made the movie makers lazy, they relied on the great visuals. At the end, the first one may be less grandiose in terms of effects, but it makes up in authenticity.

Perfect action epic that hits all the right buttons. Amazing flight and action scenes that aren't CGI mixed with a good amount of emotional content that can actually be quite touching and we'll you up at times. Storyline is what it should be with a bit of an unexpected, bad a** ending (while also being what you would expect from the Maverick character). What more could you want from a Top Gun sequel? I'd argue it's even better than the first watching through today's eyes, and I was thoroughly pleased at the half way point of the movie. Normally I don't want a sequel to a great movie, but the odd time they hit a home run - this is a grand slam.

Top Gun: Maverick stands out as a sequel that skillfully blends nostalgia with a modern cinematic touch. While the film brings back the familiar thrill of high-speed aviation, it introduces a new dimension to the narrative by keeping the enemy shrouded in mystery. This choice to not define the antagonist is more of a subtle nuance than a central theme, offering a fresh perspective on conflict depiction.
Primarily, the film serves as a homage to the original 1990's "Top Gun," targeting an audience who grew up with the first installment. It's a celebration of the past, aimed at fans who have aged alongside the movie's hero, portrayed once again by Tom Cruise. However, for those who didn't experience the first film, "Maverick" might feel like a relic of a bygone era, echoing a time when such stories were in their prime.
The charm of "Top Gun: Maverick" lies in its ability to transport viewers back to the days of the original film, yet it also struggles to fully engage those seeking a contemporary action experience. The movie walks a fine line between honoring its roots and adapting to modern filmmaking standards.
In essence, "Top Gun: Maverick" is a journey through time, revisiting iconic characters in a world that has evolved yet remains anchored in its origins. It's a film that nostalgically recalls the glory of its predecessor while navigating new skies, offering a ride that is enjoyable but may not resonate with everyone.

I will not get in to the historical inaccuracies, as in a lot of historical movies history is adapted for dramatic purposes. It is Hollywood after all and especially for big budget movies the goal is to make a lot of money. Beautiful Trailer.
My main criticism is the portrayal of Napoleon. Of course all who knew him are long gone and many accounts are subjective, so we have to make do with that information.
But I can not imagine that a man who ends up on top after all the chaos of the French Revolution, whose generals and soldiers stay loyal to him after all the battles and blood, wasn't an enormous charismatic man.
And that's where the film completely fails for me. You can hate him, admire him, love him, belittle him as Wellington, but the film makes him, and his relationship with Josephine, uninteresting and dull, and as the title is Napoleon, that was my feeling leaving the cinema. A bit more effort of Mr Scott and Mr. Phoenix to know the character and history would probably have added value.

This film is getting most of its hate because it is slow paced, very long, and doesnt live up to the hype the trailer sets up for it. The most epic scenes in the film are shown in the trailer. There are a lot of reason to not love this movie. I especially have many reasons to hate this movie, i had to write a seven page paper on it.\nBut after all the bad is said and done, this movie still stands REALLY strong as a Napolean biopic. It is so well done. It looks great. I care a lot about looks. And this film looks great. Some of the battle scenes alone merit this film being awesome, even though they make up only a fifth of the film. There is a lot great here. Great performances. Great cinematography. Great dialogue writing. It feels incredibly real to its period.\nThe pace is slow, but i still found it very entertaining. MY expectations were low. Thats maybe why i found it more enjoyable then others.

I actually fell asleep somewhere in the middle of the film.
I couldn't get a grip on the story. It felt all over the place. Also, I had an issue with English accents on supposedly French characters. The only believable character I felt that fit in was the Austrian Ambassador portrayed by Tom Godwin. Other than that, costumes were nice, set and dÃ©cor was nice as well.
There are so many stories and angles that could have been covered in this film. So many opportunities to delve into the history of Napoleon. So many wonderful actors with no foundation to build from. All missed.
What did I just see? A big budget film without a penny to stand on.

Was initially intimidated by the critical reviews.... Elected to see it over the holiday and glad. While not a documentary and borderline fiction at times it remained entertaining. And furthermore motivated me to immerse myself in the historical side. For me the notion of Napoleon was very much folklore and carried beyond the man. Thus, I felt the acting of the leads was phenomenal in depicting a characters outside the norm. Potentially taking some liberties, which could be expected with a motion picture and actors with certain depths. I did find it peculiar the amount of English accents....pondering if there were actually French people in the movie. The action sequences were assisted by a limited score but also quite gory for those unaware.

Alright, so I've read a few reviews complaining about how this movie should actually be a mini tv series (at the very least) and I couldn't agree more.
But based on this premise, we all know that a movie about Napoleon, as a whole, is simply impossible. There's just too much to be compromised. Yet, Ridley Scott aims to do that and succeeds to the extent it is actually achievable.
How does anyone expect a movie that's supposed to include politics, historical facts, war, death, romance, drama, and character development be rounded perfectly?
As a matter of fact, I think the movie manages to touch a wide array of themes that make up the life of Napoleon. Surely, the help of the audience is needed in filling the gaps in between.
I don't think Napoleon was dull or cold. I think they very well portrayed his frustration derived from his height and his tyrannical attitude as a response in regulating his inferiority complex.
All in all, I think we, as audience, got more than we could have expected from such a movie that shoots against all odds.
After all, we're talking about one of the most complex biographies out there.

Yes it's been cut short to make it more manageable at the cinema. Yes it skips through a lot. Yes there's historical inaccuracies. But overall it's an entertaining watch, with good battle scenes. Some of the battle scenes could have been explained more, definitely a lot of context but that's natural when you cut out so much from the original run time. So many armchair critics being overly negative about this film, psychoanalysing every minor details and expecting to go to the cinema and get a GCSE history lesson. It's not a history documentary but I personally go to the cinema for entertainment and I was entertained. Suspend your disbelief, grab some popcorn and try to relax.

Sadly Sir Ridley Scott's film doesn't do Napoleon justice. Joaquin Phoenix seems miscast or perhaps the screenplay makes him play the character on one note: morose, surly, un-charismatic. He was much more compelling as the tyrannical Roman emperor Commodus in "Gladiator", also directed by Scott. As Josephine, Vanessa Kirby only appears in some brief scenes and their relationship isn't very passionate.
