There are some blatant historical errors: Napoleon wasn't present at the execution of Marie-Antoinette, Robespierre was guillotined not (as in the film, I think) beaten to death, Napoleon has an imaginary meeting before the Battle of Waterloo and, most blatantly, he wasn't born in February 1768 as he states, but on 15 August 1769. In fact, 1768 - though in May - was the year when his native Corsica officially became French.
The battle scenes are certainly spectacular, and superbly choreographed. However, their choreography perhaps makes them look too elegant, not drenched in blood and gore (maybe my attention wandered). The choreography is excellent in the Court scenes, with beautiful dances - making an ironic contrast with the battles. Those are the only scenes in the film that I really enjoyed.
Understandably, it's impossible even to condense Napoleon's biography in 2Â½ hours. We see nothing for instance about the Napoleonic Code, which had a far-reaching influence on civil law, or his pioneering, and perhaps grandiose, town planning projects. So it would have been helpful to caption various scenes on the screen, explaining the nature of the battles and sketching his origins, earlier life, other achievements and rise to power.

Literally. That is all this film is - a dull, time-wasting, 3-hour tour of French life during revolutionary times. There is no comedy. There is no punch. The action sequences are beyond tepid - they are entirely forgettable and very few and far between. By far, the dullest film of Ridley Scott's career.
The closest comparison I can give you is, this is a lot like Lincoln; only, the starring historic-figure is a lot less interesting or redeeming.
Want to waste 3-hours of your life?
No comedy. I repeat, NO COMEDY.
NO ACTION
NO NUDITY
NO PACE
NO PLOT
JUST, life, in old-France, starring one of the worst historic figures one could ever wish to spend 3-hours with.

Financially, Ridley Scott rates one of the most successful directors in the history of cinema - so I expected more from this film. I am not even talking about historical inaccuracies like failing to heed Napoleon's young age (23) when he recaptured Toulon (Joaquin looks well in his 40s, too old for the part from the outset); the fact that in reality Josephine was older than Bonaparte, though Vanessa Kirby looks young and wearing a sexily short hairstyle probably caused by her time in the clink, otherwise completely out of tune with late 19th Century women's hairstyles and wigs); the unpardonable failure to mention the importance of Rouget de Lille's national anthem, and how Napoleon used it repeatedly to arouse his troops' nationalistic fervor and preserve their loyalty; or the fact that Napoleon ordered his troops to live off the land by plundering property, raping, and killing civilians, with the booty then transferred to France; Napoleon's famously enigmatic call "Soldiers! From atop these pyramids 40 centuries look down on you" is ignored, which is a pity because it leaves out Napoleon's extensive general knowledge, ability to convey ideas in stylistic phrases, his knowledge of his soldiers, down to privates whose children's names he carefully memorized, and the fact that he was an avid reader of all manner of books, notably the classics.
Instead, Napoleon is depicted by Ridley Scott as a power-driven, callous military leader who engaged in rambunctious sex with Josephine, and cared for little else. His early years in his birthplace Ajaccio, Corsica, to which he returned from the military academy in mainland France with plans of ruling, along with his numerous brothers and relatives, but from where he was ousted in embarrassing defeat by local ruler Paoli, and never returned to the island; his heavy island accent that his classmates at the military academy ridiculed and which reportedly only increased his determination to outshine them; the fact that mother Letitia and brother Lucien just appear and disappear, no mention is made of brother Joseph to whom he entrusted the throne of Spain, all such omissions make Scott's Napoleon a carboard cutout of a character.
To compound matters, Joaquin Phoenix delivers a bafflingly wooden performance that gives Napoleon the vocal intonations of a 21st Century American when he opens his mouth, about as out of place as the multivaried, noisy, meaningless soundtrack.
The film also expects the viewer to know history, a very high demand indeed. For instance, it mentions the Prussians in the Battle of Waterloo but fails to explain that Prussia is today the eastern part of Germany. Furthermore, it fails to acknowledge just how fast Napoleon moved his troops for surprise attacks in far flung parts of Europe, which Napoleon saw as a unit - prompting many historians to credit Napoleon as the seed-planter for today's European Union.
The worst flaw is the mish-mash sountrack, with a song by Edith Piaf, what sounds like South American Indian chants (Napoleon never went near South America), some funereal music, some live beat, too modern, cacophony - all very annoying and disruptive.
The best is the cinematography by Dariusz Wolski, with the battle of Austerlitz as the cherry on the film's rather elephantine cake.
I left the movie feeling that the Duke of Wellington really wiped the ground with Napoleon at Waterloo. In truth, it was a much closer battle than portrayed in the film and it was the Prussians who came to Wellington's rescue and prevented Napoleon fleeing under cover of night, with the USA as intended destination.
For a serious, knowlegeable analysis of the motivations, character, relations and other facets of the man Napoleon Bonaparte, do yourself a favor and see the documentary THE RISE AND FALL OF NAPOLEON: THE MAN WHO WOULD RULE EUROPE on Youtube.

Ridley Scott's latest historical masterpiece, "Napoleon," initially promised a riveting exploration of Joaquin Phoenix's portrayal of the iconic French emperor. However, the anticipation built on paper quickly dissolves into a rollercoaster of disappointment, echoing recent missteps in Scott's repertoire like "The Last Duel" and "House of Gucci."
The film's 2-hour and 38-minute runtime becomes an endurance test for the audience, provoking frequent watch-checking amid a narrative that unfolds at an agonizing pace. Attempting to encapsulate a multitude of events results in overwhelming frustration, suggesting that "Napoleon" might have thrived as an episodic miniseries, providing room for a more immersive historical exploration.
However, amidst the film's pitfalls, there's a silver lining in its awe-inspiring battle scenes that demand a strong stomach. Vanessa Kirby steals the spotlight with a stellar performance, overshadowing the lackluster portrayal by Phoenix. Rumors swirl about Kirby's potential involvement in Marvel's Fantastic 4 film, hinting at her ascent to more significant roles.
Phoenix's performance, though not devoid of merit, echoes shades of his Arthur character from "Joker" (2019), creating an incongruence with his mid-century Frenchman portrayal. Amidst a predominantly British-accented cast, Phoenix's portrayal leans towards laziness, emphasizing hyperbolic "Napoleon" tendencies rather than exploring deeper motivations.
The breakneck speed of the narrative allows little room for character depth, resulting in a biopic with thematic blandness. Despite a handful of remarkable battle scenes, "Napoleon" falters, adding another setback to Ridley Scott's otherwise distinguished filmography. The journey is tumultuous, but the cinematic odyssey of "Napoleon" will leave audiences questioning the choices made on and off the battlefield.

As a fan of racing I have certain standards for racing in movies. I went into this movie thinking it was going to be okay at best, but this movie was a pleasant surprise The story was quite fun to follow, if a little predictable at times. The characters weren't very deep, but decent enough. There was no character that made me want to rub my head into the couch anytime they spoke. The fact it was a glorified advertisement shown through a few times like all the times they say, "It's not a game. It's a simulator." That got on my nerves quite a bit. Besides that the racing was pretty decent. Some of the passes were way too easy, but it was nowhere near as bad as some than movies. It isn't Lightning McQueen cutting through 40 cars in a few laps then being stuck at the front for the rest of the race. I thought cars and races looked pretty cool and the failure montage was fun. In summary, It is a pretty good movie and would suggest watching it.

It's flashy, it's stylish, and it's full of clichÃ©, cringe inducing dialog and writing, and completely fabricated nonsense. The writers have never watched a race or even bothered researching the topic before throwing this thing together. And their character tropes and archs were exhausted decades ago on children's cartoons. I think the "bad guy" (why does there have to be a bad guy in a racing movie?) literally belongs on a Captain Planet episode.
The acting is subpar at best. Stranger Things guy was alright, as was Jann's actor, but Orlando Bloom was just...weird in this, and the actors for the "bad guy" (he's bad because...he's bad, ok?) and all the other drivers were just atrocious.
And the best part. If you have any knowledge of motorsport or the laws of physics you may consider this a really bad comedy. Suddenly this guy who's never driven a car knows a better line than people who do this for a living AND spend time on simulators? Oh and his line is the outside of a dry track.
Ugh I could go on, but I'm tired. So here's 4 stars for making a pretty movie.

It's one of those movies, that you can't hate, but you can't like, too.
There is nothing particularly wrong with the movie. It looks good, the story overall is ok, too. But it feels kind of... Empty? Pointless? I did not feel much of a challenge in Jann reaching his dream, even though, I'm pretty sure, it was not that easy. Since there is no challenge, and since we already know how things will end (thanks to marketing) - there is absolutely no tension, there are no real stakes, there is no... Excitement. Which is core of racing, is it not?
I remember people complaining that anime "Overtake!" lacked excitement in its racing, which was a valid criticism, but, at the least, it had something besides that: character development. It was not perfect, but it was there. Gran Turismo lacks even that. Or at least, I have not noticed any development. Besides, maybe, Jack Salter starting to believe that gamer can become a racer, after all.
The original story is something that can inspire. That's what all the marketing was talking about: "achieve your dream". But achieving a dream is not easy. There are struggles involved there. Yes, they probably will not be as intense as being in literal war, but they will be there. A movie - is a great opportunity to dramatize those struggles, to make you feel the tension of going against the flow.
This movie fails at that. Unless you think integrating elements from a game user interface equates to dramatization. I will forget this movie by tomorrow.

This was an incredible story about a young man and his willingness to strive in the race car industry. It goes to show that people who play video games or anyone with a hidden talent needs to have the ability to shine.\nA loving, heart racing, action packed race car movie. Tragedy can come for anyone, but it's what you do with it that matters. I would have never thought I would have loved a race car movie so much. I never grew up watching or playing with race cars. But a good movie Deserves its recognition.\nOrlando bloom,David harbour and Archie are absolute rockstars. Passion needs to be recognized inside and outside the home as well.

If you've seen the trailer, you've seen the movie. It's cut like a video game, super choppy and fast. Filmed like a bunch of commercials cut together. The first half is definitely one of the worst first halves of a movie I've ever seen. Cardboard characters. The actors are all phoning it in. So boring and predictable. Everyone seems super tired and weary to be in the movie. The plot is paint-by-numbers. Surprising, because I love all of the director's other movies.\nHowever, the 2nd half does get better. Better editing, more emotion and better character development.\nAll that said, I'm 48 so if you're younger it's possible you have the short attention span most of the movie is tailored for. My kids ages 8 and 10 loved it.

I love SIM Racing and I am bog fan of motor tacing, but this movie is so bad, it is unbelievable! Bad acting, totally unrealistic racing! Don't spent your time watching it! Go and watch Le Mans with Steve McQueen or Grand Prix with Jame Garner. This movie is just a marketing tool for Gran Turismo and Nissan. Gran Turismo is a great video game, though. It is a shame, because the movie is a based on a true story, but it appears to me to be made only for one purpose: to make money. I really can not unterstand why Orlando Bloom and David Harbour agreed to be in this movie. I hope they earned at least a lot of money because this should be quoted as worst movie of their careers.

Who would have thought that this movie would be so incredible! It has everything and more! How did they pull this off? Passion, courage, emotional strength, human spirit, love, drama, performances of a LIFETIME! All of it expertly choreographed to create the greatest movie of the year and maybe of the last decade. Admittedly, I went into it thinking it was going to be bad like everything else that comes out today in Hollywood, especially since it was a movie about a video game. But here I am after watching it feeling like it literally changed my life. How did they pull this off??? Holy hell it was good. Good job everyone that put effort into this!

This movie has everything you should want. A good plot that is even better knowing it's based off a true story, a thrilling experience filled with twists and turns!! Another great performance from David Harbour that will probably be overlooked by many. The rest of the cast did a nice job as well. I personally felt very connected to this movie as a gamer, to see what an unbelievable, fairytale experience Jann had to go from racing a simulation to a real race car. The visual effects annd visuals were very nicely done, where you could tell this was a major box-office film, and they put that amount of work into it. The soundtrack fits the movie perfectly. Even if you are not a gamer, if you have good movie taste, of action and being on the edge of your seat, this movie is for you!! I give the movie a 9.5 out of 10 stars!!

Our entire family liked which includes a 12 and 16 year old, me and my husband. It is an inspirational story. He is from working class family has big dreams which seem impossible, against the odds kind of thing. Main character actor was very believable and likable. Made you want to root for him. Others did great too, 2nd racer was very believable in his cocky role. Had veteran actors Djimon Hounsou and Orlando Bloom, always great. Def add to lineup of inspirational sports movies, if you like the based on true story ones, you will like it. No vulgarity but some intensity with the racing, crashes and without spoiling just know there are a couple extreme moments, may need to talk with younger kids about but it is a dangerous sport. While my teens liked, I think younger or even older would like as well. First movie I have seen like this that involves young people from so many countries, I like that, and would enjoy more of them, especially because our world is already so interconnected. So thank you to the movie studios and game. Never heard of this until Netflix, which is a shame, would have been cool to see in theaters. Seems like they need to market movies more equally.

I was not familiar with this story at all. I am not into gaming or racing. Really could not care less about either one. However, I really enjoyed this movie. A LOT. I loved the movie, Rocky, too even though I was not (and still am not) a fan of boxing. This movie stands on its own as one that explores family relationships, being your own person, overcoming fear, and meeting challenges head on. The casting was excellent as was the acting. My only disappointments are that (in my opinion) there was not a memorable music score or impressive cinematography which, along with the notion that I haven't decided if Gran Turismo would warrant my watching it a second time now that I know the ending is why I gave this film 8 rather than 10 stars.

Sequels always suck. But this one doesn't disappoint one iota. Bravo!
The beginning is so well crafted to shift the spotlight onto Spider Gwen. Her character keeps the Spiderverse accessible the female fanbase. Something that most fanboys won't recognize. I'm re-watching this movie with my 12 yr old daughter and she is transfixed.
The whole adolescent and coming of age segments were also excellent. Lauren Velez, Bryan Henry and Shea Whigham really deliver an emotional anchor.
Animation was pushed to the delicious limit and beyond. They have given the audience a feast to digest and happily dissect many times over.
How in the universe do they follow this up with the 3rd?

Following up the massive success of Into the Spider-Verse, Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse takes the story further into the multiverse of everyone's favorite Wall Crawler. Achieving some of the greatest animation put to film, every moment of this movie is masterfully crafted to give each character and universe its own unique look and feel. It truly is remarkable how much work went into this, but also unfortunate that it landed the animators in such a difficult work environment. While all of the voice acting is phenomenal, my biggest issue comes in with the characters. First, taking a joke villain like the Spot and turning him into a truly creepy and powerful foe is no small feat and I commend the writers for pulling that off. The issue comes with Spider-Man, all of them. Besides Miles Morales, every version of Spider-Man is perverse with the out of line ideals of the Spider Society. There are no versions of Spider-Man that would ever stand by those ideals and it is wild how every current mainstream Spidey has lost the meaning of what the character stands for. I won't stand on my soapbox for long, but that is an issue I hope gets rectified in future appearances. Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse is an amazing sequel to a spectacular movie and, though I don't love the direction of the characters, I eagerly await the final chapter.

I feel like I've been missing something here, don't get me wrong the film is good but the way it's been hyped I kind of went in thinking it would be some sort of cinematic masterpiece. My hopes were high for this film seeing how well it has been received and the 8.5+ rating it has on imdb but although I enjoyed it I feel a bit underwhelmed. It's kind of what I felt for the first film. It's decent but not amazing. It's been a bit too overhyped in my opinion. I also don't like how long the second film was compared to the first one just for all of it too end up in a cliffhanger. But overall it's a good film that I would recommend.

Probably the best animated film I've ever seen, and unquestionably one of my favorite movies of the year. Like the first movie, the animation style is stunning - I love the vibrant color palette and the blend of hand-drawn elements with CGI. The visuals combined with Metro Boomin's soundtrack make for a euphoric viewing experience. This film is everything a sequel should be, by expanding the universe (or spiderverse in this case) while also delving deeper into the main character arcs. I was immersed in the story and wasn't ready for the movie to end when it did. The final installment of this trilogy can't come soon enough!

I can't remember who let the jinn out of the bottle for the first time with this multiverse extravaganza, but it's definitely the biggest cinematic trait of late. Everything Everywhere All at Once quite capitalised on it last Oscars season, so it's no surprise that the latest Spider-Man animated feature, which used the same tricks first, but maybe in a slightly more shambolic manner, is upping the ante.
What used to be more of an acid trip back in 2018, is now a coherently crazy experience amplified 1000 times. Bearing traces of heavy influence from cyberpunk anime genre, Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse is one hell of a never ending whirlwind of flickering coloured specks and hard beats. Multiply it by a variety of cultural references, a dozen different graphic styles and several languages changing fluidly into one another - and you'll end up with an absolute bomb that will blow your mind, in all ways good and bad.
Visually, this film is a masterpiece. At least in the "we've never seen anything like it" sense. Yep, it's innovative, and probably not as vertigo-inducing as the first part, despite a sickening amount of action. It still doesn't make it easy to follow what's going on, but somehow the film retains your engagement, so you just go with the flow. And that's probably the biggest achievement for something that's quite chaotic and sensory overstimulating.
Still, it feels like by overloading our senses with anime-like extremes, Spider-Man bypasses our prefrontal cortex and goes directly to "the TikTok brain" that's easily captivated by shiny moving things. So we end up having zero complaints eating subpar dialogues, classic cheap tricks like driving tension by artificially induced miscommunication, or single-agenda characters that follow their prescribed paths without deviation natural to real human beings.
I can't deny that it felt good watching this film. But I am left with a tingling concern that it wasn't due to the complexity of emotions or a wide gamut of thoughts that it made us experience, but simply because our brains produced lots of happy chemicals in response to this sensory DDoS attack. Which, technically, is an achievement akin to the discovery of LSD, profound in its influence on the world. But, as with any real world drug, it makes you wonder: can feelings alone be trusted when evaluating the whole experience?
Modern problems require modern solutions. Whether we like it or not, films like this one open a portal to a new era of cinema. Let's see what awaits on the other side.

This movie is soo good it's ridiculous. That's all.
Everything about it is perfect, how it's made, the effects, the plot, the soundtrack, the characters. It carries so much emotion and it takes you on a rollercoaster ride through out the entire movie. You are so connected to the charecters and understand each point of view.
It's exiting, funny, emotional, immersive, original, visually stunning intriguing and unforgettable.
There is no flaw in this movie, nothing could have been done better. Can't wait for the next one, although I have no idea how it will ever top this movie but I have really high expectations!

I briefly reviewed Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse (2018) in one of my posts soon after it was released in theaters, and it seems to me that some people got the idea that I don't like this film. This is not the case. I went to see this film 2 or 3 times when it was playing in theaters. I own it on video. I even have the soundtrack. It's just that I like Incredibles 2 (2018), which was released in the same year, slightly more than Into The Spider-Verse, and I don't think that Into The Spider-Verse is the best Spider-Man movie or the best superhero movie ever. I think that Spider-Man 2 (2004) is still the best Spider-Man movie ever. I would say that both Into The Spider-Verse and Incredibles 2 have replay value. This is something that I can't say about many films that got made in the last two or even three decades. When I watched Into The Spider-Verse for the first time, I felt that something is not quite right with it, although I already realized that it's a special film. Into The Spider-Verse features a number of inspired scenes, appealing and detailed animation, a rather epic story, some good characterization, and many neat details. Still, perhaps the only main character that appealed to me back then is Peter B. Parker because I could relate to this character in a few ways and because he knew what he was doing. Miles Morales, who's the main main character in the film, didn't appeal to me in any way. I didn't even know about Miles Morales before I watched the film. For most of the film, Miles plays the role of comedic relief, and only at the very end does he get to do anything heroic by himself. There's also the fact that Into The Spider-Verse is a very kinetic film, in which almost everything happens fast. Therefore, it has to be seen more than once in order for the viewer to understand and to notice everything that happens in it. So, not only was seeing Into The Spider-Verse for the first time a new and somewhat odd experience for me, I didn't really find any of the main characters truly appealing. However, seeing Across The Spider-Verse in a theater made me like Into The Spider-Verse even more than I already did. First of all, both Miles Morales and Gwen Stacy get more character development in Across The Spider-Verse, thus turning them into more appealing characters. Second of all, many people (especially young men) have already been expressing their sweet hard love for Across The Spider-Verse, and especially for Gwen Stacy, on the internet. A few of them have been calling Across The Spider-Verse the best thing ever. Good for you, guys. But I don't share your euphoria. Perhaps it's because I'm a little more knowledgeable. Therefore, my reviews don't come down to phrases like "Best movie ever!" or "F*ck this movie!". Third of all, the animation style of Across The Spider-Verse is somewhat different from the animation style of Into The Spider-Verse. In some scenes, the animation of Into The Spider-Verse is almost photorealistic. But the animation of Across The Spider-Verse is often almost impressionistic. Both films feature some beautiful and detailed backgrounds. Fourth of all, I wouldn't go so far as to say that Across The Spider-Verse is a better film than Into The Spider-Verse. I think that they're equally impressive, though Across The Spider-Verse is perhaps a more exciting film. Fifth of all, all of the people in the auditorium where I got to see this animated film were adults. Most of them were in their late-twenties, thirties, or early-fourties. Some of them were old people. All of them were enjoying seeing the film a lot. What is going on here? I had a similar peculiar experience when I watched Titanic (1997) in a theater in February of this year. Most of the people in the auditorium were women, mostly young women, and some of them were truly excited and were even crying by the time the film came to an end. When the credits began to roll, these members of the fair sex all began to talk excitedly about the film. All I can say is that James Cameron knows how to make films that appeal to both men and women. No wonder his films bring in so much cash. Sixth of all, seeing Across The Spider-Verse later made me spend half a day on watching Into The Spider-Verse again on video. I watched some scenes several times, and I often paused the movie in order to look at the backgrounds and the character designs. It's true that Gwen Stacy sometimes moves like a ballet dancer in this film too. Before watching Across The Spider-Verse, I barely knew anything about Phil Lord and Christopher Miller because I had no interest in what these filmmakers have done. But, after taking a look at their filmography, it turned out that they worked on several films that I like quite a lot, and I got to see most of their films in theaters.

This is unquestionably the finest animation I've ever witnessed. The colors, lighting, characters, and animation were all extraordinary. Upon the film's commencement, the pace felt exceptionally rapid, demanding vigilant attention. This aligns well with the current generation, accustomed to the brisk nature of TikTok. The film's relentless speed compelled focused and absorbed viewing, making it one of the most remarkable animations I've ever seen. Kudos to all involved. I eagerly anticipate the third installment, hoping it equals or surpasses this excellence. Bravo to everyone involved. Well Done Sony.

You're going to like this movie; it's a cannon event! After reuniting with Gwen Stacy, Brooklyn's full-time, friendly neighborhood Spider-Man is catapulted across the Multiverse, where he encounters a team of Spider-People charged with protecting its very existence. However, when the heroes clash on how to handle a new threat, Miles finds himself pitted against the other Spiders. He must soon redefine what it means to be a hero so he can save the people he loves most.
The film's story doesn't end in this movie but will he continued in another part which makes you think that this part would be a bit slow. However, the film is very engaging and enjoyable all throughout the 2 hours and 20 minutes runtime where it explores many characters and their developments without making the pace slow and boring. The movie was also filled with suprises from cameos to shocking plot twists. It was also really funny especially that they knew exactly where to include jokes. Additionally, the action scenes were so cool keeping the audience attached even more while watching.
The film is just visually stunning; from the comic style animation, to the background, to the colors, to the textures, its just all so appealing. Everysingle frame was so nice to look at. The score and the sound effects were also so good and exciting. The voice actors (Hailee Steinfeld, Oscar Isaac, Shameik Moore, and every other actor) were all great in their respective characters.
Score:8.5/10.

I know this film has been raved about but I just found it to be a poor imitation of the first film. They leaned into the animation too much. It's too much. A couple of scenes were brilliantly done but too many were trying to be clever and over saturated the scenes to the detriment of the film itself. The story was too complicated but by the final third, it was too simple.\nThe end of the film sets up the next film in an interesting way but it doesn't make this the best film or even best animated film of the year. I just hope that they return to the way they did the first film especially with colours and animation.

I really enjoyed this movie. It's been one of my favorite movies of all time. The cinematography is great. An acting was phenomenal. It's like you can feel the characters emotions, and from someone who is read all the books I couldn't be any more happier with the final result of the movie. It's a great movie to sit down and watch with a teenager or preteen . Has slight talk alcohol and mild gore. Very emotional movie and brought me to tears and in the beginning , middle, and end . I recommend the whole hunger, games, franchise, and even the books. Couldn't be any better. Definitely recommend .

The Hunger Games is an amazing movie. The book is better but this is still a really good movie. The Hunger Games is sad, depressing, and scary, but not in a bloody gory way. This movie can be very uncomfortable, but that is what makes this a good movie. If a movie is really sad, then that means it is a good movie because it gives you with strong feelings. The movie has good action and characters, but it is just very uncomfortable to watch. I am excited to watch the sequel, Catching Fire soon. I reccomend this movie to you if you like action and drama. What a good film. In all, I give this a 7.9 out of 10.

By far, to my liking, this is the best film of all the Hunger Games saga. The history is good, the characters are all likable, the photography is also good and, above all, it is entertaining. I found myself at the end wishing for it to go on.
It was a surprise to listen to Rachel's voice and it was even nicer to see that she can act. Violet put an extra value to the film and the Snow character played his part really well. He set foot for the future hateful Snow we all know.
I feel that 7.0 is too low for this film. No way the other Hunger Games game can be better than this one. The other ones get boring at times, this was not the case with this one. Of course this is all in own personal opinion
I strongly recommend this film.
Cheers!

"The Hunger Games" adeptly translates Suzanne Collins' dystopian narrative to the screen, and Jennifer Lawrence's portrayal of Katniss Everdeen is nothing short of exceptional. The film skillfully captures the stark societal contrast between the opulence of the Capitol and the destitution in the Districts, creating a compelling visual landscape.
The movie successfully balances action with emotional resonance, exploring complex themes such as power dynamics and survival strategies. James Newton Howard's musical score enhances the cinematic experience, adding emotional weight to key moments.
The pace keeps you hooked, and the characters are so relatable. Josh Hutcherson and Woody Harrelson kill it in their roles. Plus, the friendships and alliances in the Hunger Games add so much depth.
Let's talk character relationships - it's not just about Katniss being a badass. The bonds formed during the Hunger Games are raw and real. You've got Katniss and Peeta playing the crowd, Katniss and Rue's genuine connection - it hits you right in the feels. And the mentor-student dynamic with Haymitch adds this whole other layer.

At the centre of "The Hunger Games" is an idea also found in other movies such as "Rollerball" and "The Running Man", namely that of an authoritarian government using violent entertainment as a means of distracting the attention of the populace away from its misdeeds. It is an idea that probably derives from memories of classics lessons at school and that quip from Juvenal's satires about Roman emperors providing their subjects with "panem et circenses" (bread and circuses), although it is not one that has been generally borne out by modern totalitarian states.
The film is set at some time in the distant future in the Republic of Panem, a state situated somewhere in what is today the USA. (The name of the country is an obvious reference to Juvenal's quip quoted above). The Hunger Games of the title is an annual event which commemorates an unsuccessful rebellion 74 years earlier against the country's central government. Each of the twelve districts which participated in the revolt is compelled to send two teenagers, one male and one female, to the nation's capital. These young people, known as "tributes", are forced to fight to the death in an arena. The event, televised for the entertainment of the people of Panem, and is hugely popular; those who regard the idea as unutterably cruel are afraid to voice their opposition publicly as the despotic government does not take kindly to any criticism.
The main character is Katniss Everdeen, a working-class girl living in the impoverished District 12, an area of small farmers and coal miners. (Despite modern concerns about fossil fuels and global warming, it would seem that coal mining is still a major industry in Panem). When Katniss's younger sister Primrose is selected as one of District 12's tributes, Katniss selflessly volunteers to take her place. The film then follows what happens to Katniss when she travels to the capital, and the complications which arise when she falls in love with Peeta Mellark, the male tribute from her district. (That's how the name is spelt in the cast list, although when watching the film I assumed he was called "Peter").
Both the original "Rollerball" from 1975 and "The Running Man" from 1987 were made before the current vogue for "reality" television. (I put that word in inverted commas because "reality" shows are one of the most phoney and unreal things on the box. Much more unreal than good honest fiction). They can, however, be seen as prescient in the way they seemed to predict it, especially "The Running Man". "The Hunger Games" was made after the "reality" revolution, and the satire against this genre is quite obvious. "Reality" shows might not involve ritualised killing, and for the most part they do not involve physical violence, but they often involve verbal violence and public humiliation, and pander to milder versions of the sadism and voyeurism which motivate the spectators seen in the film.
In my view "The Hunger Games" is better than either the original "Rollerball" or "The Running Man", and far better than the dismal "Rollerball" remake from 2002. (About which the less said the better). "Rollerball" is OK as an action movie about a violent sport, but works less well as a political satire, which was its main raison d'etre. "The Running Man" falls into the trap of becoming the thing it is satirising; the film is supposed to be a satire on violent and exploitative entertainment, but ends up becoming violent and exploitative entertainment itself. The main characters of both films, Jonathan E in "Rollerball" and Ben Richards in "The Running Man", are little more than ciphers who exist because the film needs a hero in order to make its point.
"The Hunger Games", by contrast, gives us two well-rounded characters in Jennifer Lawrence's Katniss and Josh Hutcherson's Peeta, characters who are more than just ciphers and with whom we can sympathise and identify. There is also a good performance from Donald Sutherland as Coriolanus Snow, the cynical and autocratic President of Panem. (To stress the link with the Roman Empire, most of Panem's social elite have Roman-derived forenames; we also meet a character called Seneca Crane). Unlike "The Running Man" the film does not idealise or romanticise violence; the organisers of the Games might talk about the "courage" and "sacrifice" of the tributes, but the film shows the Games for what they are, the savage and completely unnecessary slaughter of frightened young people. I am not normally a big fan of ongoing film franchises, but having seen "The Hunger Games" I might give the later episodes a chance. 7/10.

The Hunger Games is a fantastic adaptation of the book. It successfully captures the essence of the story and characters, even if some aspects feel rushed. The film effectively hits emotional beats and constructs an interesting universe worth exploring. Its strongest point lies in the performances. Jennifer Lawrence is great as Katniss Everdeen, delivering great acting and successfully manages to bring the complex character to life. Josh Hutcherson is decent as Peeta Mellark, and Woody Harrelson stands out as my personal favorite, bringing fun depth and complexity to Haymitch. The well-written plot, along with good pacing and editing, keeps the tension high, keeping the audience on the edge of their seats. Overall, I think both book lovers, as well as general audiences could find something to really enjoy here.

Although starting off quite slow, The Hunger Games is a thrilling and intense movie that keeps your heart beating. Set in a dystopian world where society is divided into multiple different districts according to the needs of their society. Katniss Everdeen, member of the 12th district and protagonist, is suddenly selected to participate in the annual battle royale (the hunger games), where she and Peeta, another member of district 12, must both survive in the harsh wilderness, fighting against the natural elements as well as the rest of the selected participants. A good movie with thrilling action, however a noticeable problem with the film was its pacing. The first hour started off quite slow introducing the characters whereas the second hour and a half felt somewhat rushed. Still a enjoyable movie for those who like thrilling action.

"The Hunger Games" is a gripping dystopian adventure directed by Gary Ross, adapted from Suzanne Collins' best-selling novel. Set in the post-apocalyptic nation of Panem, the film follows Katniss Everdeen, portrayed with intensity by Jennifer Lawrence, as she volunteers to take her sister's place in the annual Hunger Games-a televised fight to the death among young tributes from each district.
The film's strength lies in its world-building, presenting a bleak yet fascinating vision of a society divided into districts ruled by the Capitol. The Hunger Games themselves are a brutal spectacle, and Ross captures the tension and drama adeptly. Jennifer Lawrence's performance as the resilient and resourceful Katniss anchors the narrative, bringing depth to the character.
The supporting cast, including Josh Hutcherson as Peeta Mellark and Woody Harrelson as Haymitch Abernathy, adds layers to the story. Stanley Tucci's flamboyant portrayal of Caesar Flickerman and Elizabeth Banks' eccentric Effie Trinket contribute to the film's satirical commentary on reality television and the manipulation of public sentiment.
Visually, the film is striking, with the stark contrast between the opulence of the Capitol and the poverty of the districts. The action sequences are well-executed, keeping the audience on the edge of their seats. James Newton Howard's musical score enhances the emotional beats, creating a powerful atmosphere.
While "The Hunger Games" successfully introduces audiences to the harsh reality of Panem and establishes Katniss as a formidable protagonist, some may find the shaky camera work during action scenes distracting. Additionally, the film leaves certain aspects of the source material unexplored, assuming familiarity with the book.
In summary, "The Hunger Games" is a compelling adaptation that sets the stage for the franchise. With its strong performances, thought-provoking themes, and visually arresting presentation, it remains a noteworthy entry in the dystopian film genre, offering both entertainment and social commentary.

David Fincher is one of my favourite if not my favourite director. He showed his brilliance in this film too, like in Fight Club, the Se7en, and the Zodiac. This movie was perfect for me. An upset hitman who goes after the bad guys. The acting was almost perfect, so as the actors. I think Michael Fassbender was a great pick to be the main character. It was a great movie to whatch, definetly will watch later again, however it lacked the plot so this film is not for Plot-Lovers. It is slow as a snail but that is why i liked it. The planning than the execution. This is how every assasin movie should be.\nFincher did it again.

The first 15 minutes gives one hope that this is going to be a great movie with interesting character development, some insight into the mind of an assassin, the cold-blooded killing machine too often portrayed in movies as a cipher (the relentless killer, a trope, is invariable a person lacking certain all-too-human characteristics). And then, unfortunately, the lead character turns into just another formulaic relentless killer. The fact that he finally finds himself unable to suppress a certain vengeafulness is mildly interesting, but character development essentially stops about a third of the way through. After that you might as well be watching Vin Diesel. It's a pity, because Michael Fassbender and David FIncher could have done so much more with this.

A 5 star id a mediocre review because it's a mediocre movie. Would I watch again? No. Would I recommend it? Not really. If you have absolutely nothing else to do or watch then ok, but nothing about this character is interesting. You will not get invested in the plot because it's basic, I like Michael Fassbender but I have to say this is probably one of the worst he has starred in. Late night viewing to help you sleep is what I would say this is good for, 1 hour and 59 minutes. You will wonder why you didn't turn it off, I know I did, but it's good background if you are a multitasker because you only need to listen.

Limited cinema release is always a worry, particularly when we are talking about one of the best directors of all time. So it is on the small screen that most of us watched David Fincher's The Killer. And the results are mixed. Reviews are either an over the top 10 or an immature 1. My review is somewhere in the middle.\nMichael Fassbender plays the titular Killer as an icy reptile, obsessed with his process and set of guidelines like some kind of advanced Dexter Morgan. His latest assignment has gone wrong, and apparently his superiors aren't happy.\nFincher's artistic attempt at a John Wick/Kill Bill style caper has moments of genius, flashes of mastery and stretches of boredom. The Killer is not for everyone, and maybe not even for every Fincher disciple. I liked it, but it's not worthy of the wider Fincher library. 7/10.

This movie is great,but maybe lacks some finishing at the end,the ending what is what a movie gets remeberd for,not the beginning but the end. The movie is overall great but not that great i would watch it but not again and again maybe like other movies,but atleast everyone has its own taste about like and not like so i understand and so must every producer and director on the movie front. But its their job to understand these things and to waits for this you musnt just think everything is all rose you must undderstnad that part also because its part of your job to understand these things all so yah thats how it.

The movie begins with the titular character talking about his work philosophy while quietly waiting in an abandoned house for his victim to arrive. He seeems a meticulous killer, one who has never failed. And, what do you know, he does fail and this puts him and others in danger. I have many questions about the way in which the plot continues starting with the need to kill him, the approach taken to killing him, the failure of the assasins in honduras etc etc. When I watch a john wick movie i don.t care about plot inconsistencies because the movie is not supposed to be real. But in this case the point was for strong realism so these aspects of the worldbuilding matter. However this is not the main issue. The movie is simply boring. There are no stakes, there is nothing particularly challenging for him at any point, and watching him go along with his revenge did not genrrate any sort of emotion. Bland and highly derivative.

In theory this is a comedy of errors, where, Fassbinder a hired killer made a mistake in one of his missions. As a result, the team behind him decided to do clean-up that resulted into a weird goose chase where he tries to do his own clean-up as a revenge to mix result.\nIts difficult to pin this because it just happens. Its well made and all, and the acting from Fassbinder is fine, and the action is well choreographed. But it just happened too. Among the other works of Fincher, this will be forgotten for its sheer lack of innovation and memorable moments. Its good because its clinical and formal by nature BUT that is not enough to clear this film's path above mediocrity to be honest.

I still don't understand what David Fincher (FIGHT CLUB, ZODIAC, THE SOCIAL NETWORK) saw in the graphic novel THE KILLER (written by Alexis Nolent, illustrated by Luc Jacamon) that turned this into a passion project of his over the past two decades. I sought out and read the comic when I learned of Fincher's interest and I found the book fairly mediocre - a world-weary hit man's internal monologuing as a paid killing goes sideways and things start coming apart. Meh. Nothing that hasn't been around the block a few times before.\nOf course, it's all the execution of the film adaptation that counts and Fincher is a master of the medium. Graphic novels have become the "automatic storyboards" to many a modern movie with results that range all over the place: Sam Mendes' fine THE ROAD TO PERDITION (2002) from Max Allan Collins' solid graphic novel, David Cronenberg's A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE from the awfully lousy Vertigo comic, to all the terrible-to-okay adaptations of Alan Moore's comics like LEAGUE OF EXTRAORDINARY GENTLEMEN, FROM HELL, V FOR VENDETTA and WATCHMEN, so I guess I should be used to the process. I just didn't see what Fincher saw in the comic.\nI needn't have worried, of course. THE KILLER is a solid, beautifully crafted film from start to finish, improving upon its source in every way. It is a pulp crime novel with an organized world-of-assassins that is similar to the JOHN WICK series but more realistic and lethal with less of the absurd theatrical violence of that film (and its rapidly-diminishing sequels). Michael Fassbender makes a fine protagonist and the detailing of his world view, his profession, and his life are the central core of the film. The cinematography is gorgeous, the direction is solid, and there are subtleties to enjoy in the writing that I'm not sure were there in the graphic novel but I'd need to re-read it to be sure and I'm not sure that I care that much. If you want some pulp fiction and pure entertainment, THE KILLER will give that to you; it's not front-tier Fincher, lacking the depth of his greater works like ZODIAC, SEVEN, and FIGHT CLUB but it is a glossy, fun entertainment.

The Killer is a very focused and clinical film, which is simultaneously its biggest flaw and greatest strength.
It gives the film a drive and simplicity that is very appealing and impressive, with crisp and definitive direction from Fincher as always.
However, this hyper focused approach removes any real soul or emotion from the film, which makes it feel a tad empty.
Aside from this, Michael Fassbender gives a purposeful and engaging performance, attempting to peel back some layers of an inscrutable character.
Ultimately it really does depend what kind of film you are into. If you enjoy bells and whistles and a more emotionally charged and jam packed film, this certainly won't appeal to you. If the more spartan approach is up your street then there'll be a lot to enjoy here.

As this film opens a professional killer, and the film's narrator, prepares for his latest job. If all goes to plan he will take out his target with a long range rifle shot in Paris. It doesn't and the target is left unharmed if not unrattled. The killer returns to his home in the Dominican Republic and discovered somebody has been there before him and seriously hurt the woman he loves. He has a rule about only killing people he has been paid to kill but now he is going to break it and go after the attackers and those that sent them. This will take him to New Orleans, Florida, New York and finally to Chicago..\nI thought this was a solid drama. It was slow at times, deliberately so, and lacked the near nonstop action we might expect from the genre. Even so I was never bored and found the story to provide a good level of tension. The acting was solid, especially from Michael Fassbender who is rarely off-screen and brings an impressive emotionlessness to his role as the killer. Director David Fincher did a fine job creating a good atmosphere in each of the very different locations. Overall, while I can understand those who were disappointed, I still found it gripping and would recommend giving it a go if you like the genre.

I'm a major Gene and Johnny supporter of the Wonka character and I honestly thought Jeremy, from The Bear would make an excellent Wonka. But after watching this film, I think it was created perfectly. I laughed, I was invested, I was annoyed, and I found my heart melting. Not going lie, it got a tear out of me as well. I am not BIG on going to the theater and spending money on any film that I can just wait to watch at home but being a Wonka lover, I could NOT say no. Glad I did and even though there were children adding to scenes in their seats at this theater, it added and did not take away a single moment of the film. I am NOT a huge fan of musicals, but this was so cute and lovable.

Just got back from taking my son to see this film and was very impressed.
To be honest my typical favorite movie genres are horror and sci fi , but that doesn't mean I don't enjoy lighter stuff if done well. And this was done very well.
TimothÃ©e Chalamet is just wonderful in this. It's not really like anything else I have seen him in before, and it really shows his range. He played a young Wonka with such a sweet innocence, hopeful and big hearted.
I enjoyed the whole cast, the songs were fun and cinematography was amazing. I enjoyed this much more than I thought I would. It's a feel good movie that will put a smile on your face. My 13 year old son even loved it and he's usually "too cool" for a lot of things these days.
I feel it's a great movies for all ages and really glad we decided on giving it a shot.

This was a wonderful movie that really defined who Willy Wonka is. A magical caring person who followed his dreams and made it known you can reach anything you dream of. This was a great movie for young kids to see as it is not only magical it sets a very positive meaning to life. One of the best prequals I've ever seen and TimothÃ©e Chalamet should be an Oscar nominee for this movie. He is a next generation super star that I will enjoy seeing his movies for years to come. Maybe there will another sequal to this prequal but if not I will enjoy watching this movie for years to come. Great movie and great actor.

Let me start by saying I enjoyed this movie, but I thought the musical aspect ruined it for me. I loved the story, and the film in general outside of the musical portion. I am a very huge fan of musicals, and quite a few movie musicals, but I didn't like the musical part of this one at all. The first problem is that they did the thing that you see in many cheap and lazy musicals, like the ones you used to see on Disney Channel, where they have the actors record the songs edit and mix and master to songs until they sound unnatural, and then put them back over the footage so terribly that it barely matches up. This will always look and sound bad, and make the filmmakers look lazy. There are ways to record after and make it sound good, in fact people used to do it by dubbing a completely different person. Another large complaint I had was the way they filmed the dance numbers. A big complaint about many mediocre movie musicals is that they cut too much in the numbers, and this movie was another culprit of too many cuts. It is not just that there were to many, it was that they had no purpose. While purposeful cuts can elevate a number, the cuts in this movie brought it down. I also personally was not a big fan of the songs in general. In conclusion, it was an awesome movie, but a terrible musical.

Just wanted an easy night at the cinema and thought this would do the trick.
Was completely surprised by just how lovely this film was!
I love old classic musicals because they just know how to warm the right spots of my heart. This film had me smiling and it hit just the right notes.
The actors were PERFECTION! Loves the music and just the right balance of all ingredients (just like a wonkabar) for a lovely film.
Just LOVELY!
Saw another review here saying: "this had bo business being this good" and this was very VERY true!
The only thing that could have improved this for me would be if you received a wonka chocolate to enjoy with the movie!

The Movie has the benefit of being a Wonka film which is also a disadvantage. We've all seen him before and we really want to know his story so almost will it to be good, but the reality is the story is weak and the songs are forgettable.
There are good performances, including TimothÃ©e himself but he can't lift the film to the heights it sets itself.
You'll sing along to the two songs brought over from the original film but all the others will be discarded before you leave the cinema.
The sets are great and the production is fabulous. It has a Paddington feel about it just without the wit and soul I'm afraid.

I really wanted to like this flick, even so, I went to the theatre with relative low expectations. Well, I should have even lowered them further. So far, enough has been said about the music. About how bad it is; and it really is bad, with just very few exceptions. I could have looked beyond that fact, being a musician myself I try to be less critical, a bit more open minded when it comes to musical numbers in movies. But in Wonka that's hard to ignore as it was just one bad song after another, sometimes crippling the already crippled super-predictible storytelling. Obviously the whole story is about Wonka but more depth often is added to other characters. You like them, you feel for them, you want them to succeed. I didn't care much for any other character, neither did my kids, they didn't care much for Noodles either. All of them seemed shallow and boring, including the villains, perhaps even Wonka himself, as I felt we were all waiting for the moment his personality would flourish and make us root for him till the end. Instead, it was more like looking forward for it to be over.\nIn my sons's own words "The scenery was great, the story...meh!". In my teenage daughters' words "this is so cringe" (she still thinks Chalamet is very cute though). To be fair, there's very little in life teenagers don't find cringe. But this is coming form a couple of Willy Wonka movie fans, they both love and still watch the Wilder and Depp's versions. This one they said they're OK not to watch it ever again.\nIt felt to me at times like I was watching a TV musical presentation or episode, where you kind of expect mediocre numbers and flat storytelling, because that is exactly what Wonka was. Sadly there's not a whole lot to choose from at the theatres right now and we had seen previews for Wonka that seemed promising, we all felt let down.

Unfortunately, this movie fails marvelously. It has such incredible potential. The imagined prequel is consistent with Ronald Dahl's charm and wit. Timothee Chalamet's performance was sensational. The supporting cast including Keegan Michael Keye, Patterson Joseph, Hugh Grant, Olivia Coleman and Jim Carter were all at their best.\nThe film falls short with the casting director's (Nina Gold's) attempt to find new talent in a novice actress named Calah Lane who stars in the movie opposite Timothy Chalamet as the character known as Noodle. The character itself is drawn well but the performance is so dreadful by Lane that it single-handedly destroys what could and should have been a classic prequel to Dahls original masterpiece. Lane throws out all her lines without any emotion and spends no time listening to her supporting cast. The writing becomes meaningless and almost immediately you do not find yourself caring about the Noodle character at all. This becomes quickly distracting to any audience member who has an inclination to invest in the story or other characters in the movie. The film completely dies and falls short on this one performance because the character of Noodle is drawn in such a way that her present and future well-being is central to the strength of the story's momentum.\nOne has to blame the casting director Nina Gold first. Nina Gold's work on projects like Bad Sisters, Game of Thrones and The Crown has been quite exceptional but in terms of finding new talent for this prospective cinema masterpiece just is not consistent with her previous achievements. I would also say that the failure of this film should also fall on Director Paul King's shoulders who also needs to bare the burden of this complete and utter disaster of a decision to put poor Calah Lane in this role and have all of us suffer this miserable performance and ultimately crushing blow to Roald Dahl's reputation as a storyteller and great wit.

Chalamet's career has practically been built around the image of a drama actor. He has proven himself more than capable of taking on serious characters and pulling off many incredibly moving performances - "Beautiful Boy" and "Call Me by Your Name" are just two that come to mind. That said, he throws off those gowns and that image , and fully embraces the fun, family film genre in this whimsical festive-esque film.
Under the incredibly clear and concise direction and vision of Paul King, this iteration of Willy Wonka is a charming, bright-eyed youth full of positive enthusiasm and endearing energy to make the world a better place through "making chocolate, of course!" - to borrow a line from the titular character.
Some standout performances come from Olivia Colman and Paterson Joseph, as Mrs Scrubitt and Arthur Slugworth respectively. Both villains are so sickly bitter that they're almost a metaphor for the opposite of the sweet (good) characters of Wonka, Noodle, Lofty, and the workhouse gang.
One criticism that has been commonplace about this film is the lack of off-kilter weirdness about Willy Wonka. Perhaps that is something which could be explored in a potential sequel? I certainly hope so!

Went to this kind of grudgingly, not being a fan of Timothee Chalamet and after seeing some so-so reviews. It was delightful! Still don't entirely get Chalamet, but he's game, sings at least as well as Gene Wilder, and dances a bit, quite capably. I didn't realize it was a brand-new story from Paul King, and it's quite a dexterous one, giving Wonka a credible origin story and allowing for plenty of sight gags, warmth, and satire.  Calah Lane is adorable, and there are fun turns from Keegan-Michael Key, Olivia Colman, Rowan Atkinson, and, especially, Hugh Grant. It's visually sumptuous, especially in IMAX. The new songs, by somebody I never heard of, are just fine-OK, they have some lazy rhymes, but they tell the story, inform us about the characters, and generally do the heavy lifting musical scores used to do. It made me laugh out loud, and the "secret message" revealed at the end (but not here) is a charming, touching finishing touch. What a surprise this one was!

But fails. Honestly if you just watch the first 2/3 and then turn it off, you'd be doing yourself a favor.\nLong dead are the days of entertainment for the sake of entertainment, I'm mostly desensitized to the contrived narratives by this point. The movie was for the most part enjoyable before they stopped trying to be funny all together, which was a shame. Obviously I didn't have my hopes up after the lizzo song was playing, and it just sounding like a bunch of forced mainstream narratives. But this did get worse over time.\nThe amazing aesthetic choices, colorful set pieces and comedic decisions made my experience overall positive, although I'm the last person to be excited for more corporate, regurgitated identity politics in what should be a harmless show.

I watched this movie a couple of days ago. I didn't really know what to think of it and even after a few days of gentle reflection I haven't been able to draw a definite conclusion.
It is quite silly, over the top, laughable, ridiculous, cute and charming on the one hand. On the other hand it does have a deeper message and a good one as well.
Because it the story is so over the top and quite hysterical, it really shows you well how conservative en patriarchic standards are still dictating our society. Maybe it needs to be portrayed in such a maner to wake us up. The mirror is funny, but harsh at the same time.
Some friends are a huge fan ans some are definitely not. I am somewhat in the middle, but am still ruminating.

I might be one of the last people on the planet to see this movie, I deliberately held off because of the hype. I ended up caving and I'm glad I did and let the period of high expectations pass. This meant I could enjoy it for what it is which is lots of fun. The political messages were present but not too in your face, more a sort of background thought as you leave the cinema. As a 49 year old woman I can't say it spoke to me deeply or shocked nd surprised me any way but I did get some laughs. Margot and Ryan are brilliant and I'm sure will soon be reunited in a prequel or sequel. Calling it now.

This is by far not the perfect movie, but I enjoyed it more than Oppenheimer, which I was not able to finish.
This movie is definitely head above a lot of other media in terms of attention to little details and the costumes. Loved this side of it, and I remember seeing lots of YouTube videos that went over all the details and how they are connected to real life or to other media. It also has a really good pacing, and overall feels more like an adult fairytale. Which may not be something for everyone, obviously.
I remember when it just came out a lot of people were praising the show for how females are portrayed, and bashed it for how males are portrayed. And there were some who did the reverse. I would say that both sides are correct. Not to go too much into details, patriarchy is depicted as the evil of the world, and matriarchy is the only way to save it. This is not only not true, but it is also shallow, and ignoring real examples of matriarchic rule.
At the same time, the movie does touch upon real issues that men face in real life, like the need to fight for even a slither of attention. This is good, but it gets kind of brushed off at the end, almost as if it did not matter, that that's what brought about Kendome. "Kenough" shirt is a good message, but it gets overpowered by the main message, that it is enough for women to just be ordinary. Which is also a good message, but...
The movie just forgot that in reality you need equality. You need both sides to be present and finding common ground. It is ok to be ordinary for both sides, and both sides can do amazing things. To be honest, for more than first half of the movie, I thought that would be the final message, but in the end it was muddied by "women are better", which felt disingenuous and worsened overall experience. The final scene, though did even more damage, but maybe I just did not get it, since I am a guy.
Either way, it was more or less an enjoyable experience. Overhyped? Probably yes. Worth a watch? Also, probably yes, if you temper your expectations.

So much has been said about this film. It made huge amounts of money and had an incredible start at the box office. I wanted to see it, but the stars didn't align. Since I had read no reviews and had not talked to anyone who had seen it, I went in quite objectively. Our kids had a Barbie or two around the house, but they didn't rule their world. That said, I think I'm a pretty open minded movie viewer. This film is far from the phenomenon the press made it out to be. I enjoyed the incredible sets and recreations of the pink world. Also, the introduction to that world and all the Barbies and Kens was quite amazing. As others have said, however, is that it becomes wordy and preachy in the final third. I started looking at the clock which is not a good sign. The cast is good, although Ryan Gosling isn't dull enough to be Ken. He is never boring, even at the beginning. I'm glad I saw this because it is a cultural phenomenon (even though it doesn't deserve it). The message is a good one and spot on. It's just delivered in a less than stellar way.

Can't believe I wasted time on this movie. People are like lemmings and Hollywood is a PR machine telling said lemmings this movie is Oscar worthy. Well it's not. Its horrible. The script, the characters, the acting, the bizarre dance scene. Any social message this movie is trying to send is lost as you cringe and try to get to the next scene. It's just so weird and really makes little sense. This movie is a waste of time. The scenery and costumes are vivid and fun, and that's the only literal bright spot in this movie. If you want to waste your time go for it but otherwise for the love of god, dont hit play.

It speaks volumes about the decline of cinema that this is the highest grossing film of 2023. The marketing strategy was clever, but the film itself is completely lacklustre.
It has a severe audience problem, Barbie is a children's toy and yet this is not a children's film. Yet at the same time, it fails to appeal to adults as it's a poorly made and rushed film.
The storyline is very weak with Barbie living her life in Barbieland before transporting to the real world. The dialogue is mind-numbingly bland and everything is as cliche as can be. The scenes drag on for a significant period of time, with jokes that weren't funny to start with being hammered home.
The cast are wasted and do not appear to put in a great amount of effort. A complete missed opportunity here.
The costumes and set design look nice and you can tell that this film had a high budget with it's cinematography, but the actual film is completely insufferable and is one of the worst movies of the millennium.

Witty dialogue with an insightful story.
The character arcs of both Barbie and Ken, offer great parallels to both Men and Women in the real world.
With a great message about what it truly means to be a woman (including a hilarious joke right at the end of the film), and insights on how to better find equity within society.
Makes me want to be a better husband and father.
Also shout out to the soundtrack, those songs are catchy!
Ryan Gosling and Margot Robbie are great in their roles and seeing the behind-the-scenes footage of the cast and crew shows how much love, care, and enjoyment there was in the production process.
I look forward to a sequel but also don't think it's necessary.

As a child of the 60s and early 70s, I grew up playing Barbies until I was almost 14. I couldn't wait to see this movie.
Margot Robbie is a perfect Barbie. She's beautiful and brilliant. The Kens are great, with Ryan Gosling and Simu Liu giving outstanding performances. The settings are so good, and the costumes are amazing.
I don't understand a lot of the viewers saying the movie is too preachy. I look at it as a satiric statement on society. There are so many parts of the movie that are laugh-out-loud funny.
Barbie is a brilliant film for all ages. Watch this movie, and reminisce. It's as enjoyable for men as women.

This movie was disjointed and poorly written. I loved Barbie's growing up and hoped for a fun movie that had any sort of plot line, instead it was a jumble of thoughts that didn't go together on any level. With all of the money and good acting behind this movie it could have been good but it just...wasn't. A random musical number and fragmented ideas with a very depressing "message" if you could call it that didn't entertain and certainly left the audience confused and frustrated. It could have been like the Lego movie where people were playing, that both parents and kids could enjoy, but instead it was mattel trying to answer for their stance on women and their inability, even after coming out with every kind of Barbie under the sun, to make up for their narrow mindedness. So they hired a female director who works primarily with independent slow movies and told her to make an epic Barbie movie. No wonder it turned out like something resembling a bad 80's movie you've never heard of. Save your time and watch something else.

I've watched it about few times I think and it's kinda hilarious. It always cracks me up. The acting is great especially from Will Farrell himself. He sure did a great job for playing as Buddy, a main protagonist.
It's probably one of the funniest Christmas films of all time and it's probably one of the best Christmas films of all time as well.
It never gets old and it will always be a timeless classic.
The character Buddy himself is just mad as a hatter, isn't he?
I watched it for the first time on DVD in late November 2004 when I was fourteen years old.
If you enjoy watching Christmas films, you'll definitely love this.

Elf is full to the brim with Christmas spirit. It would not be the Christmas season without watching it multiple times. Will Ferrell gives 100% to the role of Buddy and the supporting cast is excellent. The filmmakers could have gone real raunchy with the movie and I'm so glad that they didn't. Rather than rely on cheap humor, the bits in this movie are quick, witty and hilarious.
Along with Home Alone and a few other family favorites, this is one of the most quoted movies in my house. I haven't even mentioned the brilliance of the score by John Debney... Perfect! Take the nostalgia out of it and this movie is still, pure magic. It's a story of hope, belonging and having a positive outlook on life.
Best Character: Buddy
Best Quote: "The best way to spread Christmas cheer is singing loud for all to hear." - Buddy
Best Scene: "Santa Claus is Coming to Town"
Best Piece of Score: "Main Title"

Too many of today's kiddie movies opt for adult jokes, and "slip in' offer-color humor that they think the kids won't get--too often we get kid's movies about pee, poo, farts and anything some overgrown adult-child in Hollywood will get a laugh.
This film demonstrates how innocent childlike behavior that is silly can be fun, about how misplaced priorities by adults can be redirected when they tune into what the child professes and, more importantly, loves.
The relationship beetween Elf Will and James Cann his father provides a perfect example---adults will appreciate that Caan is remembered for several violent Hollywood classics, but kids don't care, and completely understand when Will is shunned by his Dad--who does come around.
Casting Asner as Santa is genius, and the redecoration of Gimbel's classic hilarity--
And--this is really important--the film is EXCITING!

Elf is such a good movie! This fish out of water story is hilarious! Will Ferrell is in his element and the whole cast as well cast and do a great job! I really have no complaints with this heartwarming film. I watch it every year, frequently on Christmas Eve. The comedy is on point, Jon Favreau hits the nail on the head I love how the North Pole is inspired by the classic Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer. The message if priorities in life, with the growth of Walter as a character is a common but good message. If you have not seen Elf, you are missing out! This has become a Christmas tradition for many for a reason!

After all these years, I finally thought I should have a look at this, since so many people I know have it at the top of their Christmas movie list. I enjoyed some of it, but it is entirely predictable, schmaltzy, and doesn't really off much of a message. My favorite part was Bob Newhart explaining about the three thing that elves can aspire to. Otherwise we have the old father-who-works-too-hard bit as he ignores his son and tries (gasp) to earn money. Will Farrell is pretty funny at times, but his incessant talking and ridiculous actions started to lose me. There was never any doubt that he would be accepted, the boy would get his father back, and all would turn out well. At least now I can talk intelligently about it. I wouldn't have it in my top ten holiday films, but it's a decent film.

This movie has turned into such an awesome holiday classic of all times now. Will Ferrell is an absolute genius in his ability to bring such warmth, humor, love, belonging, and unique character to this movie. That's what made it such a classic. Will and Faizon love were perfect in the rolls they played in each scene. The innocence of youth longing to love and be loved is something else Will brings to the scene in such a unique way in his ability to capture the hope in everyone's heart. That hope is a reality that comes to life during the holiday season with family, relatives, extended family, and special long time relationships with friends.

I like Elf. I enjoy watching Elf. I find this movie amusing. However, I don't like it as much as many other people do, and that seems to turn them into angry elves. Will Ferrell's enthusiasm as he plays Buddy the Elf is contagious, and you can't help but smile at his innocent ignorance. James Caan also plays the part of the reluctant father so well that you wonder if he's actually going to kill Buddy. Where this modern Christmas classic starts to wear out its welcome is the ending, which unfortunately gets a little too cheesy for me. I'm happy to watch Elf every now and then, but not every year.

Undeniably there are a few laughs in Elf. And it has a decent soundtrack that has lots of festive tunes to keep the yuletide feel alive. Now a few might argue with my reasoning here. But the biggest drawback for me is the rewatchability. Take Scrooged with Bill Murray as an example. I will never , ever tire of seeing the ghost of Christmas present smash Bill Murrays face with a toaster. Still laugh as hard every year. Elf unfortunately for me, made me laugh the first time. But Subsequent viewings don't bring the same enjoyment as the jokes are "seen it, heard it" and have limited replay value. I did enjoy the movie and Ferrel. Love him or loathe him, does what he does best and borders on the farcical with a style that only he can provide. Perhaps that's the problem. Ferrel's rewatchability in most of his work is not the easiest as his work depends a lot on the shock factor which diminishes each time you see it. A movie like Airplane I could watch countless times and still be amused. Elf for me is only slightly rewatchable and If it wasn't for my Daughter wanting to watch in 2023. I would have probably past it by this year.

When it comes to holiday films, there are few as well renowned and adored as Elf. Telling an whimsical tale of a misplaced orphan reuniting with family, the story gives such charm and emotion to masterfully capture the spirit of Christmas. Though this could have been written off as another run-of-the-mill comedy, director Jon Favreau passionately crafted a new age holiday classic, to be rewatched year after year. Portraying Buddy the Elf, Will Farrell gives one of his most memorable performances, balancing his childlike attitude with an infectious holiday spirit. Elf achieves more than most holiday films, as it focuses on its characters and story and then uses the holiday to accentuate the experience. If you haven't seen it, your holiday season is missing out greatly and if you have seen it, than I'm sure you'll be watching it again shortly.

I remember when I first saw Elf at a specialized showing at AMC Theater in Neshaminy Mall back in 2009. And I love it!
Elf centers around Buddy (played by Will Ferrell), a 30-year-old man, who as a orphaned baby, snuck into Santa Clause's (Ed Asner) sack on Christmas Eve, at the orphanage that he lived in. After being brought back to the North Pole by mistake, Buddy was raised by one of Santa's elves, Papa Elf (Bob Newhart), and grew up thinking his entire life that he was an elf... despite being three times the size of the other elves, and being the slowest at making toys. Upon learning that he's a human, Buddy departs from the North Pole and travels down to New York City, without shedding his elf garments, to meet his birthfather, Walter Hobs (James Caan)... who turns out to be a cynical and self-centered businessman, and on Santa's naughty list. Because Walter never even knew that Buddy was born, he takes Buddy to a doctor for a DNA test, and finds, to his dismay, that Buddy is indeed his son. As a result, Walter is forced to start a relationship with Buddy. And the results get more and more chaotic.
The acting is brilliant. Will Ferrell is hilarious as Buddy. James Caan (may he rest in peace) is magnificent as Walter. I really like the contrast that their performances create between Buddy and Walter. While Buddy is incredibly good-natured and kind, but naive and simple-minded, Walter is cynical and small-minded.
