I took my nine year old son, and twelve year old daughter to this movie on a Friday night. We went to the late show, and had the theater to ourselves. My kids were really excited.
My nine year old son quickly realized this is not a movie in which there is a strong story. The movie is more of a musical, with a song seemingly every 30 seconds. Gone are the days of the trolls action and adventure. Disappointing.
This film introduces so many "famous" people (I assume, however researching the actors on IMDB and I'm not sure who 98% of them are) that you quickly get lost in who is who, and what story the film is trying to tell. So many characters were introduced, but were never fully explained or developed, which made the story hard to follow and comprehend.
The film has two competing stories, well, three if you count the "everyone finds their long lost family" aspect. Too many competing themes, for any of them to shine through, again making the movie hard to comprehend.
The most ridiculous thing of all? The characters say extremely inappropriate things for a film directed at children. At one point, one character says to the other "I thought I was the only one getting tied up." There is gratuitous use of male genitalia and sex innuendos. CONTINUOUSLY repeated throughout the film.
I'm blown away that the actors said some of these lines. How did they deem these appropriate for children? Did they not realize this is a CHILDREN'S film? I shouldn't be explaining to my nine year old son what a female means by being tied up. Absolutely abhorrent.
I've never considered Hollywood to be any type of role model, for any person on the face of planet Earth, nor will I ever, however, it is still somehow shocking to me that they continue to PROVE that their society and industry has zero morals, standards, values, or respect.
I never would waste the short time I have on Earth to write such a scathing review, but have not been this disappointed in a movie like this in quite some time. So, in short, this movie is NOT worth a single second of your attention, is absolutely NOT worthy of your hard earned dollars, and it is definitely NOT worth any potential moral erosion of your children's minds.

The Trolls movies, despite being technically a bit of IP-mining, have managed to inject creativity into a seemingly dead-end idea. The series, now a full trilogy, is best when working itself up into a state of tuneful delirium, sending troll queen Poppy (Anna Kendrick) through deeply weird animated landscapes and smashing decades' worth of pop hits along the way. However, the movie opens with an obligatory pathos-laden flashback focusing on Poppy's glum boyfriend Branch (Justin Timberlake). The movie defers this gag until much later, instead filling out the BroZone ranks with Eric AndrÃ©, Troye Sivan, Daveed Diggs, and Kid Cudi. Years after their partnership dissolved, the brothers must reunite to rescue Sivan's Floyd from sibling pop stars Velvet (Amy Schumer) and Veneer (Andrew Rannells), who are sapping his talent to keep their careers afloat. Poppy, a BroZone superfan who had no idea Branch was in the band, is more enthused about this mission than her standoffish partner. DreamWorks' animated "Trolls" series is a charming and irresistible movie that is sure to be a hit with millennials. The movie is designed to connect with high school and college years, featuring in-jokes about boy bands and a mix of songs. It's sweet without being sugary, colorful, and charming, with excellent voice talent and a lot of music. It's the best of the three, making it a must-watch for parents and millennials alike. The movies cleverly use popular pop songs and colorful troll designs, with the title "band" having a double meaning. In the opening flashback, Branch and his brothers were members of a popular boy band called BroZone, a nod to Timberlake's time with *NSYNC. When their performance went wrong, the group broke up, and Branch and his brothers decided to go back streets. The film also references New Kids on the Block, Menudo, and New Edition, highlighting the transition from boys to men. The "Trolls" movies are a thrilling and entertaining story about Floyd, a troll who needs to be rescued. The music, featuring old favorites and new ones, teaches lessons about sibling closeness and accountability. The supporting characters, including Zosia Mamet as Velvet's abused assistant Crimp and Kenan Thompson as Tiny Diamond, add to the happy atmosphere. The movies also feature songs that feel like home, such as "9 to 5," "Push It," and "We Are Family." The film follows several storylines, including the nuptials of Bridget and Gristle, and the unexpected appearance of Viva, who turns out to be Poppy's sister. Some characters from previous films have been dropped or made only token appearances, while new ones include Crimp, Velvet, and Veneer's assistant. The film features an endless series of musical numbers featuring old and new tunes, with an emphasis on the former. The pop earworms, performed energetically by trolls in high voices, include hits from various bands. However, the musical novelty has somewhat worn off, and nothing on the soundtrack matches the catchiness of "Can't Stop the Feeling" from the first film, including the ballyhooed "Better Place," for which NSYNC reunited.

This movie is just phenomenal. The animation is beautiful, the characters are memorable, it's weirdly dark but also extremely wholesome. I love that it also it's left vague what's magic, and what's real, allowing your imagination to take over. It's also very funny, the villains had me laughing out loud every time they were onscreen. I also love that it takes familiar stories such as the emperor's new groove, Romeo and Juliet, and Santa origin stories and make a beautiful mix into this movie. Word needs to be spread that this movie exists, the people I've showed this too were like "how have I never seen this? It's amazing." If you love this movie as much as I do, spread the word!

From time to time Netflix gives us something beautiful:\nIn a world of good, bad, curious, and terrifying movies, this one is beautiful. That word, said quickly but carrying a special meaning, is how I would describe this film. It allows us to see the humblest and purest origin of Klaus. It manages to make you feel warmth that wraps you on a cold night, no matter where you are. That's why it deserves a place on the list of classics we grew up with. There's nothing better than being with family, sipping hot chocolate in the morning, with no work to do or stressful things to think about, and feel like a child again.

So horribly formulaic, as others have said, poor character development and so epically predictable. Santa's story didn't need to be rewritten this badly. If you want a good spoiled brat turned good story with interesting villains go rent "The Emperor's New Groove". If you want to see decent heroics go rent "The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe". The animation in this one is prettier but pretty doesn't mean better. The voice talent is decent enough, but that all. The jokes are just bad and characters do a lot of things that don't make a lot of sense unless you are a depressive type and we all know how that makes for fun entertainment!

Klaus was an enjoyable film to watch. What makes a good Christmas film is something novel and interesting. Klaus keeps you entertained and wondering how things will work out. In the back of your mind you are trying to piece together how this feel good film will end. How creative to use a town in the wilderness as a setting and tell this fun tale. The tale also has some depth with a great meaningful message about acts of kindness. It is through this and the magic of Christmas that we see a hostile town transformed to a happy town. The film does not try too hard to weave in the traditional Christmas stories and legends into it but effortlessly makes references to it. Christmas movies can take a page out of Klaus's book on how to make a good Christmas film.

I took a chance on this and so glad I did. This is a truly original script that takes you on a journey and has something for everyone to enjoy. A little intrigue, a little romance, a little heartache with characters you will fall in love with. Great casting choices for the voices with a particular spotlight on Klaus. This movie will leave you completely satisfied and ready to watch it again and again every Christmas. I just wish all the Christmas movies coming out had this much quality in their script, story and casting. I saw in someone else's review, "in a sea full of Christmas movies, Klaus stands out" and I could not agree MORE!

This one has become a Christmas staple in my household. We HAVE to watch it every year and every year we both laugh and cry over this movie.
Not only is the animation of it top notch, the casting very good and the story surprisingly fresh for a tale as old as time, the flow of the film is absolutely perfect.
It has everything from the moments you detest to the moments that you love. It has characters that you fall in love with at first sight and characters that you learn to love over the course of the film. Oh and it absolutely has characters you dislike too.
All and all it is one that we keep coming back to. And honestly? It should have won that Oscar! ðŸ˜‰

The big-city spoiled child motive is elegantly incorporated into the story with Jasper. The whole movie is perfectly written and executed whilst the style of animation leaves you in awe. The soundtrack is blended well and succeeds in it's goal to make you emotional and immerse you into the scenes.\nThe ending is powerful yet simple and delivers the final piece of the puzzle that "stamps" this movie's status as an absolute classic.

SIMPLE MAGICAL.\nDo not snod movies because it is animated.\nKlaus starts little different but it works built character and of course the scenario. "Klaus," directed by Sergio Pablos, is a charming and inventive animated film that offers a fresh and delightful take on the origins of Santa Claus. This film stands out with its unique storytelling, stunning animation, and a heartwarming message, making it an instant classic in the realm of holiday films.
The story follows Jesper, voiced by Jason Schwartzman, a spoiled and lazy postman who is stationed in the remote and feuding town of Smeerensburg. His unlikely friendship with a reclusive toymaker named Klaus, voiced by J. K. Simmons, leads to the creation of Santa Claus's legend. Schwartzman brings a likable and humorous quality to Jesper, effectively portraying his transformation from a selfish individual to a caring member of the community.
J. K. Simmons' portrayal of Klaus is both gentle and profound, adding depth and warmth to the character. His performance, along with the film's storytelling, paints a touching and humanized picture of the iconic figure of Santa Claus. The chemistry between Jesper and Klaus drives the narrative, creating a heartwarming dynamic that is both entertaining and emotionally resonant.
The animation style of "Klaus" is one of its most striking features. The film combines traditional hand-drawn animation with modern techniques, resulting in a visually captivating experience. The character designs are unique and expressive, and the use of lighting and color is innovative, giving the film a sense of depth and texture that is rare in 2D animation.
The supporting cast, including Rashida Jones as Alva and Joan Cusack as Mrs. Krum, adds to the film's charm and humor. The characters are well-developed, each contributing to the story in meaningful ways. The voice acting is top-notch across the board, bringing these characters to life with warmth and personality.
The script is witty, heartfelt, and cleverly subverts some traditional holiday tropes, providing a fresh perspective on a familiar story. The film explores themes of kindness, forgiveness, and the power of goodwill, delivering its message without feeling preachy or saccharine.
One potential downside is that while the film's story is engaging and innovative, it occasionally treads into predictable territory. However, this does not significantly detract from the overall enjoyment and emotional impact of the film.
The soundtrack complements the film's tone perfectly, enhancing both its playful and poignant moments. The music contributes to the overall festive atmosphere of the film, making it a perfect watch for the holiday season.
In conclusion, "Klaus" is a delightful and visually stunning film that breathes new life into the Santa Claus legend. Its unique animation style, combined with a heartwarming story and memorable characters, makes it a standout animated film. It earns a well-deserved 8 out of 10 for its creativity, emotional depth, and visual beauty, marking it as a modern classic in holiday filmmaking.

"Klaus" stands out as a grossly underappreciated gem in the realm of Christmas classics. Despite its exceptional animation, compelling characters, and a heartwarming narrative that redefines the origin of Santa Claus, it hasn't received the widespread recognition it truly deserves. The film's brilliance lies in its ability to appeal to all ages, blending humor and emotion seamlessly. The underappreciation may be due to the overshadowing of big-budget productions, but "Klaus" deserves a spotlight for its unique charm, making it an instant classic that should be part of every family's holiday tradition.

Too many get caught up in absolutes. You either change everything or change nothing for a minor subset of people on either side. The old Seuss purists deride this story as not faithful, while others deride it as run of the mill with nothing new. After all, what's the point in telling the things exactly the same based on a societal viewpoint decades old, and little point in changing everything including the original message. In the end, the story is about the core of the Christmas spirit with spending and enjoying time with family and friends, not about the material goods that our capitalistic society has pushed. That is the message of Dr. Seuss' original story and of this movie.
Pharrell's narration pays homage to the original animation that felt lacking in the live action Carrey movie. Cindy Lou coming from a single parent home winds up resonating with more families these days, and not the nuclear family ideal from the original story. The Grinch is still humbuggish doing mean things to in an attempt to interrupt other people's happiness. The gadgetry from Dr. Seuss' story's comes to play and fits and looks better in this movie. Finally the lyrical nature of the lines, feels like I'm listening to Dr. Seuss' stories.
I'm neutral on the redo of the song. Its not bad, but I would have gone with something more along the lines of something Taylor Swift or Kelly Clarkson would sing.
Things I would have done without is the whole reindeer search and screaming goat, it felt unnecessary. Instead it could have incorporated more of what Cindy Lou tried in the live action movie, while giving the Who's viewpoint of more mean deeds the Grinch had done in the past.

Everything about it was just not good. Nothing about this version was rememberable. It doesn't even have any of the classic Dr Seuss rhymes . Most the characters were a disappointment. For some reason Cindy Loo wasn't really as interesting in this version. I don't know there was no connection to any of the characters. The music was horrible just modern pop and even a rap song? The music is what should stand out and make the movie better and fun but the music was just silly and even a little ridiculous. Just no . No thank you . I don't even know how people could rate this more than five stars. I guess some people found it enjoyable but it just didn't have that spark for me .

First I'm not doubting that this movie strayed far from the book but somehow it worked. I like the humor, I like the animation, and I love the actor Benedict Cumberbatch for playing a likable jerk in the movie. Somehow it got me loving Fred the weird deer. I understand why some people didn't like it but I can't not like it. I say it's a treat for the kids, it's a treat for the family to like, and even adults might like it. I admit I can be a loner and it stresses me sometimes being around people and so I know how it feels when Grinch was wondering around in a crowd and he had an anxiety attack from social anxiety. Not only it touches on child trauma but it touches how easy it is to feel like an outsider when people ignore you. Enjoy this movie for the laughs and fun.

The Grinch is an okay movie. This movie is a remake of a remake. I never watched the original "movie" made in the 60's, but I didn't like the Jim Carrey Grinch movie made in 2000. Jim Carrey was great, but the movie itself just wasn't great. This movie thought, it's okay. I think Benedect Cumberland had a very nasal voice for the Grinch. The Grinch himself was just not evil like he was in the book. He was just a depressed jerk who was just really scared to go down there in Whoville. I gotta admit though, at times this movie is really funny, but every kids movie is a comedy. This movie isn't terrible, but it isn't great. I mean, it's better than the Lorax. In all I give this a 6.2 out of 10.

Well, I Figured I'd Do This Movie At This Time Of Month. Get Y'all's Snacks, Food, & Drinks, & Enjoy This Review.
Well, After That Abysmal 2000 Live-Action Version, We Get This 1ne. Let Me Tell You, This Was Fabulous. Definitely An Improvement To That 2000 Version. Now If You Ask Me If I Like The 1966 Classic Or This Version, I'd Say Both. Now Let's Go For Characters & Songs.
Grinch Was A Cool Character Just Like 1966 Version, Max Was At His Best Like Always (Including The Bad 2000 Version), Cindy-Lou Who Was Very Sweet Character Like In 1966 Version, Groopert Was Charming, Fred The Fat Reindeer Is Funny, & Every Other Character Were Fun, Cute, Amazing, & Hilarious.
As For The Songs & OST's, The Songs From The 1966 Classic Definitely Deserved A Remastered. The OST Are Great.
Well, That's My Review. Be Prepared For The Other 2.
RATING: Fabulous Movie (100/100).

I consider some TV shows and movies so "classic" that I refuse to watch any type of remake of them. "How The Grinch Stole Christmas" (1966) is one of them. Or was one of them until this weekend. While Hades will freeze over before I watch the 2000 non-animated version of the story, I saw this animated 2018 version at Peacock and decided why not? I figured I could turn it off if anything in it offended me, or if it was sacrilegious in any way, shape or form.
My, my, all that worrying for nothing! This is an absolutely delightful remake of Dr. Seuss' Christmas story. In two ways it's sweeter than the original, too. One, it explains why the Grinch so hates Christmas. Two, the Grinch is not cruel at all to his dog Max. In this movie, Max is his only friend and companion. There is also a chubby reindeer named Fred, the only one in a huge herd that the Grinch could catch to pull his sled. Fred turned out to be more help than the Grinch ever realized he could be.
Cindy Lou Who is not a toddler in this film, but looks about six years old. She encounters the Grinch on Christmas Eve not by accident, but intentionally, because she wants to ask Santa Claus something. Many of the residents in Whoville are very funny, especially Bricklebaum, who loves Christmas as much as the Grinch hates it. All the voice jobs are great, including the narrator.
So, have no fears of watching this movie if you are a fan of the 1966 show, but don't touch the 2000 non-animated version even with a thirty-nine-and-a-half foot pole!

The movie is good especially for children. Funny and entertaining version that keeps the kids attention. This newer version has lots more Grinch interaction. He's not as mean as the original movie.\nThe actors add a new twist on the main characters. Max is the best character. He is sweet and has genuine emotions that make you enjoy each scene he's in.\nHowever the soundtrack sucks. The rap is awful. That man cannot carry a tune to save his life! Off key and just plain bad. How this guy got a record deal baffles me. There are a few decent songs but the main artist lacks even the most basic singing abilities. Sorry not sorry!

I'm not one to go crazy over a new version of a movie, especially when it was nailed so well the first time! I love the classic How The Grinch Stole Christmas, but this version is beautifully reimagined.\nObviously, as a longer movie, we get more context around the Grinch. And while some find it hard to connect with, I loved this version of the story! More so because I am a mom of a preschooler, and this movie was an exceptional story for sharing the Christmas spirit with children that young. It's definitely the feel-good story of the season!\nPharrell is the narrator, bringing a fresh, new take. The movie also combines the classic grinch music and classic Christmas songs with more modern songs. It's entertaining.

Lately, I've been loving Illumination's movies they've been making! With Disney and Pixar on the decline lately, Illumination has really stepped up to the plate with their recent success with the Super Mario Bros movie. I'm excited to see their newest film called 'Migration,' coming out this December. In this adaptation of Dr. Seuss's 'The Grinch Who Stole Christmas,' Pharrell Williams narrates it because he has a partnership with Illumination. Benedict Cumberbatch voices the Grinch and doesn't sound half bad. Rashida Jones even voices Cindy Lou, whose mother and the girl who plays Cindy Lou Who in this is pretty endearing.
The animation is just absolutely breathtaking in this, and they really beautifully recreate Whoville and Mount Crumpet. I really find this version far more palpable and enjoyable for kids compared to the Ron Howard and Jim Carrey nightmare-fueled remake that honestly gave children nightmares and was a whole lot darker. This version is a lot more wholesome to watch and not nearly as creepy. You can tell Illumination really cared about the design and aesthetic of this movie a whole lot, and they put top-notch animators to really bring Dr. Seuss's 'The Grinch' to life in the most honorable way possible.
The Grinch is not nearly as mean or diabolical in this adaptation compared to the original and the Jim Carrey version. He's a lot more toned down, and they focus more on how he doesn't feel loved, making him less dastardly than the other previous versions, which I feel is more suitable for kids anyway and still drives the valuable lesson home that no one should feel alone on Christmas. All the Whos are super jolly and positive.
But I think what separates this version from the previous versions probably the most is the Whos don't treat the Grinch like a monster. After the Grinch takes everything from the Whos, they honestly are more confused and upset when the Grinch steals everything of theirs but are super forgiving and heartwarmingly compassionate after they find out his tragic tale. Oddly enough, they're not even frightened by him like they are in the originals, which is an interesting take and makes the movie a lot more endearing, I think.
I think the most lovable character, obviously, is the Grinch's dog, Max, in this movie. They almost give him a Gromit-like personality with a lot of miming and a certain level of endearment. The Grinch is not nearly as cruel to Max as he is in the other two versions, and he is the standout performance that really outshines Benedict Cumberbatch most times throughout the movie with his love and support towards the Grinch that really makes seeing the Grinch's transformation lovable.
There's a lot to this movie that is different, but honestly, I think they should have just skipped the whole frightening Jim Carrey version and just created an animated movie to follow up the original to begin with. And I think the Illumination production company really hit the mark with this one and did justice to make this as poetically beautiful and honor the original as much as possible. It's not an instant classic like the original, but it's a really beautiful looking adaptation that's far more suitable for young children to enjoy and still understand the valuable messages to learn from. And honestly, Benedict Cumberbatch's voice as the Grinch sounds incredible, and I think Illumination did a good job. Like this movie or not, I think this is a good and faithful adaptation of the original.

The pros: The animation and colors are nice and smooth, the characters and character designs are like-able.\nCons: some painfully unfunny jokes including a butt joke, and a dead meme: the screaming goat (3 times), and the overdone slow motion "whoa" moment. Changing an iconic character like Cindy Lou Who from a sweet girl to a hockey loving tomboy felt unnecessary as well. Changing the characters and adding extra ones made this movie feel like it would've been better with a completely different storyline instead of "retelling" The Grinch which the live action already did better. The writers also could not let the movie just speak for itself, not only is there a narrator but also The Grinch narrates everything to his dog (and therefore also the audience.) There is a scene where he is covered in icicles and he says "It's getting really... c-cold, oh goodness!" I don't see why they had to add this line, it doesn't even sound like something the Grinch would say and I think just having his teeth chatter would have been enough to get the message across. The music was also not good Imo, especially since it was modern pop/rap music with little to no Christmas sound to it in a christmas movie, my least favorite song was the end credits. The only song I thought fit the movie was the acapella carolers but even that song was (imo) not the best choice, especially since it blatantly says the Devil's name which is a little off-putting in a cheery Christmas movie. Also there is a scene with a missing sound effect and another scene where a character's singing abruptly cuts out which was a little weird and made me think "did anyone rewatch this movie for mistakes before releasing it?" Honestly it was a little boring, especially if you've already seen the live action and the old classic movies.

The animation was ok. Songs did not make my ears bleed. And the moral of the story is meaningful Though the songs were not catchy, "This wish " was actually pretty catchy to me.
I am not lying but telling the truth. Even though Disney has failed, but it's still ok lah. Have to agree with the animation being not so-good though. But i will still forgive them. They threw in a few Dsney refencres though. I hope that Disney can continue to make great films like this in the future.
Anyway , that's it for now. Stay happy and bye!(smile's)
Love
Goh Yi
(Ps I need this review to be shortrer) Oh and Hi.

Have to apologise. First review I've done for a movie I havnt actually watched.
Probably dosnt help that this is shrouded with the worst Disney reviews and box office takings nearly ever.
Based on the Trailer and my kids response,
They pretty much said "that was the most boring trailer they have ever seen!" And had zero interest in watching it.
Which says a lot as they are huge Disney fans!
And I agree. What were Disney thinking?
Disney movies of late are big bright & cute with meaningful cultural mythological back stories.
Not sure I like the new visual effects technique that brings old and new together. Just seems like a remastered 50s cart.
They've failed in the marketing and delivery.
What a shame.
Hopefully they learn from this.

A blend of hand-drawn animation and CGI in the art style. An original story not based on a book. Not a needless sequel. A Disney movie that is not a shameless cash-grabbing remake. A straightforward villain rather than the overtired twist cliche. A young protagonist who is flawed, makes mistakes, can lose a fight, and is not an extraordinarily, way over-the-top perfect Mary Sue. Good vs evil story with themes of friendship, love, dedication. Comedy, drama, scary, hopeful. Well-written characters, fantastic songs and music. No political or sociological messages anywhere. Just pure, fresh, glorious entertainment.\nThis movie is everything that fans and detractors of Disney Feature Animation have been asking from the studio for years.\nWhat more can they want?

I truly don't understand how this movie is getting so much hate...yes, there was some character development lacking, but it's a children's movie and it's already an hour and a half long. I absolutely loved Wish. I thought it was a beautiful love story to 100 years of Disney. I loved the little nods to Disney films, I loved the music, I loved the characters, I loved the laughs, and I loved the ending. I have seen it three times with my daughter and we can't get enough. I tear up during "This Wish" and at the ending every time. Ariana DeBose is a treasure. You can tell that she's a Broadway actress by the way you feel the emotion through her singing. Chris Pine was probably miscast as the singing voice for Magnifico and should have only done his speaking voice, but he can carry a tune at least. I think the only reason this movie didn't live up to box office expectations was because of Trolls coming out the week before.\nAnyone that's tearing Wish apart clearly is not a fan of Disney and hasn't seen some of their movies that are ACTUALLY terrible (i/e: Bolt, Chicken Little, Home on the Range).

I saw this film in the cinema with my entire family. And we enjoyed the movie from start to finish. Us as adults. Have also enjoyed the 2D and 3D effects in a film. And they merged seamlessly into each other, giving it its own magical world. Great respect for the animators. The music and songs were also very beautiful like the song. The Wish , this is the thanks I get ! Im a star. Disney has finally responded again to include a real Disney villain. King magnifico.which is wonderfully voiced by Chris Pine, which we did not expect that he could sing so well. Actress Ariana DeBose was also very good, she set the right tone in her speaking and especially in her fantastic singing, what a performance All in all a wonderful film for the whole family.

I was very excited for this movie. The idea of every bit of Disney magic coming together in1 giant movie sounds amazing doesn't it? Well, It's execution is just bland and boring. I really wanted them to have a story more related to When You Wish upon a star. Instead it felt like Disney doing a parody of their own movies.
The characters were boring, and their development just felt very rushed. The songs also do not feel memorable and also ripped off from other Disney movie. The first song in this movie is parallel to 'The Family Madrigal' from Encanto, where the main character introduces us to the main plot, and it feels uninspired.
The villain also is pretty forgettable and unoriginal.
I was gonna give is a 4, but some of the humor was pretty well done, so that rounds up so a 5 (being very generous).

I saw this movie in Danish with my kids in the cinema as a Christmas present. Since we don't go to the cinema often, it was an overall nice family experience.
The movie is a typical Disney movie. There were no surprises in this. I felt entertained and occasionally moved, but it was not a movie, that is gonna stick.
It feels like Disney made a compilation of a lot of other Disney movies. I felt especially reminded of Vajana and Jafar and if I would reflect more on it, there will be more characters, that I will recognize.
I would not neccessarely recommend this movie, but I would also not say "Don't watch it, it's a waste of time". There are definitly other movies, where time is more well spend, but there are also worse movies out there.

In an era where animated films often redefine the boundaries of storytelling and visual artistry, it's disheartening to see a studio with the pedigree of Disney deliver something as uninspired as Wish. The film, unfortunately, continues the recent trend of Disney's offerings feeling more like formulaic retreads than the innovative masterpieces we once eagerly anticipated.\nWish stands as a particularly glaring example of this decline. While it boasts a visually appealing watercolor-inspired aesthetic, this artistic choice alone can't mask the movie's fundamental shortcomings. The narrative lacks the depth and nuance that once made Disney films universally appealing. Instead, we're presented with a collection of recycled elements: a predictable protagonist, a cookie-cutter antagonist, a character designed seemingly for merchandising purposes, and a soundtrack that, while competent, fails to leave a lasting impact.\nThe primary audience for Wish is, of course, children. They might find enjoyment in the film, but it's a fleeting and superficial pleasure, akin to the temporary distraction offered by shows like Peppa Pig or Paw Patrol. There's an absence of the magic and inspiration that could make "Wish" a memorable experience for its young audience. Ultimately, the film is an example of wasted potential, showcasing high-quality animation without the compelling story or characters needed to make it truly resonate.

I absolutely agree with those who say it's not enough for a Disney centenery but for all those who destroy it I have to break a lance in favour of it: maybe we are too used to "Disney movies for adults", like Inside out or Soul, who are indeed great movies with a better script than Wish, but probably for the 100th anniversary of Disney classics we need a more classic tale, enjoyable by the greatest audience, 0-99 to quote Lego boxes, and with this in mind Wish fulfills its task. Add great visuals and beautiful songs and musics and the recipe is complete. Let's once fly down and enjoy a simple, well packaged Disney motion picture.

I don't think it is as bad as some seem to think, but it is certainly middling. Couple songs worked well I thought, and my 4 year old danced along a couple times. But she also got pretty bored during the first act and asked to leave around 45 minutes in. She agreed to wait it out a little longer and then got a bit more into it, and when we left she said she liked it.\nAs an adult Disney fan I would say it is pretty middling. I was around for the highs of The Little Mermaid, and the horrifying lows of Chicken Little and Home on the Range... And Wish is no where near as bad as things can get. But as a rule a Disney film with fart jokes is always mediocre at best, and this has at least two... Sooo....

It was cute,nothing interesting when it comes to the music though. But the plot was nice,I enjoyed the story. Definitely a good family movie. I like that they casted Adam Sandler as the lizard.
He's one of my favorite actors. Has a pretty good message about confiding in someone with your feelings. Also how crying is good for your emotional well being.
I really enjoyed that part. I really enjoyed the message of the movie as well as helping your friends out when they need help. Again,nothing outstanding for the music really,I don't think I'll remember any of the songs by heart.
But other than that I liked it.

I honestly was not expecting much out of an animated Adam Sandler musical, mostly because I was thinking it was going to be a standard movie on Netflix, but I wanted to give it a chance to change my opinion on it; after watching it, I thought it was better than I thought it was going to be. The Netflix animated movie Leo (2023) was a funny and enjoyable animated musical that has good voice acting and good songs that could be funny; there is also some kind of message involving being able to talk to anyone you know about any issues you are having and help you with them.
Adam Sandler does do a respectable job as Leo, though you might find his voice a bit weird, you will get used to it as you keep watching the movie; he was funny with jokes about how old he is, the years he had lived through, and usually about kids, teachers, and parents. Leo's friend, who stays in the same terrarium in the classroom, Squirtle, who was voiced well by Bill Burr, does have scenes and is usually just talking to Leo when he is talking about escaping or talking to the kids in the classroom; he does eventually help in the third act. I also liked how Leo is trying to do what he can to help the kids in the classroom, because he knows how old he is and how long he has until a certain age that is coming close.
The animation is good, and the movie was funny with it having funny lines of dialogue and funny sight gags in the background or as the central focus; the songs in the movie are not bad with them also being funny, and the singing voices from Adam Sandler and the rest of the cast are good. What was surprising for me was that the movie had quite a few touching/heartfelt moments that are effective; also, what I will add is that the movie does have a liar reveal story in it that could be annoying, and the movie could have had a shorter runtime because the third act felt a bit stretched out.
The Netflix animated movie Leo (2023) was better than I thought it was going to be, and though it is not a perfect animated musical, it was still entertaining and funny to watch; Adam Sandler does do a decent job as the main character, which makes the movie watchable. I am not going to say to go and rush onto Netflix to watch this, but I will say this an animated musical I would watch at least once, especially for those who were skeptical about it and did not know what to think about it.

Netflix's 'Leo' is a captivating blend of high-quality animation and heartfelt storytelling. The film features a lovable main character, Leo, who resonates with Adam Sandler's best works in terms of emotional depth.
Although its pace is leisurely and its themes more mature, the movie strikes a chord with adult audiences, offering a rich, introspective experience. While it's a family-friendly film, its slower rhythm and profound message might not fully engage children under 10. Teenagers and young adults might find the plot somewhat sappy, potentially alienating the 15-25 age group.
Nevertheless, 'Leo' shines in its ability to weave a narrative that's both engaging and emotionally rich. The inclusion of Leo's buddy, Squirtle, adds a delightful touch to the story.
Overall, 'Leo' is a testament to the power of animation in storytelling, appealing to those who appreciate the genre and offering a lot for families with diverse tastes and ages to enjoy.

Enjoyed the story line: A class lizard goes home each weekend with a different student in the class and helps them with an issue they are having.
The characters were fantastic: the students are stereotypical and the teachers and parents are on point. Loved the main animal characters Leo and Squirtle.
The musical side wasn't all that great: the songs were slow and boring. They should have just stuck to the storyline and the fun of it.
A fun movie to watch as a family. There are a few "adult" humour jokes, but they go right over their heads. Would definitely recommend watching this movie. Check it out.

Leo is a nice movie! I was actually pleasantly surprised by this movie. To be honest, at first I thought this would be a terrible, low-budget, and extremely boring movie directed towards kids But I found myself laughing and even tearing up a little at the ending. The jokes were hilarious. The casting was great. The animation was amazing. As a kids movie, this is great! Your kids will be taught huge life lessons that they most likely will never forget. This is my personal opinion, but I think that this would be better as just a movie and not a musical. I didn't know it was a musical until we started watching Leo. The singing was great, don't get me wrong. Adam Sandler has a great voice, even when he's a lizard, and the students were nice too. I just think it would do better as a non-musical. Other than that, Leo is such a sweet and ridiculously funny musical that kids and adults will enjoy and maybe, just possibly, tear up at.

Ok. I went into this thinking the 'worst movie of the year'. It'll be fun to MST3000K the whole time.\nIt didn't happen, the times I was going to make fun the movie did it for me. I don't have children but I would assume most kids will love. Plus, it's just a damn "feel good" movie. I absolutely loved it.\nI hate the character limit. I have nothing to else to add. I can tell you about my day! Well, I was at work and Becky started to say that Emily is not the mother of the child she is carrying! ... OMG. It was soooo awkward! I mean what is she doing carrying another woman's baby!? She has NO CLASS! ..... thank you and Goodnite..

It's just so painfully unfunny. I made a whole IMDb account because of how bad it was. Like, yeah, tell your kid to stop crying and shut up because they're being annoying, that's a great idea! A wonderful message to be sending to kids, too. It just made me irrationally angry. Animations can be rather disturbing as well. Didn't make it through the whole movie but most of it. I have no idea why all the other reviews are so overwhelmingly positive. The intent of the messages seemed good, but it definitely backfired. Hard. Watch literally anything else on Netflix. It tries so hard to make a point yet it accomplishes nothing. Most horrible movie I've ever seen.

This was a feel good movie with great messages for all ages! You won't go wrong watching Leo! My 9 year old grandson loved it every bit as much as both his parents and his grandpa & I did! We giggled & laughed & learned a great deal! Kids from 1 - 100 years old will love this!
It's always awesome that Adam Sandler includes his family & best friends in his movies! We always enjoy the 80's music from our era too!
Skip anything you were considering watching! Stop trying to figure out what might look good & just watch Leo!
I don't normally buy movies, but I will definitely be buying this one! It's one movie you can watch over & over & not be bored!

Personally, I'm not a fan of the CG- the kids have huge heads and the kindergarteners are creepy.
I kind of wish they chose someone else to play Leo- Adam Sandler is mid.
There a few hilarious moments and quite a few heart warming moments.
The song about not crying was uncomfortable and weird for a kids movie. The songs are so awkward and could be excluded to improve the movie. Definitely unnecessary and awkward.
Overall the storyline is really good and the humor is decent. I wouldn't watch it again or recommend it to other people though. It didn't need to be over an hour. It was like the editors didn't want to cut anything from the script.

This movie really shows that what kids do are all repercussions of what they live at their houses everyday until getting to be grown ups and what a little of love can do to change their whole lives to be better on whatever they do. It shows the power of love and friendships, bonding and creating a relationship with one you can trust to help you express your emotions about things that nobody knows.\nIn my opinion, this movie is great for a family movie night, to feel a heartwarming experience, it is sweet loving and it even gets a tear on your cheek. If I had the opportunity to go watch it to a movie theater I would take it, just because you don't see this kind of movies anywhere anymore, I just feel it was great and would definitely watch it again.

After Tom Hanks performed multiple roles in "The Polar Express," the egomaniacal Jim Carey no doubt couldn't rest until he surpassed Hanks, at least in the number of roles played in a single movie. But as always he utterly overacted each role, putting the many fine nuances of Dickens's extraordinary classic into the background. Fortunately, he was unable to make this inconsistent travesty of the original story any worse: it was so bad, so full of preposterous variations on the original, that it would have been impossible to bring it lower. As the movie progresses, scenes increasingly diverge from the original until the beautiful messages Dickens embedded in the story are overwhelmed by pretentious and unnecessary histrionics. As I say, the worst if the 30 something versions I've seen.

Some reviewers have called this a "new" twist. Uh, no. It is, almost word for word, scene for scene, a faithful adaptation of the original book by Dickens.
The good? Gorgeous scenery, intriguing camera angles and Scrooge's familiar character arc from curmudgeon to repentant soul trying to get things right.
The not so good? The first two ghosts (also played by Carrey) are obnoxiously weird. Christmas Past looks like Jim Carey's smirking head floating incongruously above a wispy phantom torso. And Christmas Present is a jarring, cackling boor, with forced belly laughing at the most bizarre times.
This is not a movie for young viewers. From the beginning funeral for Marley, complete with coins on the dead man's eyes, it is (as originally written) a macabre tale filled with terrifying images. The ghost of Marley is horrific.
Most of the motion capture is mesmerizing, with only a few supporting characters looking flat and poorly animated.
The film also cries out for a more inspiring musical score, instead relying on the crazy antics of multiple characters performed by Carrey to move the story along.
Despite all this, I recommend it as a true book to movie transition, with some beautiful visuals.

Not a bad interpretation of A Christmas Carol and parts of the animation were great but then parts were rather creepy in a bad way and I don't mean the Ghosts/Spirits. Especially the children. You have great realism in parts and then AI type demon children. Strange way to make a movie. As for the dialog, kinda boring and parts of the spirits were either to vague to hear or just annoying.\nJim Carrey performed okay but it's rather monotone overall. Same goes with the spirits. The movie was visually appealing but the tone was rather plain and could of been better. It's like you have one emotion and one emotion only throughout the movie. I think they were trying to go with a literal interpretation of A Christmas Carol but could of been better if not for the weird animation style and lack of overall emotion throughout the movie. Even the transformation comes across as unnatural and forced.\nNot a bad movie but could of been better.

British Reviewer.
Although a score of 7.8/10 is quite high for an overly long, ridiculously Hollywood-ified version of Charles Dickens' novella A Christmas Carol. The sheer will and effort of Jim Carrey smashes this one out of the park and makes it a Christmas classic.
Zemeckis really dragged out some shots, like the scene with the sign above the shop. The car-chase with a miniature Scrooge went on for AGES, I mean, Ebenezer is clearly terrified already by the prospect of his imminent demise. Does he really need pursuing by a carriage pulled by hell-beasts?
Lastly, the grotesqueness of the characters is likely the most accurate portrayal of Victorian poor people but hilariously this is almost certainly a shortcoming of the animation style they chose to use.

My husband finally got me to watch this with him tonight after him owning it for several years. This was the utmost boring thing ever. For the first 55 minutes, there were several 5 minute scenes that could have been only 30 seconds each. Also, I could not understand ninety percent of what anyone was saying, and could not figure out who some people were in relation to others due to that. The only good thing about this is that it finally ended. There's really nothing else to say about this but I'm required to type in a certain amount of characters. I can not see myself ever watching this again unless by force.

A Christmas Carol is a classic Christmas movie and is watched by so many people around that time but I feel that it has been done better than how it was done in this movie. It was a little eerie and the look of scrooge was slightly scary, but that was probably what they were going for but I did not enjoy that part. I liked the third ghost and I felt that the parts he was in made the movie so much better besides when he was laughing because I felt like those scenes were drawn out way longer than they should have been. I liked Scrooge's nephew and I felt that his upbeat demeanor helped the movie when compared to Scrooge's miserableness. I felt that this movie was trying to be more of a scary movie than an actual Christmas movie and they tried too hard when it came to some scenes when they could have just kept it simple. So for those reasons that's why I lowered the rating for it.

The movie was good but it is not a movie that you should watch with younger kids around. It is very dark for a Christmas movie so much so that at points I forgot I was watching a Christmas movie. Another thing was some of the characters felt really goofy. I don't know if it was the script or how some of the characters were portrayed but the characters didn't line up with what was happening in the story. However there are still great parts to this movie. The animations were really good and all of the special effects fit very well together. Even though it was a bit darker than I would have preferred, the darkness really brought Scrooge's change of heart out more instead of just saying it happened. The first and the third spirits were illustrated very well particularly the third spirit. Even though he didn't say a single word he had more impact than the other two spirits combined and it ultimately caused Scrooge's heart. The second spirit almost felt like a transition from the first to the third. He didn't add anything to the story and the only impact he had was that he turned into the third spirit. I get the point of the second spirit but it really felt like he was just there to remind us of what was happening outside of what the other two spirits were doing.\nAll together this is a good story but I felt it kind of tried to be more of a lighthearted story but have a foreboding and haunting feeling but it didn't really succeed in either.

"A Christmas Carol" is one of my favorite Christmas stories and every year in December, when the Christmas is approaching, I rewatch the movie or re-read the book. This year, I decided to give this version of the movie a chance, and I believe it was a great choice.
The film was very well done. Despite being an animated film, the characters and landscapes are so realistically depicted that, initially, I mistook them for real actors and places. The sound and the graphics are fantastic! It felt like I was transposed in the movie and I could see the action through the character's eyes, especially in the scenes of high speed traveling.
The only reasons I rated it a 9 instead of a 10 are that some scenes felt excessively long and somewhat nonsensical, particularly in the third part of the movie. Also, it bothered me that in some scenes, the sun was shining brightly even if it was snowing.
Anyway, overall it was a good movie which I'd enjoy watching again in the following years.

Disney's A Christmas Carol is a classic with the legend Jim Carrey mixed in. A Christmas Carol is a film based on the novel by Charles Dickens. It is one of the many Christmas movies that I watch every year. It never fails to bring a smile to my face and warmth to my heart. I, at first, wasn't a big fan of the animation style but I have grown to love it. The way Ebeneezer changes from a grumpy, old man that doesn't like Christmas to a caring, generous man who loves Christmas and loves giving is really heartwarming. I always love watching this movie and it is among my favorites. Also, there are few instances where the darkness of the topic really shows and it really adds to the sadness and later on, the happiness.

A Christmas Carol is always a classic, in every sense. I find different interpretations of this story to be interesting, and how the tone changes, especially with the eras that these different interpretations are made in. This one, from 2009, probably shaped a lot of kids' childhoods. I don't quite get the "I'm not sure if this is for kids'' sentiment, because the scary/suspenseful parts are PART of what makes this story what it is. It's part of what changes the main character. Sure, some of the visuals were a little jarring in the scary department, so I guess I won't blame parents if they want to show them the Muppets version or other. Maybe they would rather have a bit older than younger kids to watch it, because it is a pretty important story. But I think those parts, especially with the ghost of Christmas Future, were some really great visuals and shots. I loved how the ghost was never fully shown, just a shadow and a hand, and a lunging jumpscare-esc moment.\nThere's something to be said for the animation, though obviously it's from 2009. I think, though, that there were really good things about it - especially mannerisms and facial expressions. The soaring shots and transitions were pretty seamless, and it was cool to see how expansive the town really felt when you're in the sky. Obviously the animation isn't really up to par with today's standards - it's a little bit weirdly colored, the rendering is strange in places and the faces are a bit uncanny, but it's decent enough. There's not really anything to complain about story-wise, because this story has been told so many times that there's nothing to quite critique - I liked how they went with a darker tone, I think it really drove the character motives better, an interesting take. Overall, a decent enough interpretation of the Dickens novel, maybe not the greatest there ever was - but it's a pretty great take.

The high points were the the promise of reliving a great film of my childhood/young adult years. Alas, they were promises unfulfilled. Although I did enjoy this film I did not enjoy this anywhere near to the extent of the original. The charm was sapped out as the script writers tried to contrive original and remake and fell short. There were some poor casting choices but the acting should have been strong from at least some of the actors, yet there was no real feeling coming through, no fight, no heart, some hammy delivery. Disappointing. The visuals were great. It was wonderful seeing such life-like rendering in the animation and CGIs but it sits stiffly when the film is about anthropomorphic creatures, which then do not show the supposed feelings they are supposed to be conveying. It's a strange juxtaposition, especially when Walt Disney himself had worked so hard to get audiences to become emotionally connected to an animated story. Overall, a bit of a let down.

I'm not sure what people were expecting from the remake of an old story. Maybe they were expecting Die Hard with lions?
It's a pretty faithful remake of the animated Lion King, but does miss something somewhere along the way.
Visually it's pretty good, some say the animals lack expression, but you either have realism or make the animals weird with too much expression.
Weirdly I thought Beyonce's voice ruined parts of the film as it just didn't seem to fit the character and her over the top shouty singing further ruining some of the music.
Overall, it's ok, enjoy it and just go along for the ride.

"The Lion King" (2019), directed by Jon Favreau, is a visually stunning reimagining of the beloved 1994 Disney classic. Utilizing groundbreaking photorealistic animation, the film brings the African savannah and its inhabitants to life with breathtaking detail and realism, offering a new experience of the iconic story for a modern audience.
The voice cast in this rendition brings a fresh perspective to the familiar characters. Donald Glover as Simba and BeyoncÃ© as Nala bring a vibrant energy to their roles, infusing the characters with emotional depth and a sense of maturity. James Earl Jones reprises his role as Mufasa, lending the same regal and wise presence that he brought to the original film.
Chiwetel Ejiofor's portrayal of Scar is noteworthy, delivering a performance that is both menacing and nuanced, differentiating his character from the original while maintaining the essence of the villainous brother. The comedic relief provided by Billy Eichner as Timon and Seth Rogen as Pumbaa is delightful, capturing the spirit of the original characters while adding their unique touch.
One of the film's most significant achievements is its groundbreaking animation technology. The animals and environments are rendered with such precision and detail that they blur the line between animation and live-action. This hyper-realistic approach brings a new level of immersion and awe to the film, making it a visual masterpiece.
The soundtrack, featuring new renditions of the classic songs and a few new compositions, complements the film beautifully. Hans Zimmer's score is as powerful and moving as ever, and the new interpretations of songs like "Circle of Life" and "Hakuna Matata" are both respectful of the originals and refreshingly modern.
However, the film's adherence to photorealism comes at a cost. The emotional expressiveness found in traditional animation is somewhat lost in the pursuit of realism, leading to a disconnect between the characters' emotions and their facial expressions. This sometimes results in a lack of emotional impact in scenes that were more emotionally resonant in the animated version.
The narrative stays largely faithful to the original, which is both a strength and a weakness. While it ensures the story remains true to what fans love, it also means the film offers few surprises or deviations, which could be a disappointment for those seeking a new take on the story.
In conclusion, the 2019 version of "The Lion King" is a remarkable feat of technology and a beautiful tribute to the original film. It captures the essence of the story and its characters while providing a new level of visual splendor. While it may not evoke the same emotional depth as the 1994 animation, it stands on its own as a visually captivating and enjoyable retelling of a classic tale. It earns a solid 8 out of 10 for its technological achievements and its ability to bring a beloved story to life in a whole new way.

Truly a beautiful piece of animation (photorealistic animation) but something lacks what the hand drawn 1994 rendition had... there was more heart in the original that I think can be impossible to find with this new style of animation, it's almost like you can't take it all in because of how much detail had gone into creating everything in screen. It's true talent, and perhaps eventually once they've done more of the work, they'll be able to find the heart like they used to have. I would've liked to have seen Jeremy Irons reprised his role as Scar, and the new characterisation of the hyenas are drastically different in this adaptation; here they are more dangerous than comedic relief.

I am of the belief that remakes are reserved for movies that in the broad spectrum considered bad. So I was reluctant to watch this movie when it came out even though I, as a kid, hoped to see a live-action version of my favorite animated movie, which is also why this review is 4 years late.
I was wondering why this movie is almost 30 minuttes longer than the original, and I thought they might expand some before only implied tropes, such as the rules of the land, other characters relationships with the lions, but unfortunately not.
Many characters that had charisma are totally gone. The hyenas are not comic relief as they were and their dynamic between them is also missing. The voice acting is also bland compared to the original, only Billy Eichner and Seth Rogen are great as Timon and Pumba, and John Oliver also has his moments, though it was hard not to miss Rowan Atkinson.
The spectacel of the scenery is stunning, but I still feel it pales compared to the original, such in scenes as the stampede, which seem much smaller and less impactful as well as the opening scene.
The music, which to me at least, was by far the originals strong point, is sidelined with mere notes that reminds you of the original. The songs are cut short, such as Scars "Be prepared" and "Can't wait to be king", and instead we are treated with an original song by BeyoncÃ©, which is good, but not compared to Elton John's songs.
The movie also have a very odd tempo. Sometimes we seem to dwell to much on things that could easily just be left to the imagination, and other times we don't dwell enough on what the original was so good at. Now we dwell more on Scars relationship with Sarabi whom he wants as queen, for some reason, and Shenzi, who were just another one of the hyenas, is the leader, though she has no goal or doesn't make any impact on any of the lead characters, and Banzai and Azizi(Ed's replacement), do try but their banter doesn't fit into how we think of hyenas. The original played a lot on the trope that hyenas laugh, so the movie characters constantly make fun of eachother, situations etc. It's unfortunate, since the original was great at balancing horrible sadness with funny moments.
Many of the voice actors also seem oddly cast. Disney marketed the movie by stating they would try to hire only african-americans for the leads. I know they mean well, but being from a country where English is not the mothertongue means that the will be dubbed regardless plus you can't always hear from a voice where people's ethnicity originates. The only thing that always was the same regardless where you come from was the music, which in the original, I felt celebrates Africa. The African a choir which sang in both Zulu and Swahilli as well as the African tunes were something I believe really stays with a lot of people when they remember the original.
So all in all, the best thing about this movie is the things that it copied from the original and didn't try to improve all to much on. For parents I will always recommend the original, not just because of quality, but also due to the tempo and the length of the remake.

A good film to watch with family members. The story line is the same as in previous versions of this film. The characters are funny and well animated, however more face expressions should be shown. The acting is good, but not better than previous versions of this film. Direction of the plot has a good pace, but the end is too fast, in my opinion. It is similar to other Hollywood films. Film's cinematogrophy is good. Best angles are shown, and the colour palette is wide and general's movie aesthetics has a good quality either. Film's soundtrack is good, but not extraordinary and does not add anything new to previous versions. Film's editing gives absorb's viewers curiosity. In general, it is a good film to watch with family members.

It's one of the Disney movies that I really liked. I didn't expect to enjoy it as much as I did.
The action is well-paced and the storyline is captivating. I never got bored watching it. The movie doesn't contain too many unnecessary scenes which makes it pleasant to watch. Not to mention, the visuals are outstanding, and the animals appear remarkably realistic. You could easily mistake them for real characters.
I was impressed by Simba and Nala's background stories and courage. Their character development was inspiring, and I appreciated the moments of humor that were woven into their portrayal.
It's a heartwarming movie which you can enjoy watching with your entire family.

First musical best left on mute.
(Yes, I meant that and actually did for a minute once. Trust me, this musical remake improves with no volume.)
Ask pretty much anyone to select their favorites of the 1989-1994 Disney powerhouse megahits (The Little Mermaid, Beauty & the Beast, Aladdin and The Lion King) and chances are they'll answer: The Lion is King and Beauty reins in a close second. I'm the opposite (I loved Aladdin and The Little Mermaid more) and probably one of a few humans who's not gaga over the original Lion King.
Don't get me wrong. I do LOVE it. The music's great, the voices wonderful - especially and mostly Jeremy Iron's Scar, James Earl Jones' Mufasa and literally every other character, the animation's beautiful, story's a tale as old as time and still holds up and it's pretty darn funny. It's just... compared with either The Little Mermaid, Aladdin or Beauty & the Beast, it's behind in the race.
Now, for this cash-grab "live" action, it just flat, didn't work. While it's GORGEOUS, breathtaking in almost every scene and the animals looked perfect, the voices/emotions just plain did not jibe. Whatsoever. Not to mention the actual voices themselves. Most were just passable, barely memorable.
I will give credit for Seth Rogen's Pumbaa and Billy Eichner's Timon - both were not bad and were by far, my favorite and only enjoyable characters of the movie. And it's always, always wonderful to have James Earl Jones back as Mufasa. He was definitely a highlight. But...the one that stood out the most was Chiwetel Ejiofor's Scar.
I barely mentioned the awful, boring and bland portrayal of Jafar in 2019's Aladdin in my review for those movies and Jafar wasn't even half as bad as this same year's Scar. Hard not to compare to Jeremy Iron's iconic voice/character, but what a complete letdown. In the 1994 classic, Scar was absolutely incredible and in a jungle of outstanding characters and voices, Jeremy Irons actually elevated the entire movie a few notches. Chiwetel Ejiofor made this 2019 mistake even more forgettable.
Add all that to how much the humor fell flat (for the most part; admittedly, I did laugh a couple of times) and how bad the music and musical numbers were, this does mirror the original four: both are in last place.
But, hey, at least it was MUCH shorter than the other three "live" action remakes. Still over 2 hours, but comparatively speaking, it's welcomed and not as bloated.
***
Final Thoughts: I've never been sure why Scar never killed Simba, himself. He had an amble number of chances, mostly with no witnesses and it's not like they had a CSI: Africa team to figure out who killed Simba.

Director Jon Favreau's exciting live-action adaptation of "The Lion King" hews closer to the Walt Disney animated masterpiece than any of the studio's subsequent remakes, from the jubilant Zulu chant that opens the movie to the thunderous drumbeat that closes it. Technically, the word "live action" is incorrect to describe the film; rather, it should be considered a cover version because it is much more photo-realistic than Favreau's 2016 remake of "The Jungle Book" and is just as animated as the 1994 original.
The debut of newborn Simba atop Pride Rock and the stunning wildebeest stampede that puts him in jeopardy as a cub are two instances where the film nearly copycats the previous Disney cartoon. Hans Zimmer didn't need to adjust a note for these scenes.
The "Lion King" sequel's guiding principle may be referred to as the "Circle of Commerce" if the original's lesson was one of birth and death and mutual respect, as symbolized by the film's intuitive "Circle of Life" motif: This is the latest trend in Disney's attempts to extract new gold from its animated library, following "Hamlet" (which academics believe to be a retelling of an earlier Scandinavian epic), "The Lion King," a Broadway musical, and "The Little Mermaid."
Favreau strengthens the 1994 classic by concentrating on improving the appearance of the earlier movie while generally adhering to its directorial decisions and storyline.

Originally rated 5 but its gotten worse since then. This is mainly for 2 reasons:\nFirst and minorly, I think it's quite clear this, like all other live action remakes, is a soulless decision to try to make more money (it made around 2bil!). There were practically no changes to the actual story, it's literally a copy-cat (pun intended)\nSecond, and most importantly, Jon Favreau did a terrible job directing this. And it's sad because I've seen works of his that I enjoy but the decisions in this movie just were not good. The realism in the animation was one of the worst decisions. I feel nothing watching this movie. Why should I care if none of the other characters show they do? Also the Lion King is a musical, a musical that has its own literal Broadway production. The lions are already singing and dancing as is; why is there no expression to match with it? I've done scene by scene comparisons between this and the original and this version has a worse version every time. I have no reason to re-watch this when I'm not getting anything new out of it and the original is much better anyway. Disney better not let Jon Favreau make another live-action remake; give him Mandalorian or Marvel but not this. Don't watch it, it's pointless.

Chicken Run is an animated film widely remembered for addressing anti-capitalist themes in its subtexts. To say that these subtexts are not included in the narrative is to watch it superficially. The anti-capitalist message is very visible, even in a children's film. These messages can be very controversial because they are in a film aimed at younger audiences. However, it is not something that will somehow influence children to follow some ideology. Those in power will remain in it and increasingly try to increase their wealth to become more powerful over those who are exploited. The characters do not believe they can live a different life, because they are limited to thinking in a different way as a result of the system in which they are inserted. In addition to these subtexts, the animation is good for managing to develop a very fun narrative with very effective comedy.

In the mid-2000s, films emerged that revolutionized the animation industry and Chicken Run has been one of them that is fondly remembered. After the Wallace & Gromit animated shorts, Aardman made its big film debut with this well-developed stop-motion film. On an artistic and artisanal level, it is a film well cared for in its production and character design. Ginger and Rocky are the best characters in the film, being very different, but who later end up forming a strong bond. Rocky is initially presented as a self-centered rooster who ends up empathizing with Ginger. Meanwhile, Ginger is a determined chicken with a strong character who shows how much she cares about her companions and how much she cares about them. The script knows how to keep the humor and seriousness that exists in the story balanced. It is a film with well-hidden social elements and critiques that make the story interesting to watch. Even the good development of the script and the emotionality make some errors present in the film easy to ignore. Chicken Run is definitely another masterpiece of ancient animation and a gem that can continue to be enjoyed to this day. My final rating for this movie is a 9/10.

Today, I re-watched this movie as it's sequel is out and I wanted to recollect the story of the original which I watched a long time ago.\nThe story was simple and light hearted just like a children's story, the screenplay was decent, the direction was good, the animation was unique and the voice actors did a good job. The thrill elements were embedded nicely in the story which makes this movie more enjoyable.\nOverall, this movie was an enjoyable movie which you can watch with your family. I don't know if this story even needed a sequel as the story had a good conclusion but let's see what sequel has to offer.

"Chicken Run" is an animated delight that will have audiences of all ages clucking with laughter and excitement. Set on a seemingly idyllic farm run by the tyrannical Mrs. Tweedy, the film follows a group of plucky chickens who dream of escaping their egg-laying fate. When the spirited and determined Ginger hatches a plan to break free, the stage is set for a high-flying adventure filled with humor, heart, and daring escapades.
The plot unfolds with a mix of clever wit and touching moments as the chickens, led by the intrepid Ginger and the charismatic rooster Rocky, concoct a daring scheme to achieve their freedom. The film expertly weaves together themes of friendship, courage, and the pursuit of dreams, creating a captivating story that resonates on multiple levels.
The animation is charming and skillfully rendered, bringing the expressive characters and lively farm setting to vibrant life. The voice talent, including the talents of Julia Sawalha, Mel Gibson, and Miranda Richardson, infuses the characters with personality and charm, making them instantly endearing to the audience.
"Chicken Run" is a feather-ruffling adventure that effortlessly balances lighthearted humor with genuine emotional depth. With its engaging storyline, well-crafted animation, and memorable characters, this film is a plucky and heartwarming gem that will leave audiences cheering for these courageous chickens. Whether you're a child or a child at heart, "Chicken Run" is a must-see animated classic that will have you rooting for the underdogs from start to finish.

This film stands out for its visual innovation, employing the stop-motion animation technique to create a more captivating aesthetic than conventional 3D animations. The narrative unfolds a captivating and creative story that seamlessly blends elements of comedy, adventure, and drama. The diverse characterization of characters, with each chicken possessing a distinct personality, fosters empathy with the audience. The film adopts a simple yet humorous style that appeals to both younger and older viewers.\nHowever, there are a few points in the narrative where the story could have delved deeper, providing a more profound and impactful experience. There's a sense that the filmmakers could have pushed further to convey a more potent message.

I do love stop motion animation, and other than the stop motion animation studio Laika having great movies, the stop motion studio Aardman is fantastic with one of the movies they made back in the year 2000 called Chicken Run. Chicken Run (2000) has a great cast, great animation, and a villain who can be scary or threatening; there are some dark themes in the movie and the way everything looks is amazing how it is animated with lots of details and funny movements.
The main chicken named Ginger voiced by Julia Sawalha takes every attempt to try to escape the chicken farm, and she has the dedication to get the rest of the chickens out of the farm to safety away from the terrible owners. The rooster Rocky voiced by Mel Gibson is launched into the chicken farm with the chickens believing he can fly so he can help them escape, with funny moments and a building relationship with Ginger. Also, the other chickens on the farm are weird and funny, with there being other characters who are rats who are getting items for the many plans the chickens use to escape the chicken farm, which is built like a prison.
The villains are the owners of the chicken farm with one of them being scary and intimidating, and the other being an idiot seeing the chickens planning something but the intimidating one does not believe him; with their plan of turning the chickens into chicken pies. The stop motion animation is well done with the locations having a lot of details to it, and the characters having many expressions, details, and funny ways they tend to move around, other than using clay for certain things, they also use real objects in a way that is fun to watch when they use them in their plans to escape the farm.
Chicken Run (2000) is a great Aardman stop motion movie that, if you like Aardman, you should give it a watch if you have not already, it is also a good movie to rewatch; it has great stop motion animation, nice characters, funny moments, and an effective villain. This movie is just a fun and entertaining time when watching; if you specifically like animation, you will enjoy this movie, and if you like stop motion films or specifically Aardman, then you will have fun with this film.

This animation is wonderful for me and full of childhood memories, most of my childhood was spent seeing and imagining these cute chicks. I am very satisfied with this animation. I remember that after watching this movie, I was thinking of making a flying car so that I could fly to the sky with it and travel to faraway places, even the plan of my so-called flying car on paper I waited, but alas, before I blinked, my childhood was over and how soon I grew up.\nNow my memories have come alive again and I am impatiently waiting for the second part of this movie to take me back to my childhood once again and travel in the pure world of imagination.

A movie I thought would go in one direction but ended up a bit aimless. Chicken Run is one of those claymation movies that you have to watch and while I enjoyed it, I wished it was way tighter and more affective than it ended up being. A plate was placed in front of me and I expected one thing, but the taste was not only different but also a bit too bland.
A chicken farm is run by an evil woman which only focus is on profit. The chickens try to escape and are blessed with hope in the form of a flying rooster.
What this movie does best is its comedy and the characters. All the characters are memorable and lovable, and the villains are fun and interesting. My favorite character and voice performance was Julia Sawalha as the lead Ginger. She brings so much sas and personality to the character, and having a strong and respectable female lead is awesome. She's such a lovable character not just focusing on her own escape but on everyone escaping together that's amazing. Other characters that I loved were the husband to the villain that was lovably dumb, the two rats and Babs the chicken being so oblivious as to what's going on at all time. The comedy is focused on the dialogue, and it works very well here. The visual gags are fine too.
The character and actually the entire main focus that made the movie feel worse to me was the male lead Rocky. It's fun how we in this era of filmmaking always had to add a man just so there was one. The entire premise goes from prison escape to having fun and lying, and that's a really annoying premise when the original idea was fun too. Having to escape with everyone before we are all killed, yeah this is a kids' movie by the way. This movie could have been tighter and more focused, instead of being about a romance that doesn't matter and using so much time on a plot tread that goes nowhere. I wish this movie was something different, more like its opening promise and premise.
I really loved the molded sets and backgrounds, expert the sky that looked a bit too fake. The opening on the mud on the ground and the metal fence looks so real and well done. The overall mouth and fluidity of the animation is amazing and never really seems like it stutters anywhere. The character designs are also really quirky, but don't really speak to me. The Claymation style is something that doesn't really look appealing to me, and it can look a bit ugly in my opinion. It clashes with the amazing prop department to me and makes the chickens look a worse.
This movie should have been shorter than it is and with a more simple premise, it can feel long and patted also because we, the audience, know the premise is build on a lie. It is a simple premise with extra steps, and that did not speak to me at all. It also doesn't add to the outcome of the movie at all having the runaround with the male lead, and that just frustrates me.
But Chicken Run is still a fun and enjoyable time. It has a lot of character and charm with amazing humor and animation, but to me needed a more compelling plot to really hit home with me.
