Oh, how utterly delightful!! Thanks to its unique premise, the wonderful stop-animation, and the hilarious events, 'Chicken Run' was an instant classic from the very first time I saw it!
Welcome to Tweedy's Farm - an egg farm run by the cruel Mrs Tweedy, who only has profit on her mind. When a chicken fails to lay eggs, she kills and eats it. Thus the chickens fear her, and secretly plan to escape. Only, the farm looks more like a concentration camp and escaping seems impossible.
That is until a rooster named Rocky arrives, who apparently flew into the chicken yard. Believing Rocky to be able to fly, Ginger asks Rocky to teach them to fly. Rocky blames the fact that he can't fly anymore on an injured wing, but agrees to teach the hens to fly. This allows for many hilarious moments. Rocky is wonderfully voiced by Mel Gibson.
Realizing the eggs doesn't turn a good profit, Mrs Tweedy decides to turn the farm into a pie-making factory instead. Now, the chickens are more determined than ever to escape. With Mrs Tweedy's husband nearing completion assembling the pie-making machine, their time is running out and they desperately need a plan...
I absolutely loved all the pun and clever humour. Every one-liner was funny, and hit perfectly. The film is imaginative and innovative and I loved every moment. This is a really sweet film destined to put a smile on your face, and will entertain young and old alike! 'Chicken Run' is just fabulous!

I love this movie. I will rewatch it any time I get sick or just feeling down and it always helps to lift me back up.
It is basically a kids version of the Great Escape with lots of homage paid to that particular movie.
The characters are all great and really fun to watch. The story is pretty entertaining and there is a great balance between adult oriented material and stuff aimed at kids. So anyone will enjoy watching this one.
I am also a fan of stop motion and can appreciate the detail and time it went into making this movie, you can see the quality which makes this one timeless. It was released in 2000 but could easily have come out yesterday.

100/10! This is definitely a movie I've been needing to start the year!\nI was looking for a happy movie and scrolled up to this one. I was planning on just watching the first few minutes, but then got hooked up and continued watching. Wow, this is really perfect for theater or performing arts enthusiasts out there. It showcases what actually happens when preparing for a show and the process. I am speechless. I think I want a performing artist guy now after I've watched the monkey guy perform. He's totally my crush now; I love his voice. I kept crying while watching the show because of how amazing their talent is and how I would love watching it live in real life. I love this movie. To more watching theater shows in 2024!\nBtw, Ms. Crawly is the best when keeping in charge!

The glorious sequel to Sing takes our beloved characters to another level, leaving the theater and venturing into show business on the big stage. The story is almost like the first film, but it is at a higher level seeing how the characters must adapt to a new environment. The soundtrack doesn't have as many familiar songs as the first film, but it's still one of the best things about Sing. Music continues to have great relevance in this universe, being an important element for the stage. The characters must face more difficult challenges such as Buster trying to please mobster Jimmy Crystal or disappoint Rosita, Ash trying to convince Clay Calloway to return to the stage, Johnny trying to be an acrobat dancer and Meena meeting love. Although it was a shame that Mike the mouse didn't return, it didn't affect the magnificence of this movie. This film reflects both the characters and the essence of its predecessor, being a worthy sequel with wonderful animation and amazing sequences. Sing 2 is an excellent sequel and a work of art both visually and aurally. My final rating for this movie is a 10/10.

The original crew from the first movie pack up and try to impress in the big city, which is their version of Las Vegas. It's a bit more cut throat then they're use to and Buster Moon may have bitten off more than he can chew.\nThe sequel is just as charming, and the music is just as good. Hard to say which one I enjoyed more, because both are very well done and on par with each other. Of course having the talents of Bono, Halsey, and Pharrell doesn't hurt one bit.\nAs an adult it's still very entertaining to watch. I mean, who doesn't love a well done talking animal movie with amazing animation and great music? I suspect only a few.

This is great and wonderful but there's a huge caveat: it's a total plot rip from the 1997 WB animation Cats Don't Dance with Scott Bakula. What's crazy is a movie as good as the aforementioned movie is not as well known as you'd think but maybe it is it's just we had not ever seen it before until 26 years later, that's bonkers if you ask me. We're not saying anything negative about either movie I just wish we had seen the WB movie before this Illumination animation. Whatever hope you all get a chance to watch and compare the two movies and enjoy both as much as we have. There are a lot of remakes so it's not a new thing.

I enjoyed the original sing. It was something new having animals audition for a singing competition and new talent. Now buster is back along with his crew as they host a show that sees a TV talent scout call them not good enough. This is the final straw for him so he takes his friends on a roadtrip to a las Vegas looking city to prove that they are good enough to a harsh Simon cowle type and his posh daughter porsha. Porsha was a good character so was the cute cat. I liked the edition of the new characters and watching busters lie get bigger makes you wonder what will happen. Overall I really enjoyed this and thought it was a worthy sequel.

Couldn't they have gotten Larry the Cable Guy instead?
I'm disappointed,
so much processing power...
so many colorful characters,
it all comes down to CV padding for the rich and famous.
Why dear Jeabus why
do people who have filled screens with film after film of their presence,
need to get into voice-over acting (or voice over-acting)?
1. Buster Moon is a Koala
Koalas are Australian
even if he grew up in San Fran,
why does he sound liquored on every line?
Rich Hall jokes about how Tom Cruise films pretty much ran the same script & just changed the scenery
Well, the award for modern day substitute goes to...

I was hesitant about the sequel because I loved the first movie too much, however my expectations were met in this movie. I dare say it might be better than the first movie. From start to finish, I was Entertained all the way. I love the characters, new characters, and the songs. Sure, it is campy but in the best way. It's one of those movies where I feel some critics and audiences are too critical when it comes to cheesy, feel-good movies. As though a good story has to have tragedy, heartbreak, or serious subject matter. Not every story. If this one had one of the main characters die then people will say it's great, but if there's no serious subject matter then it's cheesy, silly, and Eh kids' movie. As an adult, it's a good story structure and a feel-good family-oriented film.

Buster and his friends began their new career by going to Redshore City to audition for a show held by Jimmy Crystal. Buster promises an amazing show by inviting reclusive rock legend Clay Calloway back on stage.\nContinuing the story of the interesting show from the previous film, Sing 2 this time for me looks really much more interesting. The performance of the Buster show is described as much more energetic, festive, colorful and of course with an interesting appearance theme. Sing 2 has a fun, entertaining and funny story plot of each character. This film has a balanced portion of each character who has its own conflict. The final scene of Bono became the best performance of this film with his legendary song that amazes.

No pun intended - did you like the first one? Well you better! You are the reason (well one of many to be fair), that we got a sequel here. I don't know if this was an original idea or came from a different source (book/novel something else), but by now you know the characters in this - the original ones. Of course we get new ones to keep things fresh. Which includes the voice cast from the original but with many more stars added.\nThe animation is nice, the fast paced style (story wise) is being kept ... but the first one seemed to have a certain goal ... something it needed to achieve (or rather the characters) ... not matter if you agreed that animals could have money issues ... suspend your disbelief! They do not talk either (one could argue that some do sing - though not with words of course ... and playing instruments ... well maybe apes can learn or do it, to match a human playing that instrument) ... go for it! It may be the final countdown .. although I assume there will be another one ... at least ...

This movie encompasses how family film used to be. The scope of emotions and personal trials each character goes through is inspiring for children and adults. The character and the actors that bring them to life are very well casted. Too many movies are made without a moral standing or they get caught up in current events but this movie is exactly what I've been looking for. I can not recommend this movie more. It is so wholesome and well put together. It has quickly moved up the list of mine and my children's favorite animated movies. I know we will be watching it many times for years to come. I will be purchasing this movie soon.

The Nightmare Before Christmas uses stop-motion as a tool to tell a fantastic story that could only be conceived in Tim Burton's mind.
The premise is simple, a Halloween-loving man (?) discovers Christmas for the first time and falls in love with it, to the point he convinces everyone in town - who don't know what Christmas is either - to celebrate it together. However, as someone who only knows Halloween, his idea of Christmas doesn't align with what Christmas really is.
The story is told through a set of musical numbers that usually describe the emotional state of Jack Skellington, but also cover other characters like Sally and the rest of the town.
The film basically tells us what would happen if Halloween and Christmas collided. It's a fascinating tale that could only be conceived by Tim Burton.

Jack Skellington is fed up with his lot, all the ghoulishness, the gothic rot and grot, so he's left with a big frown, and found the door to Christmas Town, now he's scheming and conniving a new plot. To begin, he's taken Santa from his sleigh, this is now to be a somewhat darker day, where the gifts won't bring a smile, it's a chocolate log defile, gifts of corpses, frogs and spiders left for play. Ooogie Boogie takes the chance to muscle in, a sack that's full of bugs and evil grin, will this nightmare ever end, can the tormenting be stemmed, or will Jack reverse decay and save the day.\n... or is the nightmare here stay!

Even though Tim Burton did not direct this film, it is impossible not to think that The Nightmare Before Christmas is his best work. This is a film with a very original idea that has all the elements that characterize Tim Burton's vision. It is a fantastic story with terrifying and charming elements at the same time. The clash between two festive dates that are very different because of how terrifying one is and how joyful the other is. The characters are quite a peculiarity and the one who steals the entire film is definitely Jack. The inhabitants of Halloween Town have all the elements of a Halloween party and Jack is a clear variant of the legendary Jack O' Lantern. Here Jack feels tired of doing the same thing every year and decides to make a change in his routine, trying to spread Christmas cheer to find a new purpose, but without taking into account the imbalance that he can cause. Another character that is also worthy of praise is Sally who is definitely the voice of reason and the love she feels for Jack makes her care about him. The characters are as quirky and unusual in personality and design as they always should be in a Tim Burton story. The stop-motion animation helps a lot with the strangeness that the characters have and that is why it is still something very admirable to see in this film. The production design and art are faithful to Tim Burton's vision in many ways. This is due to his strong participation in the production. The soundtrack composed by Danny Elfman is also another admirable element of the film. The songs are unforgettable and have become somewhat iconic for the Halloween and Christmas seasons. It is ironic that Henry Selick has been overshadowed, since he has been in charge of directing and has done a good job, not forgetting to mention that this was his first feature film. His participation was also important and this experience was what led him to make Coraline years later. It is really curious that this has been a case in which a director has been able to create his greatest masterpiece without the need to direct and only taking care of the rest of the production. All the technical details have Tim Burton's vision and essence, as does the story he created. The Nightmare Before Christmas is definitely the best film in Tim Burton's filmography, one of the best animated films in history and a wonderful classic to enjoy at Halloween and Christmas. My final rating for this movie is a 10/10.

Tim Burton wrote and co-produced this short, musical, stop-animation feature, (it was directed by Henry Slick, but has Burton's fingerprins all over it)) as an antidote to other cuddly seasonal features which are available, cleverly conflating probably his own favourite holiday season Halloween with everybody else's, Christmas.
The story's quite simple and straightforward, Halloween Jack (wasn't that a line in a Bowie song?) Skellington (love that spelling!) organises Halloween for his fellow town residents but has lately become bored in the process. To rejuvenate himself, he decides to borrow a few tricks from neighbouring Christmas Town where he thinks a little mix-and-match of the two holidays might succeed. It does seem a bit like painting a moustache on the Mona Lisa and his adoring girlfriend Sally Finkelstein, who is forever trying to escape the attentions of her creator, Dr Finkelstein, tries to tell him so, but headstrong Jack carries on regardless, his master stroke, or so he thinks, being to kidnap Sandy Claws (his spelling), take his place and dispense much less wholesome toys to all the nice boys and girls. Actually in this day and age, I'm not sure old Jack wasn't onto something considering some of the videogames kids play today.
Anyway, at least in 1993, he gets it wrong, spoiling every youngster's Christmas morning and at the same time jeopardising Santa himself who he's left in the care of the bad old Boogie Man. Who knows though, maybe Sally can literally pull herself together and help Jack to save the day...
For me, the most disappointing feature of the movie was the rather lukewarm soundtrack provided by Danny Elfman. None of the songs stay in the memory although I will concede they do help the story along. I liked two sequences in particular, Jack's disastrous delivery of the kiddies' gifts and the showdown with the Boogie Man. The animation is excellent throughout, recalling for me anyway "The Wizard of Oz", "Yellow Submarine" and even "H. R. Pufnstuf". Perhaps I'd have liked a few more good jokes in the dialogue and a little bit darker treatment in the narrative, but on the whole, I'll take Burton's, let's call it a grey Christmas, over "The Snowman" any old Christmas Day.

Not for me or my wife and 12 year old daughter. My Daughter's thoughts were that she expected so much more as it had been recommended and lauded by so many but was left disappointed as the premise was interesting but was ruined by an over abundance of singing. My own thoughts were that the whole Halloweeners trying to understand xmas became pretty repetitive and I lost my interest quite easily as it felt like the same stuff repeated for 73 minutes. It wasnt that Seems we might be being a little petty. But it just didn't feel like a Christmas movie and certainly didn't evoke the same nostalgic feelings that numerous other xmas movies do. Maybe We are just traditionalists . Won't be added to our Christmas Watchlist.

An animated Disney production from 1993 directed by Henry Selick (Coraline, Wendell & Wild), The Nightmare Before Christmas follows "Pumpkin King" Jack Skellington's doomed adventures from Halloween Town to Christmas Town and back again.
Based on a story and characters by Tim Burton, the film is a stop-motion animated musical featuring the singing voice of Danny Elfman, who also wrote the score. While it wasn't a huge hit initially, it soon achieved cult classic status and is seen, to this day, as one of the best animated features of all time. Two holidays are cleverly intertwined here as Jack Skellington (voiced by Chris Sarandon), a Halloween hero, grows tired of entertaining his usual ghoulish crowd, delivering the same spooky thrills year after year. When he discovers a place called Christmas Town, he becomes enamored with the entire concept and so decides to... take it for himself.
A loving yet twisted pastiche of classic Rankin/Bass specials, as well as Dr Seuss' How The Grinch Stole Christmas and other classic cartoons, The Nightmare Before Christmas lures you in quick with its delightfully macabre "This Is Halloween" tune and it never lets go as Danny Elfman offers catchy song after catchy song, making the most of each one in his own unique style. This may have been Tim Burton's idea, and it may be Henry Selick's masterpiece, but it is, first and foremost, Elfman's baby: his work here is nothing short of genius and deserved a lot more recognition back in the day. From the lonely "Jack's Lament" to the bombastic "What's This?", the beautiful "Sally's Song", the playful "Making Christmas" and the devilish "Oogie Boogie's Song", the movie never missteps and is singalong-worthy from start to finish.
The animation here is, frankly, incredible. This is stop-motion at its best with every shot carefully composed, Tim Burton's art style perfectly captured and the emotions of all these bizarre characters conveyed with great care. The character design is unique, the settings are appropriately gothic and countless inventive techniques are used here to make the animation flow in harmony with the music. The film looks gorgeous, of course, but it also has a timeless, nostalgic feel that'll make you want to watch it for both aforementioned holidays every single year. We care about these characters, feel for them, and can't wait to see them naively attempt the impossible in true Halloween Town style!
Few animated films manage to get everything right: The Nightmare Before Christmas is one of those rarities. Hugely entertaining, a visual treat, a truly fantastic musical and, despite its frightening look, very very funny, not to mention filled with the magic that many Christmas movies promise but so often fail to materialize. It's one hell of a sleigh ride and viewers of all ages should get a big kick out of it.
Essential holiday romp.

The Nightmare Before Christmas is THE movie that combines two holidays. Halloween and Christmas are the best holidays of the year (in my opinion at least). This movie combines those two holidays in one. It is way more Halloween than Christmas, with the main characters literally being from a place called Halloween Town. The story revolves around the Pumpkin King Jack getting tired of doing Halloween year after year, which leads him to Christmas. I feel Jack is pretty relatable. There have been a time where I was tired of focusing on one thing all the time. I have recovered from that but still. I feel like the villain should be in the movie a little more. Besides that, I don't really have any complaints.

It's irrefutable that this film is already cult and has been a great influence on many people. Tim Burton's imagery is now recognizable worldwide and it all begins here, with the film directed by Henry Selick. The most notable thing, consequently, is the production design. The characters, the sets, the decoration... absolutely everything has Burton's trademark, which, helped with the practical effects of stop motion, gives us a beautiful visual spectacle. It's without a doubt the most notable.
Now, moving on to other technicalities, the script is somewhat bland, cumbersome and boring. The edition tends to be repetitive and slow, for an animated musical. Everything has a clear justification, obviously, but even so, they are, in my opinion, negative points.
As a side point, between us... was it necessary for it to be a musical? Anyway...
In short, the film can be entertaining for those who like Burton's dark and depressive style, for lovers of stop motion and for those looking for something different, because without a doubt, they will find it here.

I recall watching this back when it was first released and perhaps I was too cynical to appreciate the artistry behind it. I suppose at the time this was ground breaking imagery. And perhaps the years behind soften my take on it.
I went to see the 30th Anniversary version this weekend, and I have to say...my initial reaction was correct.
Though I am absolutely floored at the amount of dedication it takes to spend years on making a movie, the story itself left me flat.
The story is of Jack Skellington, the rock star of Halloween Town, who seems to missing something in his life. A bigger purpose. He accidentally stumbles across Christmas Town and decides to kidnap Santa Clause in order to usurp his joy of giving.
This turns into disaster, so he has to make right.
That's it. There's not real conflict here. You expect a scientist who holds one of his creations hostage to be the guy. But even he's not that bad.
This is a just a meandering film that has a impressive novelty.
Newer viewers will not be THAT impressed.

My youngest daughter of 9 years is very smitten with Halloween this year. She is taking care of the decorations inside and outside the house. And she is even counting down to "All hallows eve" as if it was Christmas Eve.
So she asked me if we could watch Nightmare Before Christmas - since she already knew some songs from her Halloween playlist. And of course I said yes.
I had truely forgotten how wonderful the story is - and also my daughter got captured by it, but she admitted in the end, that she didn't like the form of animation. I on the other side liked it a lot.
But no matter what - this is a wonderful movie and has a good story to tell.

How this sweet little movie failed is beyond me the animation is clever the story is good the characters are well realised it should have been a massive hit but it was killed by sourpuss critics on the Internet before it even started.\nEssentially it's a modern take on the Romeo and Juliette trope a boy and girl from drastically different backgrounds fall in love to the chagrin of their parents, in this case it's a fire girl and a water boy.\nSet in Element city a place where diverse cultures live together in a melting pot society it demonstrates how we can all rub along together even though we have our differences. Nice sweet movie great for children, Pixar at their best.

Elemental is one of my favorite animated films. To be honest, when I first heard about a girl of fire and a water boy falling in love in an elemental city, I thought this would be cringe, predictable, weird, and so not funny. But then I decided to give it a try and wow, I was wrong! It's such a cute 'opposites attract' love story. The dialogue is so funny and the animation is just so beautiful. I love the characters and just watching them fall in love made me so happy. I liked the ending and being able to watch their journey was very satisfying. There are a lot of themes shown, such as racism, immigration, and parental expectations. In the end, Elemental makes a great movie night and I enjoyed it a lot. This will surprise you in a pleasant way and bring a smile to your face.

HOT TAKE: Elemental is amazing. Yes, pun intended but I'm so serious here, folks; this was very done and I urge you to give it a fair shot. Elemental is a modern yet fantastical odyssey of romance and self-realization clashing with the weight of ethnic and generational expectations. A colorful and cultural onslaught of imagination, relatability and sentiment, tailored by two endearing leads with irresistible chemistry.
I'm usually not one for romcoms but if the leads are engaging enough, then I'm sold. Ember and Wade - voiced by fresh talent Leah Lewis and Mamoudou Athie, respectively - share a captivating journey together, one that isn't just focused on love but puts their humanity in a binding spotlight. Their relationship flows oh-so naturally and is 10x more enchanting than any prince and princess story. You know that scene from WALL-E where the robots dance outside the spaceship? Almost the entirety of Elemental follows that one gorgeous sequence's beat and it's utterly charming.
The animation is quite stunning to behold; fluid, expressive and diverse. I can tell Pixar had so much fun with it while pushing the envelope; such a delight to watch. The world drips with inventiveness and attention to detail; I wouldn't pass on living in Element City. I can't leave out Thomas Newman's music, too. This is the composer's fourth collaboration with Pixar (the first since Finding Dory) and his score doesn't disappoint; lovely, often hypnotizing, and always hits the right notes.
Elemental is one of the most soulful and compassionate pictures to come out of Pixar in recent years and it's getting such a bum rap for no good reason. Look, it may seem familiar on the surface but - as expected from the studio that pioneered the art form and tells personal stories - Elemental is built from real relationships and social conflicts and has moving answers to questions on affection, immigration, pressure, sacrifice, and free will. Prepare for some sniffles and tears. I felt the love that was put into it every second and that standing ovation at Cannes was well-earned.
Congrats, Peter Sohn. Thanks for telling your story.

4 out of 5 stars.\nElemental is a good romantic comedy family pixar film that is fun and creative with having a world built with characters that are elements. Certain elements clash with each other and has a story about how two elements Wade and Ember who are fire and water. Ember is from a family immigrant whos father wants her to follow under his footstep on owning the family shop. Wade is a water inspector who fails her shop which Ember tries to convince him to let it go. The opposites attract. They become close and she also realizes that there is more in the world about following her dreams.\nIt is fun. Great visuals and animation. The plot is good. The film may not have any memorable characters and humor. It is still a good worthy pixar film that has a story and visuals thats worth checking out.

Watched this with a group of children from my school on a Christmas treat. The whole cohort sat transfixed and from that point onwards this has become a major discussion point in our classroom. It's beautifully filmed, lovingly delivered and develops the story well as you move along. Yes we have seen this before - but as there are only five or six actual stories in the world that's a 'meh' argument. This isn't a 'flop' from Pixar it's a reimagining which was beautifully done. Ignore the haters - this is a film to be experienced and enjoyed and will allow each person to take away from it what they need from their perspective... well done Pixar.

Watched it with the 9 year-old at his request, knowing little about the film. Most of the metaphors about migration, starting over in a new country with a different culture, passed him by, but this is something my husband and I have experienced and it touched me. He did ask questions and we talked a little about it, which is just what we want with a children's movie: opening up conversations without being traumatic. He was thrilled and touched by the love story, and so was I. A good time, for sure, and we both finished the movie with a warm heart. Recommend watching with kids from 7 or 8 upwards, littlest ones might be engaged by the beautiful visuals but might lose interest.

I love this movie. The world building is so messy, and maybe it's a bit quaint in terms of storytelling, as well as the story itself not being quite strong or cohesive, but I don't care, this is Pixars most underrated film. The characters are endearing. I love ember. Her arc is so strong and the bond between her and her father was compelling. Wade was also pretty cool, and I enjoyed seeing these two together, as they had great chemistry and very solid emotional moments. The animation was gorgeous, with so many colors, and beautiful character designs. The score by Thomas Newman was gorgeous as well, and I love Lauv's song "Steal The Show." The film was funny, but honestly that's another issue, as the movie isn't quite as funny as it thinks it is. Voice acting was really good and I think everyone should be proud of the work they put it in. This movie obviously came from a place of passion and honestly, it's so good. Flawed sure, but it's no doubt one of Pixar's hidden Gems. A little bit of old Disney/Pixar was brought back. Not a ton, but enough.

Phenomenal story line, and animation. This film was thought out so well, I could barely look away to wipe my tears. Recommend for all ages, this is not just a family film! This is now one of my favorites of all time.\nThis film can resonate with millions for a multitude of various reasons, family origin, romance chasers, and even just as simple as a background film for your kids during dinner. I can't recommend this to be added to your watch & rewatch list enough. You won't be able to tear away your attention! Peter Sohn did a such an impeccable job writing & directing; I cried during & again after I learned his parents passed during the making of this film.

Watched this one recently and I gotta say that I regret not watching it on cinemas.
Let's start with the animation. Wow, Pixar has really outdone themselves. It's so beautiful, the design, the rendering, the effects, everything is so pretty. I found myself in awe at everything. Everything was so smart, every element had their own thing, the fire and the air guys were so cool, such a smart design.
Onto the plot, at first I thought it was typical immigrant story but it's actually supper cute. I really thought they would kill the dad and I was not prepare for that. I really love the relationship of the protagonist with her dad. The only reason I give this one a 9/10 it's because we have seen the "I don't want to do your thing dad, I want to do my thing" many, many times. I think we can really move on from that plot and maybe write something new.
Lately Pixar is not doing the best films but this one was really a hit, the kids love it and I hope they keep making great films like this. I would recommend.

So I can understand the human need to relate a movie to real life and draw similarities to what they know or experienced. However, while I am no different in drawing comparisons to known races/stereotypes like some demented scavenger hunt, I found it to be more enjoyable to just watch it as is. I follow my daughter's example and just watch it as they would.\nIt really boils down to different people falling in love who come from different cultures and parenting style. It's hard not to be able to relate as we all do this everyday. That being said...\nIt's really a good movie if you just give it a chance.

Illumination Entertainment has made a name for itself as a reliable provider of quality family entertainment since the release of Despicable Me.\nAlthough Sing is Illumination's debut musical, it shares many similarities with the company's other productions. A wonderful time is had by all, even though the star-studded cast and equally star-studded song catalogue don't go very deep.\nNaturally, though, the entire plot serves as a vehicle for the music. From Van Halen to BeyoncÃ©, the production seems to have spent no money at all obtaining the rights to a long and diverse range of songs. Some become the focal point of elaborate musical pieces, while others are only included in the soundtrack.

The creators of Despicable Me present an original animated film that revives the magic of musicals. This film is a masterful work that also has an excellent soundtrack made of a very good choice of popular songs from different eras. This story is built through the lives of different characters with a common goal, which is stardom in the world of music. We have the rogue Koala Buster Moon played by the great Matthew McConaughey, who always remains optimistic trying to do the impossible to take his theater to the top. The little pig Rosita who is a responsible mother with a big dream. She is accompanied by the charismatic Gunter voiced by Nick Kroll. Ambitious mouse Mike, played by Seth MacFarlane, who has an excellent jazz voice. The punk porcupine Ash who is voiced by the great Scarlett Johansson, and is one of the best characters in the movie. Taron Egerton playing the gorilla Johnny who doesn't want to be a criminal like his father. Lastly we have Tori Kelly as Meena, the shy elephant whose opportunity to be a singer is limited by her shyness. The film offers magnificent musical moments with excellent animation that can be admired on an artistic and visual level. Sing is one of Illumination's best films and an excellent animated film that pays tribute to the world of music in a worthy way. My final rating for this movie is a 10/10.

This is a sensational animated film for all viewers to watch and really enjoy. The crew did a great job in creating this animated film. All the music and songs were exceptional and splendid. The storyline was terrific and harmonious. The cast selection was absolutely excellent and huge. They strongly committed and connected to the storyline and to their respective characters. This animated film reveals to viewers there is no shame in anyone in revealing who you truly are in a person. If anyone has a story or something to show, they are allowed to that. The main reason that I became a writer is to tell my own story and be heard. This is a great animated film for everyone to watch.

When I started watching it i wasn't supposed that it'll hit me like that, I was thinking that it's gonna be a normal cartoon movie,but it gave me goosebumps many times, and the song used in the movie and the characters who sang those songs was so amazing
The movie doesn't disappoint you anywhere, all have to say that I laughed i cried i surprised and I got excited
while watching it.
The characters and their nature, backstory are just wow, this is a movie that won't let you to forget it
All characters was amazing but , 'moon'hit me hard, his coming timing
And the way that how he does it works was lit , it really made me cry when his theatre got destroyed, and i also cried when he rebuilt his theatre
Gotta say that,you should watch it.

Prepare to hear all your least favourite and played-to-death pop songs with even MORE autotune than ever before. The movie refuses to even take a risk of allowing singing voices to be even a single cent out of tune, and it loses all soul. That's the biggest crime, this movie is absolutely devoid of soul.\nJohn C. Reilly is in this, "Walk Hard" was one of the greatest musical comedies of all time with some truly well-written original music, this is the complete antithesis of that. No laughs, nothing memorable, no new ground, just an auto-generated, auto-corrected, useless, stinking waste of time for everyone.

No pun intended - I mean animals needing money? Also the inciting incident being quite ... well you have to suspend your disbelief to be able to go on watching. Ans to add to that: you have to dig and like Musicals to a degree .. a lot of songs (and dance numbers) thrown your way during the run time of the movie. I wouldn't have thought this would spawn a sequel, but it was quite succesful - and I finally was able to watch both movies the other day.\nThat all being said, this is quite interesting and if you don't have issues with animals being ... well humanized (though none of them even thinks about selling their organs to get out of their financial issues ... probably wouldn't get much for them anyway) ... you can watch this and have fun with it. Even more so with the voice talent at hand ... alright alright alright ... quite fast paced ... better shape up ... yes looks like this is the one that you want ... ooh ooh ooh (no pun intended)

A very enjoyable and charming movie musical featuring tons of covers, an electric cast of animals and a good dose of wit along the way. Definitely a family movie I can recommend.
My favourite character is Mike the Mouse, mainly because of his hilariously self-centred personality but also because he has the most interesting arc in terms of character development.
The formula is somewhat familiar, but you do get to care about these crooning beasts and if the big climax doesn't have you cheering to the rafters, you may very well have no heart.
A well-earned 7/10 from me. About to watch the sequel... be back soon!

Delightful animated movie that will have you singing and dancing along with its charming characters and catchy tunes.
The story is set in a bustling city populated by anthropomorphic animals, each with their dreams and aspirations. Buster Moon, an enthusiastic koala with a passion for theater, runs a once-grand but now struggling theater. He's determined to bring back its former glory, but the theater is facing financial difficulties.
In a stroke of inspiration, Buster decides to organize a singing competition called "Singing Sensation" to attract a large audience and save the theater from foreclosure. However, a small mishap results in the prize money being mistakenly advertised as way more than what Buster can actually afford.
Despite the mix-up, a diverse group of talented animals auditions for the competition, each with their unique backgrounds and dreams. Among them are Rosita, an overworked and underappreciated mother of 25 piglets; Johnny, a gorilla torn between his passion for singing and his family's criminal activities; Ash, a rebellious teenage porcupine with a rocky relationship with her boyfriend; Meena, a shy and timid elephant with a powerful voice; and Mike, a smooth-talking mouse with big dreams.
As the auditions unfold and rehearsals begin, the contestants face various personal challenges and setbacks. Buster also faces mounting pressure to find a way to raise the prize money before the truth is revealed.
Despite the obstacles, the contestants work hard and support each other, forming unexpected friendships and discovering their true passions along the way. As the day of the big show approaches, excitement builds, and the theater comes alive with anticipation.
The grand finale of "Singing Sensation" is a heartwarming and spectacular event that showcases the talents of the lovable characters. Each contestant gives their all, but a series of mishaps and unexpected events threaten to derail the show.
In a touching and uplifting climax, the characters come together to save the day, proving that true success is not measured solely by fame or fortune, but by the joy of pursuing one's passion and the support of friends and loved ones.
"SIng" is a feel-good movie that celebrates the power of music, the importance of chasing dreams, and the strength of community. With its lovable characters, humorous moments, and a fantastic soundtrack featuring popular songs, "Sing" is a heartwarming and entertaining film that will leave you with a smile on your face and a song in your heart.

I saw the original Sing not long after it came out. To me it was Illumination's best effort, not great but avoiding many of the pitfalls of their other movies. I didn't give it much of a critical eye but did enjoy rooting for the characters to achieve their goals, and even gave Buster a free pass for his bankrupt morals. Sing 2 came years later and I wasn't quite as enamored with the sequel despite of it going bigger and louder, and adding some great new characters (what they did to Jimmy Crystal was criminal, he deserves better). I appreciate the generally lowkey character moments and backstories that the sequel sort of abandoned, but the truth for both movies is that Buster Moon is the biggest thorn in this franchise's side. But things started to fall in place for me once I came to accept a theory that isn't wholly original but was solidified by Buster's behavior in the sequel: Buster Moon is a villain protagonist.
Sing is the story of a struggling theater producer and a menagerie of characters that find salvation to their personal struggles through the power of song. Buster Moon finds himself in dire financial straits after a long string of flops at his theater scares his benefactors into pulling out. With the bank on the verge of seizing his crumbling theater, Buster cooks up a last-ditch scheme to save it: put on a singing competition. We are then introduced to a group of hopefuls: Johnny the gorilla is a sensitive soul with a gangster father pulling him into a life of crime, but all he wants to do is sing. Rosita the pig is a housewife that gave up her dream to raise her family, an arc that might be slightly undercut by the fact that she has, no joke, twenty-five kids. Ash the porcupine must find a way to express her true self after decoupling from her unfaithful, gaslighting boyfriend Lance. Meena the elephant has a booming voice but is deeply shy and too afraid to perform when it matters. Mike the mouse is the designated jerk with a velvet voice, a schemer that must discover if singing is his true calling. Gunter the pig talks in a funny voice and dabbles in comic relief. Yeah, that one got the short end of the stick, but at least he has some moments of emotional intelligence.
Besides the characters' individual struggles, the main conflict arises when the $1000 prize is misprinted as $100k by Buster's bumbling assistant Ms. Crawly. Buster then engages in a house of cards scheme by trying to woo his best friend's rich grandmother, theater legend Nana Noodleman, into fronting the prize money. Along the way, Buster commits a litany of petty crimes and shows a strong aversion to telling the truth before it all blows up in his face in spectacular fashion.
Sing doesn't particularly excel at anything, but it is a comfy movie. The story is unambitious but humble and feels like there was a passion for old Hollywood movies about putting on a show to save a theater or something like that. The music selection is wide and definitely feels like it was trying to appeal to more than just kids. Character designs aren't great, with almost random proportions that make the characters feel like they were designed for a different medium before being haphazardly slapped into a CG feature without much grace or care. Zootopia is much better about designing anthropomorphic animal characters, with a world built to fit them. Sing's world is literally just our world with no regard for the wide amount of shapes and sizes for its population. I'm not sure if this generic setting is a result of Illumination's famously restrained budgets or a complete lack of desire from the creative team to do any world building.
The movie flops a bit when it comes to how non-committal it is to its narratives and character arcs. Sing has what I call "passable in the moment" writing: It's mostly working when you watch it, but if you think about anything for more than 5 seconds, it just doesn't make any sense. The conflict between Johnny and his dad is the most popular arc in the movie and a prime example. When Johnny's dad rejects him for singing, there's no given reason behind his actions. He just does. And when they reconcile, it comes off as a bit absurd, because why was he against his son singing in the first place? Nobody knows! This really extends to just about anything resembling conflict in this movie. Most problems just... work themselves out. Meena's shy until she isn't. The plot doesn't explore why she's shy or some plan to overcome it... people just tell her to stop being shy until she isn't, then everything works itself out. This movie's threadbare theme of believing in yourself is quite literal, because at no point do any of these characters engage in hard work or intelligent thought when it comes to problem solving. They believe, and then everything just works out.
Sing's biggest weakness is its protagonist. Buster Moon exists in a space of sentimentality and fluff, where morals sorta do but really don't matter. I think protagonists should have flaws, especially in kid-friendly material, because those characters make mistakes, learn from them, and grow into better people. The problem here is that Sing wants to have its cake and eat it too when it comes to Buster. He does unequivocally terrible things that hurts other characters but never goes through the stage of growth that includes acknowledging what you did wrong, apologizing, making amends, and taking steps to be better - and prospers in spite of this. This isn't a fluke in this movie; Buster's misdeeds continue in Sing 2 when he starts the movie off by defrauding Jimmy Crystal in what was a good faith business deal on Crystal's part. Crystal is one of the few characters to call Buster's bad behavior out and is horribly vilified by the movie in response, despite not doing much of anything villainous for most of the narrative. This is around the time I started to sour on Buster as a character. It feels manipulative that the gorilla disowned by his parent or the elephant struggling with stage fright can't succeed unless the con artist exploiting them does too. A sleazy theater owner taking advantage of a bunch of wide-eyed dreamers would undoubtedly be a villain character in any other story. His happy ending is just given to him on a silver platter - he didn't really earn it, and he learned nothing from the mistakes he made. Not every character needs to be a role model, but Buster is definitely a terrible one.
Despite its many warts, I feel like Sing is the blueprint for Illumination to make better movies, because it actually tries when it comes to character and narrative. They... don't seem to be following that blueprint, but with a third Sing movie on the horizon, it's never too late to learn. With all the money they rake in, there's no reason not to try to be better beyond pure hubris.

This movie, about a city of humanoid animals, a hustling theater impresario's attempt to save his theater with a singing competition who becomes grander than he anticipates even as its finalists find that their lives will never be the same, is a good beginning to the Sing duology (2016-2021).
This was a heartwarming movie. It presented the lives of different characters that had their own personal problems in their everyday life. What I really admired was its realistic context, because, as said, the general everyday lives of the characters, but also the urban visuals and the sound! It felt very real!
The story was kind of simple, but I liked the way it was told. It also had some decent humor, as well, which made the movie quite entertaining.
The animation was fantastic, but so were the actors - and their voices, especially Tori Kelly's (as Meena)! I haven't been very active on listening to Kelly's discography, but I think she sang literally perfect! Not that she's a new artist, but I haven't really noticed her before. Anyway, the theater performances were incredible, and I had a good time watching them. Every number was so talented!
Overall, a simple story with fantastic, technical aspects that can teach us about our everyday lives.

movieName: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem
content:
FILM: 8/10.
As a 43-year-old original fan of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles comics, cartoons, and the live-action films from the 90s, my expectations were as low as a pizza in the sewer. Many attempts to recapture the turtle magic had fallen flatter than a deflated pizza crust. However, Seth Rogen, Evan Goldberg, and the writers behind Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem pleasantly surprised me, delivering the best TMNT content in decades.
Featuring actual teenagers as the voice cast adds a pepperoni twist to the turtles, infusing their characters with the energy and idiocy of adolescence. The tangents and teenage spirals perfectly capture that age, earning a ninja nod of approval. The rest of the cast, a deep roster of talent, brings the characters to life with flair.
Ditching the usual focus on the Shredder and the Foot Clan, the film takes a refreshing turn with Ice Cube's Superfly and a rogues' gallery of secondary villains. It's a topping of variety that's been missing in previous TMNT projects.
The animation is as unique as a turtle shell, and Mutant Mayhem does for TMNT what Into the Spider-Verse did for Spider-Man, giving it a fresh and visually captivating spin.
Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross's score, like the perfect blend of cheese and tomato sauce, hits all the right notes. Their fusion of acoustic and electronic elements creates a varied soundtrack that complements each scene like the perfect pizza pairing.
After enduring some disappointing Michael Bay-produced films, this reboot was like a pizza delivery in a half shell, exactly what the TMNT franchise needed. Bring on the sequel, and let the turtles keep kicking shell with their newfound freshness! A turtle power revival that's as satisfying as a slice with all your favorite toppings.
FORMAT: 4K Ultra HD Blu-ray
VIDEO: 10/10.
Upscaled 4K presentation, Detail level: Excellent, Colour reproduction: Excellent, Level accuracy: Excellent, Encode: Excellent, Master condition: Excellent
AUDIO: 10/10.
Dolby Atmos audio, Dialogue reproduction: Excellent, Soundtrack & effects clarity: Excellent, Dynamics: Excellent, Surround sound presentation: Excellent, LFE content: Excellent
MOOFIEMETER: 8/10.

movieName: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem
content:
The problem with origin super hero movies is they're all the same on the surface, that's why Spider-Man Homecoming skipped Peter Parker's whole origin story because we've heard it a thousand times, but TMNT isn't quite as popular so they had to go over the basics. As a result, the characters and animation are fun, but the story could have been written by an AI. A sequel should take care of that though. In the next movie, we'll have these fun charters already established and the story can go wherever they want to take it, which is exciting!
Speaking of the characters, they're super fun and acted by actual teenagers! They're pretty annoying but in a "teenaged boys having harmless fun" kinda way which I really vibed with.
I appreciate the animation isn't the simple 3D Pixar animation we've been seeing for the past 2 decades, but I'd be remiss if I didn't say I thought this was the same studio that made the Spider-Verse movies, turns out they're entirely different and unrelated. I enjoy unique art styles, and they try to separate themselves from the Spider-verse films, but it's obvious that some studio exec said "I want a movie like the Spider-Verse movies" and thus we got TMNT Mutant Mayhem. That's not to say the animation is bad or anything, but to me it felt like the movie didn't have an identity. It didn't help having all the pop music needle drops either.
This movie will be incredibly dated in just 10 years with all its modern references, but hey it's fun now and that's all that really matters.
Overall, I'd definitely recommend the movie, but don't hold your breath for anything crazy like the Spider-Verse movies this film was so clearly trying to copy.

movieName: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem
content:
STAR RATING: ***** Brilliant **** Very Good *** Okay ** Poor * Awful
Despite protecting the city from crime, the Turtles, and their master Splinter (Jackie Chan) must live beneath it in the sewers, as the public spurn them because they don't look like them. In the middle of this, the city is under attack from the criminal mastermind, Superfly (Ice Cube), a giant, sludgy bug who's got the local crime monopoly under his control. Cue a run in with cool, streetwise aspiring reporter April O' Neill (Ayo Edibiri), with whom they strike a deal: they'll let her into their world, in return for positive exposure in the social media world April is fluent with.
I tend to be fairly loyal, with any franchise with a long established fan base, as it goes through the years, meaning different things to new generations in new incarnations. One that maybe drifted away was the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which remained fundamentally aimed at kids, without the dark potential to explore, like with the Batman films. And so Mutant Mayhem, the latest version of the original cartoon, passed me by, especially with 'permanent teenager' Seth Rogan, who I'm no great fan of, being one of the writers and producers. But, I've finally given it a go on streaming...and it's even worse than I thought, for reasons I'd never have thought.
Directors Geoff Rowe and Kyle Spears are going with an experimental style with the animation, which may appeal to some, but comes off as crude and garish to those of a certain taste. But what's even worse is how they've mangled the characters and their backstories. Jackie Chan's Splinter has morphed from his original calm, restrained manner, into some funky hipster, who plays them old school hip hop tunes that came out before most of the target demographic were born, and won't remember. To be fair, the Turtles retain their original distinctive characteristics, but what is up with Donatello's voice, sounding like some infant who's just learned to talk?!? No wonder it seems voiceover artist Micah Abbey is the only one too embarrassed to have a publicity headshot.
Crucially, though, the plot is threadbare, the humour has far more misses than hits, and the whole thing feels like a hideous mangling of the original version, that hints it may be time for the Turtles to put their weapons back in their holsters. *

movieName: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem
content:
To start off it was an easy watch for me due to the music as it was clearly compiled by someone who grew up around the same era as me.
The art style was really quite nice but for a poster, not for the film. It didn't work and a different style would have been much better.
It's not really an all ages thing. It just wasn't suitable for adults. The dialogue was really annoying for anyone age 10+. The script was the same, very immature.
I felt like there were lots of nods to different popular things to try and score brownie points with everyone, such as BTS and Attack in Titan.
The whole thing was just boring and fell flat. It was quite simply a bit of boring feature length cartoon.
Just nothing to like with a kids story that did nothing, kids dialogue that was annoying and a soundtrack and art style that didn't really work.
Yet another disappointment.
I'm actually getting so disappointed with Hollywood films that are complete rubbish, getting decent reviews that I am probably going to return to not watching films out of the US anymore. They just have no substance and keep getting worse.

movieName: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem
content: I wasn't quite sure what to expect watching this movie. First of all I am not a huge fan of the style of animation. So, for me it was a bit of a big strike against. But the biggest strike against it is changing the characters and the backstory. Villains weren't really villains and weren't allowed to shine.\nIt's campy, full of cliches and quite silly. That's the part that works. Voice acting is quite good. There really isn't much for character development. The storyline is overly simplistic. Being, primarily a kids movie, that was expected.\nDespite all the flaws it is entertaining but it starts from what is the TMNT's.

movieName: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem
content: I grew up with the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles show from the 87, saw all the movies up until this one. I was not impressed with the last 2 remakes but as average as they were at least they didn't make me upset. I don't even know where to start. They changed the origin story which might which could have been okay if it was well-written, but that was not the case. Everything seemed so bland and unbelievable. I almost lost it when there was a scene where Splinter was sitting in a couch scrolling through his cell phone like an old man having nothing else to do. The writers tried so hard to be smart and funny but to me failed at all levels. Most of the jokes didn't land and I couldn't care less or sympathize with most of the characters. This seems like one of those "modern" remakes that are so popular these days. I could almost feel Seth Rogen's touch all over the material. I still liked the animation and the voice acting was decent. Other than that it's an empty shell. Even at 100 minutes it felt so long.

movieName: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem
content:
Nerd Turtles (2023) is a batch of sensory overload and gross animation. Junk food for the mind. It actually made me feel sick after watching, and I don't know if that's done intentionally.
I would have nice things to say about TMNT: Mutant Mayhem, but for whatever reason, it just makes me feel awful discussing the fact that I watched it, so without wasting time, here's a hot take on the movie instead:
I'd probably enjoy this movie a lot more if I were a kid, but being honest, I think even the most die-hard Ninja Turtle fans know this movie didn't live up to their expectations. For one, the style is fitting, but it lacks in delivery for a number of reasons. Some of the character designs are freakishly off-putting for some reason. Not the main turtle designs, but a lot of the others. April O'Neil, at many points, had eye problems. (I'm not sure if I'm the only one who noticed that.)
Another problem with making a movie in the same vein as Spider-Verse is that, while TMNT: Mutant Mayhem doesn't directly copy the style verbatim, it does strike me as being a little bit low quality for trying to replicate the personality without understanding why the personality of Spider-Verse worked in the first place. Spider-Verse 1 and 2 may have set a high bar for what could be accomplished with visual aesthetics, but they never sacrificed simplicity. On the other hand, TMNT: Mutant Mayhem tries to do it's own thing, but at the expense of battering the Ninja Turtle source material in order to fit in. There were other problems with the animation outside of this, but I'll give the movie a pass in this area.
The writing is so generic, it actually makes me want to cry. There could be so much more done with this franchise, and if they do make a sequel, I'm hoping they learn from what stunk about Mutant Mayhem, because a lot of the writing had its high points and a lot more low points. There's nothing necessarily wrong with the premise, and the ideas stick to the wall, but without spoiling anything, it's clear this movie is made to hype up the next movie and not as its own stand-alone film. This is the "how do you do, fellow kids" to the Ninja Turtles franchise.
I am able to tolerate this movie, I just don't want to think about it anymore. I'll give credit where credit is due and say that it didn't eat me inside, but it just makes me not want to look at another pop culture reference ever again. This movie had too many of those, to which I will add, "Am I not turtley enough for the turtle club?" If what I said was hard for you to endure, that's how I felt about this movie. *sigh*

movieName: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem
content:
While I did think this was a pretty good effort on the Turtles, probably the best since the old movies I grew up on. The art style was excellent, very unique. There were parts where it looked almost like claymation mixed with illustration or something.
This is the first time I've seen the Turtles treated like actual TEENAGERS. I said so to a couple of people who said "Didn't they always act like Teenagers?" to which I say NO. They acted like Surfers. They also made an effort to incorporate some more of the comic/cartoon characters that people are less familiar with, which I thought was nice.
The movie was not without flaws. First off, there's no Shredder. I get that he's not the only villain, but I was hoping for some Shredder. The soundtrack was mostly fine, but they repeatedly used the song "Ante Up" like it was the theme of the movie and that song very flatly glorifies armed robbery. If you're going to gear your movie towards kids, maybe be a little more conscious of the messages you're sending. Also I don't mind the basic changes to April, but why did they shape her like a potato?
Overall it was an enjoyable enough kids movie for an adult to get through, it had some genuine humor and writing to it which I did not expect.

movieName: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem
content: It's cringe. I didn't expect this. This movie is just a movie for 5 years old kids, really. They will laugh, especially on that type of silly jokes about family, outdated dad and etc. I am 28 and this is a very sad thing to realize that TMNT universe is getting worser every time. All-time's best is 2003 TMNT animated series Seasons 1-5. Just try to compare it, 80's turtles, Seasons 6-7 of 2003 TMNT, Michael Bay's movie and its sequel, Nickelodeon era, and this one are on the same shame boat, it's all as bad as it can be, very silly created content. Sell the rights to Marvel, please. It may be an option to make TMNT great again.

movieName: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Mutant Mayhem
content:
As a Milenial / Gen z this is the best iteration I've seen so far. I understand the hate, as some are stating, it's not 100% true to the source material. But i'ts a fun ride, and it's a much needed addition since there are not a lot of other good movies or media as to date.
Keep in mind it feels more like a childrens' movie, but if I would have had this as a kid. Oh man, it scratches the itch.
The music is on par and so is much of the cinematography.
I am a sucker for feel good non accepted people media, and this movie made me laugh, made me sentimental, and at the end I just felt like the movie was more than worth my time.
Give this one a go if you are up for a good time.

I don't think it's possible to grasp just how great this movie is. How easy it would have been to succumb to the temptation to glorify a gigantic genius called Bernstein, illustrate it with music and make a spectacle out of it that everyone would like. Bradley Cooper chose not to do any of that, but to focus on just one aspect of Bernstein's life, namely his relationship with his wife Felicia, whom he loved and with whom he had children, but whom he did not desire. Bradley Cooper makes this Bernstein appear as a person who has faults, who is weak, but who also barely knows how to tame his own genius and whose desperation at having to choose between composing and conducting is made visible without much fuss. Carey Mulligan is a great player, without a doubt. But I miss the nuances of this initially somewhat over-excited woman, who slowly realizes that her husband tends to hang out with men, even though that was the condition of the marriage from the beginning. The moment in which Bernstein conducts the finale of Mahler's Symphony No. 2 is so cleverly chosen that one could probably write a doctoral thesis on Cooper's motif or on the function that this work, which is nicknamed the "Resurrection Symphony", takes on at this point. A remarkable film and an incredibly good piece of work. Cooper's second directorial effort. My goodness, there's a lot more to come. I'm looking forward to it.

But not interesting enough to get by the cartoon nose; it's very distracting. The acting is good but I didn't feel any chemistry between Cooper and Mulligan, or Cooper and Bomer for that matter. The story line is somewhat choppy; snapshots of high points in Bernstein's life, skipping years at some points. There isn't any character development; there isn't much of a plot. It's almost like watching an old newsreel. I'd rather read an in-depth biography of Bernstein. The clothing is interesting and the music is enjoyable, but I wish there was more music and some background on Bernstein's works. I think they could have done a better job.

Honestly, Lost all respect for Cooper after how he misbehaved while demanding awards for the worthless remake of "a star is born." Remember how they campaigned for awards, pretending he and Gaga were so in love, give us the Oscar. With this movie, Cooper has completely rewritten the story to fit his oscar attempts, not to enlighten us of Mr. Bernstein's life story. Bernstein's children and associates were justifiably critical of this movir, which is Cooper's cherrypicked vision and not at all a complete depiction of genius stuggles of Mr. Bernstein. Better to watch the PBS biography than waste time with Cooper's rewriting for his own delusuion once again. A bomb at the Box Office and justifiably so. One wishes Cooper could find another "Las Vegas" type comedy to redeem his pretentious career. At this rate, he has little chance of redemption with his previous fans. This is the last time to attempt to watch his movie for me. All I see is a man demanding awards and trotting out Gaga to do so once again.

The movie moves quickly through Leonard Bernstein's adult life, bouncing from one scene to the next, but the scenes themselves are slow and empty and never really show his inner world. The lack of deeper character development made the movie stay on the surface the entire time. It was painfully boring. And the script was trite.\nIt's unfortunate since Leonard Bernstein is an interesting topic for a movie. I think it would have been better to have focused on just one part of his life and have a deeper expression, character perspective, and story line.\nI walked away not knowing anything about him.

Before I saw the movie ''Maestro''. Didn't I know who Leonard Bernstein was.
This film opened my eyes, but also my ears to Bernstein's amazing, soulful musical ability to create music in any form.
In the film, Bradley Cooper presents Bernstein's strengths and weaknesses as an artist in classical music.
As a closet gay in a conservative USA at a time when it was difficult to be openly gay. Until he falls for the actress Felicia Montealegre, who makes him test his artistic and human limits.
Bradley Cooper who not only plays the lead role of Bernstein, but also directs the entire film. Presents the entire setting of Bernstein's classical music masterfully, presenting his music through his dark sides to his good sides through his expression of his artistic soul.
A film that touched my own soul for art and music.
If you have a great sense of classical music in a modern form, then this film is for you.
Strongly recommend.

Maestro was released at the end of 2023 and it's been a film I've looked forward to since Bradley Cooper helmed the film as director-writer-producer-actor. He's also working alongside cinematographer Matthew Libatique again, who worked with him on A Star Is Born. It wasn't like I expected, mostly regarding almost half of the film was in black and white and also the aspect ratio. I went in almost completely blind with who these two are, maybe not the best thing to do as they move through the events fast in its 129 minutes run time. Maestro begins with an older Bernstein played brilliantly by Bradley Cooper who has his face covered in makeup and prosthetics which makes him look like Leonard Bernstein, the sequence was in color and the next one is in black and white which sees Bradley Cooper in the same role but at a much younger age. Spectacular cinematography. The sound and music in the film is brilliant, making use of the atmos track, and of Bernstein's music in the right way. Where the film shines the most of Cooper's vision is how this is not solely Leonard Bernstein's story but also Felicia Montealegre's, Cooper wrote the film with Josh Singer and these two wrote a brilliant screenplay. It's also worth noting that both Martin Scorsese and Steven Spielberg produced the film (along with a few others), both were thinking of directing it and would it have been an entirely different film? I don't think so. Bradley Cooper and Martin Scorsese seem to have the same vision for the film and the same work ethic, I think both of these maestros were impressed with the film Cooper created.
This love story chronicles the lifelong relationship of conductor-composer Leonard Bernstein and actress Felicia Montealegre Cohn Bernstein.
Bradley Cooper nailed the performance and with the help of makeup and prosthetics he ultimately became the character, even getting help from Bernstein's children, what we see on the screen is a magnificent piece of performance which will be remembered as one of the best of his career. The film has him star next to Carey Mulligan and her performance was fantastic, neither are outshining each other, their acting is as impressive and I think the direction Cooper gave her helped immensely as this might be her best performance to date. Another performance worth praising is Matt Bomer as David Oppenheim.
Maestro was named one of the top 10 films of 2023 by the National Board of Review and the American Film Institute. Is this a great film? Absolutely! It isn't really a great biopic though as I wrote before, they go through his life too quickly and the focus we get is on his wife and music, nothing else really. Yet the majority of scenes are there for these two actors to act out and give us award-worthy performances. I liked the film a lot but I expected it to be grander in scale, yet, this smaller scale and focus on their relationship and the psychology makes it interesting. The cinematography, screenplay, direction and acting is spectacular. I don't think this film has what it takes to win Best Picture though, but other awards, for sure! There's so many brilliant shots, the church sequence is pure cinema, that is what this film is. Not a great story but a film for movie lovers. We get to see who Leonard Bernstein and Felicia Montealegre were, their relationship is what the film is about, everything important in Bernstein's life other than her and his music gets sidelined. I never got the feeling the film was too short, it had the perfect length to tell its story, it just didn't feel like the best story to tell of Bernstein's life. Bradley Cooper did a great and wonderful job with it, capturing every sense of who Leonard was.

After watching this movie, I am so confused. In an attempt to shoot some grand spectacular of a movie, They ended up with a very difficult and confusing movie to watch. You were never quite sure what the timeline was. There was some jumping around in his life, which again made this confusing to watch. Even the way the movie was filmed, some scenes were shot at a distance through trees where you could hardly see the characters. He was a great conductor, but when characters are on the screen or talking, there's no need to blast the music to the point where you need to turn the subtitles on. Now let's move onto Bradley Cooper. He has a wonderful actor but not in this movie. He overreacted and it showed. There's all kind of Oscar buzz about this movie, and it probably will win a lot of awards. Because usually movies that I find to be not that good usually when awards.

Boring movie that is literally Cooper in face prosthetics talking to his wive the whole time. It also kinda looks cheap in black and white to me, and sometimes Cooper kinda overacts. If he wins an Oscar for this preformance I would kinda get it, it feels like he does embody the character, but nothing interesting in the movie happens and it's only talking. I watched for about an hour but nothing in the movie gripped me at all besides some moments of excellent preformance by Cooper but these are also followed up by insincere overacting so it kinda always feels mawh. The shots in the movie do look really good but there is no story at as a Biopic Oppenheimer is a lot better than this one. Also I have no idea who this Bernstein is and this movie did not give me an introduction to who is guy actually is. It flashed out his wive almost better than him.

The film is a fascinating portrait of the first great American conductor-but its heart is in the portrayal of Bernstein's marriage and wife. Cary Mulligan is absolutely brilliant as the woman who married him knowing he was bisexual and bound to carry on with men. They utterly adored each other and their children, and even when his infidelities hurt terribly she never played the victim, having known who he was from the start.\nCooper inhabits the role of the conductor, composer, and teacher with a passion that may seem overdone-until you see footage of the man himself at the end. Cooper gives Bernstein's music plenty of room to open your heart to the genius he plays despite the pain he caused.

I didn't love Maestro (Netflix). In fact I can't say for sure how much I actually liked it. Let's start with the obvious: Cooper's performance.
Like most of us I know Bernstein from his music and professional life. I don't know what he was like in private. Cooper plays the young Lenny as silly and unserious. Perhaps that's accurate but, for me, it was distracting. But we do have plenty of interviews with Bernstein in later life and for that period, Cooper's performance feels far too much like an impression rather than a portrayal and, dare I say, a bad one. Rather than hearing Bernstein's subtle but still identifiable New York accent, I kept hearing Prince Charles as portrayed in the final season of The Crown.
Then there was the dialogue, particularly among Felicia and her friends, that sometimes sounded like the pretentious patter satirized in The New Yorker cartoons.
Finally there was the story choice. It was much more Felicia's than Bernstein's and Mulligan's performance was extraordinary and Oscar worthy. But the focus on his bisexuality and the stress that created on their marriage, while compelling, never really told us how or if that informed his professional life. In that sense, this was a story about the strained marriage of a man who just coincidentally happened to be an incredibly influential composer and conductor. For a movie entitled Maestro, that feels like a horribly missed opportunity.
I've gone on for too long and now I have to go chain smoke an entire pack of cigarettes.

I was so looking forward to having my heart tugged from this true story I previously knew nothing about. There is so much tragedy in this story, but sadly the script keeps the characters at arms length, that we never get to really know them enough to connect with them. Sure the story is naturally sad as is the nightly news, but like the news we don't get close enough to the subjects to truly feel their loss.\nThe acting is fine. It looks good, but it ultimately feels rather empty and too broad to leave any genuine impact. Maybe if I had known their story before and I had something to bring to the table I could have connected better. The father character was so broad and lacked any nuance. The mother we barely get to understand her motivations and while the sons are all likably performed, we never get to know what truly makes them tick.\nBig letdown from A24.

I'm familiar with the Von ERICHs growing up as a wrestling fan and Vice's documentary.
Thought there would be oscars all around... There was a point in the film where I think the editing was a bit off. Not a horrible film, but not the powerful film needed.
Vice's DARK SIDE OF THE RING on the VON ERICH's is much better. The acting in this film wasn't what I expected. This film might hit different for people who aren't familiar with their story.
Not a horrible film, but some things aren't working. Again, I really wanted to like this film, but it doesn't deliver and there are some issues with the way some of the scenes were executed.

Wow. I expected a muscle mania approach to this movie. What I got was dialoge, spacing, beats and proper tones that hit your heart strings with large plucks. Nothing fancy or over the top, great choreographed fight scenes and expert hair cuts. What a show!
Will be a re watch in my house hold and will be bragging about it to my friends and family.
Wasn't born in the 70's but I get that 70's vibe accurately I would say.
The family dynamics are great, would have loved to see more of the mother, but that's okay, it is forgiven due to the fact the movie focuses on the brothers.
Also happy to see other wrestlers without giving their names on screen taking away from the story. Except for Rick Flar l.

I'm currently leaving the movie theater speechless and emotional. I am completely gutted.
This movie sheds a whole new light on the wrestling world...but also on the tragic story of wrestling's most famous family. I went into this film only knowing the basics of this family's story and I'm leaving wanting to know more.
The performances in this movie are beyond incredible. Obviously Zac Efron is a very recognizable face in Hollywood. But in this you forget you are watching him because he is completely lost in this character. Jeremy Allen White, Harris Dickinson, and Stanley Simons all give equally fantastic performances as his brothers.
THIS IS NOT A MOVIE YOU WANT TO MISS.

I was so happy to see this movie and love it. Such an interesting stories. I'm not even a big fan of wrestling but I love true stories. I felt like I got to know these brothers. What a great relationship between these siblings. I was really rooting for these boys even though I knew a little bit of the story before going to see the film. Did wish they could of been a little bit more detailed about the boys. Seem like they brushed over some things that were important to the story. Zac Efron did a great job. The body didn't hurt either. All the actors of the brothers did great. Will definitely watch it again.

For 2023 it's nice to see a film in theater that is high caliber. The Iron Claw hits on many different levels and tells a story with conviction and care.
The acting was convincing and the size of Zac Efron is flat out impressive (regardless if supplements were involved). In terms of drama, Efron is subtle mostly, but really shines in the final scene of the movie.
The pace is just about perfect. There is no meandering or long drawn out sequences that make you want to check the time. There are a few jumps in years but you don't get confused how long has passed, keeping the audience engaged and not confused.
The movie is based on a true story and has a lot of tragic moments, but there is also hope which helps balance the tone. The Iron Claw is a good movie and I'm sure will be up for an Oscar or two. It's also nice to watch a movie in this day and age that doesn't have any political undertones that it's trying to convey to the audience, just pure storytelling.
