Not really the biggest wrestling fun. I think you have to like wrestling and it's history to fully appreciate this more than I did. I wasn't really captivated by the story and it took a while to get into it. But my god is this movie an emotional wreck by the end of it.
It was crazy to see how shredded Zac efron got, and really dry too in bodybuilding terms. Like he's legit dryer than most open, maybe even classic physique Olympia competitors. He seemed very dedicated to the role. All the main characters seem to have put their all into this and they're all memorable. We just get to see it through Zac's character, I think this is one of those movies we're Zac wanted to show he's more than just a pretty face and can act. First I saw of that was Gold. And here, his role looks emotionally and physically draining. Lily James was also really great alongside him and offered some contrast to the movie itself, or his life with his family curse. A ray of sunshine in the movie. Holt McCallany also portrayed the father really well, very despicable. You could say the Jos verstappen of wrestling, probably worse.
I thought this was gonna be a triumphant story of the greatest wrestling family; but it is also quite tragic. Tough to watch what the family had to go through. And it was great in that way, I wasn't really interested in the wrestling, more like the just the loss this family went through. The movie takes time to build and show case the brotherly love so all the losses hit hard. Didn't really like the ending, made it feel like fantasyland with the brothers. In a movie, based on a true story that felt so real I didn't like that went there, but I think others might. But it just made it feel less of a biopic to me.
Anyway, whether or not you're into wrestling, this is still very much worth a watch due to its depiction of a family's emotional turmoil.

"Iron Claw" unfolds the poignant narrative of one of wrestling's greatest families, driven by brothers fueled to conquer the pinnacle of the wrestling world under the shadow of a domineering, unfulfilled father. The Von Erich curse, initially dismissed as superstition, emerges as a tragic force that slowly unravels the family. The film immerses you in each moment, compelling you to experience the characters' journey firsthand.
Sean Durkin delivers a gut-wrenching emotional drama, surpassing expectations of a mere wrestling movie. It's not just a drama within a wrestling backdrop; it's an emotional rollercoaster cleverly presented through the lens of the wrestling world. This film breaks you repeatedly, delivering a finishing blow that leaves you in a puddle of tough-to-watch tragedy yet impossible to look away from.
The heartbeat of the narrative is the resonating theme of brotherhood, whether in the ring, playing football, or simply enjoying downtime. The film creates an unparalleled connection to sibling relationships, making it a compelling experience. Amid four wonderfully tragic performances, Jeremy Allen White shines, but Zac Efron's portrayal stands out as his career-best. Efron's physical and emotional transformation captivates, portraying a character that feels small and hopeless, contrasting the stereotypical big, angry wrestler persona.
While pacing issues occasionally surface, they don't diminish the captivating journey. Despite this, 'Iron Claw' marks itself as a strong contender for the best film of 2023 on my list. Experience its reflective nature this holiday season and appreciate the relationships it portrays. 'Iron Claw' is undeniably a fantastic film, a must-watch that leaves a lasting impression. #IronClawFilm #WrestlingDrama #EmotionalRollercoaster.

The story of the Von Erich's is a surprisingly powerful one. All of the best and worst aspects of a family dynamic are on full display in The Iron Claw resulting in a moving narrative that to not many people's surprise goes beyond the sport of wrestling.
Zac Efron, Jeremy Allen White, Lily James and the rest of the cast give excellent performances in their respective roles. I have to commend the amount of work everyone put in to capturing their real-life counterparts because it pays off tremendously.
Each of the family members are given a perfect amount of screen time ensuring that audiences can connect with the family as well as understand what wrestling and brotherhood mean to them.
As someone who knows little to nothing about the sport of wrestling, I found the rules and stakes easy-to-follow thanks to relationship between Kevin Von Erich and Pam. Just the right amount of time was spent explaining wrestling to people unfamiliar with the sport.
Similar to most biopics, The Iron Claw takes liberties with the real story but it's a compelling one nonetheless. Impressive performances, beautiful camerawork, and emotionally heavy themes makes The Iron Claw standout in 2023 and the sports genre as a whole.

From the meticulous casting to the captivating cinematography and the intricately woven storyline, this stands out as my top movie of the year.
Regardless of your familiarity with the Von Erich brothers' story or wrestling, this film is still worth the watch. The casting choices like Zac Efron and Jeremy Allen White, breathe life into their characters with impeccable portrayal. Zac Efron's performance is nothing short of remarkable and gives the audience a compelling rendition of Kevin Von Erich. Even the supporting cast, featuring Lily James as Pam and Maura Tierney as Doris Von Erich, delivered stellar performances.
Rare is the film that makes you feel something after walking out of the theater. 10/10, must-see for the year.
Bonus points for a great soundtrack.

Murphy is Brilliant, but that is everything good with thos movie. Another too long Nolan piece, why can't anyone give him a pair of scissors?
You need to be able to tell you story in 120 minutes, max. There were some old epic movies, that could handle 180 minutes, but that's rare. Tarantino has a record of 168 minues in The Hateful Eight, and even that Tarantnios movie took place mostly in a cabin, that movie is not as boring as Oppenheimer. The only good thing is that I watched the movie at home, and not at the cinema.
Longer is not always better. I felt the same as I did in "Dark knight rises" the movie is not geting anywhere.
And this jumping back and forward? Why? At least have the courtsey to ad date and place in the movie.
Summary
Another boring Nolan movie. He's overrated, and actually Barbie was the winner of the Barbenheimer fight.

If any movie this year deserves to to be in my top ten list, it's definitely Oppenheimer. Christopher Nolan's Oppenheimer is a richly complex and entertaining film. The first hour flys by and is compelling as hell. The "can you hear the music?" scene is one of the best Nolan's directed, and it's just greatly paced. The second hour is extremely morally challenging as characters question whether or not they should use the bomb. The Trinity Test was incredibly shot and editing, the practical effects are stunning yet terrifying. The third and last hour is probably my favorite part of the film, as it deals with guilt and punishment. Cillian Murphy and Robert Downey Jr.'s performances stand out like a sore thumb. And finally the ending is one of the best and most terrifying endings that sticks with you and lingers in your mind for a while after viewing the film. Overall an excellent experience in 70mm and awesome 4K release. Oppenheimer is definitely the best film of the year.

I rarely quit watching rentals 30 minutes short of the ending - especially after spend six and a half bucks on it - but that is what I did last evening while viewing Oppenheimer. The story went ricocheting off in so many directions, some shot in black and white and some in color - most of them boring as if watching paint drying - that I really had no idea what the movie was trying to convey to the audience. And as in Nolan's Interstellar, the overpowering musical score that never let up was more distracting than complimenting. So, onto the Nolan garbage heap goes Oppenheimer, to join Tenet, Interstellar, and Inception. His Batman flicks were OK, but if they were on one of the streaming services that I pay for, I wouldn't bother watching any of them again. I did like Dunkirk, Man of Steel and The Prestige, however.

I'm here for Cillian Murphy. I loved him as Tommy Shelby in Peaky Blinders and I was really excited when I saw he was cast in this. But the film was boring. It was too long (obviously). It was too confusing. It was too scientific. There just wasn't as much action as I expected.\nMatt Damon looks really old in this as well which is scary for me as he was one of my favourite actors growing up!\nDon't get me wrong, I appreciated the story and the events behind it. Really refreshing to see Albert Einstein in a film. But as an entertainment piece it is not one I will be rushing to relive. (Oh and I probably wouldn't watch Barbie again either!)

Christopher Nolan is a great filmmaker, but not many directors are admired as much as Zack Snyder. Nolan, known for working without co-writers, wrote and directed Oppenheimer. The movie explores the life of a complex man seen differently by the public and those close to him. With strong acting from Cillian Murphy, less impressive performance by Emily Blunt, an Oscar-worthy role by Robert Downey Jr, and a solid turn by Matt Damon, Oppenheimer's storytelling is unnecessarily complex, jumping between color and black-and-white scenes. While praised for recreating an atomic bomb test with practical effects, the three-hour film feels distant and not as good as it's hyped to be.

My husband and I really liked this movie. The acting is great from Robert Downey Jr, Emily Blunt and Matt Damon. It was especially brilliant fri Cillian Murphy. We are not Americans, so perhaps the removal of Robert Oppenheimer's security clearance (and trial, obviously) is common knowledge to Americans. We were confused as to what was going on though. (I googled it afterward, and now understand.)\nAlso on the plus side were the special effects, costumes and settings. One thing I didn't like about the movie though, is that it was about thirty minutes too long.\nAll in all, the movie is great, with tremendous acting, and an incredible story about what people can do when tasked with the impossible.

Oppenheimer is a movie that, in many ways, should be boring. It's a three hour drama, most of which consists of people sitting in rooms talking. Yet, it is movie that consistently keeps you on the edge of your seat, gripping you from beginning to end.
It's no surprise that Christopher Nolan knows how to make a great movie - he's done that many times, and even his lesser works are still commendable. Here, you could make an argument that this movie is his masterpiece. While I wouldn't say that it's my favorite Nolan film (there are at least four other movies of his that I would put ahead of this one), it is certainly an achievement in cinema and a masterclass in doing a lot with only a little.
What do I mean by that last sentence? Well, like I said, this is a three hour drama; there's not a lot of "action" in it, and yet it plays with the intensity of an action film. There are various moments shot in IMAX that feel large in scale, yet they're used in council meeting scenes. We never see the actual bombing of Nagasaki or Hiroshima, yet we feel the impact of it throughout the duration of the film. Again, it's taking what seems like little and doing a lot with it.
Visually, the movie is gorgeous to look at. Hoyte van Hoytema continues to shine as Nolan's cinematographer, showing once again that he is more than just Wally Pfister's replacement. There are many shots, some involving just an array of colors, that really catch your eye. This is complemented by Ludwig Goransson's fantastic score, which is definitely an Oscar contender. There's also the perfect balance of colored film and black-and-white, with the colored portions being from Oppenheimer's perspective and the black-and-white portions being outsider viewpoints of Oppenheimer.
This leads to my next praise: this movie creates a perfect character study of J. Robert Oppenheimer, detailing his complicated nature. He's both proud of his accomplishments and haunted by them. He has clear moral dilemmas, and yet he's also a womanizer. It humanizes him without completely slandering him. The movie also does a good job of putting you in his head.
The performances here are outstanding. Cillian Murphy gives a grade A performance as Oppenheimer, and no doubt should be in the conversation for Best Actor. Robert Downey Jr. Also does a good job, proving once again that he is more than just "Iron Man." There's a slew of other great actors - Matt Damon, Alden Ehrenreich, Josh Hartnett, and Rami Malek - who all give top notch performances here.
If there's one complaint I have for the movie, it's how the two main female characters are portrayed in the film. Emily Blunt plays Oppenheimer's wife and Florence Pugh plays his lover, and neither characters are really given the depth that I feel that they should have had. They hint at aspects of their characters, but don't flesh them out like they should. It's not that Blunt and Pugh didn't do a good job in the movie - they certainly did, but I feel like they could have dug into their characterization a little better.
Overall, Oppenheimer is a must watch. It's an engaging character study executed like a tense thriller, one that keeps you invested and shocks you with its closing moments. You leave the movie feeling less safe in the world, and yet it's a movie that you long to go back to and experience again. I'm excited to see what Nolan does next.

A great film visually and dramatically. No question.
Whether the style of a typical Nolan production is appropriate for such a dialogue-heavy film can certainly be debated. However, I have the feeling that Nolan always has to play with jumps in time and also always has to add a vibrating continuous bass soundtrack to his films. Why?
Just a question by the way: Aren't great directors characterized by the fact that they sometimes vary things, sometimes do something different? I've been wanting this from him for a long time. Now it was definitely time.
Lots of conversations, countless characters, political intrigues, psychological games don't bother me at all. On the contrary, that can make a film quite interesting. Nevertheless, I wanted a little more about the logistical and physical challenges of building the bomb and, above all, more depth on the moral dilemma.
Instead, the "Communist hunt" in the form of interrogations, which for me was soporific, was given too much screen time and thus overshadowed the more important aspects of this story.
Seriously, I'm no longer interested in this era of American communism-aversion. I no longer find it particularly relevant in this context, or at least not as relevant as other questions about the construction of weapons of mass destruction would be today.
At this point the film has missed an opportunity:
Namely, to be more current than he ultimately is.

Every time I watch a Christopher Nolan movie, I'm suprised by three things: his visual creativity; excellent character direction; and non-stop, headache-inducing musical score choices. Chris, what is going on, mate? Why do you feel the need to smother all your films in neverending strings? It baffles me that he keeps doing this. In Tenet it made the movie basically unwatchable (as you couldn't understand half the dialogue), but Tenet was pretty mediocre anyway.\nBut Oppenheimer? This movie is a masterpiece, all but ruined by the ridiculous, grating, incessant music. The movie feels like one long scene because the score never lets up, and the volume is just completely baffling. It's distracting, frustrating and completely unnecessary. Nolan does the same in Dunkirk, and someone needs to tell him to STOP THIS.\nOh yeah, the movie: it's great. The acting is phenomenal (always love seeing Josh Hartnett empowered to do some real performing), the structure works and we weren't bored once through its 3-hour runtime. Cillian Murphy is a powerhouse and the way the story plays out is as gripping as it is unconventional.

The movie "Oppenheimer" is a biographical thriller about J. Robert Oppenheimer, the physicist who played a key role in the development of the atomic bomb during World War II and thus the beginning of nuclear power. In an exceptional manner, Christopher Nolan, as the writer and director, successfully encapsulates the personal life, career, and philosophy of the scientist Oppenheimer within a three-hour timeframe.\nNolan meticulously examines the morals, loyalty, patriotism, ambiguities, and convictions of Oppenheimer, which after being exploited and manipulated by the American political machine, led to his subsequent fall from grace. This same manipulation that the American government used to create Bin Laden, Saddam Hussein, Bashar al-Assad and recently Hamas group.\nNolan made a difficult film, with super-efficient editing and stupendous and solid performances, starting with Cillian Murphy as Oppenheimer and Robert Downey Jr. As Lewis Strauss.

A tale of drama, tragedy and danger at high speed, "Ferrari" is a glimpse at a time in Enzo Ferrari's life where his personal and professional life were in turmoil what with infidelity, business troubles and deaths plaguing his dreams of racing glory. Based on the book "Enzo Ferrari: The Man, the Cars, the Races, the Machine" by Brock Yates the film takes on the challenges faced by the icon as he navigates his perilous course through destiny.\nAdam Driver stars as the racing legend portraying him as a tall and gangly poker-faced boss kowtowed by his women and who encourages and disparages his people in turn. Penelope Cruz plays his tough, no nonsense wife who milks her long suffering relationship with her husband band for all its difficult worth. Shailene Woodley is his patient and dutiful mistress while a cast of reporters, racers and celebrities pay court to the legend. While no classic and nothing particularly outstanding the movie is a fascinating look at the world of big business, the racing industry and the life and the mind of a man living at a pinnacle of power.\nFounder of one of the most popular and most revered automobiles in history, Enzo Ferrari is one of the most interesting personalities in history and "Ferrari" gives a good idea why. This is a fine, simple and direct film that every racing enthusiast and film fan wouldn't mind seeing.

Based on real events in 1957 and a book by automotive writer Brock Yates, the movie follows ambitious auto making and racing executive Enzo Ferrari (Adam Driver), his femme-fatale wife/business partner Laura (Penelope Cruz), and his long-time mistress Lina (Shailene Woodley). Everything is coming to a head for Ferrari as he struggles to raise financing for his company and keep secret his mistress and their out-of-wedlock son. Much is riding on the performance of Ferrari's team in a 1,000-mile race through the hills and cities of Italy.\nThe actors do a good job of portraying the characters as complex flawed people, not heroes. The cinematography and stunt driving are outstanding, and the accident scenes are frightening. Like many movies over two hours, this one could have been cut down, with too many long lingering shots of characters' faces.\nAlthough the movie drags in places, the action revs up when Enzo and Laura are clashing, and the race cars are zooming.

This was the absolute worst. We paid for DBOX and left halfway. Their fake Italian accents could have been fake Russian accents for all I could tell, and the pace of action and scripting were so boring I nearly fell asleep. Way too much pointless talking that didn't accomplish anything in painting their characters. The only plus was the audio of the cars on the racetrack but even that wasn't enough to keep us in the theater. As an aside, the only other movie I've ever walked out of the theater was Nick Cages Ghost Rider 2. I still need another 72 characters to finish this review so I'll say it again: absolute worst!

An amazing performance by Penelope equally as good if not more impressive Adam Driver performance 100%!
An amazing performance by Penelope equally as good if not more impressive Adam Driver performance 100%!
An amazing performance by Penelope equally as good if not more impressive Adam Driver performance 100%!
An amazing performance by Penelope equally as good if not more impressive Adam Driver performance 100%!
An amazing performance by Penelope equally as good if not more impressive Adam Driver performance 100%!
YES it was that good of a show and acting quality do I need to repeat more?

In the surface, Ferrari appears to be a well-directed, well-acted and adrenaline fuelled with excellent racing sequences. And yet, throughout the film, I couldn't help but feel disinterested and dissatisfied. This film has all the elements to be a slam dunk and yet I never felt attached to Enzo Ferrari and his struggles.
The performances are decent overall. Unfortunately, I was most disappointed by Adam Driver as the titular character. He never showcases the great range that I know he is capable with. His Enzo Ferrari is very reserved and somewhat bland. It's not helped that he is speaking English while attempting an Italian accent. If Chernobyl (2019) can get away with all English dialogue, then I feel you can do that here. It would certainly allow Driver to reach greater levels of acting. The saviour of this film is certainly PenÃ©lope Cruz. She delivers an excellent performance as Laura and I wish she got more screen time.
But if you're here for the racing, the film does delivers. It's few and far between, but the third act is a long, intense race with great sound design and editing. It's a shame that you're not invested in any of the racers since the film doesn't characterise any of them. It means the climax of the film doesn't hit as hard as it probably should. It's certainly shocking and brutal but it's hard to stay immersed when the violence is so over the top and the CGI is not quite great.
Overall, Ferrari feels like a film that could've been better. The characters could've been better, the story could've covered a more interesting part of Enzo Ferrari's life and the acting could've been more. I left this film not feeling like I did not know Enzo Ferrari. It's a film that perhaps is not for me, but I can see how others enjoy it.

The movie deals with a small part (couple of weeks or months) of Enzo Ferrari life, his personal and business problems, and we get to meet the man.\nGreat cinematography, sound etc. Particularly the racing scenes which are some 20% of the movie while the rest is drama. Solid performances, maybe an Oscar nomination for Penelope Cruz.\nHere is where most biopics fail, they are usually made after a book, a biography somebody wrote that either paints the picture too nicely or too harshly. The truth is then left between the lines. Some truth must remain, certain historical events and such. Between the lines it seems to me Mr. Ferrari was an obsessed, cruel, selfish man, likely quite charismatic and charming to those around him. We see glimpses of that, the movie has a certain darkness to it, but when viewing as a whole certain scenes just don't work, such as Ferrari at the graveyard talking to his dead son (it feels like something Ferrari would say he does but doesn't, it reeks of inauthenticity in retrospect). Perhaps the scriptwriter or director/actor are at fault but it's hard making a biopic so can't fault them much.

Ferrari has been the crown jewel of Italy since the end of the Great War. The founders, Enzo and Laura Ferrari have accomplished a lot with the company but have lost just as much. Now, with the competition closing in, Enzo must win the Mille Miglia to secure the future of Ferrari. With his relationship with Laura in pieces after the loss of their son, Enzo must reconcile with Laura and his new family.\nFrom the trailer of this film, it seems like this is a biopic about Enzo Ferrari, which it is, but not his entire life. This film focuses on one specific event in his life and how it is handled. The film does mention other parts of his life but does not go into great detail. The movie has a couple of race scenes, but other race car movies or biopics are more exciting. The film is an excellent watch but may leave the viewer wanting to know more about Enzo and Laura Ferrari, the company, the engineering that makes Ferrari, and the racing history of the company.

Ferrari: It even has nominal determinism as Adam Driver plays Enzo Ferrari. Even though it is based on the Ferrari biography Enzo Ferrari: The Man, the Cars, the Races, the Machine it's not really A Biopic seeing as it covers a few weeks in 1957, Ferrari's romantic and business crises and his preparations for the 1957 Mille Miglia. The Ferrari firm is well into the red, Enzo has to find a new partner, Fiat or Ford but his wife Laura (Penelope Cruz) owns half of the company shares. Getting her to sign them over to him won't be easy especially given his philandering. Cruz puts in a fiery performance even firing a pistol at Enzo. She misses (deliberately?) and the bullet lodges in a wall. They are both grief stricken after the loss of their son Dino, who following a life of ill health died in 1956. Enzo though has another, secret son, Piero (Giuseppe Festinese) by his long term mistress Lina Lardi (Shailene Woodley). Laura mustn't find out about this but Lina is pressing Enzo to recognise Piero as his son for his upcoming Confirmation in the Roman Catholic Faith. This thread of the film could have descended into soap or melodrama but strong acting and dialogue prevents this from happening. The main narrative thread relates to the upcoming Mille Miglia road race. Enzo's rivalry with Maserati is literally a blood feud as both of their companies are on the brink of bankruptcy and winning first place in the Mille Miglia will boost car sales. The Mille Miglia is no ordinary race, run along narrow rural roads there is always the risk of colliding with animals, onlookers or ordinary vehicles, This is wonderfully portrayed in the film and we also see how deadly practice runs can be. The racing cars are convincing in design and sound, some really nail-biting scenes, It would take a TV miniseries to adequately cover the life of Enzo Ferrari but this this is a succulent slice of it. Directed by Michael Mann, screenplay by Troy Kennedy Martin. 8/10.

People need to be managing their expectations this year for films. I think this film has a similar problem to 'Napolean'. It's pacing and majority of plot points are dramatically different to the hopes and expectations of the audience. Audiences need to caper their expectations of films, because this movie was great. (except for Shailene Woodley she is a horrible actress and doesnt know how to do an italian accent in the slightest. Get her out of the movie business, she can only play one character.)\nAnyways, sorry Shailene im sure you're a great person.\nThis film tells the story of Enzo Ferrari, during his make or break moment in his business and family life. The weight of the story delivered. I was thoroughly engaged and invested in this story. This film is a drama so it moved a little slower, not as much intense formula races, and more heart felt conversations. But it was a compelling true drama. Engaging, and incredibly well done.

Greetings again from the darkness. Since there was no early screening of this for Dallas-Ft Worth critics and it hit theaters on Christmas Day, this review is a bit tardy, yet I find myself not caring too much - kind of how I feel about the movie itself. Rossa corsa is the official name of the red color used by Italian automaker Ferrari on their racing cars. Of course, most just refer to it as 'Ferrari red'. It's as distinctive as the familiar roar of Ferrari engines, and director Michael Mann takes advantage of both in his latest film. If only the story were half as interesting as the racing scenes.
The original script was written by the late Troy Kennedy Martin, who also wrote the two film versions of THE ITALIAN JOB (1969, 2003). He adapted the 1991 book, "Enzo Ferrari: The Man and the Machine" written by the late Brock Yates. Mr. Yates is also (unfortunately) remembered for THE CANNONBALL RUN (1981). Rather than a biopic, the film focuses on a very specific and limited period of time when Enzo Ferrari was staring down trouble in both his personal and professional lives ... ho-hum subjects that draw attention from the spectacular racing scenes.
Adam Driver stars as Enzo Ferrari, putting to use the Italian accent he worked on for the recent HOUSE OF GUCCI (2021). His wife Laura is played by Penelope Cruz, and his long-time mistress Lina is played by Shailene Woodley. Driver is on screen for much of the film, but it's Cruz who delivers the two or three off-track scenes worth watching. As for Woodley, it's a mystery why she even took the role. Given nothing to sink her acting claws into, we can only hope/assume that something of interest was edited out for time. She is far too talented to be wasted in such a throwaway role.
When one thinks of "Ferrari", it's not the icon in sunglasses strutting through life that comes to mind. No, it's the cars. The red cars. And director Mann has built his career by giving us what we want in films such as THE INSIDER (1999), HEAT (1995), and THIEF (1981). The film soars when the cars are on screen. They are works of art and are a sight to behold whether zipping around the practice track or sharp-cornering the city streets of the tragic 1957 Mille Miglia (yes, that horrendous accident actually occurred). Ferrari's financial woes, marital strife, and emotional burden of two sons, never successfully draw us in to his personal drama, leaving much of the movie feeling quite flat. It's the cars that roar, not the people.
Opened nationally in theaters on December 25, 2023.

The Boys in the boat is very good, well done because knowing how it is going to end before the movie start...could have made this film predictable ...but because of the setting, depression in the Pacific Northwest & because of the two lead actors...one is a rower, the other the coach, their presence on the screen is so magnetic that you want to know more of their story. The camera work is so good has to make you feel that you are on the water. No wonder the book regain popularity\nUn trÃ¨s bon et beau film...on sort du cinÃ©ma avec une impression d'avoir vu ...presque vÃ©cu quelque chose pas juste avoir Ã©tÃ© diverti.

I have read some of the reviews here, and I don't agree with those who are picking this movie apart. It is a great movie! I was, surprisingly, moved to tears 4 different times...and that is something I rarely ever do.
The story is amazing, and true. The guys are gorgeous! The women are gorgeous! The acting is amazing!
George Clooney did an amazing job of capturing the look and feel of the 1930..the cinematography is great. We both thought the costumes were spot on, the music was really well done and matched the movie. You just really felt for the them, the boys themselves, the coaches, everyone.
See the movie....feel good...enjoy the great acting and all those beautiful actors. Feel good about the USA, too.
Great job, George.

This is a solid film from George Clooney and his team. Great storytelling, well written, edited and told beautifully, and well directed. Glad I saw it in the theater.\nThe story will bring you to tears in the best way through amazing character journeys and lush patriotism. It's a period piece that doesn't shy away from the reality of the time. It helps paint a picture of classism and disparities of the century and sport.\nThis film showcases the sport of rowing well including the commitment, strategy, and sheer will to win. As a former crewman, this story was told through the eyes of those who love the sport. It was that passion that came through the screen. I loved this film and will be recommending it to others. Go Huskies and Team USA.

The audience applauded at the end of the movie -- that's rare for where we're located. Cinematography is beautiful. Felt like we were there. The director, crew and writers did a great job making this. Movies are off-spring of the books. As a novelist & more, I understand the hard work of doing the transition to visual storytelling. The visual story is different from the book. Graphic Novels are not the same as a source book or movie.\n.... ..... .... Back to BOYS IN THE BOAT.\nThis is a film you can watch again with other family members. You'll see something you didn't see the first time. The effort to transport us back to 1930's America succeeded stupendously. Please simply add an elegantly scripted sentence at the end of the film. "If you liked the movie read or listen to the novel".

I knew nothing about this movie ahead of time but took the word of a family member that it was worth seeing and it was. I liked the underdog sports story where the boys from the working class are pitted against the privileged class.
Remembering this was the 1930's depression era, we can well imagine the problem of competing against their counterparts who are living off the inherited wealth of their families. By the same token, these young men certainly have the sympathy of the audience. The boys in the boat are also tough and willing to sacrifice themselves for the dream of Olympic grandeur. So the rest of it falls into place.
They get mocked by the sports establishment and the well heeled athletes in the sport of rowing. They are committed to putting up with the physical endurance tests, the brutalizing selection process and the possibility they may never achieve their goal. All this is the stuff of success in movie theatres.
Callum Turner, the leading man, comes from a family living in a tent city. Nevertheless he has the good looks of a star athlete and the love and support of a young woman who is willing to take risks like breaking dorm rules to get some alone time with him.
One victory after another and the key support of a boss who opts for talent instead of reputation gets them to the Berlin Olympics of 1936. That in itself is can accomplishment. What follows is a miracle on water that demonstrates the drive, stamina and determination of the rowing crew.
I knew nothing about this team but now I want to find out more. With the Olympics coming in the summer of 2024 we will hear more about the original team. There are several excellent performers in this movie who contribute to the emotional impact. I found certain parallels with Chariots of Fire from the early 1980's. That show highlighted individuals who suffered from the British class system of 1924 and how they achieved success. It was extremely well put together to show the history and class divisions of postwar Europe.
This movie is focused on one team and its success is to show the bond that ties them together and the courage to persevere. That is what builds friendships and character.

My family and I thoroughly enjoyed this simple (but not simplistic) tale of how a group of young men overcome adversity to achieve something fantastic. I have not read the best seller, but evidently the film follows the book closely. I'm so glad we ignored some of the tepid reviews and saw the film anyway. True, it's somewhat predictable with no big surprises. We know the outcome beforehand. But that's ok! The two hours flew by, and the audience applauded. I left the theater in a better mood than when I came in. Given all of the discord in our world right now, the film's messages are especially inspirational. Perhaps I especially welcomed this "feel good" film one day after viewing another two hour film involving young people.......the "unpredictable" and critically acclaimed "Saltburn".

We decided to go see this movie today, it didn't seem to be getting a lot of time slots at our local theater and we thought it must be a limited release film. I am so glad we decided to go. What a wonderful show. If you like stories about the underdog coming out on top, this is it.
Frankly, I have gotten so jaded with the films out today I seldom bother. Most are full of "social" messages, thinly veiled lectures on how terrible middles class America is or some revisionist silliness out to appease the fringe.
This movie had none of that. It was a good story about an underdog school and an underdog group of kids working hard, struggling and ultimately coming out the winner. A real feel good movie that had us jazzed and feeling good at the end.
Highly recommended.

I talked my son, brother and parents-Dad last minute not up to going but subsequently they decided they're getting the DVD-into seeing the Boys in the Boat as I got so much out of the book. Joe Rantz and his teammates were of my grandparents generation. I was surprised that responses afterwards all touched on different details.
My mom thought the humanity and grit of the depression era was the context of the movie she most enjoyed. That even though so many were poor, there was still prestige in not taking/stealing. That those who were previous competitors turned their support toward the boat. She said George Pocock stole her heart.
My brother (who restores vintage buildings) loved how the production crew got the light switches, lockers and the boats all looking so accurate. Who else notices these things? I though he would most like Joyce Rantz's parts in the movie because my brother is a hopeless romantic.
My son said he most connected with this movie because of the sporting story. Indeed, he was leaning forward as the race outcomes came down to the business end. He was the one when we were discussing afterwards that kept going quiet but then 2 hours later would say, "You know when Ulbrickson opened the lockers..."
I thought the movie caught the spirit of Bobby Moch (coxswain) fairly well. That such a so-called little jockey could push back against a coach as imposing as Coach Ulbrickson to get those boys to pull together-doing his job well! The movie character of my favorite team underdog Joe was well-represented, but of course there was so much to his backstory left out. And Roger Morris was actually mischaracterized, I thought. But, actually, it is impossible for me to fairly review this movie. Reading (for me listening to) the book is such a different experience. The movie is entertaining; The book is an impact.

George Clooney's "The Boys in the Boat" chronicles the true story of the University of Washington rowing team's pursuit of gold at the 1936 Berlin Olympics. While the film boasts commendable period costumes and a resonant soundtrack, it largely adheres to the conventional tropes of sports dramas.
The movie's portrayal of rowing is visually appealing, capturing the grace and synchronicity of the sport. However, this technical allure is counterbalanced by a narrative that seldom ventures beyond the expected contours of an underdog tale. Despite its historical backdrop and the unique focus on rowing, the film doesn't leverage these elements to offer a fresh perspective in the genre.
Regarding performances, the characters, including Joe Rantz played by Callum Turner, didn't resonate with me, leaving me uninvested in their journeys. The film's reliance on montage sequences and motivational speeches, while typical of the genre, does little to elevate the character development or storytelling.
Having not read Daniel James Brown's book, I sensed the film might have condensed or oversimplified the narrative, potentially omitting nuanced themes present in the original text.
Ultimately, "The Boys in the Boat" fits neatly into the sports drama category but doesn't distinguish itself. It's likely to appeal to viewers who enjoy uncomplicated narratives in this genre but may fall short for those seeking depth and innovation in storytelling and character development.

The film told the story of the University of Washington's junior rowing team being selected as their varsity team, overcoming many external and internal troubles, and eventually wins the 1936 Olympics gold medal for 8-man crew.\nIs it a film to last a long long time like Shawshank Redemption? It is not. The film, although beautifully showed the attractiveness of rowing and told the key events well, lacked focus on the struggles of the individual characters. Only Joe Rantz was explored a bit more but each of the 9 main members had to overcome great mental and physical burdens to achieve the success as a team in unison. As a biological sports drama, it lacked more biography, and focused more on sports and drama, which is not terrible, but leaves more to be desired.\nThat being said, I do not regret seeing the film and learn the story of these men winning the Olympic gold. The overall culture and mannerisms, and the financial struggles of the working class people in the pre-WW2 era were portrayed well. The music was a treat to the ears as the team rowed. And the shots were beautifully framed. These showed why everyone is obsessed with rowing as a sport all over the US. It also got me to buy the non-fiction book that the film is based on to read more about the events in detail.

Am I missing something? All these glowing reviews, but it's not all that by long stretch. Slow moving. Dialogue is always whispered making it hard to catch what is being said. Had to watch with subtitles to catch what was being said. Very over hyped. Important subject matter but overall very disappointing. Glad I didn't pay money to see it. On the positive, photography and soundtrack is good. Seen enough in the media already about human trafficking not to be shocked by the subject matter of this film. Sad situation but this film doesn't do all that much to shed a light on the dark recesses of our sick society. I still don't get all the rave reviews. The movie "Traffic" was so much better. Writing this as I'm watching the movie because I'm so bored.

This beautiful film had me weeping. I do not usually cry during movies, the last time was when I watched "I am not Ashamed" about Rachel Joy Scott and "End of the Spear" about Nate Saint and the other men killed with him. "Sound of freedom had me crying within the first five minutes of the start of the movie. And I couldn't hold back my tears for the whole movie.\nIt is such a good movie and one that touches on a subject of a horrible and inhuman thing that is done to millions of people daily. I am so grateful to Angel Studios to be bold enough to stand for what is right and tell the world this story.\nIf you have not watched this movie I, suggest you go do so right now.

"Sound of Freedom" is an extraordinary cinematic experience that seamlessly weaves together gripping storytelling and powerful performances. The film's compelling narrative, based on true events, takes the audience on an emotional journey, shedding light on the harsh realities of human trafficking. Jim Caviezel's stellar portrayal of Tim Ballard, a real-life hero, adds depth and authenticity to the film. The cinematography is stunning, capturing both the intensity of rescue missions and the poignant moments of hope and resilience. "Sound of Freedom" is not just a movie; it's a call to action, raising awareness about a critical issue while delivering a captivating and thought-provoking cinematic masterpiece.

I have always found it EXTREMELY difficult to watch commercials, let alone movies, on any type of cruelty or torture ~ especially to people in general, children, elderly or animals. I didn't know if I could watch this but with all of the great reviews, I had to try. I'm happy I did.
It was done perfectly! Of course the topic was heart-wrenching and sadly, eye-opening; however, the acting was superb and with the knowledge that this was based on a true story, it was intriguing. A must watch.
I'm happy to learn that laws have been changed to help combat this epidemic. I also hope that the those involved with this movie receive the much-deserved awards for bringing this topic to the big screen.
We must ALL be vigilant in watching for young children who appear to be in distress. It's sad to live in a world that demands these actions of us, but it's true.

This movie is well shot, well directed, relatively well written, the music/score is questionable, the acting isn't bad. In short, it's effective as a film. But good lord is the subject matter depressing when it's not outright horrifying. Since it's well shot and well directed it's great at really pulling you into the world of underground child trafficking and the terrifying realities of everyday life in impoverished regions run by gangs. It's so depressing I was tempted to write this review as a comedy, like "For a laugh out loud zany time the whole family can enjoy, watch 'The Sound of Freedom'!" They did a good job with the sets/on-location. It needs to be about 30 minutes shorter. You're going to have to wash this movie off when it's over.

I wanted to see this movie when it had come out in the theaters, but was unable to make it so I waited until it was available on streaming services.
I watched it today on Amazon Prime. The reason for watching is because I know is a very difficult topic that is rarely discussed and so I wanted to support the idea of shedding light on this by becoming another person that has seen it.
The movie is based on true events and I will say its excellently made. This is not an enjoyable movie in any way. Its difficult, heart wrenching, sickening, but its real things that happen in our world so we have to be aware of what goes on. I definitely shed many tears and it will be something that will stay with me for ever.
I wish we could just press a button and end all the suffering of the children. Maybe one day it can happen. Until then, more and more people need to see this and just be aware and be alert.
So I give the movie 10/10 for its efforts and being brave to make this film.

If you want tojusg the story like a movie; I would call this a crime stoppers dramatic adventure affair about the special agent that classically has to work undercover to bring the bad guys to justice and save the victims. The blood and gore of violent crimes is replace by the attitudes and fears of sex trafickers, the pedophiles, and the victimized children; these scenes can be hard to bare but make the film one of a kind. With that being the layers of the cake we are cutting into, what is the icing? To ice this story, we have the real storyline of Tim Ballard. Google his name and read his wiki. Thanks.

In my opinion, this is a must watch movie for anyone over the age of 18 or younger at parental discretion.
I was compelled after watching this to come here and do my first ever review, I had forgotten my password but reactivated my account just to leave a 10/10 review.
It is shocking, it is heartbreaking, it is a must watch.
The one star reviews in my opinion are unwarranted and from people who just cannot face the reality of how awful the human race can be, not everyone of course, not even the majority, but a very very few minority who are incredibly awful and this movie shines a light on those people.
Again, this is a must watch, I feel worse having watched it, but at the same time feel like everyone should watch this to know this is happening in the world. In my perfect Australian bubble I do not ever think this is possible or consider it and this has opened my eyes.

I hope this film not only captures the attention of people around the globe but also deeply resonates with them, igniting a sense of urgency and compassion to take action against the horrifying reality of child sex trafficking. By shedding light on the tragic circumstances that innocent children are forced to endure, this film aims to expose the dark underbelly of society and challenge the apathy and indifference that allows such atrocities to persist.
Through powerful storytelling and compelling visuals, this film will take viewers on an emotional journey, immersing them in the lives of survivors, activists, and law enforcement officials who are dedicated to bringing an end to child sex trafficking. It will highlight the resilience and strength of survivors, showcasing their stories of hope, healing, and empowerment.
In addition to exposing the heinous crimes committed against children, this film will also confront the complicity and silence of powerful institutions, including Hollywood. It will shine a spotlight on the industry's neglect and exploitation of this crucial issue, forcing viewers to confront uncomfortable truths and question the moral integrity of those in positions of influence.
By amplifying the voices of survivors and advocates, this film seeks to inspire a global movement for change. It will call on individuals, communities, and governments to prioritize the protection of children and to actively work towards dismantling the networks that perpetuate child sex trafficking. Through education, awareness, and advocacy, we can create a world where every child is safe, valued, and free from exploitation.
This film is not just a documentary; it is a call to action. It is a powerful tool for raising awareness, fostering empathy, and mobilizing individuals and communities to join the fight against child sex trafficking. Together, we can make a difference and ensure a brighter future for the most vulnerable among us.

I love seeing people rescued from human trafficking. I wish I could join a team and help catch them myself. The true story is inspirational, but this movie felt self serving and glorifying of a actor or character or agenda.\nThere are many movies and documentaries on this topic, and many cover and report much better. We all need to be aware of these criminals and stop them. We don't need movie studios trying to make a buck, trying to create super hero images, on people's pain and suffering. I imagine the real sound of freedom is not that depicted in this movie. The story was told quite boring and weak. I hope the real agent will release a YouTube video or audio book, if he has not already.\nBottom line though, glad the real agent took down so many creeps and criminals. So happy the kids were returned home. Feel sorry for the Forever lost ones.

Unique in that Marni Nixon is credited! She plays Sister Sophia, credited as herself, no less. No need to dub Julie Andrews, who apparently could sing! Who knew!\n60 years later and my 5 year old granddaughter already sings along. Definitely the loudest if not the most dulcet tones to be sure. Kind of the definition of a classic. I doubt her grandchildren will be singing along with Hamilton.\nThis and other Roger's and Hammerstein classics define what it means to be a classic musical. While easy to to dismiss as fluff, it is based on a true story set in 1938 on the eve of the Nazis taking over Austria, and has Nazis, betrayal, escapes, life and death situations, hiding behind it's musical scrim. The music and lyrics range from filler to carry the story along, to songs that became American Standards. "Edelweiss" is so well written many assume it is the actual national anthem of Austria. There are several story lines, both young children and their parents can watch the movie and leave the theatre having experienced completely different movies. Several scenes could be stressful for young children, in stark contrast to the movies general lighthearted theme. Each time I watch, a hidden gem reveals itself, worth a 30th or 40th viewing for sure. Note the stage musical and the movie version are not the same, the movie version reorders the original, and eliminates a couple of songs. Though not as extreme as the stage and movie versions of "Chicago" for example. That said I find Robert Wises version to be the superior production. Enjoy!

Quite simply the best, most heart warming musical out ther, (Westside story) a close second, talent, perfect cast, beautiful scenery, perfect choreography, uplifting, absolutely the best film I have ever seen. Julie Andrew's is sublime, her voice is so pure, no need for razzmatazz
, clever film effects, ai inspired score, just real unadulterated talent. Take note all newcomers, write fantastic music, gather a perfect cast, focus on the quality of the story and let magic happen.
Julie Andrew's, Marnie Nixon are the voices of happiness, no auto tune, no adjustments required.
If you have not seen this film, you have missed a classic.

The movie "The Sound of Music" is one of the uplifting musicals that Hollywood created in the 60s. Similar to "Hello Dolly" and "Mary Poppins", these films did not mirror the political and social upheavals of the era, but rather served as a retreat from reality into the realm of fiction. The musical "West Side Story" stands out as an exception, being the first to portray the Latino community in New York and delve into their political issues.\n"The Sound of Music" has been subject to criticism for its portrayal of politics. The film's protagonist, Captain von Trapp, resists Nazism, but his opposition is not rooted in its antisemitism, militarism, or authoritarianism. Rather, his primary concern is the threat Nazi Germany poses to Austrian sovereignty.\nFurthermore, the film has been criticized for its lack of racial diversity.

Actually, there is no need for a long comment at all. From the first second, which has a magnificent entrance to the film, it is a film that has passed into the history of cinema, filled with joy, sometimes sadness, but usually happiness. Andrews, who won acclaim with Mary Poppins, forms a harmonious duo with Plummer, while each of the von Trapp children, who are at the center of the film, are very cute. We see that the magnificent beauty of Salzburg is also crowned as a different character throughout the film. Quality songs that have been expressed musically also attract attention. It never bores a person to listen to it many times. Predictable entry-development-results do not bother at all. In fact, the film shifts to a lot of politics in the last quarter. Let's also remind that it is inspired by real events and characters that have happened. So the von Trapp family is completely real. After watching the movie, those who are curious can do some research. It can be recommended unconditionally to everyone young and old, one of the rare films that can win everyone's liking.

When it comes to timeless classics, few films have left as indelible a mark on the world of cinema as "The Sound of Music." Released in 1965, this musical masterpiece directed by Robert Wise and starring Julie Andrews and Christopher Plummer has enchanted generations with its captivating story, memorable songs, and stunning Austrian landscapes. However, even the most beloved classics can be subject to scrutiny, and in this review, we will explore the notion that "The Sound of Music" could potentially be better, examining its strengths, weaknesses, and the possibilities for revitalizing this cherished cinematic gem.
Set against the backdrop of the beautiful Austrian Alps, "The Sound of Music" tells the heartwarming tale of Maria (Julie Andrews), a spirited young nun who is sent to be the governess for the seven von Trapp children, widowed Captain Georg von Trapp (Christopher Plummer)'s offspring. The film is a captivating blend of romance, music, and drama, as Maria's free-spirited nature clashes with the Captain's stern demeanor, while they both grapple with their growing affection for one another amidst the looming threat of the Nazi regime.
One of the film's undoubted strengths is its memorable music, composed by Richard Rodgers with lyrics by Oscar Hammerstein II. From the iconic opening number, "The Sound of Music," to the touching "Edelweiss" and the lively "Do-Re-Mi," the soundtrack is a symphony of melodies that have become a part of our cultural fabric. Julie Andrews' soaring soprano voice and the children's harmonious choruses create moments of sheer auditory bliss that are hard to rival. The musical numbers elevate the film and provide it with a timeless quality that continues to draw audiences to this day.
The cast of "The Sound of Music" is another asset that has stood the test of time. Julie Andrews is luminous as Maria, exuding warmth and charisma, while Christopher Plummer brings depth and vulnerability to the stoic Captain von Trapp. The chemistry between the two leads is palpable, and their love story remains one of cinema's most enduring romances. The von Trapp children, played by a talented ensemble of young actors, add charm and innocence to the narrative, making their journey from discipline to joy all the more endearing.
The film's breathtaking cinematography also deserves acclaim. Robert Wise and his team expertly capture the stunning Austrian landscapes, with sweeping shots of lush green hills, crystal-clear lakes, and majestic mountains. The visuals serve as a visual symphony that complements the musical one, immersing the audience in the story's picturesque world. The contrast between the natural beauty of the surroundings and the encroaching threat of Nazi occupation heightens the film's tension and emotional impact.
However, despite its many strengths, "The Sound of Music" is not without its flaws, and it is these areas that warrant a critical reevaluation.
First and foremost, the film's pacing can be a bit uneven. While the musical numbers are undoubtedly the film's highlights, the transitions between these musical sequences and the dramatic moments can feel abrupt and disjointed. The film's nearly three-hour runtime occasionally drags, and some scenes could benefit from tighter editing to maintain a more consistent flow.
Another aspect that merits reconsideration is the treatment of certain characters. The portrayal of the von Trapp family's housekeeper, Frau Schmidt, and the nuns at the abbey where Maria resides can be seen as somewhat one-dimensional and stereotypical. These characters, while important to the story, are not given the same depth and development as the main characters, leaving them feeling like caricatures rather than fully realized individuals.
Furthermore, the film's depiction of the Nazi threat, while undoubtedly a central element of the story, may come across as somewhat sanitized to modern audiences. Given the gravity of the historical context, "The Sound of Music" could have delved deeper into the political and moral complexities of the era. While the film does not shy away from the looming danger, a more nuanced exploration of the characters' choices and dilemmas in the face of Nazism could have added depth to the narrative.
In addition, some viewers may find fault with the film's idealized portrayal of the von Trapp family's escape from the Nazis. The daring flight over the mountains is undoubtedly a gripping climax, but it also carries a sense of adventure that borders on the fantastical. A more realistic portrayal of the dangers and challenges faced by those fleeing the Nazi regime could have made the story even more impactful.
So, how could "The Sound of Music" be improved? One approach could involve reimagining the film as a limited series, allowing for a more expansive exploration of its characters and historical context. This format would provide the opportunity to delve deeper into the backgrounds and motivations of characters like Captain von Trapp and Maria, as well as to address the broader political landscape of Austria in the late 1930s.
A longer format would also allow for a more gradual development of the romance between Maria and the Captain, giving their relationship a more authentic and nuanced feel. It could also provide the space to explore the emotional impact of their choices on the von Trapp children and the other characters in the story.
In terms of pacing, a series format would alleviate the need to compress the narrative into a three-hour film, allowing for a more natural progression of the story and character arcs. It would also provide an opportunity to delve into the lives and experiences of characters like Frau Schmidt and the nuns, giving them the depth and dimension they deserve.
In conclusion, "The Sound of Music" is undeniably a cinematic classic that has earned its place in the hearts of audiences worldwide. Its timeless music, enchanting performances, and stunning visuals continue to captivate new generations. However, a critical reevaluation reveals areas where the film could be improved, particularly in terms of pacing, character development, and historical context.
One possible approach to revitalizing this beloved classic is to reimagine it as a limited series, allowing for a more in-depth exploration of its characters and historical backdrop. While "The Sound of Music" may never be perfect in the eyes of every viewer, it remains a testament to the enduring power of storytelling and the magic of cinema.

I know this movie is long, but it's an endless musical nonetheless. What I liked best were the Rodgers and Hammerstein songs. They are amazing, and make the movie what it is. Another reason I like it is Julie Andrews' amazing performance as Maria, a girl who longs for a better life, I think. Maria is beautiful, has a beautiful voice, mixed with nervousness and sadness, all qualities that Andrews brings to her performances. The only film she slightly disappointed was Thoroughly Modern Millie. The choreography is superb, as is the supporting cast, from the likes of Christopher Plummer and co. I can't pick a favorite scene, but who can forget the opening and the "Do ah Dear" sequence? I also thought the kids were sweet and the movie had some clever subplots, like Liesels secret love. 10/10 for a musical, which should be in the top 250. It's number 2 on Greatest Musicals, beating out Grease.

Superb,superb,superb,Damn I was smiling and bobbing my head all the way and lost all sense of time and place,this has to be one of the greatest movies of all time
A little fact,when they filming the silhouette scene during the ending of the film,the director had to go for the silhouette because Julia Andrews was laughing as the room was making "a raspberry sound"
The subtle expressions and nuanced micro acting of Julia Andrews especially when the baroness was telling her about love and all was perfect,the traditional dancing scene outside with Christopher Vonn trapp,you can see when he turned his back,his expression is that of uncertainty and when she takes his hand,he cracks a smile.
The music was catchy and the entire movie was nostalgic and had excellent vibes even for a 58 year old movie

The Sound of Music is really really my comfort movie. A place where I can run to whenever I need some peace of mind. The music, songs, the peaceful scenery of the mountains, dancing, laughing, running around freely, kids.

And not just that, but also meaningful message in it. About kindness, compassion, hope, second chances.
