Moving. Disturbing. Devastating. Horrific. A masterpiece film that everyone needs to watch at least once in their lifetime. Incredibly power storytelling. Outstanding performances. A testament to how mankind can be insanely evil, viciously cruel in through their antisemitism discrimination and treating humans like animals, and exploiting them to their death, and killing them in cold blood. While on the opposite side, mankind can exude unwavering compassion, good faith, and selflessness to save the lives of as many people as they can as what Oskar Schindler strived to do and accomplished as much as he could. The ending scene never fails to make me cry. A necessary must-watch film.

This movie didn't hit me like so many others. I know the story and see what it shows. It does very well, but not entirely to my taste. What captivated me though was the main character - played very well by Liam Neeson, Oskar Schindler is sophisticated, charming, empathetic, kind, smart. Overall - super good dude! A dude who should be an example to many of us. Steals the whole show outright.
Cinematography can not forget - brilliant performance by Janusz Kaminskiand, no less brilliant on the part of Steven Spielberg.
It's a long film, keep in mind, and while it's not for everyone, given the attention span of people today, it's shot and recreated very easily to watch and the running time doesn't feel at all.
As an addendum to all of the above - the character of Ralph Fiennes is also very interesting, has plenty of screen time, is played superbly and despite his cruelty, the character himself is slightly humorous, which is very original to do for a film like this, and very difficult for it to fit the story so well.
Final score: 8/10.

"THE ONE WHO SAVES ONE PERSON'S LIFE ACTUALLY SAVES THE WHOLE WORLD" When the movie ended, I was still under its influence, I think it will be like that for a long time, because it was a movie that shook my psychology completely. I also watched Life is Beautiful and The Pianist, which were my favorite movies, which depicted the Jewish Massacre very successfully. I watched it. However, the reality in this movie impressed me completely. It has been talked about for years and is still being talked about. The Jews are guilty like this, the Germans are right like that. Jews, Serbians, Muslims, Germans, Turks, Christians, whatever it is, it goes on and on, but which human being deserves this treatment? How is this? It is an atrocity. What justifies these actions? I don't understand what kind of mental state it is, to kill an unarmed, defenseless person without blinking an eye, and then to continue living as if nothing had happened. Neither the memories of the people whose memories are respected, nor the dead... Isn't it God who created them too? .. But there were those among them who had a conscience, like Oscar Schindler. The path he followed is still being debated by some groups. It is said, 'The man thought about his own labor force, capital and earnings', yes, the man thought about himself, but besides that, he saved as many people as he could and is indifferent to this inhumane treatment like the others. Other people have always suffered the sins of greedy, conscienceless dictators, and still do... The world has never It wasn't fair anyway.... Let me end it here, I think it's "DEFINITELY WORTH WATCHING"

Title: Schindler's List: A Poignant Masterpiece Capturing the Triumph of Humanity
"Schindler's List" is a cinematic achievement that transcends its medium, offering a searing and haunting portrayal of one of history's darkest chapters. Directed by Steven Spielberg and featuring a powerful performance by Liam Neeson, the film is a poignant exploration of the Holocaust and the extraordinary efforts of Oskar Schindler.
Liam Neeson's portrayal of Oskar Schindler is nothing short of remarkable, capturing the complexity of a man who evolves from a self-interested opportunist to a compassionate savior. Neeson's nuanced performance serves as the emotional anchor of the film, inviting audiences to witness Schindler's transformation with empathy and introspection.
Spielberg's direction is both sensitive and unflinching, presenting the horrors of the Holocaust with a stark realism that leaves an indelible impact. The black-and-white cinematography adds a timeless quality to the film, emphasizing the gravity of the historical events it depicts.
"Schindler's List" is a testament to the resilience of the human spirit in the face of unimaginable atrocities. The narrative, based on the true story of Schindler's efforts to save the lives of over a thousand Jewish refugees, is a powerful testament to the capacity for compassion and heroism amid the darkest of circumstances.
While the film's graphic and emotional intensity may make it challenging for some viewers, its importance as a historical document and a work of art cannot be overstated. "Schindler's List" stands as a powerful reminder of the atrocities of the past and the imperative to never forget.
For those who appreciate films that tackle profound historical subjects with both grace and gravity, "Schindler's List" is an essential viewing experience. With your 8 out of 10 rating, it acknowledges the film's significance and its ability to convey the triumph of humanity amidst unspeakable tragedy.

Score - 78%
'A true story about Frank Abagnale Jr. Who, before his 19th birthday, successfully conned millions of dollars worth of checks as a Pan Am pilot, doctor, and legal prosecutor. An FBI agent makes it his mission to put him behind bars. But Frank not only eludes capture, he revels in the pursuit.'
This one was very good. Many call it an underrated Spielberg film and I thought that there was a lot of fun to be had. The film is not perfect however, there are some flaws. In this review I will dive into what worked for me, and the few things that didn't work for me.
To begin with that opening scene, I think that this was a directorial choice by Spielberg, that didn't fully work. In the opening scene, you see almost the end of the story, and then cut back. I think that this almost took away from the moment when he was captured, because there was no doubt in our minds that he would be captured. I think that it would have been better if the moment was recontextualised later. However, I did quite like how Spielberg keeps going back to this moment, and we are able to see what these characters think of what they did in the past. Spielberg for the rest of the film is great, giving the film its own unique feel, and creating the perfect level of mystery. We are also introduced to our two leads here, Leonardo DiCaprio as Frank Abagnale Jr. And Tom Hanks as Carl Hanratty, our detective. Leo really showed himself here, and I think this performance was one of the reasons why he is so famous today. He plays a man who was once so confident, and then turns into scared and acceptance of his capture later on. Tom Hanks is the standout however, he plays such a serious character. He is so focussed on this case that we see it so well, and he proves yet again why he is one of the best in Hollywood.
The first act really dives into the set up for the film, as we see why Leo does what he does. There are some great scenes in here, particularly the school scene, that is quite iconic. I think that the two parents, played by Christopher Walken and Nathalie Baye were great. They conveyed such emotion in this film, Walken played a character trying to look so strong, but really is falling apart. I this that this groundwork is so important here, and I am so glad that Spielberg kept in these scenes. One of my issues is that I do not fully buy into Leo's character's motivation. I understand that he feels lost, but I don't fully buy it. I might be missing something, but the running away feels out of nowhere for me. I did enjoy seeing Leo's turn, as we have some montages that were enjoyable. Also, the sets and costumes for the planes and character designs were super great and a special shout out should go to Jeannine Oppewall and Mary Zophres.
The second act is when we saw Tom Hanks come in. I think that this makes the film take a great turn for the better, as it creates a cat and mouse feel. Any scene with Hanks in were the standout scenes, and seeing him figure out the mystery was stunning. Out focus was on Leo, and I wish we saw just a bit more of Hanks. One of the standout scenes in here was one where we thought Leo was found, but he works his way out of it in a great way. Leo's story was enjoyable, as we begin to see how this life isn't enjoyable for him. He tries to settle down with Amy Adam's character of Brenda Strong. She was so innocent, and it was so hard to watch as she found out that Leo is actually a fraud. The pacing was really good in here, as when you think it is about to drop, you get a Hanks scene and you are back into it. One scene when Hanks thinks he has found Leo, but actually hasn't and you see Leo leave was so great, and I loved Spielberg's direction in here. One other thing that I would like to mention as I feel like the cinematography could be a bit better. I think that Janusz Kaminski could have done a better job.
The third act sees Leo leave it all and fully commit. There was a scene of him really showing his fraud in a university that was fun to watch. We see Leo's capture after this, and it feels great for Hanks to catch him, it was so satisfying
We actually see a bond between Hanks and Leo, which I wasn't expecting. It was enjoyable, but I wasn't expecting it. I don't know if it was necessary but it does finish Hanks' arc in a nice way. However, the end point feels a bit generic, and I don't like the text on the screen.
Overall, this film has a lot of good, particularly the performances, direction, second act and pacing. It has some issues, notably Leo's motivation, a generic ending and I would have liked to see a bit more Hanks in here
My score is:
Plot - 7/10
First Act - 8/10
Second Act - 9/10
Third Act - 7/10
Acting - 9/10
Characters - 7/10
Direction - 8/10
Visuals - 7/10
Pacing - 8/10
Entertainment Value - 8/10
Total - 78/100.

Based on a true story - allegedly - Catch Me If You Can combine drama and comedy flawlessly, Tom Hanks and Leonardo DiCaprio bring different energy to their respective roles in this cat-and-mouse Steven Spielberg blockbuster.
The film is a classic good detective, smart criminal frenemy story. The detective obsesses over catching the criminal, even disobeying orders in the process until he finally does it; everyone learns their lesson, and the case is closed, so Catch Me If You Can is not getting any points for originality on my part.
Despite its lack of innovation, performances by lead actors Tom Hanks and Leonardo DiCaprio are outstanding as per usual. Let's not forget Christopher Walken as Frank Abagnale Sr whose brilliant performance earned him a nomination for Best Supporting Actor in the Academy Awards. On another note the score is memorable, and the cinematography is good.
Definitely not an art-house - as evidenced by the lack of nominations for major awards - but it doesn't have to be. Catch Me If You Can is still a fun watch.

"Catch Me If You Can" is a thrilling rollercoaster of a film that seamlessly blends crime, drama, and humor. Directed by Steven Spielberg and anchored by standout performances from Leonardo DiCaprio and Tom Hanks, this true story of a young con artist is a captivating journey from start to finish.
DiCaprio shines as Frank Abagnale Jr., a master of deception who successfully eludes the authorities by assuming various identities and forging checks. His charisma and quick thinking make him an incredibly engaging character, leaving the audience torn between rooting for him and the FBI agent hot on his trail.
Tom Hanks, as FBI Agent Carl Hanratty, provides the perfect foil to DiCaprio's character. The dynamic between the two leads is the heart of the film, delivering moments of tension, camaraderie, and unexpected humor. Hanks brings a gravitas to the role, portraying Hanratty as a determined and sympathetic character whose pursuit becomes more than just a job.
Spielberg's direction is impeccable, balancing the fast-paced nature of the story with moments of reflection and introspection. The film captures the essence of the 1960s with its stylish cinematography and a soundtrack that complements the era.
One of the film's strengths is its ability to navigate between lighthearted comedy and intense drama effortlessly. The humor derived from Frank's audacious cons provides a welcome break from the tension, making "Catch Me If You Can" a thoroughly enjoyable and well-rounded experience.
The supporting cast, including Christopher Walken and Martin Sheen, adds depth to the narrative, contributing to the emotional core of the story. Walken, in particular, delivers a poignant performance as Frank Abagnale Sr., adding layers to the protagonist's character.
"Catch Me If You Can" is more than just a cat-and-mouse game; it's a character-driven exploration of identity, family, and the consequences of choices. The film keeps you on the edge of your seat, thanks to its compelling narrative, strong performances, and Spielberg's expert storytelling.
In conclusion, "Catch Me If You Can" is a cinematic gem that stands the test of time. It's a riveting tale of wit and charm, skillfully brought to life by a stellar cast and a masterful director. If you haven't seen it yet, do yourself a favor and catch this enthralling ride.

Despite being often overlooked, this Spielberg movie is a hidden gem that is worth watching. Unlike other films that belong to a big franchise or revolutionize the cinema industry, this one is a well-crafted story. Spielberg's direction of this cat-and-mouse game is captivating, leaving me hooked from start to finish. The dialogue, music, and direction all work together seamlessly and to great effect. Spielberg's unique camera angles and actor positioning create perfect scenes. Both DiCaprio and Hanks deliver fantastic performances, making this heartwarming and energetic film one of Spielberg's best, in my opinion.

This film isn't totally true to the book, but as we now know, the book is not totally true either!
I suppose it's hard to be too upset at a con man lying. That's what they do. Compulsively. For profit.
The film (and the book) don't really explore the motives behind the lies. Like why didn't the bright young man study and train to be a pilot? Because he had no respect for Pilots, or anybody. Everyone was his plaything.
His tale is one of style, not substance. So I didn't mind the playful way Spielberg portrayed him.
It's still a fine movie. I even read the book again recently and still enjoyed that too. But would the book have been published if it was submitted as a novel?
Chuck Barris, James Frey and others have confessed to lying in their books. It's time Abagnale did the same. But there's the rub, who would believe a con artist?

Every time I board a plane, this film comes to my mind. It happened again, and I watched it again. The downside of watching such legendary films and magnificent performances is that we see fewer stories and actor performances of this quality over time. Tom Hanks is magnificent, Leo is great, and all the other actors present a recital. The fact that a true story can be so incredible is a whole other matter. Admiring a character I admired as a child 20 years later is, I guess, the emotional aspect of the matter... Probably I'm goint watch again 15 years later and Im going feel same like today...

As the title above stated this movie is enjoyable but not much else.
It really feels like some of the scenes are added on for more padding and to make the movie longer which is rather odd considering it probably would've been better without the excess fat.
Performances are very good with a star studded cast as expected from these names, both DiCaprio and Hanks deliver fantastic performances in their respective roles which make their characters be a lot of believable.
Despite the padding the movie itself kind of feels flat, especially when you put the whole background story for Frank and he's still rather empty as a character.

A film directed by Steven Spielberg and starring Leonardo DiCaprio and Tom Hanks. Just with these details it is possible to imagine that there is no way to make a bad film. It is actually a very good film and very well executed, with great performances and very competent direction. However, perhaps it is not as great a film as some think. It's a very interesting and fun film, but it probably doesn't make it into the top ten of these three movie stars. The story is cool, but there's nothing that incredible about it. The characters don't draw that much attention, even though they are real people. The pacing is good and the film ends in the blink of an eye. Something that bothers me a lot is the film's photography, which isn't as beautiful as the director's other films. Still, it's impossible to say that this film is bad. It's worth watching.

(2002) Catch Me If You Can\nDRAMA/ ADVENTURE\nA story about a real life con artist whose a wiz on dodging getting caught and forging checks etc... Not bad as a film but felt Leo is too wrong for the role who shouldn't be taller than the average person if he were supposed to be the one to run away from the FBI lead by Tom Hanks! By looking at the real Frank Abagnale Jr, Leo is too tall for the role but because of his high star status was able to solidify the role despite being totally wrong for it! All the extras had to be just as tall so Leo can conveniently get away from the FBI! Good, but not great because of the unconvincing chase sequences.

Unfathomable in today's world... rampant unsecured check cashing, forged diplomas that aren't checked, a hapless FBI outwitted by a 17 year old... maybe the most amazing thing is that it's based on a true story!\nLeonardo DeCaprio and Tom Hanks are great, as expected, and so was Christopher Walken. Yet even though it runs 2:21, the story is thin in places. There's only one real "scare" where Frank was forced to action in one of the careers he was faking, an emergency room event that obviously rattles him. I expected more, I guess. Maybe some sort of in-flight semi-crisis for the bogus pilot?\nIt's a nice story... a cat and mouse chase that turns into a different sort of bond between pursued and pursuer. I think I hoped for more drama than there was, but that's on me. It was good, not perfect, but worth a watch.

Interesting film, worth a watch and like all these things, how much if this is based on fact or fiction, who will ever know. Great fun and Lady GaGa smashes her role with her usual passion and ultimate professionalism. A much better actress than a singer, but what do I know? Adam driver plays a good part bouncing off Lady GaGa adding real value to the plot. Al Pacino clearly loved his character as he shines also . Some amazing settings and a dash of good humour mask the pain of the story and the love twist embedded in the corporate turmoil which unfolds before our eyes. I have never been a fan of Gucci style, But I loved the film.

Ok, you are going to say "this movie is intended for internaional viewers and mostly for Anericans" but I still don't see a point of Italian people talking to eachother in English with an Italian accent and even worse, using basic words in Italian like "ciao, si" in between sentences. If the director wants us to assume they are actually speaking Italian but we are hearing them in English, then why the accent and Italian words? This removes the sense of reality. House of Gucci is lovely to look at, the cars, the scenery and of course the clothes are opulent and fitting.
The film is a very strange affair. It is a film with very little depth and indeed the whole thing is like watching a recap of a story.
The family is pretty much unlikeable and appear quite mad. Al Pacino and Jeremy Irons are two Gucci brothers and we don't really know much about them. It seems that the brother Irons plays left the business to follow a film career and Pacino stayed to run the Gucci business.
I am reminded of "All About Eve", this film is similar in a way but far inferior. Lady Gaga is portrayed as a manipulator and perhaps gold digger. I found her to be those maybe but also a headstrong woman who had a plan. Nothing really wrong with that.
It's all very weak, limp even
No highlights at all , unfortunately.

This is absolutely awful.
I thought I was going to watch a good true life film about the Gucci family and the downfall of the brand. Instead it was like a comedy in parts and kept switching scenes which didn't gel together.
The fake Italian accents are dreadful and the English actors sometimes revert back to an English accent.
Keep an eye on the red wine they drink - it looks like diluted Ribena!!
Why produce a film with English / American actors using dreadful Italian accents and then in parts such as greetings of hello or goodbye they speak in Italian !! What's the point of that.
Acting is very poor, and if I were any member of the Gucci family I would he horrified to see my family portrayed in this way.
It could have been so good because the actual facts of this story are film worthy, and not making a mockery of the House of Gucci.
Don't bother watching!

Although now in his eighties, Ridley Scott - as his curt responses to critic of 'Napoleon' have recently demonstrated - is certainly showing no signs of mellowing.\nHere he turns his attention to the sort of Eurotrash with more money than sense with the same sardonic eye as Fellini. Despite the rather grandiose title nobody actually seems to be taking it terribly seriously, the portrayals are inclined to be rather broad and with the casting of Al Pacino - which prompts associations with 'The Godfather' - we don't expect the characterisation to be terribly nuanced, while Lady Gaga make a startling brunette with an even more startling Italian accent and Egyptian eyeliner.

Ridley Scott has been a prominent director for decades, having turned out "Alien", "Blade Runner", "Thelma and Louise" and "Gladiator". In 2017, he released "All the Money in the World", about the kidnapping of J. Paul Getty's grandson. A lot of what the movie showed was how there was no love in that family; Getty cared only about his wealth. More recently, Scott gave us "House of Gucci", about the ugly goings-on behind the scenes of the famous fashion house. I had never known about any of this. It's hard to tell if Patrizia Reggiani was simply a gold-digger or if she actually felt affection for Maurizio Gucci. Either way, these were some of the most screwed-up people of all time. I guess that's often the case with the rich and famous.\nThe movie apparently drew criticism for the cast's uneven accents and odd makeup work. I thought that they did a good job. If you only know Lady Gaga for her outrageous outfits, then you'll be impressed with her no-nonsense performance as Patrizia, as well as Adam Driver as Maurizio, Jeremy Irons as Rodolfo, Al Pacino as Aldo, and Jared Leto as Paolo. Worth seeing.

Well, you won't believe it, but I didn't have high hopes for this flick at all. I only gave it a shot because Netflix was like, "Hey, you might like this!" And guess what? It totally blew me away.
The plot? Oh, it's killer! Plus, the cast is top-notch, and their acting is on point.
Let's talk about Adam Driver, shall we? That dude's delivery is just perfection. He manages to be all confident and at the same time, he shows some real vulnerability. It's like, "Dude, are you for real?" And yeah, it's totally believable and just pulls you in.
Now, Lady Gaga? I mean, I've never been a fan of her or her music, but she surprised the heck out of me with her performance. It's seriously terrific.
And Jared Leto? He brings the laughs and adds some warmth to his character, even though the guy's a total goofball. But he's a lovable goofball, you know what I mean?
Al Pacino? He dials down his usual craziness just the right amount. And Jeremy Irons? Perfect, man. His character here kinda reminds me of his role in Margin Call.
The pacing? Nailed it. I couldn't wait for each episode to drop. This movie was a pleasant surprise, no doubt about it!

First off: why are they talking in bad Italian accents?
This movie is a stark reminder that Ridley Scott, as acclaimed and as visionary director has he become, is just a man with the sensibilities of a music video director. He is not a storyteller. And here it shows. It's one thing to adapt some memoir or biography into a feature film; apparently it is another to make it interesting.
There is nothing in this film. The story is convoluted; it's unclear who does what and more importantly why. Motivations or character traits are never brought up; almost all of them are motivated by either money or fame. That is hardly compelling.
The movie could have woven a smart plot around it. Granted, they the protagonists are acting on base impulses; but they could've hatched brilliant plans and elaborate mind tricks to get there. Nope - their schemes are as straightforward as they come. Everybody's moves are transparent; there is barely any mystery or intrigue.
Is the movie a pretext to show the backstage of the fashion world, a view on the underbelly of the glamour of the high-fashion world? Defiles and canapÃ©s on the one side, cloak and dagger intrigue on the other? Think again, the most boring scene is when Tom Ford is introduced, and still the film treats it as if you're supposed to fall from your seat at that moment.
Maybe the acting will be the saving grace. Poor story, bad plot, a remarkable memorable performance stands out and moves you in other ways?
Of course not! Everybody is acting as if they're in a different movie. Pacino and Leto are either trying to outdo each other in some sick game of which Oscar winner can deliver the worst performance, or just phoning it in pure and simple. If it's a bet between them it's actually pretty hilarious and they're both winning. Adam Driver is stiff and wooden and dry. Lady Gaga on the other hand is the only one taking it seriously and giving a genuinely good performance, but it feels completely out of place. To top it all, they all have bad Italian accents.
It is a mess of a film and it's not even an interesting mess. It's just boring, it's has the same look and feel and depth as those re-enactment they do sometimes to illustrate documentaries. Except everyone in the cast is an Oscar winner and the director is Ridley Scott.
Even if you're in love with the clothes, I suspect there are better ways to spend two and a half hours.

Can somebody please explain to me what this is supposed to be? I was actually looking forward to it but I couldn't see it in theaters. So happy now I didn't have to sit through two and a half hours of this clown show.
Why the heck are the actors talking with Italian accents? It doesn't make an sense at all and it so irritating and distracting.
What's the story?
Where's the humour?
What the hell is Jared Leto doing?
Everyone just seems to be doing their little Oscar dance.
Al Pacino is the only redeeming piece in this craziness.
Even hair and makeup couldn't save this.
Did I say clown show yet?

A true-events based story of the Gucci family, their business and the struggles for power and influence within it. A strong cast on absolute showboating form, dialling up the acting to farcical levels. The accents are absurd and distracting. There is a great deal of inconsistency as the film veers between attempts at seriousness and a completely outlandish tone. Sometimes actors seems to be brining entirely different energy to the same scene. Jared Leto and Al Pacino bring the most chaotic vibes. It feels like the actors were given total freedom without any through-line of overarching tone. All that said, it somehow works. The set and costume design is really impressive and evokes a 90s European aesthetic. The bizarre unevenness in performances and overly long unfolding of the story strangely serves to give us a film that has an enjoyable and unique feel.

Wow what a tedious, boring bit of garbage.
Fact is this puff piece wasn't made because Nyad is some hero. Nyad isnt even her name. I'll get to that.
If you watch this movie you'll know exactly why it was made and who supports it. And if you are still unclear look her up on the internet. It's another one of THOSE movies.
Only she's a complete phony that a group wants to deify.
Diana Nyad is actually Diana Sneed. Nyad isnt even her stepfather's real last name! It was Notaras. In fact, during the credits the REAL Bonnie tell the audience at some event ever to believe a thing that Nyad says! What?
At least SHE's honest.
Her swim was never acknowledged so why the movie? Already told you.
But OMG they decided to make the most boring film on earth. She comes across as a completely entitled, self-absorbed, unlikable person who has zero care or compassion for anyone but herself.
And it's all for naught because she never succeeded, no matter what this movie tries to wrongly portray.
Her entire life is built on sand. It's phony as the day is long. And if you can make it thru this debacle, you will be praying you can get your time back. You can't.
Don't bother.

This is a laidback style yet somewhat inspirational movie about a woman who is in her 60s suddenly decided to swim across the open ocean between Cuba and Florida to prove herself she could do this despite her age and to reach her long lost dream.
I'm not sure how exaggerated or accurate the storyline is, but I felt the main contributing factor for her multiple failures to be able to swim between Cuba and Florida was not because of her lack of physical skills, but rather because of her massive egos and how she didn't listen to or respect others inputs. She ended up overcoming this god complex she possessed towards the very end but this main character woman is quite unlikable around 90% of the time in the movie; how she treated people around her so poorly and so disrespectfully, like everyone was beneath her, including her best friend (played by Jodie Foster). It was off-putting the main character thought the world revolved around her to such degree. To me her narcissistic behaviors exhibited and attitudes towards others were just unacceptable. This isn't acceptable for any athlete or aspiring athlete to treat people like this who were trying to help her.
Certain aspects of the film, what it took to swim being surrounded by poisonous jellyfish or consuming food or taking medications while in the sea or what the mental state of mind she would become due to exhaustion swimming such long distance were quite eye opening and interesting aspects of the movie we don't see everyday.
Overall an interesting movie worthy of watching and acting was pretty good (though the film itself is not 9 or 10...). Just that the main character was very unlikable and if any athletes are this narcissistic they should not be allowed or welcomed to represent anything let alone women. As a woman I felt embarrassed how she treated everybody around her 90% of the time in the movie.

This movie is so inspiring! I really loved the portrayal of Diane and Jodie plays such a great supporting role. I would recommend everyone see this as a must-see end of the year movie; it will really get your spirit lifted and remind you of how powerful a dream can really be.\nThis is the kind of movie that makes you feel like you really can get up and reclaim your life and continue a voyage to complete a goal - even if you need to take a pit stop once in a while along the way. It's the kind of movie that renews your faith in possibility and that's something we could all use a lot more of in cinema these days.

"Nyad" is an uninspired, middlebrow inspirational sports story, but there's a place for movies like this. The story itself is very compelling, so even if the execution is bland, the movie stays fairly engaging anyway.
The film's biggest assets are its two main actors, Annette Bening and Jodie Foster, who have a ton of chemistry as life-long friends and the titular swimming phenom and her coach, respectively. Foster especially gives a spunky performance and has the more interesting character, having to balance moral support for her friend's obsessive ambitions with genuine concern for her life, and face the prospect of being an accomplice in her death.
I obviously wasn't paying attention to the news, because despite this happening not that long ago, I have no recollection of this story.
Grade: B+

Based on the autobiography Find a way, narrates the story of swimmer Diana Nyad and her attempts to swim from Cuba to Florida without a shark cage, facing all the odds. It presents the account of her personal life, the impact of a serious crime had on her and how she fought her way back. The kind of stubborn person she is, who never gives up and the team that made sure she achieved her goal through the five attempts.\nThis indeed was an inspiring tale of not just one woman but her entire team who stood by her, safeguarding and motivating her, backing her never give up attitude. Annette Bening is aptly cast in the role of Diana Nyad and she perfectly captures the character's various emotions throughout, can even say lived this character which again applies to Jodie Foster playing Bonnie the best friend. The narrative sticks to linear narrative as far as the swimming portions go and giving flashbacks of the past that took a toll on the child yet she ensured it didn't stop her from growing up to be the person she aimed to be. The highlight was the final moments and ofcourse the footage of the real people in the end.

I am far to be admirer of sports films. I admitt, I was real ignorant about name and swiming activity of Diana Nyad.
But the presence of Jodie Foster and Annette Bening was just enough for see the film. And their acting, their honest define of characters, the fair craft of relation steps are a real precious gift offered by director.
Maybe not exactly about sport , but about determination, ambition, courage, forms of tenacity to craziness, dark memories and five attempts and magnificent team work and support is this beautiful film about two women and their life together. And, sure, about their battles.
Unfair to ignore the inspired work of Rhys Ifans.
In short, a film deserving to be discovered .

This movie based on a true stoty of the strength and unrelenting determination of Diana Nyad a well documented swimmer and athlete.
The film based on a true story of the journey and attempts by Nyad to swim from cuba to keywest Florida. So many crushing blows as se eral unsuccessful attempts to make this swimming marathon while battling mother nature and the extreme conditions of this stretch of ocean
If you're a fan of Jodie Foster then you will love her in this film.
No one has ever accomplished what Diana Nyad done making this remarkable swim from Cuba to Keywest and doing it at age 64.
Highly recommend this film.

I remember Diana Nyad and her swimming exploits over the years, she and I are almost the same age. This movie is about her quest to swim, non-stop, from Havana, Cuba to Key West, Florida. She had tried it and failed years earlier, when she was 28. Now in her 60s, she was determined to complete it, she felt physically strong enough and better prepared mentally than she had been earlier.
The producers made excellent selections, Annette Bening is Diana Nyad and Jodie Foster is her close friend, and coach, Bonnie Stoll. The movie runs right at 2 hours, both my wife and I were wishing it had been a bit shorter, maybe 90 minutes. But we stuck with it and it is an excellent movie.
At home, streaming on Netflix.
In addition to her preparations for the big swim, the movie also has several flash backs to Diana as a teenager and swimming prodigy of sorts. Plus a less than welcome relationship with her coach at the time.
Good movie of interesting characters and interesting events.

I first learned of Diana Nyad when she successfully swam from Cuba to Florida in 2013, and the report mentioned that she had tried it before and failed. So, we now have "Nyad", starring Annette Bening as the swimmer and Jodie Foster as her partner Bonnie. Decidedly unglamorous in their roles, they show the pair's trials and tribulations as Diana pushes forward with her determination to accomplish her dream. Maybe the movie overplayed their personal issues, but Bening's and Foster's performances more than make up for everything. This is definitely the sort of movie that everyone should see. I hope that it earns a lot of recognition.

Annette and Jodie are phenomenal in this! Love how they show some raw footage. I didn't know anything about Diana Nyad until this movie and now I know everything I need to know. It's thorough and not boring. Not sure why this doesn't have a higher rating. I was looking up the real facts during the movie because I wanted to see more on the real people.\nIt was a feel good inspiring story. It's truly incredible what she accomplished and her determination. If you like a good documentary type movie, this is definitely one to add to your list. I would love to see more movies like this one. 10 out of 10 for me.

'Finding Neverland' was based on writer J. M. Barrie's conception and writing of 'Peter Pan'. 'The Man who invented Christmas' is based on Charles Dickens writing 'A Christmas Carol'. Unfortunately, as well made as 'The Man who invented Christmas' is, I didn't find it as interesting as 'Finding Neverland'. In fact, I found it rather boring. If it wasn't for the marvelous performance by Dan Stevens, I might have stopped watching.
Dan Stevens stars as writer Charles Dickens. After the success of 'Oliver Twist', he was on top of the world, attending endless balls, dinners, speeches, and parties. However, with his next three books being flops, he was running out of money - and had run out of ideas for another novel.
When he finally came up with an idea for his next book - partly thanks to his new servant girl Tara - he finds it difficult to write with constant interference from his family. With a fast approaching deadline, time is of the essence.
Why did I find the movie as boring as I did? Too much talk maybe? Or possibly because the premise didn't interest me? Maybe also because the film was too predictable. I mean, we all know he managed to publish the book. The film depicts his journey from the creation of the main character, Scrooge, to developing and writing the story, and then self-publishing it.
'The Man who invented Christmas' is a well made film with elements of fantasy, drama and subtle humour. I did enjoy the feel-good ending, but the film as a whole was a tad too boring for my liking. Also note, this is not a Christmas movie - as I thought - and actually has very little to do with Christmas.

While searching for a decent Christmas movie to watch this popped up. Since I am a huge fan of Dickens' Christmas Carol I thought I'd give it a watch. So glad I did. Every year we watch the Reginald Owen 1938 version, the Alastair Sim version & the George C Scott version. The Man Who Invented Christmas will be added to that list.\nI knew a bit about the life of Dickens; the way this merged his past & present, his reality and his fantasy was very entertaining. All the actors were wonderful in their roles and the portrayal of the life of Dickens superimposed with the life of Scrooge was entertaining. This movie ticked all the boxes. Highly recommended.

I enjoyed this movie and the cast was excellent. Dan Steven's was wonderful as Charles Dickens, I loved his struggles in bringing the characters to life and the room full of them talking among themselves. Jonathan Pryce was very believable as his Dad, a ne're do well who leads a troubled life while ever hopeful things will be better. He's actually a little bit of a con man and he and Charles aren't on good terms. The stand out actor was Christopher Plummer as Scrooge, a stellar performance as usual. The friend, Justin Edward's, was the glue that held Charles together and always supported him. The story gives us a look into this period in history and the struggles that the poor families faced, especially children who were forced to work in the poor house. Also how many of the wealthy class felt as if you were poor you had no value except to work as their underpaid servants. I am going to watch it with my Grandchildren and I hope they enjoy it as much as I did. This is a feel good story that I hope will become a Christmas classic. .

What is not to like here? A delightful period gem with some top quality actors in the billing - including the magnificent Miriam Margoyles. I absolutely love Dan Stevens, he has an exquisite way of presenting himself, with a hint of twinkle! Loved the storyline of how the classic characters of "A Christmas Carol" came to be, really very interesting and, if true, an insight into the author of whom I didn't know much before. I adored the little quirks and references, such as the policeman called Copperfield. Beautiful film set as well, seemed like a quality production. It has certainly entertained me on a wintery evening infront of the fire and the Christmas tree and got me nicely in the mood for the festive season. Will definitely watch again.

The Man Who Invented Christmas is an interesting story about a real author. The movie showcases author Charles Dickens putting himself in the role of his character to help make the story. This movie takes place during a time where Christmas isn't such a big holiday as it is today. Dickens writing the story of A Christmas Carol definitely helps revolutionize the holiday. A Christmas Carol does create the term of Scrooge (i.e. People could call someone else a Scrooge if they're not entirely in the Christmas spirit). It may help bring Christmas movies to life when it gets time to the 1900s. A Christmas Carol can be pretty impactful and this movie definitely brings its creation to life, so I recommend it if you want to know more about Christmas and why it's such a big holiday. This movie might not be a lot, but still.

This may be a splendid film. With the storyline being the extraordinary journey of how one of the most classic works in literature came to life, it is a powerful and inspiring film for anyone to watch.\nI myself am a writer (I mainly write short stories) and the adventure of how the literary characters came to life is astonishing. These kind of films are truly inspiring and has proven to have the power to make viewers create new ideas. Many generations of viewers can learn new things from biopics. I love biopics. Each cast member committed fully to their characters and to the storyline of the film.\nI really enjoy watching biopics, and this film is one-of-a-kind. Although, with this film being all good, Christmas is a tormenting period for me. As a matter of fact, I hate Christmas. One experience can destroy something for someone, and that is exactly what happened to me. For years, it has haunted me.

The movie makes the underlying theme of the book -- redemption through spiritual enlightenment of even the most inherent personal flaws -- more beautiful and clear by showing that Dickens had similarities to Scrooge. It also reveals that writers often work out their personal struggles through the characters and story lines of their works. Because of this, it makes the viewer relate the theme to the viewer's own life.\nI adored this movie. A wonderful Christmas treat that made the classic tale more lovable than ever. Anyone who loved the book should see this movie. It will make them see the book in sharper relief.

"The Man Who Invented Christmas" is a Biography - Drama movie in which we watch the way Charles Dickens followed in order to be able to write "A Christmas Carol". An amazing book that changed Christmas for ever and it still be considered a masterpiece.\nI enjoyed this movie very much and I liked the way Charles Dickens was presented from his childhood until the day "A Christmas Carol" was published. The direction which was made by Bharat Nalluri was very good and he presented in a very clever way how Charles Dickens actually wrote it and how his thoughts were transformed into words in a piece of paper. The interpretations of both Dan Stevens who played as Charles Dickens and Christopher Plummer who played as Scrooge were very good and their combination worked very well. Some other interpretations that have to be mentioned were Jonathan Pryce who played as Mr. John Dickens, Justin Edwards who played as John Forster / Ghost of Christmas Present and Morfydd Clark who played as Kate Dickens. Lastly, I have to say that "The Man Who Invented Christmas" is a beautiful movie and I strongly recommend everyone to watch it because I am sure it will amaze you.

Delightful and entertaining. I recommend it highly to those who want to learn the backstory of the book and the movies that came of it.\nDelightful and entertaining. I recommend it highly to those who want to learn the backstory of the book and the movies that came of it.
This is a perfect movie to watch on Christmas Day .... and other days as well :)\nWell acted, nice story with a sweet ending. This is a perfect movie to watch.

This was one of those movies that, after it was over Kelly and I were like "What did we just watch?" It's weird and dark and at times gross, but it was also funny (in a black comedy kind of way) and engaging.
Barry Keoghan (who we LOVED in The Banshees of Inisherin) plays Oliver Quick who has just arrived at Oxford and is a bit of an outcast. He soon makes friends with Felix Catton (Big Man on Campus) who invites him to spend a summer with his family at their palatial estate (Saltburn). The movie then goes from quirky to downright bizarre as the Catton's reveal themselves to be quite the eccentric clan.
There's some rich dialogue in here (like when one character here's of another's suicide and says "She'd do anything for attention") and weird situations (like when there's a dead body in the hedge maze - think The Shining but in summertime - but the cops keep getting lost trying to find it).
And the finale, with Quick dancing butt ass naked through Saltburn is the perfect capper. There's nothing like seeing a man's twig and berries flapping in the breeze to make me laugh. I know Keoghan has come out to say that there were no prosthetics involved in this scene which, if true, dispels a myth about Irish men.
This is available on Prime and if you're up for something out of the ordinary I'd recommend it. Try pairing it with a 5 mg edible like I did for maximum enjoyment.

The film is a black comedy and a psychological thriller, with elements of Gothic horror and satire. Fennell's script is witty, provocative, and unpredictable, keeping the audience on edge as Oliver's obsession spirals out of control. The film also explores themes of class, sexuality, identity, and morality, as Oliver manipulates and seduces everyone around him, while hiding his own troubled past.\nThe cast is superb, with Keoghan delivering a captivating and complex performance as Oliver, a character who is both sympathetic and sinister. Elordi is equally impressive as Felix, a charming but troubled young man who is unaware of Oliver's true intentions. Rosamund Pike and Richard E. Grant are hilarious and menacing as Felix's parents, Elspeth and James, who have their own secrets and schemes. The supporting cast, including Alison Oliver, Archie Madekwe, and Sadie Soverall, are also excellent.\nThe film's production design, cinematography, and music are also noteworthy, creating a contrast between the idyllic and the grotesque. The film captures the beauty and the madness of Saltburn, a sprawling mansion filled with art, antiques, and oddities. The film also uses a vibrant and eclectic soundtrack, featuring classical, pop, and rock songs, to enhance the mood and the irony of the scenes.

How could the director Promising Young Woman make such a dull, lifeless film about dull, lifeless people?
Anyone claiming to think this film is masterful, obviously only sees the superficial attributes this indulgent mess has to offer.
No character is fun or likeable or memorable and the it goes on forever! The direction is is aimless and it's one of those "we're hip and cool" movies that's shot in a long gone aspect ratio for the sake of drawing attention to itself.
Unlike PYW, you will walk away from Saltwash with no feelings. No memories. Just indifference. If that was the intent, well done. But who wants to pay $15 bucks to feel nothing but boredom?
Talk about a sophomore slump.

What a disappointing movie. If your wife says watch. Just think Brokeback Mountain! And then start drinking and turn away! Then find something to shove under your fingernails to really tell her why you do not want to watch it. If that does not work try to wet your fingers and fit them into a wall socket as this is the best you can do all day to make it all better. After this try to tie a 50 lb weight to your legs and jump in a pool as this will make you feel better then you would after watching this movie from the other side of the pond. If this does not work look for a garden tool....this will work in the end!

I dont really know what to say other then I really wasn't expecting it to end like that. I was a bit unsure if this was going to be a good watch but I watched it and... all I'm going to say is it got weird and dark fast.
I seen may may moives in my time, but this this is something else. The mind games Oliver is pulling ðŸ˜³ I just wasn't expecting.
On prime is says drama comedy I think they should throw in psychological in there too.
All and all it was a good watch some pretty wired scenes definitely not for all but if you can watch passed some of Oliver weirdo movements and power too the end you will either shocked, or "I knew it" something was off about him. ðŸ˜‚
7.5 out of 10 only because the bath water wasn't necessary.

It's a decent way to pass time, but I only watched it bc everyone on TikTok was saying how crazy it is. I guess they haven't watched many movies or shows in the past 30 years, but this was tame and didn't cover any turf that hasn't already been covered a million times. Entertaining but certainly not shocking or groundbreaking. It is always interesting though to see a story of how the other half (1%) live and this doesn't disappoint from that aspect, in the UK. A couple of scenes have put this one on the map for shock value but not memorable. If you don't find the guy from euphoria attractive then this is even less of a draw.

Excellent acting from all. Whoever says the sex is extreme in the parental ratings is having a laugh. The sex is all implied but not seen. Lots of darkness and shadows in the sex scenes conceals the vulgarity but reveals the emotions which is how it should be. There's a bit of nudity and a rather dark moment in a cemetery but it's akin to the pie scene in American Pie (awkward) However, all that implied, you CAN see a twisted version of stiff upper lip/classist/begging to belong/ in almost every aspect of the film. Go in with an open mind and if you're a fan of The Talented Mr. Ripley you'll be a fan of this. The bougie life style of the upper crust is portrayed like those in New York being barred from Club 54 standing on the wrong side of the velvet rope and the posers trying to get in. In short it's an English version of MAGA looking in from the outside of Mar-A-Lago.

Saltburn
If one were looking for a definition of tastelessness in cinematic form then I would suggest this effort as a worthy candidate. One should note that it's not particularly worthy in many other respects, with the notable exception of its cinematography and set design; these happen to be the only areas where any true care appears to have been given. For example, there are some arresting uses of shadow, and a variety of visually stimulating locations but there endeth the praise, almost...
I also wish to make some positive remarks regarding the performance of Rosamund Pike, who, to my mind, is an extraordinary actress who hasn't received the filmic exposure that her talents merit. Her icy charisma and ability to appear authentic in pretty much any role she undertakes makes her scenes one of the very few pleasures this movie bestows.
Now onto the problems. Firstly, there are the characters. The fact that none of them, except possibly Pike's, appears credible is not actually the film's biggest issue; what is much more dissatisfying is that none of the relationships in the film are even marginally convincing. There is not an iota of chemistry between any of the film's characters and that especially applies to the relationship which occupies the film's central focus, that between Oliver (Barry Keoghan) and Felix (Jacob Elordi). Now it's easy for one to excuse this by referring to how emotionally dysfunctional Oliver and Felix (as well as the entirety of Felix's family) appear to be, but that would be to miss the point. There isn't even any superficial connection or slight moment of feeling that is generated between Oliver and Felix which would make you believe that they would bother to utter a morning greeting to each other, never mind about the idea that one would invite the other to his family home. The issue here is not with the acting but with the pacing, the writing and, most significantly, the film's incessantly odious tone.
The general misanthropy and nastiness that pervades each scene does not provide any space for the actors to begin to cultivate any sense of fine feeling, or feeling of any kind in fact, for each other. Oliver talks about loving and being in love at the beginning of the film but all we are truly presented with is an emotionally barren wasteland of unconvincing characters being placed in unconvincing scenarios doing and saying unconvincingly horrid things to one another. There is no emotional texture to draw on, there's no empathy, no joy, no connection, and, thus, there are no stakes. It is simply impossible to care what becomes of any of the characters because the film never allowed any of the characters to become anything in the first place.
Some of this would've been redeemed if the film was at least humorous. However, I'm afraid that, despite a number of obvious and jarring attempts, humour was never experienced for this viewer. The film was in fact painfully humourless. After all, it's hard to laugh at scenarios which are neither persuasive nor engaging.
A word should be spoken on the casting of Barry Keoghan as the film's protagonist. Yes, he was probably miscast. His Liverpudlian accent is inconsistent and while he does creepy and arresting extremely well in other films, he possesses none of the oily charm or comfortingly sympathetic demeanour his character requires. Matt Damon does a much better job in a film with similar themes: The Talented Mr Ripley. He demonstrates a boyish innocence and exuberance alongside an unnatural cunning which makes him endearing and credible and thus draws him into a world to which someone of his station would normally be barred entry. Keoghan's Oliver, on the other hand, one would not wish to touch with a barge pole, and, if one did, one would run away from him as soon as one had found oneself doing so. However, the casting of Keoghan only serves to speak to larger faults with the film. He was unsuitable, it's true, but so was the entire movie.
So, what seemed as if it might have been a worthwhile, visceral investigation of the way class and privilege operate in 21st century Britain ends up being an ugly, uninteresting, vicious mess. Its plot begins as muddy and ends as being ridiculous to the point of insult, so insulting, in fact, that I shan't bother to offer any further comment on it. Its sense of place is much weaker than it ought to be, bearing in mind that the film's title is eponymous with it, and its sense of time is utterly arbitrary (was it set around 2006 just so the director got to include her favourite tunes? I can't think of any other reason). Thus, the overall effect of the film is to inspire very little outside of boredom and jaded disgust.
4/10 (3 points for Rosamund and 1 for the pretty colours and sets)

It had potential at first, but things got weird after. It is disturbing and dark, but i think they should've went darker and less disturbing, it's just there wasn't any balance between them. The plot was nice, we didn't see it coming from Oliver, but how did the family not suspect anything? Or anyone? Not even the maids. Cinematography was ok but it didn't give 2006 vibes at all, it's obvious they were trying hard to, but it didn't come out as such. The clothes and the aesthetic were chaotic. And i think Jacob was not it for the role, his accent wasn't convincing, his looks did not match the 2006 vibes.

Jacob Elordi was fairly convincing, but Irish Barry Keoghan supposedly from somewhere in the north of England, hard to tell where Keoghan thought his character was from given his accent was so abysmal and frequently weirdly mixed with Irish it was a joke. His acting other than that was ok but his character's ability to manipulate was unbelievable.\nThis film I was looking forward to, but it felt like a novice screenwriter trying to put their own spin on Brideshead Revisited or the Talented Mr Ripley and trying to use shock to make up for a poor effort.\nIf you want this type of film go and re-watch those older films. I cannot believe this film is getting award nominations unless it was for the cinematography.

Anyone but you is a newly released romantic comedy starring Sydney Sweeney as Bea and Glen Powell as Ben and is directed by Will Gluck.
Bea and Ben just happen to meet eachother by chance in a coffee shop and immediately gain a liking for eachother. They spend an evening together but in the morning due to some crossed wires they go their separate ways with a dislike for eachother. Cut to six months later and Bea's sister happens to be getting married to one of Bens friends and so they find themselves stuck in eachothers way. This initially causes conflict that is until both characters realise it may be advantageous to both of them to pretend to like eachother.
What follows is a mediocre romantic comedy with overall likeable characters but with only a few laughs. Don't get me wrong I know comedy is a really difficult genre as humour is so subjective. I just felt that this film didn't even really try thinking outside the box when it came to its jokes. Yes there's the expected typical sex jokes that always get a light chuckle out of most audiences however it's nothing you haven't heard/seen before.
The film to me seemed to try to sell itself on the sole basis of having an attractive cast. It then goes a step further and has its cast appear in various forms of undress throughout the film. Sydney Sweeney almost always has a fair amount of cleavage showing for instance. Don't worry though ladies there's plenty of abs and men's bums too. It all just felt like a distraction though to a story that's about as generic as they come. A nice distraction but a distraction nonetheless.
Just fine.

This is one of the funniest movies I've seen in a long time! There were multiple times throughout I laughed so hard that I almost peed my pants, but I wouldn't leave to go to the bathroom because I didn't want to miss anything. The two leads had such good chemistry and I think that is what drove me to be so attached to this movie. Much like a Hallmark movie, it was pretty predictable, you knew they were gonna end up together but of course there had to be some type of miscommunication to drive them apart so they could come back together in a super romantic gesture. Stereotypical? Yes. But made it super fun to watch? Also yes. I think it also helped that the two leads are incredibly attractive. As I left the theater I decided I would absolutely buy this movie when it comes out because I already want to watch again. Highlt recommend if you're in need of a fun rom com to put you in a good mood!

I almost didn't see this movie because I was sick of how much they were marketing it, but I miss rom-coms and haven't seen a good one in a while.\nThis movie was hard to get through. Sydney and Glenn both have unique but odd looks to. Me, they kind of have chemistry, but I almost feel like this movie could have been better with two different leads. Sydney Is good with supporting roles but she's not lead material imo and it's physically uncomfortable to watch her try way too hard to be sexy. I think I read another comment about this in a review and I've always thought she tries to be something she isn't.\nThe dialogue is okay, but I don't remember much, and overall, I don't love how predictable the movie is. Obviously, some rom coms can be but they're still fun to see how it pans out, but this movie was terrible. I miss old rom-coms from the early 2000s like Notting Hill, Love Actually, and a Cinderella Story. Anyone But You was awkward, kind of forgettable, and only had maybe 1 scene that was kind of interesting.

The trailer and marketing for this movie put me off, but when I heard it was loosely based off Much Ado About Nothing and heard good things, we decided to check it out.
Really glad we did. There was plenty of laugh out loud moments, quick moving plot, a range of characters and their connections to one another, and all in all just a bit of fun.
It is a Romcom, so like you would expect of the genre, you know where it is going to end up but it was an enjoyable ride getting there. Do get frustrated with people expecting this genre to "be better", but this delivers everything you would want it to.
Definitely recommend as a cheesy date night or a girls night out!

One of the better adaptations of a Shakespeare play. Both faithful to the original text and reinvigorated by a modern twist. I wish there had been an "Against my will I am sent to bid you come into dinner" scene as that is iconic. I am fascinated with how they adapted the "Ado" in that is ended up not really having anything to do with H+C. It did feel like the Jonathan/Don John part was a little thin and perhaps was at one point more substantial, but to be fair it is one of the least motivated villains in Shakespeare so perhaps that tracks. Highlights would be the adaptation of Beau/Borachio and that the name of the bakery is Dogberry.

Directed and co-written by Will Gluck. A runtime of one hour and forty-three minutes. With an R rating.
"Bea" played by Sydney Sweeney is at a crossroads in life. By chance, she runs into "Ben" played by Glen Powell at a coffee shop. After this odd encounter between the two, they hit it off. This turns into a magical date with them falling asleep in each other's arms.
You would think from there they hit it off. But they both make major mistakes. "Bea" leaving in the morning never communicating with "Ben". With "Ben" putting his foot in his mouth and "Bea" hearing a convo between "Ben" and his best friend "Pete" played by Gata. Who you might remember from the show "Dave".
After some time apart they meet again under unusual circumstances. Turns out "Ben" is friends with "Bea" sister "Halle" played by Hadley Robinson. "Ben" best friend sister "Claudia" played by Alexandra Shipp is marrying "Halle", "Bea" sister. It is a little strange that they never met each other before since their friend group/ family is so close. It's cool you're not supposed to think about that.
"Claudia" parents "Roger" played by Bryan Brown and "Carol" played by Michelle Hurd invite everyone to Australia for the wedding. "Bea" helicopter parents "Leo" played by Dermot Mulroney and "Innie" played by Rachel Griffiths do their own inviting as well. They invite "Bea" ex "Jonathan" played by Darren Barnet. In hopes they get back together.
Also on this trip are "Ben" ex "Margaret" played by Charlee Fraser. She brought her Diet "Thor" Aussie fling "Beau" played by Joe Davidson. So you see a lot is going on and a lot of emotions riding high.
"Bea" and "Ben" come up with a master
plan to fake like they're in love to get what they want from their old lovers. Sometimes when you're faking it, real feelings can start to form and join the party. Watch and see how this all unfolds in one of the most beautiful but dangerous places on Earth. Australia.
"Anyone But You" was a good romantic comedy. It was funny and it played into the obvious. Their looks. Lots of eye candy and ridiculous but funny scenes.
The only thing I gave some pushback on was that the ending was a little over the top. Other than that I enjoyed it. I saw it with my adult daughter. It's a little racee but nothing that crazy. If you've read my previous work you know I'm not the biggest Romcom guy. But this one was entertaining and one of the good ones. Giving you a healthy dosage of the room and the com. I give four mor fires ðŸ”¥ðŸ”¥ðŸ”¥ðŸ”¥.
