Anyone But You is exactly what you think it's going to be. No more or less. Therefore, if you watched the trailer for this movie and were completely uninterested in what you saw, then there's nothing in here that you're going to find engaging. However, if you watched the trailer and felt that it could be a simple fun romantic comedy with no attempted depth or deeper themes, then you're going to find exactly what you're looking for. Your experience is entirely predicted upon how you feel going into the film.
As far as the execution goes, it's fine. Perhaps 50 - 60% of the jokes land, the storyline of "enemies turned lovers" has been done for ages. And of course, as with all romantic-comedies, the story is completely predictable and fundamentally formulaic.
The aspects I felt standout the most is the performances of Sydney Sweeney and Glen Powell. Their chemistry is noticeably palpable throughout the movie, and it's their charming charisma and wholesome synergy that carries this film through. I'll be honest, without them, I wouldn't give this movie a second thought. But they really add the star-power necessary to make this film worth while.
Overall, as stated previously, this movie is exactly how you think it's going to be. If you're uninterested in this film, you're not going to find anything to like. But if the trailers got you excited, you're probably going to have fun. Personally, I had a good time watching it. It was energetic, charismatic, and overall a delightful experience.

Set ( mostly) in sunny Australia, while most likely viewers are suffering mid-winter blues, the film will be uplifting for the weather and scenery alone. The lead characters have good chemistry, trying to put on a show of being together, leaving the audience unsure of what is real and what is faked.\nPlenty of romance and comedy, as well as the awkwardness that comes from the situation.\nNot much else to say, it was a spur of the moment decision to see it, and it helped to take my mind off the relentless rain. It is 15 rating for language, though there was nothing worse than the F-word ; and some nudity, though the male nudity is played for laughs.

A terrific romantic comedy -The R rating implies one should have a grown-up brain & be able to accept light nudity and playful/sexy banter. We know not everybody is in that place, so parents of young teens could get squirmy. The witty dialogue was, yes, saucy at times, but that was the point --they could banter!! The chemistry of the cast is great and it overcomes that concern. My husband and I laughed throughout and enjoyed being hopeful for the young couple. Aaaaand the eye-candy was delightful. The beauty of the location in Sydney Australia is great. I just wish when the Ben referred to his night in the water in the Cayman Islands he would have had a throw-away line like "Never doin' that again--" Overall, Shakespeare would have approved seeing new life springing forth from one of his favorite comedies. Thank you Cast, crew and writers.

I hadn't heard about this movie. We watched it on a date night. I was really surprised by how much I liked it. It was hilarious! Don't get offended by the language. Our group all recommend it. I only knew the main actor from Top Gun. I didn't recognize the main actress. The movie is based off of Shakespeare's "Much Ado About Nothing" and there are several slight references to the original story. There are several small characters who almost steal the show. The Aussie surfer dude cracked us up! We have to watch it again to remember all the things he called his manhood. I only remember "the anteater". Enjoy the laughs!

Yorgos Lanthimos is continuing to do a great job of maintaining a singular style while also doing something different with each new film he makes. I don't necessarily agree with the people who say Wes Anderson sticks to his style too much, but if Lanthimos keeps taking further creative risks the way he's been doing, I don't imagine many people will ever accuse him of a such a thing.\nPlot-wise, Poor Things is sort of a coming-of-age story, but in a way that's not only hard to describe, but probably better off not describing. The premise is actually kind of similar to the weird Australian cult classic Bad Boy Bubby: we spend a decent amount of time with someone who l has the appearance of an adult but a mind like that of a child, remains trapped in a single location, and then after about 20-30 minutes, they're let out into the world, with all its surprises, wonders, and horrors. Narratively there are similarities, and both films also have some very let's say graphic content, but visually and tonally, they're pretty different.\nPoor Things might be a tad too long. I at first thought Willem Dafoe's continued presence in the story was hurting the pacing, but I like the direction his character went in, by the end. I think the last 20 minutes hurts the overall film, though. A character emerges who it makes sense should emerge, but they spend a weird amount of time on him and it's mostly a detour before things reach an otherwise satisfying conclusion. That sequence aside, I liked this film a lot. It looks amazing, it's very funny in parts, and Emma Stone is excellent. It also might have my favourite performance Mark Ruffalo's ever given, too.

Poor things is directed by Yorgos Lanthimos (The Lobster, The Killing of a Sacred Deer) and is supported with a strong cast, namely Emma Stone, Mark Ruffalo and Willem Dafoe.
The first impression you get from this movie is bizarre to say the least. In fact, it takes some time to get used to the ambiance which is nothing short of macabre. And surely, this impression lasts throughout the whole movie; but this feeling of weirdness and incomprehension serves the plot and in this sense, is most welcome. Eventually, there comes a time where, inevitably, and without even realizing it, you are suctioned right in, never to escape again. And you are glad to be trapped in what is essentially pit of limitless pleasure.
Indeed, one of the things the movie does very well is make you, along with the protagonist, embark on an adventure. Sure, you might have been to the places the protagonist went to, but those are presented in a most wonderful way. The aesthetics are magnificient and otherworldly. I do not know how they did it, but I remember being in awe and it is a feeling that I will cherish for a lifetime. It is truly a sight to behold.
It is the kind of movie which makes you feel grateful to be alive.

I remain disappointed by 'Poor Things' as it felt like an uncontrolled movie. Over-eating, over-sexed, under-sensual, truncated history, creepy, downright nasty, discordantly loud and under-delivered, hacked, sliced up, degraded and shot. Messy, too long. People, script and movie.
There, I've said it.
All the fine actors did their best as highly regarded professionals but, in the back of my mind, I sense the end result would be underwhelming to those involved and out there promoting something that didn't quite work.
Superb costumes, lavish indulgent sets, a bit of basic philosophy thrown in, lots of good stuff but doesn't feel original.

I find Yorgos Lanthimos to be a fascinating filmmaker, although I must confess that I've not really loved any of his movies. They are usually quite sharp in their social observations, and quite funny in individual moments, but also quite long, and ultimately pitch-black in their finales. Dogtooth, The Lobster, and The Favourite all fit this description, while The Killing of a Sacred Deer is more of a horror film, and a truly chilling one at that.
Poor Things, then, ranks as Lanthimos's most cheerful and life-affirming movie - even if it's also cheeky, perverse, and sharp enough to cut glass. Furthermore, it's Lanthimos' most technically accomplished film; where his earlier works set their absurdist storylines against neo-realist backdrops, this one is awash in a highly eccentric, fever-dream version of the Steampunk aesthetic -- an alternate-universe version of Victorian Europe, where odd scientific advancements co-exist with weird and colorful twists on that era's fashions and social customs.
Emma Stone (La La Land) leads this Frankenstein-like tale - (or should that be "Bride of Frankenstein?") - in which a deceased woman has been brought back to life with the mind of an infant. This miracle of science has been performed by the hideously disfigured Dr. Godwin Baxter (Willem Dafoe). He has named her Bella, and he has paternal feelings for her. She toddles awkwardly, caws in monosyllables, and calls him God.
Because he cannot watch Bella constantly, Dr. Baxter hires one of his medical apprentices -- Max McCandles -- to attend to her, and to "record her progress." Max is a gentle and naive young man, and this makes him a good match for Bella, for whom Max is the only man she has ever known, besides Godwin.
And so, progress Bella does -- up to a point. But things get complicated when another man enters the picture, and Bella discovers the pull of sexual desire.
Boy, is this film interested in sexual desire -- the odd comedy of it, the way in which it complicates us, the strange kind of power that it holds, the absurd way in which it undercuts our most evolved notions about ourselves. Neither Lanthimos nor his actors are shy about this aspect of the film, and although I wouldn't exactly call the movie "titillating" -- as its many sex-scenes feel more satirical than sexy -- there's plenty here to make a Puritan blush. If you couple the notion of Bella's sexual awakening with the notion that she is LITERALLY a 5 or 6-year-old in a grown woman's body, there emerge some very icky undertones that the film is very aware of.
This leads to my one major misgiving about this film, which is the fact that much of its comedy co-exists with some pretty queasy undercurrents. The film's awareness of this won't excuse it for all viewers -- but, as one character humorously observes: "All sexuality is immoral."
And ultimately, there is much more to this film than I've yet described. Bella's hunger for worldly experience leads her to philosophy and social-causes, just as readily as it leads her toward other men, and toward the realization that many of those who claim to love her simply want to exert ownership over her.
The basic storyline of this film has much in common with Pygmalion, the George Bernard Shaw play which was later remade as a musical, "My Fair Lady." All are stories about women who are "made by" men -- men who are then spurned when they realize they cannot own what they feel they have created. But Lanthimos and his crew made this story resonate, for me, much more than those earlier versions of this tale ever did. And it must be said, the kind of imagination and technical wizardry that they brought to the visuals -- and to the idiosyncratic use of music, which I could write a separate essay about -- really breathed the stuff of life into this telling.
Of course, Emma Stone's performance as Bella deserves special mention. The film required a certain special magic to make this character work. At its worst, a character like Bella might have come across as another groan-inducing portrait of a mentally-disabled person by a non-disabled actor. But Stone locates a real sense of childlike wonder and chaos within Bella in those early scenes. In the way she walks, in her strange shifts of mood, her sudden outbursts of violence followed by giggles, we do get a very real sense of what it might be like to be a toddler coming to grips with a grown woman's body.
As Bella learns and matures through her experiences, the way Stone modulates her performance, and gradually refines her body-language and manner of speech -- well, it's so subtle you almost don't notice, until suddenly you realize that Bella has been speaking full and intelligent sentences for awhile, and that she no longer walks like a toddler, and you can't quite recall the moment where that transition happened.
By the ending of the film, Bella has become an incredibly unique and memorable character, and much unlikely poetry (and stinging comedy) has been revealed through her journey.

A unique and artistic film which will elicit strong opinions on both sides: viewers will tend to love it or hate it. Leaving the theatre, I was reminded of how I felt when I saw Everything Everywhere All at Once, another highly unusual film which became the darling of film critics everywhere. In both cases I kept asking myself "what did I just watch??". Poor Things is inventive, stylish, well acted, but most of all, highly sexualized. Unfortunately it is also repetitive, too long, and a little too bizarre at times. The film asks a lot from its audience- from accepting the Frankenstein premise, to stomaching deliberate shots of corpses and internal organs, and to revel in the heroine's sexual episodes as they seem key to her journey of self discovery. But the biggest fault lies with Emma Stone's character. The strong sympathy you feel in the first half of the film when she is a pitiful "child" turns to apathy as her character "matures" into an annoying, self centered woman. They were aiming for strong and independent, but she just isn't likable enough for the viewer to be emotionally invested by the time the movie ends. The ending feels flat which is ironic giving that there were several "climax" scenes earlier in the film.

First of all it is stunningly beautiful. (Perhaps hints of The Science of Sleep, 1984, Brazil, Angels and Insects, and Alejandro Jodorowsky for sure) The sets are beyond dreamlike and the costuming may be perfect. The movie holds you at arms length where this other world constantly surprises and amazes you. Stunning performances by all. And the writing is superb. Emma Stone's evolution is ours and Willem Defoe is brilliant as usual and even this tortured soul evolves. And if you like revenge films this also may be your new favorite. It's a roller coaster of emotion and so beautiful you will cry. Let it take you there.

As of the most critically acclaimed movies released last year, Yorgos Lanthimos' adaptation of Alasdair Grey's darkly comedic novel Poor Things has been a top contender. Starring the likes of Emma Stone, Mark Ruffalo, Willem Dafoe, Ramy Youssef, etc, the film has been regarded as one of the finest cinematic achievements in 2023 and the winner of the Golden Lion at the most recent Venice Film Festival. So with a lot of talent onboard this strange project, it's time to kickstart the new year with a look back at one of the top choices for recommendation as far as last year is concerned.
The film focuses on a young Victorian woman named Bella Baxter, who was crudely resurrected by scientific surgeon Godwin Baxter following an attempted suicide. By means of discovering who she is internally and externally, Bella runs off with a debauched lawyer and experiences the world through a new lens. As this film could be seen as a modernized Frankenstein narrative with personal introspection, Poor Things is ultimately carried by Bella's ongoing mental development. While the film's commentary on female empowerment triumphing over sexual pleasure may be a bit misguided, it's through her own growth as a resurrected soul that makes Bella as sympathetic as she is irritating. Tony McNamara's dialogue heavy screenplay is lifted thanks in part to Emma Stone portraying Bella as simultaneously emotional and robotic, almost like we're seeing the human embodiment of AI figuring themselves out in a world that's foreign to them. It has a lot of dark comedy sprinkled throughout its runtime, but this tale of self reflection from reincarnation remains unique for all the right reasons.
Alongside Stone, the cast embrace their roles with raw passion and over the top pseudo realism, at least when they have proper screen time. While Godwin and his assistant Max McCandles care a lot about Bella in spite of their refusal for her to live a life of free will based on fear, they often don't leave as much of an impact as the people Bella breaks mentally. The biggest example would be lawyer Duncan Wedderburn, whose cunning affection towards Bella gets trampled by her constant switches from sex craved to intellectual babble, and Mark Ruffalo captures the character's worsening mental state to such a delightfully pitiful degree. Other than those few, most of the remaining cast merely come up whenever the story calls for Bella to experience different perspectives, and yet even the smallest role could make a strong impression, from bored socialites to empathetic prostitutes. With such a diverse range of fascinating characters for the main protagonist to learn from, any viewer may walk away with at least one notable player worth remembering for their eccentricities alone.
Now admittedly, some of the filmmaking qualities feel fairly mixed in the long run. On one hand, the set and costume design are gorgeously detailed and crafted with such splendor that anyplace Bella goes through feels like a surreal dream anyone can step into. That being said, the decision to execute much of the third act in black & white would have been more impactful if the film still kept certain scenes throughout transitioning from monochrome to saturated, since the change feels a bit too abrupt for its own good. Also, as impressive as the visual effects are in depicting so many different scientific creatures, some shots with a noticeably garish color scheme feel out of place in what is ultimately a comedically grim feature. However, perhaps the film;s finest achievement in embracing its frightening atmosphere is the score by Jerskin Fendrix, which gets so spine tingling and nerve wracking that even the most unphased viewer could feel turned off. Some of the production values may work better than others, but they still remind us that we're in a surreal sci fi fantasy unlike any other.
As internally self reflective as it is wildly imaginative, Poor Things is one of the finest works of Yorgos Lanthimos' career. Its bizarre nature may not be up everyone's alley, but since this film is still playing in theaters as of now, it truly must be seen in order to be believed. What seems like a weird take on examining one's life is far more outrageous and fascinating than meets the eye, and here's hoping that the film will be a top contender once the primary American award shows come about. For a movie with poor in the title, it is surprisingly a lot richer in content compared to what some may say otherwise.

Do you ever come out of a movie theater and think, when can I watch this movie again?!? This was an absolute masterpiece. Yorgos, Emma and Mark have created a world you will not want to escape from.
Bella's story starts in a dark place and moves into adventure, wonder, joy and perseverance.
It's a brilliantly crafted movie with so many layers and nuances. Her world is mesmerizing and you just want to become part of it.
The last chapter is the big twist and suddenly the genre changes and this comedic melodrama becomes a horror film. It felt that for the last 10 minutes everything and everyone was at risk.

I used to think no movie could ever be worse than Priscilla. But I was very wrong.
It was so bad we walked out of the theater. I've never walked out of a theater in my life because it isn't cheap to go to the movies. But we seriously could not take one more disgusting, pointless sex scene. Because that's all the movie consisted of past like the first 20 minutes.
We thought it would be good in the beginning because the story seemed low key interesting! But they forgot about that plot and turned toward disgusting, way too long sex scenes. It was literal torture as someone who ain't down for that stuff. It had potential to be a cool story.
Needless to say we were relieved upon leaving the room where that bs was going on. Do not watch this.

A superb story, ruined by the hugely inexplicable decision to not even acknowledge the city in which it was created. It would be more appropriate, relevant, and respectful if it was filmed, or even just implied, where it was meant to be. I'd imagine that most people who have the save levels of comprehension would have a similar view; Gray has been, generally, a local hero that we recognise but others refuse to acknowledge. This would be akin to The Krays being set in Moscow tbh, or Gangs of New York being filmed in Anchorage.\nStill, it's an excellent movie in its own right. It's not for everyone, we'll leave that to Finding NemoðŸ‘

Very disappointing. Sad that so many movies contain graphic sex scenes which gets guys to watch but requires no writing talent at all. Would have loved a movie simply focusing on Hugh Grants character. The rest was filthy talk and even graphic sex scenes. People can get that garbage at a porno web site. Takes no talent at all to write that type script whatsoever. It will get you good ratings however. Should've been named "Lewd Actually" or "Lust Actually". Sad commentary on today's devastated families through divorce because of lifestyles portrayed in this piece of trash movie. I give it 3 stars only because of Hugh Grants character.

Love Actually falls short as a good movie, presenting itself as an anthology of different stories with pieces connecting them. While there might be some likable elements in each story, it's a written mess carried by its actors, whom you might only watch because you appreciate their work outside of this film. They deliver an okay performance, but the lack of substantial material limits their impact. For a film exploring different types and ways of love, every story feels incredibly shallow, featuring characters making stupid decisions without much payoff. Despite being a Christmas film with entertaining actors, the overall lack of meaningful events may leave you questioning whether it was worth watching. It's a divisive film, and while some may really hate it or love it, I land on the 'do not care' side of the reception for this film.

Love actually is all around on Christmas. "Love, actually" is a very British comedy about love on Christmas, and the magic of Christmas and the spirit of Christmas. It's a really clever idea of having many small and completely different stories being the focus of this movie because love comes in different kinds. The clever thing is that somehow all these stories do interact woth each other but each and every one of them serves its own purpose. Emma Thompson I think speaks to the hearts of many women around the globe, and her performance is very poignant and raw and real. Hugh Grant's story is here to remind us of Clinton and Lewinsky. And Keira Knightley of course steals the hearts of many once again. Some very iconic scenes, some great pop-culture moments and a ridiculous song and performance by a great Bill Nighy. "Love, actually" is unapologetically British and absolutely ridiculous and bonkers and I love it. A perfect holiday movie.

Rating: 7.7\nOverall, an enjoyable Christmas movie that is carried by its writing and performances as we get to see the unique concept of multiple storylines happening in parallel with their common goal of finding love, though it is a bit bloated from having too many subplots and suffers from many Rom-Com and early 2000s cliches.\nPretty Good Direction (The direction on a macroscale is pretty good as he connects the different storylines into one overarching plot (though the world-building felt very typical to other Rom-Coms); the direction on a microscale was pretty typical to other Rom-Coms (though executed well); the direction of actors was good as it felt like everyone was connected and gave a performance that helped move the movie forward; the storytelling was pretty unique as it juggles multiple different subplots that converge to a giant ending), Pretty Good to Good Acting (Good from Hugh Grant (Uses his charm, charisma, and experience in romantic movies to aid his performance), Good from Liam Neeson (My favorite performance in the cast as he develops a strong chemistry with his son and effectively displays grief from the loss of his wife), Pretty Good from Colin Firth (Uses his experience in romantic movies to propel this performance forward), Pretty Good from Laura Linney (Felt a bit out of place, but does well in the scenes she is in), Good from Emma Thompson (Shows betrayal well and has a good range of emotion throughout the movie), Pretty Good to Good from Alan Rickman (A surprisingly comedic performance from Rickman, but he holds his own well and shows some range of emotion (at least however much he can with his mundane voice)), Pretty Good from Keira Knightley (Really just a name as she isn't given that much screen time (but still does a pretty good job with the scenes she is in)), Pretty Good from Martine McCutcheon (Works well off of Grant), Pretty Good from Bill Nighy (A very over-the-top performance that provides humor in his non-sequitur scenes), Pretty Good from Rowan Atkinson (Mr Bean), Pretty Good from LÃºcia Moniz (Has chemistry with Colin Firth), Pretty Good from the rest of the cast (Everyone plays their role well as this movie is more about an ensemble cast than a singular performance)), Good Story (The concept was very unique as the different storylines converging to one was a pretty new idea at the time (though it was heavily exploited after), there are a little too many stories (maybe could have cut the 1-2 of them to make the movie a bit tighter); the plot structure was very unique as it was multiple storylines converging to one climax (though there are some other climaxes as not all the storylines converge to the same point); flow between sequences was surprisingly good as the transitions between the different stories were seamless at times (using music and characters); character writing was good as you get a sense of what each character's struggle was and what they are looking for during the holiday season), Good Screenplay (The dialogue was pretty good and flowed well (but did have cliche Rom-Com lines); the movie has some very iconic scenes that were parodied/referenced in other forms of media; the humor was good (though did feel very 00s); the symbolism was kinda light (but its a Rom-Com so I cannot complain that much); the foreshadowing was very good as it was used effectively to help connect the different storylines together), Pretty Good Score/Pretty Good Soundtrack (Helps set the Christmas tone), Decent Cinematography, Decent Sound, Good Editing (Helps with transitioning between the different stories), Pacing was pretty good as it did not feel very slow or fast, Climax was executed well as it converges many of the storylines to one singular event (and the climaxes of the other storylines were also handled well), Tone felt exactly was the genre was (A Christmas, Rom-Com)

When it comes to love, we find it comes in many forms and in mysterious ways. Showcasing the truest bits of love found in everyday life, Love Actually gives us multiple stories of a human struggle. Starting off a bit slow, the individual relationships are all fleshed out distinctly and create a very unique and charming tale. While each story is fairly entertaining, some of them are worth more emotional investment, leaving others feeling like perfect bathroom breaks. Although it isn't perfect, it all comes together in a beautiful ensemble in the end. Complete with an all star cast, this film is an English 'Who's Who' of celebrities, each adding a cute and fun performance to their story. It is fun getting to see these big actors interacting in such quirky ways and taking on roles that are delightfully unexpected. Love Actually takes us on a very real and human journey through the love and lives of different individuals, reminding us that it comes we are all just people, in need of love.

When you think of the word "love", what words come to your mind? Maybe it is lust, attraction and sex? Maybe it is sharing sweet and romantic moments together? Or maybe it is unbridled faithfulness and devotion over time? This movie explores all of these aspects of love and more.\nInterwoven within this movie are stories of people from all walks of life from the young to the old. Each person explores a facet of love like a diamond glistening brightly reflecting its light and beauty in various different ways. E.g. We see those pure moments where time seemingly slows down as a person is enraptured by someone else for the first time. We also see how power can influence and potentially corrupt the dynamic of people in romantic relationships e.g. Superiors and subordinates. The film showcases the joy of couples getting married whilst also showing the sorrows of unrequited love. The film also examines the themes of dating, casual relationships, and temptation in the face of faithfulness.\nLove Actually is an enjoyable film that is funny, lighthearted, sentimental, and romantic. It will appeal to people of all ages who want to experience vicariously what it means to be in love. This film will surely bring you and your loved one into a romantic mood by the end. It is an instant classic rom-com and well worth the watch! Highly recommended!

Love Actually, a film that has garnered praise for its star-studded cast and holiday charm, presents a mixed bag of emotions for viewers seeking a fresh take on romance. While the ensemble cast brings familiar faces to the screen, the movie's reliance on well-worn romantic clichÃ©s and its struggle to provide depth to its characters raise questions about its lasting impact.
One of the noticeable aspects of Love Actually is its abundant use of romantic tropes. From the shy confessions of unspoken love to the grand gestures that seem to conveniently unfold, the film embraces these clichÃ©s with open arms. While some may argue that familiarity is part of the charm, it leaves others, like myself, wanting more substance and originality. The predictability of the plotlines undermines the potential for genuine surprises and emotional resonance.
The ensemble cast, featuring notable actors such as Hugh Grant, Emma Thompson, and Colin Firth, is undoubtedly one of the film's selling points. However, the star power fails to translate into compelling characters. The individuals portrayed often lack the depth needed to make their romantic journeys truly engaging. It becomes a parade of famous faces navigating through storylines that, despite their potential, feel one-dimensional and fail to establish a meaningful connection with the audience.
Love Actually attempts to explore the multifaceted nature of love by intertwining various storylines. Yet, this ambitious approach results in pacing issues that hinder the overall viewing experience. The transitions between scenes can feel abrupt, making it challenging for viewers to fully immerse themselves in the unfolding narratives. As a result, the film struggles to build and sustain emotional intensity, leaving moments that should resonate feeling disconnected.
While the film aims to capture the complexity of love, certain relationships portrayed in Love Actually border on the improbable. From workplace romances that seem far-fetched to connections between characters that lack authenticity, the film's exploration of love often ventures into the realm of fantasy rather than genuine human experience. This contributes to a sense of detachment from the characters and their romantic entanglements.
Pacing is a recurring issue in Love Actually, and it reflects the film's attempt to balance a multitude of storylines. The constant shift between characters and scenarios prevents the audience from fully investing in any particular narrative. The lack of a cohesive rhythm undermines the impact of individual moments, leaving the viewer with a fragmented sense of the overall story.
In addition to pacing concerns, Love Actually faces criticism for its occasional missteps in portraying relationships. Some character dynamics perpetuate stereotypes and reinforce gender norms, raising questions about the film's cultural sensitivity. While the intent may be lighthearted, these elements detract from the authenticity the film aims to capture.
In conclusion, Love Actually, with its star-studded ensemble and holiday charm, falls short of expectations due to its reliance on romantic clichÃ©s, pacing issues, and occasional problematic portrayals of relationships. While it has its moments of levity and charm, the overall experience is hindered by a lack of originality and depth. For those seeking a fresh take on romance, Love Actually may leave you wanting, as it navigates the terrain of well-trodden clichÃ©s without breaking new ground.

Alright, so here's the real deal about "Love Actually." It's a mess, mate. I mean, they chucked in a boatload of big-name actors, thinking that's all it takes to make a killer rom-com, but nah, it's like they just threw a bunch of random love stories into a blender and hoped for the best.
First off, the plot is all over the place. You've got like, what, a million different stories going on? It's like the filmmakers couldn't decide on one good story, so they just went, "Ah, let's do 'em all!" The result? A confusing mishmash that's hard to follow. You barely get to know one couple, and whoosh, it's onto the next.
The characters, man, they're like cardboard cutouts. There's little depth, and most of 'em are walking clichÃ©s. You've got your typical lovesick puppy, the guy who's pining for his best mate's wife (creepy, much?), and don't get me started on the whole American girls falling for the bumbling Brit thing. It's like they picked the most stereotypical traits and ran with it.
And the humor? It tries way too hard. Some of the jokes are just cringey. It's like, we get it, you're trying to be funny and quirky, but it falls flat most of the time. Feels like they're trying to shove the laughs down your throat.
The thing about "Love Actually" is, it's trying to sell this fairy-tale version of love, but it's so out of touch. It's like a bunch of unrealistic, soppy stories mashed together. And don't get me started on how it handles serious stuff like cheating. It's all glossed over with a cutesy bow.
Visually, it's nothing special either. The whole thing just screams average. Sure, there are a couple of catchy songs, but that's not enough to save this trainwreck.
So, in a nutshell, "Love Actually" is a hot mess. It's trying to be this big, warm-fuzzy, feel-good movie, but it's more like a cheesy, try-hard flick that's bitten off more than it can chew. If you're looking for a solid rom-com, this ain't it, chief.

Loved Actually is a 2003 Romantic/Comedy/Drama set around Christmas time. The film has many storylines that encompasses multiple characters during it's 2 hour+ run time who are searching for love. While I enjoyed jumping into one characters story to the next it can sometimes be a jumble mess which requires alot of patience on the audience who is watcing. There are a lot of big name celeberities in this film from Hugh Grant, Liam Neeson, and Andrew Lincoln to name a few. If you really enjoy a good romantic Christmas movie then you need to check out Love Actually. Love Actually gets a very solid 8 stars out of 10 from.

With Christmas 2023 I finally got around to watching Love Actually. And I have to say it's a fun, endearing, silly and a few touchingly sad moments that make for an enjoyable, if somewhat long, movie well worth seeing.\nEach of the individual storylines moved a long quickly with some being better developed than others. The best developed plot was the one involving Alan Rickman and Emma Thompson. The Hugh Grant one was silly yet fun. Liam Neeson and the kid from so many movies and TV shows back then was good. The Keira Knightley one was poignant yet unbelievable. The Colin Firth one was also unbelievable yet was so sappy and heartwarming. The whole Bill Nighy aging rocker plot line was a hoot. And the two storylines about the movie stand ins and the chav going to America were cute yet forgettable. Best of all was the one about Laura Linney's distant longing for a colleague that eventually comes to pass, yet not as might have been imagined. That one will stick with me as so touching.\nAddendum 12/26/23. Reading various reviews and critiques of Love Actually, many are trashing it for being superficial and misogynistic. And yes, there are elements of both in a number of the storylines. The Knightley-Lincoln one was the worst for this, especially with the creepy wedding video. Yet, I found the two best storylines and also the most heartfelt to be those with Emma Thompson and Laura Linney. The first a mother f two young children dealing with a straying husband. The second a single woman trying to start a relationship while also dealing with family issues. Could both characters have been more 'empowered'? Of course. And yet, that's not the way relationships and the world actually work most of the time. To me, both storylines and both actresses gave stellar performances showing a side of life that isn't always about a happy ending.

The plot is fairly simple but provides a great foundation for an adventure full of laughs. Macaulay Culkin shines as brightly as it gets and is the main reason for the movie's success, while the duo of Joe Pesci and Daniel Stern add the right amount of goofiness and showcase incredible chemistry. Excellent score by John Williams as well.\nHowever, specifics don't matter that much. The major achievement of this movie is that it perfectly captures the Christmas spirit, it's hard to imagine Christmas without Home Alone, watching it has become sort of a family tradition for me - and I know I'm not the only one. It's quite possibly the only movie I've watched so many times, yet it never gets old.

"Home Alone" is already a New Year's classic. I am writing a review a few hours before the New Year 2024, the time is more suitable than ever!
The film is a comedy, the action takes place, as it is clear, on Christmas Eve, the idea is quite original, the actors also did their job well.
I also want to say that I am not an ardent fan of this movie and do not watch it every New Year, but it is worth recognizing the cult significance and overall interest of the plot of "Home Alone".
I would recommend watching this movie at least once in a New Year's mood to feel the rush of the atmosphere. It's worth it!
My rating : 7.5/10.

A late merry Christmas from me, and I hope everyone had a nice Christmas in general. It's time to watch the same 5 movies as always because tradition, but let me be honest, I might skip this one next year.
Home Alone is a concept that screams Chris Columbus, since it's an amazing child fantasy. He has always been the master of that, creating the scenarios that speak to an inner child in you, imagining that you, in this case, were home alone owning the house, doing whatever you wanted. But after rewatching it for the millionth time, the magic has worn off, as per usual when it comes to me and Columbus movies. Maybe it's me seeing more and more small things I don't like, and repeatedly seeing them just makes me want to skip to the best parts of the movie. This is still a movie I hold dear but for the future, it can run in the background.
Kevin is a young boy in a big family, and after they forget to bring him for the Christmas getaway, he is left home alone. This is nice for Kevin, however some thieves might ruin this Christmas for him.
What this movie drives on is its concept. It's the ultimate childhood dream to be left alone and do whatever you wanted to. Chris Columbus captures the childhood wonder and fun perfectly, and Macaulay CulkinÂ´s kids charm carries the vision. Eating whatever you want, seeing whatever you want, fight off bad guys, it's a kid's wish come true. This together with the heart is incredible. The movie has these really heartfelt speeches and conversations and combines it with humor to really make a fully rounded movie.
But I must admit, it feels like a slow movie, basically because it's a concept film before a plot one. The movie goes from scenario to scenario without much connection, and the loose storytelling just doesn't speak to me. I don't know what the movie tries to do half the time, and the first half doesn't really connect with the later
The acting is also a bit all over the place. While the charm of Macaulay Culkin is wonderful in this movie, the over acting doesn't really speak to me, with very repetitive gags like the scream done too many times. The standout here is the acting of Joe Pesci and the comedic timing of Daniel Stern. The later physical comedy and the comedic parring of the two really carries this movie.
Course, while I find it fun what Kevin is doing in the first half, I just wait for the house invasion. That is the best part of the movie, proving that physical comedy still is amazing when done to perfection.
The score is pretty good, but that's no surprise coming from my favorite composer, John Williams. It is a bit all over the place, but so is the movie. He captures every emotion perfectly here.
This is a good movie to me, but a lot of empty calories and just entertainment. It don't do more than that. As per usual when it domes to Chris Columbus movies, the concept, and its elements are childhood perfection and captures the essence of having fun as a kid, but creating a strong story and doing something with the concepts are always lacking. This is a classic, and I'll watch it again no doubt, but maybe from a distance next time.

Oh, Home Alone. It's' a Christmas classic and for good reason. This film is a tale of two halves: the first is about a naughty boy who thinks his family disappeared, the second is the brutal beatdown that he gives to a couple of burglars. I find a lot of enjoyment during both parts of the narrative. Kevin's gradual regret about his "Christmas wish" is tender to watch, specifically when it comes to the relationship with his mother.
The humor in this movie is phenomenal. From the destruction of Buzz's room to Kevin's quippy remarks at the grocery store,
Macaulay Culkin crushes his performance. Across the board, one of my favorite Christmas movies of all time, even though I like the 2nd one more.
Best Character: Kevin
Best Quote: "I'm gonna give you to the count of 10, to get your ugly, yella, no-good keister off my property before I pump your guts full of lead!" - Johnny
Best Scene: Facing Harry and Marv
Best Piece of Score: "Somewhere in my Memory"

While celebrating the holidays, classic Christmas films are a surefire way to set the mood and make spirits bright. Capturing the holiday cheer, Home Alone has been a definitive film of the season for over 30 years. With Macaulay Culkin taking on his most iconic role as Kevin McCallister, it is undeniable how charming and talented he is, especially for a child actor. Although the story is fun and entertaining, it is Kevin McCallister and the Wet Bandits (Joe Pesci & Daniel Stern) that elevate the film into its iconic level. While most of the film is fun, there are some slower bits in the middle, which separate the fast paced start and the exciting heist. With memorable performances, lots of laughs, and plenty of holiday heart, Home Alone is a fun film that consistently makes spirits bright.

FILM: 8.5/10.
Ah, Home Alone, a Christmas classic that needs no introduction. What can one say about it that hasn't been said before? Well, I won't attempt the impossible.
In a nutshell, Home Alone seamlessly weaves traditional Christmas themes with uproarious comedy and slapstick. There's an undeniable joy in watching a kid take on grown men in a symphony of hilariously comical beatdowns. It's the kind of cinematic catharsis that never gets old.
Sure, the plot's technological irrelevance in today's mobile-dominated world is glaring. A quick call would resolve the entire predicament. Yet, Home Alone's charm transcends its outdated premise, entertaining on a nostalgic level that warms the heart.
Macaulay Culkin, in his iconic role, manages not to overstay his welcome-well, mostly. The initial excessiveness mellows, and by the film's end, it delivers a surprisingly solid message, even if the finale leans a tad too saccharine for my taste. Fortunately, it doesn't overshadow the rest.
The true magic unfolds when Culkin faces off against Joe Pesci and Daniel Stern. The mischief, the traps, the sheer chaos - it's a festive spectacle that captures the spirit of Christmas in an unconventional, albeit hilarious, way. Nothing says 'tis the season like watching these two stumble through a gauntlet of burns, impalements, and face-smashing.
Home Alone isn't just a movie; it's a time capsule of holiday joy. Its enduring appeal lies not just in the laughs but in its ability to transport you back to a simpler, more mischievous time. So, when you find yourself in need of a Christmas pick-me-up, just let young Kevin McCallister and his ingenious traps work their holiday magic.

VIDEO: 9/10.
Native 4K presentation, Detail level: Excellent, Colour reproduction: Excellent, Level accuracy: Good, Encode: Good, Master condition: Excellent
AUDIO: 8/10.
DTS-HD MA 5.1 audio, Dialogue reproduction: Excellent, Soundtrack & effects clarity: Excellent, Dynamics: Good, Surround sound presentation: Good, LFE content: Good
MOOFIEMETER: 8/10.

There's an argument for a few movies to be the best Christmas movie ever, but I genuinely believe this is a perfect movie for all ages at christmastime and, 33 years later, still has not been surpassed. It's a Wonderful Life is probably the only film that might surpass it, but I'm not aa big a fan of it as this.
Macauley Culkin is so good in this movie that it's hard to imagine anyone else who would have been able to play this role. How he plays off Pesci and Stern is fantastic and the level of slapstick is incredible.
That we also have Catherine O'Hara, a comic genius, who gets to share screen time with my favourite comic actor of all time, the affable, loveable and sorely missed John Candy, is a huge bonus.
That this isn't rated higher, or in the top 250 films of all time on IMDB, is a travesty. If you've never seen this film, which is something I can't believe is possible, you are in for an absolute treat and I guarantee you will come back to it over and over again.

Growing up with this film I felt very lucky
It has a wonderful story and it will always stay throughout my family
It's fun, memorable. It has all the charms of Christmas ðŸŽ„
Every Christmas you should sit with your family and enjoy it together. It's warm and endearing, you have a family who goes away and forgets their youngest son. The youngest son has to save his house from the wet bandats, but he has a plan in store for them ðŸ˜‰ and you will have to watch to see how it end.
Kevin is one Kid you don't want to mess with on Christmas
It's a film that will be around for ever. Kevin's mum releases Kevin is home alone and she has to find a way to get back to Kevin on Christmas day
But the movie has more then just one story and it really gives you a warm and wholesome feeling and a really good laugh.

Home Alone is renowned as one of the best movies John Hughes has ever written/produced, alongside The Breakfast Club, Ferris Bueller's Day Off, and many others. And I couldn't agree more with that!
The movie centers on 8-year-old Kevin McCallister (played by Macaulay Culkin), who lives in Chicago. Kevin's massive family is planning a family trip to Paris for Christmas. Unfortunately, Kevin feels ignored and unloved by his family. And the night before the plane ride, after ruining dinner when his mean older brother, Buzz (Devin Ratray), goads Kevin into a fight by eating a cheese pizza reserved for him, and Kevin ends up being exiled to the attic by his mom, Kate (Catherine O'Hara), while Buzz gets off scot-free, an indignant Kevin hopes that he never sees his family again. Sure enough, that night, a winter storm sweeps the neighborhood, knocking out the McCallisters' power, and resetting the alarm clocks. The next morning, this leads to the McCallisters rushing chaotically to get ready, and in the ruckus, Kevin is left at home by mistake. Kevin believes that he made his family disappear, and enjoys himself at first, but begins to miss his family. To make matters worse, two burglars, Harry (Joe Pesci) and Marv (Daniel Stern), the "Wet Bandits", are scheming to rob the McCallister residence. So, while Kate frantically struggles to book the family a flight home, Kevin must defend his home from Harry and Marv's burglary.
All the characters are brilliantly written! Our hero, Kevin, is a very likable and relatable protagonist. I mean, right from the pizza scene, he lets us know how it feels to be ignored and unloved by family. Harry and Marv are great comedic villains! As for Old Man Marley (Roberts Blossom), the old man about who Buzz lied to Kevin, saying he was a murderer, (possible spoiler) when he finally speaks to Kevin, he's revealed to really be a kind-hearted old man, and a really good example of "Don't judge a book by its cover." (end possible spoiler) The only two unlikeable characters in the movie are Buzz and Kevin's rude uncle Frank (Gerry Bamman), who are both jerks. Although, Uncle Frank does get one of the best lines in the movie: "LOOK WHATCHA DID, YA LITTLE JERK!!!" HA!
The acting is tremendous. Macaulay Culkin is especially charming as Kevin. Nine years old, and already a real talent! Catherine O'Hara and John Heard (may he rest in peace) are praiseworthy as Kate and Kevin's father, Peter, respectively. Joe Pesci and Daniel Stern are hilarious as Harry and Marv!
Speaking of, the movie is packed from start to finish with delicious comedy! Those include Kevin watching a fake gangster movie called Angels With Filthy Souls ("Keep the change, ya filthy animal!") and later using that to trick the pizza boy, or burning himself with aftershave TWICE. But the comic highlight of this movie is the booby traps that Kevin puts Harry and Marv through when they try to rob his house! From the paint cans to the face, to Harry literally STANDING THERE as a blowtorch burns his head, to Marv letting out a PRICELESS scream when Kevin puts Buzz's tarantula on his face... you name it! This movie's humor knows no boundaries! But of course, it's John Hughes, what did we expect? The movie, of course, is also heartwarming at times, like when Old Man Marley's true self is revealed, and of course, the ending.
And, finally, the music! John Williams, the genius behind the scores of almost all of Steven Spielberg's movies, delivered a truly GORGEOUS score for this movie, special mention going to his mystical main theme. And don't get me started on the beautiful song that he composed, "Somewhere in my Memory." I actually sang along to that as I was watching this movie tonight.
All in all, Home Alone is one of the greatest movies John Hughes has ever made, and in my opinion, a must-see for anybody who loves comedy movies like me. Especially at Christmastime!!!
Oh, and by the way... "KEVIN!!!! WHAT DID YOU DO TO MY ROOM?!?!?!?!"

Home Alone is an amazing movie. There are many sequels to this movie, and this movie outshines all of them I've seen. This movie is better than Home Alone 2, Home Alone 3, and Home Alone 4. Home Alone just has great great actors. Every actor shines in front of the glowing light. This film is just really funny, even when the Wet Bandits are not getting hurt. It just has a clever plot that gets ruined and completely changed in Home Alone 3. I gotta say, my favorite characters are either Kevin or the Wet Bandits. Really Macaulay Culkin plays great as Kevin. It's literally a perfect match. I wish that there was a sequel with Macaulay Culkin and he meets the Wet Bandits again from his childhood. Kinda like A Christmas Story Christmas. In all, I give this movie a 8.6 out of 10. A great holiday movie to watch, even if you don't celebrate Christmas.

"Dunki," a 2023 Indian Hindi-language comedy-drama film, stands as a testament to the enduring allure of quality cinema. Directed by Rajkumar Hirani, this film not only captivates audiences with its unique storyline but also demonstrates the sustained interest in well-crafted movies, as evidenced by a nearly full theater 10 days post its release.
Set against the backdrop of the "donkey flight" illegal immigration method, "Dunki" delves into the lives of a group of friends who seek a better life abroad but face the harsh realities of their decision. The narrative is a compelling mix of humor and poignant drama, reflecting the complexities and moral dilemmas of such a journey.
The film's casting is a masterstroke, with Shah Rukh Khan, Taapsee Pannu, Vicky Kaushal, and Boman Irani delivering performances that are both authentic and powerful. Shah Rukh Khan, in particular, shines in a role that seems tailor-made for him, adding depth to the film's emotional core.
Rajkumar Hirani's direction is flawless, maintaining a balance between the comedic elements and the grave subject at hand. His expertise in storytelling is evident in every scene, capturing the audience's imagination and empathy. The screenplay, co-written with Abhijat Joshi and Kanika Dhillon, is crisp and engaging, complementing Hirani's vision perfectly.
The technical aspects of "Dunki" enhance its appeal. The editing is seamless, making for a smooth cinematic experience. The background score and songs, though not exceptionally memorable, fit well within the film's narrative fabric, enriching the emotional resonance of the story.
"Dunki" is more than a film; it's a reflection of the dreams and struggles of individuals seeking a better life. It's a movie that resonates with audiences beyond the fans of Shah Rukh Khan and Rajkumar Hirani. The film's ability to hold a nearly full theater 10 days after its release speaks volumes about its impact and the connection it has forged with its viewers.
In summary, "Dunki" is a must-see film that beautifully blends drama, romance, and comedy. Its poignant storyline, stellar performances, and masterful direction make it a standout in contemporary Indian cinema. It's a film that not only entertains but also inspires reflection and empathy, leaving a lasting impression on its audience.

I am a big fan of Rajkumar Hirani's movies! I once read somewhere written; He is the Cristopher Nolan of Bollywood! The movie as always gave a great message that is to always think before just running after what looks shinny. In urdu it is a famous saying that "Door ke dhol suhaney lagte hein" which means that whatever we imagine that life is good if someone gets this or that but in actual it is not. I would really appreciate the efforts of Rajkumar Hirani's as he never disappoints the audience with his creativity and catering the current issues keep up the good work everyone and as always SRK did an amazing acting!

This movie is the best Bollywood movie I have watched this year. It is strong, with a solid plot and excellent performances.
The love angle is the film certainly steals the show! SRK and Tapsee have a chemistry that one couldn't have imagined considering it's the first time they worked together.
It is Hirani's best work and SRK's one of the best performances. Being a die hard SRK fan, I was desperate to watch him play a lover and this movie does full justice.
Hardyal Singh Dhillon is not a green flag but a green carpet!!!
He is someone everyone in love should look up to. This character reminded me of Veer Pratap Singh and also that no Jawan or Pathan can ever bring the best of him.
It is a must watch film !

Movie had been hyped a lot. But there is no proper storyline. Direction is missing everywhere.. only because of Shahrukh Khan, people are going to theatre hall. Wondering what made Rajkumar Hirani to make such kind of movie.. This will obviously collect money because of hype and SRK, but will have to think again for watching next movie of SKH... and obviously not going to watch SRK movie again. SRK has done so much over-acting in the movie. Giving 2 star only for the theme of movie that it is made on illegal immigrants. But 8 star deducted for not picturizing it properly. Hope to see SKH making better movies in coming days.

Dunki offers some lighter moments and a notable performance by SRK, adding a touch of entertainment. However, the film falls short with subpar songs and a overly stretched storyline spanning 25 years, causing a loss of audience interest. The mismatched on-screen couple of SRK and Tapsee Pannu due to age difference raises questions, impacting the believability. The first half drags on excessively, while the second half rushes through, hindering audience connection to the characters. In conclusion, Dunki is an average movie lacking emotional depth. Vicky Kaushal's brief role feels misplaced, and other actors fail to leave a lasting impact on the audience.

Living in US for more than 10 years. I cried a lot throughout the movie as it can easily relate to the people who are living abroad. I went through an emotional journey throughout the movie that makes me laugh and cry. It can easily relate to our life and it is a roller coaster ride of love, joy, and cry. A great movie by Raju sir and SRK. Vicky at his best. One of my favorite movie of SRK is Swades and Dunki may not go alongside with Swades but it is still a great movie. The only complain here is that the building up the character should be slow and it lacks the chemistry of bonding four friends.

Every actor in every scene is just awesome. My 6 yr old loved the movie so much that we had to watch it again in PVR. Shahrukh khan nailed it. Disappointed with Tapasi, she could have done better. She looked kind of distracted. The movie is a roller coaster ride of emotions. If you watch it carefully you will find the glimpses of similar situations like 3 idiots and munna bhai mbbs. You can relate that ohh this scene is similar to the scene in 3 idiots or this one is similar munna bhai.\nBut while watching it you will laugh and then cry the get excited and then you get shocked with the turn of events. This movie engages you till the end. And you come out of the theater with a big smile feeling content.

People like, love, and appreciate the movie 'Kantara' but the same kind of people is not liking 'Dunki'. What was special in Kantara except the BGM. I don't know why they are spreading such negativities surrounding the movie 'Dunki'. Is it really a that bad movie? I have seen it theatre in Bangladesh. The theatre was houseful. Maximum critics were claiming that the comedy scenes useless and it was dragged in the movie forcefully bla bla bla! But when I have seen it in the theatre everyone was laughing vigorously!\n'Dunki' is one of the best film bollywood can ever produce. Please stop going with the trend!

After 2 back to back hits, SRK is back to end the year with a final bang and paired with Rajkumar Hirani as director there was no doubt this duo would deliver another hit. And I'm happy to report that Dunki lives up to the hype.
Dunki is about a group of friends who want to go to London for varying reasons but they have one major problem. None of them have visas. Therefore they decide to take the dunki route to reach their destination and what follows is a roller coaster of emotions.
The characters are all very engaging and entertaining and have great chemistry, be it the romance between SRK as Hardy and Tapsee Pannu as Manu or the little cameo of Vicky Kaushal as Sukhee who, with the little amount of screentime provided, made a huge emotional impact in the story. The performances were wonderful. The comedy is spot on and legit makes you laugh out loud. The music is beautiful and also provides a patriotic feeling. The emotions of this movie hits you hard. And the messaging of love and patriotism is very poignant.
However, I did feel that the narrative didn't flow as smoothly as intended to mainly because of the abrupt dance sequences which felt out of place and some tonal issues.
Even with some of the issues I found, the movie was largely very much enjoyable and is definitely a family entertainer. You won't be disappointed.

What a waste of what felt like 9 hours. Only redeeming thing for the movie were the Arijit Singh songs.
Plot was barebones - as though it was written by and for 5 year olds. The acting was absolutely terrible and large parts of the essential parts of the movie made absolutely no sense.
It did do a good job of showing the reality of life for many undocumented migrants, but it really felt like an afterthought.
Might be a better watch if you go in expecting this movie to be set in a fantasyland rather than on the pale blue dot known as earth.
Overall, 2/10. Watch literally any other movie if you have the option.

As someone who is quite "scroogish" when it comes to Christmas movies - bah, mediocrity! - I recently took the chance to enjoy "National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation" for the second time. Surprisingly, it held up pretty well.
Now, this needs to be immediately stated: your enjoyment of this movie will, quite simply, boil down to how much you can stomach Chevy Chase. Because, make no mistake about it, he is the main attraction here. From his patented physical comedy to his dry wit to his outlandish facial expressions (I'm particularly fond of the last one, in this movie), Chase has his paw marks all over this Jeremiah Chechik-directed romp.
If you are a Chase fan, like I am (controversies aside), chances are you will be laughing from the opening scene to the final credits. Chase's delivery is on-point, and Clark Griswold, while very much a typical Chase character, is fun to laugh with (or at) for 90-ish minutes.
The best laughs in this movie, though, come from the fantastic supporting cast. Whether you latch on to a young Juliette Lewis as Clark's moody teen daughter, Johnny Galecki as the mature (but young) Rusty Griswold, or the great E. G. Marshall as the elderly Art Smith, there are plenty of fun stocking stuffers to help elevate this film into "classic" territory.
For me, however, it was the inclusion of Mae Questel (as Bethany) late in the film that had me belly-laughing on the couch. From her perfect delivery to fantastic lines (thanks, John Hughes), Bethany - despite having less than five minutes of screen time - is infectious. To make matters even better, her dynamic with her husband (William Hickey) is something that we can all relate to.
Is this a deep movie that will have you sobbing due to introspection when the final credits roll? Nope.
Are there some sub-par acting performances that take you out of it? Yep (looking at you, Brian Doyle-Murray).
Is it the best Christmas movie ever made? Of course not.
That being said, National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation does enough (whilst minimally offending) to be considered a very good yule-related expedition.

First they drove across country to Wally World, then they won all expenses paid trip across Europe, now the Griswold family is staying home to host a good old fashioned family Christmas.
Just like when the Griswold family hits the road, nothing ever really turns the way that Clark Griswold plans. From problems with the size of the Christmas tree to unexpected guests things go comically wrong.
Joining Clark and his family are both his and Ellen's parents, Uncle Lewis and Aunt Bethany, and of course cousin Eddie and his bunch.
There's a lot of slapstick humor and a lot of belly laughs provided by Chevy Chase and Randy Quaid in this mostly family friendly holiday favorite.
This was my introduction to the "Vacation" series. I would've been only five when this came out, so I didn't see it until its network television premiere back in 1992, and it's been a favorite since.

Not only is this my favorite of the National Lampoon Vacation movies, but it is also one of my favorite Christmas movies out there. For someone like myself, the other movies push it a bit ethically or morally, and even though this film is a little edgy, it is much for of a family film than the others in the series. Like a classic Christmas movie, everything goes wrong throughout, and its very entertaining. Todd and Margot are one of the funniest parts of this movie. Clark is funny as ever, and the whole family being under one roof is a great source of comedy. If you have not seen this movie, you are missing out.

National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation (1989) stands as a beacon of holiday cheer, earning a resounding 9/10 for its seamless blend of humor and heart. Chevy Chase's portrayal of the endearing yet bumbling Clark Griswold is nothing short of brilliant, providing the film with a magnetic center around which its comedic brilliance orbits.
From start to finish, the movie is a rollercoaster of hilarious mishaps and outrageous scenarios, each scene more memorable than the last. The film's strength lies not only in its ability to induce side-splitting laughter but also in its underlying warmth and familial charm. Clark Griswold's determination to create the perfect family Christmas, despite the chaos that ensues, resonates with audiences of all ages.
The script, a witty masterpiece, weaves together a tapestry of comedic genius. The jokes are not just humorous; they're timeless. Each viewing unveils new layers of humor, making it a perennial favorite that stands the test of time. The characters, from the eccentric relatives to the lovable dog, contribute to the film's enduring charm.
What sets Christmas Vacation apart is its ability to capture the essence of the holiday spirit. Amid the comedic chaos, there's a palpable sense of love and togetherness. It reminds us that, despite the imperfections and unpredictable events that define our lives, the true magic of Christmas lies in the bonds we share with family.
For anyone seeking a festive cinematic experience that transcends mere laughter, National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation is a must-watch. It not only elicits genuine guffaws but also tugs at the heartstrings, making it an indispensable addition to holiday traditions. So, gather the family, grab some popcorn, and let the Griswolds take you on a laughter-filled sleigh ride through the quirkiest Christmas ever.

"National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation is a holiday classic that unwraps the gift of timeless comedy. The Griswold family's Christmas chaos, led by Chevy Chase's iconic Clark Griswold, is a festive rollercoaster of humor and heartwarming moments. From the disastrous tree selection to the over-the-top house decorations, each scene is a comedic masterpiece. The film captures the relatable madness of holiday preparations, making it a seasonal favorite. Chevy Chase's impeccable comedic timing and the ensemble cast's brilliant performances deliver a sleigh full of laughter. Amid the mayhem, the movie beautifully touches on the true spirit of Christmas, emphasizing family bonds and the importance of cherishing moments together. The quirky characters, memorable quotes, and slapstick comedy ensure that Christmas Vacation remains a cherished tradition for families, providing an enduring dose of holiday cheer. It's a must-watch that embodies the perfect blend of humor and heart, making it a festive feast for the whole family."

I watch this movie with the family every year in December before Christmas Eve. I must have seen this movie at least 15 times, and I'm still not tired of it. It is without a doubt the best Christmas movie, the best in the Vacation series, and the funniest. It's also one of my favorite comedies.\nThe acting is good. The entire cast is fantastic. The dynamic is so good between all the actors/characters, but the best is Chevy Chase as Clark Griswold. I think there is a big difference compared to the other films. This movie is much better when it comes to acting, script, and humor.\nIn this movie, the Griswold family does not go away on vacation. Instead, they stay at home and relatives come to their house to celebrate Christmas. That does not mean it will be less chaos, rather more. It escalates more and more, and Clark gets more and more crazy, which is so funny. Whatever he does, it ends up a disaster. He really tries, and you feel for him, while you just sit and laugh through the whole movie. Fantastic movie!

National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation is one of the best Christmas movies ever made, and beloved by many. I know people who have traditions in watching it, like an elderly friend who used to watch it on Christmas Eve before going to bed.
The movie follows Clark Griswald (Chevy Chase) who hopes to have the perfect at home family Christmas. Unfortunately, a rodent in a tree, dry turkey, stapling lights to the house, being trapped in the attic, and an unexpected Christmas bonus is not what he had in mind.
Christmas Vacation, as the movie is briefly called, is one of the funniest Christmas movies ever. This can be attriubited to John Hughes, who wrote the script, and who would write Home Alone a year later. There are many funny scenes in the movie, such as the ones mentioned above.
The cast is also enjoyable- such as Chevy Chase, Beverly D'Angelo, Randy Quaid, Mae Questel (aka Betty Boop), Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Doris Roberts, and EG Marshall- who actually passed away the very day that I was born.
Probably due to the PG-13 rating (which comes from some sexual humor and a single F-bomb near the end of the movie), I didn't see this as a kid. However, in the last maybe 8 or 9 years, I have seen it quite a few times- maybe 5 or so times.
I know that this review is pretty short, but this would be best enjoyed without much more detail. Just go watch it and have fun- it's a blast.

Chevy Chase as Clark Griswald is determined to have a traditional family Christmas and of course everything that can go wrong, does. Family members including the disgusting Cousin Eddie and various grumpy parents turn up whilst Clark attempts to pull a perfect holiday together with the support of his despairing wife and children who know that stubborn Clark must deliver whatever the cost.\nThere are amusing scenes in this to be sure, particularly near the beginning around Christmas trees and lights which are quite fun, but it all soon becomes clumsy, over the top and relies too much on the use of Chase whose show it is, almost to the exclusion of everyone else. In the end it's a Chevy Chase centred mess with few original ideas.

I remember liking this movie a bit when i was younger. However, after rewatching this today i can honestly say that i've never seen such a bad movie ever. It has NO story, everything is just incidents after incidents that are totally predictable. The only funny thing is some of the adult jokes... in the beginning. Then it becomes too much. I don't see the humor in a man in his 40s flirting with a 20yo in front of his son. I can't see the humor in ridiculing a poor family who lives in a trailer. I can't see how animal cruelty is funny??\nIt seems like the script was made in an hour- i feel like this could be an assignment made by some highschoolers in AV class.\nIf you're wondering if it's worth spending 90 minutes watching this movie-- it's not. Spend it watching a movie with good characters, real humor, and some actual build-up stories. Or you'll sit there watching a movie with no connection to the characters and just annoyance.

If i was rating this on a scale of christmas movies i would give it a 9 but for a regular movie its still good. Christmas vacation follows a typical american family during the holidays. During their vacation their in laws make an appearance and decide to stay with them for the holidays. Everything that can go wrong, went wrong in this Christmas tale. More and more relatives start to come as the struggles of a crowded household unravel. Clark the protagonist is trying to show everyone he can have the best Christmas. With great characters and laughable moments, National Lampoons Christmas Vacation is a great movie during the holiday season.

I'm 12 and when I was eight I loved this movie and I still do! It's a Christmas classic and a masterpiece for what it is.
It's one of the most famous Christmas movies if not the most famous Christmas movie. It's characters are great and it's funny as heck.
The main character is famous, the dads famous, the bully is really famous and heck the lamp is the most famous out of them all!
I love the scene with Santa and I really love the scene with the lamp because it's hilarious.
If I had to pick the biggest downside it would be the bullys little brother kinda thought he was annoying.
Parents not to much to say but there is one scene with a little blood, infrequent language, implied f word although it says fudge instead.
A Christmas masterpiece and a classic.
8/10.

A Christmas Story was an amazing movie. A Christmas Story was a funny movie with lots of funny parts. This movie is an engaging movie with engaging characters. If Fffugde was replaced with the F word, then this movie would have been rated PG-13 ( or maybe R ). One thing I didn't understand was the two scenes after the scene when Ralphie had Christmas. It just didn't make sense to me why the existed. This movie was very similar to The Sandlot. The movies both had lots of mini stories in one movie and they were also set in the past. If you like the Sandlot, then I would reccomend this movie to you. What a great movie. In all, I would give this movie a 8.4 out of 10.

This film is absolutely hilarious EVERY TIME.
There are a lot of really weird negative reviews. Take things too seriously much, people? Sheesh. Just relax. The movie is set in the 1940s and was made in the early 1980s. Both were different times. Humor was different. Special effects were different.
The acting is delightfully, hopefully, deliriously over-the-top. The mom's facial expressions are glorious. Ralphie's dream of the fun is timeless-we've all had a similar want that we were told was bad for us. Randy is so funny-nothing better than the scene where he is all bundled up. And their dad is adorably daft.
This movie isn't for everyone, I guess, but the excessive "analysis" (if one can call it that) is ridiculous.

We love a good Christmas film here, but this one seems to have passed us by until now. We watched it last night with a bottle of wine and really enjoyed it. Very funny in parts, and with a warm and affectionate atmosphere throughout, it knocks more modern efforts for six. Darren McGavin is on top form as Dad and in fact everyone is just great. I love the way everyone in town tells Ralphie he'll 'shoot his eye out' if he gets the BB gun for Christmas, and he very nearly does! And of coures there are the local trouble-causers who get their just rewards as must always be the case. If you haven't seen this, go get it.

A Christmas Story is one of the most beloved Christmas movies ever made, and rightfully so. It's funny, quotable, and simply so entertaining that it deserves the acclaim that it has had these last 40 years.
The story being told is narrated by a man named Ralphie, who is reminiscing on the best Christmas he ever had- in which he desired a Red Ryder BB Gun more than anything. Unfortunately, his Mom, teacher, and even a mall Santa tell him no, because he'll shoot his eye out.
In between Ralphie's quest to get his gun, there are iconic scenes in which a friend of his sticks his tongue to a frozen pole, Ralphie gets a bar of soap for swearing, his Dad wins a sexy lamp as an award, and more.
These iconic scenes are part of the charm that the movie has. There are also famous quotes, like "You'll shoot your eye out", "Fra-jeel-ay...it must be Italian!", "Ovaltine? A crummy commercial?" and "I triple dog dare you!"
But apart from famous lines and scenes, there is other merit to A Christmas Story as well. One prime example is the actors who do great work- Peter Billingsley as Ralphie, Darren McGavin as The Old Man, Melinda Dillon as Raphie's Mom, Scott Swartz as Flick, and so forth.
There's more that I feel like sharing, but I am worried about spoiling too much of the plot.
When I was really little, I was aware of this movie's existence and wanted to see it, but my Mom thought I was too young for it since it revolves around wanting a gun and it had quite a bit of swearing. Luckily, I have had plenty of time in my teen and adult years to see it, in fact I have now seen it over a dozen times- it's that enjoyable.
If your kid is under 8, that may be a little young for them to see A Christmas Story. Otherwise, this would be a great movie for families. Even 4 decades later, this still manages to charm and entertain audiences, and there is good reason. It's a holiday treasure.

Seen this a thousand times and I'll watch it a thousand more, every year Xmas readily with my wife and boy, it's classic. A Xmas tale told through the eyes of a child and his one wish: a Red Ryder a BB gun. The build up to Xmas is filled with different plot points that mesh together beautifully, delivered by a fantastic cast of characters each with their own arcs and stories, truly one of the best Xmas movies ever.\nFrom the opening monologue to the ending scene you are transported back to a simpler time, filled with attention to detail and on location, this flick captures the essence of childhood innocence and Xmas miracles: Santa knows, Santa always knows.

40 years ago, humorist and storyteller Jean Shepherd's book In God We Trust: All Others Pay Cash was adapted for the screen in the form of A Christmas Story. While only a modest hit during its November 1983 release, the film would become a cult favorite over the years thanks to numerous television airings, thus leading to stage adaptations, a followup in 1994, two later day sequels in 2012 and 2022 respectfully, and a culturally significant place in the National Film Registry. So with this film having reached its 40th anniversary this year, its status remains more important than its overall quality.
Now the story of youngster Ralphie Parker dreaming of his ideal Christmas gift, a "Red Ryder air rifle.", is a story many people can relate to when it comes to struggling to keep one's hopes intact. As Ralphie has to put up with his cranky dad's odd choices and disgruntlement from school enemies like his teacher and rival bully Scut Farkus, Shepherd, co-writer Leigh Brown and director Bob Clark incorporate a melancholy feel of childhood curiosity not often seen in films today. Admittedly, perhaps the film favors its humorous setups a bit too much from its main plot since the film can often lose momentum in going from one comedic / dramatic scene to another. Most of these scenes are intended to develop Ralphie to do better, especially around his doting mother and little brother Randy, but they merely serve their purpose to the point where it mainly feels like we're watching school lessons instead of a fully realized movie. Also, the addition of certain characters like Farkus and Ralphie's school friends aren't as impactful as they could have been, although it certainly isn't all about them.
Perhaps where the film succeeds the most is in Ralphie's imaginative scenarios, complete with absurd acting and fast paced editing techniques. As ludicrous as they can get, they capture the imagination any child could have in interpreting what could happen to them before they experience something in reality. In contrast to Shepherd's humorous narration as grown up Ralphie looking back on most of the scenarios, Peter Billingsley brings young Ralphie to life through genuine emotion and sly wit, arguably more so than a lot of the other child actors who are nonetheless as funny to watch as they are obnoxious.
