The addition of holiday themed music and merchandising further adds to the overwhelming nature one can see around the Christmas season, whether in rural Indiana or somewhere else. Arguably more memorable than composers Paul Zaza and Carl Zittrer's original music, seeing adults and children throughout the film could make anyone watching feel welcome in the holiday spirit. As absurd as the film is conceptually, its heart is still in the right place.
So while A Christmas Story's narrative doesn't flow all that well due to favoring its humor over its story, it nonetheless offers just enough charming performances, witty scenarios and heartfelt holiday cheer for some amusement. Unless you're fed up with all of the film's popularity, I would say check this out at least once this Christmas season. It's by no means for everybody, but it does capture the cherished and not so cherished memories of childhood that we often don't see in film that much anymore. Besides, it's not like you'll shoot your eye out by watching this movie or anything like that.

Last night, I went to see A Christmas Story, which celebrates its 40th anniversary this year, at my local theater. And I can tell you this: whether you see it on the big screen, or in the comforts of your own home (as me and my family have done for years), it is a wonderful movie!
Set in the fictitious town of Hohman, Indiana at Christmastime 1940, A Christmas Story centers on 9-year-old Ralphie Parker (played by Peter Billingsley), who wants just one thing for Christmas: a Red Ryder carbine-action 200-shot Range Model air rifle. But everyone he talks about it to, from his mom (Melinda Dillon) to his teacher, to even Santa at Higbee's, gives him the same response: "You'll shoot your eye out." Thanks in part to writer Jean Shepherd's brilliant narration as adult Ralphie, the movie has fabulous worldbuilding, and really fleshes out all the characters; especially Ralphie and his family. One thing that makes this movie timeless is that Ralphie and his family and the people they interact with don't feel like old-fashioned people; they feel like people we know even now. In particular, the sibling energy between Ralphie and his little brother Randy (Ian Petrella) reminds me of how my older brother and I acted toward each other as kids.
Likewise, the acting is brilliant in this movie! As Ralphie, Peter Billingsley demonstrates remarkable talent, even for the age of 9. Ian Petrella plays Randy like the most realistic 6-year-old you'd ever meet in your life. But the two that stand out are Melinda Dillon and Darren McGavin (may he rest in peace) as Ralphie's parents. Their back-and-forth is truly magical. Darren McGavin, in particular is hilarious as Ralphie's old man.
The movie also has a fabulous script, comedy and such memorable scenes and quotes. The banters between Ralphie's two best friends, Flick (Scott Schwartz) and Schwartz (R. D. Robb), are super entertaining, especially the scene where Flick is triple-dog dared by Schwartz to stick his tongue on the school flagpole, goes through with it, and ends up with a bandaged tongue. There's also the storyline regarding the old man's "major award", the famous leg lamp. Other highlights include Ralphie getting a bar of soap in his mouth for saying a dirty word ("Ohhhhhh, ffffffuuuuuuuudge!" "Only I didn't say fudge." HA!), the old man beating on the faulty furnace while swearing in gibberish, Ralphie's melodramatic fantasies, Ralphie beating bully Scut Farkus (Zack Ward) senseless while cursing up a storm, and let's NOT forget the truly brilliant scene of Ralphie visiting Higbee's Santa. That is indeed, as Roger Ebert said, the best department store Santa visit ever captured on film! And whenever we get a Christmas tree every year, my brother and I always quote the Christmas tree salesman: "Now, HERE'S a tree! This here is a TREE!"
And last but not least, there's the music. True to form, Paul Zaza and Carl Zittrer wove some classic Christmas tunes into this movie's score. They also perfectly chose all the songs to use!
All in all, A Christmas Story is a fabulous Christmas movie that will never age! In fact, I consider it one of THE movies to watch around Christmastime!

I find A Christmas Story (1983) is an awesome classic. Because the story is splendid, hilarious moments, heartwarming moments and the relatable characters. The main protagonist is Ralphie Parker, He is a boy, who wanted the BB Gun for Christmas, but his mother said "it will shoot your eye out", Because She is concerned about his safety. The one-liners are memorable as well. The hilarious and awesome part of the movie is when Ralphie Parker beats up the mean bully called Scut Farkus, It reminds me of Wendy Testaburger, when She beats up Eric Cartman from South Park in Breast Cancer Show Ever (2008). Like Ralphie's mother, Ralphie's Teacher and the Mall Santa did concern for Ralphie's eye safety as well. But at Christmas Ralphie got a BB Gun as a present by his own father. He first tried to use the BB Gun for the target practices, but the bullets didn't touch Ralphie's eye and he is very lucky. Sadly the Parker Family's roast Turkey dinner is ruined by the dogs, So They are going to have the Peking Duck dinner at the Chinese Restaurant instead. I'm giving this a 9/10 and Merry Christmas.

A Christmas Story is a Christmas movie that's pretty realistic in nature. Unlike other Christmas movies like the Grinch, the Santa Clause, and Elf, a Christmas Story seems likely to actually happen in real life. The Grinch is hairy and not likely to be a creature to exist in real life and with him growing two heart sizes at the end (literally). In Elf and the Santa Clause, Santa actually exists. A Christmas Story has nothing like Santa, elves, spirits of different times, or a green, hairy creature. It seems pretty close to something that could happen in real life, in which I could find a little boring. When I watch something Christmas, I prefer if it has something like Santa or the Grinch or the Spirits in A Christmas Carol than it's a Christmas that could actually happen in real life. As well, some moments seem like general winter than specifically Christmas. Any way you look at this movie, it's still a Christmas classic. I feel like it's far from the top of my favorite Christmas movies. Even with the complaints I gave in this review, I don't think I could give it a bad rating (5 or less). 6 is the worst I can give without it being seen as a negative rating. I may not enjoy it as much as other people, but I don't think I would give a negative rating.

How the grinch stole Christmas would be utter rubbish without Jim carrey as the rest of the film is not the best. (If you complain about the town or characters looking weird that is how dr Seuss would have wanted it.
The story is just the book and is represented well with a good explanation at why the grinch hates everything about Christmas.
Sadly the rest of the film is not the best as annoying characters like Cindy Lou who kind of ruin the film.
Overall How the grinch stole Christmas would never be any better rated because it feels cheap for some reason. That is why this film held up by a Jim Carey masterclass is a.
7/10 = good fun filled Christmas film.

Although you may not believe it, 23 years after this movie was made, I had never seen it, obviously I knew about the character but I only knew that he hated Christmas. I didn't really know the true meaning of the movie, and I think we've all been the Grinch at some point, especially given how the world is today. If it strikes me how 23 years later the film still has the same meaning, how the true meaning of Christmas is forgotten and how it has become a commercial era, a superficial era, based on consumerism. Taylor Momsen really plays a very good character, she and the Grinch with the soul of the film, without forgetting Max too, Cindy reminds us of the innocence of children, without malice, they see the good side of people, always obviously being a reflection From the upbringing that has been given, she reminds us that everyone deserves to be accepted, that everyone deserves to be accompanied at Christmas. I liked knowing the story of the Grinch, about his childhood, about how bullying caused him consequences. Although it is a film whose target audience is children, it really generates a lot of reflection. For the time, the makeup and costumes were spectacular, they won an Oscar for a reason. And Jim Carrey's performance as the Grinch is very good. I think it is a film that as one grows or depending on the stage of life in which one sees it, it will generate a different meaning and reflection.

Adapting Dr. Seuss' classic holiday children's book, How the Grinch Stole Christmas brings the not-so jolly green giant to the big screen. Giving a deeper backstory to the characters and some additional elements to the story, we get a more connected journey, with a lot of heart. Jim Carrey creates one of his most iconic roles, as the Grinch's quirkiest qualities are accentuated in some of the most entertaining ways. A lot of the comedy still holds up, but some of the jokes fall flat with time and remind you that this is a children's film. Whoville stuns with a spectacularly adorable town, looking as if it were directly ripped from a Dr. Seuss story and put on the screen. Accompanied by the delightfully wonderful 'Where Are You Christmas?', the infectious holiday cheer will follow you long after you've watched this movie. Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas will always remain a holiday must-watch and, even with its imperfections, it reminds us that the deeper qualities are what matter most.

"How the Grinch Stole Christmas" is a timeless classic that continues to captivate audiences of all ages. Dr. Seuss' whimsical tale comes to life with enchanting animation, heartwarming moments, and a valuable message about the true meaning of Christmas. The Grinch's journey from a holiday cynic to discovering the joy of giving is beautifully depicted, and the iconic narration by Boris Karloff adds a magical touch. This festive film is a must-watch during the holiday season, delivering laughter, warmth, and the spirit of Christmas in abundance. Jim Carrey, Taylor Momsen, Christine Baranski and Jeffrey Tambor are all simply amazing!

This is such an amazing performance by Jim Carry. The film is nostalgic and without the comedy why would there be need to make this movie? If you like the cartoon stick to that. This movie is so underrated and the costume and make up is outstanding! Lots of feels when I see this movie every year for the holidays. All the negative reviews are from boomers who are very vanilla and have no flavor.\nIt's a cute movie and recommend for those who need a laugh, a time to feel nostalgia, and to bring Christmas cheer into your spirits. Lots of great memories made with this film. I imagine Seuss would appreciate the performance and storyline.

This movie is a masterpiece. Jim Carreys performance as the Grinch is iconic. The set pieces are so incredible that there's still being replicated at universal studios The use of practical effects and prosthetics is just amazing. I really not sure what kind of person wouldn't like this movie, unless you're a greedy CEO type that hates the idea of people diminishing the value of blatant commercialism in holiday spirit. Our family's holiday season is just not complete without a viewing of this Christmas classic. Although I'm not really one for musical numbers, I also find several of the original pieces in this movie to be very well done.

Now in no way am I dissing this Movie. First up, Carrey is undeniably fantastic in the title role and I really struggle to see who else could have played the part better. The costumes look amazing and are undeniably Suess. For me the reason I have only scored 6 is that I find Suess to be quite difficult to get on board with. I appreciate it for what it is . But don't quite have the attraction to it that it seems to demand from an enormous following. I think my biggest gripe is that the beauty of Suess is the clever writing and rhyming and this seems to take second place in the live action affair. Don't get me wrong it's a well made family flick and I'd suggest younger kids will love it. It just isn't high on the list for me when it comes to the xmas watchlist. A middle of the road attempt which remains enjoyable without being captivating.

Me and my family have only the best memories surrounding the Grinch. First in the animated class when I was a small child and than this fantastic version with Jim. It made my childhood memories complete and I know it did for my brother Erik too. We just felt genuinely connected to Dr. Seuss through this movie and also the cartoon movie. Jim Carrey really brought to life The Grinch and his stubborn mean heart, but how it could love once again and I think that happens to a lot of us in our hearts! It's the story of renewal and forgiveness. It's amazing God's love. Just remember we were ok born on Earth in order to LOVE GOD.

Firstly does this movie need to exist? Definitely not. But that does not mean it's bad. Yes it's not as accurate to the books, yes you have the animated version which is much more accurate. But like this movie is an actual full length film, they had to add more and tbh I think what they added is really good. Jim Carrey is hilarious in this movie, the set design and costume design is both really realistic, really well done and really fun. The commentary of society, consumerism and Christmas as a whole is also in a way genius. I also love the commentary on how fake people can be, like genuinely the commentary in this film is surprisingly really well done and kinda subtle if you don't pay attention. The characters are also really likeable (or unlikeable) when needed, plus max the dog is such a good boy. The only real bad thing about this film is it doesn't look as colourful as it probably should.

It seems that those who want to experience nostalgia as the new year approaches are running again. There may be those who are watching it for the first time. As for me, I rated it so high because my score has never decreased. Taking into account the year it was made, unfortunately, it is not possible to watch a New Year production that has been so laboriously created even in today's times. Moreover, one of the most popular actors of that period is also in this film. If we were to compare, it would be difficult to even create an alternative cast with today's actors. Therefore, sometimes it is necessary to look at it not with the eyes of today but with the perspective of many years ago and evaluate it accordingly. Sometimes the emotions it evokes should override a simple scoring logic and should be evaluated accordingly when voting. TrÃ¨s amusant...

The Holdovers is a new drama comedy directed by Alexander Payne, director of About Schmidt and The Descendants.
In 1970, history teacher Paul Hunham (Paul Giamatti) stays at school during the Christmas holidays. Here he is with some staff and students, who have nowhere else to go during the holidays.
Paul tries to keep order among the people at school. After a few days, he is left alone with student Angus Tully (Dominic Sessa) and chef Mary Lamb (Da'Vine Joy Randolph). During their isolating state, the three get to know each other well. In this way they try to help each other with their problems and past.
This entire film was shot in real practical locations of a school in Fairhaven, Massachusetts, during a holiday so the school was empty. For example, no film sets or soundstages were used for this film. This gives the film a realistic look and feel while watching.
Writer David Hemingson, who is better known as a writer of various TV series, has managed to write a good story with this story. He uses well-known concepts where different characters unintentionally end up together, but knows how to incorporate the characters well into the film. During the film, the characters get to know each other better and discover what bothers them or what they love. Together they try to help each other with their passions or annoyances. As a viewer, you sympathize more and more with the characters as you learn more about them.
What also makes you care about the characters is the acting of the three actors in the film. Paul Giamatti comes across well as a more grumpy loner, but throughout the film you learn why his character has become this way and that there is still a good and kind person inside him. Da'Vine Joy Randolph's character also has her mysterious storylines, but serves more as someone who tries to maintain order and balance between a grumpy teacher and problematic student. This was only Dominic Sessa's first acting role, but this is not reflected in his performance in the film. He may not have known how to use a rotary telephone, but this is more due to his young age. He also knows how to deliver heart-warming acting for characters with a less than ideal past. Together the three actors know how to provide good acting, characters that you as a viewer start to care about and empathize with more and more during the film.

The performance in this from Giamatti is outstanding.
However, what really captivated me was the atmosphere of the time period. It is EXCEPTIONALLY rare in 2023/24 to see a historical-based film that adheres to the actual time period it is depicting. That alone gained a couple star here. The entire film "feels" like the 1960/70s. It isn't littered with altered dialog to conform to current social demands.. it come across as an honest portrayal of the time period - which few productions even attempt today.
Overall the film is a slow grind about a relationship. It's entirely human interest. While I was engaged the entire film, and don't regret spending the time to watch this, it's not something overly memorable on the whole. But still.. it's worth watching if you are in the mood for a relatively subtle feel-good story.
The biggest downside for me was the soundtrack.... it seemed honest to the time period - being more "soft rock" or "lazy stoner" tunes of the time period, nothing which conveys any excitement or interest.. more somber music in general. You know, the type of music that makes one think the performer may be half asleep or loaded up on mood suppressors. But, admittedly, I may have noticed it more because I find such music mildly irritating.
So minus a couple stars because there's no repeat viewing aspect or takeaway memory from the film. And minus another due to the morose soundtrack.

I tend to avoid holiday movies due to a troubled upbringing as they always make me sad. I really didn't know that this was a holiday movie or at least I hadn't thought it through since it takes place around Christmas and a, duh, Christmas school break. So there I was in the midst of this movie when it suddenly hit me it was a Christmas movie! In any event it's a nice movie with a nice cast of three individuals played by the always good Paul Giamatti as a disliked teacher, the strong film debut of Dominic Sessa as a disliked student and Da'Vine Joy Randolph who is just about guaranteed an Oscar for this when the nominations and awards come out in the coming months. She plays the school's head cook stuck with the other two over the Christmas holidays. This is primarily about the sour relationship between the teacher and student growing warmer and warmer and both learning how to be better people. Alexander Payne is a fine director and writer, though he did not write this somewhat manipulative piece and I wish he had. It might have been a bit more sharp than sentimental. Still, it's good and there are many who will appreciate this a lot.

Paul Hunham is teaching at an exclusive boys school, Barton Academy. It is set in the late 1969-70, and the students are mainly privileged sons of wealthy parents, and often spoiled. Paul teaches ancient history, and is well versed. But he is not a people person. He doesn't change with the times, and as a result is disliked by his students and the other teachers. Yes, he is terrified of losing his job. He gives his students no slack, which is difficult for the school, as those parents expect their sons to get an easy ride to top universities, so they can avoid the draft. It is the time of the war in Vietnam and the draft, and keeping in college means keeping out of the military. There is the regular Holiday break, but a handful of students can't leave, so Paul is set to be the 'babysitter' and one especially difficult student is Angus Tully. Tully has been expelled from three other schools and the next step for him is a military school. Paul expects to run the holiday as if it were a regular school period, which becomes even harder when all but Tully get a chance to leave. With them is Mary, the school cook and a black woman whose son was recently killed in Vietnam. And she loves cigarettes. So together these three stranded persons have to deal with each other, and they have their own set of problems. And how that can work out is really the heart of the movie, and very human.

This movie should have spent longer on the editing floor. It could've been cut down to 75 mins and would have gotten the point across. It seemed like it was going to be a story of different characters becoming unlikely friends but then, 45 minutes in, four of the characters were whisked off and it turned into a different story. It felt like various plot lines were taking shape just to be cut off. The prevailing plot line was boring.\nAlong with being way too long, the acting felt empty, which surprised me because Paul Giamatti usually delivers. The end was anticlimactic, but I was glad it was over.

Easily the best movie I have seen this year.
Easily deserving and of an Academy nomination for Paul Giamatti, one of our best actors who all too often has his performances overlooked. He is among that exceedingly rare group of actors both current and past who has never delivered a poor performance in any film I have watched. This film is no different.
The story: a young troubled teen on the threshold of manhood is placed in the care of an older troubled man. Neither is happy about it. Over the course of 3 acts, they learn from one another and each is made a better man as a result.
This is a story that has been done many times before, and when it's done right, produces some of our best loved films. Good Will Hunting, Life As A House, The Man Without a Face, On Golden Pond just to name a few.
If you enjoyed any or all of those films, you'll like this one.
Simply excellent.

Thought we'd give this one a shot and didn't regret it. Great intertwined story teaching the watching parties not to be too quick to judge a book by its cover. Some really funny moments mixed with some really touching moments. Sadly some not so nice truths behind why some get sent to boarding school and why the kids develop an "attitude" toward life and people to protect themselves. The journey isn't easy but the developing relationships in this small group make this film very watchable and leaves you with a lump in you throat and a tear in your eye. This one goes straight into my top five Christmas films!

I must say, it was a thoroughly enjoyable experience from start to finish. The storyline was engaging, with a well-crafted plot that kept me hooked from the beginning. The characters were well-developed and relatable, each contributing to the overall narrative in a meaningful way.
What stood out to me the most was the impeccable pacing of the story. The Holdovers managed to maintain a perfect balance between action and character development, ensuring that I was never bored or overwhelmed. The narrative flowed smoothly, and I appreciated how the writers took the time to explore the nuances of each character's journey without losing sight of the overarching plot.
The production quality of The Holdovers was commendable. The visuals were crisp, and the soundtrack added an extra layer of immersion to the storytelling. The attention to detail in the set design and cinematography was evident, creating a rich and believable world for the characters to inhabit.
Furthermore, the performances by the cast were top-notch. The actors brought authenticity to their roles, making it easy for me to connect with the characters on an emotional level. The chemistry among the cast members was palpable, enhancing the overall viewing experience.
The Holdovers exceeded my expectations in every aspect. It's a testament to solid storytelling, skillful direction, and a talented cast.

The Holdovers (2023) :
Brief Review -
This much-hyped, feel-good Christmas comedy-drama comes with a certain appeal. The Holdovers may just stand out as the most favourite Christmas film of 2023 because there weren't many to compete with it. Although this one is a feel-good and emotional drama with a lack of good comedy, it can only appeal to a certain section of the audience. The first reason for this is that it is a slow movie. It does not really have that pace, that many engaging factors, or so-called comedy to keep you entertained. Rather, it has a lot of drama overtaken by some nice emotional moments towards the end. The other reason is the story. See, it's a very depressing tale. On Christmas, you might want to see something enchanting, right? The film is about a student who is left alone during the Christmas holidays with the most resentful teacher at the school. How many guys are there who are left alone on Xmas? Many, but do they all give a damn about it? No. They just find ways to get kicked out of these unwanted situations and find pleasure somewhere else. Only a few people don't have a choice, so they are stuck and spend time in solitude. The Holdovers is for them. The film lacks a story that can appeal to every kind of audience since the conflicts are purely based on some particular character suffering through some specific problems. That doesn't happen to everyone, so I'm afraid that not everybody can relate to it. At least I didn't. That's what took me away from the film. I would have loved to see regular teacher-student conversions instead of these strained issues. On the positive side, the performances are superb. Paul Giamatti and his eyes-I mean, how did they find such a perfect fit for the role? He looked so genuine there. Alexander Payne's direction is subtle, but too subtle, I think. Too slow, too. Overall, a fine take, but it could have been more entertaining and funny.
RATING - 6/10*
By - #samthebestest.

"The Holdovers" is a captivating blend of comedy and drama that beautifully explores the complexities of human relationships.
Story is about a grumpy instructor (Paul Giamatti) at a New England prep school who forms an unexpected bond with a troubled student during the Christmas break. Because it is set in the 1970s, the film in a way is a nostalgic journey back in time, but with a narrative that is both engaging and thought-provoking.
The performances are exceptional, with Giamatti delivering a compelling portrayal of a man grappling with his own loneliness and the challenges of mentorship. The film's narrative is richly layered, exploring themes of loneliness, friendship, and personal growth. It's a story that resonates, offering a poignant reflection on the human condition. The film's setting in the 1970s adds a layer of nostalgia, further enhancing the emotional depth of the narrative. Despite its lengthy runtime, "The Holdovers" mostly maintains a steady pace, balancing its dramatic elements with moments of humor and warmth. The main plus of the movie is its dialogue-driven approach that adds to its charm, creating a sense of authenticity and depth in its character interactions.
Overall, this is a film that leaves a lasting impression, offering a thoughtful exploration of human relationships set against the backdrop of a bygone era. With its exceptional performances and engaging narrative, I'm giving it an 8 out of 10 rating. It's a must-watch for those seeking a film that combines drama, comedy, and a touch of nostalgia.

Christmas doesn't begin for me until White Christmas is on. This movie is one of my all-time favorites! Even if it's not Christmas. You can't beat the songs and Bing Crosby and Rosemary Clooney's voices, the actors, dancing of Danny Kaye and Vera Miles, or the touching story line. The scenery is beautiful from the opening in the camp behind the battle lines to the final snow falling setting. Edith Head is a masterful, as always in her costume creations, right down to Danny Kaye's blue dancing shoes on the bridge and masterful design to flatter all four of the main characters builds and still keep the outfits matching.

I'm a sucker for old movies. This ain't one of them. Bing Crosby seemed tired and old. Danny Kaye seemed to be trying to make up for Bing's lacklustre performance. The ladies did their best (I guess??). Was this a musical or a dance movie? Awful on both counts.
What was with the dancing scene in purple? I get they are trying to showcase the dances but ???? Why?
The story is flimsy, no chemistry with any of the characters.
Steer clear and go to Its a Wonderful life instead. That movie has heart and a proper story. Maybe even check out Diehard. At least that has a more believable storyline. What a total disappointment of a movie.

This is my all-time favorite movie for the holidays. I used to watch it with my mom every year at Christmas time, usually several times through the season. I try to see it every year at Christmas time. Unfortunately, I'm stuck living in my vehicle, and don't have access to it. I wish it was available on Disney+ or Hulu, instead of only on Netflix. I'm also having a hard time finding it on DVD in stores. Hoping I can find a way to see it this year. My mom made it a tradition in our home growing up, I just want to keep that tradition going. It's a great movie, I hope it gains in popularity with the younger generations.

I fail to understand why White Christmas is still regarded as a classic. The storyline, about 2 ex-army men who team up to perform a Christmas show at a ski lodge, is hardly interesting, engaging or even festive.
I've watched many classic Christmas films in my long life including Elf, Home Alone, It's a Wonderful Life, Miracle on 34th Street, Polar Express, and A Christmas Carol, to name a few. They are all way superior, entertaining and festive, whereas White Christmas is saddled with a weak plot that just never gets off the ground. Why is a show about putting on a show regarded as entertainment is beyond me! The whole plot in fact is so tedious I find it hard to maintain any interest every time I try to watch this. It is a truly boring snooze fest.
I guess it probably means a lot more to those who grew up watching this from a very young age. I am also guessing it means a lot more to Americans than anyone growing up or living outside the USA.
As for the title White Christmas, I think the makers should be sued under the Trade Descriptions Act. There's hardly any snow to be seen until the last few minutes. Unless 'white' actually means something else. Just saying.

Danny Kaye is much the more natural here as he ("Phil") and successful partner "Bob" (Bing Crosby) hook up with the aspiring sister-act team of "Betty" (Rosemary Clooney) and "Judy" (Vera-Ellen). The latter pair have a gig at a remote Vermont inn, and so after some shenanigans on a train they all arrive to discover it is run by the gents' former wartime CO "Gen. Waverly" (Dean Jagger). Determined to come to the aid of this decent and proud man, they concoct a scheme to quite literally rally the troops! The gist of the plot is one of loyalty and integrity, but there is plenty of daft comedy interspersed to keep the whole thing from becoming too earnest or sentimental. The dance numbers are expertly choreographed and the musical numbers from Irving Berlin including the belters "Sisters" (with a little help from Gloria Wood) and "Blue Skies" keep the toes tapping too... It's a cheery, gentle romantic comedy that puts a smile on your face and reinforces any faith in the human spirit that might need topping up. I always found Crosby a little too slick on screen, but Kaye and Clooney are great and though perhaps just a shade too long, it's still an enjoyable seasonal romp, well worth a watch with some mulled wine and the odd chocolate Santa.

Real head-scratcher, this one.\nIt'd be easy to write off "White Christmas" for just the songs (none of which are my cup of tea) but one thing jumped out on this particular rewatch: is this really a Christmas movie? The only reason there's snow is that they've booked a gig in Vermont in December; Bing sings the title song a couple of times, they throw on the festive red costumes and call it a day.\nI mean no disrespect to this movie. Its place in the annals of history and Christmas tradition are assured, and nothing I say is gonna change that. It's an American institution at this point. And I may be left completely cold by the music, dancing and performances, but damn if the colors don't pop off the screen. That Technicolor worked wonders.

If they ever have a local production of White Christmas, I could step into just about any role. LOL I've been watching it annually for at least 40 years, through TV broadcasts, VHS, DVD, and now Bluray. And I've got to tell you, if you've never seen this on Bluray it's an utterly different experience ... sharp and gorgeous.
Danny Kaye gets some of my favorite lines ever in a movie, especially in the early scene where they're packing to leave on the train. He's also got my favorite dance number, outside the club where the sisters were performing ... "The Best Things Happen While You're Dancing".
Another favorite, later in the film, is "Count Your Blessings".
Of course, the movie begins and ends with the megahit, best-selling song of all time, White Christmas.
Fantastic movie.

And all time favorite with outstanding choreography, costumes, classic show tunes and a visual feast. One very important cast member who is not mentioned in credits is Judy Holliday. She plays a stage dancer in Bing Crosby and Danny Kaye's vaudeville act along with an attendee at the cast party for new show "Playin Around". Won the Academy Award for Best Actress in "Born Yesterday" opposite Broderick Crawford and William Holden. Known for her great beauty and high pitched, nasal intoned, heavy accented New York "twang". Get teary every time "the old man" enters the dining hall to be honored by his men. Glad it's never been reprised in a more recent version.

Just a great Christmas movie.
Can't go wrong with Bing Crosby, Danny Kaye, Rosemary Clooney, Vera Allen, and Dean Jagger.
Wonderful acting, great music and awesome dance scenes. The choreography is outstanding. Irving Berlin wrote some great medic for this movie.
Great setting at a quaint inn in Vermont. The sets are beautiful. The inn is a beautiful setting. Perfect for a Christmas movie. It's a place you want to be for Christmas.
The picture was released in 1954 and it's still great 68 years later !! That says a lot about this wonderful movie.
It's a must watch that will greatly enhance your Christmas season. Enjoy !!!

This is one of the greats and I recommend everyone see it at least once. It was great in its day but by today's standards a bit dated and cheesy.
IMHO there was no other crooner on the planet at the time that could match the pipes of Bing Crosby. Conversely Rosemary Clooney was gifted in her own right.
Interestingly Bing was twice her age in this production. He 51. She 26. Vera-Ellen though only 33, looked older than her age, perhaps partly because of her own issue with anorexia. The next time you see the movie take note of her ribs and waistline on her entrance into the train club car scene. Yikes!
Though an incredible hoofer Vera had no voice and Rosemary dubbed her vocals. Danny Kaye, the song and dance man, was no match for Vera. Enter John Brascia a man who imparted a serious air of masculinity to the dance numbers. These two paired together in this movie just tore up the floor.
The rest of the movie is silly but Berlin's numbers made it very watchable. Rosemary's character was a silly little immature school girl, a most annoying thing. It's a great story as the General's onetime subordinates try to help him out, producing some incredible numbers along the way.
Old, dated, cheesy but well worth the watch.

Nicolas Cage is back, this time not battling bees or stealing Declaration of Independences but facing a much weirder threat: becoming everyone's nocturnal best friend. In Dream Scenario, Cage plays Paul Matthews, a man whose face suddenly starts popping up in millions of strangers' dreams, turning him into an overnight sensation. At first, it's all sunshine and rainbows-talk show appearances, lucrative endorsements, even a fan club of sleepwalkers. But as the line between reality and dreams blurs, Paul's dream-self morphs into a grotesque, cannibalistic monster, and his waking life becomes a waking nightmare.
Director Kristoffer Borgli crafts a film that's equal parts hilarious and horrifying, a twisted satire on the fleeting nature of fame and the dark underbelly of the internet age. Think Being John Malkovich meets Inception with a dash of Twilight Zone, and you'll get a taste of the bizarre brilliance that is Dream Scenario.
Cage, as always, is a force of nature, inhabiting his role with gusto and delivering deadpan lines with a wink and a raised eyebrow. He's perfectly cast as the bewildered common person thrust into the limelight; his comedic timing is impeccable even as his character descends into existential dread. The supporting cast, including Julianne Nicholson as Paul's long-suffering wife, are equally stellar, adding depth and humour to the story.
The film's score is a pulsing electronic nightmare, perfectly complementing the unsettling visuals and amplifying the tension. The cinematography is equally inventive, playing with dream logic and distorted perspectives to keep us guessing.
But Dream Scenario isn't just about the laughs and scares. It's a film that asks questions about the nature of identity, the power of collective consciousness, and the dangers of a society obsessed with viral fame. It's a film that lingers in your mind long after the credits roll, making you question your own dreams and the reality you wake up to.
Now, it's not perfect. The pacing can be a bit uneven at times, and the ending, while satisfying, feels a tad rushed and less subtle in its satire than the first two-thirds. But these are minor quibbles in an otherwise masterfully crafted film.
Dream Scenario is a wild ride, a waking nightmare that's both hilarious and thought-provoking. It's a film that will leave you laughing, gasping, and maybe even questioning your own sanity. Try Dream Scenario if you are in search of a film that is unlike anything you have ever seen before; however, do not hold me responsible if you find yourself unable to sleep afterwards!

There's something refreshing about the plainly weird premise of "Dream Scenario". Nicolas Cage plays a nondescript evolutionary biology professor named Paul Matthews, who suddenly appears in the dreams of his students, daughters, and people he does not know. He doesn't do anything in their recurring nighttime hallucinations of anxiety or horror, in which people sometimes float into the air or the world collapses. He more or less just strolls through the background in his sweater and glasses, sometimes flashing his dopey, pleasant smile. Paul soon becomes a phenomenon, and then a pariah when everyone's dreams co-starring Paul become violent.

Nicolas Cage has not played in such a "good" movie (rated 7 by me) for sooooo long! It was quite a surprise. It is his 6th film in 2023 (7 in 2018, 7 in 2019, not really a proof of quality), whoa.
Message to the writer (and director) Kristoffer Borgli:
At 0:03:20 in the film, there is this quote (by Nicolas Cage aka Paul Matthews, a BIOLOGY professor) to his students:
"So, when talking about adaptive strategies, why does the zebra look the way it does?"
Well,STRATEGY does NOT EXIST in the evolution theory.
For more than 30 years, I've been writing to the newspapers/journalists about evolution because in 98% of the cases/articles, they don't understand evolution/evolutionism and they're writing wrong stuff.

Could not have imagined a better actor to play the MC. Cage does a phenomenal job portraying the inner workings of the main character in such a way that everything that happens towards the middle and end of the movie just makes sense. There is no sense of "WHY?" that you feel as a viewer, but rather empathy.
I viewed the whole thing as an analogy to cancel culture and this feeling that we can have as people when others dislike us for reasons that are only alive in their own head.
You can deffo see this is an A24 movie. The editing is just so good with attention to small details in a way that pleases your eyes and makes you smile from now and then (if you're the type to appreciate small details).
Highly recommend to anyone that likes political movies told through surrealism.
P. S. I wonder what everyone would have dreamt if he were to do other thing. A beautiful concept to explore as an artist.

A strange movie.
Hilarious in its own way as the entire world becomes obsessed and then frightened of the most boring person in the world.
The focus on cancel culture blows the entire premise apart. It takes it to an extreme that breaks its own reality. A feat in a movie that is paranormal but with no pay off it flounders.
The obsession with the person appearing in their dreams of believable but the transition into nightmares and the way it causes the whole world to go mad is when the movie feels beyond bizarre.
The results is an overly surreal atmosphere that bends credibility in a movie that needs direction with the movie itself becoming a walking nightmare; the viewer desperately hoping to awaken soon.
This is one time when a movie would be saved with the main character awaking to it all being a horrible dream.

It's not a bad movie at all, great concept. Although it would have been better as a 24min episode of The Twilight zone rather than a 90min feature it holds up and the best part is that Nick Cage is actually great. Really good. Not his usual hysterical outburst and overacting stuff but a withdrawn somber guy who allows his character to take the back seat.
It's not a bad movie at all, great concept. Although it would have been better as a 24min episode of The Twilight zone rather than a 90min feature it holds up and the best part is that Nick Cage is actually great. Really good. Not his usual hysterical outburst and overacting stuff but a withdrawn somber guy who allows his character to take the back seat.
There's also a few good laughs.
7/10. Best performance Nick has done since Leaving Las Vegas.

Most films now are rubbish but I liked the sound of this and by the beggining I thought it might be good. Unfortunately it turned into something just abysmal like so many films today. That have no umph just drearly plod along.. its such a shame because this film had two things going for it. A unique plot and Nicholas cage who plays his part well with what he got. I just feel the potential was wasted because whoever came up with the idea didn't know where to go with the story or bring it to life more. I really wish this had had a team behind it like the makers of the Truman Show & we could've had another classic like it here. The idea would be like a 8/10 cage 8/10.. but everything else kept knocking the stars down sadly. Though I did LOL at the fart scene but that was the last redeemable moment. & when I think back I can't help but laugh hard at his self serving Internet apology scene. Which he's called out on, which leads you to feel bad for his character despite having just Cringed hard 10seconds earlier.. Leaving me in No doubt at all based on that performance alone Cage IS a Fantastic actor. That was nailed perfectly. I feel others got it right that if the writers here couldn't come up with something to tie it properly it would've been better a short twighlight zone episode. 2 of the producers on this film I'm not a fan of any of their work. Lars & Asti . They seem to want to keep things flat and dreary in all their films. Despite they might have good actors, They are not Blockbuster movie makers. If only some1 else had had a hand in the writing.

The idea and the movie starts off really interesting.\nAt the start, we get the premise, and it gets more heated up with different dreams from other people, etc. The main issue I had with the movie is that it literally goes nowhere. It left me wondering where the movie will go - no spoilers, it went nowhere. It left me wondering why I wasted my time even continuing to watch. I am VERY confused by all the positive reviews. I felt like the director of this movie had no good ideas left where to go and said "fk it" let's make up something and just ship it out. Good idea, but terrible movie, terrible ending.

Dreams are visual representations of our subconcious thoughts and feelings that we live and feel throughout the days of life. What if instead of conjuring those visions personally, everyone in the world was seeing your subconcious reflections?
What an incredibly INTERESTING concept!
Okay so i saw this alone in the theaters, and when i see movies alone (and in theaters) i typically give it WAY more grace. So i will state some things i think kinda stank with this film before i start my praise. Even though I wasn't caught up in the stank there was surely a bit of stank.
-The last 20 minutes or so of the film were so bizzare and off kilter. Anything good or interesting the film had going for it kind of evaporated. It was a fine ending, but the plot just dissapeared inot strangeness.
-Although the concept is very interesting, this movie is a slow burn and really struggles in the beggining to engage. My movie theater was suprisingly full and people were talking in the beggining because they couldnt get into it.
-This concept is so interesting... but I think they could have done SO MUCH more with it. There was a twinge of disappointment that they didn't squeeze all the creative juices from this idea.
Okay so now that i just took a massive duce on this film, i would like to say i really like this film. Nick Cage knocked it out of the park with his performance. He either is so laughably bad, or REALLY great. And he was really great in this! I really loved this film because of it's lessons in guilt, action and the reaction of making mistakes upon our conciousness. What if your self talk was expressed through everyone in the world instead of inside your head? I loved this movie for its brilliant playing of, and reflections of the human condition of thought! I found it super cool, and really liked picking it apart during my watch. There are some important lessons to derive here. Not to mention i do think it is very entertaining, well written and just worth the watch (if youre in the mood for something weird).

This kind of movie always comes in hand with this interesting, intriguing concept. The hard part is not to ruin it. The movie did not disappoint. I like how it was at the same time a metaphor, satire, horror and thriller. A lot of things from todays world was highlighted, such as cancel culture, the differences between boomers and younger generations. Of course the main thing was dreams, but was it really? I think they were just some artistic expression of what they ment to show and highlight in this movie. If you like A24 studio then definetely watch this one, although obviously it's not for everyone.

Bad movie. Waste of good actors. Terrible all around. No consistency in the plot. Don not throw away two hours of your life watching this. Eddie Murphy, if you're reading this, "You're better than this!" We were looking forward to this movie and it was very disappointing. We expected more from such a good cast. My husband watched it till the end, I couldn't bare to finish it. We had high hopes from the previews and thought it would turn into a Christmas classic but it is the opposite. The script, the plot, the movie was all over the place. It had potential but you didn't know where the story was going.

To be frank, this movie is stupid. But for me it fell on the right side of stupid. It called back plenty of early 2000's family-oriented comedies that hold special places in my heart. Does that element of nostalgia mixed with Christmas cheer beef up my rating? Probably. But I enjoyed it, and movies are for entertainment after all.\nEddie is in classic form as I remember and love him ("Daddy Daycare" and "Haunted Mansion") alongside the loveable and whacky Tracee Ellis Ross who delivers her lines to perfection. Together they make quite a pair.\nThe plot of this movie is simple enough. It ends up becoming too convoluted and drags on way, way too long. This movie could've been a comfortable 85 minutes instead of over 2 hours. But of course the takeaway is what it always is: Christmas is about family and love above all else. A message that is timeless.

The movie has a good idea behind it but is sadly just not drawn out correctly.
The humour in this film is a hit or miss as most of it is not very funny. It is Eddie Murphy so you either like the comedy or hate it.
If it was Christmas Day this would not really be a movie I would ever put on as it is not rewatch able. If you had young kids you could put this on as it is a PG which can offer something for kids to watch at Christmas at least.
Overall this movie is like a candy cane you hate it or you love it but sadly in my opinion it just does not hit the spot and that is why candy cane lane is a.
4/10 = worse than mediocre.

The trailer looked brilliant, but please don't be fooled by that.
I've seen and even liked films worse than this, but can I have my almost 2 hours back please??
I kept watching in the vain hope that the film would actually pick up at some point, but boy was I mistaken.
This film is a complete mish-mash of every corny Christmas film I've ever seen.
I don't understand how or why Eddie Murphy took this role. He can do tons better than this film.
To call it corny is an understatement.
Were Amazon scraping the barrel with this film or what??
I seriously hope that Amazon didn't pay a lot for the film, otherwise they'll be asking for their money back...
Not worth the time to watch it.

Even though its idiot movie but entertainer for Christmas. Who dont want to be bit idiot and believe in Christmast Miracles. Its fantasy life, you got to be believe in magic, life is magic and thats how it achieved in the movie.\nI Loved the movie as is, there has to be movies like this, light hearted, fun, for kids, for Christmas and for our beloved Santa Claus.\nIf you love Christmas then you will really love this movie without any conditions. Eddie Murphy is true brand ambassador of such fun movies. I recommend all the children's to watch movie and keep the spirit of Santa Claus growing. Love Santa, Love Christmas :)

I'm glad I ignored the reviews and gave this movie a shot over Christmas. It turned out to be the ideal family-friendly film that was enjoyable for everyone. It hits that sweet spot of not being too childish and also isn't violent. It also has straightforward and easily understandable storytelling and dialogue, which was great for my non-native English-speaking parents who are difficult to please when it comes to movies. They really enjoyed it.
The pacing is spot-on, and the storyline is well-structured with a good dose of humor. It isn't laugh out loud funny, but I had a few chuckles - that's fine for me as I don't need to roll on the floor laughing to enjoy myself. The characters are all great. Some scenes are a little cringy, due to the clichÃ©d direction they take, but that's fine for these types of movies.
My only criticism is there was one scene with the Elf making reference to Christmas not being about Jesus, she was a bad elf, but IMO it's best not to include offensive things like that.
Overall it's a wholesome, feel-good movie.

We are die hard Christmas fans and we really wanted to love this movie. We previously watched the movie "Genie" and my daughter loved it, but this here is one discombobulated mess! Horrible overacting, unfunny and wayyyyy too long for its own good! It could have been great, but the focus on product placement was just too apparent and the movie itself suffered from the zero chemistry from the underdeveloped and unlikable actors. The only thing this movie had going for it is Eddie and unfortunately, even that wasn't enough to save this bomb of a movie. Ultimately, this will be a forgotten movie rather than a repeatable classic. A one time watch is all this flick is worth and even then, fails at holding your attention. I fell asleep after the first hour and I never do that for great Christmas movies which this was not! All the reviews on Youtube must be bots as it seems its getting 100% likability which is why I watched it when in fact it was closer to what we see here on IMDB.

A Christmas classic it is not! Horrible acting, unfunny and unoriginal! Went in with high hopes and fell asleep an hour in! Not sure why they needed to make this mess of a movie 2 hours long as it felt like torture sitting through it! Definitely a one time watch (if you make it all the way through) but not to be repeated! My children loooooove everything Christmas, and they walked away unsatisfied with this one! Just another example of horrible writing, terrible directing, uninspiring plot, stale jokes, over-acting "in a bad way" and obvious product placement which was probably the point of this movie and nothing to do with the spirit of the holiday! Obvious attempt at a money grab!

Every year we see the same Christmas movies that have done well in the past. They are vaunted each year with advertisements, and some even run 24/7 around the holidays (Christmas Story anyone?). But after a while, they get stale. I mean, how many times am I going to watch Elf before the magic disappears forever? And there are some movies I simply don't watch anymore, because of this. So it was a pleasant surprise to find Candy Cane Lane: it is fresh, new, funny, and heart-warming. Eddie Murphy was awesome of course, as were the other stars, and I look forward to seeing this one again next year. I can imagine that Candy Cane Lane will likely fall into the "watch every year" type that Miracle on 34th Street, Elf, Christmas With the Kranks, etc., etc. Are placed. But at least for now, this movie is different and new. I hope more stories like these continue to come out.

The only good acting in this movie is the children and Tracee Ellis Ross... Eddie fell off so hard with daddy day care, the only way to enjoy him is by watching any movie before daddy day care.
My wife put this on and we immediately knew we were in for a bad ride
The whole movie was horrid acting and just celebrity cameos... plot line was cheeks... the acting, again, ATROCIOUS.
Peppermint is by far the worst character... I hope Eddie just retires and everyone lets this movie die on the side of the road. I hope it makes the studios rethink how they think when it comes to new movies and especially Christmas movies...

For starters, don't expect there to be lots of action or any wild happenings. This movie is more of a realistic character study, so one must pay attention to all the subtle details to really get the most of it.
The movie makes a bold stylistic choice with an omnipresent repeated theme, which gives it more of a classical feeling. It is unlike most contemporary films that tend to be a lot more fast paced. Instead, May December is more reminiscent of older movies, with slower rhythm and more depth to them.
Here, nothing is spoon fed to the audience, however the strong writing + acting gives us enough information to understand the different dynamics at play - and they're all interesting.
As the movie goes on, the veil progressively lifts to reveal the emotional depths (or lack thereof) of the characters. However, it does so without ever giving easy answers.
The realization is amazing, and the music gives the movie an ethereal feeling that reveals the layer beneath the surface. May December always plays on two fronts, with the action taking place before our eyes, and the underlying emotional motivation of the characters.
In the end, what we end is a masterful character study, understated in its action because most of what it has to say is hidden in the depths of the human psyche.

This is a movie review of "May/December," directed by Todd Hayes. Hayes does an excellent job of creating a thoughtful and provocative film based on a sensational event. Although Hayes loves melodrama, he takes a non-fiction story and parallels it with a fictional story of making a film about it. The characters played by Portman and Moore are both observed objects who create a self-narrative where they are the heroes. However, in the end, they both turn out to be delusional. The scene where Moore's character makes up Portman expresses the connection. Hayes direction combines naturalist and expressionistic overtones adding the right element of distance from its outherwise sensation subject.

Todd Haynes has been brilliant in the past, but here he seriously falters. The film lacks the spark of enthusiasm that might have made up for the fact that there simply isn't an interesting story here to begin with. Deals with mental illness but only goes as deep as the glancing edge, and prefers instead to be mainly an uninsightful commentary about borderline narcissism, selfish, poor behavior, and some dull bits about acting and being an actor. Many scenes lacking in meaning and displaying only average dialogue and performances should have been cut out. Avenues that should have been pursued or at least satisfactorily explained were not, such as how and why would an actress spend days and weeks with someone they are meant to portray, who is patently uninteresting, and whose mannerisms and motivations can be imitated and deciphered very quickly? Who cares why these bland and monotonous individuals made odd life choices? It is the film's job to make things compelling or shed light on something, and nothing is really even interesting here. Each main character has flaws, but what this reveals about the human condition is zero. We simply witness tedious people having tiresome conversations which reveal far too little. We can guess, but always lurking at every moment is the dreaded "Who Cares?" No matter how hard you apply yourself to the themes covered, you will come up light, unless you enjoy medium temperature suburban drama that goes on for two solid hours with scant material to explore. Yes, we see there are some "meta" themes to pay attention to, but they are not substantial enough to make up for the lack of convincing emotion or energy.

This movie really has an interesting and thoughtful storyline with little details that made it seem like it was based on a true story. That was nicely done. Somewhat shockingly, the music was out of an '80s or early '90s movie. It gave the effect of being more like a Lifetime movie. That doesn't particularly bother me but I just thought it was extremely interesting. You don't see that in movies today. And for good reason I think. People have moved past that musical style.
This was approaching a seven for me but didn't quite get there. The positive elements again were the interesting storyline and the tension among some of the characters and the development of the plot and the characterization. The drawback was again the music was a little off and the story just wasn't quite as compelling as a seven rated movie would be.
It was funny in the graduation scene how they were clearly attempting to announce the graduates in alphabetical order but failed. Sloppy writing there. Also after they announced about eight students whose last name started with "A" the principal quickly said congratulations to the class of 2015 without any kind of a segue.
ABOUT MY REVIEWS:
I do not include a synopsis of the film/show -- you can get that anywhere and that does not constitute a meaningful review -- but rather my thoughts and feelings on the film that hopefully will be informative to you in deciding whether to invest 90-180 minutes of your life on it.
My scale: 1-5 decreasing degrees of "terrible", with 5 being "mediocre" 6- OK. Generally held my interest OR had reasonable cast and/or cinematography, might watch it again 7 - Good. My default rating for a movie I liked enough to watch again, but didn't rise to the upper echelons 8- Very good. Would watch again and recommend to others 9- Outstanding. Would watch over and over; top 10% of my ratings 10 - A classic. (Less than 2% receive this rating). For Lifetime Movies for Chicks (LMFC), drop the above scale by 3 notches. A 6 is excellent and 7 almost unattainable.

When you watch this film, you understand it is great acting, masterful film making, and something quite out of the ordinary, which are all reasons why critics love it. Simultaneously, I imagine most viewers absolutely hate it, as did I. Meandering, depressing and totally boring. I watch movies to be captivated and entertained. Confusing, meandering, irksome characters with all kinds of major emotional issues. I understand subtleties and stories that are told in such a way as to intentionally challenge viewers and keep them guessing (LA Confidential comes to mind), but this movie took this to an unnecessary extreme. It's as if the director was thinking to himself smugly how smart he is while completely outsmarting himself and losing all audience attention and interest in the process. I do love Natalie Portman and Julianne Moore, they're both phenomenal talents and have had stellar careers, which is why I watched all the way through but I now realize I would have rather spent those two hours scraping my fingernails on a chalkboard or watching paint dry ðŸ˜¡.

This film was very bad. The fact that it's loosely based off a true story makes it even worse. All they had to do was film it as it happened in real life and it would have been much more interesting.
I'm not sure how they even managed to get real actors to sign on to this disaster of a film.
I would rather watch Gili than this film again. Even the cinematography was boring. The colouring was so muted I felt like I was watching a documentary from the 70s.
I suggest you go find a field and stand in it for 2 hours and you will have better spent your time than suffering through this horrible mess of a film.

The movie perfectly shows how complex it is to know a person and figure out why they did what they did. Great acting and all. But one important thing that made me give it a 7 was that, when you finish the movie you still have so many unsolved questions that you had in the first place. The movie didn't answer whatsoever. It also focused on aspects of characters that we already has figured out. It was also kind of sad and uncomfortable at some points, but overall a very good movie to watch.\nAlso it's good to say that, the contrast of behavior's of characters and how different they were at the beginning was perfectly shown. At the end of the movie you could clearly see how Natalie Portman was becoming Gracy(?)

I am a huge fan of Hayne's work. I love his depth in character study in his films. Specifically the female.\nUpon watching this film I found myself being distracted by Portman's work. It has not been as good since Black Swan. It was not clear to me what her motives were through her performance. It felt at one point she was too visibly very sure of what she was doing and at some, very vague. Ultimately playing a judgmental narcissist. At least that is how I perceived her Elizabeth.\nI have to say though that Moore's work on the other hand was her best in years. It was devastatingly raw and remarkably in the moment. I thought I'd continue watching just for her. I am glad I did so. Thank you, Julianne.

They took an interview from Mary Kay Latourneau and Vili Fualaau where she kept asking him, telling him, rather, "Who was the boss", when at that time the "boss" was 12 years old and she was a married teacher with children.
I liked how Natalie Portman's character Elizabeth wanted to know everything about Gracie, but I thought it was disgusting when she decided to sleep with Joe. I guess she really was trying to be Gracie. She exploited him.
When Gracie and Elizabeth were applying makeup and Gracie started using that ridiculous childish lisp, you finally got confirmation that Gracie was a master manipulator and she knew exactly what she was doing when she sexually assaulted a child, who then became her husband and the father of her three children.
Art imitating life, as Mary Kay seems just as unhinged (in the interview you can find on the internet) when she asked Vili, "Who was the boss", when everyone, including Mary Kay, knew that the boss was her. Only Vili didn't know. So sad.
I recommend this film. Good acting from all three main characters.

May December, whether we like it or not, is an erotic film, but without explicit eroticism and used in an exaggerated way. The film could very well take advantage of this factor and the result could be positive. However, even without needing to use this medium, the film manages to develop a narrative with moments full of sexual tension, but without taking advantage of explicit nudity. The narrative aims to explore, through a dark comedy, the characters' problematic relationship. The problematization of the romance experienced by the characters is constantly remembered. We, together with the protagonist, seek to understand what led this couple to get together. In many moments, the film puts us face-to-face with Gracie (Julianne Moore), causing us to raise doubts about the problematization of that couple, even though the audience knows it is wrong. The film makes it clear how Joe Yoo (Charles Melton) has not matured enough because of his relationship. However, when the character seeks to face this doubt, it is when he frees himself from a feeling that was kept and hidden.

For starters, this movie is way too slow, long, and mostly uninteristing. It's a shame considering the tragic story it seeks to tell. Leonardo DiCaprio is starting to lose his luster and was severely misplaced as a WWI veteran who's pushing 50 but was continually portrayed as an young man. De Niro has never been a good actor and this film highlights how mediocre he's always been. Go back and watch any Scorsese/De Niro film, and you'll realize how overrated they both are. Yes, I'm talking about films like Taxi Driver, Raging Bull, Casino, Cape Fear, and even Goodfellas. Most people believe these are good movies because the critics tell you they are, but if you can watch them with an open mind you'll realize how terrible they all are. This movie follows the same pattern of bad storytelling and bad acting. To make matters worse, it portrays the Osage people in a very bad light.

Oil is discovered under Osage Nation land in late 19th century Oklahoma. It's 1919. The oil companies have moved in and Osage people are some of the richest folks in the world. All that wealth attracts a lot of workers, capitalists, criminals, and general scammers. Everybody is looking to get a piece of the Indian oil pie. War veteran Ernest Burkhart (Leo DiCaprio) returns to join his brother Byron and his uncle William Hale (Robert De Niro). William has become a wealthy leader of the town by having his family and friends worm their way into the native community. He is known as King Hale and has ingratiated himself into the tribe. He directs Ernest to woo and marry Mollie (Lily Gladstone), a shy and sickly native woman.\nI put off watching this for as long as possible. I don't want to spend three hours watching evil people stealing from helpless Indian folks. As I started watching this, a phrase pops into my mind. This is "stealing candy from a baby" and it's not a fun time to watch it over and over again. It's a tough watch for two hours. I find myself stopping or just multi-tasking with my iPad. When the FBI shows up, this becomes a tradition howcatchem and that's a little bit more watchable. I don't have to stop anymore. This would be a great two hour mystery movie with the FBI. Martin Scorsese probably wants the native characters to have more time. He is not shy about making these characters evil. Leo is doing something like Brando and I don't like it. It seems much more fitting that he be handsome Leo so that Mollie would be powerless to his charms. As for Mollie, her cluelessness is rather frustrating. There is no denying Scorsese's filmmaking mastery or his sincere intentions. The first two hours are a grind, but it is still a rewarding watch.

So many opportunities wasted in this film that didn't have any twists or anything clever about it. It could have been an hour and a half, but instead drags on in an unremarkable way, making you question how you were even able to sit through it. Unrewarding and a massive disappointment. The only thing it had going for it was the good acting, but if the lines aren't good, then the actors can only do so much.\nIt would've been better if there was mystery, keeping us guessing throughout, instead everything is spelt out for the audience to see throughout it, and we are dragged through a seemingly endless collection of scenes showing murders and who is doing them.

I just had the pleasure of watching "Killers of the Flower Moon. I found this film to be very engaging, and I am glad to see the truth coming out in more recent years. In California we have some literature about the genocide of the indigenous people here, but very little was written down. I have heard old stories and make up thoughts to flesh out those stories. I appreciate that this story was both written down, and also interpreted with the Osage Nation Members. The costume was just beautiful, as were the indigenous actors. I always delight in their way. I was very glad that I rented this movie in support of this type of media. What strikes me the most is that everyone was intertwined, almost as if they seemed to have no way to stop the madness while living out a grotesque version of life. I guess that this rings true, even today, as we all know where the tax dollars go, and for what purpose, yet we live on in the inevitable denial of natural law. Hopefully, we can get to a point where we actually account for all lives. All of them. Films like this are a good first step to that point in the future.

Stop acting like robert deniro is some kind of A-list pillar, he's a joke. His acting is consistent in every movie (exactly the same in each for 50 years), and his accents are beyond horrible. And this is possibly one of dicaprio's worst performances, he can usually do better than this. This movie just sucks the life out of you. Very unpleasant experience. The movie Flowers of the Killer Moon was an absolute disaster. The story was terribly written and the acting was lackluster. This movie was a waste of time and money. The visuals were unimpressive and the characters were unlikeable. The plot was unoriginal and the dialogue was dull. Overall, this movie was a complete letdown. Avoid this one at all costs.

Leonardo DiCaprio and Robert De Niro star in the epic story of American life in the 1920's. Martin Scorsese selects the Osage Nation to bring awareness of the challenging relationship between the First Nations people and the European settlers in a riveting script.\nAlthough the movie is lengthy, it is required to provide justice to the interconnected storylines of the characters. Lily Gladstone (Mollie) was amazing throughout the movie. An actress I had never seen in any other productions I have watched, but nailed her role to perfection.\nIf you have the time and want to be completely entertained, while also learning about the struggles of acceptance by the First Nations in a white man's society, it is a good choice.

The art of filmmaking is also about being able to tell a great, breathtaking story in a limited amount of time, on all kinds of subjects. Martin Scorsese is a brilliant director, but for his love of cinema he forgets the viewer, like many others (Scott, Aronofsky and many others), he made a film for himself, he certainly has the right to do so, but I didn't buy it. Everything was almost perfect, the actors*, the direction, the cinematography, the music, the editing, but it was not only too long, but distant, trying to say so much that it just wasn't enough to absorb and keep your attention. Eventually you almost started to not care about the Native Americans. You knew from the first moment what it was about, what was going to happen, it was just a matter of how "perfectly" it was going to be portrayed... a difficult film in every way, even for the viewer.

I had high hopes for this movie, which featured the powerhouse trio of Scorsese behind and DiCaprio and De Niro in front of the camera, yet the end result is a boring, overlong and very disappointing mess.
The trailer showed some real promise, but the movie was nothing like it. A relatively interesting premise was stretched too thin and with little to no surprises along the way, I was waiting for it to end.
I was baffled to find out that the movie bombed at the box office, but now I can get why.
Scorsese is still searching for his mojo after his last dull movie epic experiment (The Irishman), but this is far from his best. DiCaprio looks washed up and rather disinterested, while other high profile cameos from big names like Branden Fraser and John Lithgow are wasted.
Killers of the Flower Moon is my pick for the year's most boring movie. You can find something more meaningful to do for 3.5 hours.

The film is very calm, stable and slow. It's much, much longer than it should be.
The topic is perfect, the events are well organised. The acting, especially that of Leonardio Dicaprio, is first class. But this does not save the film.
Uncle Hale's intrigues are very striking. Robert de Niro also plays very well. However, in a film that progresses at a turtle speed, these are deflated.
The film dramatically conveys the drama of the American Indians of a period. But a warmth is missing...
I expected a more fluid, more striking film from Martin Scorsese. Not this time. That's my opinion.
I hope I have not been unfair to the actors and the director.

I think the director was trying to put us through the same hell he was trying to portrait to the audience. I don't want to give any spoiler alerts so I won't but I will say this, if you choose to start watching this movie, know it will be really difficult not to finish it due to its historic importance but oh my god, watching it is a slow tourture.\nThere was everything here to make an epic film, budget, telent, an unbelievable tragedy that could have been told in a way that would shake the world but somehow, this time, MS missed, big time, from the music, till the every other little detail and maybe that was the purpose but if it was, I really didnt get it.\nI can't say it was a waste of time as it was indeed an important story to tell the world but it could have been done in a 120 min thrilling documentary on Netflix, and much much much more to the point and better.

This film is a glorious exception to the rule that if a movie attempts to do too many things in its two hour time span then it will be disappointing. Not only is this film a gripping courtroom drama, the best I've seen since that previous "Anatomy", directed by Preminger, it is also a most acute examination of a miserable marriage as well as an uneasy mother/son relationship. That co writer and director Justine Triet manages to give moving, convincing renditions of each of these three subjects without putting undue strain upon my patience (I was never close to being bored) heralds, in my opinion, a most promising career. I definitely look forward to the next film by Ms. Triet and will, hopefully, be able to view her prior ones. And the lead actor, Sandra Huller, just may swoop in and make off with the Oscar.\nIt also has, thrown in free of charge, the best dog performance in a film since "Sounder". Give it an A.\nPS...Remind me not to ever get arrested in France. Their legal system is, if this film can be trusted, more than a bit on the chaotic side. With an alarming tolerance for speculation.

Justine Triet's Anatomy of a Fall, the winner of this year's Palme d'Or, is about as intriguing a courtroom drama/crime mystery as you can get. The film is highly intelligent and particular in what it chooses to reveal to the audience and what to conceal from them.
Never is there absolute certainty of what the truth must be. As the interrogations progress, we learn more and more about the characters and the complicated backstory of the marriage that seems to have ended in a murder.
The way the hearings -- via bits of evidence that take us into flashbacks -- serve to characterize the characters is brilliantly done and feels completely natural (nothing is ever revealed in a clunky or contrived manner). These damaged individuals are regarded with honesty; there is no clear villain.
All throughout, the acting is absolutely first-rate. Sandra HÃ¼ller (despite the pessimism I expressed when I first wrote about the movie) is, rightfully, on track for an Oscar nomination and, per some people's predictions, possibly a win.
And if you thought Dominic Sessa (The Holdovers) and Charles Melton (May December) were considerable breakouts this year, wait until you see Milo Machado Graner in this; it may be the best child performance I have ever seen, which is to say nothing of his canine co-star. Of course, Swann Arlaud as "the hot lawyer" also seems to have inspired a few crushes (understandably so), and Antoine Reinartz's prosecutor character appears to be a new favorite love-to-hate character.

She clearly killed him. I don't have any doubt about that. The movie depicts the life of a woman who forces his man into her world, setting her rules in the relationship, blaming him for her unreachable happiness, never saying sorry for being the key part of his downfall. She is lost in connection with her daily life in the French mountains, and with her child.
The part when the couple argue (listened during the trial) is for me the most beautiful and dramatic part of this movie. I would have loved to be more touched by the wonderful landscapes but the movie didn't make it, the snow and the mountains look more like a gimmick.
She probably looks strong as a lady, and weak as a broken human being. Her anger seems to be her motivation to kill him, and his last error was to put loud music to annoy her, and it was too much for her to handle.
When her son decided to support her during the trial and believe her, I understand that you can be the most horrible person but your child can save you as a mother.
At the end, she said to her lawyer "it doesn't feel like I win something" Yes, she didn't win. She killed her husband, took away the most important person to her child. She will keep his death as a sentence and she will have to live with her child, life getting harder than before. She lost everything.

Slow moving with long strings of dense legal dialogue. But there's a compelling story at its roots. The filmmaking is bare which allows for some creative choices. But that takes away a dramatic effect & full feeling.
