Slow moving with long strings of dense legal dialogue. But there's a compelling story at its roots. The filmmaking is bare which allows for some creative choices. But that takes away a dramatic effect & full feeling.

This "anatomie d'une chute" is an extremely well-made film within the genre of so-called "courtroom films".
Here, the case is to discover whether the death of a writer (Samuel Theis) happens by suicide or by murder by his own wife (Sandra Huller), with the only witness being the couple's own son (Milo Machado Graner), a boy 11 years old with serious vision problems, which occurred 7 years earlier due to an accident.
Basically, this is a dialogue film. And these dialogues that we see and hear, throughout the 150 minutes of the film, are almost always extremely tense and impactful.
The film addresses the various relationships (husband/wife, mother/son, father/son, mother/lawyer) and the court scenes themselves in a way that is almost always quite "cold".
The dialogues and relationships between characters are generally of some apparent coldness, with few warm moments, although there are also some and they appear at the "right" moments.
The film is very well directed by director Justine Triet, as she manages to make the film go far beyond the trial for possible murder, this trial brings with it several other trials such as the relationships between the couple and between the mother and the son, giving no answers definitive, approaching them in a powerful but "neutral" way, letting the viewer reflect on what they are seeing.
Excellent performances from all the actors, with special emphasis on the protagonist Sandra Huller and the "little" Milo Machado Graner.
Despite the length (150 minutes) the film never "drags", the many dialogues we see are always interesting, tense and revealing something more about the characters.
Verdict: very good. Winner of the grand prize at the 2023 Cannes festival.

Raw brilliant masterpiece filled with intense scenes and an adequate exploration into the human emotional and psychological behaviour.\nThe narrative unfolds with intense, thought-provoking conversations that draw viewers into a captivating exploration of human behaviour. Each character's emotional journey is thoroughly portrayed, opening layers of depth. The cinematography effortlessly captures the fine distinct expressions and subtleties of the human psyche, leaving a lasting impact. This film stands as a brilliant testament to the complexities of the human experience and of our emotional domain.

A German-born writer (Sandra HÃœLLER) lives with her husband (Samuel THEIS) and son (Milo MACHADO GRANER) in a house in the French Alps. One day the man lies dead in the snow, apparently having fallen out of a window. Was it an accident? Suicide? Or even murder? More and more inconsistencies appear, so that the writer comes under increasing suspicion. And even feels compelled to call on a lawyer (Swann ARLAUD), whom she knows from before, to provide legal advice. Soon there will actually be a court hearing in nearby Grenoble, where hopefully all the uncertainties can be cleared up...
Justine TRIET offers a lot in her film, which was awarded the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival: courtroom film, thriller, marital drama. However, all genre elements are essentially broken down into their components. Can the truth even be found like this? And weren't both married couples also accomplished writers or literary educators? The script that TRIET wrote together with her life partner Arthur HARARI also plays with this very cleverly. In German-speaking countries, the phenomenon of autofictional literature was only recognized with some delay. It was only the success of the Norwegian author Karl Ove KNAUSGARD that introduced German-speaking readers to a type of literature that has been very popular in France since Marguerite DURAS and Annie ERNAUX (NOBEL PRIZE for Literature 2022). Autofiction means that the author appears autobiographically in a fictional text. Actually a contradiction from which there is no escape for readers. Unless the text is received either autobiographically or fictionally. Both together don't work.
In relation to the film's plot: What does it actually mean when a couple of writers autofictionally tear each other apart in their own relationship? Are conflicts then real or are they almost acted out in order to be able to exploit them in an autofictional way? And what happens to a child who is helpless in this struggle? However, these abstract questions are interwoven into an exciting plot that can rise above such background information. But that can be crucial for winning film awards. Just think of the year 1994, when a certain Quentin TARANTINO finally used the literary option of not having to tell a plot chronologically, which had been tried and tested since the turn of the century (i.e. Since 1900!!!), in a film with perfectly normal genre elements and It also rightly received the Palme d'Or in Cannes.
A little fun fact on the side: screenwriter Arthur HARIRI has a cameo appearance in the film as a literary critic for a French television show.
But all of this should not be defamed as too calculated! Justine TRIET delivered an outstanding film. The script by her and Arthur HARARI offers pure excitement and is at the same time literary satisfying. Someone has to do that first! Basically, this can only happen about every 30 years! And then Sandra HÃœLLER! What more can you say about this exceptional actress? It takes the whole thing into another league. She already has the EUROPEAN FILM AWARD, a nomination for the ACADEMY AWARD should now be inevitable!!!
P. S.: At P. I. M. P. of 50Cent on a continuous loop, I would definitely become the Hulk! ;-)

I am very grateful to have had the chance to watch Anatomy of a Fall (2023), a film that received the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival.
The first point I want to discuss is that the overall movie is perfect.
This year, aside from Past Lives (2023) and Killer of the Flower Moon (2023), Anatomy of a Fall is a film that meets the highest standard of my satisfaction.
It made me enjoy it from the first scene until the end and didn't have a complex art sense (which may be difficult to interpret) like many movies from Cannes.
On the other hand, Anatomy of a Fall has many techniques that make the audience want to see the consequences of each scene. Especially in the courtroom scene, this movie evoked a thrilling feeling better than an action movie.
So I call it a lean movie, with no excess in the film. Because of its beauty and neatness, this is a type of film that has a chance to get an Oscar.
The main point of Anatomy of a Fall is quite similar to the issue in Marriage Story (2019) that talks about the fall of a relationship.
Anatomy of a Fall is in the courtroom drama genre. Everyone fights to prove their innocence in court. Because of this point, we can see a crack in the relationship and a big explosion in the movie.
That's why the movie is named "Anatomy of a Fall." It doesn't only mean an accident of the falling victim but also shows the falling of the relationship that everyone doesn't want to face.
So this film teaches me that the image of having a family is not always as beautiful as in ads, but it has many problems that can make couples stressed.
Therefore, talking and compromise may be the best solution in married life. It may be the way to make everyone win and no one lose in the game.
In the acting part, Sandra HÃ¼ller gave the best performance and should be nominated for Best Actress at the Oscars.
I liked her eyes and facial expression that always show confusion. It made the audience feel pity for her unlucky situation.
Besides Sandra Huller, every character is memorable.
To sum up, Anatomy of a Fall is a star this year. I guess it has a chance to be nominated for Best Picture, Best Screenplay, and Best Foreign Film.
Anyway, compared to other candidates this year, I still personally prefer "Past Lives" more than "Anatomy of a Fall," even though it has a slightly better performance.
In 2020, Parasite from South Korea was awarded the Palme d'Or and Best Picture at the Academy Awards.
Possibly, we may see Anatomy of a Fall have a chance like Parasite as well.

Overall quality of this film was very high - the acting was superb . Every single character was complex and interesting and was able to seem authentic while at the same time showing the personal motive through everything they did . Bonus points for how cute the "snoop" the dog was .
The story line was engaging and gave you a chill throughout . The complexity of marriage was represented incredible well , along with the emotions of guilt , frustration , dissatisfaction, disappointment and condition .
The opening scene ( music choice included ) was absolutely brilliant and really set the movie up very well .
The courtroom scenes felt so long , both lawyers ( the prosecution especially ) was given far too much screen time and way too many lines - it was not necessary- the audience is capable of drawing conclusions without the need for them being constantly ( and annoyingly ) pointed out .
My other beef was that when they spoke French you has access to the subtitles - but when they spoke English with heavy accents it was often very difficult to understand and there was no option for captioning - this took away from the enjoyment factor .
The conclusion is as also brilliant and powerful - any movie that can open well and close well is worth praise .
Good option for best picture and worth the watch .

If you are someone who likes lengthy, courtroom dramas then you should definitely watch this movie. I saw many positive reviews before watching this flick and of course, this movie received the Palme d'Or this year.
It's a slow-paced courtroom thriller, yet the screenplay is compelling, and the narrative is strong enough to captivate the audience. The production design is also commendable.
All the characters delivered a superb performance in terms of acting and the child actor needs a special mention. He was great in his role.
I can surely say that this film is not everyone's cup of tea and there is no point in fast-forwarding and watching this flick. Do give it a watch if you are into courtroom thrillers.

If your a fan of the series or murder mysteries in general that make you think a little during the movie you will enjoy this. My wife and I both thought the movie had a good pace with enough plot twists and parallel lines that it kept our interest and engagement the entire movie. While we had pretty well figured it out about three quarters of the way through the movie, it still held our attention and was entertaining. We both also thought the acting was really good for all of the characters except Tina Fey's performance which we both thought was subpar and lack luster at best. Full disclosure neither of us have ever been impressed with her acting.

One of the things that's noticeable right away is the lack of star power in this movie compared to the previous two. Tina Fey is expected to do a lot of the heavy lifting, and I don't know if this was the right role for her. I think for me I didn't enjoy this one as much as the other two because it had a little bit more of a horror vibe than the others. It was trying hard to make you as unsettled as Poirot was. It does do a decent job of keeping you guessing as to who is responsible for these murders. And I liked that it was pretty short, not much more than 90 minutes. Other than that, I'd say meh.

I was willing to hope that the other reviews were right, that this would be better than the other two, but it follows in their footsteps, changing things unnecessarily, being deliberately confusing instead of complex and thought provoking.
The camera work was dizzying, and artistic to the sacrifice of comprehenstion.
The actors/writing couldn't decide if it was a comedy or a drama. Even the dramatic lines were delivered melodramatically, over the top, and cringy.
But worst of all was how disrespectful it was toward Agatha Christie's characters and stories.
Branagh used to be so passionate about the source material, so precise, so dedicated. But these Poirot films have disappointed on so many levels.
I tried to set aside my love of Christie and Poirot and watch it through "clean" eyes, but the camera work and dramatics still made the film a bit much.

Poirot is one of my favorites. This was the worst representation of the famed detective I've seen. Except for the 10 minute reveal it was a waste of my money and yours if you entertain the thought of purchasing it. Save your money there are better offerings out there. I see my review is too short? Mmmmm what they should have shortened was this film. Sometimes the most informative review is short and to the point. Which should have been considered in the production of this effort. There really is little else to say. Don't waste your evening? Save your money for popcorn? Basically just avoid this film. Hurrah I've met the limit.

Kenneth Branagh's third outing as Hercule Poirot takes an original Agatha Christie story (Hallowe'en Party) and mixes-in some James Wan-ish horror to give a mystery best watched with the lights on.\nA now-retired Poirot is asked by his friend Ariadne Oliver (Tina Fey) to attend a seance at the palazzo of a retired opera singer (Kelly Reilly), said to be haunted by the ghosts of children left to die when the plague swept through the city during the palazzo's days as an orphanage. Ariadne wants Poirot to help expose the medium (Michelle Yeoh) as a fake. Poirot soon spots chicanery, but events suddenly take a turn towards the seemingly real supernatural. Have the dead returned to take murderous revenge on the living? Or is a more human agency at work? What follows is a journey through accusations, alibis, red herrings... and ghosts. Who's guilty? What's real - and what isn't? The answers may not be as cut-and-dried as you'd expect.\nAlthough Branagh is a talented actor, he generally misses the mark for me. But here he's excellent, as Poirot struggles to get to grips with what he knows cannot exist. Tina Fey, whilst not someone I would cast as Ariadne, does a good job. Michelle Yeoh convinces as the medium. Kelly Reilly is okay as the former opera singer. The rest of the featured cast (Jamie Dornan, Kyle Allen, Riccardo Scamarcio, Camille Cottin, and young Jude Hill) are all very good. Branagh's direction is tight, and he handles the supernatural aspects well (I'd like to see him tackle an out and out ghost story - something along the lines of The Woman in Black). The film was largely shot on location, and the cinematography makes the most of the Venice scenery. The minus for me is that either the mystery distracts from the ghost story, or the ghost story distracts from the mystery; they don't quite fit together. It feels like two unrelated stories spliced together (which it basically is). Nevertheless, there's plenty to enjoy - and Branagh has an eye for the creepy. 7/10.

First of all I have never read any of the books, however I watched both predecessors and generally enjoyed them, especially Murder on Orient Express. Death on the Nile was good too but I think it was more flawed and less stylish.\nSo I was really excited to see Poirot in yet another movie, especially since is was tagged as horror which is my favorite genre. Sadly I have to say that the movie rather disappointed me. It definitely wasn't terrible and it had its franchise trademarks but in general I don't think that it was as good as it could have been. The horror aspects mostly didn't work and were rather hilarious than scary or realistic and just didn't fit in. Also I think that the reveal was unspectacular and slightly predictable. But despite all my whining I think that in general I still like the movie. I had fun watching and trying to figure out more clues about who the killer is, I just think that they could have done so much better. [6,3/10]

The worst entry, by far, in the recent Agatha Christie revival featuring Kenneth Branagh and that mustache, 'A Haunting In Venice' is packed full of cliched camera angles, cheesy jump scares and quite a bit of overacting and underacting - neither of which are fun to watch.
I seem to recall Branagh being quite good in the other films, but he feels somewhat deflated here and lacking the necessary charisma.
He's a complete star though in comparison to Tina Fey who looks like someone who has won a competition to visit on set, she appears in far too many scenes contributing nothing but a rather smug grin and looking totally out of place.
Michelle Yeoh overplays an equally annoying character whilst Jamie Dornan struggles to convey torment. Riccardo Scarmaccio looks born to feature in this film, with that haunting face, but is rather underused.
These films aren't intended to be realistic - more glossy, tongue-in-cheek fun, but the laughs were all unintended here.
I can't say how closely this follows the source material, but the central plot is a bit lacking. Poirot's back story doesn't develop much either.
Younger audience members might find it a bit scary (and original), but the older ones may be rolling their eyes or stifling a yawn and many will 'solve the case' way before Poirot does.

I am afraid Sir Kenneth is aiming at doing all of Christie's material, finally reapearing as Miss Marple in the end. There is no shortage movie versions of her whodunnits and one needs to improve previous versions if another couple of bucks are spent. This doesn't seem to be the case with Branagh's efforts.\nThis time he found out about weird camera angles (German or Dutch angles, if you prefer the professional terms) and repeats some Scary Movie gimmicks, but is this suffice to star and direct another lengthy and dull movie just to have some nice plot turns at the end, when nobody listens to details anymore having left the theater or consciousness.

This is easily the worst of Kenneth Branagh's Poirot movies. The story doesn't hold together quite as well as either Murder on the Orient Express or Death on the Nile - which were well crafted mysteries with tightly told narratives. This, by comparison, is somewhat of a mess of ideas that only barely manages to come together in the end.
Let me start by saying what I liked about this... the acting and directing are very well done - as is to be expected. The movie is a visual treat with lots of nice set design throughout. And in the end, it is a decent enough murder mystery that's sort of vaguely in the style of a proper Hercule Poirot story.
That last bit is kind of the issue though. At times, this is crafted such that it *really* feels like a proper Hercule Poirot story... but at other times it feels like a Scooby Doo episode. The movie leans too heavily toward the "haunting" aspect of the title - and while some of these "spooky / haunting" moments are explained away at the end, some of them simply *CANNOT* be explained away. Upon the conclusion of this movie I immediately researched to see if the original Agatha Christie novel featured this absurd ambiguity surrounding the "haunting" aspect of this film - only to find that there is no such Agatha Christie novel at all. This movie is only very loosely based on a totally different Agatha Christie novel that features no such ridiculous haunting aspects. While I can appreciate the desire to tell a story that goes in a different direction than Agatha Christie fans might expect - I feel like they pushed a little too far into Scooby Doo territory to be taken seriously.
That having been said though, I mostly enjoyed the movie despite some of these issues and I would absolutely recommend it for folks who liked the first two films. But if you're only going to watch one of them - then stick with either of the first two movies because they're both better than this one.

I like this movie. Which is crazy to say because I'm the number 1 Kenneth branagh hater because he directed the artemis fowl movie and I hate that movie sk much. But like thus was a pretty solid movie. The only thing I strongly dislike was the cinematography. I understood the element of fear that qas being used but honestly half the time the camerawork looked silly.\nAlso I didn't like the supernatural element especially in this movie. I would have preferred if all the supernatural elements were explained with like logic or something like that. But it was a really solid murder mystery and there qas a couple twists I didn't figure out. 8.5/10.

I understand that there's a lot of you who believe the dark knight is the best Batman movie and now I do agree with some parts of that. For example the joker is the best batman villain we've had but the best batman we've had is Robin Paterson's. The way he brings a dark atmosphere in the scene defeats Christopher Nolan batman completely, also keep in mind this Matt Reeves plans more movies for his batman trilogy so this could just get better, also keep in mind the Christopher Nolan trilogy had 1 really good movie in the middle and 2 decent ones at the start/end\nAgain all my opinion.\nThanks ðŸ™ðŸ¿

Reeves acts as a conductor in love with his orchestra, in this case, his perspective on the best version of Batman and Gotham. Bearing in mind the need to build a traumatized detective working in an oppressive environment, the screenwriter also uses all his resources to, alongside Peter Craig, bring to life a narrative meticulously thought out to serve as a new origin for Batman in cinemas. If you saw the title when you bought your ticket, you probably already have in your memory passages such as the death of Bruce Wayne's parents or the beginning of the hero's role in fighting crime. In this way, Reeves wastes no time recreating these sequences and tries to use the opening minutes of the work to take us on a deep dive into the darkness of Gotham. Although the city already has a Batman established in his crusade against crime - whose "omnipresent" ghost imposes fear among criminals -, the character has been active for just over two years, always showing his growing impatience and revolt.
The director's vision is uniform for all aspects of the film, showing the solidity of the project even with all its ambitions. Unlike more recent adaptations, which involved Christopher Nolan's realism and Zack Snyder's mythology, Reeves constructs the atmosphere of the work as a dark and pessimistic portrait of today's society. To this end, he stops using a traditional dramatic crescendo leading to a climax, and prefers to transform the long duration into a constant line - constantly hammering into our heads with that place where very few are worthy of salvation. An easy-to-observe example of this concept is the use of light by cinematographer Greig Fraser ("Dune"). While most of the scenes take place at night, with the creative team making use of shadows as an active character in the film, the daytime sequences appear to have been sucked in, as if Gotham had no right to have anything alive - not even colors. Still in this approach, it is worth highlighting the use of red and orange tones in scenes where the darkness is illuminated by these colors (be it the flare or the fire), reflecting not only the bloodthirsty of the place, but also Batman's explosive personality, still impulsive and believing that anonymity gives him the freedom to do what he wants. Fraser's photography also adopts a reduced depth of field or even slightly blurred planes, using resources such as smoke or constant rain to limit the viewer's vision - thus illustrating the oppressive and claustrophobic world inhabited by those people.
Robert Pattinson plays Batman masterfully, and his interpretation makes it clear that Bruce Wayne uses his alter ego as escapism to escape his still recent traumas. Not by chance, the character spends the vast majority of the almost 3-hour running time (which could certainly be reduced) dressed as Batman. Sounding depressed and pessimistic, Wayne speaks little and in a low voice, maintaining an emotional distance even from his loyal butler and father figure Alfred (who Andy Serkis plays with a mix of affection and impatience) - and on the few occasions we see the billionaire Without his uniform, he demonstrates pragmatism by exchanging his suits and tuxedos for a cap and backpack, which allows him to walk around the city incognito, but always ready to put on his mask when necessary. Of the same, the flashy batbike from Christopher Nolan's films gives way to a common, discreet version, while the batmobile discards the stylized design to present itself as a vehicle that appears to be made of reinforced metal and that Reeves presents as if it were a monstrous creature out of from a cave to scare the villains. The existence of Bruce Wayne seems to be a mere formality in the film, and the little development given to him uses layers very similar (not to say exactly the same) to Batman. It is understandable that spending so much time on a mission means that, without the uniform, the character continues to act and think like the hero. However, all the emotional appeal that Bruce carries with him, as well as the important asymmetry between the millionaire and the vigilante were left aside. There is certainly room to develop him better, especially if we take into account that this is a film with a backwards origin, in which the protagonist begins the narrative as a disbelieving Batman in Gotham and spreading fear, and we see his journey of "redemption" to become a figure of hope for everyone.
Returning to the beginning, the opening also fulfills a second and equally important purpose: to introduce the film's villain. And there is no one in Batman's considerable pantheon of antagonists who invokes the need for a resourceful detective as much as the Riddler. Especially when behind the mask, the character synthesizes the antithesis of the method and detail of a serial killer with the chaos provided by a mass agitator. All of this wrapped in a web that mixes past and present traumas with the desire to impose gigantic changes in the future. Paul Dano's Riddler not only has fun while spreading riddles to cover his tracks, but he also shows that he knows communication methods and strategies and knows how to use them to his advantage and always be ahead of those who investigate him. It is worth highlighting the parallel that can be made between the villain's final strategy and real life, rekindling the warning about the danger of the expansion of forums and websites that shamelessly disseminate the most execrable ideas ever produced by human beings.
However, no matter how different "Batman" tries to be, there is no way to ignore that he was born in comics. And Reeves is not ashamed to embrace what the medium has to offer and takes great care of the action and intensity of everything that is happening. So much so that, even though it's a terribly long film, it's easy to enjoy the more than three hours amidst so much happening. The big highlight here are the fight scenes. They are all very well-choreographed and put together in a dry and very raw way, without the acrobatics and exaggerations of other productions. The idea here is to get closer to a street fight, with a crazy person dressed as a bat beating up criminals in dark alleys. Likewise, the entire Batmobile scene is incredible precisely because it is not afraid to accelerate towards the surreal for the sake of good entertainment. Okay, Batman caused dozens of accidents and a pileup that could have killed a lot of people, but everything is so visually impressive that you just accept it and cheer when you see the vehicle come out of the flames in the middle of a chase that is as long as it is exciting.
As already mentioned, in addition to psychological horror, the film also uses several noir elements: many dark tones and shadows combined with white in the aesthetics (Gotham is almost always dark and rainy) and beautiful photography. The detective investigation that goes from piece to piece, to discover who the killer is and why he commits such crimes and a main character with many internal demons and pessimistic views about the city he protects. Unlike several previous works, one of the points of the film is not to show how Bruce decided to become a vigilante - we don't have the fateful alley scene shown at any point in the film, but rather to show his detective skills in contrast to the emotional shaken by his personal tragedy. Fans of the comics will easily be able to see that the basis of the script is influenced by stories from the beginning of his career and focused more on the detective side of our hero, such as "The Long Halloween", "Year Zero" and "Year One".
"Batman" is a huge film, both in length and plot, with a somewhat slow initial pace, which may bother viewers eager for immediate action, as well as pleasing those who prefer a good narrative development with everything perfectly connected. . Of course, it could be shorter and the story more condensed, but when misfortunes happen, this ends up becoming just a detail. Despite this, the film rescues elements of the character that are sometimes neglected in his more recent stories, uniting them with a degree of realism: Gotham is a large and violent city (inspired by real cities of great corruption, such as Chicago) whose heroic protector, at the beginning of his career, is someone who uses intelligence and creativity, gathers clues to crimes, infiltrates places where there are likely suspects and, instead of fighting invincible ninjas or aliens, faces robbers and other lesser street thugs. Grandiose, exposing the rampant corruption and violence present in the city. It's a good adaptation of more down-to-earth Bat-Man stories, but it still maintains its own originality that hadn't yet been so well explored in cinemas and that must stand on its own two feet with the "DC Elseworlds" seal on upcoming new DCU in theaters to be led by James Gunn.

The Batman is by far the BEST of all the Batman films to date.\nNever been a fan of Robert Pattinson or Zoe Kravitz until I saw this movie. In fact, the whole cast was superb. John Turturro is always great. And Colin Farrell was outstanding as the Penguin. It could have been easy for any one of these actors to have taken their role to a caricature level but each performance was nuanced. I did not feel like I was watching a film representation of a comic. Matt Reeves's script and direction resulted in a stand-alone story which made me forget there had been other movie interpretations. I was hesitant to see it due to an almost three-hour run time, but I never once checked my watch.

Ishtar was better. Waterworld was better. Gigli was better. This is in the running for the worst movie ever made. It was way too long. Plot was terrible. Nothing happens for what seems like hours. I didn't pay to watch it and I still want my money back. DO NOT WATCH THIS MOVIE!\nThe acting is mostly terrible. Pattinson is not believable as Batman. The villains are one dimensional. Kravitz as Catwoman is the lone bright spot.\nHowever bad the acting is, the script worse. The whole thing is about three hours too long (which is impressive for a the hour movie). The editing was clearly done by a depressed, crack smoking monkey as that is the only way to explain the sheer insanity that is the bloated length of this monstrosity.

"The Batman" emerges as a visually striking and atmospherically rich interpretation of the iconic superhero. The film's grim, dark tone sets a captivating stage, enhanced by stunning visuals that perfectly encapsulate Gotham's brooding essence. The actors deliver standout performances, bringing fresh depth to familiar characters. Notably, the action sequences are intense and expertly crafted, adding to the film's gripping nature.\nHowever, the movie's final act deviates sharply from its established tone, presenting a jarring contrast. This segment feels almost like a caricature of a Batman movie, lacking the subtlety and coherence of the earlier parts. This incongruity mars what could have been a consistently powerful rendition of the Batman saga. As such, while the film starts strong and offers a refreshing take on the superhero, its concluding portion leaves a mixed impression, detracting from the overall experience.

I watched The Batman last night on Netflix.
When I started I didn't realize it was 3 hours long.
Oof!
Well. I did make it to the end. It's a good movie. I sort of mash up all the different Batmans (Batmen?). I don't really think of the fact the actors change is a problem. I like Bale as an actor so I liked his Batman.
This guy Pattinson is good. I've not watched the twilight movies so he was new to me. You get to see a whole lot of him as Batman, and a little as Bruce. He does have a presence. It's interesting to what how he physically changes as he moves back and forth between Batman and Bruce.
It's a very noir movie. More of a detective story than anything. It's quite clever in how it's done. And the Riddler role is pretty awesome.
I don't know the comics. I did watch and love the series "Gotham" and so the plot here is familiar because of that. I know the basic story already from Gotham.
I loved Gotham and throughout watching The Batman I kept being reminded of it and especially the Riddler and Penguin characters (Gotham was just so fun and campy).
I think if I'd not watched Gotham I might have struggled a bit with what is going on in the fourth act of The Batman.
The Batman is grim and dark. The fourth act comes out of nowhere and feels weirdly disjointed. I knew it was coming of course (sic) but by then you're way over two hours in and pretty much worn out.
Still there's a hint of a sequel. I would watch it.
I'm also tempted to watch some of my favorite Gotham eps again.
I recommend this movie with the caveat there's some violence and that it is long. Really long.

READ THIS FIRST: although Robert Pattinson has done some very good movies, his brooding along with everything else they asked of him in this film is absolutely dreadful. It's made even worse by Jeffrey Wright's astonishing ass kissing portrayal of Commissioner Gordon. Alfred does a good job and Colin Farrell's penguin is quite impressive but it's so poorly written and fit into the script that it's a completely wasted device and pointless avenue of the story. Scenery and set design although extremely dystopian and bleak is also somehow a little warm and very lavish. It's for the few upsides to this absolute dumpster fire. At 2 hours into the movie you know your life would have been better had you stopped watching an hour ago and then you realize you have one more hour to go still. At this point, the best ending to the movie might be a warm bath and a toaster. Skip this film, or maybe watch the first half hour if you want a clear understanding of what wasting a half hour is.

Robert Pattinson has destroyed the Batman franchise. He is a terrible and undoubtedly the worst actor who's played Batman. I don't understand why they would chose someone who looks like he's going through puberty to play such an iconic character. Robert, please step away from playing any superhero characters in the future. You've ruined the reputation of an amazing character. Aside from the huge eyesore throughout the movie, I believe this film had a great story line. To the director Matt Reeves going forward, if I may suggest I would use someone like Robert Pattinson to start in the next Planet of the Apes film as an extra. Matt I'm truly grateful you did not get to ruin Man of Steel.

Title: A Dark Descent into Cinematic Chaos
The recent Batman movie, touted as a beacon of superhero cinema, is nothing short of a catastrophic disappointment. From the opening credits to the final scene, this film manages to obliterate any expectations one might have had for a coherent and engaging storyline.
Let's start with the screenplay, an incoherent mess that seems to have been cobbled together by a group of amateurs in a hurry to meet a deadline. The dialogue is cringe-worthy, with characters spouting off lines that feel like rejected scraps from a high school drama class. Batman, once an iconic symbol of brooding intensity, now comes off as a caricature of himself, uttering lines that are more likely to induce laughter than fear.
The film's attempt at a dark and gritty atmosphere falls flat on its face. Instead of a nuanced exploration of the psychological depths of the Caped Crusader, we're treated to a haphazard collection of dimly lit scenes that do nothing to enhance the overall mood. It's as if the filmmakers mistook shadows for substance, leaving the audience squinting in confusion rather than leaning forward in anticipation.
And let's not forget the so-called plot twists that feel more like desperate attempts to salvage a sinking ship. The narrative is riddled with contrivances that strain credulity, leaving the viewer wondering if the writers even bothered to think through the implications of their choices. Any semblance of logical progression is sacrificed for the sake of shock value, resulting in a story that feels disjointed and unsatisfying.
The cinematography, touted as a highlight by some, is nothing more than a misguided attempt at artistic flair. The excessive use of shaky cam and frenetic editing serves only to induce nausea rather than immerse the audience in the action. It's a shame that the visuals become a distraction, as there is little else to salvage from this cinematic wreckage.
In conclusion, the latest Batman movie is a train wreck of epic proportions. From the abysmal screenplay to the muddled cinematography, every aspect of this film contributes to its descent into mediocrity. Die-hard fans of the Dark Knight may find themselves questioning their allegiance after enduring this cinematic travesty. Save yourself the agony and skip this disastrous chapter in the Batman franchise.

The Batman tells the story of a Batman who is one-track minded in his mission of revenge, and offers an emotional story arc of him learning empathy and the difference between justice and revenge.
Every Batman reboot comes with a new approach to its aesthetic. Burton's phantasmagorical vision to Shumacher's neon amusement park attraction to Nolan's militaristic hyperrealism, now we have a "goth-noir" aesthetic from Matt Reeves echoing The Crow and Blade Runner. It fits and is an engaging world to immerse yourself in.
The technical aspects are strongest suit here -- great color schemes and cinematography, detailed production design full of hidden features, an excellent moody musical score which is the most uncharacteristically minimalist of any Batman score (which are usually rollicking), and, most significantly, the best fight choreography and arguably the best action sequences of any Batman film. They are filmed openly and beautifully, without the headache-inducing quick-cut jackhammer editing of Nolan's fight sequences. Here Batman may take out a dozen enemies without a single edit. I'm so happy for this -- I prefer fight sequences to be filmed in wider angles and without edits, and Reeves films this so artfully. The action overall is so well-grounded too by the film's expertly mapped pacing, which still overall feels more like a smooth detective noir that happens to have moments of great action.
My criticisms are minor. I did have difficulty adjusting to a Batman who doesn't even put in the smallest morsel of effort into his Bruce Wayne persona. There's virtually no "Bruce Wayne" in this film, he's Batman almost the entire time and even out of suit behaves like a moody caped crusader, not disguising himself at all. Pattinson's performance is wooden and his feminine body type is a bit awkward as Batman -- honestly I think Pattinson would've made a better Terry in a Batman Beyond adaptation (he even looks like Terry).
But he's not so awful to bring me out of the movie. And I DO like that they've depicted a far more unhinged Batman. Almost every Batman film hints that, without his money and his virtues, Batman would just be another Arkham Asylum villain -- but this is the only film that seems to SHOW it tangibly. So one when the Riddler says that Batman is just like him -- you actually believe it.
There is great acting from the supporting cast too -- Toturro as Falcone and his people are the most Scorsese-esque we've seen from depictions of Gotham's mafia. Paul Dano is an absolute force of nature in this film and is perfectly over-the-top. Zoe Kravitz is the most grounded Catwoman we've ever had as she is depicted as sane and in control -- and far moreso than this unhinged version of Batman. And while Colin Farrel is underused and a bit underglorified as Cobblepot -- protrayed as just another gangster instead of a true Gotham villain -- he still disappears into the role (i wouldn't expect anything less from that fine performer, of course)
So I was very impressed by this version of Batman. I'm very glad I watched it. At first having a reboot so soon after Nolan's version kept me away from it, but don't let that stop you. This is a fine installment in the Batman legacy.

Dear Hollywood,
If you want to know how blue collar hardworking people act and talk, try doing some research and meeting some instead of guessing. You clearly have no clue. Pretty much sums up the film. A horrible story of what people "think" us poor working folk are like. Disgusting display of how Hollywood views society outside their bubble. There is no depth to these characters past stereotypical cliches. Most of people don't have rich parents that offer them options, like college, law school, and clerking, beyond this type of work. They do it because they have to, not to "find" themselves.
Some great actors and actresses, just a really bad script, disjointed story and unreal dialogue. The performers past work is why I gave more than one star. Most of these people are good, but in other things.
After the ship sank and they were joking and laughing while being rescued and then went straight to the bar to party, I knew the writers had no clue. Do the creators have any idea how bad it is for a captain and crew that lost their vessel? Let me just say they would not be joking and partying. Please...

I'm from New Bedford. The accents were horrendous. We don't sound like that. It was like listening to SNL skit with Fallon and Dratch. No mention of Portuguese community (almost EVERYONE is Portuguese here), other than a cookout with linguica. No real storyline. Waste of Tim Daly's talent. Scenery was beautiful. I recognized every shot! Editing, acting, writing all bad, including TLJ. Painfully long. Insulting to the actual residents of the New Bedford area. Ortega was driving on the bike trail....yeah that's realistic. They had the potential to be amazing, and blew it. Fishing is indeed dangerous. The scenes at sea looked completely CGI. Skip this and watch reruns of Cheers and Wings if you want to see Massachusetts.

This starts out as others have said, a little slow. Some viewers may feel they can predict the plot line and some viewers will be right. But being from Maine and having known fisherman, the new Bedford filming location is perfect and the choice of actors was well done. Having two of the leads coming from the Boston area helped the other actors lend authenticity to their characters. Their performances were very strong. They portray the toughness of those in the fishing community very well. Adding Tommy Lee Jones to the cast was a good addition. I would have given this a 7.5 but I don't know how. Watch it. You'll be glad you did.

My only big complaint is the movie takes a sudden turn in tone about half an hour in. Like Mabel's outlash didn't completely make sense or felt out of the blue. We'd only spent like a minute with her, maybe we should have gotten to know her a little bit more. But other than that I don't think the movie was too bad, but it's not anything remarkable either. I just wasn't as bored as other people seem to have been.
It's an okay watch, had a solid story. Maybe the father-son and step-brother relations could've been explored deeper, it felt like the movie was just telling a story which was somewhat interesting, but didn't hit the emotional chords for me.
There's a little decent love story going on and personally I'm a sucker for those so I'm a little more upset than warranted about this next bit. It's just upsetting that almost ever time Mabel popped it, it always felt like the writers thought we already know all about her, more than we actually do, we barely spent anytime with her but when she's on screen she's like the focus of the movie, her issues. Jenna Ortega was much better than Mabel, she should've been written way better. But in general, I could say that about all the actors, it felt like they thought they were in a much better movie.
But the movies okay. It's sort of feels like two movies in one. Maybe more. From all the subplots, you could probably make two or three movies out of it that were more insightful and took a deeper dive into the characters, their lives, their relationships and dilemmas. Instead it's all neatly parked into one forgettable one. I think it should've picked one genre and maybe leaned into it more, making it a crime thriller, romance or family drama, just to give the movie more character. The movie just felt like it's made up of sub plots. I didn't hate it, I wasn't bored, and I've seen much worse. Felt indifferent to it.

This was enjoyable movie. Yes a lot takes place but it all has its conclusion and closure. The open plots that actually lead somewhere and are closed. For all it does, the movie does not leave loose ends and i applaud it for it.
The cast does good enough and characters are well written. You get a good idea about each pretty fast and they remain consistent throughout.
This is part drama, part adventure, part crime, part love story, part fishing documentary. It has it all and it really works at the end, surprisingly enough. Perhaps one of the big aspects is that it is a feel good movie ultimately and leaves you content at the end.
I understand if you compare it to THE PERFECT STORM expecting hardcore fishing life simulator you will be disappointed. This is not it. This is a movie about a fishing boat crew that get in a spiral of trouble and dig out of it through various ways. The journey to that redemption is the road of self discovery some of the characters take.
7/10 will pose for the canadian coast guard daily.

Saw Tommy Lee and wanted to watch this and so glad I did. Slow start but picks up as it goes along. I love the New England area and this was no different as the setting was beautiful ocean views in harbor towns. Two brothers with different fathers grow up in the same town years apart. The younger brother wants desperately to spend time with the older one and it all starts out great but trouble soon follows. This movie packs an emotional punch about what family means and the things they do to each other and for each other. It also shows us that our kids don't necessarily want to live the lives we want for them and we need to listen to what they are saying. Worth watching.

Directed and written by Brian Helgeland. A runtime of two hours and six minutes. Streaming on Paramount+ with an R rating.
"Tom" played by Ben Foster is a fisherman off the Massachusetts coast. He follows in his father "Eldridge" played by Tommy Lee Jones's footsteps. After "Tom" step brother "Charlie" played by Toby Wallace comes to work with him for the summer a string of horrible events take place.
With one horrible event after the next, you would think "Charlie" would be discouraged. On top of his father "Gary" played by Tim Daly urging him not to. But he's even more enthralled by the idea of being like his older brother and becoming a fisherman.
"Charlie" falls in love with the local drug dealer "Mabel" played by Jenna Ortega. He gets close with his brother's crew. "Costa" played by Ismael Cruz Cordova, "Skeemo" played by Aaron Stanford, and "Nunes" played by Scotty Tovar.
Will "Charlie" throw his promising potential career of being a lawyer aside to reconnect with his brother "Tom"? Will the endless issues of this summer be worth it in the end? Find out in this fisherman thriller.
"Finestkind" wasn't what I imagined it to be. I saw Jenna Ortega in it. My daughter and I are huge fans of hers. Unfortunately, this wasn't one of her better films.
This was a mixture of the films "Contraband", which also starred Ben Foster, and "Perfect Storm". Which starred Ben Foster co-star in "Contraband", Mark Wahlberg.
This film was boring and kind of stupid for the better half of it. It was obvious "Charlie" was the issue. None of these problems arose until he showed up. Let's be clear you're going to give up going to Boston Law and have a promising future to be a fisherman.
Don't get me wrong fishermen make decent money but nothing near what he would make being a lawyer. His brother seems to not have much and he's the captain. Your girlfriend doesn't seem to have it all upstairs if you know what I mean and she's a drug dealer. Following in her mother's footsteps. He should be running in the opposite direction not trying to lay a foundation down. For "Charlie" to be so smart he sure is dumb.
A lot of the acting wasn't the greatest. You could tell apart the seasoned actors from the novice ones. The tale end of the film got a little more interesting but it still was predictable. This was a streaming film you could pass on. These actors have given you other material that would serve you better than watching this.
This also goes back to me saying not everyone can write and direct a film. Sometimes, a lot of time they're the only ones who can see or understand their vision. Sadly another film my daughter and I did not enjoy watching. I give this film two mor fires ðŸ”¥ðŸ”¥.

Who would be so ridiculous as to commit a serious crime to pay a fine for a serious crime? Fishermen, it seems. The point here, though, is to show the romantic pull of a life of fishing and, perhaps more importantly, the inexhaustible love of a father for his son. Despite the critics, the dialogue and the acting was fine, especially by Clayne Crawford as the chief bad guy and Tommy Lee Jones as an old fisherman. It's got the Taylor Sheridan touch, too. Not a great film, but the scenes of the New Bedford harbor and the handling of a catch of scallops added to a story replete with plot holes and characters who should know better.

Poor script. Bad acting. Unrealistic scenarios. ClichÃ©d. Cheap version of the Perfect Storm. I could go on and on...\nFor the most part, the cast is a bunch of nobodies. Fittingly so, since the script is garbage. This story has been told dozens of times, and all others were better. Fake, grizzled fishermen are stranded at sea after their boat sinks (surprise). While waiting to be rescued, they are cracking jokes and having a "grand ol' time" in a lifeboat. When they return to town, do they run to the relieved arms of their worried families? No, they go to a bar and start drinking!\nHonestly, this is better suited for a Lifetime made-for-TV movie. Don't waste your time!

I get making a mistake or two or even having a ton of bad luck, but seriously everyone in the movie are just morons. Hell, I saw the whole cast (literally a stacked roster) and I am dumbfounded by how they could say yes to such a weak script. Like pick a damn lane: coming of age? Blue collar drama? Drug trafficking? Connecting with a dying loved one? They have it all and barely get 10% of all of them developed. Finally, Jenna Ortega's character was reduced to just like a cheesy horror movie sex symbol (like the one in AvP). Like seriously, it's Jenna Ortega, no need to reduce her to a townie chick. And Toby Wallace has been given his worse role in his entire career. Like seriously, I get supporting a brother, but following him to do stupid decisions is not being supportive, you are probably doing more harm than good. I highly suggest against watching this movie.

Home Alone 3 was a terrible movie. This movie is dull and boring, not much even happens. Without Macaulay Culkin, this film is lifeless and bland. If this had Macaulay Culkin in this, this would certainly be be a better movie. Usally the bedt part about a Home Alone movie is when the kid pranks the robber. This time, when the kid pranks the robbers it isnisn't even funny and it is dull and boring. The only reason this heap of trash is good is because the kid is cute. That's it. This is my least favorite Home Alone ever. If you ever want to watch all of the Home Alone movies, trust me don't unless you like to watch bad movie. I would not recommend this to anyone, especially fans of the first two Home Alones. In all, I give this movie a 2.5 out of 10.

Some movies don't age well when you get to adulthood, but the first two movies still hold up for me as someone being 40+. But the humor in this movie is so vastly different. Yes, you have to suspend your disbelief when watching the previous movies somewhat, and for me, that's OK. I wasn't expecting realism when watching this movie. But when you have anthropomorphic animals communicating as if they understand humans, then that's too much for me as an adult. I'm sure any 8 year old will love this movie though!\nWhat I also don't appreciate is the scope of the movie. The first two movies involved two seriously inept burglars. Here the 8 year old protagonist is dealing with a crime syndicate.

Fun
Good premise
Good baddies
Lovable smart kids.
Lots of fun, my son loves it. And we do too.
Good premise and storyline. Believable and far fetchef all at the same time!
Good baddies, in the sense you're happy to see their demise..silly but kid still feels under threat.
Kid is super lovable, and smart just like Kevin but still different enough. Naturally his sibling are not and help!
Give it a go and get over the fact it's not Kevin and the original characters.
It was hard to follow the best Christmas movie of all time. But this is definitely a great family watch in it's own right. Give it a go!

Rat is named Doris, what else could you want?\nThis movie is the cream of the crop for the Home Alone franchise. Macaulay Culkin could never show the acting depth of the kid who played Alex. "Home Alone 3" delivers an entertaining and laughter-filled experience for audiences of all ages. This third installment in the beloved franchise takes a fresh approach, introducing a new set of characters and an exciting plot that keeps you engaged from start to finish.
The story revolves around Alex Pruitt, a clever and resourceful eight-year-old who finds himself home alone while recovering from an illness. Unbeknownst to him, a group of international criminals are after a top-secret computer chip that has accidentally ended up in his possession. As the burglars relentlessly pursue the chip, Alex uses his wit and an array of inventive traps to defend his home and outsmart the criminals.
What sets "Home Alone 3" apart is its ability to capture the essence of the original film while injecting it with a fresh twist. The new cast of characters, led by the talented Alex D. Linz as Alex Pruitt, brings a different dynamic to the story. Linz's portrayal of Alex is both endearing and hilarious, making him a relatable and admirable hero. The chemistry among the cast members is palpable, adding depth to the comedic moments and creating a sense of camaraderie that is enjoyable to watch.
Director Raja Gosnell masterfully balances humor, action, and heart throughout the film. The comedic timing is impeccable, with slapstick gags and clever one-liners that will have you laughing out loud. The action sequences are well-choreographed and keep you at the edge of your seat, as Alex's ingenuity and quick thinking are put to the test. The film also manages to incorporate themes of friendship, bravery, and the importance of family, giving it a heartwarming touch.
Visually, "Home Alone 3" is a treat, with vibrant cinematography and impressive set designs. The film maintains a fast pace, ensuring that there is never a dull moment. The soundtrack perfectly complements the on-screen action, enhancing the comedic and thrilling elements.
While "Home Alone 3" may lack some of the nostalgia associated with its predecessors, it stands on its own as a highly entertaining family comedy. With a captivating plot, a talented cast, and a blend of humor and heart, this movie is a delightful addition to the franchise. Whether you're a fan of the original films or new to the series, "Home Alone 3" is sure to bring joy and laughter to your movie-watching experience.

I don't like this movie but I don't hate it either. I have fond memories from watching it on VHS as a child and I decided to rewatch it this Christmas. I can honestly say I laughed more than I thought I would. Some of the jokes actually landed and the traps was pretty creative. As for the kid who set them.. They portrayed him as a kid genius with an IQ of 250 and I didn't really buy it. I didn't believe he was as clever and cunning as the creators wanted me to believe.\nAnd the villains overplayed their roles.. Honestly it was painful to watch most of the time. Yes, the characters from the original movies was always over the top but still within reason... And they had charm.. Something this one was sorely lacking.\nDespite all this I don't hate this movie, I would place it somewhere between mediocre and bad. I have seen lots of horrible movies in my life and I actually find this one tolerable.

Yes.. yes I know, it isn't as classic as the first Home Alone. Yes there's no Macaulay Culkin. The first movie has a nostalgic warmth and comfort, the same as a familiar bed or blanket or room. But for me, I watched this one the most as a kid and there for the nostalgia is strong. But even now as an adult, I enjoy this film. The plot is the best of the three (we don't talk about what came after three). I find Home Alone 2's plot just way too unbelievable and even though there are plot elements in three that are far fetched I just find it more watchable now as an adult. The booby traps are also far more funnier in my opinion and I like the idea of him trying to capture the crooks on film using his R. C car, however daft that may be. Plus Alex. D. Linz does a fine job.

This one is the in between film, number 4 was just an embarrassment and heist and the new one aren't much better, whilst 1/2 are obviously way out ahead for nostalgia I actually don't think this one is a bad film.
If timing was different this could've been more well received or if it hadn't have been part of their HA franchise. As a stand alone there are definite wins for 3 for some of the best moments of the series.
I like the storyline, it was more fleshed out and suited the cheesy 90s era, from music to presentation I liked that, whilst Harry and especially Marv are iconic I don't think they had much to work with. Here the 4 protagonists are a mixed bag, the leader plays the part well, the long haired guy was presented like marv was and the other guy for me was a bit redundant. However the lady playing Alice was excellent, from mannerisms to comedic timing I thought she made this movie.
Family wise it felt more natural, the kids in the original aren't good at acting, the family scenes felt more real yet again the dad has minimal impact, does the writer have daddy issues? Whilst the family is hard to compare as neither did much, when I objectively thought about the two kids, I actually preferred Alex, he felt more of a real kid, although Kevin has a piece of my heart I just felt this was more akin to being a child. Whilst neither are superb actors, this felt more natural again.
The pranks felt more realistic where Kevin's Would take hours to prepare, these were more brutal, creative and fun, I hate panning away and not seeing the impact but I guess it would not look great. Some of the ones in this were even better than the big 2.
I'm unsure about the team behind the franchise and their motive, you read in 4 they reached out to marv who literally tore the film apart and then they just recast him but dressed him as Harry, the obsession with the older angry looking adult who always turns out nice, there's a lot of lazy writing and stale components.
If this had have come out under a different name itd be sitting on a 7 atleast.

People always get use to nostalgia and prefer the original, and stubbornly accept that any reboot or sequel with a different cast is worst.
For starter Alex is way better than Kevin, 1 vs 4 enemy, even Kevin always have help from another ally.
And the pace of this movie is perfect. The villains origin are quickly showcase, and how they are shown to be intimidated and real, unlike the Wet Bandits who's a Joke.
The action/pranks are greatly done. The remote control car action on the second act was nicely done. And honestly, think the pranks for the third act was better than both Home Alone, and it was about 30 minutes long. That's tons of action.
Plus, you have Scarlet Johansson.

I've watched this mutlple times a year since we've been able to pull up our favorite movies. Now as a screenwriter and currently working on my first film The Godfather has been one of the films that has taking my storytelling to another level. It has all the components to a perfect screenplay.\nWatching old interviews and blogs on the making of the films really made it more interesting to watch. Breaking down why wouldn't they wouldn't want Al Pacino and other actors for their roles. The battle with Marlon Brando. The real connection to the mob. Not to mention the constant battle with the studio. Francis quitting multiple times, etc. All that was needed to cook up up this classic.

From the very opening scenes to the final, breathtaking moments, this trilogy of movies has left an indelible mark on my cinematic experience. Spanning over three hours in each installment, this trilogy is a mesmerizing journey through the rise of a mafia boss and his evolution, making it an absolute must-see for any film enthusiast.
The narrative is richly woven with intricate details that paint a vivid picture of the protagonist's ascent to power. The depth of character development in each movie is unparalleled. Witnessing the transformation of the main character from a humble individual to a formidable mafia boss was a riveting experience. The portrayal of emotions, conflicts, and moral dilemmas was both raw and authentic, allowing me to connect profoundly with the characters.
The storytelling prowess of the director and the stellar performances by the cast elevated this trilogy to a league of its own. Each scene was meticulously crafted, keeping me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire duration. The cinematography was nothing short of breathtaking, capturing the essence of both grandeur and grittiness, giving a visceral feel to the storyline.
What truly sets this trilogy apart is its ability to immerse the audience into the world of organized crime without glorifying it. The depth and complexity of the characters highlight their vulnerabilities and humanizes their actions, making their journey relatable despite the criminal backdrop.
The pacing of the trilogy was masterful, seamlessly weaving together various plotlines and subplots that kept me engaged and invested in every moment. The director's attention to detail in connecting events across the three movies was commendable, creating a cohesive and impactful narrative that crescendoed beautifully.
Moreover, the soundtrack was simply sublime, complementing the emotional depth of the storyline perfectly. From haunting melodies during moments of introspection to pulse-pounding beats during intense sequences, the music heightened the overall cinematic experience, leaving an everlasting impression.
I cannot emphasize enough the impact this trilogy had on me. It's not just about the rise of a mafia boss; it's a gripping tale of ambition, power, loyalty, and the complexities of human nature. The underlying themes of redemption and the price of success resonate long after the credits roll.
In conclusion, this trilogy is a cinematic masterpiece that deserves accolades for its exceptional storytelling, brilliant performances, and its ability to captivate and transport its audience into a world filled with moral dilemmas and conflicting emotions. It's an incredible journey that I would highly recommend to anyone seeking an unforgettable movie experience. This trilogy isn't just a must-see; it's a must-experience.

"The Godfather" is an undeniable cinematic masterpiece that flawlessly weaves a tale of power, family, and organized crime. Marlon Brando's iconic performance as Vito Corleone is nothing short of mesmerizing, while the film's intricate storytelling and compelling characters leave an indelible mark. Francis Ford Coppola's direction, coupled with a stellar cast, creates a timeless classic that transcends the crime genre. The meticulous attention to detail and a haunting musical score contribute to the film's enduring impact, making it a must-watch for any cinephile. Moreover, the film's portrayal of the mafia underworld is both gritty and authentic, painting a vivid picture of a world governed by its own set of rules!

\The Godfather (1972) is one of the greatest films ever made. It is an iconic classic that has been revered and loved by fans for decades. The film follows the rise of the Corleone family in the 1940s and 1950s and the struggles they face with the criminal underworld. The story is compelling and the performances are outstanding, particularly Marlon Brando's iconic portrayal of Don Vito Corleone. The direction by Francis Ford Coppola is masterful and the cinematography by Gordon Willis is breathtaking. The Godfather is a masterpiece of cinema that should not be missed. It is a film that will stay with you forever. Highly recommended.

There are simply no words to express how great this film truly is! How can one still watch this film made in 1972 today?
Very few films are able to achieve what the Godfather did, most aspiring actors look up to this movie as an inspiration and attempt to do what each actor was able to do in this film.
The movie is simply timeless and a huge reason why Al Pacino became a huge star. It is almost impossible to find any shortcomings in the film as all the performances were extremely organic and rarely felt scripted.
Last but certainly not the least, thank you to Marlon Brando, who did not just give us one of the most iconic movie posters of all-time but also hooked you to the screen whenever he came on and embodied the role of an aged mafia don with the utmost conviction.
A masterpiece of cinema, this.

One of the best films of all time, an absolute masterpiece. The Godfather is arguably the best gangster drama.
You should watch and Feeling.
I think this is an all-time famous work, most of the world has heard of it or read it.
So excellent that it makes me read this classic over and over again.
In Asian countries, this work is considered an excellent work that teachers, especially in the field of economics, will often recommend to their students. It's great to have read the work so many times. Time.
Believe me, you should read it more than once to understand it thoroughly about The Godfarther.

This film is considered a real classic of cinema, is it the greatest film of all time? Let's see. The 1940s setting is wonderfully recreated here in the fashions, the cars, the interior set decorations. The film all is a very good looking one, I loved the colours, the textures, the use of shadow. This is a long film, and I did think the wedding scene goes on too long. The film also gives us both an inside and outside perspective on the family using various techniques. Certain lines have become iconic and I also enjoyed the fact that there was some great character development. Our main character's instance that he is not his family starts to ring hollow as he becomes increasingly drawn into their murky world. Power corrupts too in this movie and I loved the performances in this film, they are so much more subtle than you might think. I thought that James Caan is brilliant in this movie, the sun drenched photography when the story also moves to Italy looks gorgeous. The soundtrack in this film is also something you cannot associate with anything other than this genera. While the film is technically superb it's really the deep theme within this movie that leave the most lasting impression.

I'll just start this review by saying this is the best movie ever made and I am not ashamed to say that. I don't care what other people say. The fact that this movie was made in the 70s makes it even more impressive. They didn't have the equipment and the camera and audio quality that we have today, but that is not what makes this movie great.\nMario Puzo's writing combined with the direction and portray on the mafia by Francis Ford Coppola make this movie a complete must watch.\nIt may be long, but it is very much worth it. This along with The Godfather Part 2 are the best movies I've ever watched and the best movies ever made in the history of the movie industry.

"The Godfather, directed by the masterful Francis Ford Coppola, is a cinematic masterpiece that transcends its genre. Marlon Brando's portrayal of the enigmatic Don Vito Corleone is a masterclass in acting, radiating power and vulnerability. The film's intricate storytelling, rich character development, and haunting score by Nino Rota contribute to its timeless allure. As we witness the Corleone family's evolution, led by Al Pacino's Michael, the narrative becomes an operatic exploration of power, loyalty, and the consequences of choices. The Godfather's influence on filmmaking is profound, setting the standard for crime epics. The meticulous attention to detail, coupled with stellar performances, crafts an immersive experience that lingers in the mind long after the credits roll. It's a cinematic symphony of storytelling, making The Godfather not just a movie but a cultural landmark that continues to captivate generations of film enthusiasts."

Proof positive if any were needed that sequels are generally pointless / useless.
The movie is almost 3 hours and could have benefited from editing all 3 hours out aka not released at all.
The dialogue and acting is wooden, yes, I get it that this movie is not supposed to make too much sense, but still having a semblance of a plot and a semblance of acting, direction, coherence, continuity would be a basic element of a movie.
Overall, not at all sure what on earth prompted people to give a high rating of 7 odd for this title.
As an earlier reviewer put it, 3 hours of the movie is like three hours of torture. Yeah!

Hitherto I have enjoyed all the outings of John Wick. But this episode was disappointing. I am usually very drawn in to the story and the action, but I was frequently bored during this film. The fight scenes were not as snappy as they usually are in John Wick movies. Many of the foes appeared not to have particularly strong or indeed any fighting skills. They were just goons to be dispatched with no sense of peril to John, even with John appearing to have very stiff joints in this film. There were attempts to make us care about the various characters, but these fell flat, as in this film the characters were cartoonish sketches, rather than someone we could have any feelings about. Over and over again, scenes were just a lazy nod to earlier themes. For example, the procurement of battle clothes and weapons which in previous episodes has been entertaining, was on this occasion very dull and looked like a careless afterthought.

I am a huge fan of the Wick franchise. I knew what Chapter 4 was going to deliver (or not) since I no longer go to the cinema, but rather wait for movies to stream. As others have said before, the plot is thin and in the background. The fights are front and center, are too long, and get tedious. I had to split the movie over two nights to make it through...and this comes from a guy who will watch Chapters 1 thru 3 every time they're on tv. This was a sad struggle to sit through. The stellar cast was wasted in this sequel. I see many complaints about dancers in the nightclubs or cars around the Arch de Triumph not noticing the kills around them. Since Ch 1, I've assumed this is an alternate reality (like a video game) where assassins run amok around the NPCs, and that is how it is supposed to appear in this version of NYC or this version of Paris. They are not the same versions of these cities if we were to travel there on vacation, so I can get past that. The script for this movie could not have been more than 5 pages of dialogue. Besides the repeat of "I need guns. Lots of guns." and "Yeah...", there isn't much else. Winston gets off a one-liner now and then, but that's it.\nAs a mega-fan, I cannot recommend that other mega-fans spend their 2 hours and 50 minutes on this steaming pile.

After three films you might think that John wick has run out of ideas and everything gets a bit samey. Sure it can be like that but in a good way. This franchise really does have so much to give and this fourth chapter is no difference. From the get go there's an explosion and tow close lives threatened. Wick comes back and we see the series latest villain played by Bill skarsgard, who is very convincing as one. The fights scenes are great as always especially the French Vs Asians fight. Also wick getting bolted down the stairs has some almost comic relief. Overall with the cast and everything John wick is still one of the greatest action series in modern times.

If you want to waste 2,5 hours of your life watching a series of complete unrealistic shooting scenes with no plot, this is your chance. They had tons of posibilities, money, time and expectations to make this a great movie. Instead they give us nothing but shooting and a cheap plot. Like another reviewer said it; it's like playing a video game on Â«easyÂ»-mode. Unrealistic scenes, effects and, again, useless plot. Some of the main charaters seems hard to understand the necessity of and the hitmens (or whatever you call the guys that shows up out of nowhere with a gun) miss the target standing 2 meters away from John. I'd rather watch the first movie again a couple of times in stead of this rubbish. Please don't waste your precious time on this.

WOW!
Mega-cool fight scenes (no wonder when Marko ZAROR and Scott ADKINS are part of the cast), magnificent sets (gorgeous: the cherry blossoms and the Shogun Museum in Osaka), beautiful shots (the fight scenes from above: great!) and then that Ride in the humming roundabout at the Triumphal Arch followed by a climb up the stairs to the Sacre-Coeur! Chad STAHELSKI knows exactly what he wants. And he delivers mercilessly!
But STUDIO BABELSBERG takes the cake with the magnificent backdrop of the Berlin club HIMMEL UND HÃ–LLE. Just big! Plus Scott ADKINS with the performance (and mask) of his life! You have to see how the dancers in the club integrate the beating, shooting and murdering killers into their own performances (better yet: ignore them)! It is breathtaking how STUDIO BABELSBERG has developed since the mega success of THE PIANIST (Golden Palm, several OSCARs). I definitely won't be able to forget this set.
The story? Well, as usual. Completely different things matter here. A discovery for me is Shamier ANDERSON with his cuddly dog. I'm glad I saw this battle record on the big screen!

The review of siderite is spot on. No plot, no storyline, slow or pointless dialogues. But what irked me the most in the 2.5 hours of the same shooting scenes is that apparently the whole world was filled with NPCs. Imagine going into a club, knifing, shooting or axing 50 people on the dance floor... Yet everybody keeps dancing. Or shooting 50 assassins and destroying 20 cars or the roundabout of the Arc de Triomphe... Yet no police shows up and everybody keeps driving as if there is nothing wrong. That roundabout has troubles digesting normal traffic that don't need to worry about dodging cars, bullets and brain from all of the head-shots. I didn't think the third sequel to the (brilliant) first movie would be worse that the other sequels but the last 2.5 hours of my life proved me wrong.

I am a total John Wick Keanu Reeves Fan! I have watched every chapter and these movies Never Fail to deliver on Action so much so that I rate them the Top of the list for Action movies there are not any better! Everyone will have their own favourites in the John Wick franchise chapter 4 is not my favourite but it is still class and worthy of the star rating of 8 imo! I hope Keanu is in chapter 5 as he for me is John Wick and it would be difficult to envisage another actor that could fill his boots in that role his overall knowledge of so many fighting skills shows! I will watch all 4 movies again whilst awaiting chapter 5!

This was an extremely well produced and well written and well directed production in every manner! Everything about this production was extremely professional and well thought out and mindful and the acting was superb as well and the choice of actors was right on the money for the roles that were played and I cannot think of a previous movie from the John wick series of movies that was even close to the thoughtfulness that went into this John wick 4 movie and they really outdid themselves this way because usually when a movie goes on and on like this through several reiterations it loses something but this one actually gained a lot and that's quite unique.

Considering the genre, the action is not bad until the discotheque fight scene. It kills the movie. Please just give us a little bit of realism. When people are murdered on a dance floor, other patrons usually leave the premise. Just saying. Awful.\nThe same thing seemed to happen in previous wick movies too. The first and second were ok and then it's all downhill from there. Kill Bill looked more realistic than this. I don't understand the necessity to push the enveloppe this far into exaggeration. I understand it is cartoonish, but even Batman movies had some limits on where to draw the line.

At a rating of 7.2 I expected it to be good but it is at totally the opposite end of the spectrum. It has clearly been voted highly by people who are impressed by swearing alone rather than any form of quality. With the use of the F word almost 180 times in the film and Sh** approaching 90 times in a 90 minute film - there is are two Fs and one S every minute ! I was ready to turn it off after the fist 15 minutes but thought it would get better because of the 7.2 rating but it never did - only worse. I am trying to think of something positive to say but I genuinely cant. It was just extremely bad in all ways.

Willie T. Soke (Billy Bob Thornton) is a raging alcoholic, who at Christmas, poses as a department store Santa Claus, while his dwarf partner-in-crime Marcus (Tony Cox), poses as an elf. When off duty, they case the department store they work at and rob it on Christmas Eve every year. When they're hired at the anchor store Chamberlain's at the Saguaro Square Mall in Phoenix, Arizona, Willie befriends a chubby, lonely boy named Thurman Merman (Brett Kelly) and a barmaid with Santa issues named Sue (Lauren Graham). But Willie and Marcus encounter an obstacle: mall security guard Gin Slagel (Bernie Mac), who muscles in on their action.
