Complete waste of time.

A young man in debt takes a job as a security guard in a restaurant. The robot dolls there have apparently developed a life of their own.
Note: I haven't played the underlying game so I can't make any comparisons.
If you ignore the opening scene, there is initially little that suggests a horror film. It's more like stripped-down drama elements that dominate the film, at least in the first half hour. The scenes that are supposed to be really frightening often fail to have an impact, especially since there is almost no blood shown. In general, the plot feels more geared towards the mystery genre, as does the personal story of the protagonist. The ending, despite the fact that it seems contrived, is watchable.
Somehow the film manages to entertain - at least once.

I didn't watch this right away like most fnaf fans, and was informed that it was going to be more like a comedy. Going into this movie with low expectations actually made the movie more enjoyable than it would have if I went in expecting a horror show. Overall, the movie was alright. This script felt kind of off, and all over the place, but the acting was actually alright, and the soundtrack was a total banger. The scariest part about this movie is balloon boy. That dude made me scream when he came on screen. This movie felt like a comedic treat to old fnaf fans, and I personally enjoyed watching it.

The movie had so much potential, and yet the result is absolute trash. Feels like a high school drama class wrote the script at a special education school. Acting is forced with weird camera angles. Whom ever green lit this project needs to be fired and sued for fraud waste and abuse. I wish you could give jail time for bad movies.\nI will say the only thing that I can commend this film on is the accuracy of a 90's chuck e Cheese. The set was spot on. The use a bal pit, disgusting carpet and neon lights was an exactly how I remembered. The woman who plays the cop should never work in any film ever again.

I am a lot older than FNAF's target demographic, but I'll admit, I had a phase where I was paying very close attention to the games. I could see there was a lot more going on beneath the surface than I think other people my age wanted to understand, and I could appreciate that. I never tumbled all the way down this rabbit hole like the kids did, but I knew enough.
This is a very technically competent movie but it feels 100% laser targeted at existing fans of Freddy Fazbear. There are so many parts that, for people under the age of 18, are undoubtedly big epic lore references. But the movie does not do an especially great job at bridging the gap to those a little less familiar with things. You get the broad strokes, I guess, but there are mysteries that got teased out over the course of 4-5 games that are bluntly one and done here. It's the sort of thing that's only interesting if you're already familiar with the source material.
Things about it feel really contrived for the sake of having a movie. Like the fact that Josh Hutcherson is over 30, but he's the big brother to a little girl who is maybe 8 years old? Mom and Dad don't seem to be in the picture anymore because, what, Mom gave birth when she was pushing 50? Or what about the whole thing with the guy taking drugs so he can repeatedly hallucinate the day his little brother was abducted in order to uncover some sort of deeper meaning? It's pretty bizarre.
Also how about the fact this movie just isn't scary? Like, at all? Even if you consider the games to be simple jump scare factories, the movie does an extremely poor job replicating that mood. It's too busy with fandom wish fulfillment to remember to be scary. I'm surprised they even bothered trying to show blood, because that is not the tone this movie is trying to convey.
I'm not even sure it's worth singing praise for Jim Henson Creature Shop here, given how simple these designs are, and how deliberately stiff and stilted the characters move. Feels like a waste of talent.
Honestly, as someone who used to like these games back in the day, I was ultimately pretty bored by this whole production. It wasn't necessarily offensive or anything, but it definitely was not good.

It goes without saying that my childhood has been impacted by the Five Nights at Freddy's franchise quite deeply. I used to talk to friends about each game and watch countless hours of theory videos. I even remember coming back from school each day, holding my breath when I refreshed the website showing sneak peaks of the next game.
The models of the animatronics were superb, they were nearly perfect. The only complaint I have is how their eyes just glowed a lame hue of orange whenever they got mad, which does not compare to the hollow white dots of the exoskeleton beneath that you'd constantly see in the franchise.
The story and characters were underwhelming. Not at one point throughout the movie did I feel like I genuinely cared about any of it, even though I tried to. There was no suspense, horror or fun. I even started to doze off near the end.
Overall, I do think that any fan of the franchise should give this movie a go, just for the sake of viewing more content. But, I do not recommend to people that haven't been invested from the start.

Love the movie but I dont know how to watch it, it just says "add to watchlist" But I have seen the movie somewhere else but I cant find it so thats why I downloaded this but I still cant watch it. If someone knows how I can watch it please tell me, I would love to see it again, but over all its a very good movie and its not that scary, I really recomend you watching this alone or with a friend or family member, its Great to watch during halloween, but still Great to watch any time around the year but as I said if someone can explain how you watch it then that would be Great, Recomend, fun movie 10/10.

I often wonder what people compare films to these days, what it "needs to achieve", in order to please them.
Yeah I get it, we are all different and like different things, but some films aren't exactly that hard to figure out, and what they're about, what they "try to do" is fairly obvious. This is one of those.
It's not terribly deep, it's not terribly complicated, it's just an entertaining ride through a fairly thin story. And to me, it doesn't try to be more and that's okay. It entertains and that's the purpose. The particular combination of a little horror, trying to be cute with a little message, entertainment, a splash of humor and some very decent effects, makes it sort of unique, despite not being a masterpiece.
So yes, I enjoyed it. And if you didn't, I think you watched a movie you were very well aware you shouldn't have watched.

Idk, i thought this movie is good bcs the rating is high for horror movie. But after i watched, i got nothing want to say.
Just the same as other mediocre horror movies. Teenagers did something stupid, got terror from demon, some characters dies, and just like that.
And how they using make up for the demons is kinda basic i guess. They can make more disturbing make up for the demons, maybe i can add more high rating for this movie. I think they just wanna to save budget.
And last, this movie never makes where this game appeared for the first time and how that can makes the devil summoned.....

The first half of this movie is incredibly effective with the concept of a bunch of teenagers having a real medium to communicate with the dead and filming themselves use it just for a laugh. Then one of their uses of the medium goes too far and problems arrive, that is great stuff.\nBut everything that happens after the possession gone awry is a bunch of predictable nonsense. It also doesn't help that the main character is so unlikeable and selfish that you don't care whether she lives or dies. It is not properly established if she is being controlled by demons but that's the only thing that could excuse her terrible decisions which could have just as easily been driven by a selfish desire to speak with her mom above all other peoples safety.\nI didn't hate watching this but the potential was there for something great and it was just not executed well at the half way point.

I should have known better than to expect some random Netflix horror to truly be excellent but based on the relatively positive reviews and claims how fresh the movie felt I was, admittedly, pretty optimistic going into it.
What I got was okay, but I really don't see what's so special about this film versus every other spirit-communication-gone-wrong genre piece before this.
On the surface this hand gimmick as the method of spirit communion seems fresh, but really it's just replacing the worn out Ouija board trope summons something evil with another communication mechanism. After that the rest of the movie falls in line with your typical story beats in relative lockstep.
The final sin for me is the movie is frankly just not very scary. I never jumped, I was never creeped out, I was never really intrigued - but at least I was never really bored so there's that.

I found this movie to be pretty effective in how it's executed. The story is interesting with teenagers able to contact spirits with a mysterious embalmed hand. I really like the idea of holding a mysterious hand to contact spirts and then say "I let you in" so it possessed that person. It really shows how it is a bad idea to do those types of things and how they affect someone. The movie is also a subject matter of grief and obsession with the main character losing her mother and wanting to contact her. It really shows how far someone can do in order to talk to a loved one again. The movie also works as a psychological horror with the main character struggling with her grief and obsession towards her mother and that hand throughout. It also affects her mental health and cause her to do some extreme stuff later on in the movie. The ending itself is pretty good on how it ends.

Talk to Me is an incredibly enjoyable watch, offering a breath of fresh air for both the horror genre and filmmaking in general. As a true directorial debut from Michael Philippou and Danny Philippou, it stands out as a great success. The film introduces a new and creative idea with a fun and energetic style, although there are some minor bumps along the way. The immersive world-building captivates viewers instantly, evoking a sense of wonder. The characters, portrayed by a talented cast, are relatable with both their strengths and flaws. Sophie Wilde's standout performance handles complex emotions with finesse. The scares are well-executed, avoiding cheap thrills and are instead blended seamlessly into the narrative. While some moments may elicit a humorous reaction depending on the viewing situation, the overall experience is enjoyable. The film strikes a balance in exploring its storyline without overexplaining or underexploring, which I feel is a great choice. Certain sequences are difficult to watch due to some intense and gruesome violence; however, I believe that because the film makes you feel this way, it adds to the experience and showcases the brilliance of how the film is crafted. Overall, it was a great film, and I would recommend everyone give it a chance.

This movie is a rare gem. It's been a long time since there was a horror movie this well made.\nIam a big fan of really scarry horror. I can't stand artsy horror or slow burners. Lately that has been all that has been made. But this one stands out for real. A new take on the classic invited evil spirit. We follow a group that looses control. The tension builds up as all things goes south. It's refreshing with all of these never seen before actors. We get thrown between the different realities and its hard to know what is reality and what's not. This stands out as a really top movie these last years.

I was really excited for this movie as it was quite hyped up. As soon as the movie was on discount, I grabbed it. The premise is pretty cool, it's sort of refreshing. Apart from that, the movie is your usual horror flick. It's a decent one, but not shockingly good or groundbreaking. You turn it off, think "cool", and it's gone. No longer in mind.\nIf you search for a horror movie for people who're not used to watching scary movies, this will be a very good choice. In my view, it's not that good of a choice for horror movie fans - at least if you want something special, the cherry on your sundae.

The end of the year 2023 is approaching as I'm writing this user-comment, and - as usual - many website and magazines are publishing their annual "best of" lists and rankings. The Aussie made "Talk to Me" appears in practically every list, and quite high to boot, so I tried to squeeze it into my viewing schedule before the year is over.
As too often the case, sadly, I must say I'm not overly impressed with it, although admittedly it does contain a few original elements and two or three genuinely frightening and shocking moments. One of the original elements is the basic premise. In "Talk to Me", demonic/spiritual possession is presented as the newest hype in party-drug sensation.
Forget taking pills or sniffing gas. It's sufficient to grab the embalmed hand relic and say the titular words, and you go into a trance where you get hallucinations of the ghosts of random deceased people that make you do all sorts of crazy stuff. The spectators obviously film everything with their smartphones and put it on YouTube or Instagram. Evidently, this is bound to go wrong, and it does when teenager Mia learns that one of her friends gets in contact with the ghost of her dead mother during his trance. Mia breaks the "rules" of the possession's maximal duration, and it has extremely painful consequences for the medium.
The idea is good, Sophie Wilde's performance is intense, and there are a couple of excruciatingly agonizing moments you won't forget very soon (featuring a teenager's face and a table), but there too many defaults and unanswered questions. For me, at least. Where does the embalmed hand come from? Why aren't there any adults aware of the new hype even though it's all around the internet? I'm sure these questions, and several more unasked ones, will be answered in a long franchise of sequels, prequels, spin-offs. I will watch those eventually, of course, but I was still hoping for a more satisfying original. In this genre, I liked "Smile" better.

I've heard that most YouTuber movies/horror movies (or whatever) AREN'T that good, but this one is actually AMAZING! (For a horror movie, AND a YouTuber horror movie).
Positives:
The movie is VERY creepy and VERY scary which obviously horror movies are SUPPOSED to be, sadly not all horror movies success by doing that.
The movie doesn't focus that much on jumpscares but more fear and suspense, which i like A LOT.
The acting in the movie is very good. Especially for teen horror acting/acting for a teen horror movie, and just acting in general.
The movie is creative and the story is good.
The movie has a good and unexpected ending.
The movie has a good length. Not too long of a movie, not too short of a movie.
The movie has a good main character who you can root for.
The movie has good characters.
The movie has a very simple concept.
The movie is VERY good for being a horror movie.
The dialogue in the movie is good.
The movie is fun and enjoyable to watch.
Negatives:
This movie MIGHT work out as a sequel (yes, they are planning to do one) but a sequel might also NOT work out. I hope that you can understand why after you've watched this movie.
The movie can be a bit slow sometimes but still good and enjoyable.
Sometimes, but just SOMETIMES the acting can fall a bit flat.

I was originally looking forward to this flic in that it had great reviews. The story seemed interesting with a lot of potential. Noticing it was Austilian didn't necessarily damper my intentions. Foreign movies (in English) can be harder to follow at times but still worth it. This was pretty much fast talking, jive talking gen Z hipster dialogue. Scares are far in between. Lots of boring crying and talking interspersed with sleeping, foot sucking, etc. Yeah I know there's a story here about pain and regret too, but it just doesn't seem to work. The screen play is to broken up. Maybe just to much fast jive talk or something. The very ending wasn't bad but getting there was tedious.

movieName: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
content: So very bad. I'd rate this a negative score if I could. The script, the dialog and direction is so very bad. Such a waste of talented actors like Colin Farrell and Barry Keoghan, even Nicole Kidman. These "artistic" horror movies are all bad. The Witch, Hereditary, Midsommar and this trash are all alike. The stories and direction are awful and it's so hard to believe that anyone finds these movies remotely interesting. Let alone good. I won't watch another movie by Yorgos Lanthimos again. If you want to watch an odd film that was done very well, go watch The Banshees of Inisherin. Martin McDonagh is a masterful filmmaker that highlights the talents of all the actors in that film, Keoghan in particular.

movieName: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
content: This was a god awful film. A terrible plot with so many holes, you're literally saying to yourself "WTF?!?" every 3 minutes. Nothing made sense, nothing was explained. The only reason why I kept watching was to see if they even answered any of the questions. And the answer is no.\nWatching this film will leave you frustrated, angry, tired, and jealous that you didn't watch literally anything else.\nI sincerely regret even trying to watch this movie. I only thought it might be worthwhile due to the actors attached to it, but I will never watch another Yorgos Lanthimos film ever, ever again. What a piece of crap.

movieName: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
content: This film is a total trip - can't believe I haven't heard of it until now. I felt it was hard to get past the stilted/robotic way everybody spoke in the beginning - I'm assuming that was purposeful. And there were small gaps in the story - which again, I'm assuming was intentional and was up the the viewer to sort out. Everything eventually smoothed out and the perceived iciness amongst the family and friends became easier to translate. I'm hit & miss w/this creator's past films and this film falls somewhere in the middle. However - the casting was expertly done and it's a true testament to Kenough's talents watching him play someone much younger than his actual years, and still scare the crap out of you. This actor is also new to my awareness and I'm 'chasing' his work so I can watch more of him. He plays such odd characters - all different in their own right - but all still odd. I have to wonder if he is actually ON the spectrum and that's what makes him and his mannerisms so unique.

movieName: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
content:
The film is a retelling of the Greek tragedy Iphigenia. In the text written by Euripides around 2,400 years ago, King Agamemnon kills a sacred deer during a hunt and thus incurs the wrath of the goddess Artemis, who demands a sacrifice from him: he must kill his daughter Iphigenia, or the winds will not leave the ships of the king to set sail to wage war in Troy. For Agamemnon, it was a very difficult, almost impossible choice. Lanthimos updates the dilemma (the first scene, of a heart beating during surgery, indicates in a very literal way that Steven takes other people's lives into his hands - more than he would like or feel prepared to do, in fact). Above all, the director renews the foundations of Euripides' text - in his own deeply uncomfortable, and also fascinating, way.
The atmosphere established by Lanthimos around these characters has the desired instigating effect, however, unlike "The Lobster", in which the eccentricity of the ensemble still allowed space for broader issues to be explored - such as incommunicability, loneliness or brokenness. Of the pre-established concepts that guide romantic relationships - here the filmmaker offers an exercise in style that seems to end in itself. Something that would be valid if "The Killing of a Sacred Deer" was assumed as such from the beginning. The feeling that remains, however, is that, with each shot, Lanthimos aims for something much more complex. The erudite soundtrack, the traveling shots through the corridors, the enigmatic close-ups, the abrupt cuts, everything suggests a gravity, an air of importance, that never materializes. There is a clear attempt to impose a metaphysical meaning, see Martin's never-explained "powers", to this bourgeois guilt that befalls Steven's family, proving liable to divine punishment - the reaffirmation of the contrast of the Murphys' wealthy life with the boy's modest reality denotes this. However, such intentions never surpass the barrier of Lanthimos's provocative impetus, which ends up undermining the possibility of deeper reflections in favor of the need to create moments of shock, almost always effective, but often gratuitous - from the opening shot that shows a real cranioplasty to Alicia Silverstone's short cameo as Martin's mother. The tense climax, with echoes of "Gratuitous Violence (1997)", by Michael Haneke, whose latent nihilism exerts a great influence on Lanthimos, summarizes well the qualities and weaknesses of "The Killing of a Sacred Deer". Because, despite being impactful at first, it ends up not resonating with the imagined force, leaving an almost indifferent void.
The visual strategy of Lanthimos and director of photography Thimios Bakatakis contributes to the effectiveness of this strange universe, obviously, the constant use of wide angles that not only deform the scenes on their sides but also expand them in their depth, leaving the characters even smaller and more fragile (and the fact that they are normally displaced to a lower quadrant of the plane is another fabulous language resource). Lanthimos creates an aseptic, hollow universe that gives voice to the muted feelings he tries to convey, so that the most important feelings here-guilt and revenge-come into natural focus. His use of an extreme plongÃ©e on the hospital staircase where Steven works, after a still camera sequence, is particularly beautiful, poetically combining with the existential emptiness and apathy of Farrell's character. Embodying Kubrick, the director uses and abuses symmetrical takes and tracking shots which, despite functioning as what Americans would call eye candy, often do not seem to have greater functions than the decorations they are, which only contributes to distract the viewer and give a longer duration than the tape needed to be. Furthermore, sometimes the script devolves into excessively expository texts that break the subtlety of the narrative presented. Particularly unnecessary moments are those that expose the question of culpability, making obvious what had already been marked between the lines. These are, perhaps, the only moments in which Lanthimos bows to the "need for explanations" that permeates productions that intend to go beyond their market niche, something that also briefly marks "The Lobster". It's understandable and doesn't discredit the experience, but it's a habit that the director would do well to suppress in future works to embrace once and for all the weird and bizarre side, as in "Dogtooth".
The first relevant point to consider here is that it hovers between psychological horror and a fantasy drama. The award-winning script by Lanthimos and Filippou is fundamental in the slow but progressive construction of this tension, at a pace of psychological horror: it is designed to never leave the audience relieved. Even though nothing is said explicitly, forcing the viewer to search their heads for explanations for what would be happening on the screen. It is very interesting how the dialogues gradually gain drama in their tone, as the characters, small and lonely in the midst of plans that oppress them, fall into despair. Only then do we realize that the film is the agonizing story of a reckoning that borders on the surreal - and karmic. Lanthimos chooses not to provide definitive answers about his proposal. However, without this harming the development of the given topic. Its direction is dry, direct, and does not fail to show violence. The soundtrack plays an important role, as at some points in the film it increases in volume until it becomes distressing to be in the armchair watching that situation. The dialogues between the characters are devoid of emotions. Lanthimos manages to reveal to the viewer how forced and even ridiculous the repeated dialogues between people are to the point of being empty words. When Martin, the dead patient's son, begins to demand more of Steven's presence, we realize that the film goes further, creating chaos in the doctor's life that begins a chain of questioning about the attitudes of all the characters present. The plot has great surprises that deserve to be preserved, so that the viewer can really get into it.
Blood is an essential element in Lanthimos' film. It appears in the first scene, is mentioned as Kim's menstruation, is involved in violence, and even in the appearance of a simple ketchup. The blood refers to Christ, to the innocence of the sacrificed deer, at the same time as it is involved in violence between men. Science, in the context of the film, serves as a counterpoint to Nature: by using it, someone who should value life destroyed one out of ego and irresponsibility. Therefore, the entire film seems to be an angry response from Nature or from some undefined deity that charges those who act in the name of the illusory power that Medicine can give to control life. Ultimately, the film reveals a disturbing coldness in its characters' decisions. With a plot that involves the viewer in doubt about the sequence of events, in "The Killing of a Sacred Deer" it is possible to be carried away by the anguish of trying to understand how fantastic the story goes and remain thinking about the film after the session.
The film's atmosphere now has a discreet biblical context (hence the maxim "God gives and God takes away"), but still maintains certain characteristics of a Greek tragedy (and the symbolisms that refer to the sacrifice and dilemma of a man in conflict are examples). Steven Murphy, as the man of science, is rendered powerless by being just a man in the hands of mysterious forces; His profession becomes useless in saving his family (a detail that is, to say the least, ironic). Martin, as a result, gains the image of an Old Testament God, charged with wrath. If his father died in surgery, Steven will then need to sacrifice someone (the "sacred deer") to balance everything. In fact, these details are absolutely interesting, as they are already anticipated through the wide-angle camera angles. She, at various times, remains above Steven, as if she were God.
Perhaps Lanthimos' genius lies in making surgery the film's great metaphor (it is cold and precise). Not only is Steven as cold as his profession, but the film's atmosphere, soundtrack, dialogue and acting are also cold. Everything is cold, latent and little demonstrated. Any coldness is on purpose, as that is what the director wanted to create. Notice how everything, so inexpressive, ends up "expressing" terror and pessimism. Coldness is what defines "The Killing of a Sacred Deer". As stable, calculated and "surgical" as its system is, a simple crooked line or a crescendo of music can be the prelude to chaos. And this film walks a fine line. The film ends on the right note, almost with symmetry, matching the coldness of its introduction. The heart of the first scene connects with the sacrifice in the Murphy family (but in different senses). His conclusion indicates that Martin is the representation of God. In the last scene, he is sitting on a bench in a restaurant, and is not even seen by the Murphys (except for Kim, who gives him a look). He is like God: he is there, he is felt, but he is not seen. There is no more sacrifice, and that family no longer owes you anything. Everything then ends.

movieName: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
content: Ancient myth, disguised in American way of life. Good actors struggling to pull out some sense from the story. Maybe interesting for deeply religious, moderately intelligent and poorly informated people. I cannot understand poimt of view of Cannes Jurie board giving the prize for playwrite. Maybe in 2017 y. There were some sinister Sun activities which influenced the jurie decision. Technically, the movie is professionally made. Director is obviouslly real professional, but didn't went far from boring psychological, mild horror and plenty of sex obssesion mixture. Don't expect of me to warch this movie once more time.

movieName: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
content:
Renowned cardiovascular surgeon Dr. Steven Murphy lives an idyllic life with his wife and two children. When he befriends a fatherless teenager named Martin, the young man proceeds to inveigle his way deeper and deeper into the doctor's life. Soon, Martin's dark intentions become apparent when Martin reminds him of a past transgression which will permanently shatter the domesticity of his household.
The latest offering from Greek director Yorgos Lanthimos who collaborates once again with Colin Farrell, whom he worked with on his equally idiosyncratic The Lobster. It is no exaggeration to describe The Killing of a Sacred Deer as a deeply surreal and perturbing look at a man whose family's life is turned upside down by an unstable teenager. Inspired by the ancient Greek tragedy Iphigenia in Aulis by Euripides, like The Lobster, Lanthimos's movie is clearly experimental in nature in so much, as for reasons that appear only clear to himself his cast delivers their performances in a stilted and wooden style. The artificiality of this is only matched by Lanthimos's script which he co-wrote with Efthimis Filippou. It's pretty much robotic as if his protagonists escaped from the Stepford Wives.
At the movie's heart, there is a good movie with a sublimely bizarre and surreal plot and Lanthimos manages to add a nuanced, somber and unsettling tone. There is something of a cold sterility to the Murphy household which may account for the unorthodox style of acting on display. Suffice to say that like The Lobster there is an underlying touch of the absurd to it's plot which no doubt owes a measure of debt to the avant-garde work of David Lynch, while there are hints of the Oscar winning psychological thriller Fatal Attraction.
Barry Keoghan, who would later feature alongside fellow Irishman Farrell in the black tragicomedy does have something of an unsettling presence as well as a awkwardness about him as the disturbed young antagonist. However, Lanthimoas can't overcome the weight of his own artistic pretensions with the stagy style of his direction and the constrained acting by his cast bog it down considerably. Which is a shame because there was a potentially good if very strange movie that had the potential to be so much more than it actually is.
Needless to say as well that the considerable talents of both Farrell and Keoghan feel wasted, and deserved better than what they are left to work with. And Nicole Kidman has done considerably better with the similarly off-kilter and dark Stoker, just seems to be infinitely bored with everything that's gone on around her. One has to wonder if her involvement is due to any artistic merit she thought the movie had or merely for the paycheck. Either way The Killing of a Sacred Deer feels like something of a missed opportunity from Lanthimoas whose seems to have fallen prey to his own overreaching ambitions.

movieName: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
content:
My husband and I watched this movie figuring by the title and written blurb about it, that it was a loser. Since it was called a thriller, which is one of our favorite genres, we decided to give it a try.
Without a shadow of a doubt, the WORST MOVIE EVER MADE and my husband's comment was perfect. Who thought this sick piece of garbage was worth investing any time or money in? They are the truly demented!
There was no plot, the acting could have been done by badly made robots. There was no substance, no message, no cohesiveness to the story. Even the so-called music was terrible. I have finally found, out of all the bad movies out there, my number 1 worst movie ever!! This one came out of the minds of truly sick psychopaths who have no clue what movie making is intended for. Shame on Colin Farrell and Nicole Kidman for even CONSIDERING appearing in this nonsense. They both went down about 1,000 levels on our respect for actors page!!
How this crap got a 7.0? Shows me what I suspect about reviewers in here. Too many up rate dumb, badly made movies to appear cool and artsy to their colleagues. Seriously? Everybody has an opinion. I cannot believe so many saw ANY storyline or relevance in this mess of a movie. There, now you have been warned. DO NOT BE CURIOUS if you are a normal, sane person to watch this one. We did it for you. DO NOT WASTE YOUR PRECIOUS TIME HERE ON EARTH. You have been warned!

movieName: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
content:
This is number 4. The fourth film ever I've given a 1 star here on IMBb out of about a thousand rated. The previous one was Midsommar and if you've seen both you'll probably understand why.
Like Midsommar this is a non-story about non-human characters exercising non-human behaviour.
The result: sheer boredom. Another one of those films where you get bored, then you grow numb as it drags on and then, the simmering frustration reaches it's boiling point as you start questioning who the hell made this and why and you just get angry. Another one of those movies deliberately designed to waste your time and p!ss you off. When it's over you just feel insulted.
Many have praised the deliberate awkward and robotic conversations,the weirdness, the creepy music and atmosphere, designed to make you feel anxious and unnerved all the way through.
And there lies the problem. The weirdness is pedestrian. Often laughable. The film isn't actually creepy either. The only thing creepy about it is the manipulative music perpetually forced throughout the film. Viewers who thought this was tense and creepy probably think Tim Burton films are scary.
The movie pretty much sabotages itself. When the characters and the plot of a movie don't feel real then it's audience tends to disengage and stops caring about any of it. Therefore: no real emotional impact.
At the end of the day this is another exercise in style over substance. An ode to pretentious nonsense. Food for the "you just don't get it" - crowd.
No no, we get it, cause it's not as intelligent as you think it is, we just think it's stupid.

movieName: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
content:
Robotically delivered lines, unsettling camera angles, elements of fantasy and characters that never bother asking why or how. Love it or hate it, these are the features of Lanthimos' work and I believe he has succeeded once again with his formula.
Be the kafkaesque elements of characters living in an apparently rational world filled with beings that behave very much like children precisely because of how blindly they follow abstract bureaucratic rules or the dry and satirical Roy Anderson type of humor, in The Killing of a Sacred Deer, illogic becomes plausible, guilt goes unexplained, and brutal punishment is doled out.
Constant unexpected turns in the plot often joined by an overly dramatic soundtrack (which consists mainly of baroque and classical pieces) make for a more intense ride than his previous movies, especially giving the sense of urgency the characters face. Like in The Lobster time is of the essence, unlike it though, the comical moments here are few. Do not be fooled by the colorful palette either, this is by far Lanthimos' most violent and dark movie (it has been produced by A24 afterall).
If I were to criticize anything about the movie it would have to be Nicole Kidman. Not her role nor her acting, but herself. Simply put, she does not fit the overall aesthetic of the movie, she feels out of place.
While it's true that watching characters facing bizarre or surrealistic predicaments and incomprehensible pain may seem like a weird way to spend your leisure time, I will go out on a limb here (as an attempt to reply to some of the haters in the comments as well) and say that whilst Lanthimos makes use of make-believe elements, underneath it lays realism. How different is the curse that haunts Steven's family from, let's say, cancer? - Or any other illness for that matter. What about the unhinged and disjointed family connections? How often are we also not the victims of unmeasurable irrationalities in a supposedly well reasoned society?
Maybe it's precisely the epic perspectives and narratives that allows us to best see our lives for what they truly are, a chaotic mess. In this disenchanted world of ours, not only is this movie entertaining but also a refreshing way to remind us of how far from rational life can sometimes be.

movieName: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
content: I can't believe some people find it good or meaningful. This by far the most absurd and ridiculous movie ever made. I'm really sorry for anyone who has ever watched this movie, anyone who's going to watch it, and any actor and actress who has taken part in making it. It's not just the robot-like act and poor music and performance. It's the plot. The plot is the most absurd plot ever written in the history of cinema. I've had 3 other movies written and made by this filmmaker and I removed all of them. I'd highly suggest doing the same to you. I can't really express the depth and width of my anger due to the policy of IMDb.

I'm afraid Ari Aster has lost the plot. I'm afraid he thinks he's some kind of genius, when he's anything but. I'm afraid his previous success has gone to his head. I'm afraid his movies are getting progressively worse. I'm afraid to think of how bad his next film will be. I'm afraid that Hereditary will be the best thing he ever does. I'm afraid his latest film is a cod-Freudian one note bore with nothing interesting in it. I'm afraid some people have decided Joaquin Phoenix is the next Marlon Brando, when he has about as much substance and acting ability as Adam Sandler. I'm afraid this is one of the worst movies I've ever seen.

This director has done some interesting movies but they all have a bit of boredom in them. With this flick, Aster drives a car so slow, he drives it Into the ditch. Phoenix is a fine actor but he needs material that is worthy of his skills. This is the case with this effort. It is too slow. Too measured. Too flat to excite, even in the smallest increments. I could only watch minutes at a time and returned to it several times to completion. It felt like a chore.\nThis is not entertainment. It is revelatory. It is not profound. It is an indulgent exercise in tedium. The fine actors in this movie deserve better. And they should've known better before committing to this snooze fest.

Never admit i was entertained by this movie...if dali and bosch had a heart stopping nightmare, it would seem like a dream where you'd died while having sex and had gone to heaven, compared to this...it's brilliant in its relentless ability to keep coming up with a grotesque story, scene after scene after scene...
it's like looking into an open wound eons deep. And i just couldn't turn away...not because i felt there HAD to be a resolution to it all, but because it was just. So. FAScinating.
By the way, this is, in no way, a recommendation. See it if you really feel the need, but...i will NEVER understand the motivation behind making such a thing.
And this DOESN'T mean it's 'bad'...for what it is, it is VERY well done. On top of all that i said...it's THREE HOURS LONG! THREE...
it makes me question my sanity, that i sat through it...granted, not in one sitting...but it might even be WORSE that i kept returning to the scene of this plane crash...

Oh my gosh it's brilliant, to a point.\nWatching this can only be equated to what I believe 500 cups of coffee, no sleep, and functioning mental illness combined would be like. Several times I actually stopped to rewind (or, whatever it's called now, I backed up a few frames) to rewatch what I just watched, shouting "WTF just happened"...it's an adventure in madness, like a song with lyrics that take you from midnight through to 5pm the next day and you're still at the bar playing random jukebox tunes while everyone else has gone home. This movie, seriously the director or producer or maybe all of them...just said action and told the actors to just do or say whatever the heck they wanted to say or do. Joaquin does a great job being the guy he's supposed to be and if you know, you know. Unfortunately, amongst the madness some of the story really never gets there and it's one heck of a LONG movie to not quite get there. Hence, I have to stop at a 7. I wish future watchers luck...it's one heck of a ride.

'Course that's not saying much in 2023. But this movie would have stood out even if the year had been full of outstanding shows.
Anyhow. Beau Is Afraid is a visual delight. Each scene is filled with more details than you can hope to take in let alone make an effort to integrate with the plot.
Not that there's a plot. Or maybe there is. I'm honestly not sure.
Phoenix is stellar, this is the sort of stuff that he excels at (as opposed to muddled portrayals of historical figures). He is constantly on the edge of panic and disconnection from 'reality' in just the right amount to make the character feel real enough to be relatable. Rather than farcical or outlandish or, heaven forbid, dour and boring. And this is absolutely necessary for the character to be able to skip from once surreal outing to the next without alienating the viewer.
But the movie is work and the time does not flash by. It's more like a 3 hour mountain climb than a pleasure cruise. The viewer, however, is wonderfully and richly rewarded for his attendance.
Hereditary was a masterpiece. But then Midsommar was a misguided, shallow disappointment and I was prepared to write Aster off as a one hit wonder. But Beau Is Afraid is clearly the work of someone who knows how to make a movie.

The director made a wonderful collage of Rosemary's baby and his previous two moviesðŸ¤£(which were also collaged and montages from Rosemary's baby). By that I mean it is more like a story board at its early stage but without real development(It could be a wonderful uncanny movie). Sadly It was not what I expected... You don't need 3 hours to describe the fear of aggressive control and complicated relationship with family... SIMPLY doesn't need to especially without some specific contexts. The set is so general and ambiguous(don't tell me it is not) I guess ari wanted to convey one vibe and psychological into many different families. But apparently he didn't realise perhaps the difference is more than the common. A very cheesy quote but it is so true: All happy families resemble one another, each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way.

I feel bad for The reviewer who said he gave up over three hours of his life watching this. Didn't take me that long. I can't understand people who give these kind of movies a 7, 8, 9 or 10. Are we supposed to be moved by their intellect or feel that we are less than Intelligent or knowing because we find this stuff senseless? Joaquin Phoenix has always been edgy but these character actors think they are so avant garde doing this kind of crap. You would do yourself a favor and watch a foreign film which is animated and done in a language you do not understand. You will get more out of it than you will this total and complete waste.

The first 30 minutes of this film are laugh out loud funny. If you don't think so, you will not enjoy the rest. Enjoyed this movie from start to finish although the middle makes for a confusing and meandering interlude. Was it deserving of 3 hours of screen time? Probably not. However, you will not forget this film. Not a single moment. It will stick with you long after you finish. For me that's a mark of a good movie, regardless of what critics say. There are many different themes to unpack\nHere, which will permeate through your mind long after the movie finishes. 6 months afterward, and I still think about beau and his mishaps, which, in my opinion, denotes a worthy film. Do yourself a favor. Watch it.

This film had no plot, no normal congruence, nothing is entertaining enough for you to forget about the insanity that goes on. Almost no script. It is a series of scenes showing you the perspective of insanity of someone but from a ridiculous point of view created by this director which doesnt have anything to do with nothing even surfacing real life. That's not how you show mental problems on film if you want people to comprehend you as a filmaker. The thing is that we've already seen that done in a much better way. WAYYYYYYY BETTER in the film "the father" with anthony hopkins. That film is a MASTERCLASS of showing insanity in a way that a sane person can understand. This movie is extremely bad from any perspective and Ari Aster should know better. Come on Ari you know how to make a good film stop slacking bro.

I love Hereditary. Absolutely love it. Midsommar, not so much. I thought it was too bloated and uninteresting. Beau is better than Midsommar. It's a completely different film. It's absurd cinema to the fullest, but that's okay. I was onboard for the 1st 2 hours of this anxiety ridden nightmare. It was funny and batshit and I hoped it would continue to be until the very last frame. And it wasn't. It's almost as if Ari went against everything he gave us for the first two full hours. He suddenly made an attempt to explain every absurd frame in his film. He swung for the fences, but he came up short of the homer. At least Chazelle stuck the landing with Babylon.

FILM: 7/10.
Returning to the 2015 film Krampus, I find Michael Dougherty, the maestro behind the delightfully twisted Trick 'r Treat, turning his attention to the holiday season. Much like his Halloween gem, Krampus serves as a refreshing counter-programming to the saccharine sweet Christmas fare, blending comedy and horror in a way that nods to classics like Gremlins.
The family at the film's centre is well cast, each member contributing to the chaos in their own unique way. It's a dysfunctional family dynamic that feels authentic, adding an extra layer of relatability to the unfolding madness. There's a chemistry that makes their descent into holiday horrors all the more entertaining, with Adam Scott and Toni Collette barely containing their frustration at the family members descending on their home.
Creature design is a standout feature, with the monstrous creations adding a touch of macabre whimsy to the Christmas setting. Dougherty successfully crafts a festive nightmare, where gingerbread men and demonic toys become unlikely antagonists in the battle for holiday cheer.
Krampus is undeniably a fun film, leaning into its darkly comedic moments while maintaining a genuine sense of peril. The blend of horror and humor hits the right notes, creating an experience that's both chilling and amusing. It's a reminder that the festive season isn't always sugar and spice, but sometimes a dash of horror adds the perfect kick.
As the credits roll, Krampus leaves you with a playful warning - if you don't believe in Santa Claus, you might just be doomed for life. It's a cheeky nod to the film's mischievous spirit, proving that holiday horrors can be a delightful gift for those who appreciate a bit of bite with their Christmas bark. A festive frightfest that keeps the holiday spirit twisted and thrilling.
