Too childish for adults and too adult for children. It's a quality mix of light horror and comedy. All star cast is fun to watch, particularly Toni Collette who is consistently great. The end makes you think and is the highlight of the movie.\nSynopsis:\nWhile the holiday season represents the most magical time of year, ancient European folklore warns of Krampus, a horned beast who punishes naughty children at Christmastime. When dysfunctional family squabbling causes young Max (Emjay Anthony) to lose his festive spirit, it unleashes the wrath of the fearsome demon. As Krampus lays siege to the Engel home, mom (Toni Collette), pop (Adam Scott), sister (Stefania LaVie Owen) and brother must band together to save one another from a monstrous fate.

Had this one in my backlog for a while and its been 2 years since i wanted to kinda transition my Halloween horror movies season into a Christmas movies season but it just didn't occured. I really wanted to watch it this year tough and with Christmas coming i did just that on the 21st.
Overall... not a bad movie, but nothing really special, yet fine for one watch. Its actually a comedy mixed with horror while keeping the Christmas atmosphere in full force.
The Krampus monster himself is actually not that present. It revolves around all his minions wich all have special imaginative designs. That said they pretty much all CGI animated and they kinda look goofy at time. I guess they were inspired by Tim Burton in some way.
The issue is im never sure if i should take this movie seriously or not. Is it supose to be a comedy or is it supose to be horror? Maybe its supose to be a mix of the 2 just like i think it is? Who knows. But its not "that funny" while its not scary at all.
This one get the yellow heart only by a tiny little margin. Its best feature in my opinion is the snow storm, Christmas stuff and altough a bit goofy like i said, the creatures at least are pretty original.

Be careful what you wish for
Because you might just get it
Hands down one of the best Krampus movies out there
Trust me I've seen more than my share of the bad ones
Is this movie scary ?
I guess it depends on what you consider scary
I could see it being a good introduction to horror for younger kids
As a adult fan of horror I doubt anyone would find it scary
But it is wildly entertaining
My favorite moments in the movie
Come from when the gingerbread cookies attack
I think part of my problem with this movie is
The movie is PG 13 and because of that
I think it limits what you get to see what you get to see on screen.

Krampus takes the traditional holiday film and turns it on its head, as Santa takes a back seat to a more devious holiday creature. Starting off like your typical Christmas film, the plot quickly starts to send shivers down your spine as you realize this has much more in store. The story is fun and exciting, with a perfectly unsettling ending to top it off and keep with its creepier elements. The cast is comprised of familiar faces and some talented children actors. While they mostly maintain a fun ride, some of the jokes can feel quite cheesy or stale, with the dialogue being almost satirical at times. As a Christmas movie, it certainly has the holiday element, but as a horror movie, the fear and unnerving nature are some of the best parts. While I didn't expect much going in, Krampus delivers a delightfully eerie tale that I have found myself running back to, time and time again.

Krampus is one of my favourite Christmas horror movies. Like many horror films, it was dismissed when it first came out for really inexplicable reasons, but I'm happy it seems to be getting a well-deserved reassesment. Because, what's not to love here?
You have a truly AMAZING cast, with great performances from Adam Scott, Toni Collette (!), David Koechner, and even the kids, who are mostly pretty solid actors and do well with the material. It has fantastic practical effects that pay homage to Rankin Bass Christmas classics, only much darker and more twisted.
The story is fun and creative, subverting the saccharine wish fulfillment of most Christmas tales, for one that has a child invoking a spirit that's almost cosmic in its power and completely unstoppable. I LOVE how Krampus is presented here as a villain; not just the awesome practical creature they made, but how much power he has and fear he induces. It's just fantastic.
Not to mention this movie is FUNNY. It has a great sense of humour and doesn't take itself too seriously. It validates a lot of the feelings people have about the holiday season, mainly about having to share a table and fake smile for family members you wouldn't associate with otherwise and the cynical consumerism Christmas promotes. However, like all good Christmas movies, the message is simple: family matters. Making it work regardless of your differences matter. Just when you think the film settles for a sweet, uplifting ending, it delivers one of the most bleak, brilliant ones I've seen for a Christmas horror film.
Yeah, Krampus is a ton of fun. If you need a break from holiday cheer, even if temporarily, check it out.

The foundations are tried and true, a scenario that's been the basis of many holiday films for decades: an abundance of outwardly unlikable characters, the false manufactured cheer of Christmas set against abject cynicism about the worst aspects of the holidays in modern life, minimal representation of innocence (usually the very young) amidst a cornucopia of cringe and dreariness. To that foundation, of course, we add in this case a frightful supernatural entity drawn directly from European folklore, and presto! - 2015 horror-comedy 'Krampus.' Mind you, in this case the genre label is a bit of a misnomer; there are stunningly few outright laughs to be had in these ninety-seven minutes, and the "comedy" descriptor speaks more to the fragments of wry, black humor that marginally lighten the horror. To that point, despite how the picture was marketed, this is substantially darker than I expected, with grim atmosphere and grisly violence exceeding what some straightforward horror sometimes achieves; modicums of levity can't begin to meaningfully touch the most dour facets of the movie. I do like it, but suffice to say that this is not what I anticipated.
Sparsely peppered with quick-witted lines that provide counterbalance, the preponderance of the length is characterized by shrewd use of light and shadow, incredibly unsettling unnatural movement, sounds, or visions, a tense and acutely disquieting score, and superb art direction that very distinctly cements the bleak, brutal ambience. This is to say nothing of surprisingly strong violence, imaginative and unnerving creature designs, and excellent stunts and effects; the computer-generated imagery looks fantastic, and to whatever extent the digital wizardry doesn't blend into the filmed footage, this is an instance where the disparity rather adds to the experience. Even the sound effects are plainly outstanding and further the harrowing airs about the feature, not to mention the costume design, hair, and makeup. Filmmaker Michael Dougherty, and co-writers Todd Casey and Zach Shields, concocted a wonderfully twisted nightmare that warps familiar Christmastime themes and ideas into an invigorating thrill ride that at some points rather becomes hard to watch for just how unremittingly sinister and cheerless the concatenation becomes. 'Krampus' is fun, yes, but in a manner very much unlike how it was promoted and spoken of since before its release.
The narrative is sharp, potent, and stridently gloomy through to the very end; the fact that it does manage to be earnest and impactful at the same time is genuinely impressive. Equally punchy scene writing keeps us firmly locked in while maximizing the harsh, charged energy and every feeling, and much the same can be said for Dougherty's keen direction. The length passes very quickly as the tale grows ever more severe, and if anything, the casting in this rarely funny horror flick of actors largely known for their work in comedies only heightens the gripping tone and accentuates how far removed this is from how it initially presents. Case in point, Toni Collette is not known for appearing in genre titles, yet like Ari Aster's masterful 'Hereditary,' this is an exception in which her participation serves to amplify the intended effect, and emphasize the underlying gravity. Collette, David Koechner, Adam Scott, Allison Tolman, Conchata Ferrell, Krista Stadler, and even young Emjay Anthony, among others, all give splendid performances of real range, nuance, and emotional depth while being perfectly suited to the gnarly cavalcade of violence that the film broadly represents.
Truthfully, I had mixed expectations when I sat to watch; I assumed I'd enjoy 'Krampus,' but I wasn't sure just how good and worthwhile it would really turn out to be. I'm pleased to say that when all is said and done, it's even better than I could have hoped. I think the heavy focus on horror over comedy actually serves the picture well, for it's made more fully absorbing and satisfying in its darkness; not only are the scant lighter touches more consequential in turn, but it seems as if the writers worked overtime to make the comedy smarter (that is, both more intelligent and more cheeky). The end result of all this is a genre romp that manages to hit considerably harder than it would seem from the outside looking in, or from the outset. Crafted with utmost skill and well made in all regards, it's both entertaining and riveting, and handily surpasses most other movies that try to play at the same intersection of horror and holidays. I'm so very happy with just how good this is, and for anyone who is open to the amalgamation, 'Krampus' earns my very high and enthusiastic recommendation!

I wasn't sure going into this movie but decided to give it a full watch and I'm glad that I did! This movie is far from the typical cliche Christmas movie. Mixed with some humor & terror. If you like Christmas, horror & comedy all in one than you'll really enjoy this one. The writer really did a great job putting this one together. No, it's not like it's Oscar worthy but it's definitely one of those movies you could find yourself watching over & over again every Christmas season. This one gave me a bit of the chills and caught me off guard quite a few times & the ending definitely left me thinking about it well after it ended. Highly recommend you give it a watch.

This film is set up pretty good with the family all together on Christmas, all sort of hating each other and only hanging out because they are family. These arguments causes Krampus to start haunting these guys.
The in-laws were the most unlikable characters in this film. Theres nothing good about them expect for the gun guy who had the only line I found acceptably funny. The rest of the jokes, and comedy tries are terrible, misplaced or just corny and dont fit in with the film.
The movies setting is mostly set in the house as theres a blizzard outside they can't get out. This setting creates almost a claustrophobic effect which worked well. No electricity so its only candle light which brings Krampus' elves and his other monsters to feel much more scary.
This film is basically horror movie 101 its basic and pretty predictable. Its basically like a home invasion film with a evil santa. The ending is very weak and unsatisfying.
Little cookie ginger bread men were amazing best part of the film. The rest of the helpers were pretty bad, except the jack box thing that opened its mouth like Pennywise and ate a kid. The CGI is decent in this film with Krampus being the highlight, we see him up close close to the end but I feel like it would of been better if he was more of a mystery. Seeing him close in the dark next to the grandma was great, his long sharp claws without seeing his face was better.
First time we see Krampus was great. Him on the rooftop jumping from one house to another. All we can see is the dark outline of him and that was the most scary part of the film, creepy, huge thing with horns jumping on roofs.
With all its flaws its one of the better Christmas horror films out there. I'd recommend it.

Don't watch it trying to be scared. Watch it through the lens of a campy/comedy rather than a true horror film.
If you liked The Ref, you'll appreciate the banter and family dynamic in this movie. Toni Collette is amazing in everything she touches. Adam Scott might be one of the most underrated comedy actors of our generation. (Please watch Severence if you have not already.) David Koechner is a gem.
Also, bulldog. Love Rosie.
The creatures are amazing. Practical effects are so amazing and underutilized in Hollywood.
Great ending as well. My personal humble opinion, of course. Felt like a Twilight Zone episode.
(The Ref + Xmas creature horror) / Twilight Zone = Krampus.

Naturally, I can appreciate that any persons Taste In film is subjective, for me however it just felt like someone had watched, and enjoyed the Wickerman, afterwards then wanted to make a film were a bunch of stuff happens in a similar vain, to a group of characters I didn't care about. Personally, I wouldn't watch it again. But other people I know, absolutely love this film, and it came very highly recommended. Again, doesn't make it a bad film, just ended up being I personally didn't enjoy. May one day give it another punt, but certainly won't be today, or for a while. But each to their own.

What a nonsense garbage, boring from the beginning to the end, and I have seen a lot of movies that are garbage but this tops it.\nI get it's a movie but like none of the characters have a brain or what is happening to them or their friends, just shows how silly humans are when it comes to cults but I guess it the writers you can blame for the lacking in that department, still not sure what happened in the end I guess she really did join a cult just because what she been through just made sense for her to feel belonged and have a home these people give it her, I thought it would went other way around but still Don't waste your time.

I watched this film for the first time in summer and it was a great experience. Florence Pough (sorry if I spelt her name wrong) acted very well from the very beginning and deserves several awards from this performance alone. This is easily the best psychological horror film I have ever seen. Watching it for the first time was oddly comforting due to the aesthetics and vibrant colours, however as the movie went on it became more and more disturbing. The acting in it was incredible and I loved the plot. If you're looking to watch a psychological horror that feels summery, I would recommend this film! (Also a quick warning: don't watch this while high - you will regret it)

For the last two months I've been doing the Marvel marathon, 20 movies so far. They're almost all worth watching if in the mood, but the lack of stillness in the camera, the constant cuts, quick quips, punchathons and artificial visuals get tiring after a while.
Midsommar is a fine antidote: the camera is beautifully still or slow. Editing-cuts are far less frequent, allowing more time to sink into an image. The compositioning of images is masterful: photography-like. Indeed, Kubrick-like (who was initially a photographer).
We also get an impactful soundtrack, excellent acting especially from the lead, good script & screenplay with plenty of quality dialogue-free sections, effectively spare FX with realistic psychedelic 'breathing' visuals, and a riveting foreboding atmosphere.
There's also very weird humour, which actually made me & my lady laugh out loud a few times....tho' I imagine others might just find it weird.
The film slightly drags in the final third (I watched the theatrical cut) and some of the character reactions will have you questioning its realism. The plot itself is fairly predictable...we've seen such films before. These are nitpicks as we also get a handful of strong memorable scenes.
Overall a decent 8/10. Feels like a worthy tribute to 1973's The Wicker Man.

Lol.. OK I've put off watching this one now for like forever, mainly coz in my head I already predicted what it was about and the sort of vibe it would give off ( like moods in other films) and unfortunately I was 100% right. I will say in the first quatre or even less than that we get to see some beautiful scenery ( I will have to read up where it was filmed locations etc) and I did like the lead actress, she held the most potential.. and for a moment with the beautiful scenery I thought I might have made a wrong assumption on how the mood and theme of film would go & I'd be in for a nice viewing. Unfortunately none of the rest of the characters went anywhere. Even their friend who had taken them for a trip. It seemed like we d get more from him but then he quietened off. But first and foremost. The place just SCREAMED Cult as soon as we arrive in the village but like I said some nice scenery I was interested to see where it went. But unfortunately you'd really have to suspend belief too far on this, especially in regards to reactions and decisions. The film is long and slow paced aswell, making it even more unbelievable, they wouldn't of all just fled, especially after the mountains viewing & no1 would believe the London guy ditched his girlfriend & if I was her I would have clung to the Americans. This is where at least something like Hostel is rational in thinking YO!! Time to go!! Before even first person goes missing. It just became to anti climatic and stupid after the beautiful scenes and initial sacrifice. It was beyond predictable & I honestly feel they wasted a opportunity for a better film in their.

'Midsommar' (2019)
Opening thoughts: It took me a long time to get round to watching 'Midsommar', due to not having time or the opportunity to watch it easily. Have always appreciated the genre it fits in, where there are many great films, and Florence Pugh showed a lot of promise seeing her for the first time in 'Little Women'. That it was also directed by the director responsible for the very good 'Hereditary' intrigued me too. The premise was one of those could have gone either way ones, it was advertised bizarrely and the critical reception was very polarising, particularly from those that didn't like it.
After seeing 'Midsommar', count me in as somebody who didn't care for it. It is not an awful film and there are things done right, including an intriguing start, but the second half was a bizarre and tedious mess, so this viewer is this case more understanding of those who didn't like the film than liked. This has absolutely nothing to do with not understanding what 'Midsommar' was going to be or going for, quite the opposite, the issue is that it doesn't achieve its aims very well at all.
Good things: 'Midsommar' does have good things. It is a very well made film visually, with photography that is both dreamlike and nightmarish in all the necessary places. The scenery is also absolutely beautiful, while also with a suitably ominous atmosphere. Did think too that the film started off well, with an unsettling opening that was creepy and suspenseful. The sacrifice scene was similarly suitably horrifying, with it being the scariest (and goriest) the film got.
Regarding the acting, to me it was quite good considering what was given to them (which actually come to think of it wasn't much). Pugh anchors the film beautifully in a compellingly tortured lead performance.
Bad things: However, there are also a lot of drawbacks. Most of the characters are incredibly thinly sketched and behave annoyingly and/or illogically. Pugh has the only character that has any development or who is interesting. Some friends thought that Will Poulter's character had the most personality, to me actually he was annoying and his presence jarred with the rest of the atmosphere. The direction did have some slickness but got very slack and muddled later on the more weird the second half became.
The script has nothing memorable, is very stilted and can fall into self-indulgence. The story and pacing are the weakest aspects of 'Midsommar'. The story starts off with great atmosphere and intrigue, but post the sacrifice scene any creepiness and sense of horror pretty much completely goes. Meaning that the second half is incredibly long winded, this out increasingly (at times non-existent) and is bizarre to the point of near-incoherence. Especially the dragged out and truly daft climax that ends on an abrupt, incomplete feeling note and one of the silliest and most unintentionally funny sex scenes in recent years.
Some of the intended creepy behaviours of the cult were potentially unnerving and sounded it on paper but were under-explored and/or left as loose ends or implied. A much shorter length definitely would have helped the pacing and atmosphere, the film is overlong and could have easily been trimmed by 25-30 minutes which would have tightened the pace. Which would have been achieved if scenes were made shorter and if motivations went into more detail.
Closing thoughts: Overall, underwhelming.
4/10.

I loved the directors previous film Hereditary. It was fresh if perhaps a bit bloated at times but it worked due to the plot's structure.
So I was pretty stoked for this one. How many pure day light horror films are there? The Wicker Man (original) of which this film pays homage too, basically remakes it. And that is where ultimately, I was disappointment.
First the good: The film is beautifully shot and minus 2 scenes the entire thing takes place in bright green fields of Sweden (shot in Hungary)
It accomplishes merging beauty with horror in a way I haven't ever seen before (The Flower Dress)
If you're a gore hound beyond just "MORE GORE!" then you may find certain scenes shocking (the cliff scene) as I did. It's not overly gory but with a background so beautiful for the heinous actions by both villagers and visitors it's quite jarring.
There is also a suicide scene that raises a good question regarding how we "civilized" people tend to push our old/sick into institutions never to be seen again. Who are visitors to judge the customs of these "sacred" people?
Sadly that theme is not explored and I found every character minus Dani to be interchangeable in their terribleness
In closing.
It feels like the director was, poorly, trying to remake the ultimate cult classic using the same methods that worked so well for his previous hit that what we end up with is a film that is
100% predictable from start to finish. In other words I found it boring.
I wanted to love it but didn't. I am very happy it was made as I think Ari Aster is an incredibly talented director who knows how to bring the terror and I look forward to his next work. I just hope he tries something unique and fun to watch.
TLDR: This film follows the themes of Hereditary with zero twists, and while it is a gorgeous (and morbid) work of art- I didn't like it or hate it.

This was a weird, but entertaining horror flick, that popped up on my danish TV app.
As a dane, and thus a real life neighbor to the swedish settting in the film, it was quite entertaining to watch this Hollywood take on Midsommar, that pagan leftover in swedish culture, something that we danes no longer celebrate.
The film is quite uneven and requires quite a bit of suspension of disbelief. Some scenes and traditions of the HÃ¥gra are too random to not have set off our protagonists in real life.
Said protagonists are paper thin in the film, it's all about the HÃ¥gra and the setting.
I will say this film is interesting from a scandinavian perspective, because it features a lot of swedish actors and a lot of blonde people. This still being normal here, particularly in places like rural Sweden.
However, from an american point of view, that is increasingly diverse, I can see how this "land of the blondes" might seem very foreign. I found this reverse exocitism interesting to think about.
Overall, I found the movie unnerving in parts, humorous in others. Well worth a watch.

When the credits were rolling, my heart was lifted.
This is a movie we don't get often. A movie about community, about empathy. A movie about the importance of traditions, and even religion. Most of all, it's about sacrifice.
Be warned, though: this film takes its time. If you want something more action-paced, I recommend the very similar-themed, but less lenghty The Wicker Man. The one from the 70s.
This is not about thrills. The ending is clear, long before you get there. As I said: This movie REALLY dares to take its time. Don't expect too much tension, because although it might feel tense, sometimes, it also lasts long enough - and then some - to ease out any of these feelings.
God, this is such a good movie about values.

As a horror movie buff i am always looking for something i haven't seen.
I have been putting off watching Midsommar for years and now i know why..
It literally has 4 scenes with anything remotely gory or "horrific" as you would expect from a "horror" movie. I can see how something like this could be rated maybe M or MA15+. But whoever deemed it so horrifying that it needed an R+18 rating, needs to quit and find a new profession.
Honestly you will save people so much time..
Unfortunately someone has placed this in the wrong category, and it should be placed under boring, unwatchable garbage...

People complain all the time everything is a marvel sequel, or a disney remake. Well, this is different, bold, new, fresh.
The movie is good and it has rare elements and moments that will haunt you even after watching it. Same as "Terrified", the previous film by the director (there are still scenes I can't erase from my head even after years of watching that one too).
There's a lot of gore, but REALLY graphic, if you're easily impressed, it's probably going to be uncomfortable for you. Some images I'm having a hard time getting them out of my head.
The movie doesn't stop, it's not like those films that have like 30 minutes of boring character development. It starts and it keeps going and you'll get to know the characters as the movie progresses (great tip for filmakers nowadays, full of viewers with short attention span, A. K. A. Tiktok syndrome).
It's a small town story. Solid performances, solid practical effects, decent story.
Spanish speaker or not, if you're a horror fan you must watch this one.

This is a seriously scary and effective horror film. I trudge through so many mediocre horror films to find the random truly great horror masterpieces...and for me at least, When Evil Lurks is absolutely one of the new horror masterpieces.\nThe story and world created are so expansive, it kept me wondering what else was going on in this mad-scary world...so much backstory to flesh out and places it could go now with the story...so much more to learn about the Rottens and the Cleaners, etc! I'm now going to search out other films directed by DemiÃ¡n Rugna...while I eagerly await to see where we go next in the When Evil Lurks story.

"When Evil Lurks" introduces a truly special concept that had the potential to make it the standout movie of the year. The first half of the film is captivating, drawing audiences in with its intriguing storyline and well-executed suspense. The innovative idea behind the movie succeeds in creating a unique atmosphere that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats.
Regrettably, the second half takes a disappointing turn towards predictability and monotony, diluting the initial excitement. The film's potential for chaos and innovation hinted at in the beginning falls flat, leaving viewers yearning for a more dynamic and ambitious portrayal.
In envisioning the film's potential, one can't help but wish for a reimagination of the concept in a grander setting, such as a bustling city engulfed in possession-induced chaos. Despite its shortcomings, "When Evil Lurks" sparks hope for a future revisit, one that could realize the thrilling experience promised by its exceptional concept.
I would have given 5 out of 10 but I really hated the second half.

This film has been overhyped as one of the best horror movies of the year. I went into it expecting to be blown away and I was let down.\nYes, this film has some crazy scenes that I enjoyed for how gory they were. But a good film cannot be dependent on shock value. And that's all this film was. It had a couple crazy moments but the in-between wasn't as interesting. The characters and the story wasn't compelling enough to hold my interest. I kept checking the run time waiting for it to be over.\nIt was a bit different from typical possession movies but it wasn't far off. There were rules that had to be followed to deal with the possessed but the film doesn't take advantage of the rules it made. The film could have shown why each rule should be followed. There also weren't any high tension moments or even any scares. The film became more disappointing towards the end with the use of the children inside the school. It just made for a weak ending.

When it comes to horror When Evil Lurks delivers on every count, whether it is atmosphere or gore, this movie holds back nothing. I had meant to watch this film for some time, as I had only heard good things about it, so I finally sat down today to watch it. I was not left disappointed. This film delivered everything I had been waiting for from a new horror film, apart from the scares, but that is not the film's fault. I am desensitized to horror. So I am sure it holds many nail-biting moments for most.\nI can't fault anything, the acting was fantastic, the locations and the special effects. You need to watch this film. Yes, it has subtitles, but people need to get over that. There is a world of foreign horror out there that deserves to be indulged in.\nOne warning though, if you can't handle horror/gore involving children then this probably isn't the film for you.

I do not understand people who are raving about this film. It has good ideas for sure, but everything was executed so poorly that it reminded me of a high school production with cheap makeup and overacting children. The acting is horrific. Everyone was screaming at the top of their lungs, which was highly annoying. The main character is probably the most stupid person you'll ever see in horror movies. The production looks extremely cheap. Child actors obviously cannot act. The lore is not explained. There is no sense of horror at any point, and there is a happy end because everyone stops screaming, and you are just relieved.

Unpleasant characters who garner no sympathy, combined with a loosely constructed plot, make this movie difficult to watch.
There are many positive reviews of this movie on IMDB, so this review is in the minority. How one reacts to a movie is subjective of course.
But an objective fact is that the writer and director of this movie are the same person. Far more often than not this kind of arrangement results in excesses and shortcomings, presumably because there is no one to check or balance the work of the other.
I saw this movie's score among fans so I had high hopes. (I never read the "critics" anymore.) This movie was a disappointment I'm sorry to say.

I was ready to recommend this movie to all my friends until I saw the last 10 minutes of it.
Those last 10 minutes ruined the movie for me. A typical example of the cliche trope of the main character making the worst possible choice even though he knows better, but the movie plot needs to happen so he has to do the worst thing imaginable which does not suit the character at all.
So if you can stomach a trash ending, then I recommend this movie to you. It has really good moments, but again, be prepared to have one of the most unsatisfying movie endings in any horror movie to date.
A shame really.

I enjoyed the premise of "When Evil Lurks", I think that it is an original possession story, that part ways with the usual stereotypes of this kind of horror. The evil takes over the lives of Jimi and Pedro slowly and painfully. The audience assists to this inevitable ascent of the darkness that multiple times outsmart the characters, despite all the precautions and strategies that they apply. The director took a realistic approach and some elements of the story are raw and credible. There is no unjustified over the top violence and no pointless jumpscares. The script takes the time to deepen the backstory of Pedro and his family, making him vulnerable and relatable to the eyes of the audience. The narration is fervid and there are many tense sequences that deliver some unexpected moments. This is in my opinion what made the first half great. Unfortunately the film starts to lose its appeal midway. All the tension that built up completely disappeared in the second part of the film. The protagonist takes impulsive decisions that have no logic and that will cost him dearly. In my opinion this goes against the nature of the character, that from the beginning constantly warns others how to kill the possessed, without contracting the curse. The ending is very dramatic and it leaves things open for a possible sequel (that most likely will not happen). Overall I liked the general concept of this film, but the director (who is also the screenwriter) made some decisions that prevented this film from achieving its true potential. "When Evil Lurks" could be one of the best 2023 horror movies, but unfortunately it only gets a 6. It is still a solid film, but I was expecting way better.

Oh boy, where do I even begin with this movie? "When Evil Lurks" is a spine-chilling rollercoaster ride that left me on the edge of my seat the entire time. From start to finish, it had me gripped with its intense and eerie atmosphere.
The theme of evil lurking in the shadows is brilliantly executed in this film. The darkness that surrounds the characters feels palpable, seeping into every frame and sending shivers down my spine. The suspense is expertly built, making it impossible to predict what's lurking around the corner. It's like a never-ending game of cat and mouse that keeps you guessing until the very end.
The plot is a twisted maze of twists and turns, pulling you deeper into the dark and twisted world it creates. Just when you think you have it all figured out, it throws another curveball your way, leaving you questioning everything you thought you knew. It's a mind-bending experience that keeps you hooked, eager to unravel the secrets hidden within the shadows.
The performances in this movie are absolutely stellar. The actors bring their characters to life in such a convincing way that you can't help but be drawn into their harrowing journey. They portray fear, desperation, and determination with such raw emotion that it's impossible not to feel their every emotion alongside them. It's a testament to their talent and dedication.
Visually, "When Evil Lurks" is a masterpiece. The cinematography is hauntingly beautiful, capturing the eerie ambiance of the story perfectly. The use of lighting and shadows adds an extra layer of suspense and mystery, immersing you in the unsettling world the characters must navigate. It's a visual feast for the eyes that adds an extra layer of depth to an already gripping narrative.
I must warn you, though, this movie is not for the faint of heart. It's dark, disturbing, and will leave you with a lingering sense of unease long after the credits roll. But if you're a fan of psychological thrillers that mess with your mind and send chills down your spine, then "When Evil Lurks" is an absolute must-watch.
In conclusion, "When Evil Lurks" is a bone-chilling masterpiece that will leave you breathless. Its intense atmosphere, mind-bending plot, and stellar performances make it a standout in the psychological thriller genre. Just make sure to keep the lights on and prepare yourself for a wild and terrifying ride.

Thrilling film in which a scientific team goes horribly wrong, releasing the deadliest ocean predators that have ever roamed the seas since prehistoric times. Jonas Taylor: Jason Statham continues to dedicate himself to the environmental care of the oceans and collaborates with the Hainan Oceanographic Institute, China. In this place, Haiqui, a female megalodon that the director of the center intends to train, is kept imprisoned. Technological advances are evident, and now the team of marine ecologists can embark towards the unknown depths of the sea, however when the underwater expedition begins, Haiqui escapes. Then a trench and a malevolent mining operation that explodes free extinct vicious carnivorous animals causing bloody events with lots of gory scenes. As the deep-sea scientific team encounter the largest ferocious marine prehistoric predator that has ever existed - the Megalodon and in its own way wreaking havoc. Get ready for the ultimate adrenaline rush this summer in "Meg 2: The Trench" !. Dive into uncharted waters with Jason Statham and global action icon Wu Jing as they lead a daring research team on an exploratory dive into the deepest depths of the ocean! Immerse yourself in the most electrifying cinematic experience of the year with "Meg 2: The Trench" - where the depths of the ocean are matched only by the heights of sheer, unstoppable excitement !. New Meg. Old Chum. Back for seconds. There is always another one. Terror has never run this deep...Fear runs deep.\nYou already know that this movie is about a prehistoric mega-shark rising from the depths and terrorizing the scientists crew. An inferior and literally larger-than-life thrill ride that supersizes the 2018 blockbuster and takes the action to higher heights and even greater depths with multiple massive Megs and so much more. It's a so-so action monster monster movie with a creepy creation of tension , thrills , terror and lots of bloody attacks. The released prehistoric man-eating Megalodon that joins with others of the same species deliver the goods, as the swimmers become their next meal while the scientists must band together to stop themselves from becoming fish food. Here our heroes and heroines pitted against colossal Megs, gigantic octopus, huge toothy monitors and relentless environmental plunderers, our heroes must outrun, outsmart, and outswim their merciless predators in a pulse-pounding race against time. This is a peculiar rip-off to classic Jaws (1975) by Steven Spielberg and Piranha (1978) by Joe Dante, taking parts here and there of these films . Stars Jason Statham giving his ordinary acting as a two-fisted veteran deep-sea rescue diver must confront his fears and risk his own life and the lives of everyone trapped below. If you liked Jason Statham in the first The Meg movie, you will enjoy this follow-up with the iconic actor doing his thing, and facing more monsters than ever. The hunk starring is well accompanied by a fine cast , such as : Jing Wu, Sienna Guillory, Cliff Curtis, Sophia Cai, Page Kennedy, Sergio Peris-Mencheta, Skyler Samuels, Melissanthi Mahut, Whoopie Van Raam, Kiran Sonia Sawar, among others. The motion picture was mediocrely and with no originality directed by Ben Wheatley (The ABCs of Death, Tourists, Rebeca, High Rise, Doctor Who, In the earth, Free fire).\nThe first Â¨MegalodonÂ¨ (2018) by John Turteltaub with Jaon Statham, Bingbing Li, Rainn Wilson, Cliff Curtis, Ruby Rose , Winston Chao, Sophia Cai, Page Kennedy , Darri Ã“lafsson, Robert Taylor, Jessica McNamee and Masi Oka has already created a mini-subgenre with imitations and rip-offs about this prehistorical animals , though some of them had been previously made , such as : Â¨Megalodon (2002)Â¨ by Pat Corbitt with Robin Sachs , Al Sapienza, Mark Sheppard.Â¨Shark Attack 3: MegalodonÂ¨ (2002) by David Worth with John Barrowman, Jenny McShane, Ryan Cutrona. Â¨MegalodonÂ¨ (2018) by James Thomas with Michael Madsen , Caroline Harris. Â¨Megalodon RisingÂ¨ (2021) with Tom Sizemore , Wynter Eddins, O'Shay Neal . Â¨Bigfoot vs MegalodonÂ¨ (2021) by BC Fourteen, among others.

I don't think there is much more to say. Horrible. Pathetic. I just don't understand why garbage like this get made. The makers shou be embarrassed.
The movie continues to get worse every minute it plays. The science has to be explained because how dumb it is
I usually like Jason, he was about all the film had.
Story is horrible.. Story is horrible.. Story is horrible
CGI is really really bad. Like cartoons. Save yourself the money cause it's not worth spending money on this one. Or watch it,,, and give it a review. Maybe someone will read it and feel bad for making the movie. I wish it was as good as the first one.

Look, I don't know what people have as far as expectations for the movie industry these days, but all I expect is to be entertained. I was entertained. This movie was fun and although it was not as good as the first movie, it was still entertaining to watch. Yes, the X could've been better, but seeing is though this is a megalodon shark movie I give it some grace for jumping the shark. No pun intended. I did not come into this expecting it to be scientifically, correct if you come into this movie expecting that you are setting yourself up for failure. Just sit back. Relax and enjoy the movie .

The first part of the movie , well more like 2/3's was trying to be a suspense/ action movie w a bit of sci-fi, and drama...then it turned into a comedy/horror failed attempt at camp flick. Essentially this film is a "what not to do when making a film in any genre 101" . I gave it a 2 or 3 stars because I actually don't even think there's anything the actors could do to save the script so the acting isn't even the worse part.
What I expected and what it was...
I didn't expect this to be scary but at least have some jump scares and a bit of excitement and some cohesive story however I found myself fast forwarding through most of the first half's dialogue because it was that boring. The action scenes are pretty bad with overdone Cgi making it hard to even follow what is happening in the scene. I actually kept forgetting some scenes were supposed to be under water as it didn't resemble water at all, it looked more like bad space scenes.
Another issue was the way the actors were so unaffected by things, like when their friends and family are possibly dead the rest of the crew acts so matter of fact that it leaves the viewer not caring either.
It's a good movie to keep on while doing house work since there's only a couple ok scenes and the storyline is pretty dumb.

I am certain that this film was made for the sole reason of giving the actors and crew a reason to go on location in Phuket, Thailand. I expected the film to be a bit of fun or maybe have some funny moments, but nope ... that didn't happen. My viewing standards have changed over the years so maybe I simply cannot get into these sort of movies any longer. And here's a very strange observation: Anyone in the cast who had a villainous role was a poster-child for bad cosmetic surgery and/or 'roid use. The only character I liked was DJ (Page Kennedy) who is reprising his role from 2018's "The Meg". I liked him because he seemed like the only half-way believable and sane actor in the entire film. And the monsters were cartoonish.

Just got through watching the Meg 2. I thought the first one was a stretch, but maybe could happen. This one, while interesting was just so farfetched and ridiculous. That I was asking myself...how LONG is this movie. Is it over yet? That's a bad sign. I appreciate that most of the cast returned for the second movie, but the constant comedic quips and outlandish fighting scenes, like firing a .50 caliber firearm while leaping sideways to shoot a prehistoric creature is just one such instance. I know movies like to go bigger and better than the first movie, but really...it was a bit TOO much. I'm praying there isn't a Meg 3 in the works. Peace.

The first one was really quite bad, but at least seemed self aware of its mindless creature feature nature. It still had the occasional jump scare and silly "so bad, it's funny" moments. This sequel has absolutely nothing going for it. I'm being generous with a 2/10. It was boring nonsense from beginning to end. Terrible performances across the board, worse than terrible writing with wall to wall cringe worthy dialogue... I get what they were going for trying to pack in other scary creatures but meh. Lame execution and didn't care enough about any single character to respond to what crazy thing was eating who.\nMaybe the stupid "Chomp On This" hip hop credits song would have been funny if any part of the movie had been remotely entertaining. Instead, it made it even worse because the confident tone of it only works if any part of the film had been successful and satisfying.\nDo not waste your time.

Most of the movie doesn't have much Meg in it.
But it does have forgettable characters, bland writing and quite a few "China good" moments to remind us who funded it
.
It doesn't even rate as a good, bad shark movie; which I enjoy. Even with questionable CGI and Statham action scenes that look like they were lifted out of Crank with the slightly oddly paced movement when he is running or on a jetski. It just seemed disjointed and odd.
I couldn't manage to make myself care who was in danger, who was killed and who was surviving; largely because everyone was so bland. The one guy seemed to be channeling Jackie Chan a couple times, which was entertaining but it didn't fit with his character at all.

I am going to get right to the point. This was a pretty bad movie. I decided to give it a second star only because the CGI was stellar. The story was terrible. The acting was a mix between decent actors and b rate actors. The camera angles were silly. There was a lot of mondless action sequencies. Just like the first movie, the parts of this movie that was meant to be funny were silly. It made the movie awkward.\nThe bottom line is, without going into the movie and providing spoilers, I would simply suggest to consider watching something else and not waste time watching this dud of a movie. Regardless how bad it is, I'll bet there will be a Meg 3 that will be just as bad if not worse.

A Middle School Play about sharks My twelve year old could write a better sequel. I usually allow for a bit of movie logic, but this isn't charming enough. At the bottom of the trench, there is about 8 tons of pressure. Things like walking from another station in a suit would take hours (longer than any air supply) and rising to the surface quickly would be fatal. Most actors don't realize how bad a movie is going to be during the process of filming. Jason Statham's acting is a bright spot in a dull movie. Most of the action is preposterous. The dialogue is horrible. Despite this, the last 10 minutes are somewhat entertaining.

This film has fallen victim of mis-listing: someone somewhere put the tags "comedy" and "thriller" beside the title, that is. It is neither though. It is a dark satire: a vitriolic portray of loathsome characters in an allegory. So, if you know what a satire is supposed to be like AND you like the genre, you'll probably like The Menu. If you don't know what a satire is, google it before watching. If you don't like what you'd find, don't waste your time on the film, as you wouldn't like it either. If you don't feel like googling, here are some clues: it's NOT funny, there's NO character development and NO catharsis. If In fact you'll probably feel annoyed, tense and a bit sick to your stomach by the end, as it DOES show mirror to the middle class wannabe connoiseurs of all kinds. So if you still watch it and you don't like that you see... well.... You've been warned.

Ive worked at the restaurant industry for seven years. Customers can truely make or break your day. This movie explores the dynamic between server and customer, with over the top drama and horror. It is such a unique movie, because they really make you feel the built up frustration of the servers and cooks.
There is great attention to detail in the movie. The dishes look fly af, which I think is a great addition. In the beginning, you feel like youre experiencing the dishes with the customers. This makes the movie that much more intruiging.
After Jeremies 'the mess', things take a turn. It becomes more of a 'saw' type of thing. Of course, the movie had to take this turn. However, I felt like the turn could have been more subtle. The servers are all unanimously suicidal, insane and sadistic. I understand that this could be some sort of analogy for the thoughts I used to have when having a bad day at work. Still, the movie turns bizarre at this point.
All in all, I liked it. Great acting, asthonishing dishes, thrilling story. A bit over the top, but that did not spoil my appetite fortunately.

I enjoyed the first half, the food tasting and watching the show.
But as a whole the movie leaves a bad taste, a thick toxic anti-rich people sentiment and other political messaging, with an unlikeable female lead (naturally, everyone was unlikeable but felt incorrect that she was too). A pity, it was so close to being good.
Zooming out, there is probably some high IQ satirizing I just don't get. As it could probably be deconstructed into various deeper takes on society; paradoxical as a similar deconstruction (this intellectual circle jerking and food critique) was the very thing that was depicted satirically in the movie to begin with. How quaint... - see I can sound like a movie critic too, but Chef knows I really belong in the kitchen.
Anyway, why do they push so hard that society only consists of two kinds of people: takers and producers (proletariat)? A peculiar dichotomy, too toxic for me, but maybe I just don't understand.

A surreal film that evoked numerous emotions within me,
High visual quality and great storytelling,
A fantastic, profound story full of surprises,
An exceptional work that is rarely matched!
The output quality was professional, and the story plot was thrilling. I liked the unexpected and coherent sequence of events! I admired the portrayal of the social pressure and occupational burnout caused by capitalism on the chef!
It was unexpected that there was no dialogue at the end. The girl's reaction after being rescued was not announced; it only stopped when the restaurant exploded!
The movie has an underlying message, which is "you should listen to others to understand them and know how to interact with them, and you should find someone who listens to you." When the girl heard the chef and spoke to him, confronting him, it was a great gesture that saved her life.

What a waste of time. Really.
Started nice. Good Atmosphere.
But then it went downhill the whole time.
You are waiting for a twist, for it to make sense, for anything to happen really. But it doesnt.
The guests dont do nothing while people get killed, while knowing they are gonna be killed. Yeah, Sure. ðŸ¤¦ No character close to a human in this storyline.
All characters are flat as F and not relatable. They act like they are aliens. And you dont care for them, since they dont do anything.
Who wrote that? WTH
It's like a dude on the street had one tiny idea about a point he wanted to make and then he accidentally won the lottery to produce a movie, while all authors and screenplay writers were on strike. So he just did it in his own. In one night.
Reviewers here call it great satire on rich people here, cause it's "different" and depicts rich peoples obsession over art. Or that people consume Till the end even when they know this will kill them. All that stuff. Bluh bluh. It just doesnt work.
The irony: these reviewers might be exactly these "art obsessed" people they are talking about. Interpreting the "overall picture" and stuff in it to make themselves important by "understanding" the movie, while others (like me) are just bored as hell.
The movie is consistent in it's stupidity.
What a waste of Ralph Fiennes btw. (and pretty much any actor in this movie; but hey, they got paid)

If they didn't tell white people this was a comedy they would never know.... Or is this funny to them? As I sit in between my blackness and my girlfriend (which has direct recent European ancestry) I ponder the entire world in the 43mins I could take before I started to feel like my brain cells were being destroyed, what's wrong with them? This movie was not how I would imagined it to go. I decided to watch because of the cast and its food theme but watching this without expectations got me excited again about watching movies again.\nTo me, the overall beauty was in the story and aesthetics that created an enjoyable watching experience. It reminded me of the beauty of polished craftmanship and how there is always a way out but we choose to follow the obvious path. I also loved how in each turn I got surprised and I would not have guessed how it ends. In addition to being beautiful and witty, I will carry many of the insights for the future as well.

This is a brilliant psychological horror i have ever watched. It's a satire on class and humour parody of the pretentious art and culinary culture.
I completely agree with makers opinion. Most of the times Cheap Dhaba (a roadside food stall) provides delicious food full of love. But costly 5-star restaurant's foods not even looks like food. Because the main soul of food to satisfy hunger is missing and only showpiece is offered in the name of exotic dishes. All hell to our normal dhaba food.
Ralph Fiennes is formidable as the head chef. Anya Taylor-Joy is just perfect as always.
A highly recommend film to watch.

A truly pointless movie if you can call it that . I wish I hadn't wasted almost 2 hours on this . Ralph Fiennes is a great actor and should have avoided this . Everyone was deadpan and lacked anything remotely artistic. The thrills, shrills and spills were constipated at best . Maybe the director was just high - who knows .\nI'm surprised Disney actually put it up on their platform so good I didn't waste any money in theatres . What trips me up is that this nonsense actually got a 7.2 rating and some people rated this as a satire - of what ? Their non existent brains or their pathetic reviewing skills.\nAvoid !

So, not intelectual, not entertaining, and absolutely not interesting.

FILM: 7.5/10.
Stuck in a mandatory two-week quarantine, Ti West did what any filmmaker would do - he wrote a prequel to a film he hadn't even shot. Collaborating with lead Mia Goth, they churned out a script for Pearl, the prequel to X, and A24 greenlit it for shooting before a single frame of X was seen. Turns out, it was a smart decision. Pearl not only stands as an excellent film in its own right but also surpasses its predecessor.
Ti West and his team maintain consistency with X, yet Pearl takes a wholly different approach. While X had a grungy, grainy look capturing the essence of 1979, Pearl embraces a clean, vibrant, and pure aesthetic - a perfect reflection of how the character Pearl sees herself in the world.
Unlike X's ensemble approach, Pearl places the load on Mia Goth's shoulders, and she delivers a fantastic performance. As a psychotic imitation of Judy Garland's Dorothy from The Wizard of Oz, Goth brings a unique and captivating energy to her character. David Corenswet, known for being the newly cast Superman, impresses as the Projectionist, giving me an opportunity to witness his talent beyond a single House of Cards episode.
Much like X, Pearl takes its time with the horror elements, and when the terror unfolds, it's as gloriously entertaining as its predecessor. What sets it apart, however, is its effectiveness in contrasting with the vibrant experience earlier in the film. Ti West's Pearl is a smart and visually striking prequel that successfully navigates the horror genre with finesse, proving that even in quarantine, creative risks can pay off. Ultimately, it stands as a superior counterpart to X.
