It's a formulaic pretentious, boring movie. It has all the elements of a horror cult, but without any substance to it. Mia Goth is phenomenal, but it's such a waste to see a performance like that in a very dull movie. People seem to be impressed very easily these days considering I can only assume all the hype comes from Goth's acting, that monologue and the final smile that closes the film, but at least in my opinion those are not enough to make this movie any good and, especially, consistent. I think the first movie was ok and I'm still curious to see what Goth will pull off next time, but I don't want to see that pathetic smile ever again in my life.

I can only assume this is getting good reviews because people adore Mia Goth and can't get enough of her playing crazy people, because, as a film, this just does not work. It's not scary, lacks tension, is badly structured and poorly paced, and is in DIRE need of an editor. It feels both too long and too short, like it ends at the end of the second act. It's barely even a film - just a bunch of acting and a thin, half-arsed script, with some pretentious and undeveloped Wizard Of Oz stylings thrown in. Scenes drag on forever, way past the point of terminal boredom, just so that Goth can show off her acting. I've never felt so much impatience and fidgeting in a cinema. The ending is supposed to be disturbing, but it just ends up being comical.\nTo put this into perspective, I thought 'X' was ok, slightly above -average but nothing special. I thought House Of The Devil was a minor classic, and I thought The Sacrament was quite effective and tense. Mia Goth is a good actor, but she always seems to play the same part. 'Pearl' just feels like an actor's indulgence.

Incredible to see people rating this pretentious fare so highly, but I guess that's modern tastes for you and I'm somehow out of sync with everybody else. This one's a prequel to the dire X and turns out to be even worse, a ridiculous 'origin' story that's so slim it doesn't require telling in the first place. Mia Goth is the star turn here and delivers a twee, over the top performance, her acting so mannered and false from the outset that I could barely bring myself to watch her. There are a few predictable deaths but they're overshadowed by the director's decision to shoot this like an old fashioned Technicolor epic for no good reason. The end result? A film utterly devoid of substance.

Look, it's fine. Arguably, better than fine - it's good. But that's it! Yes Mia Goth is terrific, as she always is, but the delirious level of praise I'm seeing in numerous reviews giving it 8 or 9 stars is frankly mind boggling, and was what spurred me to write this "everyone just calm down" of a review.\nTo those reviewers that raved about this movie and bestowed the superlative 9 stars, I have but a simple question: have you not watched any other films before? I'm trying really hard not to be condescending (ok, not that hard), but if this flic merits 9 stars, then what on earth do any of the following films merit? Alien, The Shining, Interstellar, The Departed, The Prestige, Inception... to name but a few.\nLike I said, it's good. But it's not even in the top 5 Mia Goth films: The Survivalist, Suspiria, Emma, Infinity Pool, A cure for wellness. Go watch those before this!

The year is 1918. Young Pearl (Mia Goth) has returned to live on her parents' farm after her husband Howard (Alistair Sewell) was drafted into the Great War. Pearl dreams of being a great dancer, famous throughout the country, so her frustration in returning to live at her parents' house, where she needs to take care of her sick father and is constantly humiliated by her mother, is enormous. When she discovers that a selection process for new artists in a dance company will be held in her city, Pearl sees the opportunity for the life she always wanted. But the consequences of her decision will go far beyond what she could imagine.
Created by Ti West and Mia Goth, and produced simultaneously with "X", "Pearl" is the sequel that many fans of the previous film didn't know they needed. Overexplaining is often condemned in horror cinema, and the story of the elderly murderer in "X" really required no further explanation. But West and Goth treat the character's transformation process with so much care and affection that the minimal references covered (such as the justification of the character's anger towards blondes, or the iconic gesture of silence) work almost like fan service. Just like its eponymous protagonist, "Pearl" is a film with many layers. It can be seen as just an origin story, but it is much more than that. It is also an essay on mental health, taking into account the psychotic tendencies demonstrated by the character from the beginning, exacerbated by the cornering imposed by her own reality.
Explaining who the damn villain was who turned our stomachs with such graphic deaths, the prequel to "X" is not that classic jump scare horror, but it is definitely an impeccable essay on a psychotic break. Pearl's (Mia Goth) reality could drive anyone crazy. With her husband at war, she dedicates her days back to her parents' house, where she must take care of her father - who remains in a vegetative state -, while being constantly humiliated and mistreated by her mother. Between the chores on the farm and the palliative care that takes away her energy, she dreams of the life of a star on stage and in cinema. Always between the purest and most mind-blowing fantasy and a harsh reality never desired, she tries to chart her path towards success, fame and plastic beauty. What they didn't tell you is that in an arid land, dreams born from the field don't tend to flourish. And under a very technicolor aesthetic, which harks back to the format of films from the 50s and 60s, Ti West delivers another brilliant horror that goes much further than the combo of scares that normally awaits us in a slasher horror. "Pearl" is in fact a chaotic spiral of a young woman adrift of her own existence, who perishes in a mediocre life where her identity and personality are stifled and succumbed to the pressures of an aggressive, insensitive and indifferent matriarch. But regardless of the family context that brought Pearl to us, it is undeniable that villainy already lived within her, as West makes a point of showing in her tortuous way of sacrificing defenseless animals. And this construction is fundamental to turning the elderly Pearl from "X" into a cruel and monstrous creature in the eyes of the characters and, obviously, the audience.
The story takes place in the 60s, at the beginning of the 20th century. In the typical horror setting of rural, isolated and silent America, we meet Pearl (Mia Goth), a seemingly ordinary young woman in pre-Depression America. Pearl is tormented by the anguish of her husband's return from war. This anguish gives part of the tone of the film. Anxiety gives Pearl a feeling of stagnation, of being there and stuck with her family. Pearl needs to take care of her father, who needs special care. She needs to be surrounded by her mother, who judges her and weighs her relationship with the world - a classic for complex female characters. But the family does not appear to be extremely dysfunctional like in other films of the genre. With a surgical simplicity, the photography and scenography perfectly mask what lies behind this bucolic setting. Like a bad apple: rotten on the inside, but very beautiful on the outside.
Here we have the interesting issue of mixing times and themes. A narrative with deep discussions about the feminine, family conflicts and psychoses, issues that derive from the culmination of crises between the different areas of a human being's mind, so explored in horror cinema from the seventies - there we have infinite iconic examples of characters who they stained the youthful imagination of the time with blood - but in a setting from the beginning of the 20th century. The focus on emotions and family relationships, a vulnerable and uncertain main character, who develops into a very subversive and adverse heroine's trajectory, and a lot of symbolic depth, transform "Pearl" into a beautiful way of making bloody cinema.
The film features "gore" scenes from the beginning, but it is in the second half that things start to get even stranger. Ti West manages to make us nervous by bringing horror scenes that take place in the dark or in broad daylight, causing that nail-biting anxiety just because we are sure that what is coming is not at all good. The characterization with more colorful tones and farm settings that bring peace, and even remind us of "The Sound of Music", contrast perfectly with the slasher every time blood is spilled. But terror is also in every word and attitude of the protagonist, who surprises in several moments, such as a frightening and uncut monologue seen in the final moments of the film. Pearl ends up discovering that the film industry also relies on pornography, and this discovery is crucial to the plot's relationship with "X", which takes place more than 60 years after "Pearl".
Connecting both films in a natural and almost imperceptible way, this is a derivative that stands on its own two feet and in several moments is nothing like "X". With a slightly metalinguistic approach and a different narrative development, the film focuses on the self-destructive journey of a young woman who goes crazy in the face of her reality and the impossibility of her dreams. The plot of "Pearl" is simple, only on the surface. And this is because the complexity of the narrative does not revolve around the story itself (although it contributes, of course, to the final result), but rather, its protagonist. In this sense, Ti West's film is a beautiful character study, a lesson in how to explore the different facets of a figure and what led her to become what she became.
In fact, it would be unfair to praise only Ti West for the successes of "Pearl", given that Mia Goth is also one of the work's screenwriters and producers. The actress not only helped create an entire narrative conducive to the protagonist's transformation into a terrible villain, but also delivered an award-worthy performance (no wonder, many complained about her absence in the Best Actress category at the 2023 Oscars). It is impressive how the artist manages to reinvent herself throughout the narrative, going from a naive and hopeful girl to a disillusioned and broken woman, who rebuilds herself through a cold, villainous figure, who has no problem murdering her own parents, her love interest, husband and sister-in-law in favor of what she wants most: fame (or would it be freedom through fame?). Talking about how the actress alternates between periods of remission and psychotic episodes in a matter of seconds, or the show of expressions in her smile in the final scene, is redundant. But what she delivers in an 8-minute-long monologue in the last act of the film is astounding. The young woman's speech, filmed without cuts (seriously, the passage is exquisite), summarizes everything that Pearl carried within her: frustration, depression, sadness, anger, love, dreams and so on. All cards are laid out on the table with an emotion and intensity that are not so common to see, especially in horror films, which tend to focus much more on their scary plots than on the development of their characters. And we still couldn't fail to mention the next scene, with the ax sequence, which is simply harrowing.
Filling its second act with a bloodthirsty that will fill the eyes of those most hungry for slashers, "Pearl" still makes room for a touch of humor and plays with the emotional fluctuations of its protagonist, transforming it into a small mix between horror and a sarcasm with an acidic and cutting humor. Violent but not at all scary, Ti West's newest film is something of a villain's journey. While making a number of connections, the film doesn't add anything genuinely new to "The Mark of Death," it's a wonderful companion piece, the kind of conceptual horror that's so meticulously well-made, it deserves to be enjoyed even as a one-off experience. A young woman face to face with the worst version of herself.
The film also brings an interesting critique about fame: is anything worth it to reach the top? For Pearl, limits are non-existent and there is nothing more important than the glamor of the stage. In this sense, her blood-red clothing, used during the last act of the film, in addition to representing the deaths she carries with her, is a symbol of her passion and obsession (red usually has this connotation in cinematographic works). With a masterful performance by Mia Goth, "Pearl" is a pleasant surprise and hits the nail on the head when exploring the limits of a character full of traumas, dreams and frustrations who, despite everything, apparently, will never stop believing that she is a star.

I've now seen all three of Mia Goth's extraordinary A24 movies this year. In each one she has singlehandedly carried the movie to ridiculous heights of greatness.
All three are billed as horror (X as a slasher, Infinity Pool as an unhinged psychopath study and Pearl as another psychopath gestational study).
All three deepen A24's reputation as the distributor of the year/decade, the greatest signifier of quality in moviemaking right now.
All three mark out Goth as the leading horror female actor in history if not, increasingly, one of the great female actors of her generation full stop.
It's Pearl that that confirms this most potently as her performance is jaw dropping throughout.
It's the origin piece for X, but the two movies could hardly be less similar, even though the central character is the same person (60 years apart) and shot on the same farm location in Kansas.
This tells the tale of young married Pearl with her husband labouring in the European trenches of WWII, her father a wheelchair stricken quadriplegic - a victim of the Spanish Flu which is a clever reference as it was written by Goth and Director Ti West during lockdown - and her raging mother, a German immigrant trapped by her crippled husband in rural America and resentful to the back teeth because of it.
Goth (Pearl) wants to escape this and become a dancer but is thwarted at auditions for not being blonde enough. This triggers her inner psychopath and whilst we don't get a rampage on the scale of X we do see her nascent evil emerge.
It's Goth's startling performance and Ti West's dazzling direction that marks this out as a horror of sheer class, although in truth it's not really a horror at all: not a single jump scare and very little in the way of butchery.
Two scenes stand out, both featuring Goth, a long monologue to her friend and the closing credits which are reminiscent of Sinead Connor's classic pop video.
This is movie making at its finest and a must see in my opinion.

I simply do not understand people's infatuation with this movie. What do they see that I don't? A pointless, predictable, pretentious flim that drags on and on. It felt like a 2+ hour movie. Mia Goth is a good actress, I'm not denying that, but she needs better material. This is a prequel to X, which was okay at best, that sheds very little light on what happens in X. Just a lot of goofing around and mugging for the camera. Apparently Ti West and Mia Goth wrote this while in quarantine to shoot X in during the pandemic. It makes sense because it felt like something that was wrote in a few days and just thrown together. Most of the "character developments" here were implied in X and really didn't need to be shown. What a waste of time.

So, I got this off an article about Martin Scorsese, telling me "80 Films the Director Wants You to See." (First off, Marty's got some unusual selections in there, including a fair amount of horror). "Pearl" is definitely unique and visually appealing, and this story of a Midwest farmgirl maniacally obsessing over fame, stardom, and a new life, seems to have developed a cult following on the edge of town outside the mainstream.\nI generally don't do slasher films, but I'm not above a little blood-soaked fun in my thriller-mysteries. Pearl is an angelic-faced dreamer who... well, let's say you don't want to disappoint her... or face her wrath. I thought the story was a little odd and thin, but it was like a train wreck you can't look away from. If you like your unexpected carnage plated sweetly, like apple pie or corn on the cob, this wholesome girl might be just the server for you. I was a 6.5 but I rounded up because hey, Martin Scorsese. Duh.

Although I had low expectations for this movie, after watching it, I believe it is one of the best movies I have watched. Mia Goth's acting is outstanding, and teh characterization and character development of the protagonist, Pearl, is also very well done.\nI usually prefer watching movies with more gore, jumpscares, or creepier. However, I was recommended this movie, so I watched it. As mentioned before, my expectations were low because I knew the film was not going to be as scary as other movies I have watched that I love. Nevertheless, I admit the movie kept me entretained the whole time, which does not happen often.\nI may have liked some slight changes in the plot, which I won't mention to avoid spoilers. Regardless wether I am or not satisfied with those, the film deserves 10 stars because it is just very well done. Specially because, like mentioned before, Mia Goth's acting was perfect.

Christmas and horror, a terrible mixture? Less than one might think, the film works as a special gem in both moods, although I wouldn't include it in my / a Christmas film collection, because the festival of festivals only appears from time to time in passing. And beware, those who are approaching maturity should definitely be excluded from watching this film: harsh language, the fundamentally disturbing mixture of premises mentioned above and, of course, the fact that we have a real slasher precursor here, despite the early year of its production. After Psycho, the Giallos and before the classic slasher wave comes somewhat lonely Black Christmas. And here various optional basics are already being practised, the killer-me perspective, yes, before Halloween, that there doesn't necessarily need to be an obvious motive for murder and that young ladies are a favourite target of the madmen.\nBut of course we are still in the middle of the 70s. The production focuses more on suspense than on explicit bloodlust, and the killings are packaged indirectly through special camera and sound sequences. So beware again, gorehounds could definitely be disappointed here, just like those who need high tempo and constant thrills. Nevertheless, the fantastic finale should please every genre fan.

It appears many are having a difficult time conducting a review of a 1974 film through a 2023 lens, I was in grade eight when this movie came out and I can remember two classmates sneaking into the theatre to watch this movie and they quickly became folk hero's for their effort. Movies like Black Christmas and The Texas Chainsaw were gritty ground breaking terror in their day and the original films still hold up today - so when reviewing them take that in to consideration and appreciate them for what they are, disturbing poorly lit sets and poor sound quality are all part of the classic charm.

Let me preface this post by pointing out that the reason there are so many bad reviews for this movie is because a bunch of dingus's didn't bother to check that they were reviewing the right movie. Black Christmas was released in 1974. Which I'll be reviewing. It was then remade in 2006, and remade again in 2019. And from what I've heard about the most recent remake, it deserves the harsh criticism.
Now as for the original: I absolutely loved it. I saddens me that horror films like this aren't produced as much anymore. It's far easier to just throw together a cheesy, terrible plot, and accent it with cheap jump scares, cringe-worthy dialogue, and visual effects nowadays. Looking back at the films that made the genre what it is today has helped me realize, at least, how much the horror genre as a whole has devolved over the years, and helps me truly appreciate the gems that come out every now and then that defy genre norms today.
Although the movie is labeled a horror/slasher film, I think it effectively utilizes terror throughout, as opposed to horror. For most those words probably mean the same thing, but without spoiling anything that happens in the film, let me explain the difference between horror and terror. Horror and terror are both types of fear: horror manifests itself in known threats more often than not, whereas terror manifests in unknown/unseen threats. It's an oversimplified distinction technically, but make of that what you will before watching the movie and you will see what difference the approach to fear makes in a "horror" film.
Other than the execution, the cinematography was good, the acting was good...for the most part. There were some characters that I thought could have done better, but there were no awful actors. The pacing was quite good, although I feel they could have shortened the introduction a little. Overall it was just a great film.

I suppose a sorority can be used to host a multitude of characters, so that's what Bob Clark does here as he puts four quite different girls into an house supervised by the likably dypso "Mrs. Mac" (Marian Waldman). The house has, for ages now, being getting crank calls from a guy they call the "moaner". Some get upset by his behaviour, others laugh it off but when one of their number "Clare" (Lynne Griffin) disappears and the police are called in by her boyfriend "Chris" (Art Hindle), the sense of menace ratchets up a notch. As we get to know these characters, there are quite a few suspects and quite a few decent reasons why we might want to bump them all off. "Jess" (Olivia Hussey) is expecting a child with wayward boyfriend "Pete" (Keir Dullea) only he doesn't know it yet; give-as-good-as-you-get "Barb" (Margot Kidder) quite likes to goad their would-be tormentor ("Billy") - much to his obvious chagrin. More menacing yet is the increasingly detailed knowledge contained in the calls. "Billy" is spookily well informed. Could he be one of them? I'm not too sure what this has to have to do with Christmas, to be honest. It's just another typical slasher set amongst a student fraternity that gives everyone an opportunity to scream and make some shockingly poor under-pressure decisions. Neither the acting nor the writing stand out but the photography is quite effective at creating and sustaining a modest sense of peril as our killer nears goal. It's not really very scary, indeed time hasn't been to kind to it at all - but it's watchable if you like the genre and have taken a drink or two.

For someone who's watched as many 'slasher' films in my time (and enjoyed many a 'gore-fest' along the way!) it's taken me until 2023 to watch 'Black Christmas,' which. If the internet trivia is to be believed, is up there with horror classics like 'The Texas Chainsaw Massacre' and 'Halloween' - in bringing the 'slasher' genre to the mainstream.
It's about a killer, stalking residents of a sorority house one Christmas and, er, that's about it. It's pretty simple in terms of story, but then most slasher films tend to be that way. I hear that much the major gore was cut in order to get it released - and it shows.
I would imagine that almost everything contained within this film would be considered 'shocking' and 'revolutionary' in terms of on-screen scares, whereas today, it's just kind of tame.
As I say, there's not much gore. And there's not much that you haven't seen in a hundred similar movies. I suppose there's something to be got out of the story in trying to guess who the killer is (I confess, I never managed to see how it would eventually end).
The characters are likable enough - those who are meant to be. And there are a few 'red herrings' thrown in there for good measure. The police were suitably useless in their efforts in catching the killer, but then if they were competent the film's runtime would be about ten minutes.
'Black Christmas' is worth a watch if you like competent slasher films - there's nothing here that's bad, but, after over forty years, there's nothing here that new either.

I have heard about this Christmas horror movie before, and I have been hearing people say that they love it or think it is an underrated horror movie; after watching the movie, I can agree that it is good and that it is a bit underrated. The movie Black Christmas (1974) is a creepy, disturbing, and mostly suspenseful horror movie that uses Christmas time in an investing way; plus, each girl in the sorority house has something happen to them, most of them having to deal with realistic problems, which makes it disturbing, not just because of a maniac killer being in the movie.
The girls in the sorority are going through their own problems, like one of them wanting an abortion despite her boyfriend not wanting that, but there is also a maniac killer in the attic of the sorority house with nobody knowing; it makes the movie disturbing with the real problems the characters are going through, but also it makes it creepy with the way some characters act and the killer in the house. Along with that, the characters are like teenagers doing what teenagers do, but they do act like adults surprisingly; making rational choices like calling the police or trying not to answer the phone because of the many creepy and weird calls they get.
I like that we never see the killer's face because he is covered by shadows or hides in darkness the whole movie, while also giving us his point of view where we only see his hands and his shoes when walking around; most of the cinematography have long takes and camera pans around the house that works with the creepy tone. Though the movie is rated R, which is for language and frightening scenes, it is not that gory, but it has disturbing kills in the movie that are still effective and are executed in ways that fit the Christmas holiday.
Black Christmas (1974) is a Christmas horror film that is worth giving a watch, though it takes its time building up to a point where it gets creepier, it is a highly effective movie that will creep you out and disturb you from beginning to end. The acting is not bad, the cinematography is well done, the antagonist hiding in the house is creepy, and the Christmas vibe with the movie works well with the horror side of the plot; this movie is underrated and is worth watching at least once.

Black Christmas (1974) is a horror and slasher film that I have seen over and over again ever since I was a teenager. It is written and directed by none-other than the talented filmmaker Bob Clark and it stars, Olivia Hussey, Keir Dullea, Margot Kidder and John Saxon (from Wes Craven's original A Nightmare On Elm Street 1984) The film centers around a group of college aged women who are in a sorority house, and they get killed off by an unknown serial killer after and while he makes very disturbing obscene phone calls to the home, which is probably located near a university that they attend during the college school year. This is the best horror and slasher movie that is set during the Christmas holiday. The script is magnificently written, the dialogue provides very realistic conversations. If Olivia Hussey didn't get more movie roles after her performance in Black Christmas then I would really love to know why. All of the kills are very brutal in this film, and much like the original Halloween movie that John Carpenter would later write and direct in 1978, Black Christmas has the same technique of using violence that is implied rather being graphic and gory. Unlike the 2006 remake of this film, it's what you don't see and have to you use your imagination to imagine what the kills look like graphically that is terrifying and scary to anyone who watches this movie. Black Christmas (1974) is on my top five favorite horror movie classics, it's very much on par with Halloween (1978) and the only other horror movie that is on par with the original Halloween and the original Black Christmas is Scream (1996) . I love the cinematography and the camera use in this movie. Like how the camera glides from place to place at times, and the ending is very good. I'm very happy that Bob Clark didn't turn Black Christmas into a horror franchise like how the movie studios did with the Halloween franchise. The opening kill scene with the use of a white bag being placed over Claire's head and face to suffocate and kill her is super graphic for 1974, but now a days it is very tame compared to the graphic and explicit violence that we see nowadays in horror films. Even though Olivia Hussey did an amazing job at playing the role of Jessica Bard ford, I do wonder if Margot Kidder would've played that role a little bit better. But nonetheless, Black Christmas is an amazing classic horror movie of the 1970s that strongly recommend and suggest that all horror fans watch for the Christmas season if you're looking for a great classic horror film to watch. A very high thumbs up for me.
Written by
Bailey Giannini
(movie buff and amateur film critic)

I don't want to say that "Black Christmas" is the granddaddy of them all but it probably is. There are many elements of this movie that have been copied many times in other horror movies. "Black Christmas" does skip a bit now and then but it always manages to right its ship. It delivers quite a few solid thrills. The cast is filled with familiar faces. I did find the killer more than a bit annoying but all of his noise isn't a deal breaker. The same way as other horror movies of the 1970's, "Black Christmas" is not nearly as bloody as people think. It's scarier than bloody. This is probably not saying much but this might be director Bob Clark's best movie.

Olivia husseys performance as Jessica here might just be up there with some of my favourite scream queens. Jessica is a serority girl living in a house with about eleven others. Most go off for christmas break leaving the others in the house. Its a good group of characters left. I was for some reason expecting to see blood and I thought it would be more grahpic than it. Never the less though black christmas pulls through and becomes an enjoyable dark christmas slasher. The suspense in this movie is built up well and I believe overall it was a pretty solid holiday horror. With a good cast and eerie suntrack bringing it all together.

I have never watched the full movie of Black Christmas, but when i finally did, I was impressed. I am talking about the original 1974 movie.
Black Christmas was the first of its kind. It gave us the first holiday slasher that used the point of view of the killer. John Carpenter would then use the same thing in Halloween four years later. In Black Christmas, just like Halloween, using the perspective from the killer adds a creepiness to the movie and adds to the dread.
The actors, mostly woman, were really good. Margot Kidder, soon to be Lois from Superman fame, also four years later, was a real stand out as Barb with her sassiness. Olivia Hussey was also very good.
The plot was simple. A maniac is on the loose and ends up in the attic of the sorority house where the girls are living. Most of the girls go home for the holidays, but a few stay behind, and the killer picks them off one by one, calling the sorority house phone after each death. I will say no more, so as not to spoil the movie for anyone who hasn't seen this. And once again, I am talking about the original 1974 film.
I would definitely recommend this movie, but some incompetence on the part of the police force takes a point away. The camera work is well done and the sound effects used were just as good.
This movie was entirely creepy with a few jump scares to add to it. I loved the way distraction was used so that our protagonists never realize the horrible things happening not far away from them.

Have you ever wondered what a person's path should be to become great? Talent, hard work, a nudge from the outside? What should be the motivation to practice the same skill for hours, days, weeks, years in hopes of one day becoming the best?
Honestly, I don't have answers to these questions. The very realization that I would have to practice the same thing on a regular basis over a long period of time throws me off. Constancy is clearly not my strong suit. Today I'm doing one thing, and tomorrow I'm burned out and doing something completely new. It's hard to master one skill perfectly under those circumstances, but you can try a lot of things. Maybe this is MY way - to try the world in all its diversity!
However, Andrew Newman knows exactly what he wants - he wants to become the best drummer and is ready to wipe his hands in blood to realize his dream. One day his playing is noticed by the conductor of the best student orchestra in the country and he is invited to join the troupe. As stereotypical as geniuses are often portrayed in movies, Damien Chazelle's film portrays the conductor himself as stereotypical - overbearing, ruthless, manipulative, but a true creator and builder. Are you ready to endure anger, rage and emotional swings from a mentor who wants to awaken the great musician in you?
After the tragic death of one of the conductor's previous students, an investigation begins into the teaching methods of Terence Fletcher (that's the conductor's name). At some point Andrew too breaks under the teacher's onslaught and it seems that the path to his dream is complete. So Andrew also decides to testify against his idol, after which the conductor is suspended from running the orchestra.
The story could have ended there, if not for the love of music. Some time later Terence invites Andrew to play the drum part at one of the festivals, which is important for the future of musicians - the jury members can give a ticket to life or close all roads to the professional world. Either out of a desire for revenge or intentionally manipulating Andrew's feelings once again, the conductor sets the drummer up and plays a part for which the drummer was unprepared, resulting in Andrew's public embarrassment. But instead of breaking down again, he takes the next beat into his own hands and already begins to lead the entire orchestra. In the end, Andrew and the conductor become so obsessed with the music and themselves that they produce something "beyond human capabilities," as Movie Search says about it. Without irony, the final scene was indeed very musical and inspired.
Nevertheless, I have mixed impressions about this movie. Some bitter aftertaste because of the behavior of the main character and his mentor. Probably because such teaching methods are just not for me. But maybe that's why I won't become great, who knows.
On the other hand, the drum parts with absolutely frantic rhythm and the general atmosphere of the movie are mesmerizing and keep you in suspense throughout the whole picture. So, I think it's worth watching, to at least answer for yourself the question about your limits on the way to perfection.
8 out of 10.

Wow, just wow. I'm sitting here, still catching my breath after watching "Whiplash," and I can't help but feel like I've just been through an emotional whirlwind. Damien Chazelle's masterpiece is unlike anything I've seen before, a heart-pounding symphony of ambition and obsession that left me on the edge of my seat from start to finish.
First off, let's talk about Miles Teller as Andrew Neiman. I was completely blown away by his performance. The guy not only nailed the intense drumming sequences (seriously, my heart was racing during those scenes), but he also brought such depth to his character. You could feel Andrew's burning desire for greatness, and as the story unfolded, I found myself both rooting for him and fearing for his sanity.
And J. K. Simmons as Terence Fletcher-wow, just wow. I can't imagine anyone else in that role. Simmons was a force of nature, this relentless, almost terrifying presence as the music instructor. Fletcher's teaching methods were borderline insane, but Simmons played him with such nuance that I found myself questioning whether his intensity was a necessary evil or just straight-up abuse of power. No wonder he bagged the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor.
The whole atmosphere of the film was just electric. The drumming, the jazz, the tension-it all blended together in this perfect storm of emotions. The cinematography and the score elevated every moment, making even the smallest practice session feel like a life-or-death situation. The way Chazelle captured the competitive world of music conservatories was nothing short of genius.
But it's not just about the music; it's about the human cost of chasing perfection. The film had me contemplating the lengths one should go to achieve greatness. Is it worth sacrificing everything? The relationships, the health, the sanity? "Whiplash" doesn't shy away from these tough questions, and it left me pondering the blurred lines between motivation and abuse, success and obsession.
The dialogue was razor-sharp. I mean, I could quote lines from this movie all day. Each word felt like a punch, driving home the film's themes about the relentless pursuit of one's dreams. And the editing-oh, don't get me started. The tight shots during drumming sequences, the rapid editing during confrontations, it all added to the intensity. I was literally on the edge of my seat, hanging on every beat.
In the end, "Whiplash" isn't just a movie; it's an experience. It celebrates the pursuit of excellence while forcing you to confront the price of that pursuit. I'm still processing everything, but one thing's for sure: "Whiplash" has left an indelible mark on me. It's a cinematic gem that will stay with me for a long, long time. If you haven't seen it, buckle up, because you're in for one hell of a ride.

JK Simmons would NEVER get away with physically, verbally and mentally assaulting students. Furthermore, the implication that a musician student would not react and stick up for themselves by handing Simmons his ass is a tired story. Everyone has a breaking point, everyone. A man like this would have been killed or seriously mamed by a student, a students loved ones, or the students friends etc. The message that being pushed to the brink is the only way to strive for "perfection" is a tired story and never well ending.\nThe story itself is good (for a movie) it's disturbing and even unrealistic, but it's good for entertainment.

The film Whiplash is a great movie about a young college student named Andrew, played by Miles teller, trying to improve his skills and make a career out of his drumming talents. When Andrew is chosen by Terence Flecter, played by J. K Simmons, to participate in his band, Andrew must overcome the intense and grueling training to improve his talents and make a career for himself. Whiplash had great emotions that were really intense. The acting was fantastic and had me shook. Both Miles Teller and J. K Simmons did a fantastic job in playing their characters and drawing out their emotions. Whiplash is a beautiful movie that not only captivates the beauty of music, but also the difficulty and demand needed to play music professionally.

What can i say. This is one of the best films I've seen in recent years, and that came as a suprise too.
I was never a huge fan of drama, I was more of a action packed kinda guy, but this blew me away.
First of all, the performances of both Miles Teller and and J. K Simmons were both absolutely incredible with miles Teller acting one of his, if not, his best performance to date.
The characters where captivating, with fletcher stealing the show as one of the most terrifying villians in years.
The story and cinematography where beautiful and captivating.
And of course, you can't forget the music. If you're a fan of Jazz, you will love it, if your a fan of drums, you will love it, and if your not... You will be after watching this film.
Also, the finale left me speechles. Even if you hate the whole film. You will love the finale.

I watched this when I was a teenager, which was also around the time I started to become more interested in an artistic craft.\nThis movie scared the s*** out of me. I felt so stessed the entire time. I felt so anxious the entire time. Why we make movies that make us feel this way I have no idea.\nBut I'm glad we do! Despite the rush, or because of it, I loved this movie! If you've ever trained for an artistic field, this movie can sadly feel really accurate, which I think we should see more of. Art is so much fun, but there is also this aspect; blood, sweat, tears, and probably a teacher somewhere driving it.

A film of incredible performances.. In the name of the art of cinema, two incredible actors and a director. Jazz culture, which starts from the motto "if you don't have talent, you'll end up playing in a rock band" in the name of musical art.. In both senses, we watched glorified performances for 100 minutes.\nAt Shaffer, the most prestigious music school in America, the most important conductor is Terrence Fletcher (J. K. While watching Simmons) I wonder if he's a great musical genius or obsessed and mentally ill, we're actually watching a movie full of suspense in which the magic can't be solved until the final scene. Again, the relationship of Andrew Neiman (Miles Teller), a freshman and jewel of talent at the same school, with his teacher Fletcher, I claim to be one of the most stormy cinematic events of recent times. Of course, the most important factor that makes the narrative epic is the outstanding directorial performance of Damien Chazelle. The relationship of the hometown person with the Jazz world is at a certain point, but this cinematic event has really gone beyond jazz. It's even almost the kind that will make you love jazz. After a while while watching the movie, I officially likened the rehearsals in the movie to war scenes, and the musicians to veterans. It was a really successful movie. Finally, of course, J. K. Simmons' acting was excellent, he took the film by himself. He also deserved the best supporting actor award he received until the end, even for his acting, you can watch the movie, I strongly recommend you watch it, you won't regret it, have a good time...

It is a 2014 music-themed drama film. One of the most exciting movies I've ever watched. Ambition and motivation are stimulating. The acting is admirably extraordinary. The pieces played are exquisite. I wonder how I missed this movie for so long. Similarly, there is a film of ambition and character revealing (see: Black Swan). But I think this is better than that movie. The character here is not as fragile as there. He shows his anger more.
The film is about a young man who has a passion for drums and is not appreciated by those around him, who is recruited into his orchestra by the most famous and arrogant conductor, and the psychological war between this young man and the conductor.
Since I don't know how to play an instrument, I can't be arrogant about it, but if I were younger, I would practice enough to give an instrument my own character. This movie could give me that motivation.
There is no sexuality or nudity in the movie.

We meet a music student. He has an intelligent face and is a talented drummer. His demeanour and expression are less advanced: awkward would be a better description here. The Master noticed. A brief conversation between them in the corridor and the Master knows what makes this particular student tick. He expects all his students to bare their souls. Time to throw chairs.\nA multi-level battle for mastery : Master versus student, student versus student, student versus himself, versus his expression, all expressed through music. This is not an adventure movie; it is not a high tech FX galactic battle. But there is a battle, there is tension: when it's time to perform; time to plunge in; to hit the right notes; to suffer the blisters and play till you bleed. Metaphors abound: losing your head; give them enough rope to hang themselves; being left hanging; off with their heads. Decapitation comes in many forms. This movie grabbed me from the start. I identified with the characters. They go through the paces of finding one's place, making sacrifices, perfecting oneself in whatever endeavour we choose in life. It is a backdrop, a reference point, a moment in time we all live, as we strive to excel and express within our chosen adventure. Dare to be great.' This movie certainly is.

Nine years after its release, I finally got around to seeing "Whiplash." Nearly a decade later, it remains a cinematic masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of musical understanding, captivating even those who don't consider themselves connoisseurs of music. This film, featuring the intense journey of Andrew Nieman (Miles Teller) and his tumultuous relationship with the formidable Fletcher (J. K. Simmons), is a whirlwind of emotion, skillfully blending excitement, tension, and rage.
The brilliance of "Whiplash" lies in its ability to immerse its audience completely, regardless of their musical background. As a viewer not deeply rooted in music, I found myself enthralled and engrossed, as if I were alongside Nieman, feeling every beat and enduring every challenge. The movie's pace and intensity had me watching in a stiff, tense state, mirroring the emotional rollercoaster experienced by Teller's character.
What makes "Whiplash" truly stand out is its complex character dynamics, particularly the captivating presence of Fletcher. J. K. Simmons delivers a performance that is both enraging and enthralling, drawing viewers into a love-hate relationship with his character. His portrayal adds depth to the film, making the audience yearn for more of his compelling presence.
Despite being a non-music aficionado, I found the film's portrayal of ambition, passion, and the pursuit of excellence universally relatable and deeply moving. The film's conclusion left me wishing for an extended cut, a testament to its captivating nature. I would have gladly indulged in a five-hour version of this intense, musical journey.
In conclusion, "Whiplash" is a remarkable film that resonates with viewers of all musical backgrounds. Its exceptional storytelling, coupled with powerful performances, creates an unforgettable experience. For its ability to engage, provoke, and inspire, I give it a resounding 5 out of 5 stars.

Finally saw this yesterday. I know it's considered a Christmas classic of sorts, but it lacks something. First of all, much of it has very little to do with Christmas. The idea is that the inn is open and gives shows on holidays, which means that Christmas is just one of many shown. Second.... something about Bing Crosby's awww shucks nice guy performance seems inauthentic to me, especially in light of what I know about him. The female leads annoy me. One dumps Fred Astaire's character the minute some guy waves dollars at her. Then she comes crawling back to him and expects him to forget that she dumped him. Hardly a sympathetic character. The other one can't seem to make up her mind what she cares about. Does she really love either man? For that matter, does either one love her? The best Crosby can muster for her is a perfunctory peck on the cheek, and both of them respond with an "oh well, whatever" when she bounces from one to the other. It seems like they're more interested in competing than in love. Fred's dancing is the redeeming feature, especially the firecracker dance. Him dancing while "drunk" was silly, though. The Lincoln song was awful for its racism, but it's in line with the attitudes of the period. The song White Christmas is the one truly memorable aspect.

What a wonderful actress!
I think the script for the scene where she first appears is very bland and boring, but it had a huge impact. I think it was the power of the actress. I was instantly captivated by the actress.
The whole story is the same kind of stuff that you would see in many films, but it's very well written. I have never seen such a well done film with this kind of story. I can only say that I was overwhelmed by it. Although the performances of the actors are responsible for much of the charm of the film, the script is undoubtedly excellent.
The actors, the actress, the script... I hope such a great movie will be talked about for a hundred years!

Yes, despite traditional naming conventions, the Crosby song "White Christmas" is not from the film that shares its name, it comes from this film here, "Holiday Inn". And No, the 1954 movie, "White Christmas" is not a spinoff or sequel to this movie, it just features a lot of the same cast.
"Holiday Inn" plays to the strengths of its starring cast. As they show off right away, Bing Crosby can sing, and Fred Astaire can dance. The story is a thinly veiled excuse to get these actors to do what they do best.
The characters do have a clear motivation and personality, but the conflict feels very forced. If the characters were to sit down and have a 5-minute conversation this would all be taken care of.
In a way, this film is similar to "Meet me in St. Louis", both have an all-time Christmas classic song, but both focus on various other holidays through the year. Although, strange that Holiday Inn completely avoids "Halloween". They have both George Washington and Abe Lincoln's birthday, but not Halloween?
Also, Bing Crosby is kind of a jerk in this film. Then when he is called out for it, he throws himself a 5-month long pity party, sulking about how he feels wronged.
But I digress, the film does exactly what it sets out for, it showcases Crosby's singing and Astaire's dancing. As an added bonus there is a little story to go along with it, the story even has a few good laughs to be found in it as well.

If you want a feel good old movie to combat all the gross stuff on tv now a days, this is the perfect film. The choreography is beautiful, the sets amazing and the costumes are stunning. It truly is a perfect holiday movie.\nI mean just hearing Bing sing "White Christmas" is enough. It is truly a wonderful family film that everyone should watch. It just brings you back to a simpler and happier time in this great country. If you are a fan of musicals and Christmas then add this to your list. It will definitely be in my rotation forever.\nIt's time to start just watching AMC and AMC only to find gems like this.

You are Cordially Invited to the Opening of "Holiday Inn"
Bing Crosby sings, Fred Astaire dances, and Virginia Dale does most of the coordination and a lot of singing and dancing without that much credit.
Later entered Marjorie Reynolds again overlooked. Be aware that Marjorie Reynolds' singing was dubbed by Martha Mears.
Irving Berlin's Greatest musical score
