There is an "Ending Medley"
The basic story is that Jim Hardy (Bing Crosby) wants to retire from the show biz. He buys a farm in Connecticut to get away from the rat race. Soon he finds it is just another type of work. Then he gets the big idea of making this a Holiday Inn open on holidays for entertainment.
Let's watch and see how it pans out. You may find yourself singing "I'm dreaming of a white Christmas" in the shower.

I thought this movie was just ok. But after witnessing the blackface scene, it became horrible. It surprises me that some people rated this 10/10 but perhaps they watched a version without the offensive characters singing in blackface with blonde Wigs (I saw the colorized version). Or perhaps they aren't offended by blackface. If I would've been able to see the edited version of the film, I might've liked it, especially since the songs and dancing were good at the start of the movie. This movie should be banned from all platforms. Those sort of images shouldn't be released in this day and time. It's almost 2024 for goodness sake!

I was not expecting this movie to completely shatter my sense of ethical morality. Normally, I consider myself to be someone that tries to understand that things of the past can't necessarily be held up to today's standards. The sociopolitical climate has changed and what was ok isn't what's ok now. I try... But good LORD this one broke me. Sure don't expect a movie called Holiday Inn to have an entire musical number about Lincoln with a couple dozen people in blackface and a few actual people of color praising it. The racism, the sexism, the... I just couldn't get passed it. For a film that I went into expecting wholesomeness and kindness to then be blindsided by that just... Nope nope nope.

Irving Berlin's Holiday Inn. Its got the best A-list talent for a musical you could ask for in 1942. The immortal Bing Crosby and Fred Astaire still in the prime of a long and successful career, with wonderful supporting help from Marjorie Reynolds and Virginia Dale who you couldn't do without. It also introduces the timeless christmas classic staple 'White Christmas' to the moviegoing audience for the first time (also the basis for the movie of the same name with Crosby a few years later). When it plays you'll absolutely revel in it, its calming and beautiful.
Holiday Inn as a title is appropriate because that's the backdrop that takes center stage here. Crosby retired from a song and dance routine tries his hand at farming but finds being lazy (a great number!) and not having to work a much better idea and remodels the farm into an inn literally open only on holidays; including Washington's birthday, Lincoln's birthday, Independence Day and of course Christmas! And to his closest friends surprise its a sold out hit with packed crowds and the excuse to throw out some showstopping musical numbers.
The music the main highlight of the movie here and the singing and dancing is incredible and at times literally (!) explosive. My favorite tunes of course the previously mentioned 'White Christmas' and 'Lazy' and also 'Be Careful, Its My Heart'.
The story is a bit corny and is the weakness of Holiday Inn. Its spins a romantic web between all 4 main characters that's dizzier than a 1940s film noir. Trying to keep up and make sense of it will just leave you in a bind. But it has alot of heart and a good dose of comedy, my highlight the maid Mamie and her two children, adorable little boy and girl, its always a howl when they appear.
As far as controversy, you may already know it has a musical number involving 'Blackface' which of course for the time period was general practice. Banned on broadcast TV its obviously offensive but it doesn't hurt the film in any way in my opinion. Just understand to seek out a censored version if that's not your taste. Other than its a good christmas musical worth watching for White Christmas of course and the talents of Crosby & Astaire and a talented supporting cast. For fans of the musicals of Irving Berlin as well!

This is one of our annual watches. It's not a prequel to White Christmas, nor is White Christmas a remake. They share ONE SONG, which happens to still be the top-selling song in history, White Christmas.
This is a fun, lively story of romance and stage talent. Fred Astaire delivers THE performance regarded in tap as the best tap choreography and performance ... ever. Fred's tap with the firecrackers ... or torpedoes as they called the specific firework in the day.
AND, it introduced the song White Christmas. It's the pinnacle role for the gorgeous and talented Marjorie Reynolds (even if they DID dub her singing).
It's a seasonal MUST.

We use to gather around the old black and white TV to watch this film and the 1938 version of "A Christmas Carol" at Christmas time. I recently purchased a digital copy of Holiday Inn and was surprised to have to read a disclaimer before the show began about the racism in it and how that the racists attitudes had been left intact to document our racist past. That made me laugh because they hypocritically accepted my money to purchase the film while decrying how awful it was. What does that say about the provider?
Anyway, I still love this show. It's beautifully shot and is perfect for setting a Christmas mood. Although the film flits from holiday to holiday, all the important moments happen at Christmas time. I like the symmetry of the movie. It opens and closes with Bing Crosby and Fred Astaire dueling over winning a damsel's heart with singing vs winning with dancing. They're tied by the end of the film 1-1. Bing wins Linda Mason (Majorie Reynolds) with singing and Fred gets Lila (Virginia Dale) with dancing.
There's more than a few iconic moments; Bing singing "White Christmas " is the most famous. That song would hold numerous sales records for decades. It also became the namesake of the Holiday Inn hotel chain, of course. Fred Astaire's dancing is just amazing to watch. Marjory Reynolds was quite the hoofer too. I'm surprised she never became an A-list movie star. She had it all, looks, voice, dancing.
Anyway I highly recommend this movie.

If you want to go to sleep, watch this movie. It's slow, it's "Jazzy," the story sucks, the characters are stale even thought Gosling & Stone are fantastic in other movies they just couldn't save this movie from being bad, it's just so boring. I don't understand the rating others gave it because for me it's one of the worst movies I've ever watched. I watch on average 300-500 movies a year and finally gave this one a chance and I really wish I didn't because it was a waste of 2 hours ill never get back. Everyone has their own opinions so give it a shot but for me it was absolute torture to get through.

It's the best love story I ever seen, it's full of Drama, Music, and one of the best love story's of all time, this is mi favorite movie. It contains much of the best actors in all industry including Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone who made a great job making this one of the best love story's with the dancing the music all the vibe together makes it so special.\nIf I could watch this for the first time I would give a hundred dollars for that it is so special for me, it makes me feel like love it's still possible this days and includes one of my favourites music genders the jazz makes this so special. THE BEST LOVE MOVIE OF ALL TIME.

It was amazing to see a Maestro at work. The La La Land original score is beautiful. Its lyrics takes you on a subtle journey through the movie whilst its catchy melodies inspire hope, grief and an abundance of energy.
There should be nothing more to say about La La Land at this point but I fear that isn't the case... La La Land is a musical drama rom com that follows two individuals pursuing their dreams and the inevitable trials and tribulations that ensues when trying to make it as an actress or follow ones passion for Jazz in Hollywood.
The soundtrack accompanies outstanding cinematography and set designs that creates a stunning Los Angeles awash with beautiful colours, harking back to the golden age of cinema and theatre.
La La Land is beautifully made and beautifully told. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are outstanding in their roles. There isn't a second that their performances aren't convincing and captivating and the simple plot will have you cycling through your emotions.
This was the first time I've rewatched La La Land since its original theatrical release and I enjoyed it much more having already explored the key themes and of course having listened to the original score on several occasions.

First time I played this movie was back when it was released. I'm glad I didn't watch it back then. I was watching it with company and they thought that musicals are boring, that's why we turned it off. Years later, I finally watched it, understanding more about the making of a movie and I can say, this movie is great! I can feel the struggle of the characters, finding their own paths, chasing their dreams. I'm in a similar situation today, as a young adult, still looking which path to follow. It is a really touching and beautiful film, I'd totally recommend it! The beginning of the film might not be as catching at first, but after watching half an hour, the film becomes more and more beautiful.

From the start, I was very skeptical about this movie. Why is it rated so high? And why did it win so many Oscars? I had to find out. The movie started with a scene where people were dancing in traffic. It was hard for me to keep watching because I don't like those types of movies. But I continued, and it was the best choice I made.\nAmazing shots, and the way it's filmed is so good. I love the story they have made about these two amazing characters. The movie made me feel happy and sad at the same time. The ending scene was very good and kind of emotional, but they could not have ended it better.

This movie just uhh why. I just finished watching this and going into Im a sucker for musicals and a sucker for love stories so this story was written for me to love off the bat thats what I thought. The music is good and the actors are great. The fact they can reuse that one song so many times and everytime it get me like uhhh means something bruh. The whole time Im thinking wow this story is great its so happy but huh where the conflict. I shouldnt be wishing for conflict but like this story kinda needs it. And then wham you know what hits the fan and its really sad. You just think man what happened and then things seem to get better and then they get so much worse and the ending. The ending explains the title and the title is something that resinates with me. As someone who his a dreamer who wants to do something in the world Ive always been told I live in la la land constantly out of focus in my own head. Then this movie used thay fact against me. And that ending man if I was someone who cried at movies itd be over for me. Just thats a very rare movie thing for me. And this movie got close.

La la land is a 2016 musical and romantic film. La la land is about Mia, Who pursues her Dreams of becoming on actress and does not succeed and Sebastian, Who is forced to play "Jingle Bells" by his boss despite falling in love with jazz musibet with Mia. Its telli about the love of these two people for each other. In my opinion, everyone of the music played in the film was fascinating. A movie that already start famous actors such as Rayn Gosling and Emma Watson in the lead roles cant be bad. The film is moving very smoothly and beautiful. A movie that everyone should watch. I really cried a lot at the end.

Even though the movie received a considerable Oscar award, I cannot say that I liked it very much. It is normal that people who like these kinds of movies liked it very much, but unfortunately I did not like it very much. Of the movie I will list a few of its bad points. There are too many musical scenes, even half of the movie was spent with music There were extremely unnecessary dance scenes Everything happened at once / I think dancing twice is necessary for two people to bond together They should have done more than that, from that point of view it was really ridiculous I watched almost the entire movie with 2x acceleration. If you like romantic movies, I recommend it, but if you don't, I recommend it. I would say don't even come close (I wish it didn't end badly, the last scene really made me sad)

Beautiful movie. The intensity of emotions given to us by the main protagonists is incredible. I enjoyed watching the movie from the first sequence to the last chord. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone played their roles phenomenally. There are not two people on this planet who could play their roles better than the two of them. The battle of emotions that is reflected in the chance meeting of the loving couple at the very end of the film is anthological. Most of us who watched the film recognized each other because in our lives we sincerely loved someone, but our love stories did not end happily. I really enjoyed. Bravo!

Oh dear..what a movie, what an experience! I literally laughed..enjoyed.. cried. Can't find words to describe it. The musical experience was soothing, entertaining, relaxing..the acting performances and at last the direction made it a true masterpiece. The Cinematography was something else. Watched it on Netflix..but now I want to experience it on a giant screen. It's a gift to cinema lovers like me.. literally I can't move on from this movie after watching this. God why didn't I watch it earlier. I know my review isn't perfect..but here I am writing what I truly feel after watching this movie..and genuinely it reminds me about someone who lives deep down in my heart. If you are a movie lover you can't ignore this movie. And definitely it's gonna be listed to my all time favourite movies list. Hole i successfully convenience you to watch it..so now go and watch it and thank me later.

It was like they took a movie, an audio book, and a documentary, chopped them up, mixed them up, and pasted them back together in mostly chronological order. But each thing was by different people and didn't mesh quite right with the others.
It felt like a messy dream, and maybe that's exactly what they were going for to make you feel like Elvis may have felt living it. But it's not enjoyable as a movie or as a story due to the format. They were trying to make it different and to modernize it, and to tell the story about Elvis while validating the black culture his music stemmed from. That part they did the best of anything. The bits of black culture they show is vibrant and energetic and inspirational. Definitely beats the white culture that's freaking out about some guy's pelvic jiggling. If that's how it really happened those white folk were pretty thirsty for a little sexiness.
Normally I wouldn't say quite so much about a movie you maybe haven't seen yet, but I think going into it knowing all this would've made it better for me.
I got 3/4 through it and I'm not going back to it, but I'm glad I watched as much as I did. Parts of it are interesting and though I don't like the movie overall, I also recommend trying it. It's the kind of movie that's really going to provoke love or hate.
Elvis died before I was born, I only knew the basic stuff about him and I didn't go into it with much personal opinion/feeling about him. I like him a little more from seeing the movie. I read other reviews here that say the Elvis dancing wasn't quite right, so it piqued my interest to see him dancing. Much of Elvis dancing in the movie looked more like he was having a jiggling fit of some sort, with a violent pelvic thrust thrown in sometimes, than dancing.
I liked how they meshed old and new music in the movie.

I was sooo excited when I saw the movie "Elvis" was playing on Netflix. I got my blanket, sat in my chair was ready for a good movie. I mean, Tom Hanks as a main character in amovie about Elvis , how could I be disappointed?
From the moment it started I can't believe how disappointed I was. From the HORRIBLE acting, to the pieced together sequence. The total creeped out feeling I got from Tom Hanks character. For the actor who played Elvis, I didn't get any Elvis vibe from him at all!
It's one of those movies where you have to watch to see if it gets any better..and it did not.
Way overhyped. Disappointed.

To start with, I am NOT rating this movie as Meandering because of Austin Butler's performance. Austin Butler was excellent as Elvis. Of course no one is going to really replicate Elvis Presley, Austin Butler did pretty dang close even if he was a little bit goofy looking. Austin Butler's acting was great, Olivia Dejonge was a worthy Priscilla but I'm not really sure they had much chemistry on the screen though. I didn't really get emotional when Priscilla left Elvis in the movie. Perhaps if they had been given more time together, or if the movie was entirely about Priscilla and Elvis, I would feel differently about these two. The main focus was Elvis Presley and his devil of a manager, played by Tom Hanks.
What makes this movie a big disappointment Firstly was the rapid, dizzying story pace and the jerk between present day when Tom Parker lays dying, to the past. Left me with a bit of a headache, watching. Someone thought that the producer might have ADHD, perhaps that is what happened. Because this type of pace isn't normal and I hated it instantly. Also, I had no idea who Tom Parker was so to open the movie with Tom Parker was a little jarring. Would have been more practical if they opened it up with Elvis's death. Or funeral.
Secondly, it's not often I agree with other critics but in the case of Tom Hanks' , the ridicule is completely justified. Tom Hanks' sounds like a fool with his abhorrent, fake German accent? That grated on my ears! And why did he even have to narrate the movie, when the audience is led to hate him throughout the movie? Why couldn't they have just told the story? I didn't think a narrator was needed. Especially not him! Seriously, in a movie about the King of Rock, Tom Parker's ugly voice was not needed.
Thirdly, Elvis Presley deserved a slower, more respectful pacing in his own movie. About his own life. It felt like they were constantly trying to hurry you on to the next phase of his life and didn't even give you a chance to really empathize, and absorb the life and world of Elvis. You see way too much of Tom Parker, to the point where you want to tear him out of the film, because the movie shouldn't even be about him. It should be about Elvis.
Then there's the ending itself. Just cutting off after Elvis awesomely fires Tom Parker and then to explain through scrolling the rest of history. After all of the drama of revealing what a con artist and what a Mephistopheles-like demon Tom Parker was; worming his way into Elvis Presley's life and leading him to absolute misery...
Why didn't the writers give us satisfaction of a scene of Tom Parker dying alone in the hospital? You tell such a heart-wrenching tale of all that happened Presley, it was a mistake that all we are left with at the end was just a couple history cards to read.
I have seen better biopics from Hollywood. This is not one of them. I expected a lot more of the story of Elvis Presley. Johnny Cash and June Carter got a pretty good Hollywood movie, Elvis Presley deserved better than this.
Guess I would say to the fans of the King, watch it for free and don't be surprised if you end up disappointed. And for heaven's sakes don't buy it!

Anyone who is familiar with Baz Luhrmann will not be surprised to find that this movie is visually arresting. The short cuts, the surrealistic feel, lots going on at once, fast pans from one thing to the next, the split screens, the non-linearity , etc, --- I believe these are all Luhrmann hallmarks. I appreciate the effort it took to make such a glitzy, lush display. The film has a high production value. Obviously Luhrmann had a huge budget for this project and spared no expense. Butler did an outstanding job in the title role, as did the young man who played the pre-teen Elvis. It is hard for me to be objective about Tom Hanks' performance, because I had read too many scathing reviews of it. If anyone else had played the role of Colonel Parker, I don't think his reviews would have been nearly as bad. It's just hard to watch an iconic talent play a caricature. Plus the character was creepy in all those grotesque circus and carny scenes, and his prosthetics were distracting. The soundtrack had a lot of overlays of one bit of music over another; a stylistic choice which did not satisfy me. You will guess my age when I tell you that I owned a pink plastic Elvis Presley wallet when I was a little girl. So maybe I was not this film's intended audience. It has many good points, though; and I recommend seeing it if for no other reason than to see what all the fuss was about.

First of all Tom Hanks gives an awful performance and made it a joke of a film. Austin did a pretty decent job representing Elvis. However, the film gave off a cartoon-ish feel and not to mention it was so chopped up and made it hard to follow at times and intrest was lost at times because of it. This is not the tribute I wished it had been to such an incredible artist. There needs to be a true movie made about Elvis that doesn't have Persilla's biased views on him and his life. Yes, she played a huge role in his life but her view isn't always the greatest! Maybe a movie with his band mates view on him might be more entertaining? Also, a movie based on Elvis and his music doesn't need rap music added in to it. Focus on his music and the music that influenced HIM!

The cinematic rendition of Elvis, featuring Austin Butler in the titular role, undeniably stands out as an exemplary piece of artistry. Butler's portrayal of Elvis is nothing short of masterful, capturing the essence of the icon with nuanced precision. The film's brilliance extends beyond individual performances; its impeccable pacing and a meticulously crafted script elevate the narrative to a level of sophistication rarely seen. The synthesis of these elements creates an immersive experience for the audience, effectively communicating the intricacies of Elvis's life and legacy. In summary, the film is a triumph, seamlessly blending exceptional acting, thoughtful pacing, and a compelling script to offer a captivating and poignant exploration of one of music's greatest legends.

Elvis's life was packed full of drama and conflict but all of it is thinly covered in the film.
For a film/movie to work there needs to be a strong protagonist and a strong antagonist so that the conflict is clear.
In this film the conflict is warterd down and Elvis isn't a likeable character. All we learn about him is that he loves his mama and will do anything for her.
That's not enough for him to be likeable and the writers and the director should have seen that.
The production values are good, as is the acting, but I found myself asking how can I be bored with a film about ELVIS? The greatest star to have ever lived.
Elvis fan's will like this film but if you're not a fan, it is watchable.

From the beginning it is all over the place, just back and forth it make your head spin, can't concentrate as the movie is all over the shop.
I also can't stand the mix of both old and new music, 5/10 minutes into the movie and some weird female rapper starts in the background and it makes you think "What an earth"? Terrible music choice, should have made it feel like the 50's and 60's as it was based during his lifetime.
Bad song choices, they made Elvis look like a girly when in real life he only wore light makeup where no one would notice, Elvis was a true good masculine man and they made him look weird.
Bad music choices, out of touch with reality, not true to story or timelines based on the music. You'll get lost within the first 6 minutes of this movie, it's atrocious.
Can people stop making movies about dead stars now? I've seen so many Elvis movies and it's boring now. I guess movie makers/writers have no creativity anymore.
Elvis would not like this movie, terrible mix of modern and new, and you made him look weird.

I began this movie thinking I would watch an Elvis biopic with fifties aesthetics and some rockabilly tunes, maybe other era-appropriate genres as well.
For starters, the focus was on colonel Parker as a narrator. Ok, a narrative choice, I have absolutely no problem with it. Tom Hanks make a good job out of it.
Let's start with the good parts:
The time characterization was on point in terms of wardrobes and environments. The settings look beautiful and are believable to feature in 1950's Southern USA.
Tom Hanks is a very good Colonel Parker and could have carried the movie as its de facto protagonist if it had a good narrative.
The Elvis casting was on point. Elvis looks like Elvis and also behaves like Elvis. I don't know if the songs were re-recorded, but if they were, the job was very well done.
Elvis's mother is very well cast as well. The character is believable as an overprotective provincian mother who is the biggest fan of her superstar son.
And that's it. Just so I don't get accused of having ill-will towards the movie.
Now, let's review the bad.
Elvis's father is given no chance of ever becoming more than a prop. The real Vernon Presley was a small time criminal who would deserve at least one scene exposing his character, which was denied, although the fact the father was absent was mentioned during the film. Which brings the first very big problem with this movie: the constant telling, not showing. Many important moments are either implied or just mentioned instead of being acted out and shown on screen. The Colonel approaching Elvis is implied. The negotiation between the Colonel and the Sun Records executives is mentioned. The past dishonesty of the Colonel is implied. The moment when the Colonel wants to seduce Elvis on how much of a big star he could be is extremely lazy and takes 3 minutes at most, missing an opportunity to describe on screen how manipulative and persuasive the Colonel could be. And many, many, many such instances, many missed opportunities to fill a 150 minute movie with meaningful, fluent narrative. It is a movie made for and by people who fried their attention spans on social media.
The movie also (of course, we are in the 2020s) does not miss the opportunity on lecturing the audience on still existing social issues. Don't get me wrong, the Elvis Presley story could have been a good vehicle for this kind of messaging, as his zenith was during Jim Crow and his white skin certainly helped him market black music in that era. But, of course, nothing is ever developed, no black character is deeper than a plate, no prominent black musicians of the time are properly shown (BB King is acknowledged and waves at Elvis from a window, so the producers can show you that they know the reference). Blacks are no individuals but a collective prop, like most other characters. This gets a lot of focus and screen time, without ever getting any development. Mechanical, shallow narratives make for a good pair with empty virtue signaling, and this film is no different.
The final nail in the coffin, the red marker that shows the people responsible don't suffer only of inability to make a proper movie but of a complete lack of common sense and good taste was the completely inappropriate shoveling of amorphic, corporate and soulless current songs into this movie. Fast-food soundtracks are meant to get the customers to leave as soon as possible, they have absolutely no reason to feature in an Elvis movie. An Elvis movie, an icon of popular music of all characters. In the first instance of this I felt taunted by the filmmakers and legitimately angry. In the second I noticed that this would be a common theme, and it certainly matches the narrative blandness and the unjustified high opinion the filmmakers have of their own morals and intellect, but it certainly does not match an Elvis movie. AN ELVIS MOVIE, WHAT DO TIKTOK SONGS HAVE TO DO WITH IT? HOW IS THIS APPROPRIATE? WHAT IS THE AESTHETICAL OR ATMOSPHERICAL GAIN? The third instance I finally don't know if it existed as I could not waste my precious Sunday anymore on this unforgiving, aggressively nonsensical movie.
This movie is nothing but a big missed opportunity. Go watch the actual Elvis films if you want entertainment, or 'The Green Book' if you want a competent reconstruction of Jim Crow USA.

This just goes to show you can make any autobiography about a pure legend and you'll get high ratings because how someone dare criticize anything to do with Elvis. I'll admit it's hard. First of all Austin Butler was great. I was born is 92 he's born in 91 I'm very excited for future cinema from this talent. He was not the problem with this film not by any means. Camera work, quality of picture. Even the sound wasn't great which come on? That's the most important part. I always thought Tom Hanks was over rated but this was the first time I thought he was a bad actor. Story telling was weak. I mean to be fair to everyone I'm not sure Elvis deserved a movie in the sense of a story goes. One of the most talented and influential people to ever step foot on planet earth but there was nothing we needed to see that we didn't know. He was about talent. Sure he didn't have it easy. Success has its flaws but in the grand scheme of things he had a great career.

I had a great time watching this movie and I vwas extremely surprised to see how many negative reviews it had. The only real problem I had with this movie is that some of the scenes felt a bit dragged out and its 130 minute runtime could definitely have been shortened down a bit.\nBut calling this movie uninspiring is crazy. This was both an inspiring movie about the struggles of both black and white men in 1960a America and also a heartwarming story of two dudes bonding over music. Both mahershala Ali and Virgo mortenson gave A grade preformances. I see people referring to it as a not all white people are bad story but like you can't be expecting them to change true events. 9.2/10.

Liked it very much. At first I thought this to be the usual super-pedagogical anti-racist "movie with a message", which I hate because the message is mostly too obvious and in your face, trying to lecture the viewer. However, this one is different. Both protagonists have their fairly distributed faults, strengths and weaknesses. None of them is solely victim or perpetrator. The differences between them are multi-faceted, not only between black/white, but also between rich/poor, homo/hetero, intellectual/down to earth, arrogant/likable, lonely guy/family man. The narrow-mindedness of institutionalized racism is clearly demonstrated.\nBoth actors do a fine job, the male bonding between this two contradictory characters is quite believable. It works fine as an entertaining road movie, albeit the ending reminded me a bit too strongly of Planes, Trains and Automobiles.

"Green Book" is a remarkable film that embarks on a journey not only through the deep south of America but also through the complexities of human relationships and societal prejudices. Directed masterfully by Peter Farrelly, the movie is a blend of humor, drama, and a poignant exploration of racial dynamics in the 1960s.
Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali deliver exceptional performances, bringing depth and authenticity to their characters. Mortensen, as Tony Lip, embodies the rough-around-the-edges bouncer with a heart of gold, while Ali, portraying Dr. Don Shirley, brings an air of elegance and dignity, masking his character's inner struggles with societal constraints and loneliness.
The chemistry between the two leads is the heartbeat of the film, evolving from mere employer-employee relationship to a genuine, deep-seated friendship. It's this evolving bond that forms the core of the narrative, making every shared laugh, disagreement, and moment of mutual support something special.
The screenplay is another highlight, offering a balanced mix of humor and seriousness without delving into cliches. The film tactfully addresses issues of racism and segregation, without losing its warmth and charm. Its depiction of the era is both eye-opening and thought-provoking, offering a window into a not-so-distant past.
What makes "Green Book" stand out is its ability to tackle serious issues while maintaining an uplifting tone. It's a story about breaking down barriers, understanding and valuing differences, and the power of human connection. This film doesn't just entertain; it enlightens and inspires.
The direction, acting, script, and the incredible soundtrack all contribute to making "Green Book" a memorable film. Its message of love, respect, and friendship resonates long after the credits roll. This is a movie that deserves all the accolades it has received and is definitely worth a watch.
In summary, "Green Book" is a beautifully crafted film that offers more than just entertainment. It's a powerful reminder of the importance of empathy and understanding in a world divided by differences. A solid 9 out of 10.

I consider myself to quite the movie connoisseur.
I watched the trailer for the movie and was intrigued enough to give it a shot.
Talk about an over delivery. Understanding the assignment.
There wasn't a dull moment the entire movie. It was one of those films that makes you keep checking the time because you don't want it to end.
The film covers every single part of the emotional spectrum: fear, pride, confusion, anger, humor, and most of all happiness.
This film was directed flawlessly from start to finish.
You're immediately drawn in by the unorthodox character dynamics.
The character development is intentional, meticulous, and complete.
The race dynamics were vivid and jarring but not generic.
I found myself smiling ear to ear when this movie ended, I'd give it a standing ovation if I wasn't watching it from my bedroom. Well done.

Brilliant actors Ali and Mortensen team up to deliver great understated performances in a friendship-heavy road movie that tackles America's 1960's segregration troubles. And yes, you should definitely put it on.
Right off the bat, this is not a tearjerker nor a moralistic film at all. In fact it's a film that just shows you what it is, as a sophisticated black piano player with a lot of courage drives from show to show in the deep white South, backed by his hard-as-nails Italian driver.
It's a very welcome way of portraying heartbreaking practices in society, keeping its focus on the good we have inside, especially between these two unlikely friends. It pulls a trick to achieve this, deliberately skipping the hard moments and only showing the aftermaths, stripping it from too much drama.
The camera just never loses sight of either of our friends, and that makes it an exceptionally good film. Also, it has a mad sense of superb humour, and some great music to top it all of.
It's heartwarming, understated and funny when you least expect it. What more would you want to put this on.

I'm not going to ruin this movie by writing all of the details down here. However, I will suggest giving it a watch. The main actors pulled their parts off so well. Thanks to all of the actors, to the writers, production team, camera team and everyone else, including all of the tea/coffee girls/boys. I read the book not that long ago. I never knew there was a movie too. So if you're thinking of reading or watching either then I'd recommend reading the book first followed by the movie.\nAs for Vigo he has a whole list of movies to look for on here. He can play literally any character with any accent in any situation. Thanks for reading my ramblings.

Green Book is a well told story about an American-Italian man that works as a driver for a popular black pianist, that is a square, careful man that is really into his musical things. Alongside the driver, who is more of a who-cares man, and the contrast between these two is showed very good, very clearly, and it was fun watching it. Green Book is taking up important genres. Family, racism and acceptation. The movie is settled back in the old time America were the blacks rights were better, but still on a low quality. Including the important things they talk about, it was very funny, too. The jokes were fun and intelligent, and they included some very nice ironic sentences. The story is very holding, it is almost like reading a book, with different chapters. Every chapter, was one city where the duo was on a concert. And they were driving and driving, and sooner you got longer into things, you are getting more about The Pianist and his backstory, and why he is so uptight and serious all the time. About the technicals. The pictures and scenography did really the job with some retro atmosphere, as well as some good songs, including some very old symphonies too, that is definitely a fun thing to listen for musicians. Viggo Mortensen and Mahershala Ali were both great and put power into their role, and they did their job great! Concluding everything, Green Book is more than just a green book, it is a story of two different persons that meet each other, with a completely misunderstanding, but later on, they show how you can be a good person and that you must open yourself to show who you really are. It was a good drive.

First to say about this movie : EVERY scene are so well composed that you want to stop the movie and take a picture. I rarely enjoy that much the decoration of a movie. Watching this movie is like leafing through a book of vintage photography about the US culture during the 60s.\nOnly a massive amount of work and talent behind every scene decor can explain these marvellous frame. If you are into film photography, I recommande you this movie at 100%\nDespite this aspect, this movie offer a feeling good story while dealing with important social history fact. The friendship growing between these two mens originating from opposite social categories feels true and captivate us.

This is so captivating. There were so many interesting parts that were so relaxing and funny, but also presented how racism on dark people and Italians in United States. Would never know about these if one is not familiar with American history. The selection of the music is quite nice if you like jazz. Especially remember this ' the world is full of lonely people afraid to make the first move '. So true but not so offensive. Didn't know this was based on a true beautiful story until I saw the photos in the end. Friendship stories are always more beautiful and more interesting than romantic or family ones.

An amazing acting duet between Vigo Mortenstern and Mahershalla Ali. In my subjective opinion, in this role, the ex-Aragorn himself has achieved his peak as an actor. His Tony feels so real and alive. Beautiful in the smallest details. The character is portrayed impeccably. The film is definitely Oscar worthy.\nThis film is a story in itself. It's not only about friendship between two people who are completely different. A subtle psychological and social story accompanied by excellent music and visuals. It's a complex story about how similar we all are in our struggles, even if all come from completely different walks of life. A very touching and well-made film that will surely be to most people's liking.

Full disclosure: I've never been into the Troll toys. I learned of them probably when I was eleven, and only through reading the trivia about this movie learned that they got created in the '50s.
OK, with that out of the way, I guess that "Trolls" was an okay movie. The plot reminded me of the Beatles' movie "Yellow Submarine", wherein a happy, colorful place gets overrun by a group of beings who turn it into a miserable, colorless place (obviously in this movie there are no Beatles to come to the rescue).
The songs - including an Academy Award-nominated one - didn't really catch my attention. With most movies I tend to focus on the plot, even if it's a children's movie. I will say that the movie has some splendiferous animation.
Last but not least, I of course have to mention the cast. The combination of Justin Timberlake, Anna Kendrick, Christine Baranski, James Corden, Christopher Mintz-Plasse, Kunal Nayyar, Russell Brand, Gwen Stefani and QuvenzhanÃ© Wallis makes this movie a link between *NSYNC, "Into the Woods", "How to Train Your Dragon", "The Big Bang Theory", political comedy, No Doubt and "Beasts of the Southern Wild".
Anyway, it's an enjoyable movie. Nothing special, but harmless.

Anyone recall the toys you used to get where you could push play-dough up through the body and it would come out through holes in the head like coloured hair? Well that's what these "Trolls" reminded me of - a wet dream for marketeers, toy makers. And burger chains. The actual plot centres around the peaceable trolls who must flee their home when the menacing "Bergen" arrive bent on eating them all for a "trollstice" treat. "King Peppy" and his annoyingly optimistic daughter "Poppy" lead their people to a safe hideaway but a surprise visit from their nemeses means "Poppy" and her pal "Branch" have to set off to rescue them from the merciless cleaver of the "Chef" and the new young "King Gristle". What now ensues is a series of escapades as they quite literally have to escape from the pot and the fire, stop their entire population ending up garnished and maybe, just maybe, convince their foes that happiness does not, in fact, come from eating a troll - well not unless it's a chocolate one. This will probably play well to very young children - there are lots of vibrant colours, a few songs to liven things up and just a hint of "Janet and John" moralising about what truly matters in life. It's a film you'll watch once, but I doubt it needs revisiting.

My little ones love all the trolls movies so much. We showed up late to the party and just started watching them a few weeks ago. The third trolls movie is in theaters right now. They love all of them but the first one is so good. I wish they would have put the troll wig in the second and third one. Like they all come together to make a troll wig for the Berkin troll Bridget. We love them all. The music has been the best part: it's so much fun to jam to the album in the car with them. I wish there was a poppy doll with a cowbell: I would have already bought it by now. Good job, everyone involved in this film. It's made my kids so happy.

Trolls
It was excellent, who could not love a community of trolls where they have music, dance and hugs on the hour.
The story had a central message that happiness is inside all of us and we just need to find it. Whilst simplistic on the story front, it was inspired in its music, animation and dance numbers
But what really was the cherry on top was the strength of the characterisations brought to life with very nuanced animation, and the voice acting casting was inspired. My favourite was Branch followed by the Giraffe looking like troll.
I'm giving this a firm 6 outta 10, well worth watching and good honest entertainment.

This film is crazy cute and so cartoon-like over the top, it's really refreshing seeing this brought to the 3d space.
The animators and artistic directors did a fantastic job and each little expression and hand gesture just added to it perfectly.
The story is ok, but everything else was perfect.
Well done DreamWorks! This is far better than, this came to life or that came to life, same style, same story.
Though Pixar tells a better story, but 30 years of the exact same animation style really shows they are not trying to push the boat. (maybe beside monster inc.)
This is a totally different and unique universe.

Animated musical adventure that is bursting with color, fun, and infectious positivity.
The film brings to life the vibrant and whimsical world of the Trolls, with each character exuding charm and personality. The adorable and lovable Trolls, led by Princess Poppy, voiced by Anna Kendrick, are impossible not to adore.
Anna Kendrick's lively and spirited performance as Poppy perfectly captures the character's boundless optimism and determination. Her singing talent adds an extra layer of delight to the film's catchy musical numbers.
Justin Timberlake lends his voice to the grumpy and skeptical Branch, whose journey alongside Poppy adds depth and balance to the narrative. Timberlake's performance brings a heartfelt sincerity to Branch's character, making him relatable and endearing.
Trolls is a visual feast, with its bright and imaginative animation that transports viewers to a world of glitter and rainbows. The film's creative use of color and visual effects creates a joyful and immersive experience for both children and adults.
Beyond the colorful exterior, Trolls also delivers a message of embracing individuality and celebrating the beauty of being true to oneself. It teaches the importance of finding happiness within and appreciating the uniqueness of others.
The film's soundtrack is a standout feature, with catchy and upbeat songs that stay with you long after the credits roll. It's a musical treat that will have you tapping your feet and singing along.
While some may dismiss Trolls as just a children's movie, its heartwarming story and positive messages resonate with audiences of all ages.
In conclusion, Trolls is a delightful and heartwarming animated adventure that spreads joy and positivity. With Anna Kendrick and Justin Timberlake's charismatic performances, a vibrant and imaginative world, and an infectious soundtrack, it's a film that will leave you with a smile on your face.
If you're in the mood for a fun-filled and uplifting movie that celebrates friendship, individuality, and the power of music, Trolls is the perfect choice. So, join Princess Poppy and her friends on their whimsical journey and get ready to dance, sing, and be reminded of the happiness that lies within us all.

Coming in, I was skeptic on whether Trolls was going to be an awful Lego Movie wannabe, that I was prepped with banters and ridicules. Lo and behold, I swallowed all negative assumptions as Trolls was quite an entertaining ride. It simply nails what it sets out to do, as it had us grinning ear to ear from its well placed jokes, head bopping from its insanely catchy soundtrack, & mesmerized with its oh so trippy visuals. Apart from these, the character quirks introduced that perfectly complimented the actual toy's appearance, were amusing & sensical. Story-wise, it's lack of complexity was a breath of fresh air, yet its messages on true happiness had substance.\nOverall, Trolls is a feel good movie through & through. Sure it's a film made for young ones, yet I find my 35 year old behind rallying behind it! If only this film was released during my hay days, there could have been better appreciation for that hideous naked toy, with groovy hair.

From "True Colors" to "I'm Coming Out" to the Gorillaz' "Clint Eastwood," Mike Mitchell and Walt Dohrn's Trolls goes all in on being a jukebox musical. If otherworldly creatures belting out pop hits makes you nervous (perhaps you're still flashing back on Strange Magic, shudder to think), you might find yourself nonplussed in the theater. These songs, it turns out, are the best parts of the movie. It's everything else that's wrong.
The Trolls, based on the dolls with the hair, live carefree in a blissful, wooded community, having years hence escaped lives of captivity under the rule of the giant, grumpy Bergens. When they are again discovered and a (literal) handful of them are taken, Princess Poppy (Anna Kendrick) teams up with Bergen expert and sullen outcast Branch (Justin Timberlake) to mount a rescue mission.
Trolls' attempts at humor are like the last ten years' worth of sitcoms copied down to the umpteenth generation until the jokes have become thin and hollow echoes. Jokes, in fact, is too strong a word. In place of humor or comedic characters, our protagonists affect a sort of weary smarm, reacting to one another with long pauses and stares or with a curt, dismissive, "That's weird." Perhaps that's preferable, though, to the Trolls' other mode, which panders to the young audience of a few years ago, when the movie was likely written, by having characters shout things like "OMG!" or, most embarrassingly, "YOLO!"
However, when this patience-trying dialogue goes away for a few minutes, a seemingly entirely different film emerges. The musical numbers (as well as the occasional action or chase sequence) are whimsical, unpredictable delights. Poppy's journey to Bergentown, for instance, is told over the course of a single song but in a montage that gives us a tour of the varied and interesting locales of this fantasy realm. Most of these dreamy song segments remove us from the physical world of the film, inventively employing a felt and paper visual motif that recalls Poppy's scrapbooking hobby.
Poppy's arts and crafts are just a taste of the many pleasures the Trolls find in their world. Bergens, on the other hand, can only feel happy by eating Trolls, or so we're told. Eventually, we arrive at the thematic point of the film, wherein we learn that happiness is not something you put inside yourself. It's already there and you just need to bring it out. It's a surprisingly and unconvincingly anti-consumerist message for a movie based on toys.
Trolls might be worth a dollar or two at the Redbox where you can just skip ahead to the music and action vignettes that bring it to life. When it comes to characters, story and personality, though, the movie's as thin as a wisp of brightly colored hair.

Trolls is easily one of Dreamworks' weaker animated films, as this is one of their films from the mid-2010s. I'll give the movie for its creativity with how colorful the movie looks thanks to the animation. But the film would have a predictable story, weak jokes, bland characters, obnoxious jukebox musical numbers, and a highly childish message of happiness. I would mostly recommend this for the younger crowd since they will enjoy the colors and the happiness it would present. I mean, I'll say that this movie is rather harmless and not the kind of one to be taken seriously. I know that people do like the movie, which is fine. Me, there's plenty of Dreamworks films that are better than this. I won't say it's something horrible, but I honestly think Dreamworks can do better than this.

This movie is not good at all. First, I'll tell you why this didn't make me vomit. First off, the visuals are good, and mostly pleasant to look at, and if you show it to children, they will like it. But, if you are an adult watching this with your kids, don't expect to find yourself enjoying the movie. Now, here's where I'll go crazy with cons.
First, the songs' lyrics are cringy, bland, and cliche, basically like if a five year old girl was singing about how life is fun.
Second, the adult humor in this is very little, and slightly uncomfortable.
Third, the plot is cringy, and slightly bland.
Lastly, the jokes either drag on for too long, or just awful.
Trolls: 2/10 (being nice)

Cate Blanchett puts on a very strong performance here. Sadly the story here does not match the same level of her performance. My expectations were especially high for this movie because of all the Oscar Nominations it received back in 2022. The story moves at a snails pace with taking forever where it wants to get. I even found myself nodding off from time to time watching this film. Don't put this movie on if you are already feeling sleepy trust me. The highlight here is certainly Cate Blanchett's performance but nothing else really. Ta\nTÃ¡r gets a very middle of the road 6 stars out of 10 from me.

Todd Fields 'Tar' is an impressive, subtly chaotic drama that keeps you hooked on what is typically made to be a boring scene.
This movie is more or less the downfall of Lydia TÃ¡r's, the composer's, career. She is about to make another breakthrough with her career as she's about to record her symphony but everything seems to work not in her favour. As she battles with her relationship with her wife, the accusations made from the suicide of Krista, the legal battles as the accusations of sexual exploitation, and overall the downfall of her career as she battles her trouble causing emotions too.
This movie shows us that it is never good to bite more than you can chew. The hierarchy of power in any setting can have serious impact on anything, in other words, sexual exploitation. It's the impact todays society has on the world today with 'cancel culture'.
The story is beautifully constructed and it's ability to switch from one scene straight to the next is something remarkable I feel most filmmakers don't have the guts to do. The construct of TÃ¡r's character and it's development is amazing and gradually perfect. The development of the story is great and the turning points are plotted in just when you think all is well.
The cinematography is so subtly done it works wonders to the eye because whilst it doesn't seem to be very cinematic you can tell it is still all in the shot despite there not being dynamic colours to express emotion or very specific camera movements. The long shots taking place between conversations is remarkable and represent the stableness in TÃ¡r's career and how later the scenes are a bit more complexly edited and chopped up representing the unstableness of TÃ¡r's career is amazing.
Cate Blanchett played this role terrifically, the screenplay must've been written for her as she literally is TÃ¡r and encapsulates everything TÃ¡r is meant to be and feel to an awe.
Todd Field really went all out with this film. His choice of subtle camera movement is great but what's most important is how he works around with the actors, the sets, and all else.
The ending of this film has left me in absolute brilliance as it perfectly encapsulates todays society especially in the last shot/reveal.
TÃ¡r has done the impossible and has added 'Gen-Z' into an absolutely terrific film without ruining it but instead making the best use out of it and even using it for the plot. Even using it to truly represent the downfall and what TÃ¡r's career has come to.
This film deserves further analysis and re-watches as of how brilliant the film really is.

This film has been on my watchlist for ages, and I postponed watching, being worried that it would take a big emotional tall for me, who is a professional classical musician, trying auditions and having to deal with conductors and orchestras on a regular basis.\nAfter watching it, with difficulty, I can say that being disappointed is an understatement. I'm just so curious who is this film meant for? It's very pretentious and goes very into very detailed conversations about classical music, but in a shallow and unrealistic way. I also would've expected that the music would be a big part of the storyline, however from the beginning you're greeted with a soundtrack that I can only describe as nails on a chalkboard.

In "TÃ¡r," the cinematic world is treated to a masterpiece that resonates with a unique rhythm. It's a film that demands your full attention, unfolding at a pace that is not slow but meticulously measured. For those willing to immerse themselves in its narrative, the movie offers a rich and enjoyable experience.\nThe storyline is a compelling exploration of the complex interplay between immense talent and the pursuit of success. Lydia TÃ¡r, portrayed with exceptional nuance, navigates the high stakes world of classical music. The film masterfully illustrates how subtle manipulations can spiral into profound consequences, presenting a narrative both contemporary and timeless.\nThis isn't just a film; it's an experience that lingers with you, challenging perceptions of power dynamics in creative fields. With a rating of 8 out of 10, "TÃ¡r" is undeniably a must-see. It's a testament to the power of cinema to both entertain and provoke thought, leaving an indelible mark on its audience.

I watched TÃ¡r over the course of a few hours, frequently pausing the film and watching something else, then coming back to it. Or taking a nap. I don't think calling this movie boring is that controversial; the first 40 minutes of the film are deliberately difficult, an excruciatingly long interview opens the film and it's follow quickly by a dinner conversation that goes on for way too long.
To say TÃ¡r did not need to be 2 hrs and 37 minutes long would be beating a dead horse. Of course it didn't need to be. It is beause it reflects the sort of pretentious, grandiose person Lydia TÃ¡r is. TÃ¡r, at its core, is a character study and a parable about modern times; a film about cancel culture and the accountability of cultural icons.
Cate Blanchett truly disappears into this role and delivers a powerhouse performance here. It's hard not to sound like a broken record, but she really becomes Lydia. There's an amazing physicality to her performance along with her incredible affectations and ability to portray TÃ¡r consistently, even whilst speaking different languages.
I also found the film's sometimes meandering pace to be compelling as it gave us a chance to get to know people without necessarily figuring out where they all fit in TÃ¡r's life. It really made the film feel like a slice of life, where the story has a lot of context before the movie begins, and will go on after (naturally, given the ending).
It's also a very well made film; the cinematography and sound design, thankfully, are impeccable. You really get sucked into whatever room you're in and there's an overbearing sense of atmosphere, a coldness associated with the refined world of classical music.
Yet, this is also a movie I'd probably never watch again. It does a lot quite well, but is too simple a plot to waste so much time. Most of the other um...non, TÃ¡r characters, are pretty paper thin and we don't really have any particular subplots or complex relationship dynamics. As the movie lurches towards its end, I felt like it implies a strong emotional connection to what's happening, but it never really made it.
This is a story that could've been told in a very conventional, straightforward way, but it's smarter than that. It takes a pretty nuanced and difficult-to-discuss subject and tackles it head on, but in a way that feels as if it's an aspect of the character's life and not the whole thing. TÃ¡r, like many Oscar bait films, has a lot to appreciate. But, I genuinely don't believe it's the sort of film many people will honestly remember and appreciate years down the road.

I watched all of the lengthy film Tar in one sitting, but that was only possible because I have a strong background in classical music (piano). At some points, I felt as though I was watching excerpts from Robert Greenberg's educational videos on the history of music (The Great Courses). In fact, some of the anecdotes relayed in this film were familiar to me only because of my prior exposure to the erudite Mr. Greenberg's massive oeuvre.\nLots of reviewers are comparing this creation to Whiplash, and there is something to that comparison, but mainly the story revolves around a person who seems more concerned with her own status than anything else. Others see reflections of Black Swan. I agree that there are overlaps, but this is not a copycat film.\nThe film is beautifully shot and contentful enough not to be boring--but only if you are a part of the world of art music. Otherwise, I imagine that it would be very tedious to get through. I rather liked the ambiguous ending, which seems to be a trend, judging by the other new movies I have watched of late.

This is truely a good movie like we use to have good script- amazing actors-great plot and great cinematography. I saw it yesterday on HBO and didn't care for it until I realize the build up and crazy ending. I'll have to watch it again I missed too much... so much to understand.\nMust of been such a good time for an amazing actor like Blanchet to portray a female conductor, this is a subject we aren't use to penetrate and observe. I love everything about this film so personal so different in such many ways.\nThis is a grand movie and Blanchet deversed an Oscar for it or at least a nomination there nothing easy or lazy about this film with amazing shoots specially the one with the new male student at the beginning.

How does Tar make me feel? I feel respected. Especially by Cate Blanchett for convincing me of every emotion her character is feeling, and of the rightness of it. And for saying and doing the things I would have done, and have done in my life. I think this is called identification with the main character of a book or play or movie. The main reason we enjoy it.
Obviously it is not all her work. Todd Field wrote and directed the movie. And in making the movie, he went to the greatest amount of trouble. The musicians are real musicians. Sophie Kauer is a real cellist, not an actress. Cate Blanchett plays the piano herself. The orchestra and its performance of Mahler's Fifth Symphony are real and breathtaking. There are no tricks. This is a movie to satisfy the lover of classical music. The music does not come second.
We are allowed a look into the life and personality of a very talented and powerful person. With the pathologies that such a talent could bring. This is recognized and used by those around her. As Lydia herself would say:
"Put the art before the artist".
This is a movie that we should watch and re-watch until we understand it. It is NOT an 'art film'. There are no secret depths to it, or symbolic meanings. It is a movie from which each of us can learn about ourselves. Full Marks to Todd Field.

TÃ¡r portrays a gifted conductor and composer at the summit of her career who soon finds herself at the center of a media scandal. Its protagonist, Lydia TÃ¡r, is brilliantly portrayed by Cate Blanchett, who deftly communicates TÃ¡r's fierce intelligence and credibly conveys her emotions as she slips ever deeper into a downward spiral. When she talks about music, she really does seem to know what she's talking about (at least to someone who is not a trained classical musician). And when she goes over the edge it is explosive.
The film builds towards this explosion slowly and steadily, gradually creating an atmosphere of growing unease through a succession of seemingly minor incidents, striking images, and disquieting music. When the tension finally crests and breaks in TÃ¡r's climax, it feels natural and inevitable. The film's taught two-and-a-half-hours-plus are well-used.
The scandal, or rather the combination of scandals, that take TÃ¡r down will feel familiar to anyone who has followed current events in the #MeToo era. I found the film's depiction of these events to be intelligent and believable. It did not oversimplify the issues addressed in order to score easy points among partisans of one point of view or another, a welcome change from many recent films that have often felt like they were pounding home their political message with a sledgehammer.
TÃ¡r's intelligence, production, and great acting show that there are still smart films being made in the 2020s. It received plenty of accolades, but probably deserved more awards.

It takes ages for the main plot of 'TÃ¡r (2022)' to become properly apparent, and any hint towards its true nature that occur prior to this are only really relevant in retrospect. For a long time, it feels a little aimless, a slice of life drama focusing on a renowned composer and her efforts to craft her latest concert. Slowly but surely, hints of her potential bad behaviour start to creep into the piece. There are quite a few red flags that pop up here and there, all of which soon point to something far more tangibly sinister than the protagonist's early dismissal of woke culture. By the time that you start to truly put together what's going on, though, it's almost time for the flick to finish. This means that there isn't really enough time to explore the fallout of the lead's unraveling; it would perhaps have been better if a lot of the early runtime was repurposed to showcase the aftermath of the movie's most major plot point. For a long time, the affair is just a bit dull, despite being well-made in almost every aspect. The lead performance is notably good, the direction is confident and the cinematography is beautiful in its own unassuming way. The screenplay, however, doesn't do enough to keep you engaged and it often gets lost in the intricacies of its subject matter, which may compel people interested in orchestral conducting but is likely to go over everyone else's heads. Some elements initially seem like odd inclusions but eventually reveal themselves to have been fairly clever visualisations of some later revelations, including some fleeting yet distinctly unsettling imagery that gets under your skin long before you know why it ought to have. Even these aspects don't save the piece from its slow, uneven pacing and its slightly dodgy politics. Its last few sequences feel kind of racist, in a way, and the whole piece feels as though it's pretentiously positioned against cancel culture (without even really diving into it properly - again, thanks to the strange structure that sees the most major plot element occur far too late to have any true impact). Pretentious is a good word for the whole thing, really; it sort of insists upon itself. It also seems to not want to be viewed politically while making choices that can't be seen as anything other than political, which is annoying. It's a technically solid film that's let down by its uneven and slow-paced narrative. It's not exactly bad, but I can't say I particularly enjoy all that much of it.

I saw Pitch Perfect in the movie theater ! Twice .... Love it !
It Has Anna Kendrick In It ! This is helpful. She is so adorable, talented, beautiful, and witty ! FYI she really sang all of her songs in all Pitch Perfect movies, Anna Kendrick reportedly refused to pre-record her vocals. Any time protagonist Beca, played by Anna Kendrick, was singing alone, she was singing live on set.
A movie about girl weirdos doing what they love. Bonus ! Rebel Wilson's performance!
I found myself liking the film whether I wanted to or not . I just ordered the Trilogy Blu-ray !! Relive the best moments with your favorite pitches! Triple the laughs, the adventures (or misadventures), and music with this three-movie collection.

This movie was about a capella singing so I can't say it was something I thought I'd enjoy but honestly it wasn't that bad. The singing was really good and I really enjoyed every treblemaker song. The humour was really really hit or miss throughout the whole film. Some of the jokes were unbearably and just downright awful, mostly to do with those presenters. Occasionally they were kinda funny. Some of the dialogue is really awful and the use of aca before every word was excruciatingly painful. And it wasn't once or twice, it happened so frequently and every time it did I wanted to bash my head off a wall. Overall wasn't the worst movie but there were definitely better. 7.5/10.

This movie hits the spot to me I watched so many times when it was HBO and saw the sequels in the theater just wasn't reviewing then. I love the chemistry with all the cast, the music is magnificent, so much charm, and plenty of great entertainment that makes me so happy! I very much enjoy the cast I bet they are fun to be around. The vomiting scenes are awesome comedy, the directing is phenomenal in my opinion! I wonder if I'm one of few that loves The Pitch Perfect movies although part 3 isn't as good. I bet college is great fun I wish I was normal enough to go having autism is a bizarre experiences.

As I watched this movie for the first time this week, I knew it was rated a 7.1 average on here. But as I sat through the majority of this movie I thought to myself - what do people love so much about this movie? I mean I remember when it first came out how it made such a cultural impact and was very popular. But the majority of this movie feels old and uninspired in 2023. The jokes and sub plots were all very mediocre and some didn't age well. But as the movie starts to wrap up, it hits its literal and metaphorical climax. The final 20 minutes makes this movie worth watching! Feel good movie.

One of the worst, most cringeworthy movies I've ever seen. The characters are unrealistic, stereotyped, and shallow. They are all such awful people that you don't care about any of them. They don't act like actual humans would at all.\nThe humor is crude and offensive, but not in a funny way like Borat. The movie has a ridiculous amount of projectile vomit, which comes out with the force of a fire hose. The only good thing about the film is that Anna Kendrick is kind of cute.\nAs for the music, it's all so highly-edited that it doesn't even remotely look like the actors are actually singing. For a movie about acapella singing, I was hoping for higher quality performances and less stereotype humor.

This movie is so incredibly perfect and contains many components for a rewatch. Now, I am inside the demographic to enjoy this movie heavily but, I have loved it for YEARS. In 2012 when this movie came out I was VERY young and ever since then its been playing either on a screen or (and I have to be real) in my mind. The songs are such earworms and I am always singing along with the movie.\nThe movie is about an all-girl acapella group who fell off the past year at their singing championship and are attempting to fight their way back to the top.\nI 10/10 recommend for a watch or a rewatch!!!!!!!

Oh my gosh,...........anna kendrick and anna camp are hilarious in this movie. It's one of the most fun movies ive seen in a long while and 2000s and early 1010s definitely had the fun movie area covered. The music and the acapella singing were great. It made anna kendrick a star and also our first introduction to adam devine's character. Adam devine was so hilarious in this movie. The singing and just the novelty is great. We could actually tune out and enjoy ourselves and have a fun time. I highly recommend this movie to anyone that enjoys a fun time in with your family or your loved ones or even by youreself with some hot chocolate.

Everything about these movies is great. They are so ridiculous and funny. I've seen them multiple times and they just don't get old. My favorite is pitch perfect two. I love that the girls bond at the summer camp and I love Hailee Steinfeld as the new girl. Super sweet and well done on the acting. My favorite characters are fat Amy, Emily, benji. My favorite a cappella groups are the Bella's and the treble makers, I also liked those rocker chicks in the last movie. I loved Jesse. But unfortunately I didn't like Becca all that much. She just seemed winey to me through out the series. All that to say, great mindless movies to watch for a good laugh.

*Pitch Perfect is a fun film that's easy to enjoy*\nPitch Perfect caught me off guard with how fun the movie is. It's a sneaky PG13, because the movie will go on like a Disney channel exclusive when all of a sudden you get hit with a crude joke that you can't help but laugh at. The cast does a good job playing their roles, though at times the characters can feel a little one dimensional. The plot is simple yet enjoyable. But what makes the movie the most for me is the music. I might just be a sucker for A Capella (which is weird seeing that I don't listen to it ever) but the soundtrack to the film is great.\nOverall, if you haven't seen this movie in a while or ever, and want to feel good at the end, I would recommend this movie.

Pitch Perfect (2012) is a movie that my daughter and I recently watched together on Netflix. The storyline follows a new student at a college who wants to quit but is convinced by her dad to give it one more year and that she needs to join a club to better understand what college is about. She joins a singing team that is renowned for struggling and wanting to be better than they are. Can she learn something from the group and vice versa?
This picture is directed by Jason Moore (Shotgun Wedding) and stars Anna Kendrick (Up in the Air), Brittany Snow (Hairspray), Rebel Wilson (Jojo Rabbit), Alexis Knapp (Couple's Retreat), Ben Platt (Drunk Parents) and Skylar Astin (21 & Over).
This is honestly an easy movie to enjoy. The writing of both the storyline, circumstances and dialogue is unique and clever. The cast is perfectly selected and fit the characters to perfection. Even the side characters are compelling and hilarious - I adored Hana Mae Lee in this. Her vomit scene is legendary. There's a great fight scene in here that cracked me up too. I can't say enough good things about this soundtrack as well.
Overall, this is a well created and unique coming of age picture that I would strongly recommend. I would score this a 7.5/10.

The movie "A Star Is Born" is a musical drama about a musician, Jackson Maine (Bradley Cooper), who discovers and mentors a struggling artist, Ally (Lady Gaga), while battling his own addiction. Bradley Cooper, in his directorial debut, masterfully delivers the fourth adaptation of this movie. He chooses to depict a more contemporary version, portraying an America that is grappling with darkness and illness. Furthermore, Cooper effectively transforms a popular singer into an actress who perfectly fits into Ally's role. Lady Gaga delivers a knockout performance, showing the nuances of a struggling singer with power and authenticity.\nThe movie also stands out due to the intense emotional journey of an artist at the end of his career, battling addiction to alcohol and drugs, and the healing power of music.\nThe exceptional soundtrack enhances the storyline, further accentuating the performances of the lead actors.

The film is inexplicable predictable , not just the plot . Most scenes were painful to watch and not in a good way Sorry I just cant follow Jacks pain and alcoholism its not portrayed in a believable way and I know what I am talking about . Hes not a bad actor hes just not doing it right. The story moves ahead like a ton of bricks falling down the stairs all while its supposed to be earnest , emotional and down to earth But you cant feel the big time of their success and you cant feel the pain of the couple as their path goes separate ways . The best scenes are inthe start with Ally La vie en rose and gagas a decent actor in portraying her initial concern but once shes in love the movies over. Fine with a modern adaption but this was painful like bad danish socialrealism( Im a dane)and I struggled to watch it to the unnessary end.

For this kind of person this film it's so good.
