Michael Caine gives a superb performance as the miserly Scrooge, he's very well cast in this role. A must-watch Christmas film, just skip through the musical numbers because they add nothing to the storytelling.

Muppet Christmas Carol
The most faithful adaptation of the story is also the silliest version I have ever seen. The movie was the first made after Jim Henson's untimely death, so it had a lot riding on it to see how the franchise would continue. It took me nearly 3 decades to get myself to watch it because I still hadn't gotten over his death. I mention this because it affected my perception of the film.
I first saw it in 2020 when I was going through some tough times. A close friend of mine had it on his "must see at Christmas" list every year so I finally agreed to watch it. I was immediately taken back to those days and months after Mr. Henson's passing, when I was only 13. But this time, instead of denial, I saw a charming love letter to the man who helped shape my childhood. I couldn't have been happier to see that his legacy lived on.
Now, moving on to the movie itself, I found it to be cleverly scripted, brilliantly acted by both the human performers, and the muppet performers, and enhanced by some very catchy and meaningful songs. The story is told in the familiar fashion that most people know but with moments of absurdity and silliness that help lighten the mood, but still highlight one troubled man's path toward redemption.
It is often forgotten that one cannot define a person by their actions alone. Scrooge's nephew continues to speak of the good that must be bubbling beneath the surface. As the past and present spirits reveal the true reasons behind his misery and foul demeanor, the viewer may change their thoughts on the man. Redemption is potentially possible once the pain is revealed and set free. In this situation, I am happy to see the change in him.
It's a cute movie with muppets, but it tells the story well, and I feel it is a fair movie to watch with children. Open discussion on the themes can be helpful in reminding them that what's on the surface may be hiding a pain that one knows nothing about. Be kind to one another. And Merry Christmas.

This film was an obsession for me in 1993. The music sticks in my head like no other, thank you Paul Williams. Michael Cane plays Scrooge with such seriousness that you forget that half of the cast are felt puppets. Great way of utilizing Gonzo as Dickens. Also if you go to the extras on Disney +it has the deleted song that made people too sad apparently. No, children need to be sad and know heart break. Let them grow.\nThus was the first film I believe after Jim Henson's passing, but they made it count and work. I do love how the Muppets break the fourth wall when they can, but not make it too sappy at the same time,

Stop villainizing Scoooooge. (Just kidding.) It's funny I now totally get Scrooge. Fred is such a hypocrite. Smiling and delivering words of God on Christmas day but slandering Scrooge behind his back. He is a hopeless optimist without realistic plans but counting on his uncle. He benefits from Scrooge's hard work and gains people's favor just by standing opposite of him. Scrooge yells at his employees, and it's wrong conduct. However, employees are annoyingly loud. Charity workers should not force donations and judge people who do not give money. He's rich, and paying the large amount of tax without committing crimes to evade tax is the most primal responsibility as he said. Soundtracks are surprisingly amazing. However, it's still a kids movie when it comes to the quality of the film.

This one just absolutely tops all other versions!\nEven after years and years of rewatching this movie, it hits me in all the feels every time. The songs, the characters, the portrayals are all done spectacularly for a seemingly low-budget film. Exceptional performance from Michael Caine, as usual, cementing him as the best actor of Scrooge. The story follows practically the same as the original, but it adds that Muppet charm and humor that makes it feel completely original. The crossover of Muppets and humans feels natural and welcoming, making the world feel colorful and magical.\nOverall, this definitely is the best rendition of this Christmas classic and will remain so for a long, long time!

Rating: 7.0\nOverall, it's The Muppets telling 'A Christmas Carol' (with some pretty good musical numbers).\nPretty Good Direction (The direction of a macroscale feels very polished for a Muppets movie as the use of cinematography and the execution of musical numbers is good; the direction on a microscale is pretty standard; the direction of actors and voice actors is pretty similar to other Muppets movies; the storytelling is very similar to other retellings of A Christmas Carol (but with a Muppets twist)), Pretty Good Acting (Pretty Good from Michael Caine (I have no idea what he's doing in this movie but he does a pretty good job in both being Scrooge and singing), Pretty Good from the rest of the cast (Pretty good singing and the puppeteering and voice acting is similar to other Muppets movies)), Decent to Pretty Good Story (The concept is just the Muppets telling 'A Christmas Carol'; the story construction just follows 'A Christmas Carol'; the flow between sequences is very meta/interjected a lot to talk to the audience (very typical of other Muppets movies); the character writing is just portraying the Muppets and Scrooge), Decent to Pretty Good Screenplay (The dialogue is just 'A Christmas Carol' mixed with Muppets-esque dialogue; the humor is very Muppets-esque; the symbolism is just the symbolism of 'A Christmas Carol'; The foreshadowing is just the foreshadowing of 'A Christmas Carol'), Pretty Good Score (Used pretty well to set the tone)/ Pretty Good Soundtrack (The musical numbers were pretty good and pretty funny), Good Cinematography (Very polished and used well), Pretty Good Sound, Good Editing (Very Polished), Good Visual Effects (The use of puppeteering was really good as it showed the experience of The Muppets, the use of green screen was pretty obvious), Good Costumes (Helped set the scene for 'A Christmas Carol'), Plot Structure followed the Christmas Carol template (but done well), Pacing was pretty fast (there isn't that much plot to go through and the runtime is pretty short), Climax was executed pretty well and brought everything together, Tone was a mix of 'A Christmas Carol' with The Muppets.

For over ten years, (I don't know why) every year when Christmas comes along. I always watch a different version of A Christmas Carol. Out of all the versions I have seen, my personal favourites are Scrooge (1951) staring Alastair Sims and Muppet Christmas Carol (1992).
But the version staring the Muppets is brilliant, accurate but thanks to the muppets also keeps it funny. What I like about this version is that is that it's not as "dark, moody and scary" as the other versions. It's the humour that keeps that in check.
Don't misunderstand, when it comes to the scenes of Christmas yet to come. That part would scare kids, but there is a message behind that. Because the future hasn't been written yet, people can make changes to the future to make not only there future bright, but other people as well, especially during the festive season.
Although I don't know much about Charles Dickens, this is one story i can relate to. For those who are unaware, there is a museum dedicated to him in London, UK. Trust me, its worth visiting it, especially at this time of year.

My wife and I agree that this is the best Christmas Carol version. We've watched nearly all of them. Only Scrooged is in competition with it in my opinion, but that differs quite a bit from the original.
The muppets are great, Michael Caine is great, the effects are great. I'm not sure I can think of an actor who could do a better job. Kermit is a perfect fit to play Scrooge's mistreated assistant, since we're used to seeing him play a similar role with Miss Piggy.
Just watched this recently and it's surprisingly well done for a first time director.
Looking forward to watching it in the future so that I can start to memorize the songs.

I have a very soft spot for Muppet CC - fond memories of going to see it on a snowy day in Manchester - but objectively it's not one of the better adaptations of Dickens' immortal tale. I generally watch it at some point over Christmas, and I think if anything familiarity has obscured the fact that it is just not a very good idea. The incorporation of existing Muppet characters into the story has only limited success, and sometimes the attempt is jarring. The use of Gonzo to link it, with Rizzo the rat (not previously an important character), is downright awkward. The landscapes look more like America than Britain, and some of the accents are distinctly hokey. Paul Williams' numbers are not the strongest, and even Scrooge himself, Michael Caine, doesn't compare well to the many great previous performances. Caine is okay as long as he can underplay - when he tries to emote, it's not a good look.\nBut it is fun, certainly a helluva lot better than Muppet Treasure Island. Miss Piggy, with her lookalike and actalike daughters Bettina and Belinda, is fantastic.\nFor what it's worth, I think the best Muppets film is the revival one with Jason Segel.

I enjoy this. It's saved by its soul, its songs and by Michael Caine as Scrooge. I don't enjoy the Muppets or quite understand why people are so fanatically in love with them. I grew up on Sesame Street and still don't love the Muppets. Most of the time, the Muppets are just goofy ridiculousness. I have a sense of humor, but I don't love the puppetry and characters. I do love Dickens' tale, and I believe Henson did well here with it. Michael Caine's performance as Scrooge is award-worthy. I'll watch this again, and that surprises me. I figured I'd only want to watch this once and be done with it. And that says everything to me.

This was a movie that my sister and I grew up with. It is one that we'd watch in a steady rotation. I'll be honest though; this was a movie that I hadn't seen in probably 25 or so years. Jaime and I wanted to revisit this one after having seen the prequel of Wonka. We wanted to see how well it could fit in story-wise.
Then for this adaptation of the source material, we are following Charlie Bucket (Peter Ostrum). He is a poor boy who lives with his mother, Mrs. Bucket (Diana Sowle), her parents who include Grandpa Joe (Jack Albertson), as well as her deceased husband's parents. All the grandparents are confined to one bed. Mrs. Bucket works in a laundry where Charlie has picked up a job delivering newspapers.
In the area, there is the infamous Wonka Chocolate Factory. It has been sealed up for some time. All that comes out would be the products that are made there. Things change though when Willy Wonka (Gene Wilder) hosts a contest, offering a lifetime supply of chocolate to the winners. There are five golden tickets hidden in the wrapper of chocolate bars. This brings Augustus Gloop (Michael Bollner), Veruca Salt (Julie Dawn Cole), Violet Beauregarde (Denise Nickerson) and Mike Teevee (Paris Themmen) to the factory along with one guardian. Charlie is also the improbable last guest with his grandfather.
It is inside that they all get a taste of the madness of Wonka and his crew that help him produce his candy. They are a strange race known as Oompa Loompas. The kids are told not to do it and when they go against what Wonka said, we see what the repercussions are. Wonka isn't fully letting on what his plan is and it will take a true act of kindness to succeed.
What I'm going to say to lead off here is that this is a fun movie. Wilder is perfectly cast in this eccentric role of Wonka. He adds snark and sarcasm to the role that make me laugh. It is funny that Jaime looked at me multiple times while watching this to say that is something I'd say. Something interesting is that Wonka is supposed to be a jovial person. I get part of that here, but he also seems tired and just over the world as well. It makes sense in the end as well.
This version of the story is a fantastical story and place that still feels grounded in the real world. Things seen inside of this factory don't make sense to the visitors, but to Wonka, it is normal. I do love that as it is a tough line to walk. It does a great job at capturing the heart of Roald Dahl's novel and bringing it to life. I'll be honest though, I had this read to me when I was in fourth grade, but I don't remember a lot of the book for obvious reasons. It is impressive that this is done at a time of practical effects as well. That adds charm to it.
What also makes this work is the acting. I've said how good Wilder is. It is interesting that with the new one out, TimothÃ©e Chalamet feels like the younger version to me. Albertson is good as Grandpa Joe, a character that is problematic while still being beloved. I thought that Ostrum was good as Charlie. He has the best heart and intentions of the golden ticket winners. Cole, Nickerson, Themmen and Bollner are good as the other kids who have character flaws that explain why they fall victim to different things in the factory. Roy Kinnear, Leonard Stone, Nora Denney and Ursula Reit are all good as well as the parents who should shoulder blame. All the Oompa Loompas are great and the rest of the cast push our characters to where they end up.
I'll then end this out saying that this is a classic. It is a funny movie. There are good messages here that have a different feeling now that I'm a parent. The acting is good. This is a well made movie. Extra credit there to make this fantastic place come to life in what feels like a real world. This captures that the best. Effects are good as are the different songs that we hear. That is something else, this is a well made musical as well. I highly recommend this if you haven't seen it in awhile as this is just great.
My Rating: 9 out of 10.

After saw the Fabulous " Charlie and the Chocolate Factory " by the greatest Tim Burton who did all my childhood with his own movie of chocolate, I was so excited to see the first opus of the chocolate factory and I was absolutely not disappointed !
Obviously It can be better than burton's movie cause the budgets are not the same but we feel too a good chocolate environment and well of course childhood ambiant !!!
But I was little surprised by the fact that this movie was about the same story that Burton's movie, I wanted a new story about that but is more Burton was be inspired by this movie that is own I will prefer two different story !
Finally good and not bad movie and better to see as a child for have the magic :))))))

Plot:
In the 1971 classic, "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory," director Mel Stuart brings Roald Dahl's beloved book to life with whimsy and charm. The story follows young Charlie Bucket, who wins a golden ticket to visit the mysterious and magical chocolate factory of the eccentric Willy Wonka. Inside, Charlie and the other lucky children encounter a world of pure imagination and unexpected adventures, guided by the enigmatic Willy Wonka himself.
Review:
"Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" (1971) is a delectable treat for audiences of all ages. With its vivid colors, catchy musical numbers, and endearing performances, this film captures the essence of Dahl's imaginative world. Gene Wilder's portrayal of Willy Wonka is nothing short of iconic, infusing the character with a perfect blend of whimsy and mystery.
Compared to the 2005 adaptation, this earlier version excels in its ability to convey the magical allure of Wonka's factory. The practical effects and set design create an enchanting atmosphere that feels more authentic and immersive. The musical score adds an extra layer of enchantment, enhancing the film's timeless appeal.
"Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" (1971) strikes a delightful balance between humor and heart, making it a truly enjoyable cinematic experience. The film's enduring charm and imagination make it a classic that continues to captivate audiences decades after its release. If you loved the book or seek a magical escape, this cinematic gem is a must-see, and it is no wonder that many viewers, myself included, find it more enjoyable than the 2005 adaptation.

Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory is as creative a film as it gets. It is weird, it is fun, it is everything a movie should be. Pure Imagination perfectly sums up this film and its chocolate factory. This movie as well as Gene Wilder's performance, as the eccentric Willy Wonka will live on forever. It will be watched by both kids and adults of all ages and everyone will find something to enjoy. This is an undisputed classic with an excellent set-design, wonderful music and terrific performances by the entire cast. Roald Dahl's story is a pure gem that will live on for years and years to come.

This is an amazing classic film and it was my favorite when I was six and seven. Charlie and the chocolate factory was the first chapter book I ever read.
This movie may not have a lot of stuff from the book but it still holds to be great.
I'm 12 and I still love this movie for what it is. The only downside in my opinion is the title given that the film title is different than the book title.
Gene Wilder is absolutely magical and his performance is perfect. It's funny, smart, and surprisingly well shot for a 70s movie.
The other actors do great and the oompa loompas are something else. The oompa loompas are my absolute favorite part of the movie and that song they sing hits different. The oompa loompa song while it's not in the book it's amazing.
Parents there is nothing to say that's inappropriate or violent about this movie. Slugworth may seem a little creepy but it's not that bad.
This is a 70s masterpiece and a HUGE part of my childhood.
7/10.

Very good kinda? This movie is a classic the acting isn't awful, it's not the best but it's definitely passable. The music is very hit or miss but the songs definitely have their moments. The set design is easily what makes this film so famous. It really captures the beauty and charm of Roal dahls imagination. The world feels very creative and anyone would want to see it themselves. The movie also has weirdly scary imagery and I don't know why and I'm not even 100% sure if it's done on purpose, but it's definitely their. The comedy is also astounding in this film. Gene wilder is amazing in this film he's similar in a way to bill murray in the first ghostbusters, just much more subtle with it. Finally, I think the story isn't the best. There's a lot of obvious plot holes that kinda ruin it and even when you look behind that, all the characters are very 2 dimensional even the star Charlie. (Also due to weird plot choices half the casts choices make them seem like sociopaths).

No pun intended - I was able to watch the new Wonka movie, which is supposed to be the backstory or the prequel to this and/or the Johnny Depp movie. I have to admit, I really liked what they did with the new movie! There was a lot of intelligent dialog (and songs - and I don't like musicals in general ... well that is what I thought to say the least) and a lot of fantasy and great set design (costumes and everything else included).
But back to this (no pun intended either), a movie that I assume many have a weak spot for! Especially if they have seen it as kids. And while it does seem to have quite a few adult themes in there (and can feel gruesome I reckon), it is fun to watch with quite the great performance by Wilder! The new movie (prequel) is taking a few things that you may know from this - like the Oompa Loompa (song) to name just one thing.
The beginning of this movie right here is a bit ... well bumpy. At least it felt weird to say the least - I understand that the movie needs to get the kids and introduce them to the audience ... but it feels badly aged in trying to be ... well funny and savvy and critical (consumerism and so forth).
If you don't mind the sometimes grim methods and can dig the humor of the movie (also dark at times), you will like it. How conceivable everything is? Well suspension of disbelief and all that ... chocolate is the name of the game, but being good and righteous is what really helps you move along or rather forward.

The very best part of this movie is Gene Wilder's WIlly Wonka. He is absolutely crazy, unhinged and charming at the same time, which is how real psychopaths are. Now from what I remember from the Johnny Depp version, he portrayed the character as an awkward, bumbling genius kind of guy, that may be more like how movies portray psychopaths? So either way, it seems the consensus is that Willy Wonka is a psychopath.\nOther than that, the movie was a delight to watch filled with childlike wonder, sometimes scary, sometimes wild. A not-so-subtle implication of supporting slavery while criticizing capitalism but with no regard for the government. But I'm gonna take things here more at face value considering the nature of the film and the time it came out. The new Wonka trailer does seem to be more closer to this than the remake.

Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is a magical movie that still manages to delight and enchant viewers decades after it was made. This film is full of fun visuals, clever jokes, and memorable musical moments. Gene Wilder plays the titular candy man in a way where you are kind of scared of him, but you also really like him. I also want to give some praise to Peter Ostrum, who gives Charlie Bucket such genuine innocence. Yes, there are some slower moments (I'm looking at you, "Cheer Up, Charlie."), but Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is a sweet film the whole family can watch together.

I just rewatched "Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory" for the first time since seeing it as a kid in school and I am left with the same impression, which is that this film is disturbing, bizarre and rambling, but mainly disturbing due to the way the film and Wonka treat the children. I get that the kids are supposed to be brats and that there is supposed to be some lesson in here for kids to be better behaved, but come on, kids are kids, and of course they would be excited to tour a chocolate factory. Why on earth this supposed kids musical decides to maim, mutilate and kill off the principal child characters is beyond me, but I found it disturbing as a child, and I still find it disturbing as an adult. Be forewarned, I wouldn't recommend this film for young children. 2/10 rating.

This movie is a massacre of the legacy of the original. It's dark, with no hope. It's horrendous. The only beauty is the new Wonka movie is magic. Enjoy it. Enjoy it knowing Tim Burton didn't make it!
The Burton movie was dark and more in the style of Edward Scissorhands than the Gene Wilder version.
It's morbid and Depp is almost freakiest as Wonka instead of having a childish charm.
I'm apathetic to the book as it's from the 1960s and we've all grown up a bit since then so any movie doesn't have to be perfect. But this one misses the mark.
I am a massive Wonka fan. I love the Wilder adaptation. He brings character and empathy, something Depp lacks in this monstrosity.

I haven't watched the original film in quite some time, so I don't really know how this one stacks up against it. However, I can say that I did not really enjoy this one, and I thought that I had never seen it before, but I realized in the middle of watching it that yes indeed I have seen it before. Johnny Depp gives his best in personation of Michael Jackson in the height of his wacko Jacko era, and while this does provide a few Chuckles, it just makes the movie weird and not in a fun way. He's not the biggest problem with the movie though, as the biggest problem is Tim Burton's brand of weirdness. I like Tim Burton when the weirdness comes naturally and not when they have hired Tim Burton to be weird. It's kind of like the difference between Edward Scissorhands and that horrible Alice in Wonderland movie. So there's a few good lines in this movie, but I have heard that the new Charlie and the Chocolate Factory movie is much better, so either watch the original or that one.

I've watched this film when I was a child and since I literally forgot the whole plot I decided to watch it again and I'm actually suprised by how much I liked it like in my memories it wasn't that good. I would say ignore the negative reviews reagrdless if the film is truely accurate to the book or not. I mean maybe it doesn't respect certain aspects of the book but that doesn't invalidate the film. I really enjoyed it actually and I found it genuine, heartwarming and funny. I also love Johnny Depp's comedic portrayal of Willy Wonka. He definetly carried the film. And a big shoutout to the kids in the film too. Overall a great film that I would recommend.

I love this adaptation of the beloved Roald Dahl book! Many people think it is a remake of the original Willy Wonka And The Chocolate Factory but it's is not. They made it more loyal to the books as well. So it doesn't have much of a colorful atmosphere. It is dark and crazy just like the book. It may be scary for a younger audience though. To be honest, I prefer this over the first one. And I'm glad that Tim Burton created such a wonderful adaptation of the book. It may be too scary for young kids. It is pretty dark and scary. If you're child is interested make sure you look at the parents guide. Thanks for reading!

First of all, when I first watched the official trailer of the movie I liked it and I had high expectations about it. Eventually, it was as good as I had imagined and I enjoyed it. The plot of the movie was very interesting and kinda innovative, because there aren't any other movies similar to this one. The storyline was well-written, very well-explained and easy to understand. The characters were interesting, well-developed and likeable (except, the four spoiled children). The filming location of the movie was mainly inside Willy's chocolate factory. The casting was nice and their acting was really good, Johnny Depp's performance as Willy Wonka was excellent. I have to admit, it wasn't an intense movie and there weren't any shocking moments. However, it was very funny and there were too many hilarious scenes. The opening scene was kinda predictable, fast-paced and promising. The ending scene was definitely predictable and I liked it. Moreover, the cinematography and the score of the movie were both amazing. Overall, "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" was an enjoyable family film, colorful, funny and I would definitely recommend it to anyone!

Take Roald Dahl, add Tim Burton and sprinkle with Johnny Depp. Roald Dahl was well known for his dark stories and dark undercurrents in his more light hearted works. In comparison to the Gene Wilder original this was going to be less candyfloss sweetness than the rightly celebrated 1971 movie.\nTim Burton has added his touches to this classic childrens story. He presents Willy Wonka with a palour that hints at somethnig more menancing under the top hat. Johnny Depp's Will Wonka has more of the Peter Pan, the boy that never grew up, whereas Gene Wilder's was an adult.\nIn remaking classic movies, a new cinnamon twist is needed. Tim Burton and Johnny Depp have found an interpretation that is distinct from the 1971 movie and is more faithful to Dahl's novel. Recommended watching and then watch the original.

I have always loved this movie and have watch it since I was a kid, I have also watched the original one multiple times as a kid but now the movie is trending and it is getting kinda annoying this movie has always been one of my favorites and I hate how the fan base is ruining it I can see that Tim Burton tried to follow the book more than the original movie but I can see absolutely no reason in any way to say this movie is any better than the original. People have said that Johnny drop is the best Willy wonka there is but in my opinion he is one of my favorite actors but the worst wonka there is I can see that Tim Burton had tried to make him funnier In this one and yes he was so funny in this movie but. Gene wilder was a much better Willy wonka.

Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is the remake of the 1971 classic, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory. This film has a tremendously different tone than the first film, but I like that it has its own identity. Johnny Depp truly is phenomenal as Willy Wonka as his performance is unlike anything he has ever done before. The film definitely has a very Tim Burton feel and I enjoyed that because the whole Chocolate Factory and the person that is Willy Wonka is mysterious and somewhat of an enigma. Some will not enjoy the change of tone from the original film and that is fine, but I suggest viewing this film with an open mind. It is a different take from the original film for sure, but a successful remake of the Roald Dahl tale nonetheless.

"Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" takes viewers on a delightful journey into the enchanting world of Willy Wonka's renowned chocolate factory. The film follows young Charlie Bucket as he wins a golden ticket, granting him access to the mysterious and magical factory owned by the eccentric chocolatier Willy Wonka. Alongside four other lucky ticket holders, Charlie embarks on a wondrous and whimsical tour of the fantastical factory, encountering its extraordinary inhabitants and experiencing its delectable wonders.
The movie brings to life the beloved characters and settings from Roald Dahl's classic story, infusing the narrative with vibrant colors, imaginative designs, and a sense of childlike wonder. The film's visual effects and set design create a fantastical and immersive world, capturing the magic and allure of Wonka's confectionery paradise.
Johnny Depp delivers a captivating performance as Willy Wonka, portraying the enigmatic chocolatier with a blend of eccentricity and charm. The character's quirky demeanor and mysterious past add depth to the story, while the young actors portraying the children on the factory tour bring energy and enthusiasm to their roles.
"Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" succeeds in capturing the essence of Dahl's whimsical tale, celebrating themes of imagination, generosity, and the joy of discovery. The film's musical score and lively musical numbers further enhance the fantastical atmosphere, complementing the visual spectacle with memorable songs and choreography.
In conclusion, "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is a delightful and visually captivating adaptation that offers a heartwarming and magical experience for audiences of all ages. With its enchanting storytelling, endearing characters, and imaginative world-building, the film remains a timeless and beloved cinematic treat.

Some love this version of the story and some hate it, we think this adoption of the classical Charlie and the Chocolate Factory tale is well made and one of our favourites! We do always enjoy watching it.
Johnny Depp sparkles with a solid performance and also the imagery of Tim Burton makes it easy to get sucked into the imaginary world of a grimm Chocolate factory owner and the world of poor Charlie and his family who just want to endulge in the bitter sweet taste of Mr. Wonkas chocolate creations.
As a chocolate company ourselves we do like that an awareness is shown to the craft of making chocolate, we would have love to see more manual labor but Mr. Wonka is known for his machinery and Oompa Loompas.
We totally recommed.

Are you a good witch, or a bad witch?" - Glinda
Following a lage tornado, Dorothy, a teenage farm girl from Kansas, is swept away to the magical land of Oz. Along with her new friends the Scarecrow, Tin Man and the Cowardly Lion, Dorothy must find the Wizard in the hopes he can help her return home.
I can't remember when or where I saw Wizard of Oz for the first time. It's one of those films ingrained in my memory since as long as I can remember and although not one of my favourite films of all time - its still a near perfect movie! The transition from Black and White to Colour is just as striking now as I'm sure it would of been back in 1939. Even though I know what to expect, it still takes me by surprise every time she steps into Munckin City. The performances, songs and dance numbers are extremely zany, catchy and camp but it blends in well with the ridiculousness of the film itself. The actors were well selected and every main character plays there part extremely well - the munchkins are a little flat I have to say but their songs and costumes make up for the lack of acting skills. The 4K image is crystal clear and the downside to that is certain special effects are extremely noticable and not always effectuve - such as the visible trap door when the Wicked Witch appears/disappears in the Munckim City or when the Wicked Witch flies on her broom around the castle and you can tell it's a small toy on a string or wire. Even though I did laugh at these on my recent watch through, i also appreciated the skill and effort it took to achieve such special effects in 1939 - and it would of looked perfectly realistic on CRT TV, VHS and DVD...
Final Verdict:
This movie is a classic and a much loved family favourite for many generations. The songs are catchy, the story timeless and the performances are memorable. In 4K the image is so clear and vibrant you'd think the film was made this century!

Is there a movie that has permeated pop culture so much and for so long than The Wizard of Oz? Even though this film was released in 1939, it still captures the attention of viewers today with its cinematic magic. It's a story for all ages which features beautiful visuals, memorable music, elaborate sets, and unforgettable characters. Judy Garland is adorably innocent as Dorothy Gale and Margaret Hamilton still terrifies me a little as the Wicked Witch of the West. It may be a little slow in parts and feels longer than it actually is (only 101 minutes?), but The Wizard of Oz is a classic family film.

In the late 1930s, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's studio head Louis B. Mayer had a serious conversation with some of his employees. Mayer wanted MGM to make a fantasy film in the style of Walt Disney's hugely successful "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" from the previous year. After some thought, producer Mervyn LeRoy suggested that L. Frank Baum's book "The Wonderful Wizard of Oz" could be adapted into a movie. After all, Baum's work was considered an American classic.
At that time most films were made in black and white. Working in color meant you had to use a whole new type of camera - and they were big and cumbersome. In addition, MGM was forced to accept a so-called "Technicolor consultant" from the camera manufacturer. A man who stood next to the cinematographer and told him how to light every scene. Mayer didn't care, though. He wanted to compete with Disney's pioneering feature. And "Snow White" was in color.
"The Wizard of Oz" was made exclusively at the MGM Studios in Culver City. But it was a messy production. The first director was fired after 12 days. Victor Fleming took over, but he was moved to "Gone with the Wind". So, it was up to King Vidor to finish the film. And there were cast changes, too. The Tin Man had an allergic reaction to the silvery makeup and had to be replaced. The Wicked Witch was severely burned when she went up in a puff of smoke. Even Toto (the dog) was out of commission for a week after being stepped on by a crew member.
The film had its world premiere at Grauman's Chinese Theater in Hollywood. Judy Garland then went on an East Coast publicity tour, which included the New York opening of "Oz". But it didn't help. "The Wizard of Oz" had been so expensive to produce that MGM made a net loss of millions. The studio didn't get their money back until 1949, when the movie had its re-release worldwide. The following year, MGM sold the rights to TV, where the film has been shown ever since.

Where to begin? I have loved this movie since I was a child. It has been a part of my life. I watch it all the time. It has special memories personally and professionally. I wanted to write and make movies because of The Wizard of Oz. I became obsessed with Judy Garland because of the movie. I have books and magazines. There is a lot to say about the film that love but also aware of the negative behind the scenes moments that occurred. Yes, there are flaws in the movie I can point out, but after a while I don't care. The songs are iconic, the story is iconic, and it's very quotable through the decades. And it is still ranked one of the best films of all time on many lists.

Judy Garland's portrayal of Dorothy, Dorothy's oddball friend Oz, "Somewhere Over the Rainbow", and the rest of this beautiful production of "The Wizard of Oz" lose little of their magic over the years. While poking fun at this kind of classic, innocent fantasy has become somewhat of a trend in recent years, the film itself has aged well, and will likely retain an appreciative audience for some time to come.
Undoubtedly part of the appeal of the story and the characters comes from their being old friends with so many cinema fans, but there's also a good reason why they've endured so long, and have endured even after. Becoming all too familiar. Although Dorothy is not a particularly complex character, she represents an innocent yet deep passion that is easy to identify with. Also, the 'Oz' characters are quirky enough to remain interesting, but there is a core element that is again believable. Who doesn't feel like they could use at least one of the things Dorothy's friends love?
The adaptation from the original story was well done, making good choices for characters and episodes to work into the film. The settings and visual effects may not impress devotees of computer imagery today, but in their time they certainly showed great skill and planning, and even today, in their own way they are more believable than most computer tricks that have become overused.
The famous story has also been used for several more recent adaptations, and some of them have their own good points. But this Wizard remains the most impressive of the versions of the classic story.

Thank you Judy Garland and the Wizard, Frank Morgan, for so many memories, then and now.
It is so true, how this classic has held up through the years, and in beautiful color. We all remember it being shown once a year on tv (back in the day when there was NO cable).
Everyone has passed, but these incredible artists have all left us their true labor of love. The secret, if there really is a secret behind this film's success, is everyone enjoyed each other's company and worked together as a family. You can tell, especially Judy Garland's comments that she found it strange to be so afraid of the Wicked Witch, Margaret Hamilton, because she was such a nice lady. That's family.
Get the remastered blu ray dvd, as it is something to truly treasure.

I'd forgotten from my childhood just how good this film was / is!
Watched it with my 7 year old who just loved it too and said it was amazing.
What a very clever and imaginative film / production....especially for it's time.
The film feels just the right amount of running time. The songs are wonderfully simple but catchy, cute and perfectly fitting to the film.
Judy Garland plays lead role amazingly and has great, well chosen actors around her.
Beautifully done all round. A magical tale full of everything a film should have. Everyone should watch this film. Young or old. You won't be disappointed!

As a child, I first saw The Wizard of Oz on television when I was six years old and fell in love with it and have loved it ever since. The special effects of this movie hold up to this day. That is absolutely amazing! I have never ever grown tired of watching it. I now have lost count how many times I've watched this truly WONDROUS film!
Have also read books on making of the beloved and iconic MGM film The Wizard of Oz. The Wizard of Oz: The Official 50th Anniversary Pictorial History by John Fricke, Jay Scarfone, William Stillman, The Wizard Of Oz: The Official 75th Anniversary Companion, The Making of The Wizard of Oz by Aljean Harmetz and Margaret Hamilton, The Munchkins of Oz by Stephen Cox.
And none of the information that I have read on the making of the film by reading these many books have detracted from my loving it.
The Wizard of Oz is as visually exciting and emotionally stirring today just like the first time during its release in movie theatres in 1939. It's the most famous and beloved family movie of all time.
A stellar cast featuring Judy Garland, Bert Lahr, Jack Haley, Ray Bolger, Margaret Hamilton, Terry the dog, and many others. With an enchanting score that brings the magical characters and the story to life, as the audience is swept away on Dorothy's journey over the rainbow. Every journey along the yellow brick road has creativity and whimsy that will pluck at your heartstrings.
The cinematography is simply WONDERFUL. Judy Garland emanates a delightful innocence as Dorothy that perfectly matches the film's tone, and the Wicked Witch of the West is the quintessential fantasy villain.
The Wizard of Oz deftly embeds moral messages into its enchanting story, allowing its audience to fully join Dorothy on her journey of awakening
The film is still firmly stamped into contemporary popular culture. The best evidence that it will forever endure the test of time.
We're off the see the Wizard! The Wonderful Wizard of Oz!

"The Wizard of Oz" is one of the most remembered and beloved films of all time. From his moving story of overcoming and self-acceptance perfectly outlined by L. Frank Baum to technical-artistic innovations, Victor Fleming's work does not seem to age. Even contemporary filmmakers, especially those who dare to venture into the world of fantasy, seek references from the classic feature film, remodeling them in an attempt to bring them closer to the new generations. However, its timelessness is perhaps one of its greatest attributes - after all, who doesn't know the story of Dorothy, the ruby slippers, the feared sorcerer of the Emerald City and the flying monkeys? Of course, restricting oneself only to narrative devices is falling into common sense; after all, the plot that unfolds goes far beyond what the eyes can see.
One of Victor Fleming's great assets was the characterization of two totally different worlds. Dorothy feels trapped in a cyclical routine in Kansas, and her arrival in a totally unfamiliar place is reason for a compulsory, but justified, enchantment. Therefore, it is almost instantaneous to notice why the director opted for sepia in reality and technicolor in the fantastic, in the supernatural - and I come to say that the skills of the artistic team far surpass the failed attempts to bring color to the big screen. Based on this dual principle, the scenic narrative maintains a balance between the old and the new (for the time), in addition to creating a hybrid trend that would be revisited decades later. Even if in the eyes of today's audience, the sets are quite artificial and the special effects somewhat naive, it is impressive to see what was done in a feature film shot in the late 30's of the last century. The make-up, although harmful to the health of the actors, is of an incredible quality, transforming talented performers into scarecrows, tin men, lions and hideous witches. The art direction is a show apart, with scenarios created with great care, showing us in a sublime way how magical and colorful that place is. It helps a lot that the first few scenes of the film feature a beautiful sepia, marking the difference between Kansas and Oz.
Summarizing "The Wizard of Oz" in "there's no place like home" is too reductive, not to mention silly. Reductionist, because it ignores the various subtexts to focus exclusively on the expressed text; silly, because it makes no sense that Dorothy prefers an oppressive reality symbolized by sepia-toned photography to a fantastic and happy universe that explores what Technicolor was beginning to offer. The Land of the Munchkins is brightly colored, full of joy, and makes Dorothy a hero (since she would have killed the Wicked Witch of the East). Thus, it makes no sense to read the text in this shallow way. The idea of the protagonist's transition makes sense, but there is much more to be interpreted.
In the first act, a preliminary lesson: there will always be troubles to be faced. Dorothy leaves Kansas thanks to one of her wishes, she wants to go over the rainbow because their problems melt away and dreams come true. That's what she says in the very powerful Leitmotiv "Over the Rainbow", rocked by the smooth voice of a Judy Garland still at the beginning of her brilliant career. The fantastic place where she goes may have the colors and joys she wanted, but it's not without adversity, as the Wicked Witch of the West soon appears.
Afterwards, the message is that the journey is much better in the company of friends. The Scarecrow (Ray Bolger), the Tin Man (Jack Haley) and the Cowardly Lion (Bert Lahr) show up to help Dorothy on her walk - and their characterization, in terms of makeup and costume, is simply superb, standing out the second because the actor reveals himself attentive to a body language compatible with the physical limitations of the character - and so that it also helps them. The four-want magic to achieve their goals, acquiring elements they don't have. With their union (and a little help from the kind Witch of the North), the obstacles brought by the Wicked Witch of the West are overcome.
It is in the third act that they meet the Magician, when there are two narrative dismemberments. The first is the ratification of a past message, that the supernatural (including the divine) does not exist. The Wizard is as much of a charlatan as Professor Marvel, simply because magic and deities exist only in the imagination. The god shaped by religions, the one to whom personal yearnings are directed, simply does not exist. Wishes can come true, but not by a divine grant. It is necessary - and here comes the second lesson of the third act - to believe and trust in oneself, because all people have the virtues that they believe they do not have. Therefore, the power of belief should not be directed towards an imaginary immaterial being (god-God), but towards oneself. Self-confidence is stronger than it may seem.
Supporting the interpretation according to which "The Wizard of Oz" conveys the idea that god does not exist are small subliminal messages, such as the tree scene and a questioning offered by Dorothy - without forgetting the moment when the Wizard is unmasked by Toto. In the first case, when the protagonist tries to pluck apples from the trees to feed herself, the fruits are soon forgotten, as if they had no relevance. It is enough to associate apples with the biblical meaning of temptation to conclude that, from the point of view of the feature, the religious text is disposable. Later, when Dorothy is told that no one has ever seen the Wizard of Oz, she herself has the wit to question how they know he exists. Through impressive bucolic settings for its time, director Victor Fleming makes "The Wizard of Oz" an imagery spectacle. The contrast between Kansas and Oz would be enough to convey the visual richness conceived in the literary work, but the symbolism of the parable, combined with Garland's formidable performance in the lead role, are some of the elements that make this a priceless and timeless film. In short, this is its magic.
To attribute "The Wizard of Oz" to being a simple work of fantastic fiction is to commit an unforgivable mistake. Fleming not only prints his perspective on Baum's novel, but also recovers its critical elements. Written in 1900, the rise of a powerful and feared force is a reflection of imperialist governments imposing their will on minorities - in this case, the abusive relationship between the Witch and the munchkins. The appearance of an ethereal and "intangible" force arises with Glinda (Billie Burke), the Good Witch of the South, and advocates an imminent change in the authoritarian configurations of Oz. After all, from what we can gather, it is Dorothy who brings what is necessary to depose the Wicked Witch of the West and reveal the real intentions of the Wizard (Frank Morgan), a charlatan who assumed this role to deceive and gain the respect of the population of Esmeralda. Bringing these elements to the end of the 1930s is also burdensome, as the time was ripe for the growth of extremist movements, including Nazi-fascism, and for the onset of World War II.
The feature also brings technical innovations, as already mentioned. The use of vibrant colors and competent art direction is just icing on the cake; mention should be made of the scenic dexterity with which Fleming leads the narrative with exquisite mastery, creating choreographies that are not limited to the visual plane, but extend to their respective causes and consequences. The frames bring aesthetic refinement and resemble neo-romantic paintings, scrutinized by excessive and involving fantasy. By the way, it is not by chance that the film's special effects represent a considerable leap for the niche in question, from the use of hundreds of costumes to the meticulous makeup. Indeed, some sequences are unforgettable. Whether in Garland's rendition of "Over the Rainbow", crowned with the Oscar for Best Original Song, or in the phrase that summarizes the entire scope of the work, countless constructions were reused over time and, despite not having reached the same success than the original, serve as beautiful and simple tributes to one of the greatest films of all time. And as the credits roll on screen, it's hard not to get emotional. In the end, only one thing is certain: there is no place like home.
In the cast, Judy Garland is simply adorable as young Dorothy, even at an advanced age for the role - the actress was 16 years old when she recorded her participation, playing a child character. Her sweetness in her eyes and her words easily convinced the audience that this could be the perfect Dorothy, even more so with such a remarkable performance in (Somewhere) Over the Rainbow right at the beginning of the film. For the film to win over the viewer, it is necessary for him to believe in the journey of the characters and Garland does a magnificent job as little Dorothy in front of the cast, which also has great performances - especially the affected Lion played by Bert Lahr.
The production is full of behind-the-scenes legends, including director changes - the first, Richard Thorpe, was fired 12 days after filming began, George Cukor lasted only 3 days, Victor Fleming took over for four months and left to direct "... Gone with the wind" and King Vidor finished the feature - The Wizard of Oz is not for nothing one of the greatest classics of cinema, awarded with Oscars for Soundtrack and Original Song, the famous "Over the Rainbow", almost cut by the producers who they thought she was "pessimistic".
"The Wizard of Oz" is one of those productions that will never lose the interest of the public, conquering viewers of all ages for its ingenuity and charisma when telling a story of universal appeal.

In the past, "The Wizard of Oz" was a very expensive film (budget 2.7 + million dollars), which could not immediately justify its costs at the box office. However, for future generations, this film became truly popular and was of great importance - its popularity skyrocketed in the 1950s thanks to the annual Christmas broadcasts on television. Judy Garland, whose wonderful performance as Dorothy attracted attention, became a real star thanks to this film.
The story is probably known to everyone. The heroine of the fairy tale, hiding from a sudden tornado, finds herself in her room and is magically transported to a country where she is met by funny midgets, a beautiful fairy and the sister of an evil witch, whom she accidentally crushed with her house. An evil witch is going to deal with the girl. And then the adventure begins with the famous yellow brick road, interesting friends, including a Scarecrow without brains, a Lion that is afraid of everyone and everything, as well as an Iron Woodcutter who dreams of finding a heart. The picture has a pretty enough visual range for its time, as well as pleasant songs. Well, "Over the Rainbow" became a true hit, besides taking the Oscar statuette for Best Song.
The film was created with a very careful attention to detail. This is especially noticeable when you view the picture decades after its release. The creators paid attention to many details so that the audience would have no doubts. This fairy tale is really a real story. And if adults are aware that this is only a movie, then it will be difficult to deceive young viewers who are the main target audience of the project, leaving some kind of fake both in the surrounding locations and objects, and in the game of the cast. And the development team coped with the task perfectly.
Today, "The Wizard of Oz" is a classic with a capital letter. An amazing adventure into a fairy-tale world with its own laws, interesting events and a great history of friendship and support. This project has become important, in my opinion, for many generations of children who have managed to see a gorgeous film adaptation of the world-famous story of the writer Lyman Frank Baum. The picture gives you the opportunity to enjoy vivid adventures, memorable songs and dances, as well as to understand what true devotion and friendship mean.
8 out of 10.

I'd pop a warning on this for the youngster of today or parents who tread carefully what their kids watch.
This film is an annual tradition for me, my mum took me to see as a kid, and watching on the big screen was amazing, but I was tiny.
If someone could add 3D to it, wow it'd be amazing.
It is very dated of course, but, beautifully filmed, I've been lucky enough to visit the castle where it was filmed in Bavaria, the scenery is pretty amazing.
It is very British eccentric and made in a time when not so many things were 'tiptoed' around, like The Sound of Music, it has some scary dark elements, some dark, almost gothic like tale.
Also, some very silly, funny songs and slapstick. When you think about how old it is and how all the stunts and filming were done without special effects, the car alone is a feat of amazing engineering.
I defy any adult not to enjoy this film, not sure how many kids would be interested in it now, as it's a rather unusual film really, it makes me realise how different things are now for kids.

Never re-create a movie like this, it is timeless, it is perfect.
I was born in 1999 and I remember watching this over and over again, I love the music, the setting, the cars, it's amazing. The acting is very good and truly having nothing to complain about.
Chitty Chitty Bang Bang is a timeless movie, no movie producer should ever touch. Just leave this magnificent piece to live on as it originally is.
My children will be watching this in the future as I did. It's a fun movie for all ages old and young, and a nostalgic feeling for us to re-watch decades later.
I just hope the movie industry does not do what they seem to have been doing with many other good classic movies and re-create it. There is no need. Stop touching out favourite movies. Chitty Chitty is perfect just as it is, as are other movies of it's time.

If I chose to be sarcastic, I would claim that the best thing about this movie is that Dick Van Dyke doesn't do a British accent -- indeed, that was one of the conditions under which he took the job. That would be unfair. Certainly, Albert Broccoli and his team worked to produce as good a musical as was being produced in America at the time. They hired Van Dyke, and they tried to get Julie Andrews. They hired the Sherman brothers to write the songs, which are pretty good (except I despise as lazy the title song). They got Roald Dahl to do the screenplay; if anyone understood the darkness at the heart of childhood and how to write about it, it was he.\nUnfortunately, they then handed it to Ken Hughes to direct, and he could direct trained adult actors and action scenes, but not children. In the end, they spent lots of money, which is on the screen, to produce a road show musical, just as the genre was going stale. While it did well at the box office, its immense costs made it a failure, so they didn't try again. As a result, the movie musical, like the cartoon, entered a dead period from which it, unlike the cartoon, has yet to really recover.\nLooking at it today, it's quite obviously too long. There's lots of wasted luxury casting, like Lionel Jeffries, Benny Hill, and Sally Ann Howes. While I haven't a single complaint to make about any individual scene or sequence, it goes on too long at 144 minutes, and like many an almost-perfect souflee, collapses on arrival.

Chitty Chitty Bang Bang is a film I saw as a child, and since my first viewing, I have loved it ever since!
Being a big fan of Ian Fleming as a writer and novelist, I suppose it was no surprise when I found myself watching this movie over and over again.
A lot like the James Bond franchise, which he created, Fleming also managed to write this fantasy film involving a larger than life plot, beautiful locations, memorable dialogue, and iconic characters, which was now suitable for adults and children to watch and enjoy.
I understood from my mother, who was only 5 years old when this film came out in 1968, that the child catcher was a subject of controversy as he was deemed too scary for children. My mother being one of them. I understand how the film has a divided audience because of its edgier theme in the second have of the film, however, in my opinion, the film is fun, catchy, memorable and one I will always hold dear to my heart.

(1968) Chitty Chitty Bang Bang
CHILDREN/ MUSICAL/ FANTASY
Loosely based on a novel by Ian Fleming co-written and directed by Ken Hughes, owners of the James Bond franchise by the name of Albert R. Broccoli decided to produce this very pretentious musical/ fantasy about eccentric inventor Potts (Dick Van Dyke) many failed attempts to become wealthy by one of his inventions, leading to one invention after the other, whose always impressing his two small children.
Liked this film when I was a kid and I still liked this now, catchy song numbers, dancing is fine and the situations Although absurd is obviously intended to be nothing more than a kids movie one can get from a kid's book- I don't anything wrong with that.

I've loved this movie for decades. Yet it's only in this latest visit that I finally noticed and found myself utterly charmed by Anna Quayle's performance. How did I miss this? I rewatched about a half dozen times her duet with Gert Frobe, a dance in which he's repeatedly trying to kill her and she's largely oblivious. Her physicality and subtleness of voice and expression is a joy to behold. Especially the moment she's almost impaled from above lying on the table as some doubt about her husband's affections dawns upon her.\nShe's never singled out, if even mentioned, in the reviews I've read. Just want to express my appreciation even if the critics won't.

This was never my favourite musical as child, but as I get older I think I appreciate it more. Sure, it has it's cheesy moments, but there is genuine chemistry between the characters on display here and coupled with some superbly catchy - and often poignant - lyrics from the Sherman twins, we are presented with a really quite enjoyable fable. The Potts family live in a dilapidated farmhouse. Grandfather (Lionel Jeffries); the well meaning but hopeless inventor of a father "Caractacus" (Dick Van Dyke) and the two children "Jeremy" (Adrian Hall) and "Jemima" (Heather Ripley). Luckily, one day the youngsters are nearly run over by "Truly" (Sally Ann Howes) the daughter of the wealthy confectioner "Lord Scrumptious" (James Robertson Justice). She might just be able to help the father make a few quid from her father with his sweets that double up as pan pipes. Meantime, the family manage to rescue an old rust bucket from the local garage, and lo and behold, enter our eponymous vehicle. It can drive, it can become an aeroplane, an hovercraft - indeed it can do just about everything bar make the tea. It's a must-have prize for the megalomaniac child-hater "Baron Bomburst" (Gert FrÃ¶be - who really does enter into the spirit of the story), so the family must fight tooth and nail to stop their car, and themselves, falling into his malevolent hands. Ian Fleming demonstrates great imagination with this and Van Dyke shows off his varied skills well and engagingly. Howes over-cooks her singing at times, but the almost 2Â½ hours this story takes really does fly by. The Oscar winning "Chitty Chitty Bang Bang"; the delightful "Hushabye Mountain"; "Me Ol' Bamboo" and Jeffries' enjoyable rendition of "Posh!" as he is gradually drowned in his outhouse all add bundles to this colourful and joyous series of well photographed escapades. Maybe it is wasted on youngsters? It certainly was on me!

When I told a friend that I was soon going to watch this for the first time, he half-jokingly warned that the more one watches, the less it makes sense. That remark bears more truth to it than I could have supposed, for this is an unending stream of such wild fancy that it splits the divide between pure imagination and straight-up fever dream. This is never more true than with the incredibly lighthearted, fleet-footed songs of Richard M. And Robert B. Sherman, and the impeccable, wondrous choreography of Marc Breaux and Dee Dee Wood, but that same duality comes across in pretty much every last regard. The incredible filming locations are made to feel rather whimsical themselves, aided to that end in light of production design and art direction that really seem to adopt the ethos of "if you can dream it, we'll find a way to include it." This also goes for the wide-ranging frivolity of the costume design, and the terrific hair and makeup; every stunt, visual effect, sound effect, and fabricated conjuration looks great at the same time that it's often a little bewildering. And still we're just scraping the surface of everything 'Chitty Chitty Bang Bang' represents, and as if to emphasize the point - what a name!
For everything that fills these two and one-half hours, there's weirdly not that much plot in it. At the same time, at almost exactly the halfway mark it's like a switch has been flipped, taking us from considerable content with minimal substance, to total cartoonish silliness. This is more curious still when one realizes that the original book was written by James Bond creator Ian Fleming, the screenplay was adapted by director Ken Hughes (also associated with strange 1967 disaster 'Casino Royale') with children's book author and notorious bigot Roald Dahl - and that Albert R. Broccoli, who was behind so much of Eon Productions' 007 franchise, also produced this, with a cast including Gert FrÃ¶be (Goldfinger), Desmond Llewelyn (Q), and Benny Hill (he of "Yakkety sax" fame). And still, Hughes' orchestration of every shot and scene, and Christopher Challis' cinematography, similarly embrace that same spirit of unbridled fun while at once also being stupendously smart and delicious in and of themselves. Not to be outdone, Irwin Kostal penned a score (informed by the Shermans' tunes) that's perfectly light and cheerful over every scene in which the cast give wholehearted performances of unyielding merriment and zest.
'Chitty Chitty Bang Bang' is unremitting in its extravagant ridiculousness, a cavalcade of one gag and bit after another. Yet like The Beatles' surrealist quasi-nightmare 'Yellow submarine,' it's that complete immersion in the inane that allows this to work; add a tinge of sincerity to provide an almost indifferent anchor, and the stage is set for this to be whatever it wants. Irreverent as it all is, however, every last element is guided toward the same ends, and the result is nothing less than fabulous. Everyone involved in the production turned in truly outstanding work across the board, and that includes the screenplay. Where the movie decides to have a plot, it's written with sharp intelligence; where the movie insists on just having a good time, whatever that may mean, the scene writing is robust and superbly detailed, and the rest of the craftsmanship follows suit without fail. At all points the dialogue and characters are astoundingly colorful and varied in accordance with the need of a tale in which anything goes. And so it is on down the line from start to finish, as in one way or another the feature is just a boundless bounty of bounding, bouncing, buoyant joy, realized with only utmost care and skill.
I fully expected to enjoy this, based not just on its reputation but on the strong recommendation of everyone with whom I'd ever discussed it. And still I'm ever so pleased at what a delight the film turned out to be; there are few points of comparison for a title that's so utterly resolute in its assumption of every conceivable pinch of far-flung tomfoolery. Naturally Dick Van Dyke and Sally Ann Howes curry the most favor given their prominence, but everyone in the cast and crew, and indeed everyone who participated in the work's creation, are to be congratulated for whipping up such an extraordinary, enduring, impressively enthusiastic and unfaltering flight of fancy. Given such unwavering commitment to so offbeat and preposterous an affair I can understand how this won't necessarily appeal to all - but the fact unquestionably remains that 'Chitty Chitty Bang Bang' is so absolutely, wonderfully entertaining in every regard that I'd be hard-pressed not to give a blanket recommendation. This is a tremendous, almost unparalleled classic that never feels as long as its two and one-half hours, and is worth far more than that. More than 50 years later it continues to be an exquisite marvel, and when all is said and done it's simple a must-see. Bravo!

Chitty Chitty Bang Bang tells the tale a creator who is always inventing interesting, but not always practical or necessary, or overcomplicated things and a flying/swimming car is just one of his many inventions. There are a couple tuneful and memorable songs and musical numbers. There is also one of the creepiest characters to be found in any children's film in the form of the Child Catcher, brilliantly portrayed Roger Helpmann. There are all kinds of odd and unique supporting characters throughout. The film does seem to meander quite a bit at times and weakens this film which could have been greatly improved with the help of some prudent editing, perhaps 10-15 minutes worth. Either way, it's still a fun film to check out if you haven't yet done so.

I enjoyed this movie Chitty Chitty Bang Bang day after Thanksgiving holiday - every year each holiday weekend. I remember- We would watch it every year together as a family. I have shared this movie with my kids but we were able to get the movie in VHS and could watch through out the year many times. My kids enjoyed the movie as much as we did growing up. The children catcher can be a little scary for very young children but as I said we watched as a family do the kids understood that it was a character on a movie. My kids will be sharing with their children as well.\nI highly recommend this as a wonderful family movie!

Although I have a few things I think it could be improved, like some specific parts where the scene cuts seemed a little bit rushed and even the plot transition that I honestly don't remember how it was done in the past in the original since I watched many years ago, I have to say that the music scenes were really masterfully crafted, well deserved for a Disney production celebrating 30th anniversary of this classic masterpiece of the classic cinema.
The music that happens in the dinner room specifically totally surprised me for the color, the very complex integration between the dish characters and all the lighting and camera movements that was soooo soo soooo pleasing to watch!
People always complain about casting and stuff, and that always can be reasonable, but I'm particularly satisfied with the casting selection and the actors.
So I think 8 is a fair rating in my opinion.

My daughters loved this, so the rating is mostly based on their reaction.\nHowever, for my part, it's a worthy retelling of a classic children's story with amazing sets & costumes. The CGI was well done & the actors did their part. The Beast was intimidating but not terrifying, so our 5 year old was able to watch it with her older sister. The wolves were probably the scariest part of the movie, but even our young one didn't duck behind her blanket for them. The casting of Belle was spot on. Ewan McGregor proved, once again, that he can shine in a musical & Luke Evans was an excellent Gaston.\nWell done Disney.

While the movie is a remake on the original and have a couple of differences with it, I really think it's a pretty great remake. The movie itself looks great with its set design and cinematography that goes with it. It really makes the movie looks beautiful on how they executed it. The story is basically the same with a couple of differences to it and I do think it done really well. I also like the casting of the movie which they did a pretty great job on the roles they were given. Emma Watson as Bella is a decent choice, but she isn't the best actress in the movie. I also think the songs are done really well and the singing is great in the movie. Now, the CGI of the movie is something that I have mixed thoughts about. The new design for the characters falls between looking pretty good to not looking impressive at all due to how they design them. As for the beast, I do like this new design for him and does have details on him.

This film are nothing like the original, in a bad way. The added scenes are bad, and do nothing for the film. I do not like any of the live action disney films. I wished they make the live action the same as the originals.
This film and the singing is rally bad! I needed a pilliow everytime they started singing. CRINGE!
And the voice for the clock! Can not just use the voice of gandalv. It feels so wrong!
I do not like the actors either.
It is so sad they feel they have to change the classics. It feels like they think they have to make it so much more fantastical.
Do not change what is already perfect.

From the very beginning, Beauty and the Beast captivates the audience with its stunning visuals, expertly crafted set designs, and elaborate costumes. The picturesque French village and the grandeur of Beast's castle are brought to life in a way that immerses viewers into the magical world of Belle (Emma Watson) and the Beast (Dan Stevens).
Emma Watson's portrayal of Belle is captivating, as she brings a modern and independent twist to the character. She embodies Belle's intelligence, kindness, and unwavering spirit, making her an incredibly relatable and empowering role model for today's generation.
Dan Stevens brilliantly embodies the tortured and misunderstood Beast, conveying his inner conflict between anger and vulnerability. The chemistry between Watson and Stevens is palpable, making their evolving relationship feel truly heartfelt and sincere.
The film's all-star supporting cast is equally impressive, with standout performances by Luke Evans as Gaston, the narcissistic antagonist, and Josh Gad as LeFou, Gaston's loyal but conflicted sidekick. These characters bring a perfect balance of humor and depth to the story, adding an extra layer of entertainment.

Beauty and the Beast (2017), a spellbinding journey that breathes new life into a beloved tale as old as time. Emma Watson's portrayal of Belle is enchanting, bringing intelligence and warmth to the iconic character. The film editing dances gracefully through the enchanting sequences, seamlessly transitioning between the whimsy of the castle and the quaint charm of the village. The film's strength lies in its vibrant and nostalgic homage to the animated classic, with a cast that brings depth to the beloved characters. While the music tugs at the heartstrings, there are moments where the pacing feels a touch too swift, racing to keep up with the magic. Cinematography bathes the audience in a visually stunning world, from the grandeur of the Beast's castle to the lively spectacle of "Be Our Guest." At 7/10, Beauty and the Beast is a magical retelling that captures the spirit of the original while adding a touch of modern enchantment.

Ok, I get it, it's a musical, but man, there's waaay too much singing, which makes the movie kind of boring. It felt like they sang for like a good third of the movie, maybe even more, and honestly, the songs were kinda meh, dull and pointless.\nNow, the cast, ugh. Dan Stevens in the main male role? Seriously? He didn't give off any royal vibes. And in my opinion, he looked better as the hairy beast than as the prince.\nAnd let's talk about the film set - it was gloomy and kinda dull. And don't even get me started on the character makeup - it was just plain weird, ridiculous, or even hideous, I would say.

Cannot believe this updated version is just 6-years-old now. This movie feels like it came out 26 years ago.
Decided to finally have an open-mind on the Disney Cash Grab Remakes of the already-masterpieces they made decades ago. Kinda sorry I did, even though this movie is serviceable. Not great or even very good. It's definitely nothing I'd ever want to see again.
The original's near perfect, in fact, I can find very little flaws. While I love 1989's The Little Mermaid more, any argument can be made why 1991's Beauty & the Beast is superior. I mean, Belle, what an incredible character and so unselfish. I loved every bit of the 1991 version and there's a very valid reason it was the first animated movie to be nominated for best picture.
This updated version is just okay, I mean I didn't hate it despite the poor CGI, creepy "inanimate" characters, Emma Watson butchering my favorite Disney song, "Belle" and the terrible new songs that padded the already-too-long runtime. This 2017 version felt VERY Community Theatre and made me lighten up for the performances, as if they were actors in a neighborhood theatre pouring their hearts out.
WHY do these remakes have to be ONE FULL HOUR longer when the stories are essentially the same? Yes, as mentioned, they add in cringe new songs, but other than that, I don't know why they subject us to mediocrity for even longer than necessary.
The only character I liked was the updated LeFou and believe me, I've been in his longing-for-who-you'll-never-get shoes. At least I had someone to root for and was pleased with how his arc played out.
I wish I could say I didn't regret seeing the 2017 take, but I kinda do. Everything was flat, dark and no one could hold a LumiÃ¨re to the original. Skip this.
***
Final Thoughts: Really sorry this made a ton of money so Disney could open the floodgates to more embarrassing shot-by-shot "live" action meh remakes. Unless you have a complete reimagining, such as Maleficent or Cruella, I wish they wouldn't bother.
(2017 version: 4/10 Stars, 1991 version: 10/10 Stars.)

I saw this for the first time yesterday. I loved it. So do my Grandchildren. I just don't understand why so many people are complaining about the actors and the show. Do they understand it is a CHILDREN'S SHOW. The acting was wonderland well done. The singing was fine for kids to hear. I think the actors were so good at being who they were supposed to play. The filming was brilliant. I also thought the gay guy was funny and wonderful, so did my grandchildren. Was so surprise there were so many complaints from adults. Not realising that this is just a children's fun Disney Movie, my grandchildren keep saying how it is their favourite Movie.

I've never watched the original movie but this is very beautiful, the character Emma Watson is very suitable for playing Belle, and the other characters are also very iconic like in the original film so I think this is good and successful in remaking, even though I haven't watched the original but I know the story and it's repackaged nicely in this movie.
A movie like this that disney has to make if they want to remake a story, is very beautiful and very touching.
I just watched it after 6 years of its official release in theaters, and I think it's still very cool.
I hope the next remake movie will be like this or even more, good job disney.

movieName: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
content: Adapted and based on the fourth Harry Potter book "The Goblet of Fire" is absolutely no disappointment! It's the fourth year at Hogwarts, and Harry, Ron and Hermione returns as the iconic and unstoppable trio that every Harry Potter fan loves to watch every time. This time, Hogwarts school of Witchcraft and Wizardry is getting a slight update this year. Because now, three schools are settled in together to fight each other in an epic tournament, with challenges to complete, and a great quest to finish and represent their school in honour and loyalty. This film doesn't just develop the main story greatly, but it makes small side stories to have something interesting too watch all the time. The conflict with the great and almighty Voldemort is still out there, and they did some really good and terrible scenes too represent his cruelty (Especially something we can notice in the opening scene). Hogwarts territory's are explored much more than ever in the fourth instalment, for example the lake, new areas and so. Harry Potter played by Daniel Radcliffe is showed now as a troubled, unsure and scared boy, that clearly can feel new problems coming, was great! His performance was much stronger and darker in here, his role was settled on a different level, as well as his friends, Ron and Hermione, performed by Rupert Grint and Emma Watson. Rector Dumbledore was also a character that came more in and out, but was clearly better included compared to "Prisoner of Azkaban". The new teachers are always something cool and interesting, and it was once again fun too watch them in action. Speaking of action, amazing action sequences! Great camera filming, scenography, visual effects, and build-up with great suspense. Unexpected turns and uses of camera that hasn't been used in Harry Potter before, like underwater scenes and so. The music by Patrick Doyle isn't that iconic compared to the themes by John Williams, but it's rememberable and overall well written. In the end, The Goblet of Fire was entertaining, dark, mysterious and so far the best one!

movieName: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
content:
I don't recollect the last time I have seen this movie, but probably it wasn't dubbed. I took the change with my oldest son, as his age almost matches PG's requirements and we took the journey together and it was a marvelous one - maybe it the end of it he would, finally, touch the books themselves.
Harry's bunch is starting to face teenagers' stuff, boys are noticing girls, hormones are bursting out and you can see envy and competition as part of their day to day activities. Even Hermione is not reacting as her usual self to some of the situations. Clearly is reflected properly by young Emma Watson.
