At this movie we got another two brilliant British stars as Brendan Gleeson and David Tennant joined the cast and provided brilliant performances. Another two young and promising actors has joined for a one-time performance: Robert Pattinson and ClÃ©mence PoÃ©sy, I got the feeling we will hear about them in the near future.
The rest of the cast stayed the same and the plot became darker and more mature, as for the young love stories of the main characters. At the end of this film I could not say or remember if I ever though that one of Harry Potter's films are not great, from what I see until now, it seems that none of the movies is less then fantastic.
It holds for all the runtime, made with beautiful cinematography and is a visually treat, though this one is at the dark and dark water, for some of it. The musical score is epic and the actors we grew up with, turns into young adult and talented actors, through out of the movies. Cant find any reasons not to be almost fully satisfied.

movieName: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
content: A superb entry in the Harry Potter franchise. The film explores a great range of emotions in our characters as they continue to mature. The tone is dark tone yet mixed in with some comic relief too. Bleaker, greyer, skies and a cooler blue outdoor colour palette hint at troubled times on the horizon for our gang. Cracks start to appear in the friendship between characters only to be strengthened later on. The sense of threat towards Harry increases too in this film, in the first couple it seems Harry might be hurt during his adventures, adventures that he himself chooses. In this film however it seems danger is out to find Harry, to put it simply somebody wants him dead, and you don't need much imagination to imagine who. The film is set almost exclusively inside Hogwarts which I thought worked well. The casting of Brendan Gleeson was also in my opinion an inspired choice.

movieName: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
content:
Harry and his friends are now young ladies and gentlemen. An international Quidditch event is taking place. To get there one has to use a port key (an innocuous-looking device that transports one to a different location). Things did not go as well as planned and now a dark element has been added.
Also, this year is the tri-wizard tournament in which a hero from each of three learning institutes must compete in unknown events. This is to promote friendship among the institutes. The opportunity is open to only potential contestants of seventeen years. They must enter his/her name into the goblet of fire for selection. So, you can imagine everyone's surprise to find fourteen-year-old Harry's name in the Goblet. How did his name get in the goblet? Will Harry accept the challenge? And if so, how will he fair?
We get to see all the characters for the book come to life. Most of the relevant story is included. Among the parts that were left out, I was hoping for the Blast-Ended Skrewts and the male wizard wearing the dress to get plenty of air around his private parts.
The series of Harry films has also matured with each rendition. It took several tries, some better than others, but this one has the feel of the book and even with the short time it plays shows the real feel of the ongoing story of the struggle between Harry and him, who must not be named. This includes the larger picture of more than just good versus evil.

movieName: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
content: It is a phantasy play. You mean sometimes book is as film given. Story is phantastical in showing possible(!) ways of muggles and magic things. Harry taken to write down his own fail was hard to see. For me as an adult. She a horror by knowing her in another eay cause she is an actor. Action hard with life. But it is a special with the non muggled way. The way harry got waldemord costs long distance. This given away special magic stick cause it was not harry or not the right person. The slave given a sock changes his mind. It could do so. Phantasy good. Must not be in teal life. Bit it is am entertainment.

movieName: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
content: "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire" (2005) receives a bewitching 4 stars from me, largely for its ability to blend teenage angst with dragon-taming antics in a way that makes puberty seem like a walk in the Forbidden Forest. The film introduces the Triwizard Tournament, a magical competition so intense it makes the SATs look like a game of bingo. Harry, our bespectacled hero, finds himself mysteriously entered into this tournament, and let's just say it's more pressure than finding a date to the Yule Ball.\nDirector Mike Newell deserves a tip of the Sorting Hat for balancing the dark, impending doom of Lord Voldemort's return with the light-hearted, hormone-fueled drama of Hogwarts' students. The highlight? The underwater sequence where Harry grows gills and attempts to save his friends, proving that even in the wizarding world, high school is still about popularity contests and saving face - or in this case, saving Ron's face.\nThe film, however, isn't without its flaws. The pacing zips through important plot points faster than a Firebolt, leaving non-book readers to puzzle over details like "Who is Barty Crouch Jr. And why does he twitch like that?" But overall, "Goblet of Fire" casts a charming spell, complete with teenage wizards, temperamental dragons, and dance floor disasters. It's a magical ride through adolescence, with just a touch of life-threatening peril - because what's high school without a little existential dread?

movieName: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
content: Definitely a step-down from the previous one but I feel like it's not that deep. The structure and the visual elements are not that sophisticated but it's not that bad. I feel like this one is the most enjoyable, given its "light" tone and the change on a story level from the previous three with the Triwizard tournament and the introduction of new characters, adapting that tone to the growth of our characters and us as an audience. This one will always be a confort film for me; as I was younger I used to truly feel and love - I still do - the romantic tone of this one; and the devastating effects that love had on our grown up characters, somehow reflecting myself in those fights and dreamy, romantic scenarios of Hogwarts on Christmas's Eve.

movieName: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
content: I haven't read the books because I don't want to base my opinion on a comparison to them. This movie was amazing, different from the first 2 movies, but amazing. I hate reading "reviews" where the only thing they talk about is how different the movies are from the books, and you should avoid them too. It's impossible to make a movie based on a 750 page book and keep it under 4 hours long unless you skip over some parts. If you want the whole story read the books, if you want to see magical stuff and still follow Harry Potter's story in Hogwarts from a cinematic perspective, then watch the film, it's awesome.\nI give this a 9/10 only because I always thought I'd see more of Ron and Hermione in the films, but that kind of faded away after the second one. Also not much of Draco Malfoy as I was expecting. Although that's not cause of a bad film or story, but because of my flash expectations, it still took a little bit of magic from my experience. The other thing that I didn't like was how dark the movie was, although it's understandable and it suits the story that we follow in this film, I always thought of the Wizarding World as something more cheerful, colorful and magical in a different way, but again, that's my wrong image of HP before watching it.\nI'm really excited to watch the 5th one and the rest of the movies. Already feeling kinda sad that it's gonna end for me soon. I want to live in the Wizarding World myself!

movieName: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
content: However, I cannot forgive the movie for neglecting the emotional care for other characters. Of course, please rest assured that I will not talk about the Malfoy father and son here, but rather characters who are more qualified and qualified to receive care than them, such as the Crouch father and son, Qiu, Krum and Furong, and Professor Snape. Except for the touching father son confrontation before the death of Old Crouch, these people are basically all reduced to black and white backgrounds. I really know that the pursuit of a perfect image of supporting role is like asking Draco to perform "Fall Like an Angel" in the Goblet of Fire. But sometimes one or two seconds of concentration can make the artistic conception suddenly high. At this moment, I miss Alfonso's "prisoner". Although I don't think he was as successful in character design as Newell, he was able to capture the moment of human nature with a brief lens, thus creating a realm of human nature. I particularly like the scene where Lupin reminisces about Lily for Harry in the air corridor, beautiful and sad, highlighting the vicissitudes of the werewolf experience and the heartbreaking life of his own generation; Then, for the first time, Sirius saw Hogwarts Castle under the moon. In such a dangerous moment, he could stop with Harry and marvel at the beauty of his alma mater under the melodious music. Even if it was only a few seconds, it instantly enhanced the humanistic care flavor of the film, meaning a long and profound realm. In the Goblet of Fire, even the easy to play scenes of Crouch's father and son's hidden secrets and Old Diggory's loss of his beloved son are ignored in the film's rigid and rough progression. In addition, there is no haughty and arrogant hibiscus, as well as all the moments of human spirit that need to be discovered in the original work.

movieName: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
content:
Perhaps the best book so therefore possibly only one of 2 movies in the series (the other being Stone) to not actually improve on the book.
It's fun though. The dark brooding tone feels more justified and there's a lot more of a plot to hang things on than the previous film.
Things seem pretty rushed of course but you soon acclimatize. It helps to just let go of some of the scenes from the book you hoped to see realized.
It gets very high-school drama complete with Christmas prom and he-likes-her-who-likes-him-who-likes-her vibe but I actually think that balances out the attempt at a gothic tone very nicely.

Prolific Actor and Occasional Director, John Flattery Takes the Helm in this Dark Comedy that has Unmistakable "Fargo" Vibes.
Actors John Hamm and Tina Fey Lead a Quirk-Character Cast of Misfits, Losers, Low-Life-Criminals, as an Awkward Coupling of Post-Marriage 30-Somethings.
He, with His Wife Passing, and She with a Divorce from a Dominating Husband (that She can't seem to avoid meeting-up with).
The Plot has the Mystery of 2 Murders, only Days Apart, Both Victims with the Name Maggie Moore.
Everyone in this Fictional Small Town is a Character Worthy of Sensationalized Paper-Back Fiction.
Exaggerated, Full of Colorful Quirks, Mostly a Step Slow with the Characters Designed to Entertain and Propel the Lurid Plot, Filled with Violence and Charmless Charm.
All of it is Designed a Step-Above Reality and that Design is What Could Place it in a Sub-Genre of Crime-Fiction, You Could Call...
"Cartoon-Crime-Fiction"
With its Tongue-In-Cheek Display of some Ultra-Violence by Dumb-as-Dirt Criminals who Take Turns Providing Outrageous, Surprising Laughs.
It's that Counterpart to the "Normal" or Usual Mystery, Drama, Romance, and Crime, Story that Sets the Type Apart.
Over-Reaching, as if On-Cue, to the Events that Causes these Folks to Over-React in a what at Times Seems Like Something Out of a Cartoon.
Coloring (outside the lines) and Can't Help but be Noticed by Everyone but Themselves.
A Style that is Not for Everyone, but Dark-Comedy, sometimes Called Black-Comedy, has a Legion of Fans.
They Love the Cult-Status that Makes these Movies a Different Experience from the Straight-Laced, Familiar, and Safe Movie Offerings that "Stays Within the Lines".
For those Fans, it's...
Worth a Watch
For Fans of the Traditional Take...
Not so Much.

This movie is a nice viewing on a popcorn and a movie kinda night. It starts off a bit slow and meandering. Cards are all laid out on the table, you're watching a decent murder investigation with no real questions because you already know what's going on. But the third act comes in hot with an OMG WTF that launches into a rather tense finale with some real stakes and a fairly satisfying ending.\nI think movies like this need support. It's okay to sit through a movie that isn't force feeding you "action" all the time. It's okay to let a movie marinate. It's okay to sit through the beats rather than constant jump cuts.\nThe language was a bit much for me. But overall, a decent independent movie at a time when Hollywood needs to return back to decent original movies.

What a pleasant surprise. This is one of those movies I usually hesitate to see because the poster and description don't really appeal to me and then I find out I wouldn't have wanted to miss out on it. I agree with the reviews, it is a breath of fresh air with dialogues to die for and much better than it looked. It has that kind of witty humor that makes you laugh in such a fun way, you can't help but like totally enjoy it. Some mentioned it's rather a slow burner, but I've watched a lot of slow burners - and I'm talking here only about the good ones since this movie definitely doesn't belong to the bad category, and those good slow burners were much slower than this one. In my opinion the pace was quite good because not once did it make me feel bored.\nLike I said, I totally enjoyed it, I mean like REALLY enjoyed it!! It's a movie you can watch twice in case you wanna share it with your friends and go with it a second time.

Pros: 1. Romance between Hamm and Fey. Great Chemistry here. Their relationship seemed pitch perfect for their age and personality. I would love to see them again in a rom-com. They seemed natural vs that latest yell match of a rom-com of Julia Roberts in her daughter's wedding. 2. I loved the views of my Sandia Mountains. The Sandia mountains loom over everything in ABQ, and they did a great job including them in the background of many of the scenes.\nCons: 1. Seemed like they tried to make a murder mystery in the Breaking Bad and Better Call Saul playbook. There are Scenes of funky architecture, dialogs inside crazy diners, murder in a 1950's era concrete apartment and another crime scene located out in the desert. Most of us from Albuquerque don't go to half these places. 2. Murder mystery? ...there was no mystery here. We know who killed who from the very beginning and so did most of the protagonists. Most reviewers mentioned that they tried to make a Cohen brothers/Fargo type story focusing on character development than mystery. 3. And lastly, an indian (from India) actor? I know there are Indians in NM, but I've lived here, worked here, and taught here most of my life and never met a single one. NM has the largest population of hispanic and native Americans and they couldn't find one to play the deputy or any other character? Some TV shows/movies go crazy with diversity, but not having a single Hispanic actor in a US Southwestern locale is like not having an Italian or African American actor in a NY scene.

I'm surprised so many reviews are saying this movie isn't good. It's exactly what it's billed as: a dark comedy. Jon Hamm and Tina Fey are fantastic in their roles. The other actors are wonderful and don't miss a beat. You never know what's gonna happen next, which is especially gratifying in the current film landscape of sequels and reboots. I enjoyed every strange, off-kilter moment of this, and the ending is pitch-perfect. A delightful film except for the inexcusable outcome for Deputy Reddy. If you like the Coen brothers' movies, you should connect with this - it very much strikes the same notes as Raising Arizona and Fargo - lots of death and deadpan characters.

At the library saw this recent movie with Tina Fey and Jon Hamm, so thought it would be worth a shot at something my wife and I could enjoy together. Early on it starts out with some of the crime action, that many others have pointed out is a tricky pairing with comedy.
It jettisoned my wife for sure. But I stuck around...
The problem is not just that it's a crime/comedy, but the comedy is often pretty dry and well the crime is not embezzling, but let's say much wetter. Another problem is some of the absolutely stupid behavior by the "crooks" contrasted with the more sharp-witted dialog.
Tina Fey leans hard into her ugly ducking role, but her attractive personality plus kind of belies that. Well, then there is her ex-husband with benefits, that was sort of part of the dry humor. I noticed another review thought it was John Goodman as the assassin who has some tricks up his extra-large sleeves. But no, I think it was his stunt double.
The subtle work just gets murdered by the heavier overriding plot points. It's like admiring your kids chalk work on pavement drawing well within the police chalked body outline. Hard to shake that off-feeling.
Maybe instead of trying to go Fargo, John Slattery (Hamm's old pal from Mad Men, in his 2nd full length each time with a star from that successful show)....maybe Slattery could have gone further into David Lynch territory. Even that might not have worked, here in the US with our requisite patriotic level of fear of some random act of violence, I think it's hard to laugh at mistaken identity womanslaughter.
Bottom line the film ends up being less than the sum of its parts. Damn shame as the cast and ideas I do feel like could have been forged into something uniquely successful.

I don't see a lot of new movies because they're (in my opinion) usually overdone and too slick. In case you don't know, police departments aren't full of computer nerds and hot 20-somethings. Middle-aged Tina Fey and Jon Hamm caught my eye and the 'black comedy' description led me to give it a shot. I thoroughly enjoyed the movie. It was quirky and oddball and not Formula Hollywood at all; almost Coen Brothers. I was surprised that Tina Fey was not a write or producer, and given the lengthy list of producers, she may have just asked that her name be omitted. So it's not Billy Wilder and 'Sunset Boulevard,' but it's an engaging and entertaining tale, with (possibly unfamiliar) actors delivering spot-on performances.

Despite other reviews, I felt like everything actually works really well. It's light and dark, but never so serious or jokey that the tone shifts are off-putting. The writing is really effective - it's a bit of a morality piece, but each scene is so well constructed and enjoyable and never heavy-handed. Nothing over the top, all very low-key. And the lead roles are so well delivered, there's something very Fargo-esque about how everything unfolds and the quality of the performances. The sweet, effective cop, and the spiraling criminal. Perfect stay-at-home date night movie. Can't help but wish the Jon Hamm character becomes recurring.

If you're a fan of New Mexico/Albuquerque, this is a wonderful eye-candy experience, plenty shots of the Sandia Mountains, fan favorites like Silva Saloon and Loyola's. Definitely a treat with all the bright scenery. I loved this movie, I don't understand all the hate. Did everyone become desensitized to actual movies with storytelling, real actors, real emotions, and real locations? Is everyone jaded from CGI? This is a great film, I loved the adult romance from Tina and Jon, it felt authentic and real. The real star for me was Nic Mohammed, he steals the scene every time, he has the best comic timing and brings levity to a dark moment. This was a wonderful film, I highly recommend it.

Maggie Moore(s)? I think the writer of this dreadful dramady spelled Molly Morris wrong.
Capitalizing off of a another familiar story is just sick. The families of Molly Morris(s) never got the closure they deserved. The murder of these two women have been left cold since 2002.
Hopefully the director will contribute to the search of their killer and help solve this decades long cold case.
For those who don't have a clue what I'm talking about, you can listen to the podcast or even do a Google search on the women who were actually murdered.
Again, this film is disturbing and distasteful and should have never been considered for television.

movieName: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie
content:
I love watching Monk shows and was so hopefully for this movie version.
It is extremely predictable, lacks Monk's sad-sack ending which creates the loveable loser, and has poor acting by everyone but Tony Shalhoub.
Somewhat embarrassing especially with the heavy-handed Suicide prevention angle.
The best Monk shows are quotable, memorable, fun and quirky. This was none of those features.
I gave it two stars because I love the characters and the original actors. But that's a reminiscing review.
It's still clean, mostly free from current issues (with the exception of an in your face gay character from the beginning) but otherwise a big disapointment.

movieName: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie
content:
So I was pleased (and surprised) to see this pop up out of nowhere.
If you are a fan of Monk then you will probably like this as it follows pretty much the same type of format as the TV show but with one (rather dark) overshadowing theme.
Making this film so long after the series has its draw backs - there is a certain amount of exposition as people new to the show are caught up and the absence of other characters is explained.
Once it gets going it is the normal cheesy detective show that I have grown to love so much.
Having a longer run time doesn't really add much and there is nothing special about it being a film - but I am fine with that it is perfect as it is.
This (as the title suggests) is a farewell show and it has a marked degree of poignancy.
An extra star for pulling back the original cast.

movieName: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie
content:
The movie was fantastic, and Tony Shaloub once again portrayed the character perfectly.
People with his condition rarely ever change, so expecting a happy ending to the series to carry over into this movie would have been unrealistic.
Other reviews stated they did not like it because it did not follow the series final episode. Why would it? Monk is quirky, will always be quirky, and that is what makes him loveable.
I enjoyed seeing the old characters, would have been nice to see his first assistant and their adult children too just for fun.
Otherwise, a perfect movie for everyone who has followed the series. Thanks Peacock for this movie.

movieName: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie
content: After the resolution all those years ago of solving the series-long mystery of who killed Trudy, I wondered how they could top it with this. The answer- they couldn't...But it was still nice to see the cast together again. Got choked up at times and while it felt more like a new run-of-the-mill episode than a final bang, certain elements and especially that one visual near the end in the field made it worth it. And all through the pandemic I, like millions of others I'm sure, wondered how Monk would react which I'm sure was a driving force behind the creation of this special. Some of the acting could've been better (although the show sometimes had hokey acting) but the returning main cast elevated it all. Long live Monk- whether he wants to or not.

movieName: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie
content:
I fully realize every opportunity to make money off of nostalgia is explored and monetized but to recreate a character and leave out all that made it good before is a vast disservice to the fan base.
I was very much looking forward to one more round quirky humor but wondered "how can they do Monk in a world where you are not allowed to find humor in disability, how will they take write OCD lines as funny without causing an outrage?" Answer was, they didn't. They made him a sad, depressed man without any of the quirky humor that offset the troubled mind. Monk was always the only one that didn't realize he was just fine.
Now, he fully makes you believe that it just isn't worth it, solving all the cases, making any effort, you go through this without understanding fully why he is suicidal, but just wishing he would get on with it.
Cringe is what is left. Over the top cringe. Skip this and remember it fondly, don't destroy your memories of Monk with this abomination.

movieName: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie
content: I enjoyed the film but missed Sharona Fleming. She was Adrian's nurse and assistant and was written off halfway through season three (apparently over a pay dispute). I adored Sharona and Monk's relationship - unlike Natalie, Sharona favored the tough love approach when it came to her boss. Despite the low pay and Monk's many phobias, you can tell she genuinely cared and wanted Adrian to get better.\nAlthough Bitty Schram returned for an episode of the show's final season, her character was never given proper closure. I can't really think of anyone I've ever talked to who liked the faulty concept of her going back to her ex and then marrying Randy. I think the writers were too lazy and she deserved much better than that.\nSchram's contribution to the show's success was immense and I think she deserved to be in the final episode as much as Natalie or Randy.

movieName: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie
content: Adrian Monk (Tony Shalhoub) is long retired. His publisher hates his writing and wants the advance back. He still sees his late wife Trudy (Melora Hardin). Her daughter Molly Evans (Caitlin McGee) is getting married to Griffin Briggs. Natalie Teeger (Traylor Howard) and Randy Disher (Jason Gray-Stanford) are flying in for the wedding. Griffin is investigating richest man in the world, Rick Eden (James Purefoy) and gets killed in an incident. Molly is convinced that Eden had him killed. Monk is back. Stottlemeyer (Ted Levine) is actually working security for Eden.\nMost importantly, it's great to have most of the gang back. I am troubled by two issues. First, the solution seems obvious as soon as Monk discovers the garage break-in. They obviously screwed around with the measurement. Monk would get that in the old days. Second, I don't like the suicide aspect. I get the premise, but that's really depressing. Monk was always depressed, but the show was never depressing. In that same vein, the title needs to change. It can't be his last case. It should be "The Last Trudy Case". Despite going down some wrong roads, it's still fun to ride with these characters.

movieName: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie
content:
My thoughts on this subject:
First: If you need help with suicidal thoughts - call 988.
Second: Suicide is a choice. I saw the effect of someone's suicide on family and friends. Because of that, I CHOOSE NEVER TO COMMIT SUICIDE because I did not want to hurt anyone by doing that. It really works if you think more of what it will do to other people.
Third: You are valuable to people and have done wonderful things for them. Even if it is just listening.
Forth: Ask for help: There is nothing wrong with that. Not one damn thing.
Fifth: Get a pet. Dog, cat, fish, gopher. It does not matter. Any of these will do.
Good luck and Remember - 988.

movieName: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie
content:
Monk series have a special connection with me since I got my son to watch it with me (rewatch for me) when he was 13 (now 17).
The show was great for those who have a strong nostalgia connection with the series, and "okay-good" for those wanting to see a mystery/detective show.
Though there is lots of fan fare in the show, there was no Sharona and Molly is a different actress.
The main reason for the 6/10 was due to the lack of crime solving; the movie just wasn't worthy to be a full fledge film. How it was "solved" really seemed like a throwaway moment to end the movie versus him "accidentally" figuring it out due to continuous investigation and just needing that one piece to connect it all.
Lastly, the way the movie "catches" the criminal is one of those weak Monk episodes where you put your "couch lawyer hat on" and bring up easy arguments that should get your client off the hook easily because the evidence is flimsy at best.
Enjoyed the film as a fan, but if I was a person who just stumbled up a detective movie to watch, this was definitely a "so-so" that would not make me interested enough in seeing the series. Which such as a fan, because we (fans) know how great a show this is.

movieName: Mr. Monk's Last Case: A Monk Movie
content:
Well, I hope this won't be the last case for Adrian Monk. It's been so long since the series ended and it was a sheer joy to see the whole gang back together again.
Tony Shalhoub is such an underrated actor. He pitches everything just right and it's as if he has never been away for so long. He retains the quirkyness, the awkwardness and some great humour.
The plot is good, James Purefoy makes a good baddie and the supporting gang all do a great job. Jason Gray-Stanford (Disher) chips in with some hilarious attempts to solve the case, too.
So while i understand that Shalhoub might not want to get involved with another Monk series, I do hope he'll agree to do the occasional movie.

If all the paragraphs that were cut from the final draft of Agatha Christie's stories were sewn together you would end up with something like this. If I was being kind I would call it a homage, if I was being truthful I would call it a rip-off. I admire the ambition of Ch5 to broadcast new(ish) drama to a UK audience on a limited budget but by broadcasting this at Christmas they were trying to fool us into thinking this was a genuine Christie story while we were all too drunk to notice. None of the characters were convincing, some of them barely existed at all. The story came to a sudden and unsatisfying end, I assume they ran out of plot and/or money.

No point in wasting too much time reviewing this truly horrendous mash up of a film. It is an insult to Agatha Christie, an insult to the actors and, above all an insult to the viewers.
The plot meanders painfully around the Christie plot but with none of the elegance and suspense. The acting by every single member of the cast is wooden and unconvincing. Every single one of them was there for the money and nothing else it would seem.
The set is pure American, no English country house has ever looked like this in it's unconvincingness. And then there are the appalling computer graphics presumably done by a student on day release.
And what's with the rabbits ? Pointless and useless, like the film.

First off, the script is horrible - some of the lines and the exchanges are very amateurish, plus, with the acting so so so bad, the delivery of those lines were even more awful. Based on the outside filming, it's also obvious that this was filmed in the USA and not Britain - the manor house screamed a McMansion. That only contributed to the overall crappiness of the film.\nThe gist of the story would definitely work if the writing (and acting) weren't so bad - it had an interesting core focus and that focus could get a good murderfest going. Alas, it was not meant to be. Even when the culprit was revealed, it was a torturous journey of enlightenment for us still watching at this point.

Extremely poor Agatha Christie rip-off!!\n(Of whom I'm a massive fan!) I was really looking forward to this, however it has a disappointingly long drawn-out mish-mashed plot! Absolutely dire acting - Mischa Barton seems totally out of place & awkward, very false acting abilities! Only positives are the costumes & settings, which I suspect were recored in America & not the UK! Now I've started it, feel I've got to see it through to the end - what a waste of 2 hours!!! In other words, don't bother people - no wonder it went straight to television - if it had been released to cinemas - people would've walked out in their droves!!!

Six strangers receive invites to the home of Millionaire Lewis Findley, when they arrive their host is absent, they anxiously wait to learn their purpose for being there.
The first couple of minutes all seemed to point to one thing, a reworking of And then there were none, the ultimate Whodunnit, we had the strangers, the island, the invitations, that's where the similarities end.
Let's be honest, it's nonsense, but if you are fan of mysteries and whodunnits, you may just get some enjoyment out of it, there are some interesting moments, and the story has a few clever ideas.
For me, it had the look and feel of a stage play, entertaining enough, maybe a little rough around the edges at times.
The accents are a little hit and miss, and at no point does it feel as though it's England, I've not checked the production details, but I'm assuming The States or Canada.
Mischa Barton does a fine job, more Fletcher than Marple, but pleasing enough. Chris Browning stole the show for me, I enjoyed his performance.
6/10.

Predictable sub-par acting as was the plot. Each of the characters veiled history was evident from the offset. The acting was poor aside from the "gum shoe".
Dialogue was very poor - trying too hard to be English I feel. The main protagonist being Misha who in her dialogue expressed a wish or insight using two "long words" which in effect meant the same, and really there was not need.
The worldly men who apparently are doctors and solicitors appeared trite, ineffective, play boy'ish and rather dense - considering they were supposed to be men of learning.
We DO NOT have crickets in England, so an inaccuracy on the part of the script writer and the director.
Pretty poor all in all.

This is yet another version of the Agatha Christie book, 'Ten Little Indians'. Why anyone thought another version was needed I've no idea, The acting was poor and very mushy, with no outstanding performances. Whereas the original pitted the characters against each other, this version has a woman who seems to believe she is some kind of detective. The other characters just wash around each other doing nothing in particular. There is also a whole load of rabbits involved, but I have no idea what they were doing. When you have such a masterpiece as Agatha Christies original work, it is outrageous that anyone should mess it around like this.

I watched this expecting it to be a bit like Agatha Christie's ' And then there were none' as the publicity seemed to indicate it was similar. Oh dear what a mess! Apart from Alex Hyde White, not one of the cast could speak with a passable British accent at all. Either it was a poor parody or otherwise it kept slipping into something else. The script was obviously written by an American with many American words or phrases that sounded quite ridiculous with a pseudo British accent. Many inaccuracies for the period the worst being that British police do not and never have carried guns except under specific circumstances - not a routine murder.\nWould have been far better to set this in America, then it wouldn't have grated so much.

One thing I learned from this. Mischa Barton is an English actress, I assumed she was American.
This looks like backdoor pilot for a mystery film series based on the florist Miranda Green (Barton) who adores mystery novels.
She is one of six guests invited to a small island by the mysterious and reclusive Lord Findley (Alex Hyde-White.)
The six disparate people meet on the train. When they arrive in Findley's vast mansion. They are met by his household staff but not Lord Findley. He is apparently stranded due to bad weather.
None of the people have an idea why they were invited, they are just six random strangers. Then one person is found dead, later another man. He turns out to be Lord Findley.
It gives Miranda an opportunity to investigate just who the murderer can be.
Set in the 1930s, it looks sumptuous but is clearly shot in America rather than Britain. The mystery takes a long time to get going, many of the main characters are vanilla, the script is functional.
It does get engaging when it gets going. It is a kind of Agatha Christie tribute act. Although I did guess the culprit early on.

I am not reviewing the plot, or lack of it, but the various continuity and location errors. Firstly this supposed to be southern England, but obviously none was filmed in England apart from the locomotive number 5637 and a stock shot of a train crossing a viaduct in Scotland! The follwing train train sequences was certainly not a Britsh train. Mirandas rail tickets were clearly platform tickets from the British Railways era and also were marked from Victoria to London ?? The cars at the station were American and black car miraculously appears on the island. Despite the fact that transport to the island was a small boat. The view of the island from the boat appears to have no landing stage, roads, trees or houses, let alone a mansion. Several scenes were filmed in a fairly deeply wooded area? The valet said weather conditions were precarious, but the sea was very calm! The initial shot of the boat heading to the island appeared to be empty. I gave up watching this mish mash of a production.

One of Florence Pugh's better performances but too bad about the rest of it. Cleverly written but weird and convoluted on screen. Set in a not so idyllic '50s community that to say the film packs a twist is not at twist at all. It's disingenuous, easy, cheeky - much like the film itself, which starts off strong before crumbling into baffling storytelling choices made worse by the revolting intentions behind them. More frustrating is that the film also offers stunning craft work, a wonderfully immersive quality. In short, It is less than the sum of Florence Pugh's performance. Despite great chemistry between Pine and Pugh and amazing production & costume design, the obvious and nonsensical plot and Harry Styles' unconvincing performance ultimately sinks up the film.

The drama surrounding 'Don't Worry Darling's' release had me quite concerned about how it would impact the film's quality. However, I found that the film succeed despite all this behind-the-scenes chaos!
I absolutely adored the film's style and the way it fit into the narrative. Upon a second watch, you will notice subtle things in the film that you did not see the first time. Plus, there was some creative cinematography techniques utilised that supported these two film elements.
Florence Pugh and Chris Pine gave fantastic performances. However, I feel Harry Styles performance stood out a bit compared to them. There were a few times that a different take of Harry's performance should have been utilised instead of what made it into the film. Although, I feel he did have a unique chemistry with Pugh! There are a few inconsistencies, but they did not impact the film too severely.
Overall, I would definitely recommend seeing this! It is one of my favourites of the year and I enjoy non-franchise films getting support.

Florence Pugh, Harry Styles and Chris Pine are excellent in this film set in 1950's America in a secret society living in a remote area,free from civilization and society's issues and problems. A society built on deception and lies and brainwashing.\nVery suspenseful and lots of sexual encounters. Thanks to the strength of one wife this secret society is about to get turned upside down.\nThis is the storyabout chaos and mis adventures of a community of people looking for a better life and pursuit of happiness for a select group of people chosen by the society's leadeship. Great soundtrack and i suggest mature audiences only.

A movie that is really fun right from the start for all those who are enthusiastic about the 50s. The setting is really great, the music is really fun, the great cars of the time. Everything is seen through rose-tinted glasses, and you quickly realize that this is just a facade. But that also makes it exciting, because you want to know what's behind it. Good-looking actors and actresses, beautiful fashion and the details of the set are a joy. The choreographed departure of the men, as well as the behavior of those involved, is reminiscent of "The Stepford Wives".
Thriller / psychological thriller / mystery, it all fits and I wanted to know what was behind it. I was very entertained until the final resolution. The light-hearted, almost dreamlike start, which put me in an absolute good mood, then changed and even then it was interesting to see what happened and I was able to get excited.
Only the resolution/the complete ending is a matter of taste, unfortunately it wasn't my cup of tea. But the acting performance of the protagonists, as well as the setting, music and of course the cars, as well as the one or other twist in the story, make me happy to recommend this movie.
-------------
Conclusion:
Worth seeing.

It's probably not for everyone but a great movie if you like something a little different and a bit dark and twisted.
It's Black Mirror with a Stepford Wives vibe and that is right up my alley!
You know when you finish a good movie or series and you instantly want to find something else that gives you that same feeling because you didn't really want it to end but rushed through it wanting to see how it ended? This is one of those.
This movie was what it was because of Florence Pugh and the rest of the acting was mediocre in comparison. This role was made for her!
I love an ending that can't be guessed even if it does leave you feeling a little Ill.

2 stars solely for Florence Pugh's emotionally committed performance. She pours all her acting prowess into a performance that this overhyped, pretentious, sucky film doesn't deserve one ounce of. Harry Styles is not a good actor, please stick to your manufactured pop songs lmao. Olivia Wilde, please stop making films. The screenplay tries to be "original" but it's NOT; it heavily borrows from Stepford Wives, Twilight Zone, and Black Mirror themes. Very predictable plot and plot twist all around. However, the cinematography is another positive aspect but besides Pugh's great performance, there's nothing else positive from this film. The runtime and pacing just kept dragging on, could not wait for this film to finally finish. Maybe worth watching once or just not at all.

This one was such a bummer for me. The set up was intriguing, they hooked you really well. What are they up to out there? Making nukes? Plotting world domination? Well, no.... That was the most disappointing plot twist I've seen in a movie in perhaps my entire life. What a letdown!\nFlorence Pugh absolutely kills it, as usual, but even she can't save this train wreck of a film. The first half had me so interested, the second half left me annoyed and disappointed. The writers really scrape the bottom of the barrel for this one. I definitely recommend people skip this movie and spend their time watching something a little more thought out....

This film feels like the kind of classic "twilight zone" type of SF which I would love to see more of. Not in need of big, flashy special effects, it relies on its premise and the slow build of weirdness to draw the audience in.
Florence Pugh is excellent in the lead role, and Chris Pine is effectively chilling. The plot, which I won't spoil, does have some issues which cause it to fall apart if you think too hard about questions such as "what about...?". But overall, this is an effective SF drama, which draws from the desire (of some) to return to a simpler, better time; the rose-tinted view of 1950s America.
Needless to say, what is better for me is not necessarily better for you. And the film does try to raise some questions about free will, lazy consumerism and entitlement.
Better than most films that I have seen this year!

It's a nice Palm Springs setting, full of coloques, sunshine, palms and burlesque.
But the film is too long for the storyline.
It could have been a Twilight Zone 30-min episode and that would have been more than sufficient. I am bored when I see the same dialogues being repeated on and on throughout the entire film. The script could have added other perspectives to the viewer. For example, what is happening inside the Headquarter? What are those earthquakes resulted from drilling? Or a brief flashback about how one of the other couples ended up in Victory.
Nevertheless I liked the art scenography a lot and I always enjoy watching Florence Pugh working.

I love this movie! It's so original and told by the horrific man's possessed point of view. I love it not going to get into the rights or wrongs..... just that it's a greet movie and directed perfectly, love it, I don't care what was going on! Superb movie. Stop the hate on women directors and if not any women projects!! Please regardless of what you think or came out of it, please see the bigger picture... please keep control of your body and hold on to your convictions! That is the point of the movie and stop on women including judging! The director who I praise is taken a hit that's not deserved...she was just a window? We need that window! Thank you.

Overrated, contrived mess. This type of movie only exists for the stars that agreed to appear in it, they all play according to typecast. Jackman for instance with his fierce barking and stony face.
Making the bad guys "at war with God" is just lazy, clichÃ©d writing. Very disappointing.
I suppose this is meant to be seen as a detective movie, but it doesn't have any mystery. Everything is simply given to the viewer. In the detective genre, we expect more. There's more mystery to a detective / comedy like "the hangover".
Much of the plot is directly ripped off from the far superior "The Pledge". There, Jack Nicholson shows how to extend one's range. See that instead.

I am not speaking hyperbolically when I say this is one of the greatest films ever made. The storyline, the cinematography, the acting, the ending.... Absolutely immaculate. Hugh jackman not getting any sort of Oscar attention for his role is a travesty.
As a parent of five, the tension felt during the entirety of the run time of this movie can't be over stated. The way it displays the different responses to grief etc will connect with any viewer and keeps you invested til the last second.
It will leave you asking yourself: "what lengths would I go to to bring my child home safe?"
Watch this movie. It's hard to sit through at times, but you will be glad you finished it.

A well told story with a great cast. I think that sums it up. However i'm so uncomfortable after watching this one Hugh Jackman steals the show but Jake Gylenhaal is not behind either. When you hear the word "prisoners" you might think about someone being behind bars. But it's far more complex than that. I've never thought that a 2hr 30m movie will keep on edge throught the entirety but i was wrong. Go ahead watch it. The morale factor will be tested heavily although Dylan Minette doesnt have anything to do with outcome of this movie! Paul Dano was brilliant so was David Dastmalchian!!! Not ur avg crime drama thriller.

10 years later and I'm finally watching this movie. Had I known more about the premise I would have watched it earlier as the story is great. Overall the acting is phenomenal. Jake G is one of my favorite actors. The guy who plays Alex Jones (odd they chose that as his name) is great also. This was a preview of him for his future role as the riddler. Very good.
All the scenes with jackman kidnapping the suspect, questioning, torturing, everything is 100% relatable I think. I'd do the same, probably worse had I been in his situation. Especially when the dude said what he did when he was released.
My issue is the maze/background wasn't really explained well. Who was the weirdo in the house? Also, the cop/detective work was really bad. It took him forever to notice the medallion being the same as the pictures. Cmon. The police were canvassing the property but didn't move vehicles or use scent dogs to search or anything at Jones house? Good god. What was the connection to the snakes?
Idk there's some more but this is why it doesn't get a 10. I didn't have an issue with the length either. Just too many questions and bad police work.

A detective film where the detective misses important clues and connections that the audience saw, it's all the wrong way round. I kept wondering why no one except the one detective got involved, especially after the plot thickened with other crimes being uncovered...
I was expecting some sort of tension and character exploration in the relationship between the father and the detective, but no, just a lot of shouting.
The things you find out in the end are a mixture of horrible and cliched.
The only thought-provoking character question was whether the level of violence is the filmmakers' fault, or whether the audience enjoy and ask for this.

This movie feels so so different from the kinds of films Villeneuve makes these days - no epic scenery, no special effects. This is the opposite of Blade Runner 2049 or Dune in so many ways. And yet...you see the precursors. From the ways he frames certain shots to the ways he uses silence and ambient sound. The human moments shine through the rain and muck here just like they shine through the spaceships and cityscapes in his other movies. This story is a dark and disturbing puzzle that's too easy to solve and too tough to watch at points, but it's also a gifted cast being directed by a gifted director.

I have seen some of director Denis Villeneuve's films before, and he has made great films before, so a mystery crime drama with a cool cast of actors like Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal with a simple premise interested me; after watching the film, I thought this movie was fantastic. I thought the movie Prisoners (2013) was an investing film with amazing performances, great cinematography, investing characters, and a mystery that made me be on the edge of my seat while watching wondering what was going to happen next; I did not know what to expect from this film, but it takes a simple premise involving two families young daughters disappearing, and does something different where it feels like a new thing.
Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal give amazing performances throughout the whole movie; Hugh Jackman as Keller Dover, who is the father of one of the families who find out their daughters are missing, he goes through a lot trying to find his daughter doing certain things in intense ways where you question if this is the right way to handle the problem while also learning issues about his character that I found interesting. Jake Gyllenhaal as Detective Loki is trying his best to find out what happened to the family's daughters and where they were taken to, as he interrogates people and finds interesting clues that might connect to the incident, you are on his side, and you want to know how all of it connects; along with Detective Loki and Keller Dover having many interactions with each other questioning each other's methods and disagreements on what should be done, which I found very interesting when watching. Also, the rest of the cast such as Viola Davis, Terrence Howard, Maria Bello, and Paul Dano were all fantastic, especially with Viola Davis and Terrence Howard as Nancy Birch and Franklin Birch, who is the other family who lost their daughter.
I cannot talk about whoever the antagonist is in this because it would be a spoiler, but mostly it is because every character, even the main characters have questionable problems where you wonder if they themselves are good or not. The cinematography in the movie is great with there being lots of wide shots and barely any cuts between shots, with every shot looking beautiful and giving the film a cool look and feel to it that I loved watching; plus, I will add that there is no musical score in the movie most of the time, and when there is, it makes the scenes better when they are playing out making the calm and intense moments investing and enjoyable to watch because of how well they are put together. Also, the way everything felt in the movie made it feel real, and like this could happen making the feel nerve-wracking and suspenseful.
Though I did love the movie Prisoners (2013), it will be a while before I decide to rewatch this film, mostly because of the dark themes, how real it looks and feels, and what the movie focuses on; other than that, I highly recommend watching Prisoners (2013) if you have not already. Director Denis Villeneuve is a great director, and this movie proves that with great performances, cinematography, mystery, and a premise that is something we have seen before but done differently to make it feel new; though this is not a film that will be easy to rewatch frequently, I still recommend giving this film a watch whenever you get a chance.

"Prisoners" is a riveting thriller that delves into the moral gray areas of justice. Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal shine in their roles, adding depth to the intense storyline. The film's twists and turns, coupled with strong cinematography, create a suspenseful atmosphere. As it navigates themes of morality and desperation, "Prisoners" keeps viewers engaged with its compelling narrative and standout performances. "Prisoners" is a riveting thriller that delves into the moral gray areas of justice. Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal shine in their roles, adding depth to the intense storyline. The film's twists and turns, coupled with strong cinematography, create a suspenseful atmosphere. As it navigates themes of morality and desperation, "Prisoners" keeps viewers engaged with its compelling narrative and standout performances.

Usually, any Imdb film rated above 6.5 is an entertaining watch, anything above 7 is amazing and 8 or above is a must-watch. However, this film is not worth your time AT ALL. I was left fuming at major plotholes in the first 5 MINUTES of the movie, the horrendous acting by every single character (save for the abducted girl Anna and perhaps the detective). Imagine that, a child actor with less than five lines and missing for majority of the movie being a better actor than the main protagonist, the dad, whose acting was passable and not convincing at all. What was even worse was that in the scenes with Anna's mum actually made me laugh out loud at the absurdity of her unrealistic version of a grieving, crying mum. Almost nothing is explained at the end of the movie, and the abductor was extremely predictable. It was obvious that it was the ------ (blanked for spoiler purposes, not that you should waste your time watching this film) from her very first appearance. The only reason why I managed to suffer through two and a half hours was so I could actually see whether I was right about who abducted the girls, and surprise surprise, I was correct. In my opinion, I think I kept waiting for the movie to redeem itself with a twist of some sort to explain the high imdb rating and I was least to say, disappointed. Probably the worst thriller I've ever watched. Don't waste your time.

This movie is my second favourite movie of all time. Denis vilneuve is able to create such a tense atmosphere that I'm genuinely on the edge of my seat for the whole movie which I can only say for very few movies. While I believe this movie is phenomenal it is extremely hard to watch at times especially on rewatch when you know the outcome. The rewatch value for this movie is really good and there are new things to notice. Paul dano might be imprisoned but he certainly isn't the only prisoner. Jake gylenhaal as detective loki is one of my favourite preformances of all time but hugh jackman steals the scene everytime he's on screen. 10/10.

'The Holiday (2006)' is a festive rom-com that somehow runs for over two hours, making it a good deal longer than it has any right to be. It follows two women who each experience a heartbreak and decide to swap houses for the Christmas period so they can go through it alone in an entirely different location. However, fate intervenes and sends them just the men they need to get over their past loves. Positioning their new relationships almost as what saves them from their old ones is a bit problematic, I suppose, but the picture mostly dances around the issue by giving the protagonists commitment issues (on opposite ends of the spectrum) which they learn to overcome. One of the narratives is far more focused on this sort of internal development than the other, as Kate Winset's plotline more-or-less just chucks in a romance with Jack Black as a little bonus (a lot of it concerns her relationship with an ageing screenwriter, portrayed by the wonderful Eli Wallach, who helps to bring her out of her shell). This is the more interesting side of the story, for sure, but it's not given as much time as the other, far more conventional side. Thankfully, that side - which chronicles the fish-out-of-water affair between Cameron Diaz and Jude Law - is sweet and bouncy and entirely watchable. It's exactly what you'd expect from a schmaltzy, feel-good romance, but it's well-executed and does exactly what it needs to. The stuff set in L. A. is more interesting simply because it's ever-so-slightly less conventional, but it still hits pretty much all the beats you'd imagine (yet is no less successful because of it). Kate Winslet and Jack Black aren't really given enough time for their relationship to blossom and, as such, it isn't all that believable they'd fall for one another. There's a scene where Kate Winslet is acting her heart out during an eloquent and sentimental speech about how broken she feels and then Jack Black just swears, says "you need this more than I do" in the most Jack Black way possible and hands her a drink. Still, it's a nice enough dynamic that it doesn't feel especially jarring when they inevitably come together as the finale approaches. That's kind of the best way to describe the piece as a whole really; it's a bit rough around the edges and entirely too safe, but it all comes together surprisingly nicely. It's a good version of a generic, slightly unbelievable thing. There are a handful of chucklesome moments, a few pieces of successful sentimentality and a general formal competence that keeps you engaged despite an often uneven and slightly strange pacing. It's definitely too long, but it's also enjoyable enough for what it is. It also serves as a decent movie to watch towards the end of the year, as it starts around Christmas and ends on New Years Eve.

This is almost a must to watch in Christmas season. I admit I am not a fan of rewatching the same movies every year, but once in a while this one sneaks in on my watch list on Christmas again.
I love the story - even though it is a little cheesy. But the whole movie is carried by the good actors and actresses. Yes, Jude Law is sexy and all - but the performances of all 4 of the main characters is really really good.
I like, that it includes all kind of elements in this movie, comedy, tragedy and love story. If there is a small minus to this movie, it's that the character of Iris is a little too sweet for me. And at times I wished the story would have gone just a little deeper.
Overall a very entertaining movie, that is inviting for a lot of coziness on the sofa.

I have been coming back to this movie every year during Christmas and i have no shame in admitting this is my favorite Christmas movie after Home Alone. There's something so soothing and calming effect this movie has without being overly cheesy or dramatic like most of the holiday rom-coms.
The writing, the direction, the screenplay AND the acting, everything so perfectly in sync. Never felt bored for a minute. And the dialogues are so well written, nothing felt forced, they were just flowing with the pace.
Coming to the cast and their performances, a lot of ppl say Cameron Diaz was just doing what she has been doing in most of her movies, but as i haven't watched much of her movies, i thoroughly enjoyed her here. But what stood out for me is a Jude Law, a Kate Winslet and a Jack Black u don't get to see very often. Most of the time Jude Law/Kate Winslet are seen in serious characters whereas Jack Black in comedy, but here, Jude Law as a rom-com hero was dream come true. And Kate and Jack as two miserable individuals with bad luck in relationships finding each other was a treat to watch, especially Kate.
Like every other romantic movies, this movie is also about finding the right partner and you don't know u might find it in the most unexpected place !!!

Very interesting romantic film from its script. For a movie buff, it will have several hooks that will keep you glued to the screen waiting for more.
But let's not deviate. This double story of love and heartbreak contains many elements with which the audience can identify, and it is precisely where the film finds its place.
The performances of the choral cast are quite dissimilar, with one pair standing out over the other. Winslet and Law knew how to integrate perfectly into their roles, but Diaz and Black didn't.
The soundtrack and the meta-narrative details are an excellent complement, which entertain and become part of the essence of the story.
The main negative points, in my opinion, are not minor. Direction and editing have quite noticeable errors that at certain points manage to take you out of the natural flow of the plot. Everything else is of a fairly decent level, without standing out in a good or bad way.
The film entertains, excites and makes you believe in love.
Recommended as a good alternative to watch at the end of the year festivities.

With Nancy Myers' films, you know that everything will be fine in the end. Sometimes I need such trivial stories and I don't care how believable they are. Especially when Kate Winslet shows up, I feel good right away because I think she's one of the top 5 actresses of the last 20 years. She plays her role in a correspondingly differentiated way, sometimes with a little too much verve, whereas Cameron Diaz falls down considerably, even if she is so likeable that you quickly forgive her for it. In addition to Jack Black's renewed attempt to play a serious role without any antics - which he once again fails to do - Jude Law makes for a clear 2:0 in the Brits versus Yanks comparison. He plays the mischievous father of two adorable little girls so charmingly that you can't help but be thrilled by his first appearance. So Nancy Myers - with a few clever cameo appearances - doesn't light a comedy fire, but a thoroughly likeable story with lots of artificial snow and an Eli Wallach in a great supporting role that goes straight to the heart. All's well that ends well.

The dialogs are just pure brilliance, every other sentence is a gem.
The writing is so wonderful, it's that kind that makes you say : They don't make them like that anymore..
Quote from Miles about the song he wrote for Iris: I have only used the good notes..
All the mentions of gumption. It's soempowering, makes you want to get out there and live!
Love the story, well all 3 stories in one.
It actually got me to look into home exchange and it's proper real thing! Who knew!
We have now done two successful exchanges!
We watch this movie ever Christmas, it is best Christmas movie ever.
Deserves much higher score than 6.9!

Don't we love Christmas movies? E.g. Movies that make us feel fuzzy and feel good inside? This is one such movie. This movie tells parallel stories of two women (Kate Winslet and Cameron Diaz) each both having freshly coming out of heartbroken relationships. Overcome with emotions, they impetuously decide to swap homes across the the globe to getaway and have a holiday. Unexpectedly for them, love and romance ensures. It is refreshing to see a story told from a woman's perspective. We see portrayed very sensitively the various emotions that women feel as they experience events in their life. E.g. The joys and the sorrows, the anguish and the excitement and everything in-between. Women are emotional beings more so than men.
Moreover, this film explores the themes of romantic interpersonal relationships, dating and love. It is a movie for young adults who want to watch a movie about romantic love, heartbreak and finding new love. The winds of change is in the air for these heartbroken souls as their destiny of finding love unfolds. What I like about this movie is that universal themes of love and romance are explored in this movie, themes we all desire and can relate to. E.g. We see the flirting glances of budding new love, to dating and getting to know someone, how the guy makes a move and kisses her, how he makes her laugh, to boldly confessing feelings to one another. We also see how the movie explores the idea of long-distance relationships and potential complications that go with that.
Also, it is interesting how we form mental pictures of people in our minds based on snap judgements on how they behave or act. Only for the mental picture to reverse and change once we get to know them better. E.g. We may think a guy is hitting on a girl when he is just saying hello. Or how a guy appears to be greeting his girlfriend when he is meeting his sister. This film touches on this play of perceptions.
Having watched a few romantic movies, this movie reminds me slightly of the email correspondence in You've Got Mail as the women exchange emails with one another. There is a subtle homage to the film When Harry Met Sally when Cameron Diaz's character meets her love interest (I won't spoil it). The film also features a classic romantic scene where a person realizes the errors of their ways and starts running after their lover filled with passion.
All in all, I recommend this as a solid romantic movie with a Christmas theme that will definitely put you into a feel-good romantic mood by the end of it. An enjoyable watch and highly recommended!

I actually tortured myself by watching it all the way through.. My girlfriend laughed like a hyena every time Cameron Diaz opened her mouth while I was shaking my head wondering what on earth I see in her.. Best Christmas movie ever made she said, I maintain this title belongs to Home Alone but she insisted I was wrong.. I wasn't.\nOnly tolerable part of this movie was the background music. Can't go wrong with Hans Zimmer. And the Dustin Hoffman cameo caught me slightly off guard.. And Cameron Diaz is a horrible actor.. She would never get acting jobs if she wasn't pretty and we all know it.\nCategorizing this as a Christmas movie is an insult to Christmas movies. It's a chick flick and that's all it is. Not impressed, not for a second.

Maybe it's because I watched Jingle All the Way the other day, but I liked this. Sentimental movies, double for Christmas movies probably, package maybe the last fairytale into romance and holiday "spirit". The ones that are successful, I find, tend to play into it more. These people don't have communication problems and deep seated psychological issues, they just need a push to tell people how they feel and break a particular pattern.\nBut that's why they're so appealing. Everyone has a pattern that needs breaking and so every character is simultaneously mythic beyond belief and relatable. Coupled with the spirit of the holiday, telling people how you feel and enjoying the company of others, and you have some harmless sentimentality that is divorced from real life and grounded in it, making it an enduring message.\nOf course it's unbelievable. What genre really is? It's all about messaging and trappings. And I really don't mind, as a very anxious person, the fantasy of things working out despite, primarily, miscommunication.

My wife and I caught The Holiday (2006) in theaters last night. The plot revolves around two recently single women seeking a vacation to reset their lives. They discover an app for home swaps and decide to exchange houses, embarking on a journey to kickstart their new lives, and surprisingly, it exceeds their expectations.
Written and directed by Nancy Meyers (It's Complicated), the film stars Kate Winslet (Titanic), Cameron Diaz (The Mask), Jude Law (Sherlock Holmes), Jack Black (Nacho Libre), and Rufus Sewell (Dark City).
The storyline is clever, featuring great settings, unique characters with interesting backstories, and entertaining circumstances. The cast is well-chosen, although Jack Black feels a bit out of place. The rest of the cast is excellent. The film's attire is top-notch, and everyone's outfits are particularly noteworthy. The movie delves into relatable emotions and mental hurdles as characters navigate important life decisions, creating realistic situations with a magical ending.
In conclusion, The Holiday is a unique and worthwhile holiday romantic comedy that I strongly recommend. I would give it a score of 7/10 and suggest watching it at least once.

"Kho Gaye Hum Kahan" (translating to 'Where are we lost'), directed by Arjun Varain Singh in his directorial debut, is a poignant coming-of-age drama that eloquently captures the essence of modern youth navigating life in the digital age. This 2023 Indian Hindi-language film, streaming on Netflix, delves into the intricacies of friendships, ambitions, and heartbreaks, set against the bustling backdrop of Mumbai.
The film, written by Singh, Zoya Akhtar, and Reema Kagti, stars Siddhant Chaturvedi, Ananya Panday, and Adarsh Gourav as the central trio - Ahana, Neil, and Imaad. Their performances are a standout, portraying the complexities of their characters with a raw and relatable intensity. Kalki Koechlin, Anya Singh, and Rohan Gurbaxani, in supporting roles, add depth to the narrative.
One of the film's striking aspects is its initial slow pace, which gradually builds up, mirroring the uncertainties and explorations of youth. This pacing beautifully complements the storyline, providing stability and depth to the narrative as it unfolds.
The background score by Sid Shirodkar and the songs by a diverse group of artists like OAFF-Savera, Ankur Tewari, and Sachin-Jigar, among others, harmonize with the film's theme. While the songs may be just okay for some, they subtly underscore the film's emotional landscape.
A significant strength of "Kho Gaye Hum Kahan" is its realistic portrayal of the insecurities faced by today's generation, amplified by the omnipresence of social media. The film does an excellent job of reflecting these contemporary challenges without losing the timeless nature of youth's quest for identity and connection.
The drama and romance in the film are finely tuned to resonate with current societal norms and situations, making it particularly relatable to the younger audience. It captures the essence of how relationships and aspirations are influenced and sometimes complicated by the digital world.
In summary, "Kho Gaye Hum Kahan" is a well-crafted film that offers a compelling exploration of the journey of self-discovery in the age of social media. It's a narrative that speaks to the heart of the young and the young at heart, making it a recommended watch. The movie, with its excellent cast, thoughtful direction, and relevant storytelling, is a meaningful addition to the genre of modern coming-of-age dramas.

There is no strong underlying plot of the film, it is a slightly half baked coming-of-age movie that doesn't quite tie up all the threads it starts, but a fun watch nonetheless. Dialogue, in typical bollywood fashion is shallow in most places, this could've easily been a 9 if it had good dialogue. A lot of subplots lead nowhere, but it doesn't feel too pointless because there is a central theme: the disconnect that stems from social connections.\nThe casting is perfect, Siddhant Chaturvedi is charismatic and his performance comes across as emotionally mature. Adarsh Gaurav immerses himself into his character, and plays the role with strong conviction. Ananya Panday does her best when she plays herself, and she absolutely fit her role, couldn't have imagined someone else in her place.\nOverall, a solid take on GenZ frienships, ambitions, confrontations.

The trailer made me think this is going to be a failed attempt at recreating the magic of Dil Chahta Hai/Zindagi Na Milegi Dobara, but I was pleasantly surprised by how good this turned out to be. What's even more surprising is that Ananya Pandey gave quite a convincing performance as Ahana.
Like DCH and ZNMD, KGHK explores the relationship and trials and tribulations of a group of friends. But, it does not feel like a rip-off of those cult classic films. This film has an individuality which helps it to stand on its own.
The movie realistically portrays the shallowness of this hedonistic generation through the stories of its trio of friends. The need for online validation, the want for unnecessary things, the absence of emotional intimacy in relationships, the insecurities, the loneliness; it's a mature depiction of these traits. Cannot remember the last time a Bollywood movie addressed these insecurities in such a beautiful manner. And the leading trio of actors do an amazing job in bringing these things to the screen.
Loved the flow and pacing of the film. The story was quite good, and will resonate with a huge part of the youth who try to find temporary happiness and validation amidst the deception of social media. The stand-up comedy scenes of Imaad were my favourite in the film, not because they were funny, but because how well those scenes captured the essence and themes of the movie.
We are so addicted to looking at our screens that we forgot to look into ourselves.

I dont have much technical knowledge about acting. But i felt i remember ananya Pandey's character face after finishing movie. It was so natural in this movie. And simran and kalki just give dimension to the story. Every charector got its space to feel by viewers. Unconventional ending. But gives feeling of closer. Really deserve appreciation. But fact is this movie was hard to release on theaters due to un appealing stars. Better than most of the movies released in 2023. And timing could not be better than this.. for ananya pandey this should not be the only movie viewer should remember about her.

Imaad Ali, Ahana Singh and Neil Pereira are three best friends. Imaad is a stand-up comedian yet to get his big break. Ahana is working at corporate company and Neil is a personal trainer, hoping to start his own gym. Imaad is from a well to-do film and so is Ahana, whereas Neil is from a middle-class family. All three are lost in the digital world, heavily addicted to their phones. Imaad fears intimate relationship, Ahana is desperate for her ex's approval and Neil is insecure about his social status. The film takes us through their ups and downs, as they learn to stand up for themselves.\nI did wanted to joke about how the Farhan Akhtar - Zoya Akhtar duo has the same variation script revolving around three friends, a clash among two leaving the third one helpless and eventually they all make up. This time, the script offers a lot more through these characters with Adarsh Gourav and Ananya Panday stealing the show with their respective performances. Even Siddhanth Chaturvedi catches up with a good act. The issues the trio goes through remains highly relatable and that helped to get instantly invested in the story. With the strong cancel culture, the closure given to Neil in the end is convenient but barring that, the film delivers big time. Definitely recommended.

Modern-day complexities with its compelling storytelling, brilliant direction, stellar performances, and captivating music. It beautifully highlights the platonic bond between genders, a refreshing take in cinema. Ananya and Siddhant's acting prowess shines, making it one of the standout films of recent times. The soundtrack seamlessly weaves into the narrative, adding depth to the storytelling. The movie authentically portrays Gen Z life, delving into relatable insecurities and the contrast between real and online personas. While some aspects may seem superficial, the underlying emotions resonate deeply. Siddhant Chaturvedi and Ananya Panday deliver remarkable performances, infusing the story with depth and emotion. "Lost in Translation" is undoubtedly the unexpected gem of the year, showcasing stellar performances by all three leads.

The movie masterfully weaves together its writing, direction, acting, and musical score, resulting in a superbly crafted piece. It's refreshing to witness the portrayal of a platonic relationship between genders, portrayed excellently by the talented leads. Ananya and Siddhant's performances are stellar, making this film one of the finest in recent times. The music in "Lost in Translation" is exceptional, perfectly complementing the storyline and evoking emotions that resonate deeply. This film aptly captures the life of the modern generation, showcasing relatable narratives and addressing insecurities and the stark contrast between online personas and real-life struggles. While it occasionally touches upon superficial issues, the core emotions strike a chord. The performances by the actors, especially Siddhant Chaturvedi and Ananya Panday, add layers of depth and emotion, elevating the storytelling. "Lost in Translation" stands out as the unexpected gem of the year, with all three leads delivering exceptional performances.

The film impeccably intertwines writing, direction, acting, and music, creating a compelling narrative. Notably, it breaks stereotypes by portraying a genuine platonic bond between genders. Ananya and Siddhant deliver exceptional performances, making it one of the recent gems in cinema. The music, a standout feature, seamlessly weaves into the storyline, elevating the emotional resonance. This movie brilliantly captures the essence of Gen Z life, exploring relatable stories and diving deep into insecurities and the dichotomy of real versus online personas. While some aspects touch on affluent concerns, the core emotions resonate universally. Siddhant Chaturvedi and Ananya Panday's performances infuse depth into the characters, making it a surprising standout of the year with stellar performances from the entire cast.

With its exceptional writing, direction, acting, and musical brilliance, the film stands out. It daringly showcases a platonic relationship between genders, a refreshing portrayal. Ananya and Siddhant's performances were captivating, making it one of the finest movies recently. The music in the film is exceptional; it perfectly complements the storytelling, adding layers to emotions portrayed on screen. The movie strikingly captures the essence of Gen Z life, weaving relatable stories that delve into insecurities and the disparity between real and online personas. Despite a focus on affluent problems, its core emotions resonate deeply. Siddhant Chaturvedi and Ananya Panday's performances enrich the narrative, rendering depth and authenticity to this beautifully crafted tale. Undoubtedly, this movie is a surprising gem of the year, marked by exceptional performances from the entire cast.

The authenticity of "Kho Gaye Hum Kahan" in depicting today's youth is commendable. Siddhant Chaturvedi and Ananya Panday shine in their roles, capturing the essence of their characters flawlessly. The film adeptly addresses the contrast between real-life insecurities and the faÃ§ade of social media.
