Part of why the books are so good is this perspective we get into his and others minds to see these things and it makes them deeply interesting characters.
The movie simply does not have this and made no attempt. It's mostly visual pleasure, and even then limited between CGI shots.
Also, the worms aren't big enough in comparison to how large they are in the book (the size of a space frigate or larger).

"Aquaman" is an exhilarating cinematic experience that successfully brings the underwater world of Atlantis to life. The film's stunning visuals, intricate world-building, and Jason Momoa's charismatic performance as Arthur Curry contribute to its undeniable appeal. Amber Heard's portrayal of Mera adds depth to the character, combining strength and grace seamlessly. Heard's on-screen chemistry with Momoa enhances the overall dynamic of the film, creating a captivating and believable connection between their characters. Her performance adds a refreshing and empowering touch to the superhero genre, making "Aquaman" a standout film that not only entertains but also showcases diverse and compelling characters.

I really like Aquaman, I wasn't sure what to expect from it beforehand but the trailers looked cool and after watching it I had a smile on my face. Patrick Wilson as Orm is my favorite part of this film, he really captured the character flawlessly, and his Ocean Master costume was perfect. All the costumes in this film were amazing, along with the visual effects, the world building, and of course the trident's or quindents.
This film in my opinion has a great mix of heart, humor and adventure, all though admittingly some of the dialogue does make me cringe at times. Like when Arthur meets the Daroca or however it's spelled.
The score was incredible all the way through, it reminded me of Tron at times, and I'm a big fan of that. The action was amazing, the final fight is one of my favorites; even through Arthur breaking Orm's trident the way he does doesn't sit as well with me as when Orm breaks Arthur's.
Amber Heard as Mera is pretty good, Black Manta is very well cast, King Nerious was cool; and the plot was simple and well focused; it helps when time limits are not applied!! I'm looking at you WB.
A billion dollar title well deserved, liked it so much I went and saw it twice in the cinema's. Had a good smile both times.

It is 1985 in Maine, during a massive storm, lighthouse keeper Thomas Curry rescues Atlanna, Queen of Atlantis.
They fall in love and have a son, Arthur. Thus their son becomes the rightful heir to the throne of Atlantis. But their happy life ends when the King of Atlantis sends his warriors to retrieve Atlanna, his arranged bride. So, to save her family, Atlanna returns to Atlantis.
Now Arthur is grown and has become the hero Aquaman, guarding the oceans and rescuing ships from storms and pirates.
But there is a new threat on the ocean that may destroy the surface world.... He is Orm, the wicked ruler of Atlantis and Arthur's half-brother. Orm plans to rule the Ocean and the Land.
"A war is coming to the surface whether you like or not. And I am bringing the wrath of the Seven Seas with me" - Orm
Now in order to stop his brother, save Atlantis and the entire earth, Aquaman must find and retrieve the Trident and become the rightful heir to the throne.
"In this Trident resides the power of Atlantis. In the wrong hands, it would bring destruction. In the hands of the true heir, it will unite all our kingdoms above and below"- King Atlan
Aquaman is based on the DC Comics superhero. I grew up reading those comic books and my expectations were very high.... And Wow! Jason Momo is a Awesome Aquaman. The story is pretty good, full of action, and boosted by an excellent cast. Nothing really spectacular, just a really fun comic book movie.
Cast - Jason Momoa, Amber Heard, Nicole Kidman, Temuera Morrison, Willem Dafoe, Patrick Wilson, Dolph Lundgren, Yahya Abdul-Mateen II, Graham McTavish.

Aqua Man is definitely a top tier DCEU movie. It easily one of the best two DCEU movies along with the first Shazam. It takes place after Justice League, though you don't need to watch Justice League to have a deep understanding of Aqua Man with an exception of one reference that can be easily be blown off. The visuals are phenomenal and the story is good. The story is about going out and fighting for what you think is right, even if you don't think you're worthy enough. All I have to complain about the story is that the ending could feel a little rushed. I feel like the story does an alright job at setting up a sequel. I am definitely hyped up for the Lost Kingdom. It is the only DCEU movie to earn a billion dollars in the box office and it definitely deserves it. I don't feel like it deserves all the bad reviews I immediately see when going to the reviews section.

Despite its long duration, the film can be said to flow relatively quickly and without getting too boring. I'm not much of a follower of DC and Marvel productions, but this movie was one of the ones I found good. I thought the underwater scenes were impressive. Even though the story is not very effective, the movie is somehow watchable. I can say that there is no memorable, interesting character other than Aquaman. If we look carefully, of course there are shortcomings. There's a bit of a lack of emotion. Although the action is not very high compared to the duration of the movie, it can be said that the flow is good. The plots of most superhero movies are usually boring. It could have been done differently or the characters could have been analyzed better. In short, more meaningful touches can be added to such productions instead of adding a simple action show.

This is an exceptional DC film for everyone to watch. I do not understand why all the negativity. I live in Queensland, and I can say that Queensland was an excellent location to create this film. The storyline was elegant and strong. The cast selection was absolutely terrific. They committed and connected to the storyline and to their respective characters. Jason Momoa was not exactly the perfect selection for the lead role but he was still able to deliver. Nicole Kidman really sold it in this film. She is phenomenal in every role she plays. This film teaches viewers everything about bravery and strength. My life does not have any. This is a remarkable Queensland DC film for all viewers to watch and enjoy.

"Aquaman" is a visually stunning and action-packed superhero movie that plunges viewers into a mesmerizing underwater world. With its breathtaking underwater sequences, charismatic performances, and a storyline that explores Arthur Curry's journey to embracing his destiny as a hero and king, the film is a thrilling ride from start to finish. Jason Momoa's portrayal of Aquaman adds charisma and depth to the character, making him relatable and endearing.\n"Aquaman" is a triumph in the superhero genre, offering a fresh and exciting take on the classic DC Comics character.\nMust watch for DC fans !

"Aquaman" surfaces with a 6/10 rating, and I have to say, it was okay. Jason Momoa dives headfirst into the role, exuding the rugged charm and charisma of Arthur Curry. The film editing takes us on a whirlwind underwater adventure, but at times, it feels overstuffed with CGI spectacle. Its strength lies in its portrayal of the undersea kingdoms and the exploration of Arthur's internal struggle between two worlds. However, it falters with a somewhat predictable plot and a few hammy performances. The music adds a grandiose flair, and the cinematography immerses us in the breathtaking underwater landscapes. "Aquaman" may not be the deepest dive into the superhero genre, but it's a visually stunning and entertaining ride through Atlantis that manages to stay afloat.

Where else would one see a movie with Willem Dafoe in a bun? The movie is almost non-stop CGI, with little bits of story woven between. It covers the story of baby Aquaman, resulting from the union of a lighthouse keeper and a Queen of Atlantis. And him growing up and then being put on a mission to try to unite the ocean and land worlds under a King. One learns that there are a lot of trench creatures, and that there is a sea in the middle of Earth. With all that was spent on CGI, they really didn't have money left over for a script, so it is a rather generic movie about a hero. But it certainly is entertaining enough to enjoy. No need to think.

I see a lot of complaints from people that it is very low in narrative content and very high in stick; however, that is the formula the studios are using these days. The director incorporated a wide array of action figures and elements from action movies. The underwater kingdom clashes bore a striking resemblance to battles in The Lord of the Rings.\nA particularly amusing scene involved Aquaman's attempt not to fall from a two-story rooftop after free-falling from an airplane without a parachute.\nHowever, it was entertaining nonetheless; so, if you like action movies, I would recommend watching this.

We're told we mean nothing and are just existing until we fade into black. Was this movie made to take away whatever hope we had? Is it supposed to reveal the deep truth that we mean nothing and we're just supposed to say "ok"? This movie has no deep message, it's just a big lie that you and me are specks in a void of nothing. Does it only take good acting, vfx, and fight scenes to make us believe there's no hope? We're all falling, you can either cry and find the sudden stop or grab the hand reaching out to you and accept It's help. Don't believe the lies you're being told. You matter.\nEverything Everywhere all at Once.

I finally saw 'Everything Everywhere All At Once' and I absolutely loved it! It is one of the most interesting and unique films I have ever seen.\nThe film has such a phenomenal concept and it executes it in the most fun and 'bonkers' way imaginable. It features some amazing props, costumes and set pieces to achieve this craziness. Also, there are so many themes and messages to analyse throughout its narrative.\nI also think it has one of the most accurate and heart-warming depictions of a mother-daughter relationship in all of cinema. It captures the living but argumentative side to that key relationship. There are also other major relationships for the main character that are explored effectively! Overall, I would highly recommend checking out this beautifully absurd film!

Every now and then a movie comes along that has everyone crying brilliance but I watch and go "what the heck?". This is one such film. For starters it is very slow to begin and when it does veer off into the first case of alternate universe, if you can call it that, it is just silly. I guess it's a case of Hollywood jumping on a bandwagon and wanting to praise the filmmaker and stars, when really it's all kind of daft. I was reminded of eternal Sunshine of the Spotless mind and personally I enjoyed that movie a lot, it just blended the real and the unreal better. Really what is the point of the film, though I did like the actors!

Very stressful, a painful cacophony of noise and complete sensory overload!!! All of that makes it very difficult if not impossible to follow the story. I would definitely not recommend this for anyone with sensory sensitivities. I completely tuned out less than 15 minutes into it and had to turn the sound off completely within the first 5 minutes. I do not understand the hype about it at all. Which is a real shame because I really like the actors. It's meant to be funny but I didn't find much humor in it at all. Overall it was mostly just loud, with physically painful screeching noises, super stressful and overall so annoying that I couldn't finish it.

I am not rating this movie since I could only sit through 30min of it. It starts nowhere and wishes to go anywhere just for the sake of trying absurdist meta verse complications.\nOk so if you are much of a gamer your brain might be rewired to explore all this kind of BS stratified world and thus embrace what the title says. Otherwise, if you are desperately rational in your thinking (and think you should cultivate it for fear of becoming a dumbed down version of yourself, gradually entrusting machines and AI with managing the complexity of life) then the only thing you can see is a big mess originating from some student pet project.\nIn this rational realm people enjoy just being carried away by some brilliantly creative story. But a story is not just whatever mess you can summon to metastasize into anything mixing action and meta-BS. Otherwise the meta pretence is just a self-delusional way to present one's laziness to package paraphrases, for example here in the dystopian-Matrix SF sub-genre.

One of the worst movies I've ever attempted to watch. The story is both uninteresting & incoherent. The movie failed to develop characters I cared about & then required paying very close attention to the same characters & their story arc I cared nothing about. It's like abstract art. You can look at it as interesting but it doesn't actually tell a story. It's art in the sense that it is different and unusual, kinda like Hunter Biden's booger sugar paintings. At the end of the day I'd prefer to watch a movie that uses the boring old, tried & true approach of developing characters the audience becomes invested in & using them to tell an interesting story the audience can follow.

I had no expectations going into this--it was one of the now rare freebies on Amazon. And for good reason.\nIt's one of the dumbest, silliest, stupidest, biggest streaming wastes of precious time that I've ever experienced. Why do people think that if something makes absolutely no sense that it MUST be good?\nThat's really all I have to say, but for some inexplicable reason, we're supposed to use up a specific amount of required characters even though we have nothing else to say. This character count simply encourages people to blab on and on and waste other people's precious time so I really don't.

It is a movie with great acting. Story is a little more difficult to understand. The best and only way to comprehend this movie is like Michelle Yeoh's character Evelin had tax issues and they all went to the tax office and the extreme pressure there caused Evelin to hallucinate, this hallucination took her through what was popularized as multiverse at random, seeing various things and feeling like she is singer, marshal arts expert, etc. Etc. To make her feel powerful and on the way meeting some very strange people and very strange events. Who knew that in some far away universe buttock plug gave people super powers. When the tax lady finally gave her more time and consideration, Evelin came out of her hallucination and things were great. Somehow these hallucinations give Evelin to realize the meaning of love, and this is the mystery starting with the two stones, somehow that realization was also transferred to others as well, especially her demanding father who never wanted her in the first place. Happy ending. Very creative movie.\nOscar standards have gone down recently, take a look at the awards they gave for some silly Indian Bollywood type music or movies like the Slumdog Millionaire. The tradition continues .....

First movie I watch with the age of 30. It starts kinda slow but damn it gets more and more fun afterwards. It feels more like a 2000's movie for some reason than a movie of the 2020's and gives me a Matrix vibe in a far more comedic way.\nAs the title of this review suggests this movie has plenty of campy scenes, in a good way of course. It is kinda convoluted though on the first watch. It also seems to be a good movie to watch on New Year's Eve time since it takes place on Chinese New Year. Sure chinese new year doesn't start the same time as in the western world but its still new year I guess. Anyway if you haven't watched it, give it a try.\n9/10 weird things you do to get super powers.

Wow, how disappointing this is. All the hype with the participation trophy at Oscar's, but none of that materializes as you give it your best to watch this.
At first, you think it's a complete garbage, why are you wasting your time. So you persists because it was hyped up, there's got to be some reason. Soon you get introduced to the idea.
What can I say. Chinese movie lives up to Chinese reputation. They just stole the whole Matrix idea, with some minor tweak, low budget and bad acting... Yes. You guessed it. Chinese knockoff. So sad, but true.
Is it worth watching? No. You could be cleaning a toilet. More fun. Trust me. Or watch some random movie, statistically you'll have more fun!
Garbage.

Interstellar, a solid 8, man! Christopher Nolan's space odyssey is mind-bending with those epic visuals and a killer soundtrack. Matthew McConaughey's journey through space and time is like a cosmic rollercoaster that keeps you on the edge of your seat.\nThe science stuff might get a bit complicated, but who cares when you've got black holes, time dilation, and those heart-wrenching moments? The emotional punches hit you harder than a gravitational pull. The whole survival-of-humanity thing mixed with family drama adds a layer of intensity that's both thrilling and tear-jerking. And that soundtrack? Hans Zimmer nails it, making every scene feel like an epic space opera.\nSure, it's not a flawless 10 because some parts might be a tad confusing, but that's the Nolan touch. 'Interstellar' is like a trip through the cosmos that leaves you questioning the universe and your existence. An 8/10 because, despite its complexities, it's a space epic that captures the awe of the unknown and the power of human determination - a must-watch for anyone with a love for the stars.

What a cracker!
So glad to finally tick 'Interstellar' off my theoretical list, took me far too long to get around to it but boy am I glad I finally have done - sensational film! The most obvious sign of that being the case is how the ~2hr30min run time goes by in an absolute flash... insert joke about it like being aboard Endurance here
I'm obviously not able to add anything new to what many, many others have already said gushingly about this 2014 flick, so I can only say I'm sure I agree with the vast majority of whatever praise this has received. As one would expect from Christopher Nolan & Co., it's incredibly well made, sounds amazing and looks out-of-this-world (ha!) stunning.
Matthew McConaughey puts in an incredible performance as lead, most notably nailing all of the emotion-filled scenes - not that I care about these things personally, but I'm shocked to see the lack of high accolades that came his way from this... he merited more! Aside from him, there are very good showings from the likes of Jessica Chastain, Mackenzie Foy and Anne Hathaway.
I will note one 'but', mind. I didn't love the bits at the end involving the dimensional tesseract, don't get me wrong at all it's still superb viewing... just a noticeable drop from all that preceeds it, which honestly simply says more about how outstanding everything else prior is really. I thought similarly about (the equally magnificent) 'Everything Everywhere All at Once', for example. In short: just a nit-pick, tbh.
All in all, phenomenal!

This film is another of an increasing number of films with so many 10 out of 10 reviews, that I am left incredulous when I finally get to see it. It's great to look at, once we get into space, and the story is interesting but it's also too long, the sound is dreadful (whisper whisper whisper, murmur mumble murmur, LOUD LOUD LOUD!) and the script writing is at times so Scooby Doo that it becomes a cringe to watch. There are also too few characters, such that some seem over used, in roles which would be better split, were the script to remain plausible. And overall, it's the script that is poor, not the story. I was so disappointed. Apart from the visuals, this film is nowhere near being one of the best, and the best of this genre remains 2001: A Space Odyssey.

I've watched this film over 20 times, 10/10 acting 10/10 soundtrack 10/10 casting 10/10 filming. Makes you think hard about what's out there. Easily my favourite film of all time, Christopher Nolan did an amazing job of directing it and the cast did an incredible amount of work by the looks of it. I would recommend it to anyone looking for a complex and engaging movie and to anyone who is interested in science and space exploration. It is great for all ages but i did need to watch it a few times to fully understand it. The soundtrack is a big part of this film and was composed perfectly not only adding suspense and also has a signature sound to it.\nOverall i think this film was incredible 10/10.

Had a hard time on starting this movie for some reasons but once i was hooked i could not get my eyes off of the movie despite of how sleepy i was because admit it, the movie was so lengthy and it had some maybe dull moments but not really boring maybe this is just me but pace was slow which is not up to my preferences. However a good movie still because visuals overall, so spectacular i would love to see this on a big screen. All that science stuff, confusing that's when i was sleepy my braincells weren't ready for this movie. But i still loved it! There's just a lot to it plus the emotions were so greatly portrayed it was moving and the ending? I loved it so much. I would rate this higher if i were smarter and was able to understand the sci-fi things going on but that's totally on me and not the movie.

If you have any idea how physics works and how space work, most of this movie is pretty hard to believe.\nI understand movies like Star Wars, which are set in the future, and where the premise is that you have to suspend all of your knowledge about how science works to enjoy the movie. But this movie was set near present day, and the premise of the movie was different than other movies like Star Wars Flying in and out of black holes and flying through wormholes was just a bit too hard for me to get my arms around so that kind of ruined the whole movie. I also found it a little bit too overdramatic.

Christopher Nolan's "Interstellar" is a cinematic masterpiece that delivers a heart-touching, enthusiastic, and mind-blowing IMAX experience. With breathtaking visuals and a gripping storyline, it explores the boundless dimensions of space, evoking deep emotions while challenging the intellect. Nolan's direction, coupled with Hans Zimmer's mesmerizing score, creates a symphony of sensations that lingers long after the credits roll. A journey beyond the stars, "Interstellar" is an immersive exploration of love, time, and the uncharted mysteries of the universe, leaving audiences awe-inspired in its wake.

The positives: It's beautifully photographed and the depiction of the wormhole is spectacular. Performances are delivered with conviction - Anne Hathaway and Jessica Chastain are particularly effective.
The negatives: It's very long - not necessarily a problem - but if you make a 3 hour movie it has to sustain interest (and in this case tension) for that period, which, unfortunately, it doesn't. 2 hours in, I really didn't care if mankind survived. Not helped by Mathew McConaughey's slow, mumbled delivery. I guess he was going for intensity, but it doesn't come across that way.
The absurdity: The robots are ridiculous - like something out of a 60s Sci-fi serial. The idea that a more advanced society would create something like that is just plain ludicrous. And the depiction of the inside of a black hole and how it helps solve the puzzle is unbelievable in the extreme. To me, it seems like Nolan had no idea how to solve the dilemma he had set. Sure, it's Sci-fi, but unless it's done for comic effect, it still needs at least a veneer of plausibility. But not here.
One of those films that has an over-inflated rating and reputation, which may well be revised by posterity.

"Interstellar" directed by Christopher Nolan was released in 2014. This film is about astronauts and scientists who went to another galaxy to find a new planet for human life. The soundtrack in the film keeps us focused and tense throughout the film. The plot is complex, fascinating and attention-grabbing from the beginning to the very end. Starring Matthew McConaughey, Anne Hathaway, Michael Caine and many others. Scientists go into space where they have discussions, disagreements, disputes. The main breakthrough in this film was the image of a black hole. As for me, this is the best film in Nolan's filmography. Soundtracks, special effects, characters, plot.

Possibly Nolan's finest.
The film lives with me forever. It's so much more than a space movie. A film about love, about how insignificant and fragile we are, yet beautiful and capable of magical things.
It has moments of joy, excitement, despair. The soundtrack is timeless, how Nolan has the vision to create something like this, which resonates on so many levels I will never understand.he simply is a genius, and Hans zimmers score matches his genius to perfection.
I look forward to the day when my second child is old enough to watch this film with me, the reason being they will finally learn what they mean to me. Our child is called Murph.

This film continues to maintain the essence of Guardians, for example the humor, the music, its objective of the non-blood family bond. This film covers the theme of ties, of the family, with a great environmental message, representing it in a real way. It is also a criticism of those who go against diversity. It gives a good closure to the trilogy but leaves the door open for the story to continue. It is a film where one laughs and cries. It really is one of the best late-stage marvel movies, with better effect than others. This movie really makes you make a connection with its characters, we feel their emotions, I like that they told us more about Rocket's story.

Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 blasts off with laughter, tears, and cosmic chaos! Buckle up for Gunn's emotional farewell filled with Rocket's poignant journey, Drax and Mantis's hilarious bromance, killer tunes, breathtaking visuals, and Guardians banter sharper than ever. This bittersweet love letter to the Misfits is a family story about growth, redemption, and embracing the future. Whether you're a longtime fan or a spacefaring newbie, crank up the tunes and prepare to be blown away. Don't miss this epic mission! Enjoy this movie is you are long standing fan for marvel movies very good....

You have to be either a child or someone who does not understand the depth of our world to enjoy this movie. Mindless brain rot desperately trying to make you feel something. I love marvel I really do. And if you care about these characters I get it. But you've got to take off those rose colored glasses and understand that the billionaires controlling these movies don't care. It's obvious how shallow and insignificant everything they write for these movies is. No more in any marvel movie is there a sense of danger or achievement or anything of that regard. Not so long as the multiverse exists. And this could have been fixed probably if the producers cared enough to address it, which they don't. Shallow, synthetic, and unapologetically pulling your heart strings to distract you from the lack of substance or anything of any meaning. Even the action scenes which previously have distracted the masses from the glaring blandness and dullness are derivative and uniquely boring to watch. No artistic creativity, offers nothing new and is an insult to the comic universe.

Nothing cool or original. Seems as if Gunn did this wasted and for a paycheck. What an awful way to send off a Great franchise. Leaning on all the things that made this arc cool, yet reducing it to a cheap quick payoff. No wonder Marvel is failing and this is a perfect example. What tripe.\nI felt nothing from this, mote like cheated from the greatness it once was. What an utter disappointment.\nThere was nothing to feel here. Just like this review saying it's too short but, I have nothing more to say for this waste of space wannabe so, I have to write more when I don't want to waste anymore of my time.

...this film is emotionally exhausting and utterly unsatisfying. The characters, flattened into two-dimensional self-parodies, are permitted one of two emotional states: mawkish sentimentality, or incongruous fury.\nFlipping between these extreme emotions from scene to scene - and sometimes within a scene - the cast spends the entire film either weeping or yelling at each other. With no dynamic range, there is little room for story arc, though since the plot can be summarised in five words - 'Rocket's creator wants him back' - perhaps that's no bad thing; and no room at all for character development.\nThe result is so bizarre you'd be forgiven for thinking that James Gunn had wandered off set and let an angry adolescent do the directing.

FILM: 8.5/10.
Embarking on my rewatch of Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3, I'm thrilled to report that this cosmic adventure is nothing short of an absolute blast. Director James Gunn has once again worked his magic, delivering a perfect concoction of heart, humour, and intergalactic action that defines the franchise.
From the opening scene to the final credits, the film is a wild ride that never loses momentum. Rocket, voiced by the impeccable Bradley Cooper, takes center stage with a story arc that adds surprising emotional depth to this already beloved character. Gunn explores Rocket's inner struggles, making audiences feel for this CGI raccoon more than some flesh-and-blood beings.
Visually, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 is a spectacle. The cosmic landscapes burst with vibrant colours, immersing the audience in a mesmerizing universe filled with strange creatures and breathtaking locales. The action sequences, whether in space or on solid ground, are a visual feast that effortlessly combines thrilling combat with the trademark humor of the Guardians.
The chemistry among the cast remains as potent as ever. The familiar faces - Chris Pratt, Zoe Saldana, Dave Bautista, Vin Diesel, and Karen Gillan - effortlessly slide back into their roles, infusing each character with their unique charm. The introduction of new characters breathes fresh dynamics into the team, enriching the overarching narrative.
Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 strikes a perfect balance in storytelling, seamlessly blending lighthearted comedy with poignant character development. Themes of family, redemption, and sacrifice are expertly woven into a narrative that keeps you engaged and emotionally invested.
While some may find certain sequences, particularly those involving Rocket, a tad gratuitous given Marvel's family-friendly approach, the film remains a gripping and impactful experience. So, strap in, hold on tight, and enjoy this final interstellar joyride with the Guardians that hits all the right notes.
FORMAT: 4K Ultra HD Blu-ray
VIDEO: 10/10.
Native 4K presentation, Detail level: Excellent, Colour reproduction: Excellent, Level accuracy: Excellent, Encode: Excellent, Master condition: Excellent
AUDIO: 10/10.
Dolby Atmos audio, Dialogue reproduction: Excellent, Soundtrack & effects clarity: Excellent, Dynamics: Excellent, Surround sound presentation: Excellent, LFE content: Excellent
MOOFIEMETER: 9/10.

Guardians Vol. 3 delivers what many newer Marvel movies have been lacking of late. Granted, we are presented with characters which we have grown to love so that puts this film at an advantage. However, the most recent installment added to character's depth and continued on storylines created in the previous phase. For this reason, Guardians Vol. 3 stands as one of Marvel's better films. The most striking thing to me is the emotion and feeling the animators and Bradley Cooper were able to bring to a CGI character like Rocket. Honestly one of the more moving performances I've ever seen from voice acting and animation alone. The film left me satisfied as a conclusion to this three-part story. As usual with this franchise, the soundtrack was phenomenal. The comedic performances and the action sequences were all on par with the previous films as well. Some newer characters (Adam Warlock) felt underwhelming but this didn't take away from the overall story. In fact, I loved Poulter's performance and found it quite funny, but the character himself felt unnecessary in the overall story. The villain, The High Evolutionary, played by Chukwudi Iwuji, was one of my favorite villains in the MCU to date.\nOverall, this film should be a delight to anyone who has grown to love the Guardians franchise. If you're not into the MCU films then this probably won't change your view. Otherwise, you will be happy to see the familiar faces and a film that lives up to the high bar that Marvel has set for itself, something a lot of the newer films have failed to do.

What distinguishes this movie from the previous two is that it has a darker side to it, relating to Rocket's backstory. This is at the same time the movie's strength and weakness. This story can get in your feels at moments, but on the other hand the reasons for why things happen remain in shadows. The psychology behind the Bad Guy's actions is not a point of focus. And that doesn't make him mysterious. It makes him shallow and uninteresting: The only thing he seems to be capable of is being angry.
You could say, just sit and watch the wild ride and enjoy. But the action itself is somewhat generic and the story rather straightforward. And this time the music and the jokes do not bring this movie to a higher level. The music sometimes felt out of place. The jokes were crammed in because a certain number of jokes had to be in the movie, or so I guess.
For a two and a half hour movie the story is simply not well developed enough to the point of being superficial. The interaction between the characters, the dialogue, it wasn't fresh. It didn't sparkle. More of the same. And what about those captive children? That looked so eery. And yet, it added virtually nothing to the story, because nothing was done with this fact. So you see the dark backstory gets flushed out by all the action scenes, making it almost a bit childish. The emotional moments were only there for effect.... No, this is not Star Wars where a perfect balance between fun & serious and dark & light was created.
It's not a bad movie though. The visuals are outstanding, There's a lot of action. It has its moments. It' the Guardians with a twist, but that twist makes it less funny and entertaining than the previous movies. And it does not compensate for that in depth.

I love Marvel comics and the empire that is the MCU that they've built over the past 15+ years.
With that being said, by far, my absolute favorite of all the movies have been the Guardians Of The Galaxy.
They are all over 2 hours long and there is NEVER a dull or lagging moment. They seem to always be over too quickly and I am always left wanting more because it just seems like it's never enough.
This isn't just a "comic book" movie, it's GREAT cinema and great story telling. Great characters and great action. There's comedy, there's heartfelt moments.
A great movie series to pull you out of the horrible reality that is this day and age and it submerges you into a fantastical world that you wish you could be a part of, with a group of loveable misfits you wish you were a part of.
You cannot go wrong with any of these movies.
Just my silly opinion.

Wtf guys how you can like this movie and give a score of 7 eaven 8 it s become trash ,bad jokes that you don't eaven laught, the franchise started to become wrong 1 was ok but 2 and 3 was really bad , they fool you , you paid to see that to a cinema , and after you leave, you will be like wtf I just watch,or leave from the start of the movie ,this is a garbage not a movie , you should be brainwashed to like that movie\nDisney made fun of you and the franchise , don't watch this movie for your mental health ,I hope to stop making movies with extremely bad jokes, I tink the writer was on drugs.\nStay away from this movie.

I enjoyed the movie, but watching for the second time I saw there was one glaring flaw, and I'm not sure if it's the responsibility of the new director for this second film, or the actor.
Jennifer Lawrence's over-acting (limited to 2 or 3 significant moments) doesn't maim the movie, but it certainly momentarily breaks the spell. First, as Katniss ascends the tube to the arena, Once (more than once?) when she's in the arena, and once more in the last couple of minutes of the film.
We had the same kind of crazed in the latter seasons of Handmaid's Tale; one presumes the directors didn't have a robust imagination for alternatives than "crazed expression #24".
It's as if the characters, contrary to most reasonable people I think, actually hadn't reached the point of not being surprised by anything that might occur, in spite of all that has occurred to date.
Otherwise, a very good film, well done all-around.

I think this movie offers it all. That may seem strange as I have only rated a 7 but in truth I'm not sure what I would've wanted, it might just be the fact that this movie is just another part of the story that it can't deliver everything. In my opinion it is much better than the first movie as my only real complaint from that one was that the hunger games action didn't really start until the last hour. Although this film had a similar set up, I found the build up to the return to the games was much more interesting and set up a brilliant and thrilling game. This film is clearly a major set up for a larger story but I am looking forward to watching more!

An enormous step up in storytelling & filmmaking. Frustratingly bleak & hopeless with great set design. Intense, mysterious, & emotional as the plot plays out. New cast is impossible not to love.

The First Hunger Games film did something special. It told a compelling Dystopian type story. This film took the best elements from the first film and REALLY expanded upon them.
The first film introduced the idea of the games to us, but this film gave us the argument and philosophy of why the games existed in the first place. This film also did a great job with expanding the world of Panem and it's character storytelling.
As far as character moments go, there were alot of great moments from both Jennifer Lawrence and Josh Hutcherson. Both of them struggling with life after the Games, and how they deal with the
savagery they've witnessed while going through another round of even more savagery in this film. Both are at there peak in this film and continue to shine and grow.
Shoutout to Donald Sutherland though. We definitly get to spend more time with him in this film and we really get to see more of what drives him to do what he does, and we get to see some really awesome moments between his character President Snow, and Katniss Everdeen.
The imagery and cinematography I believe have really stepped up since the last movie. There were some really beautiful shots. And the music is even more of a standout in this one.
Other than that, like I said before, the action is a lot more savage than previous, and definitely more faster paced in my opinion. The Choreography and the action scenes were done really well.
I know people say that this film may be the best film in The Hunger Games franchise, but in my opinion, both the 1st and 2nd could be potentially tied for first in my mind. You can't g owrong with either.

My biggest problem with the first film was its low production value look.
Holy Blazes! Does this film absolutely crush it in terms of production value. Amazing effects. Fantastic sets. Great color and camera work. Did you know they used handheld imax cameras for this film? Absolutely fantastic! This movie is a visual feast. The hunger games team was obviouslyt alloted a fat ton of money! I mean come on! They won over Philip Seymour Hoffman, the absolute legend, what a great actor. He kills it in this film, and casts a great menacing shadow on this film.
This film carries the same (if not more powerful) emotional levity that the first film has.
Great story.
Great characters.
AMAZING SCORE. By gosh, James Newton Howard absolutely crushed this series film score. Some of his best work.
A part of me wants to give this film a 9, its just so well done.
These films continue to depict the struggle of Tyranny Order, Chaos, Revolution and Anarchy in a profound real way.
I better walk away before i give this film a 9...

Fearing an uprising over Katniss and Peeta's success at The Hunger Games, he changed the rules for the upcoming 75th games, the pair are right back inside the deadly games, only this time, the competition is much tougher.
With the release of the new film just around the corner, I wanted to revisit them all, my feelings haven't changed, I still think that this is the best of the lot so far, I think it's better than the original film.
I think it's a little slow to start, the impression you get early on is that it's an in depth look at life for Katniss and Peeta after the games, but when the twist comes, the film really does open up.
It's not overlong, I'm glad they didn't push it out any further.
There are some exciting sequences, these games really do provide a few thrills.
Jennifer Lawrence is excellent as Katniss, her performance for me is superior to her previous one, she's excellent, as are Philip Seymour Hoffman and Donald Sutherland. Toby Jones, still doesn't work for me here.
Best of the lot for me.
8/10.

Hunger Games: Catching Fire is the second installment in The Hunger Games franchise, and so far, I'm not so excited. The only reason I watch these movies is to get ready for the upcoming one now in November. But about this one. Well, it was just ok. The plot is taking place just after part one, and things are starting to get out of control when Katniss Everdeen is changing the Hunger Games, and starts to make people mad. After that it goes a while and a new Hunger Games is out once again, with the same characters from part one. So honestly, nothing new was changed, just a new game. You know they are going to survive, because it's too predictable. Some new challenges but didn't impress too much. But I have to admit that part two was better made than the original one. The stunts were creative and well done. Great camera-work and epic angles, what gave this an extra cinematic experience. Entertaining for most time, so I give most points for that. They showed a bigger connection between the friend group in the games, but I wished some more character development form the main characters. I also wished they could show more of the world outside, because they haven't showed it so much yet. And the music. Well, The Hunger Games theme is fun to listen, but not for the thousand time. They could put more variety in the music score. The nostalgic and heroic theme was getting my out of control sometimes. But overall, this wasn't such a bad movie. It got some technical and historical problems that I would change, but at the same time it was very entertaining and good action included, with a pretty cool cliffhanger at the end! So if you liked the first one, then you should watch this one, too, but don't have high expectations.

I consider the first film in The Hunger Games franchise to be very mediocre. The steering is one of the points that bothers me the most in the previous one. However, in this second film the screenwriters and director are different. This detail completely changed the quality of the sequel, making it far superior to its predecessor. Even though it's better, it's still nothing incredible and revolutionary. It's a generic film with interesting scenes, but in the end it doesn't become anything memorable. The first act is the most interesting moment and best explores this problematic system in the universe of The Hunger Games. After the first act, we enter again into a dull story that serves as an excuse to become yet another generic action film. There's nothing special about the film, but it manages to be fun at different times.

I have a really mixed feelings on Catching Fire because of the lackness of the story, even though there are a lot of things in Catching Fire that are better than the first one, from the chemistry and the acting was better, the CGI was better, and the new supporting actor that are for me personally better than the first one, and what makes it still pretty much disappoint me was that the overall story and phasing, it just wasn't as engaging as before, and it still be good if the story was still ok but i'm not really digging it this time, and so it makes me feel whatever, and the slow phasing makes it at times pretty boring, though again there is still a lot of parts that i enjoy and like, again in terms of performances, characters, and the looks of the film was really good, the score was amazing, overall while it still have the good stuff Catching Fire wasn't as engaging and as well structured as the first one.

And already now the franchise seem to fall apart a bit. While Catching Fire has some better elements than its predecessor, fixing some of my complaints, it starts to add a lot more problems since it's a franchise movie. Not enough time with characters or enough explanation to why character are like they are, and the Hunger Game here is really just a side gig to the new plot, revolution. Some aspects work, while some really don't. I feel like this franchise really got worse from here on, because they don't stand on their own feet as good movies on their own. The first Hunger Games will forever stand on its own while this one is good, it will have symptoms of the middle child.
After her winning of the Hunger Games, a new rebellion is starting. President Snow notices the fans of Katniss and sends her back to a new Hunger Games.
A performance I forgot to highlight last time was Stanley Tucci as Caesar. He brings so much late night host energy to his role and is no doubt the biggest joy here. The performances are not nearly as great as the first movie and seems more leaned back here. The focus on romance is not helping it, as we didn't spend enough time with the characters in the first movie. A problem that carries over to this movie with a vengeance. Characters are barley here and deaths doesn't hit at all. Sure characters like Finnick add a little, but I felt nothing for these contestants at all.
The movie is centered around the revolution aspect more and therefore the Hunger game is not that interesting here. It is showed more to the side with too many alliances and too much interference from the game master. It really makes the movie feel less grand than the original. I will never understand why Katniss turns into this symbol of the rebellion. She barely does anything special in her Hunger Game and after what 75 years? They decide that the capital is evil? I don't understand why Katniss inspires people in this franchise
Speaking of Katniss, she looks so weird in this movie! The make-up looks horrendous, and I think this is the only movie where she looks like that. She looks overly dolly in this movie, and it really didn't click with me.
The action and the overall shots are so much better directed here. But it also removes something to talk about in terms of the camerawork. The camerawork is just boring now, nothing to really talk about at all, and it feels more stale. Some of the traps are a bit more intense than the original, and I kind of liked that, but this movie is a bit more about the traps than the Hunger Games contestants.
This movie uses more time on the romance than the original, but we barely got to know the love interests in the first movie, so it's not really anything worth talking about or adds anything of value.
This time around, I find the first half better than the last half, contrary to the original. I wanted the first movie to just start, but the political undertones here are far more interesting than anything going on in the Hunger Game.
This is still a fine enough movie and I see it as enjoyable enough and more or less on par with the original. But the original feels more like its own movie and a stand alone, while this one feels like a set-up movie for something bigger. It's a weakness for it, and it will lead to some terrible and mid-movies, but this one is still fine. I see it as a bit more soulless though.

The pace that is sustained throughout this movie is insane. It's two hours of nearly endless action. Characters were flawless. One liners and outrageous scenes aplenty. Watched it in the theaters three times. There isn't a whole lot of CGI in this film, which makes the action scenes feel gritty and raw. This translates directly into what one thinks of when it comes to Mad Max. I really love the different colors that are created throughout all the difference scenes. Charlize Theron steals the show and does such a good job. Overall, this one is definitely a movie to own. That's saying something in this day and age.

Great action movie. It really is a strange film. As Max, the craggy but full-lipped Tom Hardy doesn't look anything like Mel Gibson. It is Theron - or possibly Rosie Huntington-Whiteley, playing a sultry breeder called Splendid - who is channelling the eerily beautiful Gibson from 1979, except that probably neither is pretty enough. Fury Road is almost a silent film in it way. Dialogue is at a minimum, and when Max says anything it is usually preceded by an eccentric rumbling, mumbling mmmm sound. He is impassive, to say the least: the nearest Tom Hardy's Mad Max comes to an emotional outburst is when Splendid does something very brave while hanging on to the side of the truck. Rating 9/10.

I have to admit, after hearing positive things, and still a long time lover of Thunderdome, I sat down expecting... something, different, something else. While effects and visuals were seemingly spot on and no one gave a poor performance, I never once felt there was a through line story. The best I could see was a plot device to go from point a to b and then, because that was a wash, to turn around and do it all in reverse. I barely got to know this Max character. The Furiosa and Nux characters seemed to have more development. Color me baffled. If it weren't for the noise, and even sometimes when there was, paying attention to what little there was presented here took some real work.

I've always skipped over this title, until yesterday.
WOW!!! This movie is one fun, funny, demented (that's the only word that comes to mind), when I think of the rock guitarist strapped to one of Immortan Joe's rigs in the chasing party.
I was mildly taken aback when people were called called the wretched, then I looked up and laughed out loud when I looked up from my typing (Yup THEY ARE wretched).
I had a perverse enjoyment seeing how the people upon the mountain lived and had a healthy glow, expressing milk, cultivating greens etc... This lent a movie the sense of the absurd.
Witness meeeee! Watch this movie over and over again!

After some 30 years writer director George Miller brilliantly brings back to a new generation of moviegoers his iconic character of Mad Max, which was originally played by Mel Gibson in a breakout performance that made him an international superstar. Miller's new supercharged, visually stunning reboot is a punk-influenced dystopian vision with an angry feminist streak, it is also a non-stop relentless orgy of brutal violence, death, blood, automotive mayhem peppered with collisions and explosions, as well as unforgettable, adrenaline-pumping, kinetic action sequences that puts to shame every action blockbuster in recent memory! The plot concerns the revenge seeking desert nomad Max Rockatansky, played impressively by Tom Hardy who skillfully takes over the role from Gibson and proves to be a worthy successor. Max is roped into helping a one-armed, steely-eyed, badass female protagonist named Furiosa, played magnificently by Charlize Theron in a scene-stealing performance. She has escape with five young women from the clutches of Immortan Joe, a fearsome psychotic warlord who wears a teeth-bar mask, he is chillingly played by Hugh Keays-Byrne who played the sadistic villain "Toecutter" in the 1979 cult-classic original Mad Max. Joe with his army of murderous gonzo warriors and tricked-out vehicles race across the desert, he will stop at nothing to recover his female property and is totally hellbent on stopping them. Masterful direction by Miller, exceptional supporting performances by Nicholas Hoult, Josh Helman, Nathan Joe, Zoe Kravitz, Rosie Gunting-Whiteley, Riley Keough, Abby Lee, Courtney Eaton, but it's Charlize Theron's feminist freedom fighter that surprisingly steals this awesome film. Dazzling cinematography by John Seale, with extraordinary razor-sharp editing by Jason Ballantine and Margaret Sixel. The film has breathtaking stunt work. A cinematic work of jaw-dropping imagination and artistic craftsmanship, a total masterpiece. Nominated for 10 Academy Awards including Best Picture & Best Director: George Miller.

It's been 8 years since I saw this film in the theaters and I can still vividly remember that overwhelming feeling of visceral euphoria.
The film rarely gives you a pause to catch your breath. From beginning to end, it's engaging, breath taking, awe inspiring, and just an absolute feast for the eyes.
Story wise, it's pretty straight forward. For a film like this, I don't need some brain twisting scenario to keep me engaged.
One thing I really loved was the throw back to traditional FX. All the vehicles were real, all the driving was real, and it just looked so good.
It was a travesty it didn't win the Oscar for best VFX.
Do yourself a favor, find the biggest screen you can with the loudest sound system and watch this incredible film.

I liked Mad Max fury road very much. As a norwegian, the Norse religion elements were interesting, cool and relatable. The movie had everything except sex scenes, which is a good thing. There was great action, creativity, comedy (not tiresome), great acting, emotions, scenery and music. The bad guys are evil and animated and the goood guys equally well presented. There are twists in the story keeping us surprised, even though the action is almost non stop. Someone thought the Max actor didn't fit the character, but I disagree. I found him believable. Quiet, haunted, doing whatever it takes to survive, but clearly a good guy. Should you watch Mad Max Fury road? I think yes.

If you're looking for any substance, this movie isn't for you. The characters are hollow, there's very little story/script, and truthfully the movie was somewhat confusing (weird flashbacks with no context?). However, if all you care about is car chases, explosions, and killing, with no real context, then this is exactly what you want to see. I don't know why this is so lauded. It's two hours of mindless drivel. The bulk of the movie is the main characters trying to escape the lives they hate so much, whilst being chased by many different styles of gangs. But, right towards the end, they decide to go back to the city they fled, and when they return everything is magically better simply because they killed a couple bad guys. Give me a break ðŸ™„

"Mad Max: Fury Road" sets off at an often relentless and disorienting pace, which some may find more bewildering than exciting. The film's striking and vivid colors evoke a visual style reminiscent of darker sci-fi realms or the aesthetics of video games.
In this chapter, Tom Hardy takes on the role of Max, but his portrayal may leave viewers yearning for a more conventional and relatable hero. Max's limited dialogue, replaced by animalistic utterances, contributes to a sense of disconnection between the character and the audience.
The action sequences in "Mad Max: Fury Road" are undeniably extravagant, with a penchant for pushing the boundaries of plausibility. The relentless pursuit and audacious stunts, while visually impressive, may border on the excessive for some viewers.
Regrettably, the film's storyline is notably thin, serving more as a backdrop for the visual spectacle than as a fully developed narrative. The world it portrays is bleak, with survival as the central focus, and this simplicity extends to the storytelling.
"Mad Max: Fury Road" may dazzle with its aesthetics and action, but it falls short of achieving a balanced cinematic experience. It's a film that, while visually striking, ultimately leaves a sense of mediocrity in its wake.

I watched this movie with my sister and some friends in theaters back when it came out. My Dad had showed my sister and I The Road Warrior and I had LOVED it- when the trailer for this came out she excitedly showed us and I was drawn right in. We ended up going to see it and I can say for certain I have never had a movie-going experience like this one...
I always envied people who got to see films back when movies were still exciting novelties that could blow audiences away, like the first audiences to see Star Wars, and I was sad id never get to experience that type of thrill. Boy was I wrong.
This movie is better than any roller-coaster ive ever been on; better than any drug ive ever done; more adrenalyne pumping than any near death experience Ive ever had and has truly earned that funny phrase "better than sex." It is a non-stop, straight forward action filled ROMP where every single detail has been considered and you notice something new everytime. Every shot; every cut; every punch; every bullet fired; every crash; every scream; every explosion, gets your heart pumping faster and faster as you feel more and more invested in the conflict our heroes face. Part of that is because despite minimal dialogue and maximum action- you care more about these characters thsn you will in most modern movies. This movie has HEART, and a great message. It's story-telling and themes are the epitome of show don't tell. There is rarely exposition dialogue, instead props, scenes, and character costumes communicate everything you need to know about them and this hellworld our story takes place in. More is communicated in a simple nod than most movies achieve in entire scenes- partly credit to the actors and partly just because the writing and pacing are executed flawlessly. Sometimes I rewatch it when I want to feel inspired in our own warlord-run wasteland.
This movie is all gas; no breaks, start to finish. Incredibly rewatchable and never loses that high-octane adrenalyne rush I felt upon first viewing.
When we finished the movie that first time we went, it was downpouring out with thunder and lightning. But we were so amped up that as I drove everyone home, my friends and sister in the backseat leaned out windows and climbed out the sunroof to scream "WITNESS ME!" into the raging storm... in defiance of all that things ahead on the road... 2015 was a simpler time.
This is my favorite film, and it's not even close.

The plot begins with a powerful action scene, in which Barry Allen-Flash (Ezra Miller) is called to help the victims of a terrorist attack in a hospital. While the opening sequence already manages to give us the tone of the film, it also serves as an impetus for us to understand Barry's true intentions and the traumas he has carried for a long time - given that his mother was murdered when he was just a child and that the father took the blame and now awaits a trial that doesn't seem to have a happy ending. It is from there that, moved by the brief spark of hope in restoring a family that was torn apart by a poorly explained tragedy, Barry moves through anguish and melancholy to go back in time and prevent his mother from dying. However, what he did not expect is that his benevolent actions would trigger a series of events foreshadowing the implosion of the multiverse.
What would you do if you could go back in time is the maxim that governs the feature film directed by Andy Muschietti - and a question that has certainly crossed our minds. After all, we all make mistakes and feel responsible for having acted differently and fixed what was broken. Barry, in this way, discovers that he has an ability to return to the past, breaking fragile rules of space-time to "change events" and ensure the survival of the one he never forgot. Now, it is remarkable how the protagonist is enveloped by a vigilante blindness that makes him forget the butterfly effect - and that takes him on a tortuous journey of reparation and nostalgia. However, no matter how noble his intentions may have been, the plan backfires and he opens a timeline parallel to the one he belongs to, creating a perpendicular rift in the multiverse that predicts catastrophe.
For those who watched the trailers and promotional teasers for The Flash, you will probably have few surprises throughout the 140 minutes of the feature film directed by Argentinean Andy Muschietti. From the main special appearances to the apotheotic moments, almost everything had been revealed by Warner-DC's marketing department in the advertising pieces. Which, let's face it, takes a lot of the fun and emotional impact out of scenes like Batman (Michael Keaton) saying his iconic line "I am Batman". Surprising moments are really rare, usually references to other incarnations of the publisher's main superheroes in cinema and television. The plot itself shows Barry surprising himself with his ability to navigate between temporal plots and landing in the past to try to change his lonely present of orphanhood (dead mother and imprisoned father). When going back in time, he comes across his 18-year-old version, still without the powers brought by an unlikely combination of chemical elements and lightning fallen from the sky. However, the protagonist did not imagine that this world would be different from his own in certain ways, with several variants and few familiar constants. Batman is a different person, Superman Kal-el has a different destiny, but Zod (Michael Shannon) continues to come to Earth to conquer it and revive his home, Krypton.
The Barry of the past is the hero who is reluctant when faced with the call to adventure, but who proves his worth along the journey of maturity. The Barry of the present is the mentor who guides his younger version to learn, thereby demonstrating the ability to be more than Batman's boy wonder - the same dramatic curve as Peter Parker, who proved to be more than Batman's boy wonder of Iron Man. Absolutely everything revolves around these parallel and complementary journeys of the Barrys, but that doesn't make The Flash a serious film about feelings, traumas and adult sensations. In addition to personal controversies, Ezra Miller had proven in other works to be an actor with repertoire, something that in this new super production is only partially valued. An irritating and loud teenager, the Barry of the past gains space and constantly supplants the seriousness of the Barry of the present, who carries the character's tragic tones. Andy Muschietti chooses to give more time and importance to the comic content, thereby sabotaging items such as: the hero's sadness aspects, the obsolescence of Michael Keaton's Batman and the strong personality of Supergirl (Sasha Calle). No wonder, Batman and Supergirl are demoted to mere occasional colleagues. Batman is still valued for its nostalgic aspect, but Krypton's daughter is compromised by the suffocation of drama.
In addition to this issue, the film is tonally very strange, with an initial sequence of frantic action in Gotham City that serves to make it very clear that the Flash in this film is the Flash from Justice League, complete with Jeremy Irons' Alfred and the Ben Affleck's Batman (albeit wearing an absolutely hideous version of his costume). At the beginning, the tone is openly comical, with Ezra Miller reveling in his dramatic limitations as a court jester, with the beating itself taking on a veneer that was supposed to be hilarious, but which ends up only generating yellow smiles due to the exaggeration of the whole thing, including a newborn rescue sequence in a hospital featuring horrific visual effects of these babies. Then, in the other universe, the footprint is opposite, darker and heavier, but also more rushed and without Muschietti, at any point, really having the courage to bet his chips on it, which leaves room for inconveniences of displaced humor that they detract from the whole and deflate the drama, especially because the development of the two Barry Allens, especially the youngest, is relegated to the background and then, almost instantly, is accelerated from 0 to 100 without giving time.
Another problem that weighs heavily on "The Flash", especially in the final third of the projection, is the visual effects. And it's not just a standard complaint about hero films: the thing is bad even by the low standards that Marvel has been presenting lately. The opening sequence, with Flash saving falling babies, is terrible on a PlayStation 2 level and there are several racing scenes that all feel artificial and weightless. And it's something that really hinders the experience, as it takes away the impact of key moments. There are special appearances that are made entirely (and without purpose in certain cases) in CGI that look like rubber and wax dolls with which it is impossible to create any connection. What should be nerd apotheosis becomes just something shameful. Luckily for fans and spectators, Muschietti manages to balance the poverty of the effects with a firm pulse on the progress of the story. In the end, it is thanks to his direction that "The Flash" manages to deliver something that DC has never managed before: uncompromised and unpretentious fun.
The rest of the film, especially its final minutes once again in the chronosphere, is a search for references and fan service that irritatingly has become the standard for blockbusters of the genre. Out the window goes the story, which is then summarily replaced by the absolute and inescapable emptiness that are the moments that exist only for the viewer to point at the screen and identify this or that character and object more quickly than their friend next door. The cinematic experience, therefore, becomes an uninspired child's game that requires nothing from anyone other than a frankly useless encyclopedic knowledge of pop culture.
Even with all the references, "The Flash" rarely excites. The battle scenes have few textures and the action is generic and poorly finished accordingly. Post-production is responsible for showing super-powered beings in battles so sumptuous that they lose sight of the human dimension of these extraordinary men and women. And, by the way, the quality of the CGI is not always consistent with the economic power of the production. An initiative full of special appearances, Flash's first solo adventure serves to introduce the concept of the multiverse to DC and make beautiful tributes to his long and sometimes sleepy journey. This journey of weak emotions includes never-before-realized cinematic versions of characters such as Nicolas Cage's Superman (one of the good ideas) and tributes to the precursors of the wave that has reigned for more than 20 years in cinema with a more industrial feel. Furthermore, there are good jokes about changes in timelines - the best of which is about the protagonism of the "Back to the Future" Saga. In fact, recharging the "flux capacitor" with lightning is another affective borrowing from Robert Zemeckis' creation. However, the solutions are lazy and difficult problems are solved with simplistic strategies - like the lightning bolt that, if replicated, could create armies of Flashes? In the end, even the resolution of "Spider-Man: No Way Home" is recycled by DC Comics. Reality almost collapses for the protagonist to learn to accept losses and understand the value of his scars. This film, at least, should be the last of DC's current phase, serving as a reboot of the universe - so it's strange to see a Batman from the past hated by fans appearing in the final scenes in a questionable and confusing participation - it's strange to think that "Blue Beetle" and "Aquaman 2" would still be released after this production.

Barry / The Flash's life is subsumed with the fact that his father is in jail for the murder of his mother. When he discovers that he can run faster than the speed of light, he decides, against the advice of Bruce Wayne, to go back in time to put things right. As we all know though, such plans are always fraught with danger, time line wise and this is no different.\nWhilst Barry and his past self played by Ezra Miller are largely good fun in this, there are significant sections where they are both deeply irritating which is somewhat distracting. In addition the film includes a contribution by Supergirl played by Sasha Calle giving, at odds with the rest of the film's tone, one of the most miserable performances seen since The Grapes of Wrath hit the screen.\nThat said this is one of the more enjoyable DC superhero movies of the last few years featuring an entertaining story, fun set pieces and strong FX throughout. The big draw here though is the introduction of shots and cameos of past beloved superheroes (and some who nearly were) and a starring role for Michael Keaton returning as Batman. The man provides much kudos here as does the accompanying suit, quite beautifully realised bat cave, bat mobile and plane, even Danny Elfman's glorious music. These factors add to a fun tale that should appeal to most people, but which may not include ardent young fans into DC lore.

The Flash has enough action, heart and humor - not to mention fun cameos - to make up for any drawbacks.\nWorlds collide when the director of both "IT" movies sat on the chair of the first comic book movie about the fast young teen in the DCEU. Andy Muschietti showed us a good amount of unique director chooses that enchanted the feeling from the comics. As Michael Keaton brings back the old Batman, with the same vibes, Ezra Miller pulls not one, but two fenomenal performances. The pacing was great and the screenplay was actually good for a comics film (which I am not the biggest fan of).\nThe flash is funny, fittingly fast-paced l, and overall ranks as one of the best DC movies in recent years.

The Flash is really bad, it has 0 good jokes, I didn't laugh once, I couldn't remember anything when I finished the movie, it has nothing special to remember at all, it has to be one of the worst character depictions I have ever seen. The scenes from x-men were they show Quicksilver are more memorable than a whole Flash movie. There are too many plotholes everywhere so the movie also makes no sense in so many levels that it is sad how many website have shown up to try to explain this plot holes and most just speculate but offer no good explanation. I saw the movie 2 times as I could not believe it was that bad the first time and I thought I should gave it a second chance, it was a terrible idea, the movie just sucks if you are over 14 years old.

What is good in this film?
+ Michael Keaton
+ Michael Keaton !
+ Michael Keaton !!!!
+ a hommage to the 89' Batmobile
+ a hommage to Bat stuffes, the Batcave, some antagonists from the earlier DC movies
+ there are some good jokes ( 2-3 throughout the whole film)
+ there are references to unrealised DC film projects
+ the personal tragedy of Flash in his young age is represented well.
(have You noticed that only the last one is connected to Flash in a movie called "Flash" ?)
The negatives:

EVERYTHING else
no, I am not kidding. LITERALLY EVERYTHING ELSE.
The plot goes nowhere. It builds up something, than let it go, without solution.
Ezra Miller is not good enough lead.
The plot is so bad, that it even cannot provide opportunity to Keaton to show, why we liked him soo much as Batman back in '89-'92. He simply cannt show why this character is interesting.
And the whole thing looks like a mess, waisting the opportunity for the introduction of a proper multiverse.

The Flash (2023) is a superhero film that tells the story of Barry Allen, a science nerd who becomes the Flash. The film is full of action, humor, and heart, and it features a great cast of characters, including Ezra Miller as Barry Allen, Michael Keaton as Batman, and Sasha Calle as Supergirl. The film's action sequences are particularly dazzling, and they showcase Barry's lightning-fast abilities in breathtaking slow-motion sequences. But beneath the thrills, The Flash beats with a surprisingly emotional core. Barry's quest to save his mother fuels the narrative, exploring themes of family, loss, and the power of connection across time. Ultimately, The Flash is a triumph of heart, spectacle, and pure superhero joy. It's a film that celebrates family, embraces second chances, and reminds us that even the fastest man alive needs a little human connection. So buckle up, grab your popcorn, and prepare to be swept away by this electrifying cinematic adventure. The Flash is a must-see for superhero fans and anyone seeking a dose of big-screen magic.

If one wasn't concerned whether the special effects were good or bad, it is entertaining enough for teenage boys and youth. But the movie seems to have simply too much thrown in to make for a really good movie. It really becomes mindless entertainment with a very simple plot. If one goes back in time, it doesn't mean when one exits, one will return to the same temporal universe. And if that wasn't made clear enough, in the last act with the clashing of different parallel universes, that was drummed in. The younger Barry Allen character sometimes became annoying, but it never was stated his age anyway, so it may have fit with his age. Sure there were some fun spots, but also some boring ones.

After many obstacles we've finally got to see the Flash and it was a disappointment.
The bickering between the two Barry's was annoying and ofcourse the CGI was a laughing stock. Really the only goog thing was to see Michael Keaton as Batman again and even that was not handled properly. The multiverse was badly explained with the spheres.
For a movie that's been in development for many years, it is a great example of how Warner Bros. Is
Struggling and cannot make up Their mind in wich direction to go. Countless rewrites, reshoots and than we get this???? For Pete's sake. I think that WB explained to us how what the movie is in the "Spaghetti scene" with Michael Keaton.
Enjoyable? Well maybe a few scenes but in general it was really badly written, not gonna watch it again.

This year saw the release of two enjoyable films by DC Studios - Shazam! Fury Of The Gods and The Flash. If Walter Hamada is the man that's responsible for the DC Studios films that got released in the last few years, he deserves praise, in my opinion, because I enjoyed seeing almost every DCEU film that got released from 2019 to 2023. The Flash, in particular, is my favorite film of this year so far. Sure, it's not as good as, let us say, Across The Spider-Verse, but it affected me the most. The Flash is admittedly silly at times, but almost everything else in this film works well. It's clear that plenty of effort and money went into making The Flash. After The Suicide Squad (2021), The Flash is my favorite film in the DCEU. First of all, the cast, especially Ezra Miller and Michael Keaton, delivered good performances. The Flash does seem like a star vehicle for Miller. There are a few scenes in the film that are actually moving. This is something that can be said about only several superhero movies that got made in the last decade because most of them attempted to deliver only laughs and entertainment. But The Flash still features some effective comedy. One of the reasons why The Flash is often effective is because it features a good music score by Benjamin Wallfisch. What's also worth mentioning is that The Flash is kind of like a comeback for the American flag. The American flag is in the film for a bit and it looks glorious when it appears. The American flag hasn't looked this good in a film for about a decade or more. Sure, the American flag isn't a very good actor. The performances of the American flag are mostly stiff and of one note. But the American flag doesn't get cast in films because of its acting chops. It gets cast because of its good looks. There were rumors that the American flag had turned to drugs, and perhaps this is the reason why it looked bad in the films in which it appeared in the last decade. But I'm here to tell everyone that the American flag is back! Not since the 1990s has the American flag looked this good on screen. Perhaps the American flag has been spending time at the gym and consuming dietary supplements.

This was a fun movie. People have gotten too used to being Yelp reviewers and Karen's behind their screens they feel entitled to sit there after lazily doin nothing and viewing this film. Was it the greatest one? No, but it was fun. Get over yourselves people. At it's heart it's a superhero movie that goes slightly awry and that's not a bad thing.\nPart of the story gets lost in the craziness of it but it all ties in and does a good job of tying up its loose ends. It's a fun movie with some fun storylines and nice throwbacks. Enjoy it and stop waiting to be wowed with your cynical minds. Take it for what it is and go on with your lives.

Easy viewing, lots of funny moments. Great to see films about Polynesian culture that made with actors and crew connected to the culture. Predictable storyline but still interesting, humorous and entertaining, especially as it is basically all historically correct. Loved the inclusion of Kaimana playing Jaiyah who was the first openly trans person to compete in international soccer. Apparently Jaiyah wasn't in the team in this point of history in real life, but they are a real person and I thought it was great that their story was incorporated into the movie. Taika clearly cares about this project. Hilarious dialogue that was apparently mostly improvised. Not the best movie in the entire world but good fun, enlightening and worth a watch.
