I thought I could handle it because, hello Channing Tatum, but even with all of his hotness, the movie was still so hard to watch. The main character made me want to skin my scalp and staple it back on. Please save yourself the trouble and don't watch it. I wouldn't wish this movie on my worst enemy.

When I started this movie, I was extremely bored and just watched whatever YouTube had for free. This made me really judgy and I hated it within the first 10 minutes because it was predictable and boring and, let's be honest, the coach at Cornwall had a point. But as the movie went on, I began loving the characters and, well, Channing Tatum was in the movie and well...ðŸ‘Œ. The character's were so funny and didn't feel disconcerted from the movie. You'll be cheering for the two main characters as they fall in love, you'll cheer as they play soccer(and I don't even like soccer), etc. Long story short, the movie was sweet, hilarious, and yes it was predictable like all romance movies but you still love it anyway. I recommend this movie.

She's the Man is based on a very silly concept that it uses well to create some fun, but it does feel a little too stretched to really impress.
The highlight of the film is the fantastic lead performance from Amanda Bynes, who really shines as both Viola and Sebastian. It's a performance full of great comedy and physical acting, and it really brings the film together. There are some solid supporting performances, even if they are all a little overacted, with Channing Tatum as the stand out.
As mentioned the story is very silly but fun, nothing more than that really. It maybe could have been taken further and the concept used to create a bit more chaos and fun. It's all very predictable but it works.
Like a lot of movies from this era, it does have a good feel and tone to it which is welcome, and it does make for a light hearted and breezy film.
Overall I was expecting a little more from She's the Man, but it is still fun nonetheless.

This film begins with a high school student named "Viola" (Amanda Bynes) being informed that her chances of winning a college scholarship for soccer have been destroyed due to the sport being cut from the program. Still wanting to be able to demonstrate her skills to college recruiters, Viola then goes to the boys' soccer coach, but he not only dismisses her request, but also humiliates her in the process as well. Even worse, her boyfriend "Justin" (Robert Hoffman) also joins in the laughter. Infuriated by this, Viola immediately breaks up with him. Not long afterward, she learns that her twin brother "Sebastian" (James Kirk) is secretly heading out of town for two weeks and--since he is living with their dad and is set to attend a different school not far away--she decides to masquerade as a guy and try out for the boys' soccer team there instead. Obviously, this subterfuge presents enough challenges on its own, but what she doesn't count on is the fact that Sebastian's girlfriend "Monique" (Alexandra Breckenridge) is looking for Sebastian and has a habit of appearing out of nowhere at the worst possible times. Neither does Viola factor into the equation the possibility that she might fall in love with one of the soccer players named "Duke" (Channing Tatum). Or for that matter, that Duke might have a crush on the prettiest girl in school named "Olivia Lennox" (Laura Ramsey)--who quickly becomes attracted to Viola's version of Sebastian. Now, rather than reveal any more, I will just say that I was expecting this film to be nothing more than a remake of the movie "Just One of the Guys" which came out 19 years earlier. And as such, I wasn't expecting it to be nearly as entertaining. To my delight, I turned out to be quite wrong, as I found this movie to be just as good with Amanda Bynes putting in a really good performance all along the way. That being said, I can understand it if there are some viewers who prefer "Just One of the Guys" over this as it came out first and seems more original. Be that as it may, I found this movie to be quite entertaining and I have rated it accordingly. Above average.

I've heard this movie mentioned by a few friends as very fun, and I'm thinking that is more the nostalgia speaking. It is fairly pleasant and mildly entertaining, I'll admit but "very fun" it is not. It's also definitely a product of its time, completely corny and predictable with some questionable jokes. There are definitely better movies to watch in that genre from that era so if you have to be picky about what you're watching I would say you can skip She's The Man, you wont' be missing much. But if you need something in the background you don't really have to think about much, knock yourself out.

Entertaining comedic timing from Amanda Bynes, effortlessly shining in the lead role as Viola and showcasing her versatile comedic range. Her impersonation of Viola's twin brother, Sebastian, is silly and really funny (the fake Jamaican accent she uses to sound cool had me laughing so much). Channing Tatum is equally awesome in a more subtle supporting comedy role as the roommate-friend turned love interest, sharing a sweet chemistry with Bynes in her dual role. The sexism and gender politics in sports theme is well crafted through the storyline. Also, big praise to whoever hand-selected this film's brilliant soundtrack; meshes seamlessly with each scene's vibe and atmosphere. A must-watch sports rom-com from the 2000s and one of Bynes BEST films! A good pick too if you're looking for a feel-good film to watch.

Almost all child actors have problems because of the crazy lifestyle of working as an adult with adults, so it's good that she's retreated to finding a normal life away from Hollywood. But in addition to Shirley Temple, Bynes has been my favorite young actor.\nAmanda Bynes is a comic genius. She plays everything moment by moment. If you listen to the script, you can imagine how the majority of actors would say the line. What she does with each line is deliciously funny and original. All of the other actors are great, too. The writing is well thought out, cute the way they incorporating Shakespearean names into this modern homage to Twelfth Night.

I've watched this movie 3 times in 3 different stages of my life and still find it funny and romantic. Yes, it's corny at times but still cool and enjoyable. A real comedy that makes me laugh outright. It's a movie that will definitely make you happy and put a smile on your face. Don't think this is a movie for teenagers only. It's great to watch with your family or even on a date or even on your own. Very fast paced, not a dull moment and filled with different characters though some probably with exaggerated acting but still not annoying. Recommend to watch. I won't be surprised if I will watch it again and still find it funny.

The plot and character intro lasts all of 9 minutes. The only time I laughed was at how bad everything is. Pointless scenes and forced jokes that just don't land it's just embarrassing. Seriously go watch Just One of the Guys.

It's a Normal but fun movie! Something to casually watch if ur in the comedy romancey mood.\nOverall I enjoyed it, but there was times the comedy would seem cringey but I just got past it. It was a good movie to see Amanda Bryes in as it's my first movie to see her act in. Though at times it is cliche with the switching "twin" charade and her having to be one persona to another but it was an enjoyable movie I could not forget!!

I watched it again last night, this time on some Italian channel, dubbed. I can't recall how many times this masterpiece blew my mind but I recall very well the first time I had seen it, a decade after its release, on TV... And before yesterday, 9 years ago, I had seen it on DVD with who was my beloved at the time, for whom it was a first.
Why are these even worthy of mention, you might ask. I do think it is important for us to be able to enjoy a film at very different stages of our lives. When you're a kid, you'll look up to Rocky as the young man you wanna be. When you're of middle age, you'll understand better how Burt Young's character felt. And probably when we are much older, we may identify with Mikey who was lamenting about being 76, still chasing a chance, a dream.
John G. Avildsen is the guy who set the standards for popularizing the most precious emotions. You just cannot neglect Karate Kid or Rocky. These are more than films. They are citadels of audiovisual culture.
Watch Rocky, and then just look at a pic from some recent Sylvester Stallone movie. The difference of quality and grace is abyssmal. It just blows your mind to see that, the man who rose to fame with such a gem is today appearing in "products" that are literally nothing compared to Rocky.
I won't say I don't understand it. Nor do I condemn Sly's current path. Maybe it's inevitable. Maybe it's normal that, after Rocky, you can never reach so high.
There's so much to say about this movie. Yet, we don't even need to put our feelings into words. The score does it for us. The climax we reach by the ending, the victory of the guy who on paper actually lost the confrontation, the love and affection he has for the woman he has gained the heart of along the way...
Rocky is not just a movie. It's that sports game you can watch again and again, knowing the result, just out of your desire to relive the emotions leading to it.
There are several movies we can choose as "the best ever". And each have their power points. But to each, you can approach also in a pedantic manner and argue this or tat could have been handled better. Borrowing an analogy of Alan Watts, only to apply it to this masterpiece:
"Have you ever seen a misshaped wave? Or a wrong cloud? There are no such things. They come with nature exactly as they are supposed to."
To me, Rocky is to cinema what a wave or a cloud is to nature. It's perfect. Just perfect, and impossible to imagine in a different way of existing.
What we feel for the protagonist of the film is the exact same as what we feel for the brains and souls behind it. Respect, respect, respect.

Heard about this film for a very long time but hasent been able to watch yet until today. Heard it was gonna be good and it should, due to the very high rating on imdb. Heard it is a must watch, if your into film.
Early into the film, I directly felt that i really don't understand the very high rating at all and i don't understand whats so special about it. Nothing unique to it. Pretty bad manuscript aswell at some moments.
Sylvester Stallone does a average performance in his role, of some regarded to be one of his best ever.
A extremely boring and slow film.
Filming starts pretty bad and shaky, but gets much better the longer into the film.
Good soundtrack.
A Classic, but a very average film. Watchable, but do not expect too much.

Sylvester Stallone at his best, an easy but exciting plot, a controversial and borderline character. This is the recipe that makes Rocky one of the most watched, famous and appreciated films of all time. As I often say for masterpieces, raise your hand if you've never seen Rocky, look around you won't find anyone. A semi-desperate Italian boxer who scrapes by on fake jobs, in a squalid house with 2 turtles for company, will find himself facing the world heavyweight champion in Philadelphia in front of his people. Well, a sort of male Cinderella, a dream that comes true and that will change the life of both the character and the interpreter Sly forever. There's also boxing but that's marginal... Top film!

Sylvester Stallone wanted to make it in Hollywood, but he couldn't get cast in anything other than...stuff he'd rather forget he was ever near. So, he wrote his own screenplay, heavily influenced by Elia Kazan's On the Waterfront, and got it funded by the independent producers Irwin Winkler and Robert Chartoff, and they hired the largely unremarkable young filmmaker John Avildsen to direct. The result is a tender character piece that, especially when combined with its rousing score by Bill Conti, ends up a fun, touching sports film that never loses sight of what it's about: its central character.
Rocky Balboa (Stallone) is semi-pro boxer with little technique but a lot of heart who wins more than he loses, but he can't get any particularly good fights since no one will manage him or really believes in him. He's alone in the world, trying to get the mousy, shy girl who works in the pet shop, Adrian (Talia Shire) to laugh at his corny jokes while working as a leg breaker for the small time loan shark Tony (Joe Spinelli). He has no real friends, the closest being Adrian's brother Paulie (Burt Young) who spends most of his time trying to convince Rocky to get him a job with Tony to get him out of his meat packing job.
Essentially, the first hour of the film is a portrait of Rocky, his lonely life, and his early courtship with Adrian. It's a warm portrait of a bum, a guy who has something within him to make something of himself, but who has never applied himself quite right, as Mickey (Burgess Meredith) ends up saying, that he has wasted his potential on a little life in service of someone like Tony. He's also kind of dumb with the kinds of street smarts that at least allow him to acknowledge that he's made bad decisions in the past about who he had spent time with, as he outlines in a little rambling speech to a girl hanging out with the wrong crowd.
He gets his chance, though, when the heavyweight champion of the world, Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers) has spent too much time and too much money prepping for a bicentennial fight that is at the risk of cancellation because his opponent has a broken hand. With only five weeks to train, he can't get anyone ranked to commit to the fight, so he and the promoter George Jergen (Thayer David) decide on finding a local boy in Philadelphia to fight, zeroing in on Balboa for little reason more than his nickname, the Italian Stallion. He's reticent about the prospect. Rocky understands his limits and Creed's status as the best in the world, but it becomes too good of an opportunity to pass up.
I think one of the keys to how this film works is the timing of certain events. The first is that Adrian and Rocky have their moment coming together, learning to open up to each other and fall in love, before Rocky gets his shot. This cements her as the one person he knows he can trust, as contrasted with Paulie who only seems to get helpful afterwards, hoping for a slice of the guaranteed $150,000 payout from the fight, or Mickey, who had told him off before the offer and comes begging to be his manager afterwards. After years of being rejected and used and insulted, Rocky has trouble trusting anyone, and he does eventually find ways to bring people in.
And that's really the point of the film. It's not the literal fight with Creed, it's Rocky discovering his connections to other people who do genuinely love him, namely Adrian. It's about him discovering for himself that he's not a bum and that he could go the distance against Creed, last all fifteen rounds. It's not about winning. It's about proving that he belongs in that field, that he hasn't wasted the last six years of his life fighting to get nowhere. It's weird how a film where the hero doesn't actually win a fight can end up so affirming.
I will say for a moment, that I found the direction rather pedestrian at best. I wouldn't really comment on it much normally, except that Avildsen won Best Director at the Oscars. I have no problem with Rocky winning Best Picture, I'd probably have voted for it, but I cannot imagine Avildsen deserving that Best Director award, especially up against Syndey Lumet for Network. I often at least partially attribute good performances to directors who can help mold the work of actors, so I cannot dismiss him completely here. The actors are all very good, and that's part of the package, but this really does feel like, overall, Avildsen getting a raw and very good script fall into his lap and largely just not screwing it up. I'm fine with that as a result, but it just kind of irritates me that Avildsen beat Lumet.
I don't think that Avildsen's direction is a drag on the film, though. It's nothing special, but the strength is the script and performances, and they really get a lot of help from Conti's score. I have a major soft spot for Conti's music (like on Huston's Escape to Victory), and it's largely absent from the first hour, only getting an early show during the opening credits before slowly filtering in towards the buildup to the fight. Of course, the fight itself isn't the point, it's Rocky proving himself, and that's the ultimately victory. That it becomes so satisfying is really wonderful.
Just, please, don't make any sequels, Sly. Rocky doesn't need it.

One of Sylvester Stallone's best films put him on the map, and launched a very successful franchise. Stallone wrote and stars as Rocky Balboa, a down-and-out fighter getting beat up in smoky clubs for chump change. He has a love/hate relationship with his friend Paulie (Burt Young), loves Paulie's sister Adrian (Talia Shire), and enforces payments to loan shark Gazzo (Joe Spinell). Heavyweight champion Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers) is looking for a title fight to celebrate the nation's bicentennial, but his opponent drops out. He and promoter Jergens (Thayer David) cook up a plan- give any mook a shot at the champ, in the name of the American way. Balboa is chosen, and Creed goes about the financial business of being a champ, not taking Rocky seriously. Rocky enlists the help of Mickey (Burgess Meredith), a gym owner who saw Rocky's potential many years before, but the two never acted on it. As the fight draws near, Rocky's relationship with Paulie deteriorates as his love for Adrian takes center stage.\nI had not seen the original "Rocky" in decades. I highly recommend the crisp widescreen DVD transfer, which puts all the videotape releases to shame. I literally forgot what a dark and grim film this is. Rocky's Philadelphia neighborhood is a bit run down, his apartment is a pit, and director John G. Avildsen captures it all perfectly, which is strange considering the almost comic book style of the sequels. Stallone does a fine scripting job. While Rocky's relationship with Adrian takes a while, and the volatile Paulie is never explored too much, Stallone seems to know what the film audience wants. I always thought the fight at the end of the film was longer, but it barely makes ten or fifteen minutes. Weathers' Apollo is not as big a jerk as I remember, until he gets into the ring and must put on his show. Adrian could not be mousier, even with Mickey ears and a tail, but her transformation is believable without being jarring. Young and Meredith also turn in fine performances, not yet the one dimensional characters the sequels would turn them in to. "Rocky" is not a excellent film. It is certainly a strong film, full of solid acting, writing, and directing. While I cannot fault any one ingredient for keeping it from being perfect, I do highly recommend it.

I had no high expectations before watching Rocky, actually we could say that I had some preconceptions about it, being a gen z girl, but man, was I wrong!\nThis movie kept my attention high from start to finish, and got me to keep thriving for the protagonist, impersonated by an amazing Silvester Stallone. Rocky, as I found, is not the stereotypical macho figure you might think: even though he is a boxer with the classic ''tough guy" look, he often shows his most sensitive and fragile sides, which makes him a role model in many ways. I really liked the way they developed his love story with Adriana, because this side storyline was made almost as important as the main one, creating some balance and avoiding making it an action movie.\nEven though the movie came out in 1976 it is still perfectly enjoyable and the values it conveys are still relevant to our society nowadays, which to me makes it a timeless classic.

So, hot take and I am not going to make many friends with this one... I don't think Rocky is very good. It's filmed on a shoestring budget, it seems. Stallone's "acting" is obnoxious. Adrian is a dead fish with zero personality or energy that he basically stalks. Carl Weathers is the best part of this movie and the only thing in it worth watching.\nI do give it credit for the ending. I knew it was coming, but considering when this came out I'm impressed they ended it like they did. Maybe that's part of the problem. This movie has been hyped up to me my whole life. Rocky is this great bit of pop culture history, something I had never seen and now, finally marking it off the list and frankly, I was bored. I wanted it to be over. I imagine if I had the nostalgia to back it up, maybe this would be a different story but without that, it was really an underwhelming flick.

I don't know what it is about 70's movies that I feel attracted to so much but I think it has to do with the gritty look and feel. They usually have this raw, genuine and unflinching feel to them that is so gripping to watch. It's the handheld camera sort of feel and the lack of screen filters that I find refreshing. This movie is no exception to that. I would even say it's one of the grittiest-looking movies I've ever seen. It's impressive to think that Sylvester wrote the whole story for this movie. The dialogue and the way a lot of the characters interact with one another is fantastic - some of it is actually pretty clever and funny. The chemistry between the actors feels great, it's a good energy. Sylvester definitely has a charm and charisma and it shows. I really liked Adrian, the shy girl Rocky ends up falling for - she was really cute. And Pauly is hilarious. This is one of the best underdog stories ever. It's about a humble guy with a good heart and a natural talent who's going nowhere in life but gets his big break, an opportunity of a lifetime. It's an inspirational and feel-good movie with a good heart. The cinematography was actually beautifully done - very well thought out. Especially the shots of the city and environment. It was kind of cheesy how Rocky would walk around everywhere punching the air, but I guess it adds to his characters charm. That last training sequence will forever be iconic and I can see why it's such a staple in pop culture. I can't believe it took me 32 years to watch this movie, but I'm glad I finally did. I enjoyed it and I can see why it's so iconic and so well-regarded.

Rocky is a 1976 sports drama about a boxing nobody who one day gets an opportunity to take on the world heavyweight champion.\nSylvester Stallone wrote a fabulous story and created a wonderful, now iconic character in Rocky Balboa, and John G. Avildsen also did a fantastic job directing this sports classic.\nThe movie is down to earth and really lets you get to know the characters driving the story. The whole cast is great, the film builds great suspense leading up to the final showdown, and the end leaves you wanting more. If you've never seen this film before, I'd highly recommend checking it out.

Where to start...!
Rocky is so beautifully written, composed, acted and directed that you get lost in the rocky world for days!
It's a journey of a man's life who shows you that you can achieve the impossible and the one's you love the most is your biggest support.
The simplicity of Adrian and the love of Rocky for her is so beautifully written and done that it's almost mesmerizing. Rocky & Adrian are one of the best couples in cinematic history.
There are very few movies that live up with you forever, this is by far at the top for me and am quite sure for many.
There is no end to Rocky!
Keep punching!

Forget its 2010 reboot/remake, this is probably one of the best 1980s films of all time. About years ago I watched some bits of it on TV3 (now Virgin Media One) and I thought I never saw any 1980s films like that before in my entire life. In late 2014, I watched the whole film on DVD. It's brilliant and the acting is very good especially from Ralph Macchio, Pat Morita, William Zobka snd Elizabeth Shue themselves. It never gets old and it will always be a timeless classic.\nI'd say it's definitely way better than its 2010 reboot/remake which is kinda boring and it's not great as its original 1984 version.\nIf you are a fan of karate films, you'll like this.

A Superb film. The Karate Kid comes onto 4K blu ray with a lovely authentic transfer. The film retains all the grain and grit of a film shot in the 80s. Colours look lovely and natural, scenes shot at night get quite grainy but those filmed in the bright sunshine of California pack lots of colour and detail. The acting is superb, the casting also is great, the teenagers all actually look like teenagers in this film. Everything just feels nice and natural, the editing is good, the clothes and music are so 1980s. The lighting and fog on the beach when the boys on their motorbikes make their entrance, with the music playing alone is so iconic. There is some clever subtext in this film about family and also social class. There's also a strong underdog element to the film and the fight choreography is fantastic. The dialogue feels natural and casual, never rehearsed or forced.

It's a solid movie, Miyagi is a great character, he's got fantastic dialogue. Daniel isn't perfect. He's a bit prickly and ungrateful to Ali, it's a part of his defense mechanism, but it does make for some uncomfortable scenes.\nThe movie doesn't impart any profound life lessons on viewers, but there's enough to be heartwarming and enjoyable. Action in this movie is OK. It's just barely passable, but this was made in the 80s, so I'll take what I can get. Soundtrack is pretty solid, some good tunes matched up to the scenes.\nEnding and resolution are abrupt, probably the weakest part of the movie but at least it makes for a happy ending.

The Karate Kid is not just an iconic 80s movie. It's a well-made film which tells a timeless story that has stayed in the hearts & minds of viewers since it was released. I'm surprised by how well it holds up. This movie even kept my youngest kids engaged almost the entire time. Ralph Macchio is absolutely relatable as the timid Daniel LaRusso and William Zabka plays a villain you love to hate. Most of the magic, though, comes from Pat Morita as Mr. Miyagi. He portrays a mentor for the ages, full of wisdom & warmth. It's nice to see that The Karate Kid is still able to compete with modern movies.

This franchise was in my watchlist for a long time and today I finally decided to start watching the franchise movies.\nFor me, the movie was full on entertainment. It was same 80s flicks with an addition of karate in it. The story was simple, lovely and effective, the screenplay was good, the direction was good but could have been more better and the performances were good. You connect with the both lead actors. One thing I wanted to talk about was the climax which felt rushed to me, it could have been 10-15 minutes more longer.\nOverall, it's a good movie and you should definitely give this movie a try.

(1984) The Karate Kid\nDRAMA ACTION\nPopular during it's time, self- indulgent teen flick with a too simplistic story line starring Ralph Macchio as Danial who's antagonized by another fellow martial arts student Johnny (William Zabka) after he falls for his girlfriend, Ali (Elisabeth Shue). Daniel then gets taken under an older Japanese elder, Miyagi ( Noriyuki 'Pat' Morita) whose actually a karate instructor. To say anything more is ridiculous because you can pretty much know how this story is going to turn out. After looking back at it, this film is very tame in today's standards because I seen more effective martial art movies than this, where the action is plentiful and the training is vigorously harder to do. The more I think about this film the more simplistic it reminded me something from a ''Sunday Afternoon Special'

This is a sensational film. This is a film for all viewers to watch and enjoy. The cast selection was brilliant. The storyline was truly great and reveals to viewers multiple things. The cast really committed to the storyline and to their respective characters. The chemistry and connection between was really strong. This film reveals to viewers that it is possible for anyone to do anything in life. It also reveals the full limits of strength and courage. I have had a lot of troubles in my life. I was bullied too much growing up. This film also reveals to viewers the reality of growing up. This is an absolutely tremendous film for everyone to watch, enjoy, and learn.

FILM: 7.5/10.
I just revisited The Karate Kid from 1984, and it's safe to say it's still got that classic charm. The heart of the film, a story centered on an unlikely friendship that bridges the gap of ages and cultures, continues to resonate with me. Pat Morita's portrayal of Mr. Miyagi is an absolute standout. His ability to teach Ralph Macchio's character, Daniel, not only the art of fighting but also the deeper philosophy and patience behind it is truly impressive.
Directed by John G. Avildsen, the creative mind behind the camera for Rocky, the movie carries a familiar underdog vibe that I've always appreciated. It's evident that the DNA of his earlier 1976 film is imprinted on The Karate Kid, from the training montages to the triumphant journey that leaves you rooting for the protagonist.
While the film mostly hits the mark, there are moments where the pacing falters. This, combined with some clichÃ©d dialogue and stereotypical story beats hold the film back from outright glory. However, considering the film's vintage, some of these elements kind of add to its nostalgic charm.
The training and tournament scenes are where the movie truly shines, keeping me engaged and invested in Daniel's growth. The relationship developed over the course of the film enhances the emotional impact of these pivotal moments, reminding me why this film became such a classic in the first place.
Ultimately, The Karate Kid continues to hold its own, delivering powerful messages about mentorship, friendship, and self-discovery. Despite its minor flaws, it remains a must-watch for anyone who enjoys martial arts, life lessons, and a dash of 80s nostalgia. Its enduring appeal remains, and the invaluable wisdom shared by Mr. Miyagi continues to be a highlight.
FORMAT: 4K Ultra HD Blu-ray
VIDEO: 9.5/10.
Native 4K presentation, Detail level: Excellent, Colour reproduction: Excellent, Level accuracy: Excellent, Encode: Excellent, Master condition: Excellent
AUDIO: 9/10.
Dolby Atmos audio, Dialogue reproduction: Excellent, Soundtrack & effects clarity: Good, Dynamics: Excellent, Surround sound presentation: Excellent, LFE content: Good
MOOFIEMETER: 8/10.

When I first watched The Karate Kid I absolutely loved it and watching the Cobra Kai series just amplified my love for it. Not only is this a great coming-of-age story, but it's a very competent sport and underdog story that is so fittingly directed by the man who created the quintessential underdog sports film, Rocky.
Pat Morita is so great as Mr Miyagi and his chemistry with Ralph Macchio who gives a more than competent performance as Daniel LaRusso is the beating heart of the film. Throughout the entire film, there wasn't one moment where I wasn't convinced these two were like father and son, sure some cheesy moments arise due to this but I'd be lying if I said I wasn't smiling whenever they were together.
I like how the main character isn't your ideal lead, especially in a sports film, Daniel LaRusso is a lanky and unwealthy teenager that has no father and rough origins that are exacerbated by bullying when he leaves Newark for California. He befriends the maintenance guy at his residence who eventually teaches him karate and becomes a role model and a father figure in his life. He's someone that people can easily relate to especially when you throw in his complicated love life.
The soundtrack for the film is just as good as the training montages which are a joy to watch. Some of the fighting scenes at the tournament were unconvincing but I'm just glad that most of it was convincing, especially the final. The Karate Kid is definitely one of my favourite films ever.

It's tough for Daniel, a teenager, who's moved with his mother from New Jersey to California, unable to fit in, Daniel is bullied and beaten by a group of boys from a local karate school. Daniel is rescued, mentored and trained by Mr Miyagi, Daniel gets a shot at taking on the bullies at their own game.
This one one of my favourite films growing up, it really is a triumph over adversity story, with Daniel taking it straight to those that bullied him, and turning the tables.
If you're a fan of those feel good 80's movies, then I'm convinced that you'll enjoy this, it really is an easy going, uplifting experience. It's loaded with iconic scenes, such as wax on, wax off and the ultimate kick scene. This film is definitely worth your time.
This film helped bring a martial arts story to the masses, prior to that, you could argue that many of the martial arts themed films had something of a niche appeal,
It always saddened me that Ralph Macchio didn't have a great career after this film, you would have thought that this would have set him up, it didn't, fortunately Cobra Kai had helped to redress the balance.
The follow up films and the remake are all below average, and perhaps better off avoided, if you've not seen Cobra Kai, I would recommend it, it truly is the great follow up that this film deserved.
Worth seeing.
8/10.

To start this is not the best film I have seen or even in that category but the emotions it brought in me were do strong that I had to rate higher then I would have if I based it on just as a film alone, probably would have rated it an 8. This film is the perfect example of what the highly touted iconic words "The American Dream" stands for. You got a very highly skilled football player who had a very bright future, finds a beautiful & supportive significant partner, but then everything came crashing down early on & along the way hes lost in his downward spiral, barely hanging on & struggling. We get to see the hardships endured by Kurt, while he forges deeper bonds with so many around him.
Whether minor characters or major characters you get to witness enter his life & its as if each of them were meant to be Gods hand in pushing Kurt on the right track, no matter if its just simple words of encouragement or new opportunities that come knocking. Who doesn't love an underdog story anyway?? We always hear the successes n glamour of big sports stars but its not everyday u get to see a film dedicated to showing what it was like for them in their path climbing upwards & it has the love stories, the friendship bonds, it is so inspiring honestly while watching this.
To be clear Football isn't even my top 3 sports I like lol & though I do watch the Super bowls & sometimes the playoffs too, but after watching this film it totally makes me want to watch football lol. Though I obviously logically knew how the film plays out, but I felt shivers & chills course through my body, full of excitement & energy as you watch the underdog trying to claw its way back up with everything to lose on the line & making his last push towards success... it was heartwarming honestly.
Oh ya Great acting by uh the Shazam guy & awesome acting by the woman that plays his wife. If you lookin for something to pick yourself up when you're in a slump, losing faith, on a losing streak... I totally recommend this film to boost yourself up because while some of the facts of this film dont line up exactly to how his career actually started but I think thats not important cuz the main point of the story is showing what perseverance can do for someone even when they are at their rock bottom with no hope in sight, sometimes a Hail Mary can light their life up in 1 moment.

Who pays to all these members giving it 9-10 !?!?!? It is 100th time of these kind of stories in a movie even though this one is based on true events.\nMovie is maybe 4*, bad plot, very bad actors, only camera is okish. Check what masterpieces from Denzel have 7+ and then come back to this junk, it is done so poor, cant believe 20k people gave it 7.\nAvoid it even if it is free, go watch some rerun of some good movie. There is barely any good movies out here these days but as a rule, if it is on Netflix then it is pure junk, Netflix movie has like 1 of 1000 that it can be called good movie, everything else is wasting time.

We've always loved sports movies, often baseball, but American Football works just as well. Not huge stars, although well known (Shazam, The Piano) and of course the wonderful Denis Quaid, but great casting and they work well together. It's a love story too, so something for the romantics amongst us, but like the name of the film, it's a story of adversity and living your dream. It's a super little film and we are so glad we found it. Especially after some of the dire movies that have been showing recently, and the constant super heroes that we see (I'm not adverse to DC or Marvel), but sometimes, you just want something well acted, with a great story, likeable characters - a film you can invest in without browsing on your device. Enjoy!

Such an inspiring movie for anyone that feels like the underdog in any dream they are aspiring to achieve! Believe in yourself and others will believe in you too! Never give up! Give God the Glory when he blesses you with your dreams! This movie brought me to tears of joy! I love football and enjoyed every moment of this movie! It is a must watch. I am not sure why it is not rated much higher. It deserves ten stars! With every dream comes challenges and sometimes we have to change paths to get there but we eventually get there with God's help! God is with you every step of the way! Thank you for this ðŸ¿, I loved it.

Just endure long introduction, this beginning will help you understand the present and empathize with it. Great sports drama! This is an inspiring picture! A dream can come true, you just need to believe and not give up. The hero will have difficulties and, most importantly, this is a story about a real person! When I remember this movie, I want to cry tears of joy, but don't believe me verbatim. :) The viewer together with the hero of this film will be confused, then he will struggle with life's difficulties, and then he will win! - A real classic hero's way! This is one of the best Zachary Levi movie roles!

I'm a sucker for sports movies, I truly enjoy them despite the common tropes and clichÃ©s that they fall into. American Underdog is different I would argue because the theme of faith makes up the foundation of the film, while not being overwhelming or preachy. Sporting an all-star cast that all give great performances, this film manages to avoid most of the cheesiness often associated with both sports and faith-based films. Sharing the inspiring story of Kurt Warner and his quest to make it to the NFL, this story of perseverance and heart will make for a great time with the family.\nWhat were your thoughts on the film?

Based on a true story, American Underdog is a wonderful and uplifting story about QB Kurt Warner's struggles and challenges he had getting to the NFL.
Growing up, Kurt Warner always dreamed of playing in the NFL. He watched Super Bowl XIX and he decides that he will play in the NFL and win a Super Bowl and MVP.
So years later Kurt is the quarterback for the University of Northern Iowa. He plays 5 years and he has very good stats as the starting quarterback. He is so sure he will be picked in the NFL draft... But one team after another, every team passes him over.
Kurt went through several NFL tryouts with various teams but to no avail. So Kurt goes to work for a local grocery store. But he never gave up, and gets a offer to play Arena Football. Kurt became a star QB of that league. He even made the Arena Football Hall of Fame.
Soon Kurt's fame spread and reaches the NFL scouts. Finally the door is open to his dream. Dick Vermeil, coach of the Rams goes against his entire staff and signs Kurt Warner as the Rams backup quarterback.
"I just want my shot. I want one chance to prove that I'm good enough" - Kurt
When the Rams starting QB is injured, Kurt steps in and becomes the starter. Oh and not just a starting QB, Kurt won a Super Bowl, Super Bowl MVP, and NFL MVP.
As much as Kurt loves playing football and receiving all the awards. He placed his family first and gives them credit, having the people you love to stand by you through all the struggles.
"It doesn't mean anything if you don't have someone to share it with" - Kurt
I really enjoined this underdog movie. A bit rare and unique for a football movie... And even if you are not a football fan, this is a really awesome feel-good underdog story. I do wish there more films like this.

As a European i can see this as a 'true' American story.
Just a shame that the left out the part where he played in NFL Europe with the Amsterdam Admirals.
I was at all the games but guess it was a phantom on the field and not Kurt Warner...
True story it is not, it is shortened and adapted for making an entertaining movie.
So when you watch this keep that in mind.
Fact is he did not come on the team the season they went to the superbowl.
That was his 2nd season with the team and between 98-99 he played the season in NFL Europe.
It is said his wife hated the godless city of Amsterdam so it could be 1 of the reasons they left that part out.

Rare nowadays to see a clean movie of nice things people doing their best to do good. Honesty. Integrity. Beautiful human piece. Yea the ending is happy. But the pathway was long and hard and it is clear that all involved appreciate and acknowledge it. Watch it with your family. Solid acting. Includes a clear religious undertone but it is not explicit nor uncomfortable for any viewer. Watch to the end of the credits to see a great clip of the son Zak and what that amazing couple did for him and the challenged adults. Again watch this with your own family and enjoy good clean values and morality.

The movie is solid and a feel good as it should be.
BUT and this is a big BUT!
The casting is catastrophic!
40 year old actors plays 25 years old. It is not realistic at all. Brenda has two kids from earlier marriage with the same man but they have different ethnicity.
Not knowing anything about Kurt I needed to use Google to understand that he was not a middle age man that got his chance of his life (like Invincible). If they had found 25 year old actors it would have been more realistic that it could be though to get date a girl with 2 kids. For a 40 year old it is a totally normal situation...
Sorry but it ruined the movie.

After being defeated by the New York Yankees in the 2001 play-offs, losing three of his key players to bigger contracts at richer clubs, and then being refused more funds for new players by the club's owner, Oakland Athletics general manager Billy Beane (played by Brad Pitt) hires an inexperienced Yale economics graduate (Jonah Hill) and starts utilizing hard statistics (now known as sabermetrics) to recruit specialized talent who are seemingly over the hill or has another defect which have made them unattractive to other clubs. Will this novel and - to many - controversial approach pay off?\nIn form and structure, Moneyball is a familiar underdog story which have been known to work ever so well many times before on the big-screen. However, this is no Rocky with lots of action and simple, emotional dialogue. And it's no Youngblood style of film in which the game itself is simplified to attract "regular" viewers. On the contrary, Moneyball is something as rare as a sports film about numbers and tactics. It's not only based on real-life people and events, but it also treats and presents these people and events accordingly, and not through a conventionalized archetype-filter. A film as technical and theory-oriented as this one may sound inaccessible to outsiders, but as a typical European soccer-fan with minimal knowledge about the game of baseball, I say on the contrary. This is a breath of fresh air in a world of movie-making which often underestimates its viewers. Moneyball is a detailed and fairly fast-paced account from an environment about which the filmmakers are never afraid to be specific and comprehensive. And this works as a perfect counterweight to the heart and moral of the story, which is undeniably simplistic, but also inherently beautiful.\nBrad Pitt gives arguably the best performance of his career as real-life GM Billy Beane. His performance has a drive and a carefreeness which I haven't seen in Pitt for years, and combined with appropriate mannerisms and a clearly deep understanding of the character, he gives the film the momentum it needs. Jonah Hill and Philip Seymour Hoffman complement him with fine supporting work in a film which puts Aaron Sorkin's edgy dialogue to the best use that it has been since A Few Good Men. And the fine directing job is credited to Bennett Miller (of Capote) and he conveys the script, which Sorkin co-wrote with Steve Zaillian, with a clear focus about what he wants to accomplish, handling the sentimental and the bittersweet with equal aptitude.

"Moneyball" is a sports film that revolves around the efforts of Oakland A's general manager Billy Beane, portrayed by Brad Pitt. Beane attempts to build a competitive baseball team while working with a tight budget. He employs innovative methods to acquire new players. Now, after this brief introduction, "Moneyball" firmly falls into the 'Sports' genre, a genre well-known for its predictable narrative arc. In such stories, underdog teams must struggle relentlessly to achieve what nobody believes they can. This formula has a long history of success because everyone enjoys a compelling comeback story from time to time.\nThe film shines primarily due to its exceptional ensemble cast, featuring outstanding performances by Brad Pitt, Jonah Hill, and the legendary Philip Seymour Hoffman. They are the driving force behind this film, making it worth a watch.\n"Moneyball" is a deliberately paced and grounded film. It maintains a clear sense of identity, avoiding the grandiose moments that some might expect. It stands as a well-acted film with an ideal pace and tone, emphasizing its strengths while leaving behind the repetitive elements often associated with the 'Sports' genre.

...who either likes baseball or who doesn't watch baseball. It is something that can entertain the most unknowledgeable viewer in terms of baseball.\nBrad Pitt and Jonah Hill deliver excellent performances and their chemistry really shows throughout the whole film. Brad Pitt especially delivers a convincing performance as Billy Beane. The film approaches sports in an analytic point of view while still showing the baseball being played. The music score will give you goosebumps in some scene and it's a film that I come back to watch time after time. To balance out the drama, there are some comedic moments scattered around in the film.\nThis is one to watch for sure.

Moneyball.
Oakland A's general manager Billy Beane's successful attempt to assemble a baseball team on a lean budget by employing computer-generated analysis to acquire new players.
I'm really astonished how a movie about baseball is that interesting and fun to watch, considering that I know nothing about it nor the numbers they were discussing most of the time.
So, this movie can be people like me as much as baseball fans and that couldn't be possible without the well-written dialogs by Aaron Sorkin and especially Brad Pitt's performance, he literally can fit any given role.
This movie present also a very important subject, which is youth and science vs experience and rituals .
The exploitation of statistics in different fields can be a game changer as a revolutionary step that a lot of sport club are taking and it had so many great outcomes through the years.
I forgot to mention that Jonah Hill was great too.

This is the only movie I have ever seen where the movie actually was better than the book (And the book was great - Thank you Michael Lewis!)
While there are some subtleties that the non-baseball fan will miss, the basic theme of changing old philosophies reasonates. Does not matter if is technology, the arts, or even a game as old as baseball, change is inevitable but even harder to implement.
A rare gem thst transcends the sports and allows all viewers to appreciate the resiliency to "stick your guns" when everybody says u r crazy.
I cannot recommend this movie enough to all the non- baseball fans out there. This movie is first and foremost a triumph for anybody who thinks outside the box and does not conform to the masses.
Brad Pitt and Jonah Hill are amazing. Phillip Seymour's genius- his non verbal actions- are all the more reason to ache for his talent which was taken far too early from all of us.
4 out of 4 Stars.

REDUX (08/15/2023)
Rating: 9.3
Overall, my favorite pure sports movie as this incredible underdog story uses writing, acting, and score to help make the audience feel invested in the team's journey, though its tone and historical inaccuracies hold it back from being incredible.
Very Good to Great Direction (Nothing extraordinary about the directing style but does a very good job at moving the story forward and getting the most out of the actors (Plays a lot into dramatic tropes in directing)), Very Good Acting (Great from Brad Pitt (A very calculated performance as he used his experience as a leading man to drive the movie forward), Very Good from Jonah Hill (A very soft-spoken role that is a departure from his previous work, but he does a very good job in playing off of Pitt throughout the movie (especially capturing the anxious/nerdy parts of the character); the main issue with the performance is that it is very limiting (so Jonah Hill really cannot show that much off)), Good to Very Good from Philip Seymour Hoffman (Uses experience to play this role as his character seems more like a cameo than a central figure (but he does a very good job in holding his own and building tension with Pitt)), Good to Very Good from the rest of the cast (Everyone plays their role very well as they all come together to be this island of misfit toys that can be pushed to greatness)), Great Story (Story is laid out incredibly as it chooses the right elements to focus on; the main issue with the story is its factual inaccuracies as it deviates from the truth for no reason (as simple searches will show where they are making things up); Great character writing as it does a great job exploring the demons of every character and how almost everyone has something to prove), Great to Incredible Screenplay (The dialogue flows incredibly well and is very iconic (but there are some lines that are a bit questionable), the symbolism is incredibly profound as it helps with driving the message forward; foreshadowing was good as a biopic could be), Great Score (An iconic theme that is used very well throughout the movie), Great Cinematography (The best moment is during the streak but overall captures the movie very well), Very Good Sound (The pop off the ball helps with portraying some symbols and elements of the movie), Great Editing (Really enjoyed how they used the grainy TV screen for flashbacks and how they interpolated old footage into the film), Very Good Costumes, Plot Structure was incredible as it does a great job at setting up the different plot elements and uses the individual story elements very well to help with driving the movie forward, Pacing was a bit on the slower side (but this is more from the tone); runtime is fine as every scene is used well, Climax was great as the movie ends how it is supposed to end as this helps with showing its meaning, Tone was a bit on the blander side as there is just a bit of some dead-air (though overall it can combat this with great writing and great scenes)
ORIGINAL (06/13/2017)
Rating: 9.4
Great Acting, Great Story, Great Screenplay but some lines are questionable, Great Score, Very Relatable Movie, Great Job exploring the demons of every character and how almost everyone has something to prove, Ending was kinda out of place.

This sports drama represents the peak of the American indie cinema movement of the early 21st century led by Newline Cinema but not without affecting the rhythm and tone of the film. It portrays a sociopath baseball coach (Pitt) with bigger dreams than his university skills can allow. And so he spends most of his time lobbying for a sponsorship for a pathetic team of boys and for some salvation along the way in a moneyballed league. The film then circles around to focus not on the rules of the game but more on the human side to life. It grows out of its immature shell exactly as the director wants and to the approval of the audience into serious and compelling cinema.\nThe film balances itself solely on the experienced shoulders of Brad Pitt. A word must be said about how impactful the acting is as he emotes his way through the crisis that he does not deserve. Moneyball is a tearful script but still a badly made film. It has ordinary lines and the scenes drag themselves with no special effort from the director and his team and it seems as if Pitt should be encouraging them instead of the players. Sadly in this case, it is just not uplifting enough.\nA poignant thought arises about the two important dimensions of any game, the unbroken will of an individual and the sacrifices that are made by members of a team. Moneyball hints at these qualities as it seeks to elucidate the tenets of human adventurism. The theme of the film unaltered, it falls into the list of the stoic Clint Eastwood hero but very much for the new age in this case.

As we all know, the best films that revolve around a particular sport are the ones that can be shown to anyone and they'd still enjoy themselves. This is what Moneyball got right thanks to great performances all around from Brad Pitt, Jonah Hill, the late Phillip Seymour Hoffman and an excellent child's turn from Kerris Dorsey.\nSome serious credit must also be given to Wally Pfister who shot the film with such detail, cleverness and expressiveness that almost each and every shot conveys the story of each scene perfectly.\nMoneyball is a sports drama that others within the genre should take notes from and has a screenplay that ranks among some of the best that I have come across.

I've seen a game of baseball at the Yankee Stadium. I do not understand the scoring and so I have no idea how it came to be that the Yankees won the game.
Notwithstanding my limited knowledge of the sport I really enjoyed this movie. The performances of Hill and Hoffman are far and away my favourite performances by those actors. I think Hoffman, for the role he was in, was perhaps a rather quirky piece of casting. But he was perfect.
Brad Pitt was also very effective and believable both in his exchanges with colleagues and in the few scenes with family.
The film is mainly about taking on the doctrines of the old guard with a new approach to finding wins. But against that backdrop, there are good scenes of humour and humanity.

This is a movie about baseball set in the America of the years around 2000 when the clash between teams Oakland Atheletics and NY Yankees was in progress. GM of the Oakland team Billy Beane ( Brad Pitt) is in conflict with his scout group due his disagreement over selection of players. He feels that the methods used are outdated and subjective.( Scouts would typically use 5 tools for evaluation, that is can he run, field, throw , hit and hit with power ? ) Billy meets smart young Peter Brand ( Jonah Hill), a Yale economics graduate who uses saber economics methods rather than discussion and brain storming to evaluate the players. Using economics and statistics Billy and Peter then form a team to weed out non effective players and recruit lower valued but promising players much to the displeasure of their scouts group. Initially there are reverses ( teething problems ) but things start looking up with many wins along the way.\nDirector Bennet Miller uses the talents of both Brad and Jonah to set up an engaging narrative of plans, promises,efforts, firings, recruitments, conflicts, victory, defeat ,frustration etc. There are interesting scenes on what happens behind the scenes during formation of baseball teams with budget constraints and the strategies used in order to win. Brad Pitt performs superbly as the impatient, curt, terse, animated, GM who won't accept no for an anwer.( I hate losing ,he says). He doesn't watch matches himself in a type of superstition. His love for baseball makes him say " How can you not be romantic about baseball ?. Brad must have a scene in his films where he is eating, has his mouth full and says his dialogue. This also happens in a scene in this movie. Matching Brad is the cool and calculating ( pun intended) Jonah Hill whose understated dialogue delivery is very effective. Both Brad and Jonah have given award worthy performances and were rightly nominated.

The 2013 "Rush" from director Ron Howard is a high-quality and soulful film that demonstrates the exciting story, adrenaline of Formula 1 racing and human drama. This picture was even nominated in the Best Film category at the Golden Globe Awards, but lost to the film 12 Years a Slave. A serious opponent who could not be bypassed. Nevertheless, Howard's project became a memorable work in the careers of all involved.
In the "Rush", the excellent acting and successful directorial vision create a rich and exciting world. Chris Hemsworth as James Hunt and Daniel Bruhl as Niki Lauda go beyond the simple embodiment of the characters, and their characters come to life. Charismatic characters allow the viewer to feel the inner fire of rivalry and passion for victory.
Hemsworth, known for his appearance and charm, convincingly conveys the passion and audacity of his character, creating an image of an intriguing and often uncomfortable hero for others. Involuntarily, a comparison with the famous hero Thor, whom Hemsworth has been playing for many years, suggests itself. Here, under the appearance of Thor, there is a completely different character, into which the actor has so successfully reincarnated. Chris's excellent performance, a worthy role that will forever remain in his career as one of the strongest.
Daniel Bruhl as Niki Lauda perfectly conveys the character of this legendary racer. His acting work is characterized by precision and depth, revealing not only Lauda's professional qualities, but also his inner world, including difficult moments in his personal life.
The script of the film is masterfully written, paying attention not only to racing and high speed, but also to the deep human relationships underlying the story. This balance between competition and friendship creates a touching and exciting aspect that manages to be conveyed in every frame.
Technically, the painting was created with great care. Decent editing and soundtrack give the film a special status, taking it to a new level, especially in the racing scenes, where the viewer almost physically feels the speed and adrenaline.
Especially impressive is the attention to detail in the visual design of the film, recreating the style of the 1970s. Costumes, cars, scenery - everything embodies the atmosphere of that era and gives the film a unique character. And the color correction is deliberately specially selected in such a way that the viewer feels like he is watching a 1970s movie.
But, of course, one of the main achievements of the "Rush" is the exciting racing scenes. They not only immerse the viewer into the world known even to people who are not interested in Formula 1, but also convey the extreme sensations and risks associated with this sport.
Ron Howard's compositional work is an art that can pull the viewer into the dynamic world of race tracks and at the same time remain true to the deep human aspects of the story. The director's vision of the director deserves the highest praise. He expertly handles Peter Morgan's script, immersing the viewer in the intriguing world of Formula 1 and at the same time paying attention to human relationships. Howard emphasizes emotional moments and moves from exciting racing scenes to deep reflections of the characters with ease, as if playfully, not allowing the viewer to understand where the transition from action to drama and back happens.
The director not only gives the viewer the opportunity to feel the adrenaline of racing, but also delves into the psychology and motivation of the characters. He carefully balanced the dynamic racing moments with the touching and meaningful scenes between Hunt and Lauda, creating a harmonious piece.
The painting is remembered for another important aspect - the work of Hans Zimmer. It has long been no secret to me that the projects to which the composer puts his hand are literally doomed to success. I love Zimmer's music, and it's very good here. The musical work in the film adds an additional layer of emotional saturation and enhances the visual range.
Hans Zimmer, known for his unique style and sense of rhythm, created a soundtrack that perfectly matches the dynamics of the racing scenes and at the same time skillfully emphasizes the internal conflicts of the characters. His compositions in the film seem to become a separate character who actively interacts with the plot and conveys subtle interweaving of emotions. The picture is not limited only to visual and acting aspects, but also includes the musical magic of Hans Zimmer.
"Rush" is not just an ordinary film about professionals driving, of which there are probably a dozen. This is a great real story about friendship, passion, overcoming oneself and difficulties. Director Ron Howard has created a work that can delight and inspire, even those who are not fans of the world of racing. The painting is still remembered with interest, even a decade after viewing. This is an exciting journey that leaves an indelible impression and causes deep admiration for the work of the entire team, and, most importantly, opens up the real stories of Niki Lauda and James Hunt for the average viewer.
9 out of 10.

In the mid-1970s, charismatic English playboy James Hunt (Chris Hemsworth) and Austrian perfectionist Niki Lauda (Daniel BrÃ¼hl) share an intense rivalry in Formula 1 racing. Driving vehicles that are little more than gas-filled, rolling bombs, Hunt and Lauda burn up the track, all the while pushing themselves to the breaking point of physical and mental endurance. Meanwhile, the women (Olivia Wilde, Alexandra Maria Lara) in their lives can only watch as both drivers risk death with every lap.\nEver since I developed an obsession with Formula 1, all the old F1 fans have been telling me to watch this movie. To start off, you don't have to be a Formula 1 fan to watch or like this movie at all. However, if you are one and still haven't checked Rush out, you definitely should.\nAs a sports movie, Rush is an incredibly crafted movie by Ron Howard and Peter Morgan that is very entertaining and focuses on the massive difference between the 2 main characters and how they develop throughout the movie. The cast, and especially Chris Hemsworth and Daniel BrÃ¼hl as they genuinely emotionally attach the audience to each of their respective characters in a very good way. Also due to their acting and to the brilliant screenplay, you can't really side with one character over the other as both their flows and good parts appear in this film. I just have a slight problem with the movie's pace at just minor instants but overall its a very fun ride.

It has been on my list since it was released, and I always postponed watching it even though I knew I would like it; It was a story that I liked when I watched it. You don't need to be familiar with Formula culture to love the movie. There is a natural and simple expression. Both actors did justice to their roles and showed quality. The ambition and passion of two different characters for the same goal is conveyed very successfully. The most striking line of the movie is; "Happiness is the biggest enemy. It weakens a person. It puts doubts in your mind. Suddenly you have something to lose. When I say happiness is the biggest enemy, it is too late, you have already lost."

I saw Tony Scott's "Days of Thunder" last night and disliked it for a variety of reasons, one of which being the lack of intensity and elaboration on the 'Rivalry' aspect.
"Rush" not only provides great suspense during the main races, but it also wonderfully captures the off-track enmity as well as latent respect between Lauda and Hunt, which ultimately pushes them to their absolute limits!
I don't follow Formula One religiously, nor do I claim to be an expert on the sport, but I do have tremendous regard for the drivers of Formula One who compete in it and defy death on a daily basis.
"Rush" provided some flashes of the same, and it was delightful to look at.

**Title: Rush (2013) - A Dynamic Blend of Speed, Rivalry, and Cinematic Excellence**
*In Ron Howard's 2013 film "Rush," the marriage of a compelling plot, stellar acting, and breathtaking cinematography creates an adrenaline-fueled masterpiece.*
**Plot:**
The film chronicles the intense Formula 1 rivalry between James Hunt and Niki Lauda, transcending the racetrack to explore the complexities of competition, friendship, and resilience. The plot's brilliance lies in its ability to balance the thrill of high-speed racing with the intimate portrayal of the characters' personal struggles. The pacing is expertly crafted, keeping the audience on the edge of their seats from start to finish.
**Acting:**
Chris Hemsworth's portrayal of the charismatic and reckless James Hunt is nothing short of captivating. He seamlessly captures Hunt's charm and vulnerability, making the audience both root for and question the character. Daniel BrÃ¼hl, on the other hand, delivers a powerhouse performance as the methodical and determined Niki Lauda. The chemistry between the two actors elevates the film, adding depth to the fierce competition at the core of the narrative.
**Cinematography:**
Anthony Dod Mantle's cinematography is a visual feast that propels the audience into the heart of the racing world. The dynamic camera work captures the speed and danger of Formula 1, creating a visceral experience for viewers. The film's visuals are not confined to the racetrack; they extend to the character-driven moments, allowing the audience to feel the emotional highs and lows alongside the protagonists.
In conclusion, "Rush" stands as a triumphant example of how a well-crafted plot, exceptional acting, and stunning cinematography can synergize to create a cinematic tour de force. Ron Howard's direction ensures that every twist and turn in both the characters' lives and the racecourse is a pulse-pounding journey for the audience. The result is a film that not only pays homage to the adrenaline rush of Formula 1 but also explores the human spirit in the face of rivalry and adversity.

A dive into the past for those who lived it, an epic and legendary duel sweetened just enough to make the story more exciting. The protagonists perfectly embody the two historical F1 characters Lauda and Hunt. For us European racing lovers it was like reliving that season, so dramatic but at the same time so exhilarating. I didn't feel like giving it a 10 just because, like all films that border on documentaries, they don't have that inventive component that gives it that extra point. But Howard really did a great job! I recommend it to all those who lived through that period as enthusiasts and will not be disappointed. They will love it!

I'm a fan of biopic and historical movies as well as sports movies, though I do find F1 (in its modern incarnation) pretty boring. With this in mind I was very curious how I would find this film as a lot or reviewers were saying how amazing it is (F1 fan or otherwise).
Overall I wasn't disappointed and think it's very well done. The design and photography really convey well the period and the actors all resemble the people they portray. The racing is very well shot and keeps you interested in the intense rivalry on the track as well as the personal differences off of it.
I would say it tries to put the characters too much into their box to keep the narrative of the film (Lauda being hyper geeky, unlikable, boring, intense etc, and Hunt the polar opposite). But otherwise a well shot movie with a good pace that didn't drag.
It's a rare type of film for this age so I'm happy to be educated as well as entertained by this overlooked sporting rivalry from the 1970's.
8/10.

Rush
This movie, for me, is very great and one of the best movies I have ever seen, and I am not really exaggerating, and I can't find anyone talking about the movie at all. I don't know how.
If it was on the level of directing from the oppressed director Roaword, the thing that caught my attention the most was his choice of actors, because after the movie I couldn't imagine anyone in their place playing these characters, and Chris Hemsworth was a really good choice and very appropriate. I couldn't imagine anyone in his place, and this is his best performance in his career, in my opinion, and the same. We are also talking about actor Daniel BrÃ¼hl and his wonderful performance as Niki Lauda
The soundtrack by the great Hans Zimmer was amazing, I can't forget it, and one of Hans Zimmer's greatest works
This is not the impressive cinematography
In my opinion, this movie is the greatest sports and racing movie
Also, and better than the Ford v Ferrari, although I liked the Ford v ferrari very much, but in my opinion, Rush is better.

First off you don't have to be a race fan to enjoy this - everything you need to know is very neatly encapsulated into this movie.
This has lots of action and the car races are thrilling but this is mostly about the two characters at the heart of this.
This is set in the 70s and a great deal of effort has been put into setting the period.
Seeing spectators precariously perched on billboards or almost wiped out by debris really absorbs you into the time.
The casting and acting is amazing - watching Chris and Daniel BrÃ¼hl spa on and off the track is very engaging.
Special mention to Alexandra Maria Lara who effortlessly injects a huge dose of emotion into what could have become an empty thrill ride.
I have this on Blu-ray and I would recommend watching the extras - they are short sharp documentaries on the story and making-of.
It was fascinating to see how this masterpiece was put together.

Best movie to watch for Racing enthiuistics, We at bizbuk all teal applaud.\nWhat a breath of fresh air... A brilliant film in every respect. I was lucky enough to this movie at a special preview and I cant tell you how great a film this is... At first you think its about racing cars, but its not it really does give you an insight into the human condition...\nThe rivalry between Hunt and Lauder is just played brilliantly... The race sequences are superb, really taking you back to the 70s... The heyday of this awesome sport. It shows the end of an era where the gentlemen drivers begin to give way to professional sportsmen and the end (in my opinion) of the excitement of the sport. It shows what a pale reflection today's F1 is of this once great sport, and what great characters we have lost...

There are a few slightly adult short scenes, no nudity but probably not for kids under 12 years old.
It's written well and is a charming movie The mentally challenged actors in the film speak well enough to easily understand. You might seem to get annoyed at them at the beginning but later you end up getting drawn to their characters and really cheering for them.
Woody Harrelson carries the film with ease with his excellent natural acting. What's not to like about him?
This movie is a feel good movie without being too corny and insulting to the audience. It's just a lot of fun and has a couple laugh out loud moments.
This is a good movie to watch with your spouse and teenagers.

The plot of the movie was enough of a turn-off as it seems degrading to use intellectually disabled people to make Woody Harrelson or anyone else look funny or entertaining. But I gave it a chance. The supporting actors were fantastic, even through working with a horrible screenplay. But Woody Harrelson comes out blazing as the same character he always plays in every movie and continues to play himself throughout the movie. The writing isn't great. So much is left out or forgotten. The sudden back and forth changes in his behavior and treatment of the members his basketball team are so ridiculous and unbelievable. One minute he's cutting them down, the next he's supposed to be believable in his (terribly bad acting) deep concern for them and their well-being when the players leave for the day. And the fact that a coach talks about himself getting hard-ons and his intellectually disabled team getting hard-ons is disgusting and reprehensible. Not to mention against the law. It's the worst movie of the year.

If you've ever spent time with adults with developmental or intellectual differences, maybe you'll enjoy this movie more than the critics who didn't get it. Old school, obvious jams? We'll, yeah! Basketball plus people who like familiar music. Some dialogue seems practiced? Yes, it can be common. People acting goofy when they're happy? That was my favourite part of workðŸ’“. I watch a lot of dark material, but this was buoyant and fun. I don't find it "forgettable", if nothing else because there aren't enough. *actual* diverse films with a diverse cast. Yes, there are plenty of "jerk out of water" films, but this was one a pleasure to watch. Plus, basketball! ðŸ˜€

This movie is so entertaining I can't get my eyes off the screen! The characters in this movie shows such emotions and it really makes me and my 96 years old bloodhound dog tear up! Throughout the course of the movie my bloodhound showed so many emotions such as excitement and sadness. The basketball team full of disabled people make it so life changing me myself and other who have watched this movie, this shows that anyone can do anything even if you have a severe case of Down syndrome. These are the reasons to why I rated this movie a 10/10, I would strongly encourage this movie to other around them.

I felt in the movie a great deal of truth and reality, woody Harrison is a great choice for a person who doesn't give a toss about anything then turn to become a person who actually cares and have feelings.
The director and cast didn't let the movie fall in the hole of sympathy instead gave us a solid and comforting scene with their acting and drama they give in a mix of comedy and light drama.
Have no idea whether those talented actors have performed before but sure they have presence and charisma.
The story may be a cliche in which the good intentions and well succeed eventually but the line and the casting have brought a different aspect to the movie.

Yes, it's everything you'd expect, which of course means there are no real surprises. But that's fine, you're not watching this movie to get challenged or to do too much thinking. This movie is all about the feels, and it delivers.
Of course, all the supporting cast are inspiring and you can tell that they had fun making this movie.
Of course, Woody nails his part as always.
But the female lead was my favorite character. She's beautiful, snarky, and has some great one liners.
Kudos to the writers for some very witty lines.
Kudos to the directors for creating a simple gameplan, drawing it up in practice, and nailing the execution.
Oh yeah, it also has Cheech!!!

This was an okay film. It was the typical sports film, down on their luck team that starts improving with the help of a new coach. It did have some funny moments and the cast did have good chemistry but overall the story is just very simple and predictable. It something to watch if you want to kill some time without having to worry about a convoluted plot.\nI didn't find it to be as heart warming as it could have been considering it had to do with kids with intellectual disabilities. It needed a lot more drama to make it worth a while.\nThe characters were somewhat developed and each one had their own personality but in the end the story was too cookie cutter.

This feel-good sports comedy is essentially the most generic thing you could imagine. Seriously, if you looked up "generic" in the dictionary, I'm pretty sure you'd find a picture of this film's poster right beside it. It's exactly what you expect it to be, and it's not even a notably strong version of that. It's really tempting to dock significant points from my score simply because of how uninventive and safe it is. However, and this is a big however, the flick is just good-natured, warm-hearted, solidly executed family fun that puts a smile on your face and keeps you engaged for its undeniably excessive runtime. It isn't deep or important or thematically rich or keenly observed, it's just a simple slice of uplifting fluff that knows what it needs to do and does it fairly well. 'Champions (2023)' is kept afloat by its strong ensemble cast (lead by a grumpy but easy-to-like Woody Harrelson) and its ability to be inclusive without being patronising, allowing its various disabled characters (portrayed by real disabled actors, something which should be a given but sadly isn't) to exist beyond their disabilities and emerge as rounded individuals with character arcs and memorable scenes that don't just reduce them to caricatures. It just gets right what most movies get wrong, which is worth praising even if it's actually the bare minimum a piece of media can do. It's hard not to be won over by it when all is said and done. Of course, it's far from fantastic. It comes with a lot of the same issues that plague its near-identical predecessors, and it's only ever so engaging. Still, it's undeniably enjoyable and sweet (without being particularly cloying), which is really all that it needs to be. If you want something familiar that will make you smile, this might just be the thing for you.

Hot headed basketball coach Marcus Marakovich loses his job after lashing out at his boss, instead of a prison sentence, he's ordered to do community service, and coach a basketball team, with learning disabilities.
This is a magical, funny, wonderful, heart warming movie, it's super funny, it's one that tugs at the heart strings, it's genuinely a film I didn't want to end.
It's an underdog story in a sense, it's a film that proves that anyone can do anything. Marcus is a bit of a dinosaur, it's his journey that makes this such an utterly engrossing watch.
The Friends..... I loved each and every one of them, what a fabulous, talented bunch of individuals they are, I hope I get to see more of these guys in many more films, brilliant all round.
Woody Harrelson, he's one of my all time favourites, he never disappoints, as always he's a joy, he's funny, he's natural, he's awesome.
Sublime. .....but I still don't understand curling.
10/10.

IN A NUTSHELL:
The heartwarming film was directed by Robert Farrelly, and written by Mark Rizzo, Javier Fesser, and David Marques.
This is the American remake of the 2018 Spanish film Campeones.
