There is no parts of this movie that didn't feel unnecessary or bloated. The meticulous attention to detail is at a level that every film maker can only hope to strive for. Every scene was important to the story, every character had a moment to shine, and every line was well thought out and executed to near perfection. Humphrey Bogart as Rick Blain is masterful in his role, allowing all the subtleties in his performance to make a huge impact in his character progression from a cynic to a 'sentimentalist'. Ingrid Bergman as Ilsa Lund brought a charisma and innocence to her role that can make just about anyone fall in love with her. Together their performances brought to life one of the greatest love stories in cinema history. I can go on and on about the excellent performances from Paul Henreid and Claude Rains etc., but I would just become a broken record at that point. I urge most people who have yet to see this movie to do themselves a favor and watch it ASAP! It is a must watch for all movie lovers.

(19420 Casablanca\nWAR DRAMA\nSarcastic dialogue in films was used earlier but never quite as effective as this film! If there is ever a film that reinvented how dialogue is spoken in films it would have to start with this one! I also respect how the film allows other actors of other ethnics to use their own actual language or their own foreign accents! Fictional plot starting with the Nazis takeover over France with stubborn bar owner Rick (Humphrey Bogart) mixing it up with old flame Elsie played by Ingrid Bergman unveiling his past! All performances are top notch- though the story could've been heightened at the end.

I don't suppose there's a lot to say about Casablanca. It's about as good as 1940s movies get, and holds up better than just about any other movie of its age. It's an iconic romance film, an engaging World War II movie made during the middle of World War II, and it's also really funny - it probably provides more laughs through its comedic relief than many comedies do in two hours (The "What watch?" "Ten watch." "Such much" exchange is one of the funniest little throwaway moments maybe ever).\nI remember always liking it, but finding the film surprisingly dense. It moves pretty quickly and has many characters, so it's the kind that's continually rewarding the more I return to it. I think this might've been the fifth time I watched it, and it was at the cinema, which made it even better (it was part 1 of a double feature with The Maltese Falcon second; that one I'm not quite as crazy about).\nHumphrey Bogart is legendary here, all the side characters are great, and it's all very well-paced and manages to successfully navigate a whole range of emotions. The ending is also perfect, as has probably been said before many times. All the praise that could be said has already been said, regarding the ending or any part of the film. Casablanca's is that kind of classic.

1942 the Nazi occupation of France. Refugees must take a long and torturous route Through Casa Blanca on their way to America; there "Everybody comes to Rick's." Rick's is a nightclub and a way station for a chance to get to America. Humphrey Bogart plays rick.
Here we also stay for a while to watch a drama unfold. There are overlapping stories. One of a young couple trying to get to America and the girl wondering if a girl should have to do something naughty was wondering what would happen if her husband, "a boy in many ways," would find out? A second-rate crook (Peter Lorre) obtains something of value at the expense of two German curriers. A Police Captain (Claude Rains) is shocked to find there is gambling going on at Rick's as he stuffs his pocket with his gambling earnings. Many other stories surround the main theme of a love triangle that started in Paris and now can mean so much to individuals or the effort for freedom.
Will the Nazis win their prize?
Will Capt. Renault get the young girl?
Will Rick get away with Ilsa?
This film has become quite a classic. There are many quotes and misquotes attributed to the film. You will find yourself kibitzing. One memorable scene for all is the showdown where the Germans are singing "Watch on the Rhine," and Yvonne (Madeleine LeBeau) overpowers them and herself with tears in her eyes singing the "La Marseillaise."
Cannot tell if it is Blu-ray or just the big screen but many details are suddenly visible. It does not add to the story, but it improves the viewing experience.

Casablanca is a romantic drama film directed by Late Michael Curtiz. The film stars Late Humphrey Bogart, Late Ingrid Bergman, Late Paul Henreid and Late Curt Bois.
A cynical expatriate American cafe owner struggles to decide whether or not to help his former lover and her fugitive husband escape the Nazis in French Morocco.
One of the best and probably one of the greatest film of the cinematic history which is also one of the most perfect film be it the plot, the acting, the music or the dialogue delivery. The film can be called as the complete package as the film has the perfect dose of romance, action, comedy and drama.
The plot of the film is good and the execution is superb. The film will keep you engrossed throughout with it's fast paced screenplay.
Acting in the film is superb and none of the character disappoints and even the character with smaller roles will impress you to the core.
The BGM and music is superb and supports the film very well and the climax of the film is probably the strongest and the most satisfying part of the film.
A must watch classic.

*I know what Nolan was trying to do, make a war film with as little cgi as possible. He wanted everything to be in front of the screen. We have to applaud him.
Execution wise, this movie is boring, slow, and even at less than 2 hours it feels 30 minutes too long.
*There is no story, no characters, and Dunkirk looks very very bare. Just watch that "Dunkirk-scene" from the movie "Atonement" and you will see that it is done way better in "Atonement."
*This movie is just boring but Nolan can't help but add his "magic" to it. He just can't make a straight forward film anymore, he has to make different timelines, he has to try to make everything "Memento-like." Not everything needs that back and forth thing, just make a straight up story.
5/10
Good directing and acting, but boring film, action scenes are boring, no story, no characters, and Nolan really needed to add come CGI for his Dunkirk films to show more troops. It just looks so bare.

Visually thrilling with amazing performances achieved through minimal dialogue, replaced instead with superb sound design, the scream of the enemy planes in the sky above the evacuating troops in particular stood out.
Characters and Structure
Dunkirk stars Harry Styles, Tom Hardy, Mark Rylance, Keneth Branagh, Fionn Whitehead and many others, the main cast is nearly entirely British.
The film tells the story firmly from the perspective of those British forces caught up in the disaster, the strafing of beaches and ships for example is filmed purely from the perspective of those under attack looking up at the planes. It never cuts so that we see the German pilots in their planes looking down on their targets nor do we see allied generals and politicians in a war room, spoon feeding the audience information. There are only two characters of seniority that really deliver any exposition about the wider context of what's unfolding and even their dialogue is brief. Nolan's approach during the beach and sea sequences is almost equivalent to a camera gliding along the surface through the events as they happen, this gives it a kind of rawness and realism which a more traditionally structured film couldn't do. The focus here is purely on a handful of characters and their life and death struggles, several times machine gun fires rips out from an unseen enemy, just like our characters we never get a good sense of the other side's perspective. The sequences of boats sinking filmed from inside their interiors for me surpasses Tiatnic (1997) in terms of its nightmarish power. There is an amazing close shot of a ship in the inky black of the night lit up by the red and orange of a fireball bursting out of it's hulk.
Harry Styles is sort of our main protagonist, right from the go he is running for his life. Without much dialogue what we learn about him comes mostly through watching his actions and expressions. He seems to be a perfectly ordinary young man caught up in a horror he couldn't have imagined. For all the ear-piercing noise and hellish fighting some of the most profound moments are the still quiet ones of soldiers stoically waiting their turn, characters sat gazing mournfully at the rough sea, perhaps too exhausted to do anything else, hoping tomorrow they will have better luck. It's a film about people just clinging on, quite literally in several sequences. It's lack of dialogue in favour of visually storytelling is on par with Mad Max Fury Road (2015) another Tom Hardy film.
War films can tend to fall into two different kinds of structures, there is the Sands of Iwo Jima/The Dambusters/American Snipper/Hacksaw Ridge kind which introduce you to your character/s, then in the 2nd act take you through their training before the 3rd act is the climactic battle you know has been coming. The other approach is to pretty much open and close the film in the middle of the war, Saving Private Ryan being such a film. Unlike a Oliver Stone movie this doesn't seem to be an anti war theme nor is it a jingoistic affair. Its simple matter of fact approach just tells the story.
Cinematography and Score
The score I loved and think it really suited this material. Hans Zimmer does an excellent job of combining traditional score with more ambient sound to create a grittier sounding music than you'd otherwise get.
The cinematography does a fine job balancing a filmetic look with at times a more documentary style. There wasn't any excessive colour grading that I could see, it all looked nicely balanced and natural. The film's colour pallet is of course made up of lots of sandy yellow, and khaki green, this fits nicely with the greyer colours of the evening with the blue sea and dark interiors of the ships. The tone of the film is sombre, at times desperate and naturally lacking in any humour or levity. The film was shot on location at Dunkirk at uses thousands of extras as well as real aircraft and ships to create it's impressive sequences. In an age which is increasingly going digital Nolan shot this on real film.
Other thoughts
Soldiers of all nationalities in our media and culture can often be portrayed purely in terms of projecting power, impossibly fierce, fearless killing machines. Dunkirk shows us exposed, vulnerable and sometimes frightened traumatised troops stuck in a dire desperate situation. The effect of this choice is characters feel real, not Hollywoodised movie characters who yell out witty dialogue to eachother between reloading or unstoppable baddass types who charge around implausibly dodging bullets while pumping lead into their enemies.
As you'd expect part of the story allows time for the civilian effort to rescue soldiers from Dunkirk. Mark Rylance is given a big part here. In a way the film does make you question whether in 2017 a similar response would follow from people in the UK if lots of other people found themselves needing help. If a sense of shared purpose and unity ever existed or such a thing as a national spirit then it's hard to believe it is just as alive and well today. The film also made me question a bit too whether people today would be hard enough to go through something like this. A delay on the M5 the other day had a woman on the news in hysterics over the fact her dogs in back were very hot. Half the audience at the cinema I'm afraid were overweight, mostly dressed in shorts and t-shirts, munching on their food as they watched the men on the screen struggling in the waves. A man in his 50s at the front of the cinema had even stripped down to his vest by the time the film was over, have we become so unhealthy now that sitting down in spacious cinema for two hours can make a person this hot?
In terms of negatives with the film, I don't have many. There's quite a lot of cutting between short sequences which I haven't noticed quite so much in Nolan's other work, it was a times a bit grading. I found a bit of the dialogue from Mark Rylance hard to follow, incidentally he probably has the most lines in the film. It's stated to this man lost his son into the third week of the war, not impossible but I'd be surprised considering 1939 was known as the Phoney War, a period of near total inactivity on the Western front.

I will admit my subject title is misleading.
However just how in the name of all that is good, can a website that facilitates people who adore cinema, be the arbiter of a 7.8 for Dunkirk (at time of writing) is frightening.
7.8 means its on par with Love Actually!!, I accept to each there own. But what next..... Love Actually is mildly entertaining in parts, but it's no masterpiece, of storytelling and narrative.
RT rating at least try's to strikes a balance of those that want to be entertained and those of us that want to be challenged and entertained.
Dunkirk is a 9 at least, and it's foolish to suggest otherwise.

This 2017 film Dunkirk was the best war movie I have ever seen as well being a world war 2 us GI reenactor / history buff. The uniforms of the soldier in the movie was very authentic and not farby. If you have not seen this yet it is the best movie to watch. It is a Great War drama to watch.
I hope all of y'all enjoy.

From the first seconds of the film, the viewer's attention is inextricably riveted to the screen. War tension, fear, pursuit, shooting. This is not a simple war film, with lots of shots, attacks and shouts of 'Hurray!' No, 'Dunkirk' is a film about the soul, about how war affects the human soul and about what people are capable of when there is no way out.
The idea of the plot unfolding from three different angles (land, water, air) is simply amazing and shows us the picture of military operations as broadly and realistically as possible. Thousands of soldiers who are exhausted and dream of only one thing: to return home. Enemy planes targeting ships filled with wounded and water claiming thousands of young lives.
Incredible cinematography by Hoyte Van Hoytema conveys human emotions and genuine anxiety. The body shakes from every explosion, from every shot. Close-ups, long shots - everything looked simply unsurpassed and alive.
This film is filled with emotions. There is very little text here, but a lot of action. Every movement of the facial muscles is filled with one or another emotion that simply cannot be conveyed in words.
Separately, it is worth noting Hans Zimmer and the mood his music gave to the film. Tension, hope, struggle, luck, anger, loss and victory. It was all amplified hundreds of times thanks to the magic of music.
What's really nice is that Nolan, along with famous actors (Kenneth Branagh, Cillian Murphy, Tom Hardy), put young guys at the head of the plot. But the film does not boast of big names, because it is not about individuals. The film tells the story of hundreds of thousands of soldiers and the steadfastness of the people. 'When the soldiers can't go home, the house comes after them' - and it's amazing. Each story told, which ultimately comes together, allows us to feel the tragedy and joy of this historical event.
'Dunkirk' is a quality film that captures the viewer's imagination and once again reminds us that war is evil.

Christopher Nolan's masterpiece Dunkirk, is one of the greatest war films ever crafted, period. The sheer amount of filmmaking artistry to relive the heart-rending moments of Operation Dynamo & the miracle of deliverance thereafter, deserves momentous praise, with its affecting themes conveyed through technical feats over embellishments. The film then honors the fact based stories, and what an achievement it was.
In Dunkirk, the esteemed filmmaker captures the perils of war flawlessly, with tantalizing frames that brims with genuine drama, whether from land, sea or air. These frames showcase the most harrowing moments of the escape from Dunkirk, staged to perfection, that the immense fear, hopelessness & desperation of his characters resounds to its audience, without the need for dialogue & expositions. Nolan as well, veers away from manufactured sentimentality & false heroics, guaranteeing a spectacle whose most compelling feats, are in the filmmaker's chosen details. Nolan's directorial marvel peaks further in the RAF Spitfires & German BF Fighters dogfights, whose insane camerawork ushers exhilarating point of views that renders the action as original and authentic as can be.
Apart from the fantastic direction, Dunkirk as well satiates the technical prestige Nolan films are known for. Hans Zimmer's sound design for instance, was impeccable, elevating the spectacles & tension of each riveting plot piece. The cinematography deserves mention as well, with striking images that serves to both dazzle & horrify. The use of practical effects over CGI offers transporting realism, an uncommon treat for war aficionados with a craving for factual representations.
Overall, Dunkirk is Nolan's honest-to-goodness tribute that showcases the realities of war, and its psychological consequences. It then redefines the genre that is so used to aesthetically pleasing heroes with personal dramas, emotional arcs, & orchestrated valorous deeds. In its place are the most suspenseful & immersive sequences, unafraid to depict its star studded characters as random & expendable, terrorized by the bleakness of the situation. My sole criticism on Dunkirk, is its unconventional, multiple timeline approach that was needless. Beyond that however, is pure artistry!

The movie has many major flaws like how there's no character development. Nobody is memorable and nothing really happens during the movie. There is no story nor plot and the only stakes are the other nameless characters die ye hat we have no attachment to. It's entertaining, sure, but when it stacks up to other films from Nolan it's really kind of a disappointment. I feel if they would've fleshed out the characters and had storys and trauma a bit more, it would've had a amazing chance to be up with some of his best works, because in theory Christopher Nolan making a World War II movie sounds amazing but I genuinely cannot tell you any of the characters names and just about nothing happens. I get the movie was trying to go for the message that even surviving in war is difficult, but it was pretty boring except for a few moments that do shine.\n5.4/10.

So just watch this movie and feeling like i am glad that i watch this movie. Movie scene ending starting overall such a great experience i have feel movie is showing that sirvivial is imp and understand in war is also imp nolan shows this perfectly the way he shoot the scene putting in suspense and many things i like the plot the twist the ending emotional ending the music the cinematography and editing colour grading have best i was watching this in English I don't understand but i feel the movie after understanding the movie i like the way they show overall you should try this movie in a life.

This movie was different from other war movies. Most war movies aren't as silent as this one. This movie had a lot less dialogue then what you would expect to see in a movie. The camera shots by Christopher Nolan were very well done, as it blew me away. When Harry Styles was brought in to act in this movie, I thought it was going to be a decent, not great acting by him. But he did fairly well for a pop singer. The amount of suspense you felt was unreal as you were hoping for something that might not happen. The score by Hans Zimmer was very well done as it kept you on the edge of your seat and it fit very well with this movie. If you like war movies, or like movies with mostly music, then this is the movie for you...

"Dunkirk" is an intense and thrilling war film that really keeps you on the edge of your seat. The movie tells the harrowing true story of the evacuation of Dunkirk during World War II. The non-linear narrative and immersive cinematography create a sense of urgency and tension throughout. The performances are solid, and the score by Hans Zimmer adds to the overall intensity. "Dunkirk" is a unique war film that focuses more on the experience and survival rather than traditional storytelling. It's definitely worth watching if you're into war movies or want to learn more about this historical event.

I feel like 1917 does a good job at showcasing the fighting during World War I. It shows the trenches as well troop morale during the war. I feel like people have more interest in the second world war than the first and there's way more WWII content out there than of WWI. This one is a piece of the WWI content out there I like to see more of. World War I is what the second one is based on and I'm surprised to not see it adapted into film as much as WWII has. I hope that it gets adapted more down the line. Side rant over, time to talk more about this film. It focuses on the British side of the war. It takes place near the end of the war, in the year 1917. There's a lot of action in it, way more action than talking. It's based on the stories told by writer-director Sam Mendez's grandfather, in which some creative liberties taken. Overall, a solid WWI film.

Only just seen this film at Christmas 2023, and I cant think of a more enjoyable film I've seen this year. Admittedly there's not a lot of competition at the moment. The main measure for me is, was I completely entertained the whole time? And thats a definitely yes.
A simple story really, not great depth, but that didn't matter, I really appreciated the way it was beautifully filmed and edited. The acting whilst fairly simple, was sparse but spot on. I also enjoyed the slower, walking scenes, building tension, adding realism.
Yes there are a few times, that, in reality, you know it's not logically correct but it's a film, depicting reality the best it can.
It's a film you can watch more than once, just watch it through again only looking at the camera angles and how it was filmed and cut.
Just a brilliant stand out film.

1917 is a harrowing journey directed by Sam Mendes that follows two British soldiers, Lance Corporals Blake (Dean-Charles Chapman) and Schofield (George MacKay) who are given a critical mission of delivering a message to a battalion of soldiers before their imminent advance on the German forces. From start to finish 1917 reinforces the central themes of the futility of war and its complete insouciance for human life. This is achieved by Chapman and MacKay's commendable performances as they convey both the physical and emotional toils that is war. The camaraderie resulting from their critical mission between the lead cast adds a poignant layer to the narrative of the film and reinforces the film's underlying themes of friendship and sacrifice.
While Chapman's and MacKay's performances should be noted, the deluge of side characters that the main cast encounters offer exceptional performances. Most notably Andrew Scott's ephemeral but highly diverting performance as Lieutenant Leslie. Andrew Scott embodies the pessimistic indifferent lieutenant so common amongst war films and supports the central theme of the film. As Lance Corporal Blake and Schofield prepare to embark upon their journey, Lieutenant Leslie sows doubt among them by way of sarcasm and prayer knowing quite possibly that the chances that Lance Corporal Blake and Schofield are killed are high.
A most notable aspect of 1917 is its tremendous use of its innovative and seamless single-shot technique made possible by cinematographer Roger Deakins. The seamless single-shot technique creates an immersive experience for the audience by having the film unfold in real time. This technique gravitates the audience towards the chaos and urgency that is so prevalent throughout the film. With moments of silence and intense action all in one shot, the technical marvel achieved with the film elevates it to a masterpiece in editing and camera work.
Along with the skillful single-shot technique, Thomas Newman -the film's music composer- blends wonderfully with Mendes' production design. Together, 1917 offers a rich atmospheric experience. Whether the main cast finds themselves navigating no man's land in moments of silence or eluding the gunfire and bombings of war, the music offered creates an emotional impact for the viewer and highlights and brutality of conflict throughout the film.
Overall, 1917 delivers a cinematic triumph reminiscent of many immersive war films such as Dunkirk (2017) and Saving Private Ryan (1998). 1917 will no doubt leave an indelible mark on the war film genre with its clever use of editing, camera work, and astounding performances while leaving the audience with thought-provoking questions on the futility of war and its brutality.

It's a narrowly focused war drama that takes place on April 6-7, 1917, in Northern France. It follows two British soldiers on an urgent mission to cancel an attack against the Germans six miles away, which is a trap.
General Erinmore (Colin Firth) orders Lance Corporal Thomas Blake (Dean-Charles Chapman) and Lance Corporal William Schofield (George MacKay) to carry a message to Colonel Mackenzie (Benedick Cumberbatch) canceling a planned attack by the 2nd Battalion on the Germans on the morning of April 7, as he has learned the Germans have set a trap. Thomas Blake is single and unmarried, with an older brother, Joseph (Richard Madden), in the 2nd Battalion. Will Schofield is older and more cynical, having survived the Battle of the Somme in late 1916.
"1917" follows the two men on their harrowing journey through No Man's Land and German lines in the next 24 hours, and we learn if the mission was successful. The cinematography is brilliant and very striking, as it appears in the film as two long takes for the entire movie. Chapman and MacKay are superb. The ending is beyond belief but probably necessary in most war movies.
Fortunately, there are no large battle scenes. We only see three or four actual deaths, but they are very personal. The results of war are graphically portrayed in the scenes from No Man's Land and at one river crossing. The intimate nature of "1917" makes it a compelling anti-war movie.

My original thought before watching 1917 was that this movie was going to be a boring, non-combact movie. I never expected to be standing on my feet waiting to see what happens next! The combat in this movie is insane and unlike many war movies out there, 1917 doesn't overload you with it. I would say through that this movie is not for anyone under the age of sixteen due to the fact of the amount of violence there is. Of course that is just my opinion. Another thing I loved about 1917 is the connections you get with the characters. With many movies you don't get that anymore. That is not the case with 1917!

The movie 1917 portrays the story of two soldiers who are forced to call off their attack on Germany during World War 1. From a technical standpoint, the film is impressive, featuring a smooth and continuous camera shot that follows the soldiers for 110 minutes. The cinematography is stunning and effectively captures the emotional turmoil of the soldiers and the brutality of war. The movie is immersive and evokes a sense of walking alongside the soldiers.\n1917 is incredibly suspenseful, and its intensity can be compared to many horror films. The set and music add to the war scenes and help to create a sense of the historical period. Although the performances of the two lead actors are decent, they could have been more nuanced. Their lack of detailed expressions cost them recognition at major award ceremonies.\nAlthough the plot is well-crafted, some of the sub-stories feel empty, and the dialogue in certain parts seems unnecessary. Despite these minor flaws, 1917 is a unique and valuable experience that accurately depicts the horrors of war.

I can truly say that this is a film masterpiece and I can also truly say that it's the best war movie I've ever seen. They way that Sam Mendes creates the no-cut type of movie is absolutely astonishing!\nI absolutely loved everything about this movie, by the stories I've heard and by the photos/videos I've seen I can say that this film is amazingly accurate, it's sad at the right bits, it shows the living conditions of life then and so much more. You can tell by this cinematic masterpiece that WW1 was a wicked and twisted war, filled with ups and downs (mostly downs) I liked how the director showcased how sad loosing a friend through battle really is, he shows us that even though you would really want to stay with your late friend but u cannot because u have a country to serve.\nI would highly recommend this to anyone who likes a good war movie.

Sam Mendes is a genius. He is amazing. Many scenes are extraordinary. Tomas Newman is a great composer but not for this kind of film. If the music was the appropriate this would have been the best war film ever. There are only a few war films I can compare with. All of them had a better score. All had well known actors but in this film acting is very good. Colours are fantastic and scenes all over the film are great with a senses of something different than we saw on other films. Camera is moving very good and clearness of the scenes is something you can notice even from the beginning of the film.

The way this movie is directed it makes you truly feel you are with these characters from beginning to end. So many great WW2 movies, but very few WW1 movies that capture the hell these men went through. The acting is phenomenal, gun shots, explosions, the path of their mission is simply incredible.\nI recommend after watching this film, you watch All Clear on the Western Front, then begin watching the Peaky Blinders series to truly understand what these men went through. All are masterpieces in their own way displaying the battlefield, as well as the similar mindset among all the men who fought.

Don't know why this movie is rated so high. Don't know what the director wanted to convey except that the character wanted to hand over some papers to stop the war.\nThere are continuous walks by the soldiers without any meaning. They reach an abandoned place and there's a cow and you find milk which is fresh. If it is abandoned who has milked the cow. But, then this guy takes milk to be given to some lady later who's job is only to tell the route to reach the final desintaion.\nThere are no plots.. nothing that is interesting except that the visuals are rich. Watched this movie only because this director had this movie American Beauty directed so well, which is connected so well.

Kingdom of Heaven is a great movie accurately telling the historical story of the crusades and the history of the Kingdom of Jerusalem. The dialogue fits a confident tone throughout the movie as well as one of greed and anger when the Templars are being shown. The sound design and scenery create a sense of reality. The battles show the desperation of both sides and how chaotic and gruesome medieval warfare was. Although these are definitely pluses, I would have liked to see more involvement with King Baldwin the 4th and how he has defended Jerusalem as well as his relationship with Salahudin. The Queen of Jerusalems story was breaking to see in the end when she fell into a depression instead of pushing through it and making some sort of impact on the kingdom.

This was absolutely an amazing film. The battles where so good and realistic especially the final battle for Jerusalem. I really love the strategic battle and the tension of who will win the battle. I also love the ending of it, it just has something with it that makes it so good. I also love the acting especially Orlando Bloom does great work in this movie. I really love how he plays balian and how his character evolves thru the movie. I also really love the negotiation scene between Saladin and Baldwin. Overall this movie is just great and really does a great job with the battles that take place.\n9/10.

Ridley Scott is good at scale, and here he shows just how good. A story about the crusades, Jerusalem, and the deep conflicts of the medieval world could be romanticised one sided and have no historical clarity, but here, real history and authenticity are given a chance, whilst of course mixing in a degree of dramatic licence and wistfulness. In many ways this is often visceral and balanced in its outlook, sweeping and often spectacular, but the film does have its issues; Orlando bloom is underwhelming in the lead, but just about gets by, and I found the dialogue a little unclear at times, but the theme, the dangers of religious fanaticism, are acutely observed, and the crusaders, a confused rabble with equally confused motives, are portrayed accurately, well balanced by a fair portrayal of the opposing Muslim forces. Generally there are no goodies and baddies. It's impressive, and well worth a look.

This film could have been better - but it's length, jump around and especially ridiculous portrayal of Christians in the film hurts it.
I thought Orlando Bloom acted well, Liam Neeson as a wise mentor is ALWAYS good. The film is shot beautifully, looks amazing and goes for the epic and works.
But the star in my eyes is the Leper King (Baldwin IV), his quotes, leadership and courage (and faith) overall is great to watch. Just watch extracts of that on youtube (even though hes not perfect).
But I just don't want to watch Christian bashing. The crusades weren't good for either side but Christians were FAR from the only bad guys. Ridley Scott should have done better.

"Kingdom of Heaven" is a sweeping historical epic that transports viewers to the heart of the Crusades with breathtaking visuals and a compelling narrative. The acting, led by Orlando Bloom, is engaging, as characters grapple with questions of honor and faith. The film editing keeps the story moving at an engaging pace, allowing the audience to become fully immersed in this tumultuous period. The music by Harry Gregson-Williams adds depth and emotion to the epic battles and personal struggles. The film's strength lies in its exploration of the futility of war, the clash of cultures, and the enduring pursuit of peace. While it may have moments of historical inaccuracy and a sprawling narrative, the cinematography captures the grandeur of the medieval world with stunning detail. With an 8/10 rating, "Kingdom of Heaven" is a captivating journey through a tumultuous era, offering both spectacle and substance for those who appreciate epic historical dramas.

"What is the value of Jerusalem? ; Nothing"
I think the hidden voice in the film was well heard by everyone; Killing and bloodshed caused by religion
I think the film was a good narrator for the storytelling of this period of time, although it was made from the perspective of the West, but there was still an insistence on sticking to what really happened in it, and there were additional quotes and sub-narratives in the main line of the historical narrative. Were not involved
In history, Saladin has been mentioned in a good way (apart from his religion). What we see in this movie is dignity.
Humanity and peaceful coexistence is a priority and is more important than religious differences. (Impossible wish)
The actors of this movie are all excellent, especially David Thewlis, although his dialogues were few, but his acting is always amazing, his voice tone is amazing.
This movie is definitely one of the greatest historical-religious movies, if you watch it carefully, it is not difficult to understand the events (the director's cut must be watched)
And again: "What is the value of Jerusalem? ; Nothing"

(2005) Kingdom Of Heaven\nHISTORICAL FANTASY\nAt the beginning of the film, nothing much happens as the Liam Neeson character as Godfrey de Ibelin, a leader of a small group of ailing crusaders stops by at a random village to stock up before continuing to move on again. But before he leaves, he sees what appears to be his only son Balian (Orlando Bloom) as the village blacksmith and offers him to join them. At first becomes reluctant until he became invoked with rage, killing one of the corrupted monks who stole and wore a necklace once around the neck of his just deceased wife who committed suicide and was supposed to be buried. After running away and eventually catching up with his father, his father becomes gravely injured when a sneak attack came in full circle when the village army were coming to retrieve Balian to stand trial for the murder of one of the so-called monks. The Liam Neeson character eventually dies but as a last resort knights his only son to take his place leaving and telling him that he has ownership of some land somewhere in Jerusalem and wants him to go there. This is where the real the movie starts and I become more tired just watching it! Ridley Scott whose last successful film was "Gladiator" solidifying actor Russell Crowe on the map was attempting to redo what he did for him to doing the same type of movie again but with Orlando Bloom is slow, boring and predictable. This film has been done already and it's called "Gladiator" why not make something different this time and that's why the film didn't perform well because it's the exact film but with a different setting, using different actors. To pin point the turning point why "Kingdom Of Heaven" is similar to "Gladiator" is that, although both characters could've chose the path to become great leaders in an uncorrupted and civilized way, they ended up turning it down, allowing the villains or the corrupted to take over resulting to thousands of undeserving needlessly deaths kind of make me hate the main protagonist even more.

First I should begin this review with saying that the version I watched was the extended directors cut- clocking in at a whooping 3 hours and 10 minutes.
I have to say that I enjoy pretty much all of the film, it didn't feel like it was dragging on or anything despite the long run-time. I didn't really feel anything was out of place and should have been removed.
The film itself portrays highly fictional events in a historical setting, and it does everything it sets out to achieve.
The characters are well fleshed out (even the minor ones), the music and atmosphere is great and the story acts as a great way to move the plot forward.
There are some cheesy parts of the movie but they don't spoil the overall experience.

See nothing but the Director's Cut, for the theatrical release, has been rendered unintelligible by studio hacks, who insisted that Director Scott cut the movie down for the short American attention span.\nLoosely based on history, Scott and Writer Moynihan's idealism and humanity are compelling themes woven into this uplifting storyline. The entire cast is superb, especially Liam Neeson, who is at his very best as Balian's Father. Other notable cast member performances are from Ghasson Massoud as Saladin, Brendon Gleason as Raynald of Chatillon, and the mesmerizing Eva Green as Sybilia.\nAs in The Gladiator, Scott's battle scenes are among the best ever portrayed in cinema.

I only wish to say that the casting of Syrian actor Ghassan Massoud for the role of Saladin was the absolute most impressive acting role in the movie
He has truly brought to life the character in the most convincing manner possible and that alone (as short and limited as it was) carried the movie for me and made it worth while.
All the cast was perfect in the movie but this one in particular stands out the most IMO.
In the case of a few others that were side or central characters, it seemed like over kill for the calibre of the actors that they were who portrayed these individuals.
Hope you enjoy this movie. It took massive effort to pull it off by the great Ridley Scott!

I have read the original source novel (which many of the critics seemed not to) and seen the original 1930 film and upon reflecting on my thoughts once the film had finished, I kind of wish I hadn't. Both the source novel and the original film convey the ultimate sense that war is futile, on all sides and its widely viewed as the ultimate ant-war story.
Where those sources excel is the unwavering simplicity of it all. The book focuses on the troops from the German infantry side but also on how troops were viewed back in Germany both before they went, during and when they came back. It is simple in its narrative but that by no means takes away the message it so skilfully conveys.
Where this adaptation excels, is the unsettling no holds barred approach. Unsettling score, bloody close ups, clarity of how futile it all is, and the palpable sense of unfairness for a whole generation.
It's not perfect though. For me, the last 40 minutes or so, whilst we'll made, tell us nothing. Veering away from the source text, what we actually get here is a message that has been conveyed many times in war before (that the powers in charge have no sympathy for their men) and it feels like it is trying to say more than it actually does.
I think whilst this is good, the source novel and original form are perfect. This is not.

Netflix's 2022 adaptation of "All Quiet on the Western Front" is a remarkable cinematic achievement that profoundly conveys the essence of Erich Maria Remarque's classic novel. The film is a harrowing depiction of the senselessness and inhumanity of war, brilliantly capturing the core message of the source material.
The film excels in illustrating the sheer absurdity and contradiction inherent in war. It portrays the experiences of young soldiers propelled into the chaos of conflict by ambitions they don't fully comprehend and a sense of duty that becomes increasingly meaningless. The narrative powerfully conveys the idea that war is like an unfathomable fever, illogical yet somehow inevitable.
One of the film's most striking aspects is its ability to communicate the horror and utter irrationality of war. It's a poignant exploration of the senselessness of conflict, particularly resonant in the current global climate. The film doesn't just tell a story of war; it immerses the viewer in the visceral reality of the front lines, making the horror and futility felt in a deeply personal way.
The adaptation is timely, serving as a stark reminder of the ongoing relevance of Remarque's message. The film's portrayal of the last hours of the war is particularly impactful, showing soldiers being led to slaughter even as the end of the conflict nears. It's a powerful commentary on the ongoing human cost of war, irrespective of its causes or conclusions.
"All Quiet on the Western Front" is a film that does more than depict historical events; it questions and challenges the very nature of war. It's a necessary and haunting reminder of war's devastating impact on the human spirit and the absurdity of conflict as a means of resolving disputes. This adaptation is a must-watch for its honest, brutal, and unflinching portrayal of one of humanity's greatest follies.

This film stands as a testament to the harrowing realities of war, transcending mere storytelling to offer a poignant portrayal of the complexities inherent in the human condition amidst conflict. At its core, the film (guided by an accomplished director) masterfully depicts the camaraderie, love, hatred, hubris, egotism, and the sheer stupidity that characterize the theater of war.
The camaraderie shared among soldiers in the trenches emerges as a central theme, providing a glimmer of humanity in the darkest of circumstances. The film vividly captures the deep bonds formed between soldiers, bound by a shared struggle and an understanding born of facing death together. Their solidarity becomes a lifeline, offering solace and support in the face of unimaginable horrors. Through the camaraderie, the film showcases the resilience of the human spirit amidst the turmoil of war, highlighting the strength found in unity.
Love, in its various forms, also finds its place amid the desolation of battle. The longing for normalcy and the enduring power of connections to loved ones left behind. These glimpses of love serve as a reminder of the profound loss experienced by those thrust into the maelstrom of conflict.
Hatred, both for the enemy and the war itself, permeates the narrative. The dehumanization of the enemy becomes a necessary coping mechanism. The internal conflict, torn between duty and revulsion for the senseless bloodshed, exposes the moral ambiguity inherent in warfare.
Hubris and egotism, prevalent not only among commanding officers but also within the ranks, underscore the folly and absurdity of war. The disillusionment experienced by the soldiers, witnessing the callousness and incompetence of their leaders, breeds a profound sense of cynicism. The film skillfully portrays the absurdity of commands issued from afar, divorced from the grim realities faced by those on the front lines, highlighting the tragic consequences of unchecked arrogance and ignorance.
Moreover, the film does not shy away from depicting the sheer stupidity and futility of war. The juxtaposition of the idealistic fervor that initially drives the young soldiers to enlist with the grim reality they face on the battlefield lays bare the tragic irony of conflict. The systematic destruction of a generation's hopes and dreams through the brutal machinery of war serves as a scathing indictment of the folly of human aggression.
All Quiet on the Western Front transcends a mere anti-war narrative but is a timeless commentary on the human condition itself. Its unflinching depiction of the horrors of war, coupled with the exploration of profound themes and the senseless nature of conflict, make our reality true.

One of the most incredible war stories on film, especially of World War I. It is visceral and intense. It is bloody and full of war horrors. If you want a real depiction of what war is like, and what it does to men in battle, this is a great example of that. World War I was exceptionally bloody based on the style of warfare and the means used to kill the enemy. This is from the German viewpoint. But equally, it shows the human cost. It shows the Germans, like everyone else that was in that theater, our regular people trying to survive from one minute to the next that is often a commonality amongst warriors. This does not get into the history behind the war, and why it started And so forth. This is a human, in the mud, ground level, experience. Nothing to do with generals, making grand decisions, except for a few moments here. It focuses on ground level troops in the infantry, where all the blood and guts are real. Just remake his right up there with the best of all war films.

A film of young men's dreams and illusions of glory and victory horribly crushed.\nThe film opens in freezing woodland with some foxes in their den, the cameras pans down from above the forest and we see it full of dead soldiers while gunfire rings out and the camera glides across the warzone. The film's battle sequences are expertly shot with all the smoke and cloud and rubble and shells landing around the characters. The film is largely told in one large flashback beginning in 1917 with several young friends eagerly joining the army full of high moral. I'm a bit surprised they were in such a state in 1917, 1914 yes but anyway. The production design is great in this film, the streets, the props, the costumes, you don't for a second question any of it. We also experience the battlefields, the ruined villages, the soaking trenches, the music is also brilliant with this hard industrial clanging sound to it as the soldiers march towards the front line. The film is extremely well acted, I saw it in it's original German language and I thought it was really well cast. As well as the experience of the soldiers we also follow a character in 1918 on a mission to bring the war to the end, his role is to negotiate an armistice and has just 3 days to agree to the French terms. The film lets us know this man is fully aware that the lives of all the soldiers still left in the Germany army may rest on his ability to negotiate a surrender. The film does a good job though at hinting at the power struggle taking place within Germany, the Kaiser and the army have effectively be running the country since the war began, and the army leadership is in no mood to compromise, a particularly callous and mad general seems to believe that just one more successful German attack will lead to a breakthrough and the end of the allied advance, even as his army collapses around him he orders more units to the front. The film gets great little details right too like the thinness of the men who are fighting by the end, the mud they often end up caked in when crawling through the trenches, the longing for good food and the thoughts of women and home dominate the lives of these men who are engaged in a fight to the death now. Not all details are perfect though, German soldiers didn't have to run into farms to steal food and then leg it before they were shot, German soldiers were expected and even encouraged to loot French farms and towns which fell under their control and the French were powerless to stop them. The details are horrific, the dead soldiers and horses littering the landscape, men are reduced to almost animal like instincts, thinking only of killing and eating. The wounded engage in a desperate struggle to survive, men carry comrades for miles only for them to die within minutes of safety, again and again we are reminded how futile it all is, some characters are killed unexpectedly, it's all some random. The film is very heavy handed in contrasting the filth and agony the lowly soldiers live with against the command HQ where the general staff live in luxury and comfort. We even get a scene of the general assured that a factory making riddle saddles will have a long and productive future. The not so subtle point is he's a man now with ideas about 50 years out of date. The truth though is both sides did their best to embrace new technology and innovations, no one solution could have ensured a quick victory and a low number of casualties once these mighty great industrial powers were engaged in all out war across such a vast front. The German general worked night and day for 4 years during the war with the weight of the country resting on his shoulders, when his son died in the fighting it broke him, nobody was spared the pain of the war, despite what this film tries to suggest. In this though the mad commander yet again orders his men to the front for one final attack despite everyone knowing it's madness. But then war is madness I suppose is its message.\nI do recommend this film as one of the best WWI films out there in terms of recreating the combat experience, this is a world without women or comfort or even humanity for these men, all that matters is the killing goes on.

This movie is overall a very good movie with good story telling and good cinematography while also showing the brutality of war which not a lot of movies show while the movie is a bit disturbing some times it has some moments which are very sad also it hold up pretty good for being a war movie though it can be a little bit unrealistic at times it has most of what a movie needs simply because the people who made the movie they knew what they were doing to make an anti war movie (also if you want to know what an anti war movie is it's basically where it show that war is bad and the lives lost are meaningless.

Personally for me this movie is a well deserved 10 star because of how great this movie was, it had a great plot, good start, good ending, good acting, and good characters. This is the best war movie that i have watched out of all of the ones i saw, it had really close calls and really panicky and tough situations and made you feel at danger and had you really paying attention and the timing for everything was perfect they pulled it off as best as they could, and you can tell that they put a lot of time and effort into this movie because they pulled off every scene perfectly and not sloppy. This movie was also very tragic because the main character had to see things that he wouldnt be able to recover from. Honestly this movie was a well deserved 10 star because of how everything just came together perfectly and the movie shocked you more and more even when you thought you saw enough. In all i could say that this movie was magnificent and well deserved 10 star no complaints, its a must watch!

I've never read Erich Maria Remarque's book, although I've previously seen Lewis Milestone's Academy Award-winning 1930 adaptation starring Lew Ayres. Now I've seen Edward Berger's Academy Award-winning "Im Westen nichts Neues" ("All Quiet on the Western Front" in English). Talk about a gut punch. This movie lays bare the saying "war is hell", making clear the futility of war (never mind that the Versailles Negotiations set the stage for World War II). One can see a contrast between the horrors of the battlefield and the generals' comfortable residences. This movie - or the 1930 version - could easily be a double-viewing with Stanley Kubrick's "Paths of Glory".\nAll in all, everyone should see this. With all the wars that have dominated the 21st century, movies like this one become all the more important.

Ill start off by saying ive read the book before watching this movie.
Ill start with being positive, As a war movie alone, its good,
but if you want to call this "adaptaion" i wont agree with you, the movie left out alot of good things that the book brought up like the ending scene that was totally different in the book. Also the book let us read the thoughts of paul and what hes going trough which is something you cant put out on a movie.
Ill say that this movie is more "inspired" then adapted
ill recommend you to read the book before watching the movie or even after it because its worth it.

This was a pretty average World War One movie to be honest. It was pretty depressing and monotone for the whole movie which was really good because thats the kind of atmosphere that should be set for a war movie. Was it an accurate depiction of the last charge? No but it was able to display the horrors and brutal uncompromising and harsh reality of trench warfare. But to be honest the whole movie kinda got a bit muddled in the middle of it and towards the end. Like a lot was going on but nothing was really happening. Also like I didn't like a single character in the whole film which is a bit annoying. 7/10.
